text: 1:34 Mins If you are looking for the best possible audio cable, look no further. I was sent a sample of this cable and I was very impressed by just how well made it is, which isn't easy for something as simple as an audio cable.First of all, I like the cable itself. Anker claims the cables can withstand over 10,000 bends.  While I can't do that kind of testing, I can say I was impressed by how well they handle bends.  It's clearly thicker than most, and almost magically withstands bends, and springs back into shape without any trace of a kink.Second, there are rubber grommets to provide added protection from bends at the ends, and the connectors are enclosed in metal, not plastic.The connections are gold plated, giving you the best possible connection.  The bottom line, this is a premium cable for people who want the best possible connection to their audio devices.

0:55 Mins This is a case for people who hate bulky cases.  While it doesn't provide protection from major drops, it does give you scratch protection on the back and side, which is great for people who carry their phones in their pocket or handbag.  I've never used protection on the front of my phones, but if you are concerned about something scratching the front glass, you should pick up some front protection sheets.I like the fact that the back is clear, because a lot of people go out of their way to pick a color for their iPhone, only to hide it under a case.I was sent a sample to review and I gave it 5 stars specifically because I think this is a great value.  You get 2 cases for a great price.  While I know there are other cases that offer more protection, I rated it based upon comparisons to other products in this price range.  I hope you found it helpful and I welcome your questions or comments.

From the minute I opened the package, I was impressed by this mouse.This mouse does an amazing job of going exactly where I want it to go, without any lag.  Since I use a massive 5K display, this is important to me.  Besides the great performance, I love the quality of the components and how it feels in my hand.  The cable is soft, strong and lightweight, with a rubbery silicone feel, it's not round, and not quite flat; it's sort of like linguine.  Even the USB connector is high end.  Their attention to detail is quite impressive.  Even the packaging impressed me.I'm often asked to evaluate technical products, so it's hard for me to be impressed by a mouse.  This one definitely impressed me.

I never considered the idea of eating seaweed as a snack, but when they sent me a sample to review, I didn't even know what to do with it, so I asked some friends what they knew about it and they told me they use Nori for sushi, but it's also a healthful snack.  Since I'm not a sushi eater, I focused on it's snacking potential and it turns out it's a great snack.For those who have never tried Nori, you're going to love it.

When I first brewed a sample of Dechunxian DongTing Green Spiral Spring Tea, I originally thought I didn't use enough, because it the water seemed pretty clear.  I used a simple tea ball to brew it and I basically filled one side.  After brewing, the tea leaves expanded an filled the entire ball.In spite of the light color, the tea itself was perfectly brewed, and as a green tea lover, I thoroughly enjoyed it.  It was just right, smooth, not too strong, and it left no aftertaste.After enjoying my first cup, I added more water and re-used the same leaves and the taste was absolutely wonderful.  Naturally it was lighter, but for some people, the second brew is the preferred way to enjoy it.  If you've never tried brewing green tea like that, you should give it a try.  In fact, some green tea companies make it a point to recommend people fill their cup and let it sit for about 20-30 seconds, then discard the water and re-fill it.  When you brew tea like this, that short batch of water takes away the edge and leaves behind the plenty of flavor.

1:16 Mins When I was asked to review this speaker, I immediately tried listening to it the way I would use it if I was on the beach, which means I needed to hear how good it sounded even if it wasn't pointing directly at me.  What I found was that the sound quality was so good, it sounded almost identical regardless of what direction it was pointed.This means that if you take it with you to the beach, you can hang it on your bag or your chair and let it swing around and the sound will be just as good no matter where you are sitting.I've tested a few other waterproof speakers in the past, but I have to say this one had sound that was far better than any I've heard before. In spite of it's size, there is a lot of depth and bass.It's easy to use, and doesn't require any special codes to pair it with your phone.

2:00 Mins If you love the great outdoors, you NEED one of these to protect your stuff.  I've been kayaking for years and I wouldn't even think of getting on the water without one.  In fact, I wouldn't even go near the beach without one because it not only protects your stuff from water, but from dirt and sand.If you're not familiar with dry bags, they are rubber coated bags that you seal by rolling down the top and clipping the sides together.  Once you clip in the sides, the bags are completely waterproof and submersible.I was sent a sample to review and I found this dry bag is super strong, and has plenty of space for cameras and other items you want to keep dry.

1:27 Mins Whenever I'm asked to review a product designed to plug into the lightning port on the bottom of an iOS device like an iPhone or iPad, the first thing I do is look for Apple certification.  I simply won't endorse or use any device without that certification.The reason I say this is because I've bought a few non-certified cables in the past and they cause my devices to throw a message on the screen that says I'm using an unauthorized device.  According to Apple, any uncertified cable can potentially harm your device or void any chance for warranty support.  Apple includes a unique serial number on a chip inside every cable and your device will know if it's certified.So, after I checked for the certification, the next thing I did was plug it in... and make sure the cable was recognized.  It worked perfectly!In addition to checking that the cable was certified and recognized, the final thing I did was bend and twist it around.  I like the feel.  It has a nice rubbery texture and extra reinforcements on both ends.  When compared to the original, these cables seem a bit thicker and the connector is much bigger and presumably, stronger.I can easily recommend this cable to anyone who is looking for a high quality, reinforced cable for their iOS devices.

I'll be honest right now and admit that I've been using Photoshop for years.  When I first started, I found it very hard to figure out how to accomplish tasks--the way it worked seemed illogical.  Now that I'm happy with the Photoshop interface I've switched to PaintShop Pro, and I find it frustrating.  There's a good chance that it's because I'm so used to Photoshop.  It may be that once I get better at using PaintShop, I'll find it to be as powerful and useful as Photoshop.  For now, somehow, everything I edit looks like a small child attacked it with crayons.PaintShop is often slow and cranky, and sometimes mouse pointer movement is not smooth across the screen.  On the whole, though, it seems to be slightly more nimble than Photoshop.Magic Move is pretty clever, and I wish I had a greater need for it.  PaintShop also seems to handle text a lot better than Photoshop.  Batch processing and scripts are available, and for me they're essential.  I'll need to dig into them a bit more deeply and write some more complicated scripts to see how well this feature works.Since I'm working with lenses that have some pretty standard flaws, I've found Lens Correction to be a help.  I don't have it tuned perfectly yet, but I'm hopeful that I'll get there eventually.As I learn and adjust, I may be able to use this the way I need to.  For the moment, though, every time I open PaintShop I find myself wishing for Photoshop.  The price makes PaintShop much more accessible, and there's no subscription, so this will be my choice whether it turns out to be as powerful as I need it to be or not.

When I think of seaweed snacks I think of seaweed, not a tapioca starch, canola oil, and brown rice chip with a thin coating of seaweed on one side.  So this seems like a bit of a compromise to me.  These hold up better to humidity than plain seaweed snacks, at least.To me the flavor is sweet and a little spicy, but I like spicy foods.  To someone who is sensitive to spicy heat, this might be more powerful than I think.The texture is fun, very crispy and easy to eat.  It seems like when I first opened the package, I ate about 3/4 of it without even being aware of how much I had eaten.  (There are two servings per package.)  Even with the rice chips, these are not very filling.So they're crunchy, sweet, and a little spicy.  They're really more rice and tapioca starch than seaweed.  I like them and I wouldn't turn them down, but I probably won't go out of my way to find them again.  My first choice would be real seaweed snacks.

Since this arrived over the summer, my first thought was "*gasp* WARM".  I'm pretty sure it'll be a good jacket for all but the coldest of days.The sherpa lining is only on the front and back of the shirt.  The sleeves have a black nylon lightly filled lining.  This makes it much easier to put the shirt on or take it off without getting hung up on the fuzzy lining.I've washed it on cold and lightly dried it on the lowest setting, pulling it out to hang while still damp.  It shrunk a little, but it wasn't bad.  If anything, it's more comfortable.  Judging from the other reviews it might shrink more if I let it dry completely, but this size is exactly right so I'm going to keep hanging it to dry.A long time ago I had a denim jacket that was broken in perfectly.  (Curse you, battery acid!)  I've never had anything nearly that comfortable since then, but this comes close.  I'll update my review if this disappoints over time, but right now I'm really looking forward to wearing this regularly.

I haven't seen some of these flavors locally (and a couple I've seen but haven't tried.)  These are full-size candies, slightly more than two ounces per package.  At the current price they're far cheaper than anything I can get locally.Looking at the reviews, it looks like the flavor mix wasn't right a couple of years ago, but for the moment it matches the product description: 8 packs of Original Skittles, 4 packs of Wild Berry Skittles, 3 packs of Tropical Skittles, 3 packs of Sour Skittles, 6 packs of Original Starburst, 3 packs of Tropical Starburst and 3 packs of Starburst FaveReds.The tropical flavors were a surprise for me, and sometimes the colors don't match expectations.  I'm getting used to the idea of checking the label to see if the green is lime or apple, or something else that's unexpected.  The Wild Berry Skittles are probably my favorites overall.  Sour Skittles are unpleasantly like a punch in the jaw, and worst of all, there are only three packages.I'm not keeping this amount of candy in my house again, but if I needed it for a special event or fundraising, this might be the way to go if the price holds.  It's a good mix that might have something for everyone if they like strong fruity candy, and it's a way to get flavors that might be hard to find locally.  Just be sure your will power is better than ours.

These buttons are the best mistake that's happened to me in a long time.  Some time ago I spotted these 10mm buttons being sold by Amazon as an open box returned item.  I grabbed them.I'm guessing they were returned because they were too big for the buyer.  I didn't get 10mm buttons, I got these 13mm Elan Beads buttons.  And I love them.  Here's what I said about them at the time:"The first impression that I got from these buttons was sometimes blue, sometimes green, and always a fair amount of sparkle from every angle. I bought these to use as focal closures on jewelry pieces and it was a good choice. They are definitely interesting enough to hold their own in a piece of jewelry."The silver colored back is securely attached, and the buttons seem well made."Best of all, the seller found my positive review and offered to fix the mistake.So: lovely, bright buttons.  Very well made.  And a very responsive seller.  I want to give six stars on this review.

I live in a place where the temperature fluctuates between hot and hotter, so I always have a bottle of water with me.  I've tried just about every kind of water bottle there is in the hope of keeping the water cold.  Insulated containers don't stand up to the heat, so lately I've been moving toward single-walled containers that can be frozen.  This bottle seemed perfect.It's better than that.  I fill it about halfway and put it in the freezer, tilted so it's diagonal.  When it's frozen I top it off with cold water and transport it in a small lunch-sized cooler with ice packs.  This keeps the water much colder than any other container I've used.  When it's empty I can roll it up and stuff it into my bag.  That's more convenient than walking around with a bulky empty container.Best of all, today I brought it to our weekly card game.  No one had ever seen something like this wobbly, floppy, droopy water bottle.  When I poked the top half and it flopped over there was total silence at the table.  Then someone said "Your water bottle needs a little blue pill."  The jokes continued for the rest of the night.  +1 star just for keeping us laughing all night.The one warning I will give is that if you're not careful, it's easy to gulp some air with your water until you get used to drinking from this bottle.  And because it really requires two hands to support the whole thing, I use a different bottle in the car while I'm driving.The instructions tell you to fill it with boiling water before use, and that worked with no problems.  I was wondering if it would damage the plastic lid, but it was fine.  It's an easy way of cleaning something that probably won't do well in the dishwasher.The instructions also warn "Do not put high concentrations of acid and alkali and other strong corrosive substances in the bottle".  Orange juice is probably not a good idea.So, two hands required, and no acidic juices or other drinks.  For me it's different than anything else I've used and I gulped some air until I got used to it.  But I can clean it with boiling water and I can freeze it to take ice cold water with me, and that's what I really needed.  It doesn't take much space to store it, and the humor value is unlimited.  Love it.Sample received.

I've been using this for things that are only needed once or twice a week, not daily.  Most of the time it sits on the shelf, and when I need to grab it I have no trouble finding it among all the blue and black binders.  For high visibility, this is it.But I'm not impressed with the durability, which surprises me in a Five Star item.  The cover is not bad--one very flexible plastic layer.  I bend it back so I can fold it over and write on the desk instead of the divider, and so far the cover hasn't been damaged by this.  But the rings (which are round, not D-rings,) are not great quality.  I've already bent one so that it doesn't close properly.  Clearly I have arms of steel.I'm not sure if this would last for a whole school year, but if there are hallway games of binder football I'd doubt it.  For the kid who takes good care of their binder (I've heard they exist) this would probably work well.

I've got pretty much the same stress as everyone else, and I'm really not moody... more like one mood, all the time.  I've been taking rhodiola root for a couple of weeks and so far I haven't noticed any change.According to Sloan Kettering, rhodiola "improve(s) physical and mental performance by reducing fatigue caused by stress".  For me there have been no improvements, but no side effects, either.  Since I use Natures Bounty for other things and have never had a problem with them, I'm going to guess that the problem isn't these capsules, the problem is probably me.Now that I'm digging a bit deeper, I see that rhodiola may cause problems with other medications, and I probably should have talked to my doctor before starting it.  That would be my advice to anyone else as well.  (No, not MY doctor, he's already too busy.)But it may help with stress and fatigue, and who doesn't have those?  It might be worth a try with a doctor's approval.

I've got a couple of lights on timers.  At first it was so that my home looked lived-in while I traveled, but I left it that way because because having lights turned off is a good way to remind me to stop what I'm working on and go to bed.  This timer is another reminder for me, and it controls a light that's visible from the street.It was fairly easy to install, though it is kind of large and is a little difficult to stuff into the light switch box.  Basic tools are needed, like a flat screwdriver and a selection of cuss words.  Four wire nuts are included.  The decorator-style faceplate is not included.Once it was installed I used the manual switch for a few days until I got around to programming it the way I wanted it.  It was a little hard to see, which made programming it a bit frustrating, but with the battery backup I hope I won't have to think about it again.I like the random feature, which hopefully would be a little more convincing if someone is watching the house to see if it's empty.It was fairly easy to install, somewhat annoying to program, and is working the way I want.  So far, so good.

I ordered two of these, and I'll admit they're better than I expected, though I wasn't expecting much.  Each individual order contained a random mix of sizes and colors and there wasn't much that worked well together, but buying two gave me a lot more options.  Each order will vary, but to give an idea this is what was in my two orders (colors are my best guess):1 10mm strand of basic pearl color (very heavy weight)8mm:1 white1 pearl1 champagne1 funky goldish-tan1 light pink1 peach1 rose1 sage green1 dark blue-green6mm:1 light brown1 red1 grey1 black1 Wedgwood-ish blue1 purple4mm:1 pearl1 (kind of) tan1 light green1 purpleThe 6mm blue are a really lovely color, and I wish I could get more of just those.  Oddly, I've got a lot of colors here that seem close (several flavors of very light brown/champagne, for example) but they've got green or red or other undertones that make them seem to clash with each other.  The greens also don't work with each other, but work with the various tan beads.  I'll have to leave them mixed together and see what jumps out at me over time.The thing that surprises me is that these were obviously dipped or sprayed in color while on the strand.  Some strands are fairly tight and didn't leave the beads much room to move, and those beads are stuck together.  Moving them around breaks them up (and covers the table with iridescent colored dust.) Yet color coverage is excellent, all the way around the bead, even where they've stuck to each other and the strand.So lots of different colors and sizes, not chosen for any particular color harmony.  It's a lot of beads and would work well for a craft group.  These will keep me busy for a while.

I want very much to like this necklace, and there are some things to like about it.  But I have some problems with it.In the box, or if I hold it up to the light, or if it happens to be positioned properly when I wear it, the pendant catches the light very well.  It sparkles in even the darkest room.  On someone who is very slim, this would probably look well all the time.On me, though, the pendant likes to turn.  It never twists to the back, which is nice, but it does often rotate so that the face of the pendant is pointing down and someone standing in front of me has a view of the top of the pendant.  It's not that the chain is too short--if I pull the chain to tighten it the face of the pendant rotates up.  I don't know why it does this and I haven't found a fix for it yet.The chain seems very flimsy and arrived pre-tangled in the box.  It took a long time and serious magnification to get the knot out so I could put the necklace on.  If this will be a gift, it might be a good idea to check the chain before wrapping the box.The lobster clasp is small and difficult to work with, and catches my hair.  The loop actually looks like a stamped piece, and between the thickness of the piece and the small size of the hole it is very difficult to get it on to the clasp.The necklace comes in a very nice gift box: Amazon's standard black box with blue lining.  I'm not sure I'd give this necklace as a gift, but I know I wouldn't hesitate to give a gift in this gift box.I've got very mixed feelings about this necklace.  When it rests properly it looks wonderful, but getting it on is difficult and looking in the mirror to see that it is facing downwards is frustrating.  It's not large, but it catches the light well.  It's a subtle and lovely detail for someone with very nimble fingers or a helping hand.

I'm not sure what Smart Target Benzoyl Peroxide Delivery Technology is, but to judge by the painful red lump on my cheek, apparently my skin can defeat it.Actually, for me, this kind of breakout is new.  My skin is usually in the "annoying and eye-catching" range, but I never have painful breakouts.  Until I started using this--now I have several.I can't explain why.  The active ingredient is benzoyl peroxide 2.5%, and this is something I've used on and off for years.  It can't be a reaction to that.  In any case, I'll be going back to another product with benzoyl peroxide, so I'll know more in a couple of weeks or so.If this worked for me I'd have nothing else to complain about.  The lotion feels soft and smooth, it applies evenly without feeling unpleasant or greasy, and it leaves a matte finish that doesn't affect my makeup.  There is a slight odor, but it is not strong enough to bother me and it fades quickly.While I'm testing a sample, this product is expensive enough that I'd have tried to return it if I had bought this and gotten these results.  I know it works for some people and in that case it may be worth the investment.  But now that I've tried it, I wish I had stayed with my regular benzoyl peroxide product.

Don't get me wrong, I love and miss my grandmother very much.  But while I'd give anything for another afternoon with her in the kitchen, I don't want her blue hair, and I don't want to smell like all the moisturizers she used to apply.  And this fragrance remains for a long time.The lotion itself is wonderful, but I'm not sure if there's any benefit once I try to wash the fragrance off.  It absorbs very quickly and doesn't feel greasy, so maybe there is some benefit.  I finally gave up and applied it to my legs so that I could leave it on and see if there's any visible change.  My legs are very dry, and after a couple of weeks of this moisturizer they seem just as dry and flaky.  My skin looks and feels good for a while after applying this, but within a couple of hours the dryness is back.  (But the odor lingers on...)This might be good for someone who doesn't mind fragrances, but the minimal short-term improvement is not worth the smell to me.

Original review 06/19/2015: The first impression that I got from these buttons was sometimes blue, sometimes green, and always a fair amount of sparkle from every angle.  I bought these to use as focal closures on jewelry pieces and it was a good choice.  They are definitely interesting enough to hold their own in a piece of jewelry.The color in the photo is a good match, but the shape of the buttons is different.  I received 15mm buttons, not 10mm as described.  Since I'm building around them this isn't a problem for me, but it might be tough for someone who needs to fit these in a buttonhole.(Edit: description removed.  Looks like I received these buttons.  And it looks like I should calibrate my caliper--they're 13mm.)The silver colored back is securely attached, and the buttons seem well made.I like them, but I was really interested in the color.  If you need 10mm buttons and you order these, you might want to check them when they arrive to be sure they fit.UPDATE 09/18/2015: The seller has responded.  (Wow!)  Human error, she shipped the wrong buttons.  I can see how it happened.  It took me a long time to figure out I had the wrong buttons--they're very similar.  But I'm updating my review because these things don't happen often, and now I know that Liz is happy to fix it if needed.Best of all I now have the seller's storefront, so I'll be able to get more of the wrong buttons when I need them, along with some amazing beads.  Liz is here:http://smile.amazon.com/s/?me=A1M4PZWD73IZDB

Every now and then I like to find new ways to review old material I already know.  (Ok, I *have* to, or I'll start forgetting details.)This would be a great companion to a basic anatomy textbook, probably at the high school level.  It would also be good for younger kids who are ready to start studying anatomy on their own or with help.  The drawings are pretty clear and the text is easy to understand.  Because the human body is not flat, several structures that might be difficult to understand with only one view are visible from several angles, sometimes including cross sections or range of motion.For me, I find that putting colored pencil to paper and filling in the drawings makes details clearer and easier to remember.  Glancing at an image in a textbook is one thing, but actually filling in a drawing forces me to consider the shape I'm working with, to pay attention to where one bone ends and another begins, and to think about how things like joints actually work.I think that if I had worked with books like this the first time I took classes on this subject, I might have understood the mechanics of how the body works a little better before getting into the field and seeing damaged bodies, not working.This isn't a primary anatomy textbook.  But it is a great basic workbook, and for me the act of coloring forces me to slow down and learn well.  And it's an enjoyable refresher if you haven't picked up a textbook in a few years.

I got 40 out of 50 boxes.  The order is short by 10 boxes.  All things considered, this is actually a good thing.At a glance they look shiny and promising.  Some of them are so badly made that the base and lid don't fit well together, and once opened it's a pain to force them closed.  But that's not the biggest problem.Each box had a large sticker with bar code, ASIN, and item title.  Some stickers were on the bottom of the box, some were on the top.  Some of the stickers come off without damaging the silver foil, some rip it right off.  Sticky residue is left where the stickers were.It's a waste of time to remove these stickers and too many boxes have been damaged already.  I will never make this mistake again.

Back when I was a teenager, I had a friend who burned incense in her room constantly.  I'm sure it was just because she liked the smell.  I had completely forgotten about that... until I opened this bag of beads.These beads smelled powerfully of sandalwood, I think, strong enough to make someone else in this house cough.  While my friend liked the scent, I don't want to try to sell jewelry that smells like it.  But they're beads, I'll just wash them.That didn't get rid of the smell.  So I soaked them in mild soapy water overnight.  That didn't work either.They've been airing out now for about a week, and the scent has faded a bit.  It will probably take at least another week to get rid of it completely.These are very interesting beads, with eye catching colors and seemingly random lines.  Slightly less than half are drilled badly, at an odd angle.  The rest are fine.  But I'd rather not buy beads and then have to air them out for a couple of weeks to get rid of an odor.

Rodents aren't usually a problem in my garage in June.  I'll see more activity when it gets colder.  Right now I can't really say if these packs will repel critters that are having way more fun outside at the moment.But I can still give them a try and see how they smell, and so that's what I'm doing.  I've had one on the garage floor for a week, and even though the garage is fairly large, one pack is enough to make the whole area smell strongly of peppermint.  The pouches are filled with corn cob bits soaked with peppermint oil, and yet the oil hasn't stained the unfinished floor.Usually when the garage door is open a frog or an anole or some other small thing will wander in, but I haven't seen that happen this week.  Could be coincidence; I'll have a better idea over time.I wrote the date on the pouch so I'll have a good idea of how long it will last.  So far even the south Florida heat and humidity don't seem to be knocking the scent down very much.I'll get a better idea of how well these repel rodents when the weather starts to turn a little cooler.  For now, the garage smells of mint, the frogs seem to be staying outside, and the floor is not stained from the peppermint oil.  If these packs disappoint I'll update this review, but so far, so good.
There I was, quietly concentrating on a puzzle, sound and music off, while family slept next to me.  And then the ad started, FULL BLAST.I am in deep yogurt.  Uninstalled.

I'm giving a five star rating with some hesitation, because the zippers on these containers seems a little flimsy.  But so far I haven't been able to break them by beating up on them a bit, so until they fail I'm going to assume they're good.  If I do have problems with these I'll update my review.Actually, the whole thing seems flimsy, but that's not a bad thing.  They're flexible enough to give a little on the overstuffed side, and to collapse on the thinner end.  I haven't been able to tear the paper, and the plastic top is sturdy enough.  I've got thin blankets and a couple of pillows in these along with a few sprigs of peppermint, and they stored easily under the bed for the summer.  Since they won't be used daily the zippers probably won't be a problem.  There's no real way for dust to get in.  And the plastic top makes it easy to see which of the two containers I need.I thought about turning them upside down to make it easier to slide these under the bed, but it wasn't necessary.  The paper bottom slid across the carpet easily.When the weather gets colder I might take out the blankets and put summer clothes in these, or I might fold them up and store them.  They fold down to a small, thin square.I look back on the dust covers and storage containers that used to be in my grandmother's attic, holding old clothes and uniforms and moth balls.  They were thick and heavy duty, and they took no abuse at all.  They might get opened twice a year for the winter coats, but beyond that all that heavy duty plastic was unnecessary.  I think that these will keep dust out without taking up much space, which is exactly what I needed.

In my house, dressing usually comes in two flavors: take it or leave it.  I dress the salad in the kitchen with whatever works with the meal, and if you don't like it you can see if there's something in the fridge you want.  So having special servers and a caddy to carry them suggests way more effort than I usually put into a salad.But hey, maybe variety is wanted.  Maybe yesterday's dressing was so good that I should have made extra.  Maybe today's is so bad that yesterday's seems wonderful by comparison.  Now I've got bottles to store those dressings in.I look at this set and I see the cute side and the practical side.  I'm a grouch and don't care about the cute side, so I'll get that out of the way first.In case ounces and milliliters are not your thing, the other side of the bottles offer measurements of "full of deliciousness", "half way thru the good stuff", and "sadly almost gone".  Clearly the Zak folks are optimists even when the bottle is half empty.This isn't actually a proper set, since the caddy and the bottles each come in their own box.  Expect to have three boxes to wrap if you're giving this as a gift.  But it does look nifty together, though with four spots in the caddy you might want to give two more bottles to fill it.  Green (or actually kiwi) is available if you want to mix up colors.  There are also spice mills if you really want to go crazy, or a two section caddy if you want to keep the four section caddy for something else.  For me, if I wanted to give this as a gift, I'd get two bottles and a two section caddy.  It's significantly cheaper, comes in the same number of boxes, and there are no worries about balancing the load so it doesn't spill on the way to the table.On the practical side, I'm keeping the caddy for something else.  Even I can manage two bottles at once, and the caddy comes with a lid and four sections that would work well for olives or assorted pickled things or extra salad stuff like croutons or nuts.The description says "removable handle makes for easy use once on the table", but the instructions say something different: "Keep handle fully assembled; do not take apart once assembled."  I assume the "removable handle" is actually the whole handle assembly, including the base plate that goes under the caddy.  But the base plate can be cranky to remove from the caddy, and I've jostled the caddy pretty well trying to get the base plate off of it.  If I've got food in the caddy, that seems like a great way to spill.  And I don't have a whole lot of room for the whole assembled thing in my kitchen.  So I'm using the caddy without the handle.The bottles work really well, though "Zesty" (the one with the push button) requires quite a bit of force to use it.  I see one other reviewer is having trouble with it, and I suspect anyone with arthritis or other hand problems will be frustrated by it.  This might not be the best gift for older grandparents.  "Saucy", with its flip top, is much easier to use.  Both pour well, with no drips.  Both have an o-ring on the neck of the bottle above the threads.  So far the bottles don't leak, even when filled with "Runny" vinegar.By me this is an interesting design that solves problems I didn't really have.  I like the bottles and will start making enough salad dressing to store, so that I don't have to go through the trouble every time.  The caddy will probably live in the pantry until I go to a party and bring food, and even then because the lid is not tight the foods will be transported in their own containers and moved to the caddy when I get there.  The handle is quite large and has to stay assembled once you put it together.  The box doesn't say anything about it, but the product page says this is dishwasher safe, so that's a plus.  And the caddy comes apart into three pieces (plus the handle) for easy cleaning.  I like the bottles, but the whole set strikes me as a bit more fussy than I like.

As my mother was dying, I wrote a detailed journal.  As Scott Simon's mother was dying, he wrote tweets.  I think his method is much better than mine.The tweets are woven into the book, wrapped around memories and offering slightly disconnected punch lines.  It's unusual, but somehow it makes me feel like a fly on a wall, as though I'm observing what's happening in real time.My guess is that Simon actually used the tweets to jog his memory as he wrote this book.  The sparse information contained in tweets could have allowed him to fill in the memories and conversations as he wished.  With this structure, he created an image of a woman I wish I had had the opportunity to meet and to know.It's an interesting format, and highlights some very personal memories.  It's a very easy read, but for me and possibly for someone else going through this or not too long past it, it can be difficult to go down this road.  In a way, it's comforting to know that we were not the only ones who had similar experiences with doctors, and it's very comforting to know that Mrs. Newman's nurses were as wonderful as my mother's nurses.  For me it was painful, but I'm glad that I've come to "know" Scott Simon's mother.

My shower has always been easy to clean, with just a few items to move before cleaning.  Then I got a shower caddy, and I think my brain decided that since I've got four shelves I have to fill them all.Removing all that junk before cleaning the shower is a pain, and more than once I just cleaned around them.  But this is perfect.  Everything fits... shampoo, conditioner, heavy duty conditioner, three soaps and a bottle of body wash (how the heck did I do that?), exfoliators, razor, and so on.  Removing everything and tossing the whole thing into the sink makes it easy to clean the shower.Last time I left everything in there and hung the caddy from the towel hook.  The things that were removed and left in the shower are the things I use, and the things that stayed in the caddy after a week probably aren't going to be used, and were tossed.Then I rinsed it, let it dry, and folded it up and put it away.So for me this is a cleaning tool and a decluttering tool.  It rinses clean easily and dries fairly quickly, and folds up for storage.  I thought I didn't really need this, but I was wrong.

The day that this arrived, I was in lousy shape from no sleep the night before.  My back and shoulders were in knots, and for some reason everyone was avoiding me.  Normally I'd lie on an exercise ball, but that was too extreme a stretch for me that day.I dropped this on the floor, sat down, and relaxed my back over it.  The first couple of minutes of muscles untwisting brought tears to my eyes, but after that the pain faded and the knots untied.  I may even have examined the inside of my eyelids for a few minutes.So this was immediately added to my stretch routine.  It feels wonderful and I actually look forward to it.But I also exercise with it.  I don't do sit-ups with this, because it feels like a questionable position to start with.  It is good back support for reverse crunches, though.  And I've finally found a way to to do erector spinae work without buying a Roman chair, something I really miss.  The range of motion is not the same, but so far it's the best I can do at home.The padding is comfortable but not too soft, and it doesn't slip on carpet.  I'm not sure I'd recommend this for sit-ups, but for other ab and back work at home this has worked well for me.  And I've found it's great for stretching.  It doesn't offer the range of motion of a Roman chair, but it does more, costs less, and stores under the sofa.

According to Scotts' charts, this Bermudagrass should have been good for me in South Florida.  Maybe the problem is that a lot of my yard gets full sun for most of the day, but I prepped as instructed, put down a pound of this seed in the usual bare spots, and watered as instructed.  (When I'm writing a review I always read the instructions, even though I know what I'm doing.  This way I test the instructions, and sometimes I find out that I didn't really know what I was doing.  Not this time, though.)A couple of spots did not sprout at all.  The other two grew a little, but not as much as I expected considering the coverage.  It's been a month and a half and I'm going to let the rain take over the watering, but I'm doubtful that those spots will fill in.I'll be the first to admit that my yard is a challenge.  The soil is very sandy and alkaline, and the direct sun is severe.  There's little to no shade in the spots that I planted.  And I don't have a sprinkler system, so seeds are subject to human forgetfulness.  One advantage these seeds seem to have is that even though there's a bird feeder nearby, the birds showed no interest in these seeds.  Maybe it's the coating.In a more hospitable (and less far south) South Florida yard, these seeds might do well.  In my yard, I'm not thrilled so far.

The current photo on this item (as of 5/4/15) shows two grey spools and two brown spools.  Warehouse Deals had a great price, and while I didn't need these colors I thought I could get away with them by using them in pieces where the cord would not be obvious.  S-lon works well for me structurally, and I planned to use them where strength would be more important than looks.But that's not what arrived.  There are four spools, the package is labeled "CHINO", but the colors are a very light beige, a sort of denim blue, a cornflower-ish blue, and a color that I see somewhere else described as antique gold, but it looks a bit more like a brownish OD green to me.  The blues don't seem to work well together but otherwise it will be fun to mix and match, and I have no problem making any of these colors visible in the pieces I'm working on.I don't know if I got an old package that has been replaced with the colors in the photo, or maybe a new package when blah brown and blah grey didn't sell, so I'm not sure what I'll get when I reorder this item.  But for now I am really happy with these colors.

We unfolded this blanket and discovered that it was a generous size for Dixie, a large golden retriever mix.  Dixie has had skin problems for years since fleas appeared in the yard.It's just a blanket, not the cushy padded bed she's used to, but she loved it anyway.  She flopped down on it and rolled over for some belly rubs.  After about two minutes of this, I noticed a tiny biting ant fall off her, stagger a couple of inches across the blanket, then curl up into a ball.I expected a repellent effect, but having it kill the bugs that fall off of her is not a bad thing.  At this point Dixie has VERY sensitive skin, so if she reacts badly to the blanket in the next few days I'll update this review.  For now, it seems to be working well and hopefully will be a better option than the medications the vet prescribes.

These arrived at a moment when I had broken glass on the kitchen floor.  (The gloves have wonderful timing.)  I pulled on a glove and grabbed a handful of glass.While the texture made it easy to pick up every last glass chip, I realized that I couldn't feel the sharp points through the gloves.  To test them, I squeezed the handful of glass until several pieces broke.  (Seriously, the things I do for reviews... what was I thinking?!)  The glass did not puncture the glove.I've used the same pair of gloves to clean up other messes like a pile of wood screws.  At this point I almost want to make them rip, just to prove that I can.  I've been using another glove with a mandoline, then washing it and reusing it the next day.  I've slipped a couple of times but still haven't lost any blood.I've also used these for standard gross clean-ups or chemical use, and while they haven't been damaged they still get thrown out after that.Large gloves are usually a little loose on my hands, but these are pretty snug.  They aren't uncomfortable (beyond the fact that my hands are warm, just like every other nitrile glove.)  There are no places that bind up, like some cheaper thin exam gloves I've tried.  These run a little small but overall are a good fit.These gloves have provided excellent protection and the texture makes it easy to grab even tiny things.  They run small but don't run tight across the thumb or knuckles.  Generally when I buy disposable things like gloves I shop by price, but I think when I use up these gloves I'll be buying more.

I'm using these dividers with an Avery extra wide heavy duty binder, and while they will fit into a couple of my older binders (the larger ones, with back-mounted rings,) it's probably a good idea to plan to have an extra wide binder for these dividers.  They are a generous size, which makes them easy to spot in a thick binder full of paper, but they stick out of most of the binders that I own.  In a larger binder they look very professional, but sticking out of an ordinary binder they just look sloppy.I wanted these more for durability than for the way they look, and I'm happy with that.  I've stored thick stacks of paper, a couple of magazines, and a couple of smaller books in the pockets.  The clear front of each pocket will eventually look battered and the stiff back of the pocket can crease, but they take the abuse without falling apart.Avery has label templates which can be downloaded as well as software that can be used to design labels online, but they require a name and email address to use them.  On the bright side, the "Send me free offers, templates and tips from Avery" option is unchecked, which hopefully means they'll keep the junk mail to a minimum.  I've downloaded their Word template and tried the design app online, and I prefer the online app.  Someone with different design needs might find that the templates are better.The "Easy Apply" strip makes it easy to mess up all the labels at once, instead of one at a time.  If your hands are steadier than mine your labels will look better.  The alignment and consistent spacing add to the professional look.  My page of label strips warned that I should "first print on the Easy Apply Practice Sheet to ensure the label sheet is fed into your printer in the correct direction.  The practice sheet is located on the back of the supplemental instruction sheet."  My dividers don't have that sheet or (obviously) the practice sheet.  A sheet of plain paper worked fine.  I made a mark on the sheet to note which way it fed into the printer.These dividers look professional and are heavy duty.  They're large and stick out well from the paper, making them easy to find.  But for that reason they require an extra wide binder.  Avery's software is good but requires a name and email address in order to use it.  I like the dividers but I'm a little frustrated at the need to give away my email address in order to get nicely printed labels.

These bags work well for dry items.  They're pretty good for sandwiches, and the wider shape seems to work well for an opened sleeve of cookies or crackers.  I tried food with a little liquid and ended up with a slow leak and small puddle in my fridge.  And yes, I made sure the bag "clicked closed" when I sealed it.The features listed on the box aren't really that impressive.  "Patented Maxlock track design for an extra strong seal".  (But not strong enough for liquids, apparently.)  "Clicks closed so you know it's closed".  Somehow this has never been a problem before.  "Zipping sound indicates the seal is secure".  Well, mostly.  This is another feature I can't bring myself to care about.It seems like Hefty is trying to improve on something that works just fine without zips and clicks.  That's fine, but I'm still buying based on price--there's nothing here that's worth paying extra for."Recycle if clean and dry", the box promises, but local recyclers here won't take plastic without a recycle symbol.  The symbol is only on the box, not the bags.  Not every recycler is the same, of course, but here these bags are not recyclable.So these are OK but unremarkable.  The next time I store anything wet I'll put the bag upright in a container in the fridge.  I'll buy these if the price is right, but they're not my new favorite storage bag.

I'm in Florida, and we have problems with bugs year round.  (I'm not complaining!)  These baits arrived and I walked out onto the lanai (an enclosed porch, to everyone else) and spotted a line of ants marching through.  I put one of these baits down about six inches away from the ants.Within seconds the whole line took a left turn and covered the bait.  They hung around for a while, and when I went back to check the line had resumed, in the new location, with a pit stop at the bait.The next day they were gone.Two days later I had ants on the other side of the lanai.  I moved the bait and the same thing happened, and the next day they were gone.Ants keep re-appearing every few days, but there's no way to know if they're the same nest taking a different route, or just overflow from my neighbors, who don't seem to do any pest control at all.So yes, these work, and they seem to be very popular with Florida ants.  I can't tell if they're eliminating the nests.  But I always have ant baits on hand, because I always have ants on hand, and I think I'm going to stick with these baits for a while.

My Jeep has been limping along for a few months with repairs that I couldn't do because nuts and bolts that have rusted into place for two decades couldn't be loosened.Do I take it to the shop?  Do I buy air tools and a compressor?  Neither option is in the budget... but this impact wrench is.There are some cons to this wrench.  I find I was taking breaks a lot, because heavy use makes the tool smell like it's burning.  It didn't burn out, but I didn't push it too hard.And it's heavy, which I expected, and not balanced well.  It's awkward to hold in place, doubly so if you're working in a tight spot that requires three elbows in each arm.The rocker switch was a bit odd, and it took me a minute to get used to it.  Not my preference but not a big deal.All my sockets fit well and stayed on, which is good because the tool would wander a bit because of the balance.  I could concentrate on trying to keep it in place without worrying about trying to hang on to the socket, too.And it broke loose some pretty nasty old bolts that haven't budged for any amount of leverage or heat.If you're a pro looking for a tool that will survive a serious daily beating, this ain't it.  But for me and my old Jeep, and a few repairs that have piled up for months, this was exactly what I needed.  It's not the first tool I'll reach for when the next repair comes along, but I'm pretty sure it will be the last.

Shed & Garage Alarm!  Loud enough to be heard all the way inside the house!Doubly so because it has to be inside the house.  If you squint to read the mouse print on the back of the package, on the very bottom, it says "For indoor use only."  So we installed it on the bathroom shed.Seriously, I wanted it for a door inside the house anyway.  But for anyone who is buying this for a shed, you should know that you can't expose it to the elements.  If the inside of your shed door doesn't line up properly, and if the sensor is more than 12 mm from the alarm, this won't work.But hey, I want it for inside.  The nice thing about family is that when you tell them "Please don't oil that squeaky door hinge," the first thing they do is oil the squeaky door hinge.  And then they find out what happens when you startle me, intentionally or unintentionally.  (If you don't know what I'm talking about, good.  I hope you never learn.)  Just try to re-squeak a door--the folks at Home Depot gave us funny looks and no answer.  So.  Door alarm.Except that the chime is loud enough to be heard through an exterior concrete wall, and through three interior walls.  The chime, not the alarm.  That would be great, if this were an outdoor alarm.  And there is no volume control.  We wrapped up the speaker in bubble wrap and old socks, and it is still loud enough to be uncomfortable.So this has all the disadvantages of an outdoor alarm and you can't use it outdoors.It was easy to install.  The "Learn" function was easy to use.  The sensor can be placed on either side of the alarm, a nice feature.  It was a little more difficult to remove than it was to install.  If you've got a leak-proof shed that is square and not at all warped, you might be able to use this inside the shed, but not on the outside.  I'll be looking for a different door chime.

I do like these scissors a lot, though I'm just as happy with these Scotch Precision scissors), which work as well and are slightly cheaper.These Westcott scissors, like the Scotch, are 8" and nonstick titanium coated.  I've used both to cut through heavy cardboard and other thick materials, and both work very well.  These scissors have a distinct advantage in visibility--most of the time I grab these because they're the first thing I see.  The two shades of pink are eye catching and can't be mistaken for anything else.I find that the Scotch scissors fit better in my hand.  These are OK, and if I'm just trimming something quickly it's not even something I'll notice.  But if I have a lot of work to do I'll look for the Scotch scissors, since they seem like a better ergonomic fit and they make my hand a little less tired over time.In a few years I'll need new scissors, and what I'll probably do is compare these two and choose the one that is cheaper.  These work, they clean up easily when cutting through tape or label adhesive, and I have no trouble seeing them even when I put a piece of paper on them.  It's good to see that even after all these years, Westcott remains a reliable brand.

I wasn't really sure what to expect when I started taking these.  We don't fully understand the gut microbiome yet, and here I am taking a probiotic for my mouth?  But dental work is not really an option right now, and I'm doing everything I can to keep my teeth in good shape.  When Hyperbiotics offered me a sample of these and their Pro-15 probiotics, I figured I'd give them a try.The Pro-15 didn't really do anything for me, and at first I thought the same thing about these.  Every morning after brushing and mouthwash I'd chew one or two of these, then grab the first cup of coffee for the day.  Bad planning on my part.  After a couple of weeks I switched to taking these before bed.I didn't give them much thought, until one morning while stopped at a light I realized my teeth felt like I hadn't brushed.  Yep... I hadn't.  In my rush I somehow thought that I must have brushed my teeth already because my mouth didn't taste like someone parked an old truck in there overnight.  My breath was fine, it was just my teeth that were gross.  (Here's a tip I found out the hard way: do NOT use a hand wipe to clean your teeth if you forget to brush.)Once I realized that, I knew what the problem was: my morning breath (which was, by all accounts, no worse than anyone else's) was gone.  Whatever was making my breath nasty in the morning is gone, and while I still can't face the day without brushing, it's amazing the difference this makes.I don't know if this will improve my dental health over time.  I'm placing an order for a new bottle and I'll be taking this regularly from now on.  It's cheaper and less painful than dental work, and I'm hopeful that it will make a difference.  When I have to break down and see a dentist I'll see what they have to say and update this review, but now I've got a permanent addition to my nightly routine.

As someone with digestive problems and a family history of lousy gut biota, every now and then I try different probiotics in the hopes that they'll help.  When Hyperbiotics offered me a sample of Pro-15, I went with that hope again.Again, I was reminded that either the problem isn't my intestinal microbiome, or there are additional problems I'm not addressing.  Like every other probiotic I've tried, this one also didn't fix my GI problems.  But I suspect that the problem is me, and not the Pro-15, for two reasons:1) When the shipment arrived I checked the expiration date.  I found a manufacture date, which was one month earlier.  If I were taking an aspirin I wouldn't care if it was a bit stale, but probiotics lose their effectiveness over time.  If these didn't work for me, it's not because of age.  (Well, not the pills' age, anyway.  Maybe MY age.)2) Shortly after trying this, I tried a different Hyperbiotics product: PRO-Dental.  That really did work for me and it solved a problem I didn't even know I had.There were no side effects.  The pill did not taste bad (didn't taste much at all, actually) and was fairly easy to swallow.  And the probiotics were fresh.  They didn't work for me, but I suspect there are additional problems I need to fix.  Based on what I've seen here and my other Hyperbiotics experience, I'd say that this would be a good place to start for someone who has a need for probiotics.

I've never used a primer before, but I've heard good things about them.  Based on reviews of other Japonesque products, this seemed like it should be a good place to start.  It seems I was right.Since I didn't know what to expect, I gave the primer the best chance to fail that I could think of.  One morning when I had a lot of sweaty work piled up at home, I applied this primer to half my face, then applied makeup (to my whole face) as usual.  Then I started moving stuff, and didn't look in the mirror for hours.  Good thing my family loves me.Several hours later, I finally stopped and checked my makeup, or what was left of it.  Lipstick, of course, was completely gone.  The side without the primer had a few smudges left, but most of the makeup was washed away by sweat.The primer side was not perfect, but the makeup was surprisingly good.  I'd have been comfortable bringing that side out into public.Since then I've been using this primer whenever I apply makeup, and I'm getting a little spoiled by it.  I no longer bother much with touch-ups through the day.  The primer feels impossibly silky to apply, very little is required, and the light fragrance is not noticeable within a couple of minutes.  (I dislike fragrances, so this is important to me.)  I seem to be getting better results while using less makeup, too.  I'm pretty sure that no primer will make my skin look "flawless" unless Kilz comes out with something in my skin tone, but I do see a bit of an improvement.This primer helps my makeup last a lot longer, and I use less makeup too.  It's not quite an "illusion of flawless looking skin", but it does help a bit.  It applies incredibly smoothly and easily, and not much is required.  The light fragrance fades quickly.  I do like this primer.

I'm aware of the historical significance of the bean--worldwide, a primary source of protein and the lifeblood for many people and cultures, sometimes signifying prosperity or fertility, a sign of new life or new beginnings.  And beans are a significant part of my diet and, hey, you are what you eat.  So I'm a human bean.But I knew my friends would look at this bean and think of "the musical fruit".  (Your friends may vary.)  I was right.Once we got the laughs and the doggerel out of the way, they suddenly wanted to admire this bean.  The bean itself is about 19mm long and about 10mm at the center, so it is easily visible.  My friends loved the color, which is surprisingly rich under indoor lighting.  They admired the way it floated on the chain.  They noticed that it has a very flattering effect on the things it reflected, and that no matter which way I turned some part of it caught the light.Then someone made a very questionable bean joke.I don't care if it's rude; I like this necklace.  The curves of the bean are surprisingly graceful, and I like the shape of it better than the original Tiffany necklace.  This one seems more natural, healthier, more promising.  And this one is available, which is no longer true of the Tiffany necklace.The chain had me worried.  It seems very thin and delicate.  I wore it to bed for a couple of nights, to give it a chance to compete in the Tossing and Turning Olympics.  It survived both nights with no damage.Both boxes are also nicely done.  They are a very slightly textured matte black, with contrasting brilliant blue.  The inside of the interior box is a slightly padded soft black, which does a wonderful job of highlighting the piece inside.  If all Amazon Curated jewelry comes in these boxes I may have to start looking here for gifts.This is the loveliest, most delicate piece of jewelry that I've worn that has inspired absolutely the rudest jokes.  It's the best of both worlds.  And it comes in a perfect gift box.  I didn't think I'd like this, but I really do.

The color on mine is pretty much exactly the same as the scarf photo, which makes it a little darker than the scarf on the model.  It's also much shorter than the model's scarf, though it is definitely workable for an adult.  Longer would have been nicer, but for the price I can't complain too much.It shipped flat instead of twisted, so there's not much in the way of crinkle.  I've misted it and twisted it up and the light material should re-shape fairly quickly.If you're not expecting something to wrap twice around your neck and then reach below your waist, this scarf works.

I agree with Titanium Lily's review.  The purple is rich but there's very little of the other colors shown in the photo.  It's a nice scarf with a soft and comfortable feel, and if left mostly crinkled and turned so that the small blue spot is visible, it looks interesting.  I know there will be variations in scarves like these, but I suspect they carefully selected the best one of the batch to photograph.  If you like the purple I'd say go for it, and hope for a bonus color variation or two.

While reasonably priced, this simply does exactly what Elmer's Glue does if used as a base coat.. and works the same way.  Apply a layer, let it dry, paint over it with acrylic paint.  The results are exactly the same as Elmer's... at about twice the cost. The finish isn't all that impressive.  While it does give the effect of weathered wood, some of the cracks are so big all they look like is separation of paint rather than actual weathered look.I tried 5 different brands of crackle medium and none of them performed satisfactorily.  Of the five this worked best... but no better than standard white glue technique, which is a lot less expensive.  So I see no reason to go the extra expense in this "specialty" product that isn't so special.

I purchased 5 brands of crackle medium / paint.  All five performed unsatisfactorily.This particular brand is very inconvenient to use.  The instructions say to apply and then wait for it to get "tacky"... but doesn't provide a time frame.  So you get to sit there, periodically checking to see if it's "tacky" (whatever that particular consistency is supposed to mean).  The instructions warn to not let it dry completely, so if the phone rings or you get distracted and it dries... goodbye finish.The final crackle pattern is no better than using standard Elmar's glue as a base... and you can let Elmar's dry completely.  It's also considerably less expensive than this.

I purchased 5 different brands of crackle medium / paint and none of them perform as advertised or satisfactorily.This item "crackles" into very tiny, sand-like beads; it could hardly be considered a "crackle".  The consistency is no different than textured paints that have a rough surface.  The finish is inconsistent, even when applied thickly.  Not at all what I would call "crackle paint".  It's more of a "rough sandpaper finish" paint.

I purchased a total of 5 brands of these "crackle" mediums/paints, and am sorry to say none of them perform as expected.This particular product crackled better than most... but has almost no adhesive properties.  It crackles great, but flakes off very easily at the rub of a finger.  It absolutely must be sealed with a top coat (polymer might be preferred) in order to retain any kind of permanence.  Even then I would expect it eventually to come off the item.  It may work well on wood, but I wouldn't use it on metal, plastic, glass, vinyl or any other slick-surface, even if primer is used.  It's just "flaky".This crackle paint must be applied thickly to achieve proper crackle... and will crackle differently at the slightest difference in thickness.  It's almost impossible to get a uniform coat / crackle pattern on a surface... especially curved surfaces.  Simply doesn't do the job for me.
This is terrific.  Well-made, fairly large (exactly the right size for the purpose I had in mind), nicely finished.  Meets all expectations and arrived in pristine condition.

I have tried other keyboard of this general class.  This one works better than any others I've used.  The touchpad is responsive and accurate, the keys respond well.  The keyboard is very thin, easy to charge, and it has an easily-accessible key to totally shut off the keypad if you're doing something with which the keypad interferes. (Why didn't Microsoft put a "disable pad tap" function in Windows 8 & 10?).  It is thin enough to fit in the same case as my tablet and still allow the case to close.The only reason I rate this 4 stars instead of 5 is because it doesn't come with driver software to give it capabilities beyond Windows (such as turning off pad tap).  Other than that, totally pleased with this purchase.

I must either have received a defective product... or am totally missing something here.  This is a 15 watt 8 ohm speaker and should be able to produce a fairly loud signal... but the sound was pitiful.  I hooked it up to two different sound sources, both capable of producing pretty high volume, yet neither one managed to get more than a tinny-sounding, micro-speaker type sound out of this.  This doesn't surprise me.  It is extremely lightweight; the size of the magnet can't be any more than a couple of ounces, tops.  I could literally build a better speaker than this out of an old transistor radio speaker and a bit of rolled-up posterboard.I build amps all the time.  I don't see how this received such high ratings-- unless I received a defective unit (which is always possible).  Returned it for refund.

This is a lovely ocarina with nice mellow tone.  Being ceramic it has a much nicer sound than plastic ocarinas.It comes in a sturdy heavy-nylon case with belt loop and includes an adjustable bead-string neck loop that's as pretty as the ocarina.  The instrument is easy to play once you get the fingering down.  It comes with instructions.  If you already know how to play a 12-hole ocarina you'll have no difficulty with this.There's nothing at all "cheap" about this ocarina.  I wouldn't call it "concert" quality... but it's better quality than most.  For an instrument in this price range it is excellent quality.  The instrument itself is well-made, the glaze finish very nice (as well as the hand-painting), the neck cord is very pretty and even the case is high-quality.  For a quality musical instrument it is certainly a good buy.Note: one review stated this is difficult to blow and they have difficulty getting out low tones: I would have to say they didn't have a thumb hole covered (which would produce such results).  This ocarina plays fine and is not at all difficult to blow.

The product itself, although a "squeeze stress toy" felt like it wasn't properly filled with squeeze stuff (about half empty).  Very flimsy, the hands did not reach the face.  When squeezed the arms do not separate as advertised.  The base of the figure was distorted and it wouldn't stand up.  In short, it is a very-poorly-manufactured item.BUT THERE IS HOPE!  Feeling around I realized the squeeze stuff, whatever it was, wasn't gel.  So I cut the bottom out of the figure with scissors (see photo) and discovered the innards are some kind of white, water-soluble putty.  I removed this putty and without the distorted bottom, the figure stood on its own quite well.  If one wanted it could be filled with sand to add some weight, the bottom glued to a form-cut piece of wood, plastic or cardboard, and you'd have a decent display figure.  But it's fine hollow; it stands on its own and holds its shape without filling.What about the arms?  The entire figure is made of very flexible vinyl.  I really like the floppy wings.  So I took a stiff piece of thin wire and ran it carefully through the head into the body.  I then bent the head downward so that the face was hidden by the hands.  The effect was perfect... a Weeping Angel with a bowed head and face hidden.  To open the arms, forget the squeeze action... just pull the arms apart at the elbows.  No one is going to care when they see that horrid hidden face.So you can rescue it from its poorly-manufactured state and turn it into what it should have been to start with-- a detailed display model with arms that can pull away from the grimacing face.  I'm now rather pleased with the figure.  I'd give it 4 stars if I hadn't had to do all that work.  (But really, it's simple and took about 10 minutes total.)  It's fairly easy to mod if yours doesn't work out of the box.  From what I've read and the ratings stats (at this time) you have about a 30% chance of getting a "good" one.  Fortunately it can be modified.

I've read the mixed reviews on here and wondered why it worked for some folks and didn't work for others.  I think the reason is the very scanty instructions that don't stress clearly enough how this product is used... and the fact that it is labeled as a "medium". From the instructions it is clearly not a medium (ie, it is not mixed with paint).  I finally figured out how it's used by going to YouTube and watching a demonstration.  I then realized the instructions were correct; they just didn't emphasize an essential step.This product requires a FOUR-STEP process...which is why I give it only 3 stars; it's very time-consuming to use.STEP 1)  Paint an acrylic base coat as a contrast color.  Let it dry.STEP 2) Paint this "medium" over the base coat . Let it dry.  IMPORTANT:  do not expect to see crackles yet.  This stuff doesn't crackle by itself.  Instead it provides a crackle environment.STEP 3) *ESSENTIAL TO FUNCTION*  Once the Weathered Wood dries, paint it over very quickly with a coat of different-color acrylic paint.  This is when you will quickly note the cracking.  There is a chemical reaction of some kind that occurs and the crackling begins very quickly.  It begins so quickly in fact, you may not be able to apply the paint fast enough.  If you re-brush over a pre-coated area it may actually pull both paint and crackle away from the project.  That's another reason for only 3 stars... lack of working time.  The crackle effect starts taking place within 15-30 seconds.STEP 4) Once the crackle step is complete and FULLY DRY, overcoat it with a sealer.  I'm not sure what kind of sealer to use since acrylic reacts to the crackle, but a wipe-on polymer might do best.  Without this sealer coat the crackle will be like actual weathered paint... rather unstable.So this is a very time-consuming and tricky process.  It works, and the effect is interesting, but it requires four distinct steps with four drying cycles that will cover (at the very least) a two-hour period-- as opposed to a "mix with the paint and let it dry"... or a crackling base that you then paint over.I have tried five of these "crackle" products.  They all are similar in concept and results.  None of them approach the crackle we might find in a ceramic crackle glaze... which is really what I'm looking for.  If anyone knows of such, lemme know.  : )
Terrific strings, really bring out the "blues" and mellow tones in a guitar.  Just the right diameter.

Like several types of glasses in this genre, the lenses are far too dark to make these viable.  Manufacturers:  using "black plastic" in sunglasses and then covering it with reflective material does not work. These are so dark it's difficult to see even outside on a sunny day, and inside turns the environment too dark to walk around safely.  As sunglasses they're actually dangerous to use, and as costume props they're useless-- you can't see indoors.

Very good quality wire.  Hair thin; handle with care (of course).  I use this to wind guitar pickups.  Touchier to handle than 42 but excellent conductive qualities and resistance.  Will be a repeat customer.  I do wish it was available in red.

I bought this to go with the female and tiger cub I already owned.  It is proportionately sized so that they make a very nice set.  The appearance is as shown in the photo.  A detailed and well-crafted piece.

I've purchase four similar-type guitars lately for practice in building electric guitars.  This guitar is surprisingly nice.  It should be considered a "starter" guitar-- but a good one.  Here are the pros and cons:- Has only one pickup and that's near the bridge.  Don't expect rich, deep tone.  This guitar is obviously designed to appeal to the younger generation looking for metal / distortion guitar playing... thus the location of the pickup.+ But it's a rather nice humbucker and pulls the best sound possible out of this guitar, considering its location.+ The body is pristine, gorgeously finished.  The wood (at least on the one I received) was well-assembled with joint marks just barely visible and blended in with the transparent / grin finish.  It's an attractive guitar.+ A swirl-maple 1/16" veneer on the surface of the neck provides an attractive and durable surface+ The neck is straight and sturdy.  I did not have to adjust the guitar or action at all... rare with off-the-shelf guitars.+ The amplifier with this-- although predictably "tinny" due to the small speaker size-- is surprisingly robust.  The basic tone is clear and clean, even at higher volume.  Hit the "overdrive" button and you can get all the dirt and grit you want.  Overall, it is a much better amp than a similarly-configured competitors guitar set (which I also bought.  In short... this guitar set is better).+ I like that the bottom of the neck (where it joins the body) is rounded and smoothed rather than cut off straight as we see with some guitars in this price range.+ Comes with everything you need-- guitar cord, strap, picks, tuner and gig bag.In summary-- this is a nicer guitar set than I thought it would be when I first purchased it.  You get the entire set for about the price of a Fender Squier and the nicer tone and power of a humbucker pickup (although of course, not the tonal versatility of a 3-pickup Squier).  I consider this guitar set to be well worth the purchase price and a good choice for a beginning guitar player.

This is a good-quality "starter guitar" with a pitiful practice amp thrown in to the bargain.  For around a hundred bucks, it's not a bad deal.I'm reviewing this item from several directions:* Is the manufacture of good quality?  (yes)* Does it suit the intended purpose? (starter system for first time players... somewhat yes)* How does it compare to other products? (right in the middle... not the best, not the worst)This is a "starter kit" aimed directly at young / first time guitar players.  The guitar and amp should be rated separately.  Part of me wants to give this 5 stars for quality of manufacture, but other issues are involved-- including what else is available for $100.My overall satisfaction with the purchase:  I bought mine in "used excellent" condition and am very pleased with the purchase, even though I've played guitar for (mumblety mumble) years / decades.  The lower used price attracted me to try it.GUITAR PROs and CONs:* WELL-MADE.  Finish is pristine.  Beautiful body, gorgeous neck.  The maple veneer fingerboard is lovely. Appears to be 1/16" veneer, so the surface should hold up well.* SET UP.  Easy to set up.  Almost every off-the-shelf guitar has to be "set up" for proper action.  A few turns on the neck rod and resetting of the bridge screws produced action that is very acceptable in this level of guitar.  Of course it's not the same micro-fine action one will get out of a $2000 guitar... nor should it be expected to be so.  I am picky about such things but find this setup to be very acceptable in this range of instrument.  In short-- it's quite playable and even enjoyable to play.* VIBRATO is excellent (wiggling fingers to get a tremolo tone).  Not all guitars can make that claim... not even expensive ones.* TONE.  Considering this has one humbucker at the bridge and is intended to appeal to the high-tone, distortion hard-rock base of the younger generation, the sound is fine.  For the trained ear or someone who wants mellow blues / jazz tones, this would not be the instrument of choice.  This is a "twanger" for sure.  (That said, add a P90 below the neck and some good strings and yowza, might have a very nice-sounding guitar.)* This is a humbucker rather than a single pickup, so it has that to its credit.  And it's a good enough humbucker to not require replacing.* The tuners are very touchy (small ratio), but they do tend to hold once tuned.Bottom line:  one shouldn't buy a guitar like this and expect professional features.  This is a starter guitar... but it's a well-made starter guitar. However for the same money one can buy a Fender Squier and have near-pro quality.This guitar really is made very well.  It's not as good as a Fender, but considerably better than some other $100 guitars I've seen.  So 5 stars for quality of manufacture... 3 stars for being (as expected) a basic $100 guitar with a single bridge pickup.  (Note: had they put a neck pickup on this as well I'd have given this 5 stars hands-down).THE AMP PROs and CONs:+ It's included with the guitar+ The controls are easy-to-use- Pitiful poor speaker.  If someone likes distortion... you'll surely get that. It's difficult to get the amp to NOT distort.  A lot of young "rockers" will love it.  But if you want clean sound you'll have to turn the Gain all the way down, Volume all the way up, and all tone dials to the middle.  Even then, don't strum too hard.- Very "tinny" sounding.  It's basically a "junk" amp thrown in for a starter.If one were to replace the speaker with something better, there's a chance the amp part of this unit is better quality than the speaker allows.  I'm going to try to scrounge a higher-quality speaker just to see what I can get out of this.OVERALL:  The quality of the guitar is the high-point here.  It is built much better than I expected it to be.  The finish is very nice, the neck is good quality, and the action can be easily set to "very playable".  It's beautiful in appearance (better than the photo demonstrates).  That is the shining "5 star" grace of this kit.Conversely, the sound of guitar and amp together is tinny, distorted, with zero depth.  If you know how to mod a guitar... stick a $15 P-90 pickup on this near the neck and you could double the playing sound/value of the guitar.  It would be worth it; you'd have a nice guitar with great vibrato play.Surprisingly I like this guitar as a "modable".  I have plans for it, definitely.  I suggest this mainly for modders who want to have some fun starting with a well-built guitar base.  For that purpose, this is perfect.  It's also a low-cost alternative for the first-time guitar player who wants a playable instrument, one that can be set up to be easy to play and will at least encourage them to keep playing.  A viable alternative to the popular Fender Squier.

These are some of the best-looking Steampunk glasses I've seen.  But the lenses are so dark it's actually dangerous to drive wearing them.  Forget wearing them inside or using them for cosplay; worn inside you become blind.From what I can tell, the lenses are made from "dark black" plastic... then have the reflective covering over them.  The reflective covering would have been enough to serve as sun glasses. The dark plastic makes them virtually unusable.It's a shame.  These are great-looking glasses.  But the truth is one simply can't see through them well enough to enjoy them.

All of these steampunk-style glasses with mirror lenses have the same flaw:  they're made with darkened lens material instead of clear.  The mirror material itself would serve well enough as sunglasses.
