But with the combination of dark lens and mirror finish they are so dark it can be dangerous to drive with them on, and it's impossible to see indoors (goodbye using them for steampunk cosplay).

* Well-made* Two roller sets for less $ than some singles sell for* Two different colors is niceThe bridges are easily adjustable by using an L-wrench (unfortunately not included) and the standard thumbwheel knob common to such devices.
A simple-but-sufficient tremolo system.  Easy to install (make sure this is for your model of guitar).  Price is the main concept here, but works as well as any I've seen in this style.

I checked three of these out at a local guitar store.  For the price, awesome guitar.PROS:* Around $400 retail.  That is cheap for a quality guitar* Excellent tone.  I would put flat-wound strings on it to really bring out the blues.* Official Bigsby licensed tailpiece (see cons as well)* Tri-switch between pickups offers neck, bridge or both pickups for variety of sound* Two volume controls and an overall tone control (I like that much better than the Les Paul 4-control system)* Master volume control* Two P-90 pickups... just right for anything from blues to 50s to surf to (with the right amp) gritty rock* Action can be set to very good (I've never bought an off-the-shelf guitar that didn't need adjustment to the action)* Solid neck runs straight through center of the guitar for added strength and sustainCONS:* V-type saddle makes it difficult to keep strings in tune when using the tremolo bar.  Replacing this with a roller bridge would likely fix the problem (I would consider such replacement a necessity).  Bigsby is a respected tail system but if not installed precisely is known for going out of tune.  I'd plan on springing for a roller bridge.  They're inexpensive and easy to replace.* The tremolo bar the three guitars I tested was too stiff in both directions.One must remember this is a $400 git and not a $1000 one.  Except for the tremolo stiffness and need to replace the bridge, it's a near-perfect guitar.  As it stands, it's significantly better than lower-price guitars, and even excels most guitars in its price range... but because of the tremolo / tuning issues is just "okay" overall (as shipped from the factory).  A roller bridge will be an essential add-on and if you can get one with a little looser tremolo, you could easily wind up with a 5-star guitar.

Note:  I received this microphone from seller Hong Kong Keenwin, to run special tests for use with devices other than a camera (phones, tablets, digital recorders).  I have not tested this for camera use but I am pleased to say it passed my tests for non-camera recording very well.The operation of this microphone is very easy.  It comes with a standard 3.5mm (1/8") plug, which can be used in any standard "3-ring" microphone jack.  If you have a device such as an iPhone, Android phone or tablet, or Windows tablet, you will likely need to obtain a 4-ring adapter or USB splitter specific to that device.  Such are available very inexpensively on Amazon.  Note that Apple 4-ring adapters are configured differently from everyone else's (no surprise there)... so be sure to get the adapter specific to your device.  Such adapters often can be purchased in a microphone / headphone separator configuration, which is very handy so you can listen to your clips immediately after recording them.PROS:* Sound recording is far better than I expected for a microphone in this price range.* Stereo, with splitting performed by two separate parallel pickup devices in the mike.* Excellent recording quality; faithful reproduction of sound* Relatively small and lightweight* The LED light flashes briefly when you turn it on as verification the mike is working.* Removable wind screen* Handy mini-clamp on the back of the mike to hold excess cord and keep it from flapping against a device while recording.CONS:These aren't so much negatives as they are simple operational procedures.* This is a nature-cannon mike.  As such it is  very sensitive and will pick up all ambient noise.  There's no ambient filter (it's intended for filming nature and all that comes with it).  However, such background noise is usually very easy to cut out using free programs such as Audacity and its Noise Removal function.  Most ambient filters I've used muffle all sound, which I find undesirable.  I would rather have the clear, full, accurate reproduction of recorded sound that this mic offers and cut the background noise in production.  Most recording techs I speak with feel the same.* Battery required (supplied).  The battery is stated to last over 800 hours... which is a very long time.  However there is no indication of automatic shutoff... so you will need to remember to turn the switch off when done recording.Of the above two "cons", both are normal in even high-price cannon mikes... so both can be discounted as "standards of the industry".The instruction booklet is very small and written in "Aslish" (something I rather enjoy reading; their English though chopped, is considerably better than my Asian, and brings me the occasional chuckle).  So you will likely need your reading glasses and a sense of humor.  If you have both, you'll enjoy the manual.I consider this to be an excellent microphone and a good purchase.  I have purchased several mics in this price range that I didn't find to do a good job-- and posted lesser-satisfactory reviews regarding them.  I am pleased to say this microphone deserves its 5 stars.

This is a cheap-metal, "screws strip faster than you can blink" clone of a Floyd Rose bridge.  It is seriously not worth the money, no matter how inexpensive.  This is one of those "pay more for a reliable one" deals; I doubt this one will last even through the first month of use.

I'm not really sure what this is meant to be used for.  I can say what it CAN'T be used for:* Can't be used to feed a USB mike into a cell phone or tablet* Can't be used to plug a flash-drive into an AUX port on a car* Can't be used with anything that requires USB power* Can't be used to plug USB headphones into a standard earphone jack (most USB headphones require power)About the only thing I can think of that it might be used for is plugging a self-powered USB sound output device into a cell phone... but I can't really imagine what such a device would be.  Most such devices would already have a 3.5mm output port, which would allow use of a standard connector cable.I think the main problem here is the manufacturer / seller failing to inform the public exactly what this device was intended to be used for.  The obvious uses of 1) plugging a USB mike into a phone or pad or 2) plugging USB headphones into a cell or tablet... simply don't work.  This will probably leave most people scratching their heads and deciding it's not worth the hassle of returning it.

It's a good-quality guitar strap for the price.  The padded shoulder strap is comfortable.  The nylon belt is a bit large-weave for my taste but fully viable.  The leather ends are thick enough to do the job, but aren't as thick as one would expect from a more expensive strap.  Overall it's fine.

The tshirt I received was printed poorly, with the entire print off to the left.  The bow tie and shirt seam didn't line up with the center of the shirt... and the collar was about an inch and a half below the shirt collar... making the entire effect look like it was hanging far too low on my neck. Returned it the next day.  If someone is going to charge $20 for a printed T-shirt, time should be taken to insure the print is lined up properly.

For the price this makes an excellent "first time" guitar.  It looks fancy and sports two humbucker pickups.PROS:* A visually interesting and unusual guitar* Handles well; balance is good* Body finish is pristine* Two humbuckers and a single-- rare to see 3 pickups in a guitar this price range* Once it's is set up it plays well enough and is enjoyable to play.  That's a big "plus" with this level of guitar.CONS:* As is common, the entire guitar will have to be set up when first opened.  This one took a bit though; I spent more than an hour adjusting the neck, the bridge position and the string action.* The 5-position switch is too close to the volume knob, actually touching the knob at the uppermost position.* The positions of the switch do not allow simultaneous use of both humbuckers.  This is an unfortunate drawback.  The switch allows  neckbucker alone, neckbucker and mid-single, mid-single alone, mid-single and bridgebucker, and bridgebucker alone. In reality of playing, it is unlikely one would use the mid-single by itself; that position should have been reserved for both humbuckers (or all three).  This of course can be overcome by opening the back of the git and doing a bit of informed re-wiring.  It's not insurmountable, but it's a poor wiring design... especially since it would have been just as easy to wire it better.* The tuners were a bit loose-- again not unusual on a guitar in this price range.* The nut was not properly grooved for the strings.  The D-string grove had to be widened.* Tremolo is very stiff.  Solution:  open up the back and remove one of the springs.* There were two hairline finish cracks in the headstock, apparently from over-tightening the neck adjustment cover screws.* None of the pickups lined up with the strings.  The strings are all offside the "dots" on every pickup.  There's no way to fix this other than replacing the pickups with bar pickups (which would make this a much more awesome guitar and would be worth the extra cost).* The mid-single pickup is not height adjustable.  It simply screws in place.  The other two pickups are not angle-adjustable.  They would need to be shimmed underneath to line up with the strings.In other words, it's a starter guitar at a super-cheap price.  It is playable (once it is properly adjusted) and even fun to play, but it will require a lot of "set up" and a bit of knowledge to make it play correctly (also, give a day or so for the strings to set in).  This will make a nice-looking learner or practice guitar, but to be honest there are better guitars on the market in the same price range.  I give it 3 stars because it's an under-$100 guitar and no one should be expecting much more.  One can buy a Fender Squire for near the same money and get a much better guitar for the dollar.  However the humbucker pickups are nice and some first-timers will love the unusual style.This has potential as a "hobbyist-rebuilder" guitar.

Gorgeous set, looks exactly as in the photo.  It was a little smaller than I had visualized, but presents every bit of detail and beauty one would expect.  I've included two photos to show detail and relative size.  Definitely worth buying.

When I first received this I gave it 5 stars in general appearance.  Then I looked at it closer, with reading glasses, and discovered this is not the same figure as shown in the photo.  The photo figure is far more detailed than the one currently being shipped.  While the figure is still fairly awesome... it is just not the same as the pictured one.I am an admirer of Papo work.  This is the 4th piece I've purchased; prior pieces are the Shark Pirate, Warrior Orc, and Armored Crocodile.  I also own the Tigress Carrying Cub because it is so realistic.Rhino Man is a good figure... it's just not the great figure shown in the photo.  It is significantly less-detailed and the paint job is shoddy (for example, the axe head is brown rather than painted silver).  For these reasons I'm disappointed with the purchase.  It makes me wonder if they put out two different figurines, if the one in the photo is an artist rendition rather than the actual figure, or if the original mold wore out and this is a re-release.  Whichever, it's just not the same.These are sturdy enough for children's play... but detailed enough for display pieces.This makes a good addition to my fantasy figure collection. I don't collect many things and I'm very discriminating in what I add to it... but this line of figures has earned space on my shelves.  But this isn't what was expected.  The photo needs updated to accurately represent the actual product.  (Photos included to show the difference.)

Least-expensive reproduction of the Firefly space ship on the market.  For Firefly fans who haven't already acquired one of the expensive models ($300 to $3000)... this under-$30 version will press the collector's-desire button.  The fact that it's marketed as a Yahtzee game is probably pretty much irrelevant.  We can play Yahtzee on our computers.  I'd wager almost every person buying one of these is buying it for the ship itself and couldn't care less that it comes with Yahtzee dice (although they are interesting little dice).I do wish the engines rotated and the tail fins were movable... but can't have perfection.  Does make me wonder why no one ever came out with a detailed marketable model or toy.  Coolest space ship ever.

When I purchased this it was under $20.  For that price it has a lot of features and reasonable performance.The entire line of Lepai amps has something in common: they work fairly well for the price range and what they are, but they don't pack near the punch one would expect from a car amplifier.  They make decent hobby-experimentation amps.  But for use as an auto amp, they just don't have what it takes.There is an exception:  if you're using a preamped external source (such as an MP3 player) these can produce quite good volume and tone.  I believe that's what the manufacturer is relying on.  But preamping is pretty much a necessity.If you're low on cash this may be worth the purchase.

Works great.  I haven't had a problem with it yet.  Doesn't mean it will continue to work... just that so far it hasn't broken.  One has to consider the very low price.  Functionality is fine; the volume wheel has a wide range.
Sorry, but this is awful solder.  It clumps and slags rather than soldering.  Its adhesion properties are slim or none. I recommend everyday "Wal-Mart" solder over this.

I read review after review about what a wonderful tool this is.  But I don't see the value.  I've used old-fashioned draw-knives  and they do a better job, more reliably and quickly.This is basically a plane with handlebars.  It can shave quite a bit of wood (the wood will have to be clamped) but it does so very roughly rather than smoothly.  The blade will require adjusting prior to use; it doesn't look like the factory spent any time getting it to working level before shoving it out the door.  It works best when the blade is just below the plane bottom; in this position it removes wood fairly well.PROS:* Well-built and sturdy* Good-quality blade* It works... kindaCONS:* Adjustment system is cumbersome and difficult to use* Blade does not come properly adjusted from the factory* Handles are narrow and uncomfortable to use* A standard plane does a better job for fine work* A standard old-fashioned draw-knife does a far better job for stripping and wood removalIn short, this is an unnecessary tool that tries to replace a draw knife and a plane with one low-cost tool... and fails in both aspects.If you're looking for a tool like this to shave wood (ie, a "spokeshave") I recommend a regular double-handle 10" draw knife.  They'll cost more than double what this tool costs, but will do the job better.

These headphones produce amazing sound.  I ordered them because they were Koss and relatively low-priced.  I've been a Koss user for years and have found even their cheap headphones to be of decent quality.  But these are unexpectedly terrific.  The bass response is incredible, accuracy of sound production the best I've heard anywhere near this price range... and they even out-perform headphones I've heard that cost considerably more.I have two sets (one for when a friend visits and we're watching video-- headphone sound is easier to hear)... and am extremely pleased with this purchase.PROS:* Comfortable.  Flexible top-head band sits comfortably on noggin.* Unexpectedly good bass response* Incredibly accurate sound range and reproduction* Volume knob easy to locate and useCONS:* None that I've seen.Seriously the best headphones I've ever used.  Makes me tempted to buy about half a dozen more for when these eventually wear out. (I use headphones a lot.)

This might be good as a carpenter's paperweight or conversation piece.There is no indication of just how small this item is.  This is not a full-size spokeshave; it's the size of a carpenter's refrigerator magnet.  When the description stated: "312 total width" I figured it was a misprint and took it for granted to mean the blade was about 3".This tool is 3.5" long... TOTAL.  The blade is 7/8" wide.  When it arrived it first struck me as a joke.  Then I was just peeved that the tool description wasn't more accurate... especially in light of the probably-bogus 5-star first review.If this tool was about 3 times larger it might be a nice item.  It does not arrive adjusted properly; the blade is far too deep in cut to be of any value.  There is no blade locking mechanism save for one single screw.  As a wood-worker's tool I can't imagine the application.  It's just far too small to be of any value.  There's only room on the handles for a thumb and finger; how is one supposed to hold it and do any work?The only real value I can perceive is as a joke-gift for your favorite craftsman.  Even then, he'd probably be as disappointed as I was when I opened the miniscule envelope and realized how tiny this "spokeshave" actually is.

Definitely a case of "get what you pay for".  These B500k pots when set to a multimeter provide severely inconsistent readings, jumping all over the scale.  The same multimeter when applied to a different brand, larger B500k provided highly consistent and steady readings.  These pots simply don't work properly.  I tried to use them on a guitar as a tone pot and the tone range was as expected, inconsistent and minimal.  I would recommend a better quality potentiometer.

The concept is simple:  smoothed edges for handing, sharpened edges for scraping.  You use these opposite the way you use a chisel; set the sharpened edge against the wood and pull it toward you.  It will remove minute quantities of wood and leave a fairly smooth surface.  The multiple shapes allow you to scrape flat sides, curves and grooves.This is a good-quality, well-made set of scrapers.  They are good for bringing wood down from rough to much-smoother finish and if used lightly can produce a very smooth finish on wood.  They can replace coarse-grid sandpaper and save scratches in the wood as well.  For final finish you'll still need to use either fine sandpaper or a burnisher.  You'll find numerous opinions as to which works best.As far as these tools go, they do the job they're intended to do, very well.  Press hard and they'll take off small strips of wood.  Press lightly and they'll tone wood down to quality.  Finish off with a burnisher or fine sandpaper.

It's not easy to review a magnet; it either works or it doesn't.  Not much to say beyond that.  These magnets were shipped in a box far too large and rolled in an immense amount of packaging to insure their safe delivery.  Form is consistent and performance excellent.

Decent wire.  I purchased the 1-lb reel after going through a half-lb reel.  This wire is strong (for 42awg) and performs well.  There was no breakage at all that wasn't caused by external problems; the wire itself held up fine.  I've tried other 42awg wire and was frustrated with the amount of repeated, seemingly random breaking.  This wire presented none of that, allowing me to finish projects with minimal headache.  I'm a repeat customer and very likely will be again, depending how quickly I go through this reel.The reason I rated this 4 stars rather than 5 is because there are a considerable number of "break welds" in the wire itself (where the wire has broken in production and been welded together).  One would not ordinarily notice this at all unless feeding the wire by hand (which I do)... in which case the break welds can be felt as they pass through the fingers.  As a break weld is about double the thickness of the wire alone, this causes a bump in coil wraps, alteration of resistance (minor, but it builds up with each break), and in excess reveals the wire is not "quality".For my use, this is inexpensive and acceptable.  It works well.  But buyers should be aware there are too many break welds in this wire to be used for critical work.  For regular coil winding (its most common use) it's adequate.

For almost as long as I've played guitar I have found D'Addario strings to be consistently good quality, whether I'm buying nylon classical (my first introduction to the brand), phosphor for my Ovation acoustic or electric strings.  They're consistent, have good tone, and are available in just about any configuration a person would want.The EXL 115 is a standard low-cost medium-gauge set that provides a good standard electric vibe.  If someone prefers a little lighter or heavier string, all that's needed is to switch to one of the different sets.  I enjoyed being able to pick the exact string I wanted all on one page.Very pleased, will definitely purchase again.
Good quality magnets, as advertised.  Not much more one can say.  They're what's expected.
These are good-quality magnets.  There's not much one can say about a magnet that works except it's as advertised. No downsides I can discern.

At this price one should not expect a "precision" bit set nor the highest quality.  But for the price, these are exceptionally good bits.  They are well-centered (relatively speaking), have a decent case and cut well.PROS:* Bits are of surprisingly good quality at this price* Bits are decently-centered; no significantly off-center bits* The case is metal and protectiveCONS:* These aren't precision bits nor should they be expected to be so at this price* Some bits may have a very slight "wobble"... but not enough to cause project problems* The plastic handle on the case is junk; you'll wind up throwing it away almost immediately* Box can be a bit difficult to open (I just leave it closed but not clasped)* Some bits may not be completely finished-sharp... however they still drill and a micro file can fix them easily* Bit sizes on the back row are blocked by the front-row bits and difficult to readWhile these cons may seem significant, one has to remember this is a 25-piece drill bit set for less than a buck a bit.  That's why I give it 5 stars:  value for price.  I would definitely buy this set again.

Seriously... "Dragongirl"?This is not the worst book ever written... but it is far from the Pern we came to love under Anne's hands.Todd brings us a tale of plague and... plague.  Again.  I would go into detail, but to discuss the plot of this after-Anne series is to just prolong it... something all should avoid.If anyone wishes to understand the true value of this book (and similar post-series not written by Anne herself)... check the seller prices.  They start at 5 cents... plus 3.99 shipping (typical shipping for a book).  When sellers consider a hard-cover Pern book to be worth 5 cents... readers can wisely take a hint and save themselves both money and time.My suggestion:  if you're a Pern fan-- just re-read the original series.  You'll enjoy it more.

This is good wire and I like the red color; it is much easier to see that the wire is stripped when removing insulation than it is with copper-colored wire.  This holds up and performs as one would expect.  Do be aware that the insulation is intended to be removed only by the heat of soldering or with fine sandpaper.  It lives up to that expectation.  I have tried every solvent I can think of and nothing removes that coating.  So you can pretty well rely on the insulation coating holding up and protecting the bare wire.  The downside is you need to have your soldering and sanding skills down pat.  This is thin stuff.

These are decent-quality 9v battery holders with on/off power switch.  They include both battery clips and wire leads.However, the design leaves quite a bit to be desired.  The battery access is on one side of the case... but the power switch on the other side.  This leaves one wondering how these were intended to be installed.  If they are mounted on one side, the power switch is blocked.  If they're mounted on the other side, the battery door is blocked.  If a small opening is made to access the power switch from the outside of an object, the access door is trapped inside the object.The only evident option is to just "leave it hanging".  If that was the goal, regular 9v battery leads are much less expensive.  The only advantage I can see to this case is that it does has an on/off switch.  But I really can't figure out a proper way to mount this on any device.

This is a good value for the money (currently $6.52)... depending on your needs.PROS:* 5-way switch, three pots and guitar jack already pre-soldered* Good-quality parts-- 500K pots and a sturdy switch* Low priceCONS:* Unusual layout (see below)* No instructions  (bad in this case because of unusual layout)UNUSUAL LAYOUTIn most items of this sort we would expect either two volume controls and one tone pot, or two tone pots and one volume control.But in this case we find two A500 pots with capacitors and a single B500 pot with no capacitor.Ordinarily, the B500 pot would contain the capacitor and be used as a tone pot.  The A500 pots would have no capacitor and be used for volume control.So it's unusual (and confusing) to find a non-capped B500 linear pot and two capped A500 audio pots.  It makes me wonder if the factory got a couple of parts boxes mixed up.  If this was a single A500 non-capped pot and two capped B500s it would make sense.  But as it sits it's backwards to what we usually see.Because of the unusual layout and no instructions, I give it 3 stars.  I'd give it an extra half-star because of quality parts.  They're just backward from what they need to be.

This system uses a separate-single humbucker system (two individual coils wired to counteract hum).  The sound is good.  If one wishes to use them to make a cigar box guitar they can be cut apart and used individually (with proper hum control ie, ground the strings to the jack).  Good set for the price.

When I first received this the LED wire was so thin I thought this was just a battery holder (which I order often).  It was only later I realized this was the LED system. :DThe lights are very small and very bright.  Totally pleased with the purchase.  I actually hadn't expected the LEDs to be as bright as they are, but they're very bright and a terrific green (no wash-out effect).  Would definitely order again; it can be used for all sorts of decorative ideas.Side note:  the seller shipped it quickly; got here in prime time.EDIT:  I ordered a second of these.  Nifty little item.

These are nice-looking gold pickups, exactly as pictured.  The sound quality is excellent, the volume good, with no hiss or buzz.  Dual set of matched humbuckers works well with double-humbucker guitars (either HH or HSH).

Very nice pickups.  I love the flat look and the sound comes across fine, with no hum or hiss.  The dual-set is great for guitars that allow for two full-size humbuckers (HSH).  I've re-ordered these.  The sound and pickup is good and mellow.

If one is going to go for low price it should be expected the heavy quality won't be there. Since these come in well under 2 bucks apiece, I don't think anyone will complain because the metal may be a bit lighter than more expensive units that sell from $5 to $10 each.  For the price these work fine.  I can't say as to the longevity of the item, but for what these are and what they cost, no complaints.  I'll likely buy them again.

These are fast-blow fuses, designed to blow quickly before any circuit damage is done.  They live up to expectation.  The first fuse I use received a surge and blew instantly.  The second I installed handled the non-surge charge fine. I wouldn't recommend these for guitar amps as they're a little too sensitive.  But for applications that require fast clampdown, these work great.
Ordered the 15th. Received the 19th. Good quality fuses.  Work fine in my Fender amp.

I've tried several active (battery operated) preamps in the past.  Thus far this has been the poorest quality.  A friend who lives across country purchased this and had the same experience.This preamp easily clips (overdrives) to the point of distorting the music beyond audibility.  Volume levels have to be kept very low on instrument, Joyo preamp and amplifier.I have purchased several decent-quality preamps at half the cost, and a good one at the same cost.  This is the only premp that has clipped on a regular and excessive basis.You will need to provide your own 9v battery as none is included.
Set does not come with a hookup diagram, so I am adding one here. Photo uploader seems to have shrunk it a bit, so you'll need to download the photo and zoom in to get the details.

This wire is intended and advertised as "wrapping wire" and for such purpose works fine. However, it is equally good for the purpose for which I purchased it: fine wire work on audio electronics.* The wire itself is single-stand and thin yet holds shape well when bent.* The insulation is sufficient yet minimal thickness.* The metal solders easily and conducts current wellSome have mentioned difficulty stripping because of how thin it is. Stripping is actually rather easy if you know the secrets:1. Use a hobby knife, lightly score one side of the wire, pull off the end with your fingers or pliers.2. My preferred method: open a pair of good scissors slightly, insert the wire until it stops between the two blades, pull on the wire. The natural sharpness of the scissors should catch and pull the insulation right off. Using this method I've had no difficulty stripping 1/2" or more of insulation at a time.The insulation doesn't stick unduly to the wire and once it it sliced slides off easily.Good quality wire. Pleased with purchase except that order arrived late.

Good quality magnets shipped in an oversized plastic container.  Also included a detailed safety warning which contained information I had not read prior:* Dust from broken magnets is highly flammable* Burning neos can produce toxic fumes* Heat above 175F causes them to lose their magnetic charge* Neo magnets can interfere with pacemakers, as well as other magnetic-sensitive devices.  Keep 3 ft away from all such things.... lots of valuable info.  Good purchase

This is a gorgeous vintage-type single pickup with great tone.  I'm planning on making it the center single-pickup accompanied by a neck and bridge gold humbucker set... so the resulting sound should be an awesome mix of humbucker and lipstick bar.  Really looking forward to the final installation.  Visually it's pristine; comes wrapped in protective plastic and not scratch on it.  I'm actually surprised by the quality of sound and manufacture at this low cost.  I will definitely be ordering more of these.

This book relates the historical development of quantum mechanics, and should serve as a useful adjunct to quantum mechanics textbooks. I liked this book a lot and highly recommend it to physicists and students of physics, both those taking university courses and those seriously studying on their own.  However, I do not recommend the book for those with only a very limited knowledge of physics, because while no equations are presented the book is replete with somewhat in depth discussions of some of the finer points of the subject, particularly with regards to the interpretation of the Schrodinger wave equation, the meaning of the uncertainty principal and on the EPR experiment.  All this is best illustrated by discussing what is in this book.What is in the book The book discusses the development of quantum mechanics from 1900 to 2010, as depicted by 40 moments- critical junctures in time.  These 40 moments are divided into seven parts, as follows:Part I  Quantum of Action.  This part details the origin of the idea of quanta, first developed by Max Planck in 1900. It goes on to Einsteins application of Plancks ideas and to additional developments, up to 1925, including the work of Heisenberg, deBroglie and Schrodinger.  I found this to be a very entertaining and informative part or the book as it mixes basic ideas of physics with a bit of the biographies of the men who development them.  This approach is carried out throughout the book, with some biographical information accompanying the physics discussions.Part II  Quantum Interpretations.  This part of the book discusses the various interpretations of the meaning of quantum mechanics and the controversies that developed, covering the period of 1925-27.Part III  Quantum Debate  This part of the book further amplifies the debate about the meaning of quantum mechanics during the period of 1927-47.  It focuses on Einsteins reservations and his EPR thought experiment that sought to show that quantum mechanics, as it was formulated, was incomplete.Part IV  Quantum Fields  This part of the book, covering the period of 1947-67, focuses on the development of quantum field theory and quantum electro-dynamics.  I liked the development of Feynmans approach and how it compared to that of Schwinger and Tomonaga.  It also goes into the beginnings of the development of the quark model.Part V  Quantum Particles  This section deals with the development of the standard model, covering 1968-2003.  I found this and the preceding sections to be the most difficult when they delved into the ideas of group theory.  Part IV contains a good description of the relation of symmetry to basic conservation laws, but then the author jumps to group theory and then to its application to particle physics, but without explaining very much about group theory and even less about how it is applied to the problems of describing the interior of the atom and the interior of protons, neutrons and of the particles that are observed in accelerator experiments, some of which are also found in nature due to cosmic ray collisions.Part VI  Quantum Reality  I found the discussions of Bells theorem and Bells inequality to be excellent.  I learned that there are many version of the experiments meant to investigate this inequality and determine if reality is local or non-local, and that there are newer types of expressions of the sort that Bell developed that are being tested.  This part of the book covers the period of 1951- 2006.Part VII  Quantum Cosmology  This part of the book deals with quantum mechanics, its application to cosmology (especially through the work of Hawking) and to attempts to develop a theory that encompasses both gravity and the standard model for particle physics.  This part of the book covers these subjects from 1966-2000.  There is also a brief epilogue that discusses the search for the Higgs particle up to 2010.

I enjoyed this book and found that it helped to clarify the paradoxes discussed in this book (see below).  In doing so, it also provided a good overview of many of the conundrums that relativity theory and quantum mechanics have created.  I give this book 5-stars and recommend it to people, like myself (a retired research metallurgist with a long ago exposure to modern phyaics in graduate school and further reading since I have retired), which have some understanding of the ideas presented in this book, but with the reservation that those with little or no background in the subjects covered are likely to view the book less positively.What is in this book-This book discusses the most important paradoxes created by modern physics, plus two introductory chapters that discusses some logic paradoxes.  The chapters and their content are as follows:Chapter 1  The Game Show Paradox  Monty Hall and how his knowledge of what is behind the three curtains alters the odds when he lets a contestant switch from their initial choice to another one.Chapter 2  Achilles and the Tortoise  Classical paradoxes and how they are resolved.Chapter 3  Olbers Paradox  Why is the sky not covered with stars, making the nighttime as bright as the daytime?  The physics here is about the finite nature of the visible universe and the ideas concerning the beginning and expansion of the universe.Chapter 4  Maxells Demon  The physics of the second law of thermodynamics is discussed in this chapter.Chapter 5  The Pole in the Barn Paradox  - Special relativity and length contraction are discussed in this chapter.Chapter 6  The Paradox of Twins  This chapter focuses on special relativity and time dilation.Chapter 7  The Grandfather Paradox  This chapter focuses on relativity theory and the possibility of travel back in time that the theory allows for.Chapter 8  The Paradox of Laplaces Demon  This chapter deals with the ideas of a mechanically deterministic universe and free will.Chapter 9  The Paradox of Schrodingers Cat -  The basic paradox of Quantum Mechanics and the question of entanglement is discussed in this chapter.Chapter 10  Fermis Paradox -  Fermi asked - if there are aliens from other planets why havent they visited (at least as far as most people are concerned) or have given any indication of their existence?  The physics is about the possibilities of life on other planets.Chapter 11 - Remaining questions  These are not paradoxes, but questions which the author thinks will be answered in his lifetime, answered but not in the foreseeable future and questions that may never be answered.  This chapter is only 6-pages long and only lists the questions, but does not discuss them.

Note  this review is based on the 1976 first edition of this book.  Several more recent editions have been produced, but based on the page lengths, comments of other reviewers, and the publishers note that this book is republished every ten years; I believe that all of them are essentially the same.The title of this book is a bit misleading, since most of the people discussed in this book were neither mad in the legal sense or probably in a strict medical sense.  The book should have more accurately been called Fanatics of History, since all of the men and the one woman discussed were surly fanatics, even if their fanaticism did net rise to the strict level of madness, although the author defined their fanaticism as madness of a sort.  These people were generally characterized as having a difficult upbringing, one that made them loaners and often sadists.  This was then channeled into a cause, which they espoused fanatically, leading to their impacts on history.  Several were rulers; others were assassins or henchmen and mystics.  The book was interesting, although the author tended to focus on the goriest details, which I found unpleasant.  Given that there are 18 capsule biographies in 234 pages, the level of detail was a bit skimpy.  For the most part I found that the book was most useful as a guide to further reading, although the book contains no bibliography, notes or index.  Were partial stars allowed, I would have rated the book 3.5*, which I upgraded to 4*.The subjects covered were:Part I  Despots  Ivan the terrible, Alexander VI, Robespierre, Mussolini, Hitler, TrujilloPart II  Assassins  Booth, Guiteau, Czolgosz, Oswald, Corday, PrincipPart III  Hangmen, Henchmen & Mystics  Eichmann, Rasputin, Quantrill, Turner, Mishima, Torquemada

This book details the efforts of the US Navy to use submarines to learn what it could about the Soviet Navys capabilities, particularly those of their submarines, as well as their general capabilities and intentions.  The book details the successful efforts to tap Soviet undersea cables, follow their submarines and to learn as much as they could about them.  Since most of this information is still classified, the authors were forced to focus on events which have become part of the public record, particularly with regards to submarine mishaps and the sinking of several, including the USS Scorpion and the attempt to recover a sunken Soviet submarine.  The book clearly shows the dangers that the men who served on submarines (both of the US and USSR) experienced and of their sacrifices.  It shows how the US Navy strove to protect the US from the nuclear weapons that soviet submarines carried and how the Walker spy ring undermined this effort.  I enjoyed the book and found it very interesting and informative.  I recommend the book to anyone interested in US military history, military policy and the Cold War.In my opinion, this book not only gives one a flavor of what is was like to serve on a submarine during the cold war, but also provides valuable insights into other aspects of the US Navy  political infighting between it and the CIA, and between Naval Intelligence and the Nuclear Navy that controlled the nuclear submarines that it relied upon to gather information.  I also feel that the book also gave insights on the relations between the US and the USSR, and on the end of the Cold War.  The book contains a appendix listing known collisions between allied (US and British Royal Navy) submarines and those of the USSR.  There is also a brief appendix that provides the USSR Navys perspective on events and on actions that they were taking.  The book also has two very useful maps and over 30 black and white photographs printed on glossy paper, that show some of the people, submarines and equipment mentioned in the book.The story of the US Navys submarine intelligence gathering efforts ends in 1998, the year of publication of the book.  As is noted in the book, with the end of the Cold War these US intelligence-gathering efforts have shifted somewhat to the Middle East.  It would be interesting to know how the rise of blue water Chinese navy and of Russia under Vladimir Putin has altered this intelligence gathering effort.  However, as any information of this sort is surely highly classified I guess we will have to wait many decades more to find out what is going on now.

The great British military historian and military theorist, B. H. Liddell Hart, is the editor, not the author of this book.  He wrote a four-page introduction and a 25-page section on the Red Army in WWII, but the rest of the book is by other authors.  Some, like German Generals Guderian, von Manstein, Blumentritt and Student were leaders of the German army, likewise for General Weygand of the French Army.  Military historians and lower level officers of the Red Army wrote other articles.  The book covers the imperial czarist heritage of the Red army, and the Red army during the Red/White civil war and purges of the late 1930s, as well as during WWII and the period after the war, up to 1955 (just before the 1956 publication of this book).I found the chapters to be of varying quality.  Some were interesting and provided some insight into the Red Army, whereas I found others to be too general and unfocused.  All in all, I do not think that this is a book that provides much detailed analysis of battles, campaigns and military tactics.  These topics are covered, but only superficially, and for the most part I found that the book provided me with few new insights.  Some of this stems probably from the fact that the book was written only ten years after the end of the war, with the German generals still trying to make themselves and the German army look good, and with Soviet officers unwilling to criticize their superiors or the army tactics and behavior during the war.I would only recommend this book to students of military history.  I would not, however, recommend it to those who might purchase the book because of the fact that Liddell Hart is the purported author.  As noted, he was only the editor.  Were fractional ratings allowed I would have given the book 3.5 stars, but because they are not, I am rounding the rating up to 4-stars.

I like this sunscreen a lot, and  I use it on myself, and  I am well over 60 years of age.  It is initially a bit oily (it is oil based), but it rubs in and the oiliness disappears within about a minute, as does the initial white appearance that it produces.  When the tube arrived the ZnO had separated from the oil, but shaking and kneading the tube for a minute or so quickly remedied this. Likewise, I shake the tube before use to make sure that the ZnO is not separated. It is easy to tell if there has been any separation as you can hear and feel the oil in the tube if it has, and this disappears when the ZnO is properly mixed.  Note that there may be some variability in the degree to which a tube arrives with its contents completely mixed.  I have purchased three tubes and I had to mix two up, but the third arrived without any separation.  However the the tubes that I had to manually shake and kneed worked as well as the one that I did not have to do this to.

While George Washington is shown on the cover illustration, this book is not primarily about him.  He plays an important background role, but the book is more general in its treatment of espionage during the Revolutionary War.  The  book provides a lot of interesting reference material, and I recommend it as such to those who are seriously interested in the US Revolutionary War.  However, I would not recommend it to someone who is primarily interested in an exciting narrative history.  Rather than being a narrative history  one that tells history as a story, hopefully an engrossing story, this book is more of an outline of events with capsule biographies of participants.  The book is also quite dry and I found it very slow going.  One of the features that made this so, was the fact that the book is printed in 7 point typeface (I measured it).  Books are generally printed in 10 or 11-point typeface, which produces a lowercase letter o with a diameter of about 2mm, whereas a 7-point o is only about one mm in diameter.  The result was a typeface that was readable, but one that I could only tolerate for perhaps 30 minutes at a time.  Letters written by the characters discussed in the book were printed in 7 point italics, whose letters were the same size as the rest of the text, but the lines making up the letters were thinner, making them still more tiring to read.What is in the book The book describes the influence of spying, both by the Americans and by the British, on the conduct of Revolutionary War.  The war is described in terms of the military departments established by George Washington  the New England, Canadian, New York, Middle, Highlands, Northern, Eastern and Southern Departments.  A chapter is devoted to each department, containing an outline of the military events in that department throughout the whole war, plus short biographies of persons of interest whose live impacted the events described in that chapter, and finally ends with a brief summary of the material covered in the chapter.  I found the material to be interesting, but the presentation to be very dry.The book begins with two chapters devoted to overall intelligence operations of the American and British, followed by a chapter devoted to the command structures of the opposing forces.  These chapters are followed by a department-by-department discussion of the war and how it was impacted by intelligence operations. The last chapters are devoted to technology during the war and to codes and ciphers.  The book ends with an overall summary.I found a material in the book to be very useful, particularly the initial and final chapters that cover overall subject like how the British and American armies were organized and how technology such as the development of a primitive submarine and the use of smallpox inoculation was carried out.  The book was therefore a very useful reference book, whose utility outweighed the dry nature and small size of the text by enough for me to give the book four stars.

Two of eight of these bulbs have failed in 7 months of operation, whereas they are supposed to last for 23 years.  These bulbs were in a bathroom fixture and were in operation for far less than three hours a day.

Two of eight of these bulbs have failed in 7 months of operation, whereas they are supposed to last for 23 years.  These bulbs were in a bathroom fixture and were in operation for far less than three hours a day.

This is an interesting history of the US between 1900 and 1920.  I read this book because I am interested in the period and not because I was forced to for a college course.  I found the book to be interesting and I learned a lot.  However, being only 376 pages long the book was of necessity a bit superficial, but I feel did a very good job of explaining the period.  The emphasis was on Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson, and the progressive politics of this period.  While there is a lot on the politics of the period, the political conventions, the elections and the presidencies of  Roosevelt, Taft and Wilson, the book also contains other topics such as the social changes in the period, the struggle for civil rights, womens suffrage and the home front during WWI.While an academic text the book was far from dry and was written for students as opposed to scholars (there were no footnotes or bibliography, only an extensive section of suggested further readings).  I recommend this book to students and to anyone interested in US history.  It is a great starting point and the suggested readings allow one to get much deeper into the subject.

Entertaining, well written and informativeThis is a very well written book that does all that one can ask of a non-fiction history book - it provides a wealth of information in a very entertaining manner.As with "Team of Rivals", Doris Kerns Goodwin has produced a multiple biography - a biography of individuals whose lives interacted and enriched each other's. In the case of this book the lives are those of Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, their wives, and several members of the populist press, primarily Sam McClure, Ida Trabell, Lincoln Steffens, Ray Stannard Baker and William Allen White. The focus of the book in on how these progressive journalist influenced Roosevelt, Taft and the nation as a whole. While the book does not contain a detailed investigation of the complete lives of all those discussed in the book, it does contain enough to give the reader a good understanding of the character of these individuals and how they interacted with each other.I highly recommend this book to all lovers of history, biography, Teddy Roosevelt, William Howard Taft and the progressive movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

This is a focused biography of Theodore Roosevelt - focused on his hunting and environmental activism.  It covers the period from his birth to the end of his presidency.  The focus on his environmentalism is so great that more time is spent detailing each of his important camping and hunting trips than on events like his involvement in the Spanish-American war.  His tenure as a New York Police Commissioner is covered in about one page, whereas whole chapters are devoted to trips to Florida, Mississippi, and Texas in the quest to hunt and kill bears.  I mention this so that a potential reader is not mislead into thinking that this is a Theodore Roosevelt biography, that covers his environmental activism in addition to the rest of his accomplishments.  The book also provides thumbnail biographies important experts on birds, mammals and forests as well as hunting guides and other curious characters.I would recommend this book to people seriously interested in the US environmental activities in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.  I would only recommend this to people who are primarily interested in Roosevelt if they have previously read a more standard biography and if they are interested in all of the details concerning Roosevelt's camping and hunting trips, his books that discuss these trips, and his general expertise on birds and mammals.  I found the book interesting and it did supplement my understanding of Roosevelt, but after a while I became a bit numbed by the minute details that are covered.  I for one feel that the book would have been better at 400-600 pages of text instead of 800-pages.  While I read the entire book, after 500 pages I grew tired of the endless descriptions of Roosevelt's hunting trips, and his establishment of bird sanctuaries.  However, if you are seriously interested in Roosevelt's outdoors life you may find the length to be about right and not get bored by the excessive amount of detail that is provided.  If I could have, I would have rated the book at 3.5 stars, but giving it the benefit of the doubt I am giving it four stars.

Let me say at he outset that I hold 15 patents, so I know a little about the patent process, but not enough to write a patent on my own. I wish that I had had this book when I was working and filing patents, as it would have greatly aided in the process.  This book will not teach one to become a patent lawyer or agent, as that is not its aim.  The aim, which it fulfills nicely, is to educate an engineer, scientist or inventor in general, as to the patent process, so as to enable them to understand several critical concepts concerning the possible patentability of an idea or product.  The book describes: The current First to File rule vesus the older first to invent rule. The book discusses when an idea is ready for a patent and possible bars to patentability, such as the prior disclosure on the internet or in a technical paper. The book describes the importance of record keeping. It discussed if an idea or product novel enough for a patent? Challenges to a patent and when you might of might not want to go to court are also discussed. Different patent strategies are discussed. The book also covers trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets.I found this book to be very useful and recommend it to anyone interested in possibly patenting an idea or product.

This book details Teddy Roosevelt's reactions to WWI and his conflict with the Wilson administration over its policies.  The book is largely based on Roosevelt's speeches, letters and publications during the period, and it provides much more detail than that provided in other books.  I would recommend this book to anyone seriously interested in the Roosevelt, and the history of the US entry into WWI.  However, the casual reader who has only a general interest in these subjects may find the book a bit too focused.What is in the book:The book is chronological in its approach, starting with Roosevelt's return from the Amazon in 1914, and ending with his death in 1919.  The main points are: Roosevelt believed that Germany was the aggressor because of its invasion of Belgium.  Roosevelt understood why all the states of Europe went to war, and had Germany not invaded Belgium, in violation of treaties that they had signed, he might have wanted the US to remain neutral in spite of a his personal pro-British bias. Roosevelt was strongly opposed to Wilson's  apportioning blame for the war equally among all of the combatants, whereas Roosevelt felt that Germany's invasion of Belgium clearly made them the aggressor. He opposed Wilson peace initiatives as Wilson believed that all sides were equally at fault and Roosevelt believed that this placed the conquered Belgians on a par with their conquers, who were also guilty of war crimes. Roosevelt was opposed to Germany's use of submarine warfare as he considered it murder. Roosevelt felt that Wilson's relatively weak condemnation of early German submarine sinkings led to the sinking of the Lusitania, and that Wilson's response to the sinking of the Lusitania was completely inadequate. He felt that the US was completely unprepared for war and attacked Wilson for not gearing up for a possible US involvement. He wanted to be allowed to lead a volunteer force to supplement the soldiers who were drafted after the US entered the war, but Wilson had no intention of making Roosevelt an hero and stronger candidate in 1920. The book details Roosevelt's attacks on Wilson and on the counter attacks by the Wilson administration and the Hearst papers.  The book discuses the Wilson administration attempts of muzzle him and of Wilson's attack against a free press. The book discusses the fighting of the Roosevelt sons and of Teddy Roosevelt's death.

This is an interesting and very well written  Teddy Roosevelt biography, covering his life from  birth to  death, but one that focuses on his relationship with New York City. The thesis of the book is that Roosevelt was shaped by New York City and rather than being the "cowboy" president, he was actually the New York City President, and was the only President who was born in, lived in, and was shaped by the city.  (His cousin Franklin was shaped more by his upstate Hudson River home, and was not as associated with New York City as was Teddy.) I enjoyed the book a lot and recommend it to anyone interested in Teddy Roosevelt, New York city and 19th century US history.What is in the book?The book does an excellent job of depicting the city during Roosevelt's life.  It discuses how the city impacted his childhood, Roosevelt's early political experiences in the New York Assembly, his time as a police commissioner and as governor.  The book also briefly discusses Roosevelt's time at Harvard, as a Rough Rider in Cuba and as president, although these parts of the book are very brief.  The book goes into detail concerning Roosevelt's conflicts with the Republican Party boss Thomas Collier Platt and of how Platt impacted Roosevelt's career.

This book covers Theodore Roosevelts 1913-14 expedition down a river, the River of Doubt, to determine its course and if it was a river feeding into the Amazon.  The book is well written and highly informative.  One not only learns a lot about the expedition, but also a lot about the Amazon  how it was formed, the plants, animals and men who lived in or near it, and about the explorers who braved its dangers to learn more about it.  I recommend this book to anyone interested it Theodore Roosevelt, the Amazon and to anyone who likes an exciting true story.

This is an interesting book that is aimed at those interested in naval history, particularly the naval history of the US. It is a detailed account of the round the world voyage of the US "Great White" fleet, from December 1917 to February 1919. It discusses the voyage, the stops that the ships made and the reasons why TR sent the fleet on this voyage, namely: as a fleet exercise to improve the fleet's readiness and capabilities to demonstrate the its ability to sail from the Atlantic to the Pacific and arrive ready to fight demonstrate to the Japanese that the US was prepared to defend its Pacific territories and commitments in that part of the world to illustrate the need for the Panama Canal, which was under construction to demonstrate to the people of the US and the rest of the world that the US had arrived as a world powerMost of the book is spend on the details of the trip and the ports that were visited. I feel that the book is to be of most interest to those with a specific interest in naval affairs as opposed to a general audience.

This book contains all 18 chapters of Tarbells original work, but each chapter has been condensed by about half from the original, which was published in two volumes.  The History of the Standard Oil Company was a compilation of articles that appeared in McClures magazine in the early 1900s. They were instrumental in the ultimate breakup of the Standard Oil Company into its constituent parts. The book is interesting, but should be read in the context of the history of the time and of the overall biography of John D. Rockefeller. I would recommend that anyone who is seriously interested in the subject read Ron Chernows biography of Rockefeller entitled Titan. Chernow puts Tarbells work into its proper context and provides valuable information on her and on the book. For instance, Tarbells brother was a founder and officer of the Pure Oil Company, a major competitor of Standard Oil. Tarbell praises Pure Oil, but neglects to mention her family connection to it, or that she might be less than an unbiased reporter with respect to Standard Oil.Tarbell provides the complete history of Standard Oil, focusing of its railroad rebates, which she believed were instrumental in it obtaining a monopoly on the refinement in US oil in the 19th century, contributing to the business failures of many men, including her father, another fact that she neglects to mention. That Standard Oil was a monopoly is clear, as was its use of railroad rebated to lower its cost of transporting crude oil to its refineries and kerosene from the refineries to its customers. The central part of the book is Tarbells contention that such rebates were illegal as the railroads were common carriers. She neglects, however, to provide Rockefellers position that these rebates were not illegal by statute and were justified by his larger volume of shipments, which reduced the railroads costs.

This is truly one of the easiest computer devices that I have ever setup.  The instructions are on the cover of the box and are all that were needed.  The setup was truly plug and play and took less than five minutes.I was anxious to use a new router because my wife is always having problems with her I-pad disconnecting from the Internet.  This router was somewhat less prone to do this than our previous one, but did not completely eliminate the problem, which I am now convinced is more of a problem with out Internet provider than any wireless connection.  So far I am very satisfied with the router, the range is good and it is working well.I have, however, two complaints, but not  serious ones.  Unlike my old  router, this one does not have an on/off switch for the WiFi, which allows me to use a hardwired Internet connection to my desktop computer, while not transmitting a WiFi signal to my laptop and I-pad.  I found this to be a feature that I sometimes used and miss.  My second complainant is more of an annoyance, than a functional problem.  This router uses a very large AC/transformer plug, which is so large that it takes up three spaces on the terminal strip that I have to use in order to plug in all my equipment.  An annoyance and one easily overcome, but annoying nonetheless.  The input to the router from the transformer plug was also a bit smaller than the one that I had been using previously, so I could not use that somewhat smaller AC/transformer plug, which output the same voltage, so I had to modify my system to accommodate this larger AC/transformer plug.

This small book (103 pages of double column text) was published in 1955, but all but one of the selections was considerably older.  The book consists of 10 short articles, that are listed below.- J.A. Hobson, Imperialism, written in 1938 but was an updated version of an even earlier article.- William Langer, A Critique of Imperialism, was written by William Langer in 1935.- Charles A. Beard, Territorial Expansion Connected with Commerce, written in 1934.- Julius W. Pratt, American Business and the Spanish-American War, written in 1934.- Joseph E. Wisan, The Cuban Crisis as Reflected in the New York Press, written in 1934- Richard Hofstadter, Manifest Destiny and the Philippines, written in 1952.- Henry Cabot Lodge, The Philippine Inlands, a speech before the Senate in 1900 supporting the US holding on to the Philipines.- Carl Schurz, American Imperialism, Address given in 1899 opposing US imperialism.- Samuel F. Bemis, The Great Aberration of 1898, written in 1936.- Tyler Dennett, The Philippines, written in 1922.Most of the articles were written in the 1930s or earlier and only one was written as late as 1952.  While old, these articles do present a balanced picture of the early 20th century view of imperialism.  The article by Hobson is distinctly Marxist in tone and is refuted by the articles by Langer and Beard.

This book is a valuable and important addition to the literature of WWII.  It is very well written, but often difficult to read because of the subject matter.  Difficult to read or not, this is an important book to read as it details the beginnings of the Holocaust.  The author's research is compelling and the story he tells is likewise compelling and extremely important.  I recommend this book to anyone who wants an important insight into the Holocaust, and Germany in WWII.The prologue of the book begins at the Nuremberg Tribunal at the end of WWII, with the presentation of evidence of one of the earliest of Nazi crimes.  The evidence was of the 1933 murder of four Jewish detainees at Dachau, as compiled by a Munich prosecutor, Joseph Hartinger, later in 1933.  This book is the story of the murders that Hartinger uncovered and his attempts to get justice for the victims.  It is the story of an extremely brave and highly principled man who was willing to stand up to what was evolving as a brutal and murderous regime.  The book is important because it shows that there were men willing to stand up to the Nazis, but that there were not enough of them. The Nazi regime was in its infancy and had enough people stood up they might have been able to avert what was to come.  The book details how Hartinger's investigation and quest for justice were derailed.  It also discusses the earliest concentration camps and the evolution of what was to become the Holocaust.

My seven-year-old grandson loves this Mega Blocks set.  He has been building with many Mega Blocks and Lego sets and this is a great addition to them.  This set provides instructions and pieces for eight racecars, but with some imagination one can build their own design.  This fosters the skill of following instructions and also fosters creativity.  The pieces were typical of Mega Blocks, they snapped together reasonably well, but in some cases did require considerable force.I liked the set but two features have prevented me from giving it five-stars.  The box shows a racetrack, but none is included with the set.  This was no problem for my grandson as he has built several tracks from different kits, but I feel that it is misleading to picture something on the box that does not come in the box.  All the pieces come in separate bags, but the pieces are for all of the cars, not just for a single car.  This meant that all of the bags had to be opened to build the cars, adding to the complication for the build and the mess of having to content with almost 300 pieces at the outset.

This is the final book in the three-volume biography of Theodore Roosevelt by Edmond Morris.  Although it covers a somewhat less important period of Roosevelt's life, it is a worthy companion to the other two volumes. The book is well written, interesting, informative, and it held my attention. We see how Roosevelt struggled to remain relevant to the US after his presidency.  We see his decline, both physically and in terms of his ability to shape events, and we see his struggles to try to regain power and influence.The book details his trips to Africa and the Amazon and his futile attempt to gain the 1916 Republican nomination for president.  It discusses his personal life, his illnesses and decline, his reactions to WWI, to the death of his son Quentin in the war and finally there is a poignant chapter on his own death.

This is an oil based, 20%ZnO sunscreen.  I found that it went on with much less drag than other ZnO sunscreens that I have used.  It has a very slight scent, but it dissipated quickly and was not objectionable.  It was white out of the tube and for the first instance on the skin, but the whiteness completely disappeared when I rubbed in the sunscreen. While the oil base made the product a bit greasy when I first applied it, this disappeared within a few minutes.When the tube arrived the ZnO had separated from the oil, but shaking and kneading the tube for a minute or so quickly remedied this.  Likewise, I shake the tube before use to make sure that the ZnO is not separated.  It is easy to tell if there has been any separation as you can hear and feel the oil in the tube if it has, and this disappears when the ZnO is properly mixed.  I do question the SPF50 rating, as similar products are only SPF30. I use this for my face and I wear a hat, so I cannot tell exactly how effective the product actually is.

I like this kit on two levels, it was fun to operate the machines when they were built and it was very educational to build them.What I liked - the instructions were pictorial and relatively clear, but it still required patience to follow them- you can build 20 different things following the instructions and more if you choose to be creative- the remote control motors actually worked and my grandson had a lot of fun operating the things that were builtCaveats - I think that it is a bit of a stretch to put the lower age limit at 8-years of age. My eight-year old grandson worked on building these models, but it required more than a little adult help. His sister, an eleven-year-old, had no trouble building things, and only needed a bit of help when she made a mistake and had to backtrack, but this was part of the learning experience.All in all, definitely five-stars, especially for an older child, and for a younger one if you are willing to help quite a bit.

UPDATE  - This bulb stopped working after 11 months of operation, whereas it was supposed  to last 23 years.  I have therefore down-rated it from five to one stars.  Also, two of eight LED bulbs of this exact type from Sylvania OSRAM failed in only 7 months, leading me to believe that either the quality control for LED bulbs is poor throughout the industry, or that the industry greatly overstates the life of the bulbs.  I do not think that their short lifetimes warrant the high prices being charged when these bulbs are not on sale.I like LED spotlight bulbs as replacements for incandescent and compact fluorescent (CF) bulbs.  LED light sources are point light sources and are excellent for a spotlight or flashlight application, but I had my doubts as to their applicability for an omni-directional bulb.  I was therefore delighted to see that this bulb has been engineered to give excellent omni-directional light of the sort that I would expect from an old fashioned incandescent bulb, or the newer CF bulbs.  The color is the equivalent of a 2700-Kelvin light source, that is to say that it gives off a warm yellow glow.  Being an LED source, the bulb contains no mercury and is therefore not the threat to the environment that a CF bulb is when it is improperly disposed of.  While LED bulbs are more expensive than CF bulbs, the fact that they will not poison the environment with mercury makes them, in my opinion, a much better replacement for the energy wasting incandescent bulb.  This bulb gives the equivalent light (800 lumens) as a 60-watt incandescent bulb, but requires only 10 watts of power.  It is heaver than the equivalent incandescent or compact fluorescent bulb, but fits into the standard A19 base used by a 60-watt bulb. The outer shell of the bulb appears to be plastic, so it may be less prone to breaking if is dropped. I RECOMMEND THESE BULBS ONLY WITH THE WARNING THAT THEY MAY NOT LAST AS LONG AS ADVERTISED. This would be a great bulb if it lived up to its advertised life.

I liked this inflator. Note  the advertising literature states that the extension hose is optional, which made me think that it was something that you had to purchase separately, but this is fortunately NOT the case  it comes with the unit. I found that the inflator worked as advertised and had some nice design features, and I am now carrying it in my trunk.Features The inflator has a light at the tip It has a chuck design to attach to the tire valve stem. It comes with a four-inch extension air hose and attachments for inflating beach balls, etc, all of which store nicely in the handle of the inflator. The inflator comes with an unpadded bag for storage, but not being padded it does not give any protection to the unit.How did it work? Attaching the chuck directly to the valve stem was difficult, making it necessary to use the four-inch valve stem attachment. I found this extension optional only in the sense that it might be possible to inflate a tire without it, but I think that it is actually quite necessary. It was impossible for me to read the pressure gauge when I tried to connect directly to the tire valve with the chuck. I could, however, read the gauge when I used the four-inch extension, but not easily. A longer extension would have made this easier. The four-inch extension uses a screw-in connection to the valve stem, as opposed to a quick connect, so I found that I had to connect to the tire valve first and then connect the extension connection to the inflator using the chuck connection. The dial indication gives only an approximate tire inflation value, and I agree with other reviewers that the pressure drops when the inflator is turned off. I also agree, that the inflator labored to get the pressure to over about 20-25psi, but this should be good enough in a emergency get to a service station. The pressure indicator goes to 150psi, but frankly I think that this is wishful thinking on the part of the manufacturer.All in all, this is a nice unit for inflating things like snow blower tires, beach balls and a car tire in an emergency, or if the pressure is low. I have found that if a tire is completely flat, the tire might not be contacting the rim, making it necessary to jack up the car to remove the weight of the car from the tire, allowing it to contact the rim and then seal when the tire is inflated.

This is a good basic vacuum.  It lacks some of the features of more high-end machines but does a good job at vacuuming.  The vacuum is a bagless wind tunnel type machine with a HEPA filter system, with clear plastic dirt cup, with the following attributes:Pros: I would rate the vacuuming as very good, the motor was loud, but not excessively so.  There are settings for hardwood floors and four carpet heights. The capacity of the dirt cup was sufficient to vacuum a large room, and even more depending upon the amount of dirt that was collected.  Emptying the cup and replacing it on the machine was simple, but as with all machines of this type, you have to be careful when emptying the dirt cup to insure that dirt does not fall out onto the floor. The machine has a hose and wand system plus attachments for doing chairs, drapes, and hard-to-reach places on carpets, and I found these to work as well as those of any of the other vacuums that I own. The wand and all the attachments can be stored on the unit itself. The vacuum is very easy to assemble out of the box.  One needs only to remove a single screw, insert the handle, and replace the screw. Then the machine is ready to go once the dirt cup is in place and a plastic holder for the powered hand tool is popped into place (no tools required) - that is, if you want to store this attachment on the machine.Features that this basic unit lacks.  (I do not consider these as negative features, just as tradeoffs for a less expensive machine.) This vacuum lacks a ball or other pivoting device, so it is not as maneuverable as the more high-end models that have these features.  However, while not quite as maneuverable, it was maneuverable enough to get the job of vacuuming done. There is no automatic carpet height adjustment, so when you go from a hardwood floor to a carpet, or from carpets of different pile heights, you have to bend down to adjust for this.  The adjustment is done via a knob as opposed to a slider bar.  I have a much more expensive machine that has such an automatic feature, but it does not work all that well, and the beater bar does not work on some pile heights, so I do not mind the lack of an automatic adjustment. To some degree, I prefer the manual adjustment, but I do not enjoy having to bend down to make it.  If you are to use the vacuum mostly on carpets of a single pile height, then the lack of an automatic adjustment is not a problem and may be a plus. There is no automatic cord retraction system.  Many people like a cord retraction system and when they work, so do I.  However, it does add a bit of weight to the machine and is another thing that can malfunction, and when they do, you may be left with an unusable short cord or a long one with no place to rewind it on the machine.

Thanksgiving update - This knife was the best of all the knives that were used to carve a turkey and slice a roast beef.I am not a professional chef or a knife expert, so I am rating this knife from the standpoint of the general kitchen user, and I found the following:Pros - This knife had a nice balance and the soft grip made it easy to hold without slipping - a great plus.  This knife is great for things like slicing meat, but its 8-inch length makes it a bit cumbersome for jobs where a shorter knife might be a bit more appropriate.  However, if you want a shorter knife OXO makes a 6-inch model that except for the length is similar to this one. Reasonably sharp out of the package.  I had no problems cutting meat and soft tomatoes.Minor Concerns - This knife was extremely difficult to remove from its plastic packaging.  Ordinarily I would not even mention this, but this is dangerous when dealing with a sharp knife that has no protection inside of the plastic case, so that if you slip in removing the knife you could be severely injured. The knife does not come with a protective case or sheath.  I realize that expensive knives do not necessarily come with a sheath or protective case (except for transporting them), as it is sacrilege not to store a knife in an oak block, ready for their use.  However, this is not an expensive knife and I no longer use my oak blocks because they take up too much counter space, and I do not have a magnetic wall knife holder.  Many of my knives do come with a sheath of some sort so that you can store the knife in a draw, which is how I store them, which is fine for my purposes.  I therefore had to make a sheath out of the cardboard insert in the package that the knife came with, but I should not have had to this.

My experience has been exactly the opposite of the one-star reviews; my machine was very loud, but had a reasonable amount of suction.  This makes me wonder if there was something wrong with the units that people complained had no suction, but were very quiet.  All in all, this unit does what it was designed to do, but is very loud.  I am quite satisfied with its performance for doing things like vacuuming my car and stairs, but the unit is definitely not a good choice if you it want primarily as a carpet cleaner, which in all fairness is not what it was primarily designed to do.Pros - Relatively light weight and easy to handle Reasonable amount of suction, but not as much as a full-size corded unit Good for specialized tasks like stair cleaning, in fact the lack of a cord makes this unit ideal for that task.  It is also good for picking up crumbs and the like. The unit comes with several attachments, all of which fit into the wand, but can also be used without it. Easy to charge and clean. The unit comes with two plastic caps that you have to snap into the charging base in order to hold two of the tools.  If you put the pet hair tool over the crevice tool you can get all three tools to fit on the charging base.
