In twenty five years a small pin-headed sized piece of the white coating on the hour hand has flaked off but it is of no consequence. The woven fabric band is plain and simple - and Ive worn out one and am on my second band in a quarter century. Battery life is extremely long and I think Ive changed batteries every eight years.Overall, this is the only watch you will ever need. I bought this watch 25 years ago from a Swiss Army retailer.

They securely cover and protect the pitot tubes on the club Cessna just fine. They are long and bright and impossible to miss. We've had them for a year and used them through last winter and they still look like new. I bought these at  the pilot shop at our field.

I use these bulbs in two table lamps and so far they have been acceptable. The light is bright and comfortable and the color is not a harsh white. They dont create an interfering buzzing noise in a nearby AM radio as some other LED bulbs have done.There are a couple of negatives about them:- After it has been on for a while, the main part of the bulb itself remains cool but the plastic insulated bottom gets very hot to the touch. This is not good for an LED bulb. This also means it can be used only in a base-down position. I would not use these in a desk lamp or ceiling fixture because they may cause problems with the socket and the bulb itself.- There is a warning not to use these bulbs with a timer. Occasionally I must use a timer on some lights so this is a disappointment. Another brand of LED bulb I use does not have this warning and works just fine with a timer.Overall, these are fair and economical bulbs but I wont be using more of them. I bought these Greenlite bulbs when they were on sale at my local hardware store.

This is a real Nokia battery and was a direct replacement for the dying, unchargeable Nokia battery in my ancient, 9-year old Nokia emergency cell phone:-it takes a full charge in about four hours-it keeps the charge for about seven days with the phone on standby 4 hours a dayThis is an economical replacement. It does not seem to have the capacity of the original BL-6C Nokia battery that came with my cell phone when it was new, but since these batteries appear to have been out of production for a while this is an adequate and economical replacement.

We have used two of these for over a year and they are perfect for cats.  They dont tip over, they are very easy to clean, and the rubber ring on the bottom keeps them from sliding on a smooth floor.My only quibble is that after six months the rubber ring on one of them broke during washing and the other is starting to split. But even without the ring, the bowl doesnt move around much.I bought these bowls at a local supermarket.

I love this grater. I bought this from Amazon years ago and Ive used it at least once a week since then  and its still as sharp and easy to use as it was in the beginning.  Its easy to use and if I have problems with an exceedingly hard cheese like Pecorino Romano, I just brace the end of the microplane on the counter top and grate away. The result is a fine, thin grating that makes the cheese easier to use in baking recipes or pasta.Grating ginger is a snap if the ginger is first hard frozen.  Garlic can be a little messy  it grates as a paste than anything else, but its still good! Zesting oranges or lemons is easy and takes only a couple of seconds.Though the blades are sharp, cleanup is simple and easy. Clean the grate side with a soapy sponge by wiping up along the blades NOT down and across them. Its also dishwasher safe.For large pieces of cheese that would be impractical to cut I use the larger Microplane 38000 Professional Coarse Grater.Both these tools have a place in my kitchen

Just about all TOBS shaving creams are top-notch and this rose scented shaving cream is one of the best.  Like all the other TOBS creams just a small dab on a wet brush is enough to fully lather up for a full shave. It sets up the whiskers and lets you get a smooth, close shave without having to go over the same patches of skin more than once.There are emollients and softeners in the cream so theres no harshness or sting after you shave. The rose scent is very pleasant while you shave but rinses off when you are finish and you are scent-free.  The cream itself doesnt clog the razor and easily rinses completely off. It is a little thicker than the other TOBS shaving creams and needs just a little more hot water on the brush to make a good, creamy lather.This is one of the best shaving creams available. I also like to use Taylor of Old Bond Street Almond Shaving Cream.

While this wedge doesnt make wood splitting a lot of fun it sure makes it easier.  I use it primarily to split 18-24 cut wood into halves or quarters and it works well. I have no problem in splitting everything from cedar to ash and oak. Normally I use a DR power log splitter, but to split fireplace wood this wedge and a maul is a bit faster to split the right size (and good exercise for me).I bought these at a local hardware store  prices vary so shop around. I have many Truper tools because they are economical and rugged and are designed to make work easier.

Its a nice looking chess board but the letters and numbers are imperfectly embossed into the board and are really almost sloppy.  The chess pieces are NOT weighted as claimed in the advertising and are very light. The round pieces of felt glued to the bottoms of many of the pieces are misaligned and glued on crookedly. The interior storage area is thin molded plastic with a spray-on flocking instead of felt. The locking clasps that hold the board together when closed are tiny and actually are dollhouse size and quality  they are there for looks rather than utility.Overall, its a nice looking board but more for display rather than giving it some heavy use.  We wont be using it for fast timed games where pieces can get quickly shoved around.  The board is a bit of a disappointment.

This is the best tasting tea you can buy. Ive always been a strong coffee drinker and my family members are tea drinkers. They got me to try this tea and it just blew me away. The taste is satisfying and actually rich  something I never thought a tea could taste like.  After drinking too much coffee during the day I have a cup of PG Tips at night with a splash of milk and sugar. Its delicious.Its a lot better than any of the black teas you get off the shelf in a supermarket.

An excellent electric blanket and its much more convenient than the smart blankets that just warm you around your body.  The bed is actually WARM when you get into it on a cold night! The blanket itself is light but has a thick plush pile that is very, very soft and comfortable to the touch. Its nice to have a good warm blanket and coverlet in the winter instead of having to use a large comforter or quilt.The twin controllers each regulate the heat on either side of the blanket so that I can keep the heat setting comfortably high on my side and my wife can keep it comfortably low on her side.  With 20 heat settings its easy to set a precise comfortable heat. And the pre-heat setting actually works (unlike some other blankets weve used) and warms the bed for 30 minutes before reverting to the setting I like to use.Over the years weve tried several other brands of electric blankets and most of them were pretty good but failed after a season or two and certainly werent as warm as this one. We should have gone back to the old reliable Sunbeam brand years ago.

This pouch is STURDY, water repellent, and flexible and I can easily tote around hearing aids and a spare card of batteries. The interior has a slightly padded soft lining and really protects the hearing aids. It securely locks up with a Velcro patch and keeps everything protected.I use over-the-ear hearing aids and when it rains I take them off so they dont get wet and ruined  this case really protects them and I feel confident that they are safe. It fits easily into my shirt pocket and I always carry it with me.

Well, its sort of like a Sonic Screwdriver but its delicate and flimsy.  It is a keychain and the Sonic Screwdriver itself is about 4-inches long and the chain and ring adds another 2-inches so youll have a 6-inch keychain in your pocket. Kind of bulky. The casing fell apart on me after carrying it in my pocket for a month. The LED light is bright but the button is easily pressed and sometimes it accidentally turned on in my pocket and this didnt do much for battery life.Its thoroughly impractical. Its not much good as a keychain or as a toy.  The only thing to do with it is stick it on a shelf with any other Dr. Who collectibles you have. Right on the package it says, not intended for use by children  - or adults either for that matter.

This is good Channellock quality and I frequently use it to maintain wire and electrical fencing. Its easy to grip pull staples and pound them in. The tail is a little thick for popping staples out so you have to grip and pull them to get enough clearance. You can crimp, twist and splice and cut electric wire quickly and easily. The hammerhead is heavier than others and makes it easy to whack staples into posts.When I walk around to inspect fencing this is the one tool I stick in my back pocket. I dont have to take a box of tools with me. I bought these at a local hardware store. Prices vary so you may want to shop around.

I mainly use this for two tasks: to strip paint with high heat and to seal shrink-wrap on jars of honey with low heat and with the variable heat setting it works extremely well on both.  It's sturdy and lightweight.Stripping layers of paint is pretty simple. I fan the gun back and forth on a high temp setting and scrape away.  The gun isn't heavy and there is no fatigue after using it for long periods.Sealing corked bottles of honey with shrink-wrap is also simple on a low to mid heat setting and I can do 25 bottles a minute with no problem. The temperature is stable and delicate shrink-wrap heats and tightens very quickly with no damage.When setting it on its back for hands-free operation the gun is solid and secure and there's no fear of it falling over. Even if it did fall over it's well enough protected so that nothing hot will ever touch the worktable. You can work with it and just lay it down on the table when you have to.Over the years this is the third heat gun I've bought and so far it's the best one. It's the usual Porter-Cable good quality. I bought this at a local hardware store. Prices can vary, so shop around.

I've been using a Garmin GPS system for years and finally bought this one because of the free lifetime map upgrades.  It's much better than my previous nvi 265W.  The display is larger, the recalculations are much faster, and there is more optional detail displayed as far as conveniences on the road (restaurants, rest stops, ATMs, etc) and that makes a BIG difference to me when traveling.Maps load faster and upcoming turns display in a much clearer manner - my previous GPS was confusing sometimes when an upcoming turn suddenly appeared on the map and I was already halfway past it. Frustrating!  This model doesn't do that and the map turns are prominent and display well ahead of time.Battery life is much longer and using it as a hand-held lasts for a couple of hours - with my previous GPS I was lucky if it lasted 30 minutes before the battery drained.The one thing I don't like is the semi-permanent ball mount.  It's inconvenient and difficult to remove the unit from the ball mount when it's attached to the windshield glass (I remove it from sight when I park since I don't want it to tempt a thief).  The old unit had a snap-in frame that was simple and easy to use. I wish they had kept the same design for this one.So, overall, this is a very good GPS indeed. It's faster, the display is clearer, and there is much more optional and handy information available.

Nice, comfortable wrap-around glasses with side lenses for terrific field of vision.  They are snug against my face and filter all sunlight with no problem. The lenses have no distortion and are large enough to give me good vision while driving. I use a head strap with them when riding a motorcycle.I even bought a pair for a friend who had cataract surgery because he didn't like the sunglasses the clinic gave him - he thought they made him look like an "old man."  But these are really super cool looking and he's happy with them.They really are wrap-arounds and don't fold flat - that's why there is a supplied microfiber carry bag instead of a hard case and the big advantage is that the microfiber bag can be used to wipe the glasses clean if they get dusty or smeared.

This is sort of a good book to introduce shortwave listening to new listeners, and the introductory chapters are well done.  The "Getting Started" chapter by Ken Reitz was originally published in 2002 but the basic ideas and techniques described still hold.Some of the band descriptions are outdated - the "tropical" bands are pretty much dead now and the 40-41 meter broadcasters have long since moved on to other bands and there is no "mess" on those frequencies. There are nice intros to utility and digital monitoring and a handy chart of service allocations right up to 30 MHz.  Even though this is the Summer 2015 edition, there are a number of references to the winter edition and I can only attribute this to sloppy or lazy editing.The general guide lists shortwave broadcasts by time slots from midnight to midnight with no separate listings breaking out region or country. With computerized listings it would have been simple for the editors to sort out and create separate listings by language, target area, and country and this lack makes it a little more difficult than necessary for the user to find certain broadcasts.Probably the handiest part of the book is the Internet Resource Guide which gives the URLs of a LOT of shortwave broadcasters and this may be the very best way for shortwave listeners to find broadcast schedules of the countries they want to hear.Generally speaking, despite some outdated information this is a decent introduction to shortwave listening but should not be considered the very best information available.

This is a great lantern for casual use. It's a dual use lantern - I use it to illuminate my way along paths at night and I can use to read outside by flipping it up to directly light the table. The light is not blinding but is plenty bright for regular illumination where I don't need a flashlight or bright spotlight. It has come in handy during a few wintertime power blackouts (not uncommon in northern Vermont) and provided decent light to get around in a room.It's pretty weatherproof too. It's been left in a gazebo and it's gotten wet, covered with snow, and frozen and it still works just fine.  It's a very handy light. I keep one by the back door and one in the emergency box.I bought these at a big box store - prices vary so shop around.

I bought this LED flashlight almost five years ago and with Duracell alkalines I have replaced the batteries only once in all that time. The light is exceedingly bright and white for two LEDs and it is small and weighs only about five ounces. It is a little less than six inches long but comfortably fits in the hand like a regular flashlight. The two molded-in lenses on the front of the flashlight magnify and keep a nice focused beam. At a distance of ten feet, the beam is two feet wide and bright.I would not use it for trying to illuminate something more than 25 feet away because the intensity of the beam falls off dramatically, but for regular use in the house or garage it is absolutely perfect.I bought this light at my local hardware store. Prices vary so you may want to shop around.

Each of these moisturizers has a lovely scent that's not overpowering and the lotion easily rubs into the skin and the moisturizing lasts a long time.  The person I gave them to is happy about that because she doesn't have to frequently reapply the lotion to her hands as she does with her other favorite moisturizing lotion. She said it leaves no residue and is not sticky or greasy and rubs right into the skin with no problem.The Sandalwood is a strong scent, while the Orange Blossom Honey, Lavender and Beeswax, and Pomegranate and Honey are nice and delicate.  The six tube sample pack gave her the opportunity to try all "flavors" of these lotions and she's been able to pick out favorites (Orange Blossom Honey and Unscented) and now she'll be buying those particular Naked Bee moisturizers in larger quantities for herself.I bought these as a little birthday gift for a relative and she was very, very pleased with them.  These do not come in a box but are loosely shipped in a plastic bag so be prepared to wrap them in a bundle or in your own box if you give these as a gift.

This is a very handsome mug with bright colors and at 13 ounces holds a good cup of coffee. I bought this for a woman who is a beekeeper and she got a huge kick out of it and her family thinks the "Queen Bee" on the mug is exactly right. Even the box it came in had black and yellow bee stripes.The only quibble is that it seems a tad fragile and I hope it lasts with regular use.

Hands down, this is the best fat free ranch dressing available. It really tastes like regular ranch and the consistency is thick and creamy. I always go for low-fat/non-fat foods and this is my number one salad dressing.Just one thing I am a careful about with this dressing: in serving of two tablespoons there are 220mg of sodium - and that's about 10% of recommended DAILY intake. It's high, but at 50 calories and only 11g of carbs it's great as long as you keep this in mind.I buy this at my local supermarket  - prices vary tremendously so you may want to shop around.

Bought this for a friend's dog and he (the dog) really has a lot of fun with it. He especially likes the rope end to bite on and pull in a tug-of-war game. He loves to fetch it too. So far we haven't had any of the noted problems with the rope ends coming loose although I can see where the rope ends are taped together inside the knotted turns. He's a middling sized dog (30 lbs) so shouldn't put too much stress on it but we'll keep an eye on it. Bought this at a big-box store but Amazon is a tad more economical.

It's very easy to keep a dog clean smelling fresh with this shampoo. I just spray it on him, work it into his fur, then towel him off... and I have a clean, good smelling dog!  Then after a good brushing his coat it smooth and really good looking. Since I normally don't bathe him except once a year (unless there's something really bad he rolled around in) this is a great way for me to keep him clean, looking good, and smelling good. Since it's a nice mild waterless shampoo, it won't irritate any hotspots or rashes.

I have always read Renata Adler because she writes the truth. This is a good collection that has some of the best articles she has written and even though some of them go back as far as the 1970s, they always seem fresh. Her writing on the Selma march is one of the best accounts written; her letter from the Six-Day War is fascinating and gives new insights; her justifiable evisceration of the New York Times in "The Porch Overlooks No Such Thing" is brilliant.Only one article has always given me pause and that is "A Court of No Appeal" in which she takes down Judge John Sirica among others. Ms. Adler has a law degree. I don't believe she has actually practiced law but the case she makes against Sirica seems to be circumstantial at best and she makes a lot of assumptions. If she was a lawyer in a courtroom and was presented with this case from the other side I'd bet that she would dismantle it with ease.Anyway, it is great fun to see her eviscerate, dismantle, and puncture those who deserve to be eviscerated, dismantled, and punctured and there's plenty of that here.

I gave this book as a birthday gift to a young family member and she absolutely loves it. I looked closely at it before sending it off and I was impressed with the very careful editing that was done: the heart of the story is intact and a young reader will easily understand the plot and recognize the beauty of the story. It will probably inspire her to read the play itself.The illustrations are very well done - nothing cartoonish about them. My only criticism is that a number of the panels are printed in darker-hued inks than necessary and visually detract from the story. Otherwise, this is a very fine graphic rendition of Shakespeare's play.

Sue Morse is a well-known scientist, professional tracker, conservationist, and wildlife photographer and this book will open up a new world of forest life for children.  With Swinburne, Morse explains how to recognize many of the signs of wildlife in a forest - deer, bear, cougars, bobcats, and all the other animals that live in the woods. After reading this book, a child may never look at the forest in the same way again... and may even be inspired to learn more about forestry, ecology, and animal tracking.I bought several copies of this book and donated them to the children's section of my local library.

This made a great gift for an 18-month old neighbor and hes having a heckuva lot of fun playing with it. At about 9 diameter its just about the perfect size for him and hes learned to throw and catch it with great skill.  The material has just the right feel and is not slick so that its easy for him to grip. Playing catch is now one of his favorite games. This is a great gift for a baby.

I have 4-year old nephew who is a huge Batman fan and I sent this mask to him as a gift. His mother says he wears it all the time with his Batman pajamas and sometimes she has to convince him to take it off for meals or bedtime. He REALLY has fun with it!The material is firm but not stiff and the Velcro strap in the back works just fine and it really make him looks like a pee-wee Batman. There is a tab on top that is used to hang the mask in a store display, but it just snaps right off.

This is a very, very light roast coffee and does not have much of the richness I expect in coffee. There's nothing particularly pleasing about the taste - it is just weak coffee. It is probably good for somebody who doesn't drink much coffee but needs a little caffeine in the morning. It's not terrible, it's just not a particularly pleasing coffee.For morning coffee I usually start off with Kirkland Pacific Bold K-Cups.

This is the good stuff. I use it at least three times a day not only as a breath freshener but as gingivitis preventive and it is very effective. It doesn't have the awful taste of "Original" amber colored Listerine, but has a cool minty flavor that's pleasant in the mouth.  I do regular, careful brushing followed by a 30-second thorough rinse with Listerine.Also, all my life I have never been able to effectively floss even when I tried using those little flossing gadgets, but using Listerine as I do I have never, ever had any gum problems in years and my periodontist is happy.

ICHI is a cute and interesting game that can turn into a time-suck if you're not careful. I downloaded this as a FAOTD to kill some time while waiting for an appointment and got really absorbed in it and had fun. It's almost a cross between the old arcade game Asteroids and Pong. It has rotating bumpers that bounce balls and the object is to get them through holes while avoiding hazards. The graphics are almost retro in their simplicity and the progressive levels are almost unlimited since you can create your own..It only needs a couple of network permissions from your tablet but it uses a gigantic 80+ meg(?) of memory.

Coghlan makes excellent bear bells. I bought this jar and give the bells to friends and visitors when we go hiking in the woods here where we have our share of black bears.To human ears the sound from these bells is pleasant and doesn't become annoying after a long time. The Velcro strap is long enough to attach around the top of a hiking stick, a backpack, or button hole, or even a dog's collar (but I don't recommend attaching it to clothing because it doesn't hang free and isn't very effective).In bear country sometimes more than a little noise is needed, so when we are hiking or walking the woods with more than one person, we all have a bear bell (sometimes I will attach two bells to a hiking stick). One of us will also carry something like a Falcon Safety Super Sound Horn which is a pretty good deterrent if a bear gets too curious.

We've owned Keurigs all the way from the first B40 through the K75 Platinum. The most reliable was the old, original B40 but they don't make them anymore. Well, after the second expensive K75 bit the dust within three years and only Keurig 2.0 machines were available I was just about to give up with Keurig and go back to my reliable Cuisinart Brew Central when I came across this obsolete K45 in a hardware store.  It was the only one available and was high on a shelf in a dusty box. It was discounted and I bought it because it's the closest thing to the rugged old B40.It does not have all the bells and whistles of the later models. It has no on timer but does have an automatic 2-hour shut off option. It comes with a charcoal filter kit but I don't use it and use a Brita pitcher instead (since the 48-ounce reservoir isn't particularly big I would rather use the space for water instead of taking up room with a filter).  When first I turn it on in the morning the water heats up within 30 seconds and is ready to brew and it makes a nice cup of coffee.BIG BONUS: Unlike the terrible Keurig 2.0 machines, this one actually takes reusable and refillable baskets like My K-Cup so you can use your own ground coffee instead of a K-Cup.Prices vary tremendously, so shop around.

This was a nice little birthday gift for a pre-teen family member and shes really had a lot of fun with them.  Shes made necklaces and bracelets and bangles with the supplied connectors.  The colors are bright and the illumination is startling.  They dont last forever (18 hours?) but 100 glow sticks should last for quite a while.

(This review is for the Superman romper.) Good quality onesie and at a very nice price. Snaps are firm and reinforced and the light material is perfect for the summertime.  The little cape fastens to the back of the shoulders with two small buttons and its the right length so it wont interfere with movement or diaper changing.Minor quibble: it needs an additional snap at the center of the crotch. The gap is too large and the diaper can visibly hang down through it.I gave this to the parents of an 18-month old baby who went into the hospital for multiple surgical procedures on the same day(!) and he wore it when he came home. Superbaby was on his feet and up and around by the next morning. I think the Superman outfit helped.

I like to get simple close-up magic tricks to show off with and this one is very effective. The gimmicked shell, cover, and ring are nicely machined from brass and fit together very well. They are easy to manipulate.-Show a stack of four nickels on the table-Cover them with the brass cap-Tap the cap, lift it and the nickels have changed to dimes-Show the cap to prove the nickels are not hidden inside-Place the cap on the ring-Tap the cap, lift it and the nickels have reappeared-Place the stack of nickels on the back of your hand-Cover them with the brass cap-Tap the cap and the four nickels drop to the table after seeming to travel through your handPretty neat! It's fun and easy to master after a couple of practice sessions, and you can even make up your own variations of the trick.

This is a good paper for flyers. The color is canary yellow and not bright neon yellow, so be forewarned. It prints nice but its a little thin and light at 20 lb. I get this at an office supply store.Prices vary so shop around.

Bought a couple of these to give to kids in the family but everyone was disappointed. They require a LOT of adjustment by moving the glass body up and down on the clip before it even starts to work - and then it works poorly. Sometimes it makes it all the way to the glass but it just stays there. More often it just waggles back and forth and eventually stops by itself.  Pretty dull stuff and no novelty for kids.I suspect there is too little fluid in the bulb so there's not enough to really evaporate and condense inside the body and make it work the way it should. The glass body is extremely thin and fragile so this isn't a good toy for a small kid.

This is perfect for spaghetti or vermicelli and I use it along with Oggi 5 Piece Acrylic Canister Set with Locking Clamps and it easily holds two pounds of pasta. It matches perfectly but should have been part of the 5-piece set.The body is strong, clear acrylic and the lid tightly locks down on the silicone seal.

These are good, strong (and very handsome) canisters and are much better than the metal variety.  I use them to store dried peas, beans and small pasta. The silicone seals are airtight but after a few months of use I have to take care that they line up properly when I clamp and seal the containers - they seem to have a tendency to slightly stretch a bit.The tall canister at 9" is not tall enough for spaghetti or vermicelli since something around 11" tall is needed.  Oggi has an Acrylic Airtight Pasta Canister which fits the bill and this canister set would have been perfect if it had been included.

Susanne Alleyn nails it with this book. She's an experienced, published author of historical novels and has little tolerance for the sloppy research and writing many HF authors inflict on us. She points out the more egregious errors typically found in many these novels (clothing, anachronisms, hygiene, daily life, and especially the misinformation spread about the French Revolution).No, underpants as such weren't worn by everyone and she explains why; potatoes weren't eaten in 7th century Europe, and neither were avocados, beans, and chilies.  She has a pretty detailed chapter on the use of English titles which is sort of interesting to a casual reader, but contains vital information for an HF author.Her basic lessons can be summed up: check your facts and then check them again. Use PRIMARY sources. Never depend on other historical novels or movies. Never ASSSUME something was true "then" because it's true now. In fact, never assume anything.By pointing out a lot of the mistakes made by HF authors she provides tons of fascinating detail about life in past times going all the way back to the Romans. For a casual reader the book is an absorbing read; for the HF author, it's an absolute requirement.

I live in northern rural Vermont where winter power outages are a fact of life so the battery backup for the clock AND timer is a great feature - even better is that the batteries are rechargeable and built into the units so I never have to replace them. The timers are rated for up to 500-watts for incandescent bulbs and I also use them for CFL and LED bulbs with no problem.The instructions need a careful reading to properly set these up, but once they are set you can forget about them. I was able to program both timers in a couple of minutes with little fuss - it's about the same as setting the clock on those old VCRs so I keep a copy of the instruction handy because I'm sure I'll need them again.What I really like about these:-Full built-in battery backup-I can program two different on/off cycles-Works with all LED and CFL bulbs-Works with incandescent bulbs up to 500 watts-They are small and take up only one outlet

These are wonderful books - well written and perfect stories to read aloud and they are sure to stimulate a young child to start learning to read. Even though the stories are predictable with the same pattern of behavior on Curious George's part, they are delightful. The little family member I sent these to for his birthday can't get enough of them. Interestingly enough, his mother was a Curious George fan when she was very little and I think she knows these stories by heart. We have two generations of Curious George readers!These paperbacks are well-made and the illustrations are quite nice. Highly recommended!

I'm seriously watching my carb and fat intake, as well as eating a number of smaller meals a day instead of 3 large ones.  It's been difficult to find a packaged snack that fits the bill and isn't just empty calories.I like these.  Not only are you getting the benefit of chia seeds, but it's filling and tastes good.But if you're eating this during the day and expect to be meeting with anyone, be aware that the chia seeds will form a gel around each individual seed and you'll be picking these out of your teeth for the next 1/2 hour or so.

Ana has a serious heart condition.  She, her mother and younger sister move to a small town in IDher grandmothers vacant housewhen her mother is laid off but able to get re-hired at a bank she worked for years ago; they have to have insurance for Ana.  The eighteen year old is shy, does not want anyone new to know about her heart and takes pains to hide her surgery scar.  On her first day of school, shes paired up with Chance in two classes and a friendship begins with this good-looking Native American guy who keeps to himself and doesnt hang around with anyone.  He too is keeping a secret.I liked the concept of the story, the characters and whats shared of the Navajo culture.  The family relationships are very strong; possibly too strong for the ages of the kids involved.  Hormones and teenage angst appear to be missing.But the story moves kind of slow with a number of repeat scenes.  Ive read over 1000 urban fantasy or paranormal books and in order for them to be believable, the non-paranormal stuff must ring true.  That wasnt always the case when it comes to the conversations and how different things are dealt with.  Were told that they love each other and show it with words and actions, but I never felt it.Overall its a decent read and I could easily see younger readers enjoying the romance and family closeness angles, because boy, wouldnt that be great to experience?

Juliet had worked her way through college at the Java Jive, along with the owners son, her best friend, Pete. Now, at the age of thirty shes accepted the position of manager at the coffee shop that Pete now owns after having to close her own in another town when her fianc, a co-owner of her shop, wiped out the accounts and stole everything from their apartment. The staff doesnt like the idea of someone new taking over and that night, after find a body in a dumpster after hours, shes the lead person of interest in his murder.Similar to the writings of Janet Evanovich? There is quite a bit of humor, often at others' expense, but most of it is more subtle. There is one laugh out loud scene, though, that I dont think Ill ever forget.Juliet feels she needs to find the killer herself or shell be arrested and of course she doesnt have any experience in doing so. She and Pete find themselves in some interesting situations. There are two other characters that could be somewhat compared to the Stephanie Plum series. Both are interesting and one is a hoot.The story had a slow start and for a chunk of it I would have just said the story was okay. Then things started to pick up and I was really enjoying it. I thought the mystery was well done with the twists and some red herrings. I was surprised at the who and why. There is sex but its PG with nothing explicit using more of a fade to black technique and picking up the story afterward.Other than Juliet, we learn the most about Pete. No real in depth on any of the other characters and there is definitely one that I believe a lot of readers will want to get to know better.An ARC of the book was provided by the publisher via NetGalley in exchange for a review. I liked this well enough to pick up the first book in the authors Lizzie Hart series.

Somewhat similar to the Kate Daniels series in that Serafina Dering works for a guild fighting monsters for very little money while needing to hide her magic.  In her case its because the Magic Council determined long ago that those with Dragon Born magic are too powerful to allow to live; its an automatic death sentence.She comes to the attention of Kai Drachenburg, a powerful mage that heads up one of the larger families when shes able to stop a mage from breaking into one of his buildings, and hes very interested.  Hes also a dragon shifter and a member of the Magic Council.The overall series could be considered a romance, although its just starting in this book as she keeps putting space between them, fearing both the discovery of what she is.  But shes definitely drawn to both him and has magic.I liked Sera, the situations, plenty of action and her non-magical abilities.  If I hadnt read Magic Edge firstAlexs storyI would have been more upset with Kais actions when it comes to getting to know her.  Hes definitely an uber alpha that gets away with doing things that no one dares call him on.  But having the male lead do something huge for the heroine to object to and use that as a reason to keep her distance from him, was done in both books.  It is obvious that Kai has her best interest at heart and shes not afraid to call him out on what she sees as unacceptable behavior.This was read via KindleUnlimited.  Im happy that I picked it up and look forward to the next release.

Alex hunts supernatural monsters that either break the laws or hurt others.  Shes been in Zurich for the last 2 months to do so, having been hired by an incredibly old mage.  Alex has spent her life hiding her magicshed be killed outright if anyone knew what she isbut an assassin who is attracted to her is seeing more than he should.  They team up together when a group of magic haters called the Convictionites have a plan to wipe out all supernaturals.Ive never read this author before, but I picked this book up via Kindle Unlimited and really liked it, finding the type of book that you just absorb in one sitting.  We dont know a great deal about either of the two main characters, and as it turns out, they dont know everything about themselves either.  So were learning as we go.  But what we do know is interesting.Alex is both stubborn and uses sarcasm when shes scared or wants to change the subject.  She physically trains hard for stamina and her ability to use her sword and knives; rarely using magic as she doesnt want folks to know she has any.  Logan, the assassin known as The Slayer, is quite capable and has been watching Alex for awhile and is both drawn to and intrigued by her.  He wants nothing more than to partner with her.  Expect some fairly G-rated lust in the form of getting lost when kissing.The story starts off in the middle of an action scene and I was sucked right in.  The story obviously continues and we get an idea of the next threat theyll face.  But it doesnt have the feel of a cliffhanger.One thing that surprised me is that at no point did I feel like the story was set in another country, even though its in Switzerland.  That can be taken as either good or bad.  I was also surprised at the lack of editing errors.Ive just downloaded Serafinas first book and cant wait to get started.

Second book in the series taking place about 6 months after the action in the first one.  Dina needs guests; its been awhile.  Not only does she need the money, but the inn requires the energy from guests.  So shes both surprised and alarmed when an arbitrator wants to hold a summit at the inn, hoping to get three warring factions to agree to peace.  Hes already been turned down by all of the other inns because the risk is too high for the reputation of the inn when youve got guests trying to kill each other.  This will either make her or break her.Two characters coming to the summit are people weve met before.  Arland, the vampire who is interested in her, and the Merchant she often deals with off-world, Nuan Cee.  And we pick up a new interesting character when she realizes she needs a chef to feed her 40 guests.I really like Dina.  The woman knows what she needs to do and she doesnt let people get away with stuff.  Shes not afraid to throw her weight around, especially when people show disrespect.  And we end up with a mystery and a no-win situation to figure out and overcome.But my favorite character isnt a character at all, but the house.  Who wouldnt want a house like that.

Part paranormal and part science fiction.  A ghost hunter and her team are approached by a man when he needs her help at the Winchester House, renowned for the number of ghosts it has and the purposely difficult layout that requires a guide to get through it.  Garrie needs some excitement and decides the team is going.  Little does she know that this sexy guy with the scary vibes is a bounty hunter from another world and what shes needed for is, in essence, to save her own world.The story is told from three points of view.  The main one is Garrie, or Lisa McGarrity, who as we are reminded of often, is a small person with a whole lot of power.  Exactly what Garrie does with ghosts isnt quite clear.  We do see two or three captured, but what happens to them from there?  Other than that, we see her talking to, attempting to negotiate with them or use her power to push them back when they become unruly.Trevaar is the off-world bounty hunter who in order to keep Garrie safe from the notice of a council on his world who would be very interested in her abilities, is keeping a whole lot of secrets from her.  The only thing we know about his past is told from the point of view of Nevahn, his grandfather who raised him once his daughter died.  This is done via scattered chapters and you dont realize if its the past or present until quite a ways into each of those chapters.The third voice is the most entertaining, although Sklayne, another off-world entity who often takes form as a cat, is somewhat difficult to follow at first.  The fact that hes not from around here and doesnt think like a human is showcased by very different thought and speech patterns.  But you soon get used to it.I like the idea of the storyline and the different threats that were faced, but there were just too many places where I didnt know what was going on.  Some of it is explained later.  Some of those flow okay from there but others are rather jarring, especially when the scene changes between one paragraph and the next.  And for much of it I was never really clear on what Garrie was doing when using her abilities.It took effort to keep reading and it did get somewhat easier about a quarter of the way in.  It especially got more interesting in the last quarter.  There is a love interest that is just beginning to take hold and I liked how that was being handled.  But it never really sucked me in and it was too easy to set aside a number of times.A copy was provided by the publisher to read in exchange for a review via LibraryThing.

The same smooth chocolate you are familiar with when eating a regular Kiss.  This one is twice the size and has a layer of toasted rice (like Rice Krispies), another layer of chocolate and a roasted hazelnut in the center.This was so good!  These aren't going to last long in my office.I do have to say that the hazelnut seems small for the overall size of these Kisses.But ordering a case of 12 at a time?  Perhaps for Christmas.

The need to stop Luciana, the witchs coven leader, becomes more critical than ever, and the stakes are raised for not only the werewolves, but for humans as well.The first part of the story overlaps the last book somewhat when it comes to whats going on with Raphael and the need to get him as close to Claudia as possible while she searches for a cure for him.We get action and a number of new situations in this storywhich I enjoyedbut I have to say the first half of the book was difficult for me to get through. Tessa has a lot of good reasons for her angsty thoughts and feelings, but it was really becoming a drag to read. But things really start to pick up and/or get more interesting around the halfway mark.I find the story arc interesting and like many of the characters, especially Tessa. Shes only been a werewolf for a couple of months and known shes a bruja for about the same length of time, yet shes more powerful than many. And her experiences as a human save the werewolves more than once.Id give this higher marks if the first half of the book hadnt dragged so much. And Id be more impressed if it was better edited.

When open this approximate 24 x 13 calendar contains pictures of Siberian and Sumatran tigers.  Each month with a Sunday thru Saturday layout contains one picture along with some information about the tigers along with where the picture was taken and the photographer.The calendar appears to contain the major holidays celebrated in the US as well as other countries.The pictures are absolutely stunning.

I dont have bunions.  My problem is that my little toes curl in and the knuckle on one of them rubs against the side of my shoe.  So instead of pulling this down completely over my toe, I barely slide it down and it provides the layer of padding that prevents a sore.You cant just slide your socks on like normal when wearing it this way.  Youve got to put your sock on like youd put on nylons, pretty much rolling the sock down from the toes in order to keep the guard in place.  Other than the first time I tried this, I havent had an issue with it moving in the months Ive been wearing it since then.If the rubbing you are experiencing is due to the shoes being too tight, well this isnt going to help.  It will provide padding, but itll be taking up even more room in your shoes and be uncomfortable.

90 full-plated meals are provided with each plate (except for breakfast which only has 2) broken down into 3 separate recipes; protein, starch or grain and non-starch veggies.  Youre provided the recipes for each, serving size, prep time and nutritional information for each of the categories on the plate as well as the meal in whole.  And that means you can do a lot of mix and matching and still be able to follow the numbers.  The book also contains recipes for drinks and deserts.You wont find a bland meal in this book.

Were back to being focused on Lily and Rule, but also with the point of view of an interesting new charactera touch sensitivethat not only sets the stage but fills in a great deal of information regarding a high-ranking conspiracy.  This one is set on the East Coast.  Mika, the dragon that sucks up the excess magic in the Washington DC area has gone missing.  Sam, the black dragon close to the Nokolai territory that has been teaching Lily mindspeak, has her go to Whisper, OH without telling her why; and Rule must stay behind with Rueben.  And thats when the conspiracy starts to unfold.Once again the world building, as well as the twists and intricate details of this mystery and how things work are incredible.  This type of thing with the theory on magic has blown me away since the first book.  This takes magical theory in a new direction.  Plenty of action, tension and emotion along with a lot of details on not only magical theory and the conspiracy, but on the investigative process that pulls it all together.  Ok, sometimes all of these details can get pretty deep, but the author is good at changing the course of the conversation or thoughts enough to prevent those details from becoming overwhelming.If you've been reading this series, you'll find this one difficult to set aside for a time.

I've used these type of bottles for years.  The only thing different about this one is that the round sponge covers a larger area at once.  I mail out a lot of envelopes and find this easy to use.  Just turn the bottle upside down and squeeze over a plant, garbage can or sink until a few drips of water comes out.  You shouldn't need to squeeze the bottle again.  With that first envelope you might have to go back and for a few times to get the entire flap and sponge moist.  But after that, with each stroke of the sponge across the envelope you are also re-wetting the sponge.I'd give this a higher rating if you could replace the sponge heads (they will wear down) instead of purchasing a new bottle every time.

Set in Half Moon Hollow with many of the characters weve already come to know, Libby, a widow with a soon-to-be 6 year old son, is dying of cancer.  Theyve run out of treatments to try.  Her in-laws are more than willing to take raise her son Danny, but in the image of Dannys father, not taking into consideration that Danny is a very different type of person.  So with a lot of trepidation and second guessing her decision, Libby puts an ad in the paper for someone to turn her into a vampire so she can raise Danny herself.As always, there is plenty of humor throughout the story which covers a wide-range of issues that Libby now must face; everything from what she physically experiences and learning to control her urges, to how to raise her son when shes not awake during the day, friends turning on you, fight for custody of Danny with the in-laws and a couple of guys who are now interested in her.The writer does a good job of letting the reader feel the characters emotions, which to me is an important aspect of my enjoyment of a story.  The story is interesting and has a number of fun conversations.My only criticism is that Danny, now 6 in the story, comes across as a much older child in his understanding of events and his conversations.

Youve really got to love dark chocolate to enjoy this.  You get four different flavors.  I dont know how many are in the jar  I didnt think to count.  But there are a lot of these individually wrapped chocolates.Dark  This one is the most bitter and it leaves an aftertaste in your mouthBittersweet  Just slightly less bitter than Dark, but without the aftertasteSemisweet  Again, just slightly less bitter than Bittersweet.  Actually, there isnt a great deal of difference between the three.Milk  This one seems to be the most popular among my friends, and the texture is the smoothest of the four.Packed well for shipping, this looks really nice.  Take off the lid and the smell of cacao is wonderful.  I leave mine on a table with the top of the jar off and it acts as a potpourri.  YumI believe it would make a great gift for dark chocolate lovers, or even as a hostess gift for the upcoming holiday parties.  And I can definitely see using the jar for other things when the chocolate is gone.

Mason jar recipes have become more popular.  Fill them up  and it can be days ahead of time - and when its time to eat, dump the contents in a bowl.  But the glass jars are heavy to carry around and if you dont want to carry your dressing separately, you have to pay attention to the order the ingredients get stacked.This is both lighter and more convenient by having a place to store your dressing as part of the lid.  I definitely like the idea of this.However the lid on mine doesnt fit the jar very well.  Twist the lid into place and its not a solid fit.  You can lift up one side of the lid from the screwed down position.  For that reason, I cant give this more than 2 stars.  The glass mason jar definitely keeps things fresher than something that doesnt offer the same solid seal.
What can I say - it does the job

The extra rim extension is nice, making this a more effective brush than one without this type of feature.  The regular brush seems to be a little smaller than the one I'd just retired.  But it does the job.The entire thing is so light - even the base.  This would be so easy to knock over.

Instead of eating larger meals Ive taken to eating a number of smaller meals  although it would be difficult to call them that  per day.  Im seriously watching my carbs and fat intake and it can be difficult to continue to come up with a variety of things day after day.I love these.  Small and slightly sweet, this meets all of my criteria and tastes good.  And chia seeds are so good for you in a variety of ways.  Ive checked out other snack bars and the nutrition most offer is non-existent or barely there.  Its nice that this small snack packs such a large punch.Those not already familiar with chia seeds might be a little surprised to find that a few seeds will get stuck in your teeth and a gel will quickly form around them.  Kind of weird the first time you experience it.  But expect to be picking some out of your teeth.

Private investigator, mother and vampire, Samantha Moon must make a very difficult decision.  Her son is going to die within hours; apparently his life was supposed to be short and Anthony is accepting of it.  Should she be selfish and turn him into a vampire to prevent his death? Would he be trapped in a seven year-olds body forever?  Can the medallion that she has and everyone else is looking for really reverse vampirism and make the person mortal again?  If so, how?  If she changes her son she figures shell only have 4 days to find the answer; thats the length of time before she started craving blood after being turned.The bulk of the story centers on finding a specific person who might have the answers that she needs about the medallion.  We had a cliffhanger in both the 2nd and 3rd books, but this one has a sense of closure.  Not for the series, but for the immediate story arc.  And it appears that a new back story has begun.I like Sam the situations and story line as well as the philosophy discussed between characters.  But Sam has cried a lot, especially in these last two books.  Its for a good reason, but the fact that shes cried harder than ever before in her life, many times now, feels overdone.  Id think you could really only convey that once for the reader to believe it.

A very short book consisting of six, for the most part, scenes instead of short stories.  Two of them, however, are a little longer.Id picked this up via KindleUnlimited to read Fangs story from the Samantha Moon series.  Teeth is a more in depth explanation of the details surrounding his imprisonment than was provided in American Vampire.  He doesnt come across as a very pleasant person, but at least you understand why and can empathize with his character a little more.  I enjoyed this story the most.None of the other stories are related to the series, and honestly, if you cant get this for free you might feel like you wasted your money.  Most of the tales here are a tad disturbing.My Fathers Eyes is a scene that tells how a man learned that his father had passed away.  Okay, I can at least appreciate this one.The Fridge is a little more involved about a sentient refrigerator.  Somewhat humorous as well as scary.Die Spy is a scene in a bar about a spy being told by his mentor to get out of the business.  There just didnt seem to be a point to this one.Step on a Crack is a scene set in Jamaica about a not very nice eight year old boy and a curse.  More along the lines of a moral.Two Ghosts is a scene about the beginning of a relationship between two ghosts living in the same apartment.  This one also seemed pointless.

PI Vampire, Samantha Moon, has been online chatting with a guy going by the name of Fang for years now.  He knows everything about her as shes poured out her heart and soul and she believes she loves him.  This book starts off with meeting him for the first time, only to discover she has already met him a number of times and now doesnt know what to think.Two cases are worked on.  One involves a missing child who somehow phones Sam for help.  The other is a missing item taken from a small museum.  But taking up a good chunk of her focus is on a family matter.I like the story itself as well as the situations and characters.  Were starting to build more on a back story and it will be interesting to see where that goes.  But two things were really bugging me.  The more obvious one is the sudden cliffhanger, which quite frankly reminds me of watching episodes of Batman.  Tune in tomorrow to see what happens.  Im glad Im reading this years after the initial release so I dont have to wait for the next book if I dont want to.The other issue that came up this time is repetition within the story.  Im not talking about things described in one book and described again in the next.  Im talking about repetition in this book alone.  At least 3 times were told something wed already read.The story is entertaining, but additional effort needs to be put into editing and continuity.  Heck, a character from the last book was named Monica in Vampire Moon and in this one were told its Cynthia.

PI Samantha Moon, who happens to be a vampire, was forced out of her house by her soon-to-be-ex-husband who blackmailed her into leaving and is making it difficult for her to see or even speak to her kids.  Monsters come in all forms.  But shes keeping busy with a couple of cases.One is a woman whose husband has attempted to kill her twice and even though hes on death row, has taken out a contract on her.  The other is a guy whose wife was murdered in a plane crash along with everyone else who witnessed a murder executed by a powerful crime lord.  The widower wants vengeance.What I liked about this book and the series so far is that even though Sam has been a vampire for the past 6 years, other than her strength and recently learning how to turn into a giant bat, really doesnt know a lot about being a vampire and heavily weighs most of her decisions when using the abilities she does know about.  Her kids are so important to her that shes doing her best to be both human and a good mother.  Shes good at what she does and I like the resolutions she comes up with.This story leaves you with a cliffhanger when Fang, her online confidant shes fallen in love with, talks her into meeting him.An easy read, I just wish it had better editing.

Long ago some non-humans staged a sort of coup that took out millions and now no people who arent completely human are allowed to live free, own any property or have any rights whatsoever.  They are locked up, sold for research and development, sold to hunters or purchased by traveling carnivals.Delilah has always been interested in the cryptids and studied them in school.  On her twenty-fifth birthday her boyfriend gives her tickets to Metzgers Menagerie, which makes her uneasy, seeing how those in cages are jeered at by the audience and abused by the handlers.  When a young girl in a cage is shocked with a cattle prod for not performing for the audience, something comes over Delilah and shes outed as one of those and is sold by the county sheriff to Metzger.  All of this is made worse because Delilah had no clue there was anything different about her.Through Delilah as well as a few others in the menagerie, we experience their stories, abuse and humiliation.  But Delilah is something a little different and shes not going to let them break her.  Her handler, assigned to break her, isnt quite what he seems either.Well written with great characters, the first half is definitely not a happy story; a combination of disbelief, abuse and hopelessness.  But the second half of the story starts to change as they finally learn what Delilah is and that she has a purpose.Id had the book for a couple of weeks before reading it, mostly due to already hearing that the first half of the book could be difficult.  But wow, I picked it up last night and it immediately sucked me in and wouldnt let go.  Monsters come in all forms and its not surprising that some of the worst are the ones that arent chained and caged.  Were provided small newspaper articles throughout the book that indicates what took place so long ago that caused the current laws and opinions; and it would be easy to see our own laws and opinions following the same course if it happened in real life.The book is the first in a trilogy, but it feels like a complete story on its own.

From the Charley Davidson series, this is Reyes story.  Not a lot that you havent already learned if youve been reading the series, but this is from his point of view beginning when he was 3, taking you through his coming out of the coma at Charleys urging.  It certainly gives a different perspective on not only him, but Charley who hes checked in with all of her life.Definitely not a happy story but it wasnt as difficult as I feared even though youll wish you could jump into the story and help him.  You do learn more about him and will appreciate him even more than you did before.If youre reading this series youll want to read this one.  And now I want to go back and re-read that first book.

When purchasing this I'd done a search for Dial Anti-Bacterial soap.  Guess I wasn't paying too much attention when I saw this product come up.  It's not an anti-bacterial but states on the label that it washes bacteria away.  Apparently this is no different from most other body washes.The scent is light and pleasant and it lathers well.  I'm sensitive to scents and I can't smell this on my arm after drying off.It says it's moisturizing and I don't doubt that, but I've yet to find a moisturizing body wash that helps by itself when your skin is already dry.  You'll still need to use an oil or lotion to re-hydrate your skin.  On the other hand, this won't dry out your skin.

This is my second order of this GE filter.  Both times I received exactly what I was ordering.I'd been gifted with a 3 year old new fridge and immediately bought the filter.  These are supposed to be good for 6 months but it was 14 months before I purchased the second one, mostly because I felt I should, not because it wasn't filtering as well.  On average I probably dispense about 50 ounces of water, plus a couple of 15 oz cups full of ice cubes per day.I think it works well and it's pretty easy to install.  The water tastes a whole lot better than what come out of my faucet, so I'm happy.

Lark and Ash, elementals with Earth magic, are captured by the Enders from the Pitin the first story they killed four Enders there and the price of killing an Ender is deathso are being taken back to the place where those with fire abilities live, for their execution.  This is a place where people go swimming in lava.  The stakes are raised as not only does she have to get Ash out of there, but rescue a childhood friend and according to the mother goddess, a whole lot of others.  And in this one she picks up a familiar, the cat from the last book who wants nothing to do with Lark.Weve also got an interesting bad person who I expect well be seeing in the next book.Im definitely enjoying the series and seeing Lark get out of some pretty impossible situations; at least most of the time.  Shes kick butt, however not invincible, as well as compassionate.Her relationships with others, especially creatures not accepted by many, make her really likable to the reader.  I dont believe shes prejudiced against anyone or anything that hasnt done her any harm and shell go out on a limb for someone even when she has no reason to.  And I really like Peta, her familiar.  She makes a great addition.One thing bothers me and that's the resolution between two sides of a drama.  They can't communicate with each other so how are they going to pull that one off?

Tight knit through the foot with a thicker bottom.  From the ankle up you've got a looser weave that nicely hugs the leg without sliding down.  This is a huge issue for me as I have larger legs.  I don't feel like the compression is cutting into me at all.  But wow, are these soft.I don't need a diabetes sock, but they sounded like a good idea for my situation.  Very comfortable and they don't slide down on me.  I'd order them again.They do need to stay in the dryer a little longer than thinner socks; roughly as long as a thick towel.

This is my 7th year in a row, purchasing this for a small office.  This one covers December 2015 through January 2017.  The entire month is displayed over the 2-page spread with a 2 strip along the outside of the left-hand page showcasing 6 months of calendars; the prior month, the current month and the next 4.7 lines for notes are provided for each day with the calendar in the Sunday thru Saturday format.  Normally I wouldnt mention that format, but was surprised when purchasing a calendar and hadnt been aware beforehand that it was a Monday thru Sunday format which I dont like.  The lines are enough to give this office manager the information needed to know whats going on and when, as well as who will be out of the office.The calendar provides both the number of days into the year as well as how many are left.  All of the major North American holidays are listed along with some lesser known religious ones.At the back the planner also has a 2/3 of a page devoted to future years planning with the other third a contact list.  Also 1 page of calendars for 2015 thru 2017.Wirebound with a somewhat flexible nylon-type of cover, I've never had one that isn't still in perfect shape by the end of the year.  Actually I have all of them as once in awhile I need to refer to when something took place and all of them are still in perfect shape.If I wanted something more personal, Id get something smaller with more lines for notes allotted per day.  But for the way this is being used, it works out well.

This author is known for her gritty mysteries told from the perspective of law enforcement or the coroner.  In each book we see through these folks eyes the horror of what a human can do.  This story is quite different in that its told from the point of view of a victim and their family members; how a horrific event can drastically change all of their lives.  The story is more along the lines of psychological thriller.The story actually starts out in the novella-length prequel, Blonde Hair, Blue Eyes.  It follows a university student, Julia, who also writes for the school paper and wants to do a story about girls that have gone missing.  Through her we also learn about her family before her disappearance.  Its not necessary to read this book first, although its the only way to really get to know Julia.  This book picks up twenty-four years later with the story told from Julias sisters with todays actions, along with letters their father had written to Julia over the years about what was going on and how he was still looking for her, scattered throughout.But its so much more than a grieving family that was torn apart.  The youngest, Claire, is married to a really rich guy and on the night we meet her, her husband dies in her arms after being stabbed during a robbery.  Things quickly dont start adding up and eye-opening revelations are uncovered.  Its obvious that some in law enforcement cant be trusted so who do you turn to with the horror you uncover?This book isnt going to be popular with everyone.  There are some really horrific scenes described.  I had trouble as I wanted/needed to get away from the story while being drawn in as I had to know what happens.  I purposely had to set it aside to get some space from it and couldnt wait to finish the book.Well written?  Absolutely.  The characters are well fleshed out with details that might not seem important that often figure in later in the story.  Like any good mystery there are enough twists and revelations to keep things interesting.  And you will end up liking the entire family even though you probably wont care for any of them at first.Would I read the book again later?  No.  The author did a great job on the horror aspect of it and it took a lot of my energy to get through the story.Read as a ARC via Edelweiss.

Not much happens in the small town of Liberty; certainly nothing exciting ever gets written in The Liberty Chronicle, the newspaper Lizzie works for as a copy editor.  But that suddenly changes when a murder occurs just across the street, followed by a second one soon afterward.  Lizzie knows dang well the second one is a murder, but the cops are calling it an accident.  So what else can she do but find the murderer?Add to the mix the super sexy Blake Morgan who works as an investigative reporter for the newspaper.  Lizzie has a mind-numbing crush on him but when she sees how much hes hurting from the second death and finds out he doesnt have any friends (hes new in town) she decides he needs a friend more than a lover.The mystery itself was good; the who and why was a total shock to me.  And the relationship between Lizzie and Blake provides some sexual tension.  But too much of the story involves their weird relationship with Lizzies minute by minute changing attitude.  I found it somewhat hard to keep up with why shes suddenly feeling the way she does at any given moment.Wow, did the author come up with some interesting characters.  The antics of one in particular provide much of the humor.Read via Kindle Unlimited

A fairly simplistic and unbelievable tale about an heiress who runs away from her wedding by sneaking out the back door of the church and taking off in her fathers limo just minutes before shes to walk down the aisle.  She did try to call off the wedding days earlier but her autocratic father wouldnt hear of it and threatened to freeze all of her assets.  So without any identification or money, she ends up in a small town where people just want to help each other and shes such a kind and wonderful person that everyone loves her.Wow, I just dont know where to go from there.  A romance?  Yes.  No problem with that.  She meets a really nice guy whose only fault appears to be that he so easily jumps to the wrong conclusions.  And yes, there is comedy with the majority of it taking place at the beginning of the tale.  The characters are quirky, interesting and quite likable.But to specifically discuss the unbelievable aspects would be giving away too much of the story.  Although I will say that a piece of it involves how easily she gives away the only assets she has without having a penny or a job, and her apparent disregard for insurance fraud.Not a bad read and for the most part light and easy, but too many things just dont come across as realistic.

Shoulder-length coarse, curly, colored hair, Ive been having a problem with it being too dry for years now and have used a number of products with varying degrees of success to prevent the frizzing.  A few months ago I changed the product being used to color my hair as well as the shampoo and I have seen an improvement, although my hair still looked bushy.I couldnt find my glasses to read the directions, so the first time I used this I applied the same number of pumps (5) that I use for another oil product on humid days.  While my hair was air drying I found my glasses and to my horror saw that only 1 pump was needed.  I feared an oily look with weighed down hair.  Nope.  My hair absorbed it all; it felt light and soft when it was dry and dang, it looked good.Since I let my hair air dry, its still damp when I get to work.  On those days I dont have the option to apply the product to both damp and dry hair.  For those days, 1 pump isnt enough, although 2 pumps works out quite well.I also apply a couple of pumps worth on the nights before the morning when Ill be washing my hair.  It does look somewhat greasy when I go to bed, but again, its been completely absorbed when I get up in the morning.Ive seen a huge difference in my hair since starting to use this and Im so happy with the results.

Seventeen year-old Lila stays under the radar in the tourist town that boasts its the most magical place in America; a place with mortals, those who have magic, and the monsters that live in the surrounding woods and mountains.  The town is run by magical mob-like families and you dont want to come to their attention if you arent a member of one of them.  Having been trained by her mother, Lila is an outstanding thief and excellent as a fighter with a couple of magical Talents that are kind of rare.Much to her chagrin, she steps in when seeing an assassination attempt and comes to the attention of the second most powerful of the families.If I were rating this book at only one or two chapters in, the rating would not have been too good.  Lila has a mouth and attitude that arent especially endearing, especially when coupled with what she does to earn money.  That and when recapping what took place 4 years prior that now has her in her current situation, too many things just felt off.But the story and her situation soon sucked me in and we see a much different side of her than what she wants and needs others to see.  Smart, capable, loyal and compassionate while attempting to not let others get too close.  The characters are interesting as is the mystery, action and the already building back story.Read from a library book.  Ill definitely be reading the next one.

Zelda has just served a nine month sentence in the witches prison for killing her cat who just happened to be her familiar; it was an accident.  A strong healer, what had her sentenced for so long was that shed been using her magic for selfish reasons, conjuring up designer clothes as well as expensive cars and vacations.  On her release shes given back a portion of her magic and is on probation for a month and needs to complete a task during that time.  Her aunt had left her a house and shell know what to do when she gets there.  She had an aunt?  If after a months time she doesnt complete her task, all magic will be removed and shell become mortal.  Only shes not quite sure what that task is.One of the things Ive enjoyed about this authors writings is the crazy main character she often comes up with.  This one is selfish with not quite the intense potty mouth of another popular lead character.  With Zelda, its the names she comes up with for others that stands out.The situations are definitely unique and funny, but I found it difficult to like Zelda for a good chunk of the book.  Due to her upbringing, shes never been emotionally close with another and to protect her heart, just doesnt want to establish connections with the people who like and appreciate her.  Hang in there; it takes a while but things do change.  And thankfully, the secondary characters are likable and interesting enough to carry the story until that time.

My hair is over 95% hard to color gray.  The recommended 25-30 minutes has never been enough; I need 45 minutes, even when having it colored by a hairdresser.  This is the second Garnier hair color product Ive tried since starting to do it on my own to save money and hopefully get my hair in better condition, about 5 months ago.  Both products gave me a rich looking color and did a good job on the grays and my hair feels a lot better than when I had it done by my hairdresser.The first one I tried was Garnier Olia Oilmy hair was pretty dried out and more oil sounded good.  It did a good job with the color, but the bulb-shaped applicator was too large for my hand making application both awkward and messy.  It also required a great deal more product on the hardest to color areas around the temples.  My hair was definitely getting healthier using this versus having it done at a salon.This Nutrisse version uses a regular bottle-shape for an applicator and comes with the developer already in the bottle.  Squeeze out the color crme from a tube and fruit oil from a small plastic pack.  The bottle opening is not as large as the one on the Olia, so you have to be more precise when adding in the other ingredients, but this bottle is great deal more narrow and easy to grip for both shaking and application.It truly is a non-drip formula and I didnt have to put nearly as much product on the temple area to get the color to stick.  My hair feels better each time I color; approximately every 3-1/2 weeks if I dont want to look like a skunk.Okay there is one area that Id like to see an improvement on and its the size of the gloves.  My hands are on the short side of medium and the gloves fingers are almost  too short for me.  This makes it uncomfortable when first starting out.  Not sure if the gloves stretch out or you just forget about it and dont notice it any longer when concentrating on the applying the color.Of the two Garnier products I have to say I like this one better.  And the savings for doing it myself when factoring in the tip is roughly $750.

Two romances for the price of one.  PR consultant Gillian is hired by those financing the SBC to steer Drew Black, the man who created and lives for the SBC, into a more personable figure.  He wants nothing to do with it, but is intrigued and turned on by her looks and her brain.  Someone wants to discredit him in the worst way and will do anything to bring that about.The other romance is between an up and coming fighter, Brett and Audrey, the woman who created WAVS; Women Against Violent Sports.  She has a change in attitude once she gets to know Brett and learns that there are rules in place to prevent the type of fighting that killed her brother.I enjoyed the dual romance, especially as there was enough ink devoted to each that you dont fill gypped on the second one.  Prior fighters met in the series are on hand but have a smaller role than in the earlier stories.  The characters are all likeable, but Drew does take a little getting used to.  The threat involves a bomb threat, hit and run, arson and a shooting.  The perp is interesting and wow, what a nutcase.A nice escape for a few hours.  Read from a library book.

This is a compilation of short stories or novellas that had been released years ago.  Three are set in Kates world and the other two are either in the same world or one similar to A Hidden Legacy.  None are new to me.A Questionable Client is a prequel to the Kate Daniels series where Kate meets Saiman for the first time when she accepts a high-paying gig to be his bodyguard.  It explains why he gives her a break for his services.  It had been available for free for quite a long time on the authors website, and was released in Magic Graves.Retribution Clause is set in Kates world, but takes place in Philadelphia with Saimans frost giant cousin, Adam.  This story is about a claims adjuster and his partner who must fulfill the clause in a life insurance policy to terminate the person responsible for the policy owners death.  The story was originally released in Hex Appeal.  The story has some twists and might be confusing for a bit, but it all makes sense at the end.Of Swine and Roses had been released by itself back in 2011.  Set in the same or a similar world as A Hidden Legacy series, its about a teenage girl who, for her familys sake, needs to accept a date with a guy she knows to be a thug and bully so her family can get a loan from the bank owned by his family.  A short story with a nice outcome.  Quite a few editing errors in this one.Grace of Small Magics is also set in a world where families have magic and the stronger the magic the higher your place in society.  The story had been released in The Mammoth Book of Paranormal Romance as well as Under Her Skin.  Its about a girl whose family is indentured to another and they must come when called for help or her family will be killed.Magic Tests is about Julie, who when forced by Kate to check out a new school, accepts a challenge to find a student who has gone missing.  The story was originally published in An Apple for the Creature as well as at the end of Magic Breaks.  For the first time we get to see how smart Julie is.Read this via KindleUnlimted.
