Tiff Banks is an investigator and only a few understand or accept that much of the information she gets that leads to solving a case comes from ghosts that were victims of violent death.  She has two living in her house.  But she finds out what life is like from their side when her soul separates from her body and the doctors cant figure out why she isnt waking up.  Shes got to find a way to communicate with Royal to stop him from pulling the plug on the machines keeping her alive, as well as figure out how to get back into her body.Finding the solution has them crossing into Downside--magical world--and bringing characters together from both series as well as facing a scary adversary from their past; one who seems impossible to stop.Well this was a nice treat since the author had announced that A Conspiracy of Demons, released in December 2012, would be the last in the series as she started a new one.  There is enough information in this story to remind readers of what they might have forgotten, but its not a good place to start, especially if you hadnt read either series.  Along Came a Demon, the first book in the series, is free as of this writing.This story is loaded with a great deal of emotion; pretty much hitting on every one you can think of  with the story told from Tiffs point of view and the situation she finds herself in.  And through her eyes we see how it affects her Gelpha lover and investigative partner, Royal, as he needs to make a decision that would affect not only Tiff, but Downside as well as his own world.I liked how the characters from the two series were brought together.  We get a lot of interaction with Jack and Mel, her ghostly roommates as they help in the investigation and teach Tiff how to deal with her situation; experiencing the limitation in their existence certainly gives her a new perspective.

Stephanie Plum quits her job as a bounty hunter after rolling in the garbage with a fugitive.  She just wants a normal life.  Only she has problems with every other job she takes on, a couple in a huge way when it seems a ghost from her past is toying with her with some spectacular results.Ranger offers her a job sitting in front of a computer at Rangeman, doing searches and background checks, specifically focusing on the disappearance of some men.  In this job shes actually safer as no one can get to her car when its parked in the Rangeman building, although Joe isnt too happy about it.Weve also got Valeries wedding, Joe gets hurt, Lula now working as a bounty hunter and needing Stephanies help, fire, car explosions, sexual tension and a great deal of humor.One of the things its easy to get bugged about is the fact that Stephanie doesnt seem to grow or get any better at her job.  And yet in this story, while shell never be as good as Rangercertainly never as capable or intimidatingit is obvious that shes better at it than she used to be, especially in comparison to Lula.Ive reread this one a number of times since it came out.  Even knowing what happens I find its a relaxing escape for a few hours.

Bounty hunter Stephanie Plum is on hand to witness the robbing of a store by the Red Devil, a masked guy who robs stores, sets fire to them and gets away on his bike.  Discovering hes part of one of the local gangs, she makes the mistake of cruising through their territory trying to spot him, and to escape when her car is mobbed, has to run a few of them over.  Now theres a contract on her head and they seem to find her wherever she goes.To add to her problems, Ranger is out of town, although this turns out to be a good thing as she discovers the location of the Bat Cave.  While trying to lay low and avoid gang members, she still has to bring in skips, deal with the preparations for her sisters wedding and her relationship with Morelli.As with the prior stories, chaos reigns and there is both plenty of action as well as humor and sexual tension.  And the ending is rather unexpected.Forget common sense and the fact that Stephanie doesnt seem to grow and many of the gags have been used before.  Its still a fun story and a great way to escape reality for a few hours.

This is a novella-length story following Julie, a woman going to the University of GA for a degree in journalism. She works for the campus newspaper and after a pretty young woman had gone missing without a trace, she starts looking into other disappearances of girls written off as the girls leaving on their own.  She wants to write a story for the paper about them.Set in 1991, the story is a precursor to Pretty Girls, coming out in September. The stories are stand alone; not part of either the Will Trent or Grant County series.I got this ARC free to review from the publisher via Edelweiss/Above the Treeline and hadnt realized when I started reading this that it was a shorter story or the precursor to another book and the story wasnt going along as I expected because of that. But it made total sense about halfway thru when realizing I wasnt reading a full novel.Tension and expect to be making some assumptions about people. It grabbed me. The attitudes toward physical crimes against women have changed since 1991, although still not enough; thought-provoking.I was also fortunate enough to read Pretty Girls from an ARC.  Is it necessary to read this before Pretty Girls?  Not necessarily.  However,  I recommend it just because we get so much information about Julie and her family in this story and youll see a big contrast to what theyre like in the future.

Originally released in 2010 in the anthology, Inked, this novella takes place near the end of the novel, Night Season when Cynna and Cullen are off world.  Lily and Rule are in Washington when he receives a call that a Nokolai friend had been killed and another had been arrested for the murder.  Of course it doesnt help that Robert Friar lives in this small town and had just started the group, Humans First.  Lily first has to prove that magic was involved in order to stay on the case.Id just reread this story in my copy of Inked and its been so long between reads that I couldnt recall most of what happened.  You do get a complete story involving Rule and Lilys relationship, the mystery, investigation and action.  And of course magic is involved.  What it doesnt have that all of the novels in this series have is the rather deep discussions on magical theory.  In that aspect it makes this an easier read.Most of the series regulars are mentioned, if not on hand, including Arjenie, who we hadnt physically met yet at this point in the series.If you've been enjoying the series you'll definitely like this story.  But I don't suggest this as a place to start.

Honestly, practically anything sitting on a table or counter in my house will eventually get knocked to the floor at one time or another.  This timer has hit the floor twice now that I'm aware of - and it still works!  I find that thrilling since the timer this replaced - different brand - no longer let you know the time was up after hitting the floor the first time.As with all spring timers, if the time you want to set is for less than 30 minutes, it will be necessary to move the dial beyond that point before positioning it for the time you need.  One fairly loud ringing sound lets you know that the time is up.I'm using his in my kitchen when multiple things need to be timed, as well as for laundry that I want removed from the dryer in a shorter amount than the rest of the load.

Evelyn Soder is on the run with her daughter Annie and her grandmother, Mabel who lives next door to Stephanies parents, asks Stephanie for help to find her.  Both of Annies divorced parents had to take out a child custody bond in case the other took off with their child and Evelyns ex is calling it in.  Not only is Mabel worried about her granddaughter, but shell lose her house if Annie isnt brought back.  Stephanie finds herself involved in a war with Eveylns landlord and is constantly under attack while still trying to bring in FTAs.This one took me a little longer to get in to, but it is still loaded with humor, catastrophes and sexual tension.  And in a switch, Stephanie actually finds a use for her gun.  There is some sex, but its fairly glossed over and not especially detailed.Still a good quick, relaxing read that still holds true on a re-read.

Bounty Hunter Stephanie Plum is shocked when told the next FTA her boss wants her to bring in is Ranger, her mentor that shes sometimes worked with.  She turns it down knowing she wouldnt stand a chance.  But then Ranger also becomes a person of interest when a Greek mob boss son is killed right after Ranger is caught on camera seeing him.  Now others are looking for Ranger and following Stephanie, believing she knows where he is.  And Ranger enlists her aid.If thats not enough, Grandma Mazur decides to move out of her daughters house and in with Stephanie, and Bob, a Golden Retriever is foisted off on her.  There are plenty of laughs and sexual tension and frustration in this story that branches off into so many different directions.Ive been rereading some of my favorites and many of them involve working with or for Ranger.  And its funny to see how tough he is and so many people afraid of him, and yet trying to force Stephanie to obey him for her own safety is something he cant seem to accomplish.If you read these books expecting to see much growth in Stephanies character or even her skills getting better over time, well thats an incredibly slow process that you might not even realize is happening.  And dont expect her to make a permanent decision between Joe and Ranger as that would end the series.  Just look at these stories as a few hours of escaping reality with some laughs from old favorites, and enjoy.

Bounty Hunter Stephanie Plum is partnered with Ranger when a man on a work visa bond goes missing and she finds herself caught up in a deadly game.  All of the regulars are on hand to add chaotic humor and in a twist, instead of destroying cars, Stephanie is destroying Rangers men.These books are potato chip reads; light and easy to get through and youre done before you know it.  Dont expect any growth on Stephanies part and thats part of the charm, as is the sexual tension with Ranger while in an on again stretch with Morelli.  We see a lot of both in this book.I dont know how many times Ive reread this book over the years, but it still brings enjoyment and a nice escape from reality.

Dria, a very old vampire and her human husband, Rafe, own property and a resort covering fifteen miles in Alaska.  The resort caters to vacationing vampires and their entourages with a heavy emphasis on sex.  The resort even includes some sex-themed rooms.  The mystery surrounds the corpse of a human found in one of the rooms being checked prior to a groups arrival.I had not been aware this was erotica when I picked it up for free and while those scenes are well-described, they take up a whole lot of the book.  Its cool that after fifty plus years that Dria and Rafe are still so turned on by each other that they have sex whenever and wherever possible (multiple times a day).  And even though many guys are drawn to and turned on to Dria, shes fully committed to Rafe.  Thats a nice change from so many other Urban Fantasy series Ive read.But a number of things bothered me and yet I can come up with a counter argument for each.  Sex is encouraged in the guests to the point that Dria does something considered illegal in the vampire world; messing with their minds, adding thoughts and pictures of others in attendance, guaranteed to turn them on.  It is with the intention that they have a good time, but that feels a lot like mind rape.The human employees are paid a really hefty salary and many of them are available as both blood donors and for sex.  Makes them sound like prostitutes.  And yet none of these employees do this unless they want to and it seems every one of them enjoys it.  When ready, they ask to be added to the resorts list of donors; but they dont have to.There is an observation room with monitors showing whats happening in each room.  Ewww.  And yet they use it whenever an employee donates blood or has sex with a vampire for the first time to make sure theyre okay.  And each of these employees wears a bracelet with a panic button on it in case things arent going well.  So its obvious that the welfare of the employees is really important.I did like the mystery although that took a while to get going.  And Im intrigued with this authors vampire culture and her place in it.  It seems obvious that the governing body will play a larger role in future books.  I am torn on what I think of Dria.  The enjoyment and safety of both her guests and employees is important to her and I do like her philosophy on not tying others to her as servants.  But that mind rape thing really bothers me.

Roland Quinoa Flour has been an excellent flour for our main use, making Quinoa muffins. Quinoa flour is hard to come by in local markets in our area, and when found is usually over priced. The Roland Quinoa Flour has been both a bargain and has had very good quality. The price on Amazon (about $8 per 17.6-ounce bag at the time of this review) has been about a third to half the price charged by local. RECOMMENDED.

The KitchenAid KBLR19CRPN Streamline Ceramic 1.9-Quart Casserole is a superb small casserole for lasagne and other recipes needing a deep baking dish that can also present well at the table, clean up easily and survive a trip to the dishwasher. I had also bought the larger 4.2-quart model, in red, and had been so impressed that I decided to also buy a smaller 1.9-quart model. It's heavy duty and nicely finished bake-ware. Although I bought the version in a lovely Persimmon I also have the 2.6 quart version in Key Lime and the 4.2-quart version in red. The colors are beautiful and if anything slightly more intense and deep than the photos suggest. I am a happy user of the KitchenAid Streamline Ceramic 1.9-Quart Casserole. RECOMMENDED.

The PORTER-CABLE PCFP12234 3-Tool Combo Kit is the same unit, with different color and a minor refresh on the compressor styling, as the BOSTITCH BTFP3KIT 3-Tool and Compressor Combo Kit. It's a super bargain at $199.00 (the selling price on Amazon at the time of this review) for a light duty compressor plus three tool kit. It might not stand up to day after day, week after week use building houses. But for the homeowner wanting to have something on hand for serious home remodeling and expansion projects it will likely serve long and well. Once you have a kit like this the home improvement possibilities start to expand.I have seen some on-line posts by people wondering what the comparison is between the BOSTITCH BTFP3KIT three tool kit and the PORTER-CABLE PCFP12234 3-Tool Combo Kit. Some people seemed worried about which one to buy. Fact is they are both the same kit. Both BOSTITCH and PORTER-CABLE are owned by Stanley. Go with whichever package has the lowest price on buy day.Although I might like a longer hose than the 25 footer included with the kit, and I plan to buy a Hitachi 3 1/2" framing nailer to add to the mix, I am a happy buyer of the PORTER-CABLE PCFP12234 3-Tool Combo Kit.

The All-Clad Textiles Fiber Reactive Kitchen Towels are good quality but underwhelming in person. Although they are very good towels they are neither as thick nor as absorbent as many other less expensive towels. The biggest downside for this buyer was that the print, which is a major attraction when considering the towels for an on-line purchase, and a big selling point, is only on one side of the towel. The reverse side is all white. Bummer. Not sorry that I bought a few of these but I wouldn't buy them again. All-Clad needs to up their game and make these towels both thicker and with the print on both sides.

At 4.5 pounds a jug of Roland Barchetta Kalamata Olive Halves is a whole lot of Kalamata olives. But, if you consume a lot of olives for things like bruschetta and pizzas and other dishes, it is a super bargain. Quality is excellent. The olives come packed in natural oils and a bit of red wine vinegar that adds some edge to the already intense taste of Kalamata olives. For me the olives arriving already pitted and halved makes them extra easy too use for most recipes. Everyone has their own opinion about rinsing olives before use, but I would recommend giving a serving or portion of these olives a quick water rinse before use to get rid of the packing liquid and any debris. A supper value. RECOMMENDED.

"How To Eataly: A Guide to Buying, Cooking, and Eating Italian Food" is an outstanding and comprehensive guide to basic Italian food terminology and classic recipes, as well as a quick survey of techniques and sources. In Italy the book is available as "I love Eataly. Il cibo italiano narrato e cucinato".Although the name and brand EATALY is in the United States associated with Mario Batali, who along with his partners are the US partners of the brand, EATALY, founded in Italy by Oscar Farinetti, has been a presence in major urban centers in Italy since 2007. As such it has in many ways revolutionized Italian gourmet food stuff selling in Italy which, in some places, like Florence for example, has been plagued by local shops charging sky high prices and huge markups to tourists having major Italian food-gasms at the sight of culinary treats and ingredients that are hard to find in the US. Although EATALY's prices are not low in the shop they are usually much lower than the tourist trap food boutiques that cluster in tourist areas. In Italy EATALY also has a very good web site and mail order business that can supply almost everything sold in the Italian EATALY shops."How To Eataly" is not cutting edge info, it's traditional. But what's presented is spot on with staple recipes and a lot of solid info about Italian food cooking and preparation practices. It's beautifully illustrated and laid out, as one would expect from a book published by Rizzoli. A great addition to the resources of any cook interested in Italian food, and for any traveler planning a restaurant and market tour in Italy. RECOMMENDED.

I had expected the Norpro 18/10 Stainless Steel Soft Cheese Slicer to be only bit bigger than an egg slicer. But when it arrived I discovered it was a both well made, nicely finished in 18/10 stainless, but also big enough to handle a mozzarella cheese ball or other soft cheese about as big as a baseball softball or ostrich egg. This is a big and serious cheese slicer. It has been great for making mozzarella slices for capressa salad and for making multiple slices of cheese dice for pizzas and so forth. Easy to clean up in the dishwasher. A great slicer. RECOMMENDED.

The KitchenAid KBLR42CRER Streamline Ceramic 4.2-Quart Casserole is a superb casserole for lasagne and other recipes needing a deep baking dish that can also present well at the table, clean up easily and survive a trip to the dishwasher. It's heavy duty and nicely finished bake-ware. I liked it so much I bought two, one red and one yellow. Colors are beautiful and if anything slightly more intense and deep than the photos suggest. I am a happy user of the KitchenAid Streamline Ceramic 4.2-Quart Casserole. RECOMMENDED.

The Lenovo Flex 3 15.6-Inch Touchscreen Convertible Laptop is an excellent laptop with an outstanding Full HD 1920x touchscreen. I will say right up front that my main interest in this unit was in its function as a laptop, not for its dual convertible laptop/tablet functionality. I am not generally speaking a fan of the convertible Windows based laptop/tablet systems. The interface paradigm that makes full screen apps and swiping and so forth so compelling and useful on smartphones and normal tablets starts to run out of gas in larger devices with 15" screens, at least for this user. And, of course, the folded over keyboard and bottom section, no matter how thin, and the keys being exposed on what becomes the back of a quasi "tablet", is an awkward arrangement. All that said, when it comes to the "flex" aspect of this system, Lenovo has delivered excellence to the hardware design and implementation of what some may consider a half baked software concept foisted on computer makers by Microsoft as part of the Windows 8 roll out. Lenovo has done its part by delivering an excellent hardware implementation of the idea.Windows 10, due out in July 2015, goes a long way toward rolling back and reversing some of the awkward Win 8 interface elements while adding a lot of new and improved functionality for the Windows platform across multiple device types. But, reactions to the convertible concept and Windows 8 aside, the Lenovo Flex 3 is an excellent laptop system.When reviewing a computer it's sometimes easy to get the part that the computer maker is responsible for and the part that Microsoft is responsible for mixed up. So I will try and limit my comments to the part that Lenovo had control over, the hardware. Many features of any laptop are also generic to most laptops, or part of the specs, so I will also try and limit my comments to what I think are the distinctive aspects of this model.The Screen: The Full HD 1920x screen with touch function is outstanding. Contrary to what some might think, adding extra pixels does not make a screen sharper per se. But it does remove the subliminal perception of pixels, the retina effect, that can cause images and elements to look, or seem to be, slightly less sharp. It also produces a much smoother, less granular image. The screen on the Lenovo Flex 3 is just wonderful to work with for both text reading and, of course, for images. If you work with a lot of digital photos, or watch a lot of content on-line, it will be a huge step up over the lower pixel HD displays that have been pretty much standard on laptops for the past few years. It's a pleasure to watch films and edit photos on this screen. Touch functionality is excellent. The screen responded crisply to swipes and pinches and so forth with the standard Metro apps included with Windows 8.1.Sound: The Lenovo Flex 3 has quite simply the best built in sound that I have ever had on any laptop that I have ever owned. Volume is substantial and there is excellent mid bass. You can actually listen to music and films on this laptop. Paired with the excellent screen it's a joy to watch Netflix videos, for example, on this system. There are no speaker perforations on the top deck of the laptop. The speakers are located on the bottom of the laptop, although in use the impression is that sound is coming from the keyboard. However they are doing it the system has excellent sound with good stereo imaging. There is no internal CD/DVD player.The Body: The Lenovo Flex 3 has a fairly thin bottom section, where the keyboard and computer guts are located. Both the body shell and the screen lid are made of metal (it feels like metal to the touch, I couldn't find a spec for the material on the Lenovo site or in the docs), as is the top deck that surrounds the keyboard and track pad and so forth. The Lenovo Flex 3 body is admirably rigid. How this rigidity is achieved may displease a few users. For one thing, there are no access doors or hatches on the bottom of the base section, for accessing or replacing the hard drive or upgrading memory. The battery is internal and non detachable. The bottom of the base is featureless except for ventilation. The hard drive and the memory can be accessed, but only by a rather complex disassembly process that starts with removing the keyboard. This shouldn't be a problem for most users, who will likely never want to change anything. But users who are accustomed to adding memory or swapping out hard drives may be a bit put off. Likewise if the battery should ever die it will require a tear down, and probably a trip to a repair station that may cost so much in flat fees that it won't be worth it.SD Slot: The SD and card slot on the left side of the system is of the type that only allows the card to be inserted about a third of the way, just enough to make contact. Therefore, you cannot insert a card and then pack the system in a carry bag, or easily leave a card inserted for backup and so forth.The Keyboard: The keyboard for the Lenovo Flex 3 has a wonderful back-light. The back-light lights up the keyboard characters and can be toggled on and off with the space-bar + the Fn key. This makes typing in a semi dark environment, like an airplane, much much easier. It's a great design touch that really adds to real world functionality.The Wireless card: The Lenovo Flex 3 wireless card is dual band and supports 802.11ac.The Power Button: The power button is located on the side, rather than the top panel, of the laptop. There are no activity lights visible from the in use position on the top panel. There are no activity lights than a power on light. The power on light is also located on the side of the machine, by the power button. This means that when shutting down you can't see the 100% off state of the system. The screen goes black, as though the system has shut down, while the system is in fact still shutting down. So if you have your power options for closing the lid set to hibernate or sleep when closed you may close the lid too soon when shutting down if you don't keep eye on the side mounted power light.USB 3.0 Ports: The inclusion of two USB 3.0 ports rather than only one, as has been the case with many recent laptops, greatly eased copying back and forth and backing up between two USB 3.0 hard drives. No external USB 3.0 hub was needed.Bottom line is that the Lenovo Flex 3 is an excellent laptop with a few quirks and an excellent implementation of the convertible laptop/tablet concept, a feature that may not be very relevant to many users. For me the whole laptop doubling as tablet idea is a non starter. But, if you like the concept then the Lenovo Flex 3 is an excellent choice. It is also an outstanding choice as a laptop only. Performance was excellent, the system did not come with too much bloat-ware, although there was some, and Microsoft has gotten its act together with Windows 8.1 to overcome some of the really awful aspects of the original Win 8 release. Windows 10 should be a big improvement. After a couple of weeks of tweaking and smoothing out the system to my own habits and needs I am a happy user of the Lenovo Flex 3. RECOMMENDED.

"National Geographic Traveler: Florence and Tuscany, 3rd Edition" is an outstanding guide to Florence and Tuscany. I can say this because I have done just about everything described in the book, and if a friend asked me I would make a lot of the recommendations included in the book myself. It has been said that a travel guide isn't really useful until you have already been to the destination and so know what the content in the guide is really about. It's tough to read a guidebook at home, about a culture or country you have not been to before, and not have your eyes glaze over with facts and figures and histories that may not be meaningful for you until you are there, or you have been there, for context. But having spent a lot of time in Florence, and Tuscany in general, this book really hits all the right points, doesn't waste your time with a lot of filler, and has just the right amount of photos and detail drawings and maps to help you get the best from a visit to Tuscany.Travel books have evolved quite a bit over the past few years, and National Geographic Traveler: Florence and Tuscany is very much a contemporary travel guide in that it understands that people now have access to all kinds of travel information while traveling. For example, a staple feature of travel guides for decades has been restaurant and hotel recommendations. But, in the age of TripAdvisor and other rating and info web sites and apps and with every traveler, it seems, having a smartphone or tablet with them, is it really necessary to use up many pages, and to make a guide bulkier and less portable, to provide information and recommendations that may already be out of date by the time the ink dries? National Geographic Traveler: Florence and Tuscany wisely dispenses with an excess of these sections, although it includes a brief but concise guide to perennial favorites in an appendix at the back of the book. This would have been a minus many years ago, now it's a plus.The book strikes a fine balance between text and illustrations also, with very articulate and instructive explanations about what you need to know without veering off into lecture length presentations. It also avoids one of the great sins of many other recent travel books, in my opinion, which is the use of superficial, pithy adjective laden text and cheerleading. It is well written, has some opinions, but reasonable ones, and is a smooth read. It does not attempt to be your new best friend or to blog past personal feelings and experiences at you. It is well written and, perhaps more importantly, well edited.Likewise the photos and maps are very helpful without becoming the kind of illustration clutter that are one of the big shortcomings of the Eyewitness guides, for example. The walking tours are just right to take you through various parts of Florence. The section on Siena is shorter than the one on Florence but covers what you need to know to make an enjoyable day trip to Siena or to stay there for a day or two while visiting other Tuscan hill towns. The snapshot sections of features and history for Chianti, Lucca, Pisa, San Gimignano, many other hill towns and the coastal areas are just enough and not too much.But, best of all it's all very useful and spot on, and the book is neither too large to carry with you nor so brief as to make you feel you might be missing out on something. If I had never been to Tuscany I would have been enthusiastic about this book just on its design merits, but having been to many of the places described I can say it will be a wonderful companion for your own trip there. RECOMMENDED.

The Kanu Surf Men's Havana Trunks are good quality all around shorts for casual summer town and sport wear. They are 100% polyester, fit this user well, and they dry out quickly. The only negative is that the mesh pockets are unusually shallow. In fact, these may be the shorts that you remember some day as the shorts you were wearing when you lost your cell phone. I wouldn't recommend jumping up and down with a lot of spare change in the pockets either. But, that said, at the price these are real Columbia beaters on value and the quality seems very good.

Bialetti 6956 Musa Stovetop Moka Pot is a wonderfully stylish update on the classic Moka pot design made by Bialetti. That said, it's not perfect. The Musa ontinues Bialetti's tradition of making pots that are both stylishly Italian while also looking and feeling distinctly cheap in manufacture. Although the Musa is a big upgrade in aesthetics due to its non tarnishing polished stainless steel, it still requires careful placement on all but the smallest burners to avoid the handle being overheated. and the art of detecting when the pot has pushed the last bit of water through the coffee, but before the coffee has started to burn, still takes a bit of practice. My main complaint would be that they did not bother to put an encapsulated aluminum disc on the bottom, similar to what is used on even cheap stainless pots and pans, to make heating more both more even and efficient, and that the Musa is not made in Italy. It's made in China, and some of the other recent Bialetti models are made in India. But, bottom line it makes a great mini pot of moka style coffee. RECOMMENDED with regrets that it's not 100% Italian.

The Casabella Quick 'N Easy Upright Sweep Set is clearly a cut above most sweep sets on offer. Having used a lot of really cheap sweep sets in various vacation rental apartments I can say that the people who are complaining in other reviews may not have a clear standard of reference. Some of them seem to be complaining that the set was not made for military service. It's a sweep set, for your home, to be used maybe once a day. At the price it's really disposable after a year or two. But, I don't think that will happen. I found the Casabella Quick 'N Easy Upright Sweep Set to be actually rather well made, to have great design touches, and to have appealing looks. It works great. The detachable brush head for hand use is a nice feature. I leave the dust pan in the extended position and don't fold it up after every use. At the right price it's a winner. I'm a happy sweeper with the Casabella. RECOMMENDED.

The RCA RCARCRN06GR 6 Device Universal Remote with Learning and Macros is a very good, and low cost, universal remote. It is not perfect. But so many after market remotes are so very far from perfect that it shines in comparison. My previous favorite universal remote was the One For All URC-8820 which has, sadly, been discontinued. The RCA is not quite as flexible as the old One For All model, but it also has some distinct advantages. It is much easier to program to learn functions from other remotes and to assign keys and to make macros. It has a back-light for the keys -- despite what some other reviewers have said the example I have of the RCARCRN06GR illuminates the entire keyboard with a somewhat over bright blue light. The only negatives are that the IR emitter is somewhat recessed and so has a relatively narrow angle of operation, the finish is glossy piano black which is a fingerprint magnet, macros can only be assigned to number keys 1-8, and the OK button and the arrow surround for that button produce a very audible click when pressed. Other than that I am a happy user of the RCA RCARCRN06GR. It's not heirloom quality, what do you want for $12.00? But it will probably last until you step on it, spill something on it, or it suffers some other typical device end of life tragedy. RECOMMENDED.

The VonShef Solid Granite Mortar and Pestle is sized just right, nicely finished.  The bowl has a lovely polished black granite look, but both the inner bowl of the mortar and the tip of the pestle are finished in an abrasive texture to facilitate grinding. It weighs quite a bit as would be expected of something made of solid granite, so careful handling when washing by hand is advised. It is not something to put in the dishwasher. Have used it several times with great results. Looks great, works fine and was priced just right at $20.00 (The price on Amazon at time of my purchase). RECOMMENDED.

The BenQ TreVolo Electrostatic Bluetooth Speaker is a very attractive and innovative mini Bluetooth speaker system that utilizes electrostatic speakers, technology that is unique for a product of this size and in this category.Electrostatic speakers have been available for many years. Way back in the Jurassic era of audio, in the now ancient 1960s, when dinos roamed the Earth, back before CDs and digital music, the process of getting maximum fidelity from the grooves of an LP record to the ears of the listener was part science, part art and part black magic. Electrostatic speakers were, in that era, and today still are for many people, the ultimate speaker technology. They were also physically large, sometimes as tall and wide as a person, even if only a few inches thick, and were hugely expensive. Electrostatic speakers still are, even today, usually large, expensive and confined to enthusiasts for elite audio. Electrostatic speakers are also finicky about placement, excellent for some kinds of music but not so much for other kinds, unforgiving in the way they reveal shortcomings in other parts of a system, etc. They also have relatively narrow and focused sweet spots where the sound is best, think the audio equivalent of the useful viewing angle of a LCD TV. For the record: I have over the years owned the original Quad Electrostatic speakers as well as Acoustat electrostatic and Magnepan ribbon panel speakers, so I know of what I speak about these sometimes difficult and often times amazing audio devices.So, for BenQ to include two relatively tiny electrostatic speakers, that fold out like wings from a tiny sub-woofer and amp section, at under $300 both raises eyebrows amongst people who have previously owned this kind of speaker and raises the question of just how good can this product sound?The answer is: better than I expected, but also a mini/micro version of the same characteristics that define full size electrostatics. The sound from the BenQ TreVolo is actually very good for music that is either acoustic or involves ambient qualities like the sound of a room in which a performance takes place or the presence of a naturally recorded vocal. In other words it seems best for classical, jazz, acoustic music, vocals and so forth. But it suffers in comparison to a conventional mini system with regular drivers and bigger sub-woofers for rock, hip hop, electronic and other forms of highly processed pop music. The amount of mid bass produced by the BenQ TreVolo's twin 2.5" sub-woofers was rather good. The system has pre-set DSP  profiles for various genres of music and some listeners may either like or dislike those effects, or like them less as volume increases. The system is not a huge volume producer. But it also does not seem to suffer from the sweet spot effect. That may be because the speakers are so small that they are heard more as a point source.To be clear, the unit will play loud enough to be heard in a large area, just the same way as a computer monitor can be seen from across a large living room, although you wouldn't try and use it that way. As is true with most "personal" audio speakers the system is best used and experienced in relatively intimate surroundings, like a dining table area or a small living room or a bedroom. It is not what you should pick to fill up a big living room or party space. Connectivity options were plentiful, with Bluetooth, USB in and a audio line in connections. I had a good experience with Bluetooth playback, but tended to prefer using the docking mode of my phone to pair with the system through a USB cable. Battery life was very good, easily lasting an entire evening, although for at home use I left it connected to the charger. I did not try the speaker phone/Bluetooth option.Generally speaking I am happy with the BenQ TreVolo Electrostatic system because I have the right combination of music and environment, it's great for playing jazz and blues at the dinner table. If your music tastes and listening area coincide with what the BenQ TreVolo Electrostatic is really good at you will likely be a happy buyer. RECOMMENDED.

The ThermoWorks DOT Model TX-1200 is a great successor to and replacement for the now discontinued ThermoWorks TW362B Oven Cooking Thermometer/Timer. I was sort of upset when ThermoWorks discontinued the TW362B Oven Cooking Thermometer. I had really liked that model. But, after trying out the DOT I am enthusiastic about the DOT and the re-design.Although the DOT lacks a number of functions that were in the prior model the DOT has boiled, so to speak, the basic function that people actually use most of the time down into a simple, elegant and, to my eyes, very well made unit. The DOT has the industrial design elegance of the original iPods, for example, and many other great devices that combine form and function. All the DOT does is measure temp and sound an alarm at a preset temp level. That's it. But the fit and feel of the system is so superior to the countless cheap knock off and other oven thermo-timers on the market, and the probe and cable are rated for so much higher a temp, up to 700 degrees for the cable, that the price is a bargain after using and contemplating the DOT in person.And, and I think this is long over due, the probe is both shorter than probes used for past models and competing products, making it easier to clear the edges of pans and to place the probe in upright, and the probe is straight rather than "J" shaped, which makes it easier to place. I am a very pleased DOT buyer. RECOMMENDED.

The Chef Craft Stainless Steel Ladle is OK, for the price. But just OK. Quality is good. But the picture used for illustration is somewhat misleading in that it suggests a more robust ladle with a fully formed body. The ladle is in fact a stamped piece of stainless, with a hollow form on the reverse of the front facing side. The handle is also slightly short at only eleven inches. Certainly usable and durable, but it's also lightweight and cheaply made. RECOMMENDED at under $6.00 with the mentioned caveats.

The Hansgrohe 31920001 Focus Single-Hole Bidet Faucet exudes a quality feel with a solid build. Bathroom fixtures are so much a matter of taste. Styles run all the way from what someone imagines that Renaissance Grand Dukes would have used if they had had running water and bidets to something that imagines what George Jetson would use if he still had a bidet. The Hansgrohe falls squarely in the middle with very tasteful and, to this buyer, lovely and restrained modern styling. Functionality is great and it matches the other faucets and accessories in the same bathroom. A great single hole style bidet faucet. A definite value at the under $130.00 (the average selling price on Amazon at the time of our purchase). RECOMMENDED.

The Proctor Silex 40884A Stainless Steel Electric Kettle is a fairly representative and good quality example of the current fashion for stainless finish electric water or "tea" kettles on sale worldwide. The pluses are the satin stainless finish, that is easier to keep clean than chromed finished kettles, and the low selling price. The body is actual steel, not plastic in a steel like color. The lid snaps shut with a latch that is button actuated on the handle. Some people may prefer a lid with handle or knob that is manually opened and closed. The dual water level windows, one on each side rather than in the handle make checking the later level easy for both left and right handed users. The only real negative is that it takes a relatively long time to come to a boil. This is somewhat typical of appliances sold in the US and other 110-120v electric current markets. But it does seem to take a bit longer than past kettles we have owned. I am of course convinced that there is one gigantic factory in China churning out zillions of such devices for sale around the world under various importer brand names. This has to be one of them. All in all a good value at under $30.00 (the selling price on Amazon at time of purchase).

It's important to state right in the first sentence the two reasons that the Kenwood KM080AT Cooking Chef Machine is different from every other stand mixer on the market, and why it is different than all the other Kenwood stand mixer with similar styling that may look to be much the same. Those two reasons are: it has a built in induction burner heating element AND Kenwood has re-imagined the mixing bowl as a combination cooking pot/mixing bowl. The Kenwood Cooking Chef Machine also includes a Cuisinart like food processor, chopper and shredder and a built in Blender attachment. Kenwood obviously has made its mission on Earth to allow you to need nothing else in your kitchen to fix a meal.How successful are they at that goal? That depends on a lot of variables that come down to both the cooking habits and practices of the user, the kitchen it's going to be placed in, and whether or not you buy into the whole meal prepped and cooked with one device idea or see it rather as a set of distinct tools you may use for this or use for that in concert with your other cooking pots and pans and routines.First, this thing is the Death Star of kitchen machines. It is big, it is heavy, it will dominate any counter top it is placed on. At forty-pounds in weight it will likely stay planted wherever you choose to place it. Those of you accustomed to taking the mixer off the shelf to use it and putting it back will need either a personal trainer or one of those kitchen beasts of burden known as a husband. It's likely to stay put.The food processor attachment is a reasonably good Cuisinart substitute, and the blender is pretty good as a blender. But the real question of course is "what about this cooking in the mixing bowl thing?".Although Kenwood would like to promote the idea that you can cook almost anything with the Cooking Chef Machine the fact is, as any experienced cook knows, that some recipes need a vessel or pan of a certain shape or behavior and other recipes need other types. The one vessel for everything idea has been promoted for decades to sell Crock Pots, for example. Although Kenwood has re-imagined the bowl as a pot it is still shaped like a bowl. That means that, aside from height and width, that it has a relatively small footprint, or base, in contact with the heating element. That's not a bad thing, but just as with a normal sauce pan or pot it does impact on what you will do with it.The Cooking Chef Machine would seem especially good for soups and sauces, especially for sauces that need constant whisking. I was able to make a very good Bchamel sauce, for example and let the mixer do the work of whisking the roux and then the milk until the milk set and the sauce thickened. Makers of chocolate sauces and various deserts would probably find the Cooking Chef Machine very useful. Although one can of course make risotto, notorious for its need for hands on adding and stirring until the right consistency arrives, in a bowl shaped pot, risotto is really happier in a skillet or saut pan. Nevertheless, I forged ahead using the Cooking Chef Machine to keep the risotto moving while adding liquid every few minutes and was able to produce a risotto with very nice texture. And lest we forget, the Cooking Chef Machine is a very powerful conventional mixer, and will easily conquer all kinds of baking and other projects that stand mixers are uniquely suited for. I used it to whip up several batches of quinoa muffins, which may not be a test of industrial strength, but it's a great mixer.A wide range of recipes can be cooked with the Cooking Chef Machine, but some of them may need to, and the operative words here are "NEED TO", be re-imagined a bit to adapt to the re-imagined cooking pot/mixing bowl. Although it was a little disconcerting to see something bubbling away in the bowl, I mean pot, of a stand mixer, the idea is sound if you have reasonable expectations. One slightly annoying issue is that Kenwood supplies a plastic shield to fit over the underside of the mixer head when using the machine for cooking. That of course is to protect the head from steam and so forth but it is, just like the pouring shields for KitcheAid mixers that we all think are a good idea and then lose or break, just another part to keep track of and avoid damaging.The big issues in assessing the Cooking Chef Machine come down to whether or not you will use it as Kenwood intends, as a complete solution, or will you see it as a set of discrete functions that you would use just the same way you would use a separate food processor, blender, hot plate and mixer? And, last but not least: price. The asking price for this system is easily equal to a restaurant style six burner gas cook top or a new behemoth side by side refrigerator. Kenwood knows their business, but I am not sure who the customer is for a two-thousand dollar mixer, no matter how ingenious and well made.But, one market that the Cooking Chef Machine might have worldwide, that might not be so obvious to Americans, accustomed to kitchens as big as shopping malls, is in the sort of tiny kitchens that are common in European apartments and many other places around the world. The typical Parisian apartment, for example, makes do with a two burner hot plate, a microwave, a bar sink, and a mini fridge. In such a small a limited cooking space the Cooking Chef Machine might loom especially large but it also might add a lot of functionality and be worth the price. In American kitchens, which are big enough to be subdivided into apartments, its value might seem more mysterious.I am giving the Cooking Chef Machine four stars for its quality, many useful functions, and unique and ingenious functionality. I am knocking a star off only due to the Hedge Fund manager level price. In the Hamptons, Aspen or Silicon Valley the cost of the Cooking Chef Machine is barely a rounding error. But out in fly-over America it may produce a kind of befuddled stress. If the price point is in your comfort zone and the functionality, especially in a limited cooking space, has a lot of appeal then the Kenwood Cooking Chef Machine may be the solution you are looking for. RECOMMENDED with caveats about price.

The weBoost Drive 4G-M Cell Phone Booster Kit delivers an effective increase in cell phone range for users working at the fringes of cell coverage in rural areas or in urban environments where obstructions or transitions from one tower to the next create cell coverage dead spots. The installation of the kit, including running the various cables and placing the removable external antenna, recalls the requirements that were once common in the days of CB radios or retrofitting older cars with stereo systems.I live in an area of low rolling hills with thick tree cover where there is a particular low spot that always seems to produce dropped calls. I also frequently go by car to a vacation area near the coast here that is just far enough away from "civilization" that cell reception is always spotty at best, and sometimes non existent. Although cell coverage in any modern urban area is near total and coverage along highways is almost always complete these sorts of problem areas can be frustrating. Travel too far away from the highway or from developed areas and you can rapidly be back in 1980 connection wise -- cut off from the Internet of your everything, constant updates of every little thing and comments flowing to and from your life. Some might argue that this would be good for you. But the practical reality is that people want to stay connected, even in the bottom of a sinkhole or the vast western outdoors. Using the weBoost Drive 4G-M eliminated the dead spot in my neighborhood all together and provided enough connection in the rural vacation area for a solid 3G connection.I was the only user so I can't comment on multi user access through the system. But for me it worked as intended. The only hitch with the weBoost Drive 4G-M is the installation. Installation is straightforward. But it does assume that you either don't mind cables being visible in your vehicle, for the inside antenna, the attachment of the power adapter to a cigarette lighter style power source, and for the cable run to the surface mounted external antenna, or that your vehicle is built in a way that makes lifting up molding edges or carpets straightforward enough to run cables out of sight. Depending on the style and fit of your vehicle interior you  may need a professional installer, if only for the sake of neatness. The assumption is that you will either place the head unit under the dash, an increasingly rare place in modern cars with center consoles, or under one of the front seats. Either way the external antenna is definitely not a fashion accessory for the beauty of your vehicle.I set my system up as a temporary installation with the cables visible as I didn't plan to use the unit all the time. But users planning on leaving the system in place should contemplate the requirements of their car or truck or RV interior. An RV is probably the friendliest installation environment for this system. For urban users the system may offer only minimal gains in coverage, due to the saturation of urban areas with towers. But if you work in or travel to rural areas and have to stay connected then the system could be a real connection saver. RECOMMENDED.

Let me say up front that I am a fan of Kraus faucets, and have previously bought and installed several of them in my home. I like the Kraus design sense, and I very much like the models that come in either stainless steel or a stainless steel look finish. In the case of the Kraus KPF-1630SS Single Lever Pull-down Kitchen Faucet reviewed here, it arrived at just the right moment as an IKEA single lever faucet that had been installed in a previous kitchen remodel was getting a little edgy. And, the new Kraus was my chance to redeem myself in the eyes of the significant other, who had never quite forgiven me for buying and installing a single hole sink with no spray attachment and then installing a single lever faucet with no pull out sprayer. The new Kraus set all that straight.Single hole kitchen faucets are, assuming you have some access and reach up to the rear of the sink, very easy to swap out. In under half an hour I had the old IKEA faucet out and the new Kraus faucet in. It looks great, I am very happy with the stainless look finish. Functionality of the pull out spray attachment is very smooth. All in all a win-win faucet choice in this house. RECOMMENDED.

Scalisi Skincare Advanced Wrinkle Cream arrives in a jar that exudes the aura of a high quality cosmetic cream. The time line suggested by Scalisi for best results with the cream, up to six months, is a lot longer than the deadline for a review of the cream. But in the first three weeks of trying it out every day the cream has been a pleasure to use, very soothing to the skin, with a scent that is perhaps innocuous but pleasant and unlikely to clash with other products.The dispenser top is an interesting solution to the problem of jar tops that require the user to scoop some cream out with their finger tips and pumps that always leave a usable amount of the product in the container when the pump "runs out". You can have your cake and eat it too with the convenience of a pump, very ingeniously designed and embedded in the top, and the ability to take the jaw wide top off and get that last little bit of expensive cream.Of course topical creams can't really fix underlying conditions, that may be rooted in your DNA, your age and health issues, and of course everyone hopes that they might, a hope that springs eternal. But the results so far have been encouraging, it at least has had a soothing and somewhat softening effect. Long term or if you stopped using it, difficult to say so far. Will keep using the product and report back with a review update further along in the six months that Scalisi suggests for getting the best results. For now, although it is somewhat expensive, if the price point is within your comfort zone it's recommended to try with hopes for good things.

The Linksys AC3200 Tri-Band Smart Wi-Fi Router has tremendous specs and potential but it is also a bit problematic. A quick survey of user reviews on Amazon of recent high-end high performance Linksys wireless routers reveals a small number of users who have a deep love/hate relationship with the various 802.11AC multi antenna models that Linksys has recently brought to market. Many users love the routers, the majority of reviews are positive. But there is a vociferous minority of recent buyers who swear the routers are ether possessed by the devil or are Satan himself masquerading as an access point. Many of the complainers are Mac users. I am not a Mac user myself, so I can't speak directly to what's going on there. But there does seem to be a built in problem with these routers that may not in any way derive from incompetency on the part of Linksys so much as a gross mismatch in both user expectations, real world use and compatibility.For one thing, although many new devices come with 802.11AC included the vast majority of devices in use pre-date 802.11AC and are probably 802.11N at best. NONE of the advanced features touted for the Linksys router will work without 802.11AC compatibility. Even if you have 802.11AC compatibility there is the issue of 5Ghz range and penetration. 5Ghz is generally speaking a poorer wall penetrator than 2.4GHz. Also, the monster bandwidths advertised for 802.11AC utilize a much broader, up to 160MHz, bandwidth and a multi antenna mode, which assumes a relatively non competitive environment with other devices needing their own bandwidth. And, of course as channel width increases transmit power decreases. Even with Beamforming and MIMO technology the trade offs may result in a wash on range and connectivity. And, last but not least, let's not forget all this horsepower may be throttled in the end by the user having only a 50-100 MBPS Internet connection to their ISP.I was able to get flawless 802.11N performance out of my Linksys AC3200 Tri-Band Router on the 2.4 band. However, in my own home environment I have never had much luck with 5Ghz connections, and the performance of the router in the 5Ghz band was spotty, including lost connections and connected thruput that was not terribly higher than on the 2.4 band 802.11N. As it's always worth saying: your results may differ. Despite a few hostile rants by some users about the firmware I didn't have any trouble at all setting up the Linksys AC3200 system using the browser interface. But the maximum performance available from the technology deployed here, beamforming and MIMO and so forth, is theoretical at best for most home users. As with all things involving the commodification of once advanced technology, the price point for this technology is falling rapidly. I wouldn't over pay for it now, when the benefits are largely abstract at best for 99% of the users and applications out there. I am giving it four stars because I think it's a quality unit with good technology, even if its absolute performance may remain elusive for many users.

It's mostly the nostalgia effect, but I love this fan. There were many fans like this one in my childhood world, back in the Jurassic era. Way before modern plastic molding technology and computer design made it possible to maximize air movement, minimize noise effect and make a fan look like whatever zoomy shape you wanted it to be, there were these machine age fans.Although none of the fans from way back, that I ever saw, were finished in brushed nickel silver, this is a pretty good recreation of the classic post-WWII pre-60s metal desk fan. Just like the old days it has a sweep bar control on the base, and the styling is spot on, although the fan blades seem to have been updated slightly. It is retro in its noise versus wind produced ratio also. Some people may think it doesn't put out enough wind for the amount of sound that also is generated. But that's not the reason you buy a unit like this. It seems solidly made, looks great, and is authentic except for its lighter weight and not being finished in industrial black paint. RECOMMENDED.

I love this casserole. Part of it is nostalgia, I grew up with dinners being cooked in and served out of casseroles like this, but the larger part is the quality and practicality of the dish itself. Although I have a wide number of other casserole and roasting pans, in glass and nonstick coated metal,  that serve well for baking a casserole, the KitchenAid Streamline Ceramic Casserole is the only one that both cooks well and also looks good enough to use for serving on the table. It's solid and heavy duty, and has a pleasing heft and quality feel. The finish is very good and clean up was a snap. Although I wasn't sure about the color scheme when I saw the pics of it on-line the casserole in person is really charming and attractive. All in all this is great for lasagna and baked pasta dishes. A good value. RECOMMENDED.

The Linksys AC2400 4X4 Dual-Band Gigabit Wi-Fi Router is one of the increasing number of hyper competent high bandwidth wireless routers on offer that are difficult to evaluate on a single criteria. Gone are the days when routers did little but create home or office networks for sharing a single connection to the net. These days modem connected bandwidth for some, but not all, homes has exploded to over 100 mps in many cases, and everything form streaming videos to on-line gaming now places previously unimaginable burdens on thru-put. But, that said, most day in day out uses of a net connection are very ordinary and mundane.As a wireless router the Linksys AC2400 will easily allow you to connect your home or office network and configure it for whatever security level suits you. It has all the standard interface features and security standards. It also has both USB and eSATA ports for connecting shared storage and printer devices. There really isn't much to say -- without repeating a long long list of industry standard features and specs and modes and commenting on the aesthetics of the plastics used for the box -- other than, like a microwave, it sits there and churns along doing a great job. That last statement in itself is testimony to how far we have come, that a feature rich, high performance piece of technology like this, that would have been unimaginable just a few years ago, has now become a mere utensil, a commonplace consumer product sold at affordable prices.It's at the extreme that the router's high-end specs come into play. The ability to stream wireless bandwidth substantially above the actual bandwidth that the entire home net is connected to is a feature that may not be a value added feature except for a very small slice of the user base. The total bandwidth ability of the router may in fact be only relevant for large office installations where dozens of users are all attempting to use the system at once. Or for video gamers wanting to get max thru-put and take advantage of the system's MU-MIMO Ready connectivity for high demand video centric applications.For the average user these abilities are just not an issue. And the system may be over kill for a single person, a couple, or even a large family wanting to do basic net chores and tasks. That said, all the usual issues like setup and installation, security and so forth worked easily and flawlessly. Coverage was excellent and there were no dead spots in our house with this router driving the WAN. I am not a gamer, so I can't critique how it worked for intensely interactive purposes. And I am of course not fifty people all wanting to access the router at once.The Linksys AC2400 4X4 Dual-Band Gigabit Wi-Fi Router  is unlikely to ever have its full potential used in an average household. But that doesn't mean that you should avoid it. Quite the contrary, if the price suits your budget you could probably do little better than to build its redundant capacity into your home network. At the end of the day the Linksys AC2400 is a very high end wireless router that will only be limited by the bandwidth of your connection to the net, and the wireless abilities of your connected devices of course, and allow print serving and shared storage for your WAN. There's no reason to buy a lesser router if this router hits your price point. RECOMMENDED.

"Amore: An American Father's Roman Holiday", by Roger Friedland, has many fine qualities.  But it is also not without quirks, intermittent flat spots and tangents. What book of personal experience in a world of blogging and self-aware long form reportage of the minutely personal is not? That said, and although prose is wholly a matter of personal taste, this reviewer found the book a bit of a slog."Amore: An American Father's Roman Holiday" is in many ways representative of a modern genre of writing that might be termed a long form blog, a stream of topics, events, reminisces, opinion and idealized depictions of the environment, broken up into what might be called chapters or might be called posts, laced together by a recollection or an event, maybe many of them, all cohered by an underlying opinion or theory. A novel it is not. As a letter home it is too long, and as a 350+ page blog it is too much.The author has, for this reader, the annoying practice of mixing past tense descriptions in present tense situations, rather than telling thematically whole stories of what happened in the past or how something was. The author confuses recounting information and details with story telling, which it is not. If it had been written with a more literary sense of place, prose and events, and with both more discipline and more wit or anger in forming the narration of things seen and felt, the book could have been twice as long and four times more interesting. There are a wealth of interesting observations and fascinating individuals in it. As it is, the voice on the page makes it twice too long and, for this reader, rarely involving.Friedland nevertheless has a keen eye for cultural behavior and customs. There is a lot of texture and detail about Rome and life there in this book, as seen from his expatriate moralist viewpoint. The author idealizes Rome, and the implication throughout is that this is the better way to live, a view that reflects on American society in a way that seems to annoy some American Amazon reviewers. A main theme in the book is the author's concern for the toxic effect on his daughters of American style pop-feminist culture, personified for the author by the insidious person of Madonna, with its perceived emphasis on warrior bitches and role playing slut chic empowerment. Friedland's idealization of Rome assumes Rome to be a safer place with a distinct and more deeply human culture that is resistant to soulless American influences and gynokult propaganda. He was intent during his time in Rome that his daughters come of age in imperfect and sometimes traumatic Rome rather than in imperfect and sometimes traumatic America. The cultural context and style in which one is excited, traumatized, saddened, inspired or enchanted in youth leaves a lasting impression, and Friedland wanted his daughters to be cast and molded by experiences with a distinct not in America flavor.Friedland has a worthwhile point to make, albeit a politically incorrect one that is sure to annoy those fueled by received wisdom in the United States. But he does not illustrate his views with any narrative events that convey the choices, consequences or realities of the two worlds he has posed against each other. His ideas of Rome may be an expatriate's romance of place as much as it may be a reality. But if there is one thing true about the Internet as a global force, and about the techno-aristocracy and global media and marketing corporations that profit from it, it is the instinct to make the world like California and to make America like the world. There may be no escape, even for refugees seeking peace in the heart of ancient empires.It is interesting to note that Rome, especially ancient Rome, with all its many sins, faults, mayhem, dysfunctions, vanities, cruelties and debacles, has persisted through two-thousand years of history to remain a hazy ideal to many people in western societies. In the case of the "Amore: An American Father's Roman Holiday", the author takes the view that modern Rome, with its deeply ancient core at the heart of a sprawling city that is in so many ways deeply imperfect and brutal as an urban, civil and social environment, embodies an adaptation of human nature to reality that is more in tune with life and love. Rome has caused many Americans and British to exult in print about a freedom that they did not have at home. But Rome as a society frequently remains opaque and inscrutable to the readers of the many books that have been spawned by expatriates recounting their time spent and their loves had there. It's possible that it may be that way even to the Romans.Rome is the original Cosmopolitan society. But it's organized for a far older and perhaps more realistic set of assumptions about human nature than modern pious America, the land of perfectible human nature and experience. One can enjoy Roman Cosmopolitanism without being insanely ambitious, endlessly productive, tightly scheduled, fully booked, wealthy, morally obsessed or endlessly judged before courts of literal minded goodness. Who is to say which place is best for each reader? In fact America may very well be all about the perfectibility of human nature while Rome is all about he complete imperfectability of human nature, whether before God, law, science, history or authority.For the author of "Amore: An American Father's Roman Holiday" the old ways obviously make for a happier place, even if they do not make for a completely engaging or cogent book of his consciousness midst the subject. Although the world does not perhaps need a "Daddy Dearest" take by the daughters on Mr. Friedland's experiment, it would be interesting to know how this voyage seemed to the objects of his worry and the beneficiaries, for better or worse, of his quest. But that's another book.

The Ipevo CDCU-04IP VX-1 Internet Conference Station is an extremely well implemented conference call solution for the remarkably low price of about $200.00 on Amazon at the time of this review. Although I have no office colleagues to teleconference with, nor any distant workgroups or family members to teleconference with, I do have a spouse that has exactly those professional situations to cope with and who works from home frequently while conferencing with many different parties far and wide. The setup for the device is so simple that it barely rates a description, It really is pretty much plug and go.Although designed to allow multiple people in one place to converse with one or more people in a remote location or home office, the main use for it here was to allow someone to walk around while speaking in a normal tone of voice and to also listen to the remote parties speaking in something resembling good fidelity that does not sound like a squawking speaker-phone. On all counts the device worked smoothly, had good sound, and seemed to provide the remote listeners with stable and consistent voice quality whenever there was speaking from this end, even though the distance from and orientation to the station varied back and forth from moment to moment.The only downside of switching to this solution from a headset with attached mike or a blue-tooth headset is that now I get to hear the entire conference too. But that's what noise canceling headphones are for. One device addith better connectivity and sound, another device taketh away the noise and chatter. Progress. A great value. RECOMMENDED.

I really believe in this Scent A-Way Max, Odorless Spray. I am skeptical about scents and odor control untill I see the results firsthand. I wanted to see how animals reacted to my presense ,on a real  hunt. I just got back from a Western Style High Desert  Mule Deer spot and stalk, rifle hunt. I would spray this product on my clothing and me, right before I entered the sagebrush,into one of my several hundred yard long, honey holes.  It had also rained a little overnight ,so the stalking was a little bit quieter.  With this product sprayed on me and  my clothing, I was amazed at how much  closer I could get, to the small groups of does, before they busted me and scattered, compared to when, I had not used this product. Product is engineered to attract and attack odor causing bacteria. I never did spook up a buck this hunt, but had several opportunities for a harvest, had it been a buck I spooked up.  Remember these animals, deer and elk , live there on the high desert and are on the highest alert for movement and scent ,of their other main  predators ,the wily cougar and wolves  24 hours a day ,every day of thier lives. I really believe this product really  helps eliminate  human odor , that along with other prevailing  conditions , will help you achieve your goal of harvesting, the big  game animal, that you have a legal tag for.  I give this product a very high recommendtion for, overall human scent conrol  along with weather /wind conditions, to help a hunter in  harvesting a legal wild game animal.  This review was written to help readers, make and informed buying decision.  { FISHGRILLER APPROVED }

This new Rodent Zapper by Pest No More  really does the trick ,for all of the pesky critters I have here in my yard, on the High Desert of Central Oregon. I really like the safe  way this trap performs , and the way  it runs on my home ac power and 4 D cell batteries. If I put it farther away from the house, I string a small cord . Product comes with a  detailed instruction sheet,and flashing I GOT ONE LCD light. This trap is a very humane way, to get rid of pests ,all you do is dump it in the garbage ,put some new bait in it and you are ready for more Rodent Zapping. If trap gets soiled by critters ,first unplug ,then scrub inside with old toothbrush, or green scrubby ,then rinse and let unit dry in sun ,till completly dry. Then rebait and plug in.  I give this product a very high recommendation for overall quality electronics ,Humane kill and easy disposal of this type, of hard to catch ,dirty,unsafe rodents.  { FISHGRILLER APPROVED }

This comes to us from 1972, more than 40 years ago at this writing. So, it's a nice enough plot: Our Heroes visit some backward world, have adventures, and save it.Add in 60s/70/ lines and drawing, not too different from Asterix, and you've got a lot of it.But, this also has the "battle of the sexes" theme going on, where Man vs. Woman was a confrontation..The M/F team split up early on, and she ends up in a bikini.So many comics and other stories from that era presuppose enmity - I find it so disappointing.Fair story, fair enough art, broken premises. It's pretty good, but I look for more than "pretty good" in my collection these days.-- wiredweird

The plot centers on petty jealousies and control posturing. Beautifully, elegantly done, but with emotional depth my middle school might have been ashamed of.But, I found the styles fascinating. Even a lady's fashionable figure is subject to the fashion of the moment, and those very fashionable ladies had broader shoulder, hips, and waist than any current magazine could advertise.But that was hot then, and I like it, and I like it in the very attractive ladies around me today.I might not remember the action in this movie, but I hope I remember the actresses.-- wiredweird

Especially good if you and your date are well along in life.It's sort of an "odd couple" movie with a premise that needs to be taken seriously: experience keeps on counting. Business, business models, work, and workplaces change drastically over decades, but the people in them haven't changed much for thousands of years. Knowing the people keeps on mattering - much to the surprise of Jules, who complained "He's too observant."But, in the end, it's a feel-good flick. The older Ben doesn't come in like a white knight to save Jules from herself. He's there to help her succeed, both at work and at home, a subtlety that raises this one above cliche. Speaking of which, I kind of wondered about that workplace romance of Ben's until I realized that was another cliche-breaker. It gave Ben a romantic interest (and pajama party partner) other than the leading lady, so defused that potential complication. By directing Ben's love life elsewhere, it helped stabilize the personal and professional relationship between Ben and Jules. Yes, men and women can be friends and colleagues without Cupid mucking things up - I thank the movie for remembering that!So, this one's hard to describe. It feels like a happy genre flick, until you start to think about it. Then you realize that it undoes some of the most common tropes and re-does them, only better.-- wiredweird

The story is a charming one: An unlikely pair becoming fast friends and, in the end, reach for their dreams, together. It's perfectly chaste, but there's a Romeo and Juliet quality about their friendship in the face of objections from each one's family and community - or maybe more of a  Guess Who's Coming to Dinner feeling, toned down enough for a children's story.It's not the story I'll remember this for, though. It's the gorgeous, painterly animation. According to the extras, each scene had to be animate three times: once for the line work, again for the color, and yet again to put the physics of watercolor paints into each frame. Whatever they did, it works, and works beautifully. The watercolor feeling gives this a gentle feel, and ties the imagery together into a unified whole. Even more, though, it gives an expressive range that normal animation can't approach: dense, dark cellars, busy city scenes, or lone characters as the sole mark on the page. The artistic crew really got it, and made it come to life. I can think of only one other animation that uses that look and, as much as I love the other, E&C mastered it.As a kid's movie, I imagine it works well - but haven't kid-tested it myself. But, as a distinctive achievement in animation technique, I recommend it to anyone who loves the medium.-- wiredweird

I admit, I haven't kid-tested it. To me, it's mostly a silly set of sight gags, on the general theme of cleaned-up movie monsters. The underlying story, however, starts as acceptance of people's differences, and it does a pretty fair job of that - up until it sort of shoots itself in the foot towards the end by undoing the difference most central to the plot.I was looking for something amusing and not requiring too much thought. This was nearly perfect: amusing, and not able to stand up to too much thought.-- wiredweird
The imagery is as good as any ever. The detail draws me in completely. But the plot is all middle school, not a part of my life I want to bring back. Visually wonderful, but shallow.-- wiredweird

Sweet, and hard, and loving, and tough, and very girly. Not the most lubricious of reads, but good for the human an humane story behind all the fiction. Not actually the steamiest around, but builds the who mood beautifully.-- wiredweird

Miss Naomi must have been huge fun at parties.This grandmother amassed a wonderful collection of art regarding human reproduction, apparently spurred my a mostly-innocent request from an adult son.It's an amazing assemblage. This doesn't divide into chapters, but it has some inner logic of its own, shifting from topic to topic, often before I knew it had happened. So what's here? Well, everything. 1950s girly kitsch, prehistoric sculpture, paintings from India in or imitating the Moghul era, African fetishes, sculpture, drawing, litho, painting, music boxes, ash trays, and pretty much everything else you can (or can't) imagine. Nothing goes far into the dark side, but an awful lot goes into the dork side.I call this a gold mine of erotic art. But, please remember that a commercial gold mine these days yields one gram of gold per tonne of ore, or less. You'll find some lovely nuggets here, but a fair bit more dross, too. Some of these pieces are magnificent artisanry, but I found far fewer to be memorable art. But, that's just me.-- wiredweird

As a technical manual for a 21st century student, don't get your hopes up. Where you or I might reach for any of several torches, Fuller relies on coal fires - but I never imagined how many ways you could build a furnace for, or in, or around a workpiece. I admire these guys (yes, all guys) so much more for the blunt instruments they made such fine work with. Forging, moving metal, hasn't changed since metallurgy hasn't changed, and the student looking for technique might find some novel approaches.
