On the other hand, the Pivotal Living app uses activity sensor data from a Members smartphone to reconcile the data returned from Pivotal Tracker 1, and overlays this information every 20 minutes to corroborate basic health data for a higher degree of accuracy.  But as I often leave my cell phone turned off while at home and don't take it with me when I'm out exercising, that could be part of the problem.The company has an interesting business model.  When you buy the product, you get to use their app for 12 months.  If you like it, you pay $12 for another years usage, plus you get a new band.  So, the price up-front is cheap, and you pay as you go thereafter.  While its a risk for the company, I think its a good idea and will be interested to see how it plays out in the future.Overall, this is a decent, inexpensive fitness tracker.  I was able to use it and it pretty much does what Im looking for in an activity monitor.  Four stars.

I actually ordered this planner for my young daughter, who is in second grade. She is very organized, and likes to write things down  not only her schedule (amazing full when compared to the comparative social desert that was the norm for the children of my era), but also her thoughts, hopes, and ideas.So, we were pleased with this product, the AT-A-GLANCE Weekly / Monthly Planner, Garden Party Design, Academic Year, 12 Months, July 2015-June 2016.  The planner is 8  by 11 inch size (double that when opened), which basically gives you a monthly calendar with space each day to place any meetings, a little room to the side of the calendar for notes, and best of all, on the following pages, you have a 7 line, 8  inch section for each day in the month to write more detailed information.  So, there, plenty of room to let an imaginative 8 year old not only keep a schedule but document her life.  And my daughter loved the Garden Party design of the cover, but my wife, no so much.  :-)Overall, a very nice planner, and not just for kids.  Five stars.

I have a six year old son who is prone to be afraid of many things  heights, going fast, bees (Im with you there, big guy), the dark, and so on.  I thought Id give this toy, the Worry Eaters "Saggo" a try to help him calm his fears even though hes not into dolls. (Power Rangers action figures, yes; cloth dolls no.)  As can be seen by the pictures of the product, Saggo is a very colorful (well, colorful if your colors are white and orange), soft cloth doll with a zippered mouth.  You write your worries onto a piece of paper, put it in Saggos mouth, and close the zipper, letting Saggo eat your worries.When I gave it to my little boy and explained what it was for, he immediately was captivated by the idea, and went off to get a piece of paper and pencil.  After he had written down something and zippered it shut in Saggos mouth, I asked him what he had written down.  He answered Monsters.  Well, at least Saggo is a monster he can deal with.Overall, Im not sure how much its helping him with his fears, but he does like to sleep with Saggo and hasnt put him away or out of sight, so Ill consider that a win for this toy.  I like it, and if you have a boy or girl with worries or fears, I believe this product is worth a try.  Four stars.  Now if it only came looking like the Red Ranger  :-)

One of the things I like about books by Robert Forczyk is that he either finds new things to write about, or new things to say about things that have already been written.  This Osprey Campaign book, The Caucasus 1942  43 is no exception.  The book follows the typical Osprey Campaign format - typically about 96 pages long, consisting of analysis of the campaign, commanders, forces and styles of warfare, pictures, illustrations, and maps.What makes this book different/special is that this campaign was part of Case Blue, but even though the drive to the oilfields in the Caucasus was the main point of the operation virtually all of the literature in English focuses on the secondary objective  to destroy the Soviet forces between Voronezh and Stalingrad  mainly because of the German disaster at Stalingrad.  Any discussion of the efforts to take the oilfields is typically summarized and brief.  This book is fairly unique in describing the huge struggles in the Caucasus in great detail.As typical of books by this author, he is able to pack a lot of detail into a limited page count, and still make it interesting.  He does a tremendous job of covering the fighting from all possible angles, from conventional to unconventional warfare, showing where the combatants did well and where they didn't.  The included maps, photos, and illustrations are better than average for this series, and are excellent.  Although very well read on the Eastern Front, I learned a lot of new things in this book, the most surprising of which was that the Germans were both qualitatively AND quantitatively superior during the campaign, and the important role that lend-lease aid played here.  I was also surprised at how poorly the German leaders (primarily Field Marshall List) directed the operations, and that with better ... even average ... leadership, the Germans could have accomplished more.  It is very doubtful that they could have accomplished all of their goals, due to the  logistical nightmare that they were operating under, but the oilfields at Grozny could have easily been captured.Overall  an outstanding book, particularly given the dearth of other in-depth material in English.  On a side note, this book is detailed and complete on its own, but I can only hope/dream that Mr Forczyk will do a full-length book on this operation as he did after his Osprey Campaign book on the fighting in Sevastopol in 1942.  Five very big stars.

This tool-less, top-shelf TV mount is one of those products that make me go wow! and wonder why nobody has thought of it before. It literally installs to the top of your TV in seconds, and gives you six inches or so to place a TV remote, game controller, small speaker (I dont know about you by my LCD speakers are terrible), or such. (And you can get this in larger sizes if you need more storage room.)You install it by hooking the front of the shelf to the top of your TV, adjusting the supporting arm, and then twisting a small lever to lock the arm in place. It literally took me less time to install it than it did to type this sentence. They also include a small mesh pad to put on top of the shelf to keep a speaker from rattling on the metal stand should you put one there.About the only drawback, and its just a minor point and not a problem, is if your TV has its speakers on the top rather than the sides or bottom. If you do, this will sit over them on the side you install this shelf. It wouldn't totally block the speaker, but it could divert the sound a little.But I really love this gadget. Its easy to install, sturdy, and gives you a place to put things that would otherwise be clutter around your TV. I give this product my highest recommendation. Five stars.

I originally ordered this necklace (through the Amazon Vine program) for my wife. I liked the simple, yet somewhat elegant look of the heart-shaped pendant jazzed up by the Amethyst, as shown in the picture of the product. My wife has a large neck (dont read this honey! :-) ) so the advertised 18 inch length with a 2 inch extender was also a big plus, to my eyes. So now that we have it, here are my impressions.It is attractive, and the Amethyst looks better than I thought it would, but the pendants are smaller than I expected. Its actually looks a little better on my 8 year old girl than my wife because of the smallish size (although it's not "kiddie" jewelry). Without the 2 inch extender, it would have ridden too high on my wifes neck, so the extender was indeed a nice touch for this jewelry. The two chains are on the thin side and get tangled if youre not careful. They do not adjust individually. But the chains and pendants ride well together for my two ladies.Overall, this is a nice necklace for the suggested price, but it could be a little bigger. Im going to go along with the majority if other reviewers here, and give this a solid four star rating.

To me at least, Samsung is not one of the names that come to mind when I think of vacuum cleaners.  TVs, yes.  Cell phones, yes.  But vacuum cleaners, thats a new one.  But, as my wife wanted a lighter vacuum cleaner to replace a failing one on our upstairs floor, and the Amazon Vine program just happened to offer me a this product to review, the stars lined up and here we are.  Below are my pros and cons about this upright cleaner.Pros:- It is lightweight for its size, coming in at just over 13 pounds.- Very strong suction.  And I mean very strong.  It does an excellent job cleaning big carpets.  At full power, it pulls up lighter weigh rugs, like throw rugs, right off of the floor (my wife said it felt like the vacuum was sticking to the rug like a magnet to metal).  But you can adjust the cleaning strength to suit the carpet you're cleaning.- It was very easy to snap together/assemble.- As seems to be the norm nowadays, its bagless.  While bagless vacuums are by nature more messy to empty and you have to clean the filters, I like not having to keep buying bags and filters.- The cord is pleasingly long.Cons:- The cord doesnt self-retract.  I only consider this a very minor con, because if you want a light-weight vacuum, you have to eliminate things like a self-retractor to keep the weight down.  It also doesnt self-propel itself, which again, was a way to save weight.- The cleaning head swivels.  While this can also be considered a plus from a cleaning perspective, it feels a little too loose for my tastes when I vacuum.- The optional hand tool doesnt have a place to hang on the cleaner, you have to store it elsewhere.Neither a pro nor a con:- It has a dust sensor on the cleaning head area  vacuum until the sensor turns from red to green and the rug is clean.  I cant tell how well this works  it seems kind of gimmicky to me, but I could be wrong.- When I went to dump the dust container, it was packed down and I had to poke around inside to get to all come out.  (I also had a small piece of plastic wrap get stuck inside, which also required me to take things apart.)  I dont list this as a con, though, as I think this is a byproduct of the strong suction and because tight compaction means youd have to empty it less often.Overall, I consider this Samsung a little quirky, but its an above-average vacuum cleaner.  It is lightweight and does a good job, albeit at the trade-off cost of a few features that heavier vacuums have.  Four stars.

I have three children, and I'm making a set of the common coins for each of my children, so I own a few dozen different sets/volumes of Whitman Coin Folders.  What I do is collect my pocket change and buy rolls of coins from the bank to find coins to put into the folders, and when I find a coin of better quality in my change/rolls, I replace the poorer quality coin with the better one.  And whatever I have left, I roll up and sell back to the bank.  Whitman coin folders are my favorite brand of folders for holding my coins, and most of the are very good for the price you pay and for what you get.  Sadly, these folders don't quite measure up.  I have three problems with them.First, the coin slots are generally too tight, so that you have to force the coins into slots in the folder.  In some cases, you almost have to deform the slot to get the coin in.Second, the "backing" between the coin slot and the back of the folder is thin ... so thin that when I pop a coin out to replace it with a new one, I occasionally tear the backing.  Exacerbating the problem is that the coins are wedged in too tightly so I have to push harder, but the thin material is most of the problem, and is not the same quality as in other Whitman folders I've purchased.And third, the other folders give you two coin slots per year, one for the Philadelphia Mint and the other for the Denver Mint.  (Virtually all common coins are made at both mints.)  These only have one slot per coin.  This means that you have to buy a second folder for each volume if you want to store the coins from both mints.  Other Whitman folders of similar size/style do not force you to do this.  This folder very generously spaces out the spots for the coins and has four "blank" spots in the end of the folder which has no real purpose ... it could very easily be re-organized so you could have two spots per coin like in the other Whitman Folders.Overall, I'm very disappointed in these folders for Presidential Coins, especially when comparing them to all of the other excellent Whitman folders for other coins.  I won't stop buying them, but I'm not happy about the general poor quality and the need to buy two folders per volume instead of only one for this set.  Two stars.

As I get older (and older!), my typical activity level has gone from running/playing softball to biking and trying to keep up with my kids. One thing that hasnt changed, though, is my appreciation for a good pair of sunglasses that are comfortable, fit well, and stay-in-place during activities. How do these sunglasses, the .Under Armour Men's Core 2.0 8600082-000930 Sunglasses, measure up? Read onPros:- Are adjustable to allow a custom fit  mostly (see my cons below). They stay on my face very well when Im sweating and being active.- Do a great job of glare reduction (per the manufacturers specifications, they block 100 percent of UVA, UVB & UVC rays)- Have good, low distortion peripheral vision from the wraparound lenses- Are lightweight yet toughCons:- You need to try these on in the store (or *really* know your sunglasses size); I have a round-shaped face, and while otherwise very comfortable, they were tight across my temples.- They dont fold flat so you cant store them in a more standard sunglasses case. They do come with a soft bag you can carry/store them in, though. This honestly is not a major flaw, but with a bunch of active children, Id personally feel a little better with a more protective case.Overall, these are good shades, provided you try them on before you buy them to ensure they fit your face. They arent cheap, but theyre worth what youd pay for them. 3  stars, rounded up to four.

Legend: A Harrowing Story from the Vietnam War of One Green Beret's Heroic Mission to Rescue a Special Forces Team Caught Behind Enemy Lines, by Eric Blehm, is a nice surprise  a tense, taut story about an American Hero, Green Beret Staff Sergeant Roy Benavidez that reads like fiction but is very, very true.The book covers Staff Sergeant Benavidezs life but also covers the supporting characters as they all zero in-on May 2, 1968, when a Special Forces team gets inserted into Cambodia and things rapidly go from bad to worse.  If youre not aware of SSgt Benevidezs story or the outcome of this mission (like I wasnt), there are a lot of twists and turns to the narrative that keep you hooked until the end.The author does a fine job of balancing technical jargon, mission and personal details, and gripping writing to enthrall anyone with a desire to read about the Vietnam War, heroism in the face of mortal danger, or how a person preservers though the hard times in life.  I highly recommend this book.  Five stars.

Isn't That Rich?: Life Among the 1 Percent, by entrepreneur Richard Kirshenbaum, is a collection of his monthly columns for the New York Observer, along with a few new essays for this book. As the title suggests, the author writes about the ultra-wealthy, wryly observing how they live and how they differ from (or are alike) compared to the common man. (Although hes probably writing more about the top one-hundredth of the top one percent with regards to wealth.) Organized thematically, the book covers various topics such as divorce and dating, vacations, diets, how rich you have to be to be rich, and so on.Kirshenbaum writes in an easy, whimsical style that make this a good book for when you just want to read something light and gossipy. When he discusses a new topic, he often gets his friends and acquaintances opinions, such as on how some people have paid friends, or the (bad) trend that some high-end restaurants are intentionally offering poor customer service. He cloaks his sources with nicknames to protect both the innocent and guilty, although if you follow along closely over several columns, you may be able to guess who they are with a good degree of certainty (such as with Lactrice and her husband Silver Fox).My only minor nits with the book is that it gets a bit repetitive, so you might want to read it a chapter at a time rather than the whole book at once, and I dont like how the author often transitions by saying things like and I raised my glass of (high priced alcohol) or " and then we ordered the (fancy food). Both of these are just minor annoyances to me, not serious problems.Overall, this is a nice book for the beach or for when youre looking for something different to read. Four stars.

"Marine at War" was originally published back in the 1960's by Russell Davis about his experiences as part of the First Marines Regiment in the First Marine Division.  While first published in 1961 in hardback form for adult readers, in 1965 it was published in paperback, interestingly enough, by the Scholastic Book Services for school children to read (I would guess middle-school and up).  But don't let that age grouping fool you; this is one of the best war memoirs I've ever read and not written primarily for young readers.The book, which comes in at 246 pages, seems shorter than it is, due to Davis's storytelling ability.  It begins as Davis and his fellow marines begin their assault on Peleliu during World War II, follow their battle there, subsequent rest/rebuilding/recovery on Pavuvu, and then their assault on Okinawa, the book itself ending rather abruptly at the end of the battle.  Davis does not give you his "backstory" nor subsequent life, just the time frame from the start of fighting at Peleliu to the end of Okinawa.I would hold this book as a near equal to E. B. Sledge's "With the Old Breed", which covers the same time frame.  Although each book is a little different stylistically, both Sledge and Davis became college professors after the war, so both books are very well written.  I only recently (and accidentally) learned of this book's existence, and after reading it, I am surprised that it is virtually unknown today.  Perhaps adult readers weren't aware of the book due to it's publisher, or maybe it was released at a time when war memoirs flooded the market and it was missed, but if you relish taut, tense, descriptive war memoirs, then this is a book you should not miss.  Five stars.

My oldest son suffers from allergies (as does my wife), and with the spring pollen season upon us, I was happy to be offered the Febreze HEPA-Type Tower Air Purifier to review as part of the Amazon Vine program. Below are my thoughts on this unit.It comes pre-assembled right out of the box. The only things you need to do is to open up the doors on the unit to remove the plastic bags from the two HEPA filiters and to drop your scented cartridge into its slot in the purifier. Then plug it in turn it on. There are three fan speed settings. The lowest setting is whisper quiet, the middle setting is noticeable, and the highest setting is loud. The amount of scent you get is dependent on the fan setting  higher speed means more scent. The unit is rated to purify an area up to 170 square feet, which is roughly 12 feet by 14 feet, or enough for an office or bedroom. As with similar portable purifiers, youll need to close the rooms door in order for it to really clean that rooms air, vice leaving the door open and trying to purify the entire house. My son and I didnt mind the scent, but my wife is not a big fan of scented air, so we removed the scent cartridge. The unit runs fine without it. The manual says that the scented cartridge will last about a month and the two HEPA filters for four months.Im running it in my sons room at night, and it seems to be helping. Hes not coughing in his sleep as much, which is a very good thing as hes also prone to throw up in his sleep when he coughs. Overall, this is a good purifier. Four stars.

I ordered this product, "Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Tall Fescue", to try and fix a problem with patchy grass spots in my front yard.  The grass there is fully exposed to the hot summer sun and tends to start browning-out by mid July, which I can deal with.  However in several spots, a few square feet each, the grass dies completely and I have a patch of bare soil.  So, I decided to give this product a try.I put the seed down in these area about 18 days ago, and carefully followed the instructions with regards to prepping the area and watering.  After about 12 days, the new grass began to appear, albeit not as widespread within the spots as I would have liked.  However, I'm hoping that with additional time, the grass will fill in better.Since I've just planted the grass, I can't yet say how well how things will look in late July, so I'll update this review as needed.  (As I received this product as part of the Amazon Vine program, I have to write a review within 30 days.)  But as of now, the turf builder is doing what it claims, growing grass in my bare spots.  We'll see how it tolerates the heat, but I'm hopeful.  For now, a provisional four stars.

I don't often read books aimed at my children anymore (after years of reading books TO them), but after I received this book for my daughter to read, I was intrigued enough by the premise to read it myself.  Pip Bartlett, the heroine, is a 9 year old girl who both loves magic animals and is the only person in the world who can speak to/understand them.  (In PIp's world, magic creatures are real.)  The story is basically has Pip and a new friend trying to solve a problem with fuzzles (if you're an old Star Trek fan, this may be a wink to  the "Trouble with Tribbles" episode) while helping her aunt in her veterinarian business for magical creatures.The book is well written, engaging, funny, and fun.  My daughter likes it, and honestly, so did I.  Five stars

Panzerfaust and Panzerschreck is Osprey Publishings 36th entry in its Weapon Series, where to quote from Ospreys website, they present the most important, famous and infamous weapons throughout history  (examining) the full story of each weapon, beginning with its design and development, following through its operational history, and finally analyzing its impact on warfare and violence.  This book, as typical for the series, is 80 pages long and contains over 70 period pictures and illustrations, as well as charts, tables, and so on.Author Gordon Rottman does a very good job of covering both the Panzerfaust (designed as a cheap, single use, throwaway rocket-propelled anti-tank weapon) and the Panzerschreck (a German built weapon based very heavily on the American bazooka) from inception through the end of the war and beyond.  He covers both types clearly and lays out how each was used by the Germans, and details the changes to both as the war progressed.  For example, one interesting fact I didnt know was that the Germans developed seasonally adjusted propellant charges for the Panzerschreck, as the propellant was very sensitive to temperature.  The aforementioned color illustrations and black and white photos were also excellent and many give good details that will be useful to modelers.These weapons were built in huge numbers, particularly the Panzerfaust, and were important in that they gave the beleaguered German infantrymen a better way of defending themselves from enemy tanks.  (Until these weapons were deployed, individual infantrymen typically had to either place a charge directly on the tank or use other, near-suicidal methods.)  The Panzerfaust was also useful against concrete, masonry, log, and sand structures, due to its large high-explosive warhead.Overall, these weapons were far from perfect (as shown in the book), and the local situation had to be bad for them to be used at all.  But they gave the infantrymen a fighting chance, so to speak, when faced with enemy armor.  I recommend this book.  Four stars.

As a child, I was always fascinated by lightning bugs and later glow sticks.  It seemed magical to be able to take a glow stick, bend it, and have it produce its own light.  My children now share a similar fascination with glow sticks (and lightning bugs for that matter), which made this product, the 100 8 Premium Glow Stick Bracelets Mixed Colors, something that I was interested in.What you get is a re-closable tube with 100 glow sticks and 100 connectors, that you can use to  make a bracelet or circle, of various colors.  My daughter is particularly enamored with these.  In addition to just wearing the glow sticks as a bracelet, weve played a sort of ring toss in the dark with them, and shes had a sleepover where all of the little girls were playing little girl games in the darkened basement and bedroom with them.  Weve even put bracelets on our children while we walk around the neighborhood in the early evening dark of winter, to keep better track of the kids while waking in less-well lit areas.  Well be saving some for a similar use during Halloween later this year, too.Youre only limited by your imagination as you can do with them  you could make a chain, a looping necklace, use them as accents on other shapes, and so on.  These are a good value for the money.  Five stars.Disclaimer:  I received a free sample of these in return for a fair and honest review.

"Archie in the Crosshairs (The Nero Wolfe Mysteries)" is author Robert Goldsborough's 10th book featuring novelist Rex Stout's detective Nero Wolfe and his able assistant Archie Goodwin. (As I'm pretty sure everyone reading this review is aware, Mr Stout passed away in 1975, and his family authorized Mr Goldsborough to write additional stories featuring Wolfe and Archie.) As I don't discuss any plot details that aren't on the back cover or give any spoilers in my reviews, below are my thoughts on this book.At the time I'm writing this review, I see that there is a wide variety of ratings for this book from other reviewers ... there is no consensus of "love it" or "hate it" here. Me, I by and large fall into the "love it" camp. I think the author does a very good job of capturing the mood, style, and sly humor of Rex Stout. The only very mildly false note was that Archie felt a little bit off sometimes, something other reviewers have noted. But there was nothing wrong or incorrect about Archie, and he was very Archie-like throughout, it just seemed that occasionally he hit a b-sharp rather than an a b note, to butcher a musical analogy. I even chuckled out loud at a few of Archie's wittisms to others or asides to himself, much like I used to do with Rex Stout's works. I disagree, though, with some other reviewers' criticisms about how the author characterized Nero Wolfe ... I thought Mr Goldsborough nailed it.With regards to the plot, this is one of Goldsborough's best efforts and is on a par with those conceived by Stout. I happen to like the timeframe the author chose for this story ... late 40's-early 50's, as to me that's solidly in what I feel is the golden era for Nero and Archie, where detective work was more brainpower and hard work, at least in fiction, as opposed to today's CSI-style of vacuuming up small bits of evidence and running it through spectro-analysis and the like. Goldsborough writing style is easy to read, and the story flows well.I've read all of Rex Stout's "Nero Wolfe" novels and stories, and while I'm not a card-carrying member of the Wolfe Pack, I'm very familiar with Stout's work. This novel is very good, and it satisfied my hunger for more adventures from my favorite detective duo. As I stated in a review of an earlier Nero Wolfe pastiche written by Mr Goldsborough, as long as he keeps writing them, I'll keep reading them. Four stars.

The Zume Games Tenniz Set is a great set that includes everything you need to play a little tennis  and I make a small pun here, as this is a bit of a miniature tennis set.  As can be seen in the product description, the net is 12 feet wide, and a few inches over 2 feet tall, so its not a full-sized net by any means.  But I mildly digress.  The set includes 2 rackets, 2 somewhat heavy, foam tennis balls, the net, framing to support the net, and a nifty carrying case/bag.  The total package weighs 7-ish pounds.You need around 15 feet of width (more would be better to allow for angled shots), and per the included instructions, 24 feet of length for your playing area (although again, more would be better).  As its too cold outside at the time of this review to lure the kids out to play, I set it up in my large basement (after moving furniture and stuff out of the way).  I was easily able to set it up in less than 10 minutes the first time (and around 5 minutes in subsequent attempts).  The instructions say you need a hard, flat surface to play on, and my Berber carpet was both flat enough and hard enough to allow the balls to bounce well.My kids had a fun time playing this set in the basement, and Im certain it will work even better once the weather warms up enough to take it outdoors.  (My basement, while large and relatively open, is too space limited to really be able to let loose when playing.)  I really like how everything is included and fits into the included small carrying case, making it portable enough to take anywhere, to include summer parties and visits with relatives.  Given the dynamics of the ball, I think you could even play it on grass and have a good time.Overall, this is a very well thought-out toy, and I dont see any downsides to it.  Five stars.

As you can tell from the green "Vine Customer Review of Free Product" under my name, I'm a member of Amazon Vine, which means I get offered stuff to review (more often books than other things) in return for a fair and honest review.  When I got offered the chance to review "TurboTax Deluxe 2014 Fed + State + Fed Efile Tax Software + Refund Bonus Offer", I did a little happy dance, as I have used Turbo Tax Deluxe for years now, so I saw a chance to both offer a balanced review of how well this new 2014 version works as well as to compare it to previous years' version.  Oh, and I could also save 50 bucks from having to buying it again myself this year, too.  ;-)Fast forward to when I'm doing my taxes with TurboTax Deluxe.  So far as the program itself is set up, the changes from previous years are minimal ... you load it, let it update itself, import your files from previous years, and then start answering "questions" and filling in information.  So far, so good.  But then, as so many other reviewers have noted, if you have to file a schedule C, D, and or E with your return, bam!  This year's version informs you that you need to upgrade to a higher level version in order to do that.  WHAT???  As I mentioned, I've been using TurboTax Deluxe for years, and Schedule D and E was part and parcel of what I expected to be able to do with this version.So, I started researching what had happened.  If I understand it correctly, TurboTax states that the problem is that these schedules were not included in the Deluxe version for other platforms (mobile and tablets) and it was causing cross-platform problems because they were included in the desktop/laptop versions.  So, in order to make everything hunky-dory, they deleted them from the Deluxe version.  They did add a small notice in their advertising that TurboTax has changed this year and to look at feature charts to make sure what you buy is the best version for you.  However, in my experience, most people don't either read that warning because they're buying the same product title as in previous years and don't expect any changes, or they order it online and don't necessarily see the warnings until after they've received the product.What I don't understand, from a marketing point of view, is why Intuit, the makers of TurboTax, would take a product ... a more expensively priced product than what their direct competitors charge mind you ... and strip features from the desktop/laptop version, while leaving the price the same.  I would think that a more customer friendly approach would be to add the missing functionality to the other platforms, while perhaps increasing the price marginally, if at all.  Maybe the vast majority of people using the Deluxe version don't need to use one of those schedules, but based on a quick reading of the reviews posted here, there seem to be a lot of people like me, who do.Intuit has belatedly began doing damage control, after appearing to ignore the problem for over a month.  They are offering a $25 rebate to anyone who bought last year's version of TurboTax and had to upgrade this year, collectable when you file your returns.  And I recently saw an ad from TurboTax where you can do your tax returns for free this year, which I haven't checked this out yet for veracity or conditions.Anyway, if it weren't for the fact that I couldn't file my taxes this year without paying for an upgrade, I would have given TurboTax Deluxe either four or five stars, as the product itself is solid.  However, I did need to get an upgrade.  I won't give this product only one star, as they did advise potential customers to check to see what product would work for them, albeit not nearly clearly nor aggressively enough, in my opinion, for a feature change that impacts what I can only assume to be a significant minority of their customers.  I'm somewhat like a sheep ... if I find something that works well, I'm likely to buy it again next year.  It's only when I have a reason consider other options do I actually re-visit my original opinion.  Well, now I have a reason.  Two stars.

"The War That Forged a Nation: Why the Civil War Still Matters", by Pulitzer Prize winning historian James M. McPherson, consists of a series of essays he'd written about the Civil War, including two written specifically for this book.  The essays cover a wide variety of subjects  - from Reconstruction and President Grant, a discussion on the Naval War, several on President Lincoln from various perspectives, and so on.  In many ways, the essays represent the views of Mr. McPherson on the various topics, which given the fact that he has devoted his life to the Civil War, are well worth reading.To my mind, the essays run from "ok" to "great" (my favorite in the book is #6, the one regarding the Naval War).  One thing to be aware of, though, is that while the title reads "Why the Civil War Still Matters", and although the author stated he had re-written several essays for this book, I really didn't get the sense that most of the essays really showed that the Civil War still matters today, except perhaps indirectly.  So if you buy this book with the mindset that you just want to read some insightful essays by one of America's premier historians on the Civil War, you'll be happy with your purchase.  But if you're looking for the essays to provide a strong correlation as to why the Civil War still matters, you might not see this to the level you're expecting.This is a very good book covering a wide variety of topics about the Civil War.  I'm well read on the Civil War and I found his insights both interesting and compelling.  I also like the fact that you get to read about a variety of subjects in good depth in the multiple essay format, as compared to only covering one subject in a longer effort.  I recommend this book.  Four stars.

In "Iron Hulls, Iron Hearts ", author Ian W. Walker takes a deep look at whether the Italians ground troops poor fighting reputation in World War II was truly deserved.  He selects the Italian armored units to analyze in North Africa from 1940 to 1943, as these units were as elite as any other Italian ground pounder in World War II.Although on average the Italian mobile divisions were not as good as the Germans and British ones, the authors point out why this was initially so, while also showing the improvements they made over time, so that by the end of this period, they were every bit as good as their contemporaries once you adjust expectations because their smaller size and obsolescent equipment. The poor reputation of World War II Italian fighting men that carries forward to this day was cemented in the losses the Italians suffered in 1940, and as the authors show, was a result of many factors: obsolescent/obsolete equipment, very poor leadership both at the national level and within armed forces, an inadequate industrial base, as well as wartime and post-war propaganda by the British and Germans. However, the Italians performed better after 1940, although they seldom received the credit they earned.The book is well-organized and well-written, and provides a great deal of information on the Italian armed forces in general and on how Italian armored doctrine and tank development specifically evolved from inception through the Axis surrender in North Africa in 1943. The descriptions and analysis of the fighting during the desert war clearly show the strengths and weakness of the Italian soldiers, and provide a more balanced portrayal of their true combat capabilities.  The 8 pages of black and white period pictures were also interesting, and would be useful to modelers.This book does a good job providing a full view of the Italian armored units and gives the reader a more nuanced view of the fighting, and shows that without large number of Italians fighting at their side, the far less numerical Germans would not have been able to win their spectacular victories in Libya and Egypt, before their eventual defeat.  I strongly recommend this book.  Five stars.

Aircraft of World War I: 1914-1918 (The Essential Aircraft Identification Guide), by Jack Herris and illustrated by Bob Pearson is an outstanding reference book that covers all of the relevant aircraft (both airplanes and airships) of World War I.  Although first and foremost an illustrated guide to these aircraft, the author organizes the aircraft into general time frames and specific mission types, and provides an excellent narrative to accompany the aircraft.  Chapter titles include Opening Moves, Air Combat Turns Deadly, Strategic Bombing, Maritime Aviation, The Italian Front, among others.  And let me be frank in that the accompanying narrative is strong and complete enough that it could serve as a stand-alone work on the air war even without the illustrationsThe illustrations are in profile view for each aircraft and have a short description and general specifications, such as armament, speed, weight, and range.  These color illustrations give the paint scheme used by the combatants, unit insignia, and other touches that will aid modelers.  In addition to the first-rate illustrations, there are many relevant black and white period photographs and numerous tables full of information like production numbers for various types of aircraft and available aircraft assigned at the front.  Although this book isnt meant to be a combat primer or history, the text contains plenty of examples of this.The book isnt quite perfect.  Because the authors often give multiple illustrations of the same aircraft (showing different paint schemes and equipment variations), the descriptive text can be repetitive.  Also, there are (rare) errors in the aircraft specifications.  (These are usually very easy to spot, when a particular aircraft is listed as being able to go over 100 miles per hour faster than similar aircraft with similar (or the exact same) engine.  These are obviously typos, not errors by the author, and do not detract from the enjoyment of the book.)Overall, this is an outstanding work that covers virtually every relevant aircraft of World War I, while also comparing them against their contemporaries and placing them into proper historical context.  Five stars.

"M10 Tank Destroyer vs StuG III Assault Gun: Germany 1944 (Duel)", by Steven Zaloga and illustrated by Richard Chasemore, is a book in the Osprey Duel format that compares the American M10 Tank Destroyer to the German Stug III Assault Gun. The duel format is 80 pages long, and presents an analysis of the factors ... human, mechanical, and tactical ... of the two weapons systems being compared, describes how the weapons were developed and utilized, and includes maps, drawings, photographs, and illustrations.The first part of the book examines and analyses the design, development, and technical specifications of these two weapons, as well as a discussion of how they came to be.  The author then describes how the Germans and Americans were trained, how they were organized, and how they fought.  He finally describes the strategic situation on the Western Front in late 1944, covers fighting around Ubach-Palenberg, and analyzes the strengths/weaknesses of how the two vehicles were used and provides some good tabular information on unit strengths and losses over time.Note that this book really isnt a duel in the traditional sense.  The Stug III was originally designed as an assault gun and, due to the extremely pressing need of the Germans for viable tank destroyers, was converted to fit that role.  The M10 was designed as a tank destroyer, but by the time it arrived in theatre in appreciable numbers, the Germans were on the strategic defensive, severely limiting the opportunity for these weapons to be used against tanks, as intended.  So, the M10 was used more and more frequently as assault guns supporting infantry.  So while these two vehicles undoubtedly tangled from time to time, especially as the Stug III was occasionally forced to act as a poor-mans tank, their usage in 1944 were not as direct combatants.Once you understand that, youll discover that this is an excellent overview and analysis of these two vehicles.  As a World War II history buff, I have many books that cover the Stug III, but this is the first book I own that provides detailed information on the M10, particularly on why the American tank destroyer force was even created.  Unlike the Germans, who viewed a tank destroyer as a much cheaper alternative to a tank, and desperately needed to produce as many armored fighting vehicles as they could, the Americans had the industrial capacity to basically build whatever they needed in the quantities they wanted.  As it turned out, the decision to build tank destroyers was a doctrinal one, and was eventually discarded, as tanks were found to be the best defense against other tanks.As the author shows, neither vehicle was perfect.  The Stug IIIs largest fault in the tank destroyer role was its lack of a turret, and the M10s was that it was open-topped, leaving it vulnerable to bursting artillery and small arms, as well as comparatively think armor.  However, both weapons were used to good effect even if outside of their intended roles.Mr Zaloga superbly presents his material, displaying the ability to pack relevant information into the constrained Duel format in an entertaining and informative fashion.  The photos, illustrations, and drawings are also top notch.  I particularly liked the cut-out illustrations showing the fighting compartments of both vehicles.Overall, the author does an outstanding job of setting the stage and presenting relevant data, anecdotes, and analysis of these armored fighting vehicles, and provides interesting and well developed analysis and conclusions.  Five stars.

I'm not a pro but I like using quality stuff that lasts a long time. I have this knife and the 5-1/2 inch. Honestly, I bought them based on online and Amazon reviews.  After several weeks of using them and getting used to them, they are my favorite and the two knives I reach for the most. The size and shape of these two are so versatile. I use them for everything. They are so sharp and hold their edge extremely well. They are light and well balanced. Makes cutting anything easier. I had other knives I loved but the wooden handles dried up and split and the plastic composite handles got sticky, melted, or cracked over time and exposure to heat and oils. The handles on the Global stay clean. They take some getting used to but they don't slip and I have not had any problems with them. Really looking forward to using these knives for a long  time.

I wanted something light and easy to use to wear my baby. This was light but it was not easy to use.Using the sizing chart, I ordered a medium, but it was way too big. My baby was hanging low around my stomach. So I sent it back and got the small which fit a lot better. But no matter how I practiced, I couldn't get it to look like the pictures. My baby was nice and secure but I always looked like a hot mess as the carrier would bunch and twist in unflattering ways. There was no way I could get my baby in the carrier quickly and look picture perfect. Maybe this is my fault, but I got tired of messing with it and ended up sending the small one back too.One more thing I didn't like is all the tags that have been sewn onto the carrier. There are three Baby K'tan logo patches sewn on various parts of the carrier. There are two huge user caution patchs sewn in on the inside of the carrier. These patches are scratchy, have sharp corners, and cause the material of the carrier to bunch and strech weirdly compared to areas that aren't covered by the patches. They are sewn in a way that makes it hard to removed because they probably don't want you to remove them. Though I returned my carrier and didn't attempt to remove the patches, I could tell that you have to be really careful to remove the patches and risk damaging the carrier is you try to.I really wanted to love this carrier but didn't no matter how I tried.

If you are looking to buy a PPB Boxy backpack, I recommend you get the newer version as it has an additional pocket in the back. This one doesn't and it was a deal breaker for me to not have that extra compartment. I give the older version of the boxy backpack like this one 3 stars for the lack of the back pocket compartment. I give the newer versions 4 stars, deducting one star because I'm not a big fan of the flap. It doesn't do anything and you always have to move it aside to access the zippered compartment beneath.The best thing about the boxy backpack is that it can be worn on one shoulder using the shoulder strap or as a backpack freeing up both hands. This is really helpful when you have more than one kid. Another PPB bag that can be worn both on the shoulder and as a backpack is the Satchel. I would recommend the satchel model like the Petunia Pickle Bottom Embossed Satchel, Central Park North Stop Special Edition over the boxy backpack because it can be worn both ways, is sleeker, and it doesn't have the added flap that gets in your way.

So far so good. Minimal assembly. You just have to open it, take out and install the handle, fill it with peppercorns, close it, and it's ready to go. It produces is a fine to medium grind. It feels heavy and sturdy in the hand. I like the solid metal construction. I had three other pepper mills that were made of acrylic with plastic/silicone pieces. Those all started to disintegrate and get sticky (the kind of sticky you can't clean) with time and exposure to heat and oils. And I had to throw them away. I got the chrome one and hope it lasts as long as the other reviewers says it does because it looks absolutely beautiful. I know the metal will. I hope the grinding mechanism will, too.

Works like sunscreen but feels and goes on like lotion. It's easy to spread and feel moisturizing. The whole family has used it and it works great without irritation. I'm surprised at how much I like this. And its a great value for the price. I would recommend.

This is a huge 200 piece basic starter set. I bought two of these to get my toddler started. We have enough pieces to build things and keep our favorite creations in tact while there are still plenty loose pieces to play with. I wished the storage box was made of plastic. Only the top piece is plastic and it fits over a paper cardboard storage box.

I bought this set for my toddler just for the Mater and Lightning Mcqueen. The other pieces that come with the set are pretty basic. There's not a whole lot to this set and it is not very playable/buildable unless you already have some Lego Duplo blocks. This is a nice specialized add-on set. I wouldn't recommend it as a basic starter set as it doesn't have enough pieces.

Not a very fun set on it's own. There's not a whole lot to this set and it is not very playable/buildable unless you already have some Lego Duplo blocks. This is a nice specialized add-on set. I wouldn't recommend it as a basic starter set as it doesn't have enough pieces. My toddler does really love the cute teddy bear piece that comes with this set though.

I knew these were going to be small but they were even smaller than I expected. They are well made and the 18/10 stainless steel is easy to clean and maintain. They have stayed shiny and polished after months of use. I'm very happy to have added them to my silverware collection. They also turned out to be way more useful than I expected. They are the perfect size for tasting, small desserts, espresso, condiments, baby food, and etc. I'm glad I bought three sets. I use them all the time.

Sleek,  beautiful, and luxe. Lookwise, this is and impressive curling iron. Functionally, it heats up fast and evenly.  High temps allows for fast curling.  I have thick, naturally wavy, Asian hair.  Curls stay all day and the heats seals cuticles and leaves hair shiny.I gave this curler 4 stars instead of 5 because even though I got this curler free to test and review, I think it's pricey for a curler. For way less, you can get a Hot Tools curler (same brand that my stylist uses) and get the same results.  But of course the Hot Tools curler won't be as sexy/pretty looking. I believe in spending more for a flat iron because the nice expensive ones actually makes a difference.  But I have found little difference between pro curling irons of various price points.
Beautiful machine that works great.  I love making the frothy milk in the morning.  It is so fast and easy and completely changes my morning coffee routine.

Small compact blender doesn't take up a lot of counter or storage space. Perfect for making small batches/single servings of drinks and smoothies and homemade baby food! Blends smoothly. Has a pulse function for initial chopping. Easy to clean. Did not notice much in way of noise reduction.Would recommend this blender if your looking in the neighborhood of a Nutribullet/Baby bullet or Ninja. For serious cooking or milling various grain flours at home, I still prefer my Vitamix.

Nice wooden highchair that looks good too. It goes with the rest of my dining room furniture.  The seat is padded for comfort.  The pads are removable for easy cleaning.  The got print is not too large. I'm happy with this chair.

Good Radio Flyer trike thought I would recommend a different model over this one.Good thing is it is a quality trike and it was easy to assemble. It is almost exactly the same trike as the other one I would recommend over this one except for a few things. The one I would recommend is Radio Flyer Radio Flyer Deluxe Steer and Stroll Trike. For about $20 more, you get the removable pushing/steering rod and a bell that this model does not come with.1. Steering rod - It lets you push and steer your little one along without you having to bend over and break your back. Useful for teaching your little one how to ride his/her trike. I got my 2 year old the trike with steering rod. It was very useful before she got tall and strong enough to peddle herself. I could push her all the way to the neighborhood park and back. It was a nice change of pace from the stroller. My 2 year old is average in size. About 50 percentile in height and weight. Her feet reach the peddles but she is still not tall enough to actually peddle herself. Although both the Deluxe version and this version of the RF trike is rated for 3 years and up, the deluxe version I'm recommending can be purchased for younger tots and because you can push them around, it is more useful and you can use it longer. When your tot no longer needs you to push, the rod pulls right out and basically you have them same trike as this one.2. Trike Bell - This is not as important but the deluxe trike comes with a bell and this one doesn't. I'm pointing it out because this was the first thing my 2 year old learned to do on the trike and she really enjoyed it. Not a total deal breaker but I wished this trike came with a bell.Otherwise, the two trikes are basically the same in height and size and weight. Both were easy to assemble. You just need a couple of wrenches and screwdrivers (different sizes). The tires on both are made of hollow plastic and not rubber. No pumping required. But they are not as grippy or heavy as rubber either.This is a good trike if you're buying for a 3+ year old. If you are buying for a younger tot, I would definitely recommend the deluxe version because of the steering rod.

Lots of fun for babies as young as those who are just starting to sit up by themselves and up. Little ones can engage with this toy in so many different ways and there are multiple modes of play that increase in complexity and grow with your child. As little one begins to stand, they can support themselves on this arch. Great toy with lots of music, talking, and lights made to Fisher Price's standard of quality. I'm pleased with this addition to the play room and would recommend to anyone who is looking for something interactive for their child that will last through the early growing stages.If you are interested but want to check it out in person, I saw one on display at Toys R Us as I believe this is a relatively new line for Fisher Price and they are promoting it.

Super adorable, simple, well made little buckets that are perfect for bath time and play time in the sand box. They hold about a cup of water each. And each has different slot patterns at the bottom for water to come out in different sprinkle and drip patterns.My tot uses these mostly for bath time. I couldn't be happier that she enjoys them because they are easy to keep clean and dry after bath time. I have replaced the bath squirts that have grown black mold inside with these buckets and my 2 year old hasn't noticed. I can use these buckets to rinse her off as well.I really like and would recommend these.

Green eco-friendly claims? I'm not sure about that. Here are my observations from using them in my children's toys, TV remote controllers, and wireless keyboards and mice.1. Lots of batteries for the price. This is a good deal for the price.2. Claims to be lead, cadmium or mercury free. This is great but I have no way of verifying this.3. Doesn't last as long as my Duracell but lasts longer than my rechargeables. This is based on casual use and observation. I did not do experiments to prove this.4. Recyclable. But you cannot just throw them into your recycle bin. Recycling is free through their company but you'll need to have purchased a certain minimum amount. One pack of these does not qualify. You'll need to purchase at least two. I still just pack up these batteries with my other used ones and take them all to a local facility that collects batteries.In the end, I don't think I would go out of my way to buy these batteries. Batteries are batteries are batteries. These work and I like them about as much as all the other batteries I've used in the past.

Fisher Price quality and design is some of the best. I never have any complaints with any of the Fisher Price products I get for my children. This gym has plenty of color and interesting toys to make tummy time fun for infants and parents. However, there are a few cons...because I actually prefer other gym designs better.1. Small. I found the mat size to be smaller than other baby gyms I own or have used before. This is not a complete deal breaker but depending on the size of your baby, you  may not be using this for too long. For most, I think this would work for infants.2. Mat is not attached to the arches. This is also not a deal breaker but it does make it a bit more of a hassle to move it from place to place.I prefer the larger criss-cross design of these gyms much better: Fisher-Price Rainforest Melodies and Lights Deluxe Gym or Infantino Twist and Fold Activity Gym, Vintage Boy and because they are larger, you can use it longer. I would recommend these over this particular Link n' Play Musical Gym. However, if you don't have a lot of space, I can see how this gym would work better for you and your baby.

Wonderful body oil that is extremely light and absorbs quickly. The scent is light and smells just like the body lotion. Very pleasant.I like to apply the body oil straight or mixed with the lotion for added moisture right after shower when skin is toweled dry and still a little damp. A little goes a long way. There is no oily feeling or slickness after it absorbs but my skin feels great and looks even better.The current packaging does drip a little. Just have to be careful when pouring and to wipe up excess afterwards. I wonder if a pump would be better.This is a great product that has been around for years. I would recommend.

I am not an horseshoe enthusiast. I actually have never play horseshoe until I received this set to test and review.Initial reaction...1. Very high quality2. Heavy and heavy duty3. Beautiful set and carrying case4. Not for childrenSet comes with 4 heavy horseshoes in two different colors, steel stakes, wooden carrying case, official guidelines. Might be overkill for the occasional/casual player. I can't think of how to improve this set, maybe except the colors of the horseshoes themselves. I like the colors as they are but for play, they could be brighter or more contrasting.If you are a serious player or just want a beautiful serious set, you can't go wrong with these.

Excellent steam mop. Assembly was fast and simple. Heats up fast. Big tank lets me clean 1 or 2 rooms before I have to refill. Decently long cord. Hot steam and nice pads does not leave floors super wet. Removable tank and becomes a hand held steamer to clean other areas of the house.I had a Hoover Twin Tank steam mop. It died after two years of service (I used it only once a month at the most). Not knowing which mop to get as a replacement, I bought another Hoover Twin Tank steam mop. Then I received this Bissell PowerFresh Lift-off steam mop to test and review. Hmmmm...I wished I did not buy the Hoover. I like how the Bissell looks and works a lot better and that it can be used to clean more than just floors.

Not my favorite pusher of the three I own. The cuticle side is not as sharp as my other two. If you're looking for something more gentle, this is for you. As for me, I can't seem to separate some of the more stubborn cuticle skin from the nail bed with this because it is just not sharp enough. This is even with the use of a cuticle softener.I do like the nail cleaner end. My other two pushers don't have the nail cleaner end. When I reach for this item it is only because I want to use the nail cleaner and not the cuticle pusher.

Works great. I use it on my cast iron for cooking and scraping down the pans and griddles afterwards. I've used it on the barbeque to turn burgers and steaks. I've used it to lift cookies off baking sheet.Has been wonderful and still looks brand new. I will be getting the slotted one next.

Love the smell, love the texture, love how my baby's skins feels afterwards. It soaks in so quickly and  baby skin looks plump and dewy and fresh. Baby smells fresh, too. The lotion is yellow in color due to some of the natural ingredients used (calendula, I think).I was using the regular Cetaphil and the Mustela Hydra Bebe lotion on my child before. I tried this on a whim. She loves it and the fact it's yellow probably because all her other lotion was white and this new color is interesting to her. This lotion feels and works more like the Mustela than the original Cetaphil, which I like better anyway.I deducted one star because I do not like the packaging. I would much rather prefer a bottle with pump than the squeeze bottle it comes in. Granted the lotion is on the liquid side pour easily and quickly, but the pump is just more convenient when you have a squirmy toddler or baby to deal with.I really enjoy this lotion and would recommend. I don't recommend if you are looking for a fragrance free lotion though.

Love this peeler. When I first I got it...I used it to peel ripe mango, papaya, kiwi...OMG worked great. I've since peeled ripe peaches and roasted beets. I have never had a peeler that could peel soft ripe fruits and cooked vegetables without gouging or obliterating them. I bought another one the very next day and gave it to my mom!Works great on hard fruits and vegetables too like potatoes, carrots, apples, pears.How much you want to remove is completely up to you. I have so much control with this and don't feel like I'm wasting my produce anymore. Press down firmly if you want to remove a thicker layer of skin. Use lightly and it will remove the thinnest layer of skin.The handle is not always the easiest to hold for me. It's rugged/durable but not ergonomic. Maybe I have small hands or it is just that because of the fruits I'm working with my hands are usually wet and slippery when I use this peeler. It's not a deal breaker at all but I thought I'd mention it.I highly recommend and wouldn't hesitate to purchase again when I need a new peeler.

Very durable, sturdy, well-made, and ADORABLE umbrella.Yes this umbrella is $15. It cost more than any of my other umbrellas. but this has stood up to my two year old's rough play. We haven't actually used it for rain yet since it's summertime in Southern California right now. But my daughter really wanted her own umbrella after seeing it on TV one day. So I got her this one and she plays with her umbrella almost everyday. Opening and closing it. She hits and swats things with it. She swings it around. She twirls it. She steps on it even when open. She's sat in it. It's maintained it's shape and doesn't look any worse for the wear. I think it will be fine by the time wintertime and some rain comes around.It is very easy to open and close. There are no buttons or triggers. Just push up to open and pull down to close--I think it works by friction. You can easily teach your child to do it on his/her own. And little fingers won't get jammed or pinched. I'm very happy with this purchase.I'm also very happy with my shopping experience with Amazon on this particular product. The first umbrella arrived damaged. The postal carrier must have been rough with the box because it was dented and the umbrella was bent. I placed a replacement order and it arrived in 2 days. In the meantime, my daughter still played with the damaged one. Then when the replacement arrived, we swapped it out without her knowing and sent the damaged one back--return shipping was free.

My daughter picked this as her souvenir on a trip to the Aquarium of the Pacific about a year ago. She was 1 year old then. It has become her go to plushie that she cannot sleep or leave the house without. She drags it with her everywhere. It's very soft, washes in the washing machine easily, and light weight. I think the big googley eyes and bright color also add to the appeal.My daughter is two now and I've since needed to buy another one of these chicks--not as a replacement but so we have a back up. Sometimes we leave one at grandma's or in the car so I just wanted to have another one at home at all times to prevent any terrible-two's meltdowns. I'm glad I was able to get it on Amazon and not have to make another trip to the aquarium. It was cheaper on Amazon, too. She loves both and will sometimes carry both around, one in each arm.Good purchase. I would recommend.

This Fisher Price Calming Seas Projection Soother is just adorable.It has three sounds: White noise which sounds like a fan, music, and nature sounds which sounds like trickling water + ocean waves + underwater bubbles.It has two light view: Full room projection that makes the room look like it's under water. And there is the fish tank display where a seahorse and a fish swim around a clam that sits in the middle. So cute. Projection and fish tank display do not work at the same time. You pick one or the either.It has three modes of play: Music/sound with projection, music/sound only, music/sound with fish tank display. Again, based on the three modes of play, you'll notice that projection and fish tank display do not work at the same time.It has three volumes: Off, low, and highIt plays for up to 60 minutes which is plenty to sooth a baby to sleep.It is easy to operate. Doesn't require any set up other than to remove the tab in the battery compartment that keeps it on "demo mode".I deducted one star because it is fully battery operated and does not come with an AC adapter. Sure it is portable and you can move it and put it where ever you like because it is not plugged in to the wall, but I usually just use noise machines at home and I would like to have the option to plug it into the wall instead of having to change batteries all the time. Having the AC adapter would have made this a 5 start product for me. I've included some photos that I think will be helpful.

I like to keep a heater in the baby's room during colder months even though I turn on the central heater for the house because sometimes the there are cold spots in the baby's room particularly near external walls and close to windows.PROs: This is a lovely heather. I love all the safety features and it circulates and warms the air gently without making a room overly hot or stuffy. I also like the way the heater looks and the colors go perfectly with my baby's room/nursery. It's also a lot more compact compared to the tower ceramic heater I was using before which is not specially designed/made for baby. And honestly I always worried if it was safe to leave the tower heater in the baby's room. Now that I have the Vornadobaby Sunny Nursery Heater, I don't have to worry anymore.CONs: Though it has an adjustable thermostat, you can only turn it from low to high and then adjust the fan setting. I prefer the digital climate control thermostats that actually display the current room temperature. That is available in the next model up: Vornadobaby Sunny CS Nursery Heater, Automatic Climate Control. Based on how great this model works, I think it's probably worth the extra $$$ to get the next model up, if you prefer having the ability to set automatic climate control. I just happened to have received this model without automatic climate control to test and review.Still if you need a baby safe space heater that works well and is reliable, the Vornadobaby Sunny Nursery Heater certainly met most of my expectations.

I received a manufacturer sample from Vivisky claiming this was a new product they were planning to sell on Amazon.  Thinking it was a cool concept, I agreed to try it in exchange for a fair review.  If you're considering it, you've already gotten over the acid-trip zebra, so I'm not going to review design aesthetic.  But I knew I was in trouble when the package arrived and it didn't get better from there.The immediate thing I noticed is that on the package, the metallic silver Vivisky stickers seemed very out of place.  So removing one, sure enough the actual manufacturer, Homi, was below (see customer pictures).  Opening the box, the umbrella was sheathed in a black velvet sleeve which also had a Vivisky sticker on it, and on opening the umbrella there was a fourth sticker, awkwardly placed on the handle for no apparent reason.I'm an internet shopper, so a quick Bing search showed that Homi is a Chinese wholesale brand that peddles these umbrellas at wholesale for about a dollar a pop on Alibaba and other sites (minimum order 500 - sorry if that was your next go-to).  And that price is probably about right.  The umbrella itself is heavily plastic, even places like the control arm and spoke joinery where you would normally expect metal.  The handle is diminutive, sized perfectly for my 5yo, but notsomuch a grownup.  Kudos to the manufacturer for the zebra-printed Velcro closing strap, which is its one nice detail. Overall, though, it just exudes a feeling of dollar-store quality - branding stickers aside.Sure, but does it work as an umbrella, and does it change colors?  Sorta and yes.  It the strictest sense, it will keep water off of you.  But here in the mid-Atlantic, rain is a windful event (not Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day-level windy, but gusty for sure) and this umbrella has a low disk, the frame of which kept inverting in the wind.  I've seen umbrellas go fully inside-out, but this is the first I've seen do it part-way.  I guess if this were used in the shower it would probably work well enough, though I skeptical about the number of times the little plastic flanges will open before breaking.  But for all of its other quality issues, yes, it really does change color (and as vibrantly as shown).One last note, though, because I think it's important to understand who you're buying from (since Vivisky has created their own product page and are claiming this is their product).  Also included in the box is a paper which, in poor English, begs for a 5-star Amazon review and offers a 50% refund in exchange for doing so.  It's the latter part I have an issue with, as it's a direct Amazon policy violation.  This is, spelling and punctuation as-is, exactly what it says:Dear FriendThanks for your Purchase and Congratulations!  We are Sincerely invite you to join our new product testing that can get "Half Money of Your Order Back to You" Bonus Schemes.  Just a Simple Process, You can obtain the reward.Please join us if you satisfied with our product and service![instructions to write a review]No matter what kind of problems you have during purchase, please Email us from the Order Purchased page for fast and easy solution!  Looking forward to hearing good feedback from you.

This is one of those products that Amazon should really start a new page for, but for some reason hasn't.  There is an Xbox/PC controller that came out for Win8 that is not the same as the new Xbox One/Win10 controller now being sold.  So watch the dates, because most reviews prior to November 2015 are from previous versions of this item.The current item, which I'm reviewing, is the Xbox One controller + wireless adapter made specifically for Windows 10 and the Nov 12, 2015, Xbox One update (aka "the new Xbox One experience").  While it works similarly to the previous Xbox 360/Win7 and Xbox One/Win8 versions, it would be impossible to review the hardware without also reviewing the integration experience, so that's where there's some significant difference.  I am primarily a console guy (yeah, yeah, I know) so most of this review is for the Xbox One -> PC streaming, and I'll hit the direct-control option at the end.  If you're using this solely as a PC controller (non-streaming), the short version is that you'll like it, go ahead and buy it.  If you're an Xbox user considering streaming, read on (yes, that's my 38k Gamerscore in the pic; I'm not new at this).The controller itself is the same controller that comes with the current generation of Xbox One's.  That means that it *does* have a 3.5mm headphone jack (previous versions of this did not).  I was able to pair and use my other base controller (came with the Xbox), my Elite controller, and my Guardians controller, meaning that the wireless adapter will allow you to pair any Xbox One controller, not just the base one it comes with.  Before that gets my Elite brethren too exciting, I will say that I noticed significant lag streaming my Xbox to my Alienware.  If you're casual gaming, it's not the sort to bother you, but on games like Forza and Fallout where split-second timing matters it's definitely pronounced.  I also found that lag did not improve if I connected the PC and Xbox directly to the router, or by swapping routers, meaning that it's not a wireless lag, it's an interface lag (that's actually good news, because that means MS should be able to improve it).The out-of-box experience was simple enough.  The wireless adapter is surprisingly large, but plugs into the USB easily.  Give it a few seconds for Windows to recognize it and power it up while you pop the included AA batteries into the controller.  Then power on the controller, press the sync button on the adapter and controller, when they stop flashing and are solid, you're paired.  In the Windows 10 store, search "Xbox Accessories" and download that app.  When you launch the app with your controller connected, it will prompt you for a firmware update, do that, and close when done.  You're ready to go.  Launch the Xbox app on Windows 10 and click the "Stream" option.  Now you're doing exactly that, streaming your Xbox One.The description of this controller doesn't (currently, hopefully Ammy updates it) include the hardware specs necessary to stream.  You'll need at least a 1.5GHz multi-core processor, 4BG RAM, and an 802.11N wireless connection (if you're not hardlining your Xbox and PC into your router).  While almost any Win10 PC will pass those rec's with flying colors, some Win7 and Win8 PCs that upgraded to Win10 may need to be checked.  Personally I think that those rec's sound a little low, but that's what MS swears will work sooo...  ;-)If you're not streaming from your Xbox One, but are using this as a direct-controller for your PC games (and there are a few out there optimized for it), this is a great option.  Without the streaming lag, the precision of the Xbox One controller really comes through - especially if you have the aforementioned Elite.  I tried wireless and tethered and found that for direct-control there was no noticeable difference.  While I usually prefer a gaming keyboard for PC games, the Xbox controller works fine and is a little less fatiguing for less-than-real-time arcade games like Dragon Age.  That's just personal preference, though.  Enjoy!

My girls have love Beados, and since these looked similar I picked them up to try.  And they're really not dissimilar, like Legos and MegaBloks.  Beados are the brand advertising on *every* NickJr and Disney Channel commercial break, but kids will have fun with either.This particular AquaBeads studio has both regular beads and crystal beads, which is kinda cool (they're two separate things in Beados).  The construction tray is transparent so if you want to do an existing template you just slide it in the bottom and match the beads - sort of the bead equivalent of paint-by-number.  This is a great option for little ones (AquaBeads recommends 6 and up, Beados says 4 and up - I think 5 or 6 is probably right just for the requisite dexterity).  Once you have your design made the way you want, you mist with water, let dry, and it fuses together.Last year we let the girls Beado us some decorations for the Christmas tree and windows, which they absolutely loved.  The clever part about both brands is the use of the little pellet pen to place the beads, which makes it fun for the kids but also significantly increases the amount of time to make anything.  And the more time they spend playing, the less time they spend fighting - so that's a win!If you have Princess-obsessed girls like me, Aquabeads has both Frozen and Cinderella sets.  For the boys in the house who may find a rainbow-star filled with gems a little girly, Qixels are the boys' version and work exactly the same way.

Made famous by Tom Hanks in big, the original FAO Schwarz floor piano came in right at 70" and my brother and I played the heck out of it in the 80's.  Fortunately technology has made a great toy even better.This new-generation version by ALEX has a crystal-clear speaker, sharp instrumentation, and a record-and-playback function.  With easy to adjust volume, this was a blast for my 5yo and her 5yo and 2yo cousins without driving the parents crazy.  My too-cool-for-school 9yo rolled her eyes when we first put it out, and dubbed it a "baby toy", but Saturday I caught her and her bestie laughing away while running up and down the keys trying to recreate some Megan Trainor song or another.And let's be real, there was no chance I had a giant floor piano and didn't play, too.  My brother and I resurrected routines from three decades ago, and laughed as we hadn't since we were boys.  And, in turn, every one of my 40-somthing friends that's spotted it has immediately thrust themselves on it, because it's not just a kids toy, it's an everybody toy.

It's always tricky to take a carefully-measured, sensual song and attempt to make a cardio-dance tune of it.  In essence you're sampling the original and re-working the entire melody.  So my hat's off to Liam Keegan (whoever he is) for a precise arrangement that pays homage to the original tune while pairing it back to mid-90's dancefloor stylings like Amber.  I'm not sure that I prefer it to the original, but as an artistic work it's pretty admirable.

A hair slower and playing up the 80's influences: glock-smacking, synth-flaring, snare-mashing (even a Queensyrche-esque sample drop).  I'm not sure I prefer it to the original, but I certainly appreciate the artistry of it - it's a well-done, technical remix.

Pair ZZ Ward's lyricism with Zella Day's synth-melody and this is its beautiful love-child.  Wigmore takes the current indie girl rocker sound to a (slightly) darker place with a revving electric guitar cutting over the snare, and it's pretty good.  I'm definitely watching to see how this new artist progresses.

This is a simple, single-propeller craft.  It works by using the lightest-weigh plastic and Styrofoam so that it requires little lift.  While the commercials (if your kids watch Nickelodeon like mine do, they're on every break) claim there's some sort of magical means that the craft adjusts its height, I'm pretty sure it's just good-ol'-fashioned push.We've actually had a couple of Air Hog toys in the house before and this one is very similar, so here's the up and down of it.  On thie up side this is a very cool toy that the kids will absolutely devour.  It's not an app or video game, but it has that techy feel.On the down side, it's really designed as a disposable toy.  If played with regularly, I give it tops a few weeks before the motor burns out or the Styrofoam irreparably breaks.  Like our Air Hog Zero Gravity Racers, the Vectron Wave has a noisy little engine that runs for about 10 minutes on a charge and takes around 30 minutes to recharge.So while it's got a huge "wow" factor for kids (and grown-ups), its play time is short and you should go into it knowing its a disposable toy.

I rarely enjoy a story told in first-person, but after several friends *insisted* that I read Uprooted, I finally picked it up.  And then couldn't put it down.Novak does an amazing job of spinning her tale, ratcheting the tension incrementally and expertly.  What Uprooted lacks in technical writing (with sometimes uneven scene changes and character development) it more than makes up for in heart, following the classic path of local-nobody to savior.
