Who is this unidentified sociopath and why is he or she fixated on Eric?I could not read this book fast enough, eager to find out who had done what.  I had suspicions that the "puppeteer" had to be a colleague.  But at the very end, a stunning reveal left me reeling.  5 stars.

When Mabel Dagmar, an ordinary girl, first met the privileged blue blood Genevra Winslow, the most relevant thing about her was how little she noticed Mabel.  As if she were simply an annoyance to bear.  Or an item of furniture, something she could overlook.  Since Ev was her college roommate, Mabel tried to find a way to coexist with the strange girl.So when Genevra (Ev) made an overture, offering an invitation to a special event, Mabel didn't know what to make of it; she did notice, however, how Ev's moods changed from dark to light, and that her occasional invitations afterwards were unpredictable.  But the "intermittent reinforcement" had definitely hooked Mabel.The invitation to the Winslow family summer retreat at their Vermont estate seemed almost like a gift that could then be quickly withheld.  And what Ev did in the subsequent weeks, as Mabel found herself in the middle of a privileged world, was true to form.  She alternately snarled, scowled, and withheld her attention, and then drew Mabel back to her with one kind gesture.  To say she was spoiled and entitled would be an understatement.  I did not like anything about this character, even though I realized that her parents had had a role in creating this behavior.Because Ev was often unavailable, both physically and emotionally, Mabel found her own way among the family members, and developed a unique relationship with Ev's aunt, Indo, an eccentric woman who made an unusual request.Narrated in Mabel's first person voice, the reader is drawn into the story, seeing the privileged world through Mabel's eyes...and wanting to warn her as she becomes more and more hooked on the feelings this world engenders.  Our narrator tells the story as if looking back on this time and these events.  There is a sense of loss about her tale.  And all the while, she, too, has a dark secret.What did Mabel discover about the Winslows?  How did what she learned change everything about her summer and her life?  Did she rise above the evil she had inadvertently become a part of?  And who would be an unexpected ally in the end?Bittersweet: A Novel was a story about a family so dysfunctional that one would have to look very hard to find anything good about it.  How Mabel turned things around in the end brought a satisfying conclusion to the dark and twisted history of this family.  5.0 stars.
I love my Kindle (Pippa) Paperwhite cover!  It is gorgeous, it fits nicely on the device, and I feel good using it.

After finishing medical school at Yale, along with her internship, Zoe Goldman has returned to her hometown of Buffalo for her psychiatry residency.  But coming home has brought some baggage with it.Years ago, Zoe lost her birth mother in a fire, and has some physical and emotional scarring from the traumatic episode.  In addition, Zoe has ADHD and some issues with compulsivity.  She struggles with these issues, along with how coming home has caused old feelings to resurface.  And now the nightmares have begun again.How will Zoe manage her patient load while dealing with her own issues?  Why is her adoptive mother, now suffering from dementia, hiding things from her?  Was everything she was told a lie, or has her mother "forgotten" the facts due to her memory issues?Little Black Lies is a page-turner that I couldn't put down.  I loved the mix of Zoe's personal life with the issues of her patients.  Why has one particular patient, Sofia Vallano, who incidentally killed her own mother when she was fourteen, started showing up in Zoe's nightmares?  Can Zoe find the answers to her own nebulous past?  Will she discover the truth behind the lies?  And when, in one horrifying moment, she does learn it all, will she survive it?Finding the answers can be life-changing.  There are still too many unanswered questions, Zoe realizes, and what is the truth?  What are the lies?  I liked this summation Zoe made:  "Maybe the truth is this:  There is no truth."A great story for those who enjoy suspense, mixed in with family issues.  5.0 stars.

This is a woodsy / somewhat sweet scent, with a heavy tobacco flower and violet scent. It is a pretty vigorous scent, and wakes one up in the morning. Like every body wash I have ever used, the odor is gone 5 minutes after I leave the shower, so I would not rely on this to last for the day or even for several hours. It smells nice in the shower, and then goes bye-bye. The comments about smelling this for the rest of the day (whether that is good or bad depends on the reviewer) strike me as being pretty inexplicable, as my wife has a very keen nose and did not smell this on me after my shower at all. Is this residual psychological or are these other reviewers possessed of bloodhound level olfactory sensors? In any case, I like the smell, but if you want something mild and / or very floral, you will not like this too much.As a body wash, 63 is a decent performer. A center of palm full on a loofah will do the trick; they say most body wash users use about 2 to 3 times more product than they should, which is why the manufacturers would rather you buy washes over bar soap, which is both cheaper and harder to squander. Try to use only a teaspoonful or less of 63, and I think it will be enough. The wash did not irritate any area of my body, even when left on for a few minutes. and it did not leave any film or tackiness on the skin once rinsed. The shea butter and glycerin did a fine job of moisturizing my skin, so I felt clean without any drying side effects.As a shampoo, 63 was somewhat less impressive, as it seemed to need more product to cover my scalp than dedicated shampoos would. I liked the smell a lot, but I feel American Crew smells as good or better, felt like it got my hair cleaner, and did so more efficiently. Plus if you use this as a shampoo and body wash both, you will blow through this teeny 8 oz bottle in a flash.Which brings me to my only complaint about 63: the cost per ounce. If you used this as a body wash only, and efficiently measured one teaspoonful each day of product, you would get about 48 days of use out of this. Most of us will use more by accident or intent (some days the loofah does not lather up too well!) and if you use this without a loofah, and / or use it as a shampoo, you could easily blow through this small bottle in a couple of weeks. If $2 an ounce for 2-3 weeks of use sounds distressing, you can either get something cheaper or carefully ration out the dose, use a loofah, and get a separate shampoo.I am not quite sure why 63 costs so much; the smell is great, so I presume the fragrance is the main price factor, but the allure of a luxury French product probably also adds some inflation. Ultimately, I think this is a good body wash, but unless you are ultra frugal with it, you will not get your money's worth. The dollar conscious may want to get some luxury bar soap instead, which can do just as good a job at cleaning without drying out if you get the right brand, and which last a lot longer. If the bang for the buck ratio does not trouble you though, 63 body wash is excellent.I should also mention the 63 shave soap and cream which are excellent products as well, and also proportionately better deals, as both last longer for the price. The smell is just as good, and the technical performance as shaving products is very high quality.

This is a sturdy well made cord that charges an Apple device quickly. It works with all Apple chargers as well as other socket charges and computer ports. (As could be predicted, it charges most quickly from a 2A or higher wall charger and charges more slowly from a computer USB port.)The cable resists tangling well. No charging device is included, this is only a cable, and of course, it is USB to Lightning only.I was favorably impressed with the thick durable connector cable here, and thought the color was lively but tasteful. There are cheaper options, but for a top quality connector at a fair price, I think the Belkin is a very good choice. I could not ask for any more features here at the price point, and so give this five stars.

The answer to that question will determine how well you will like Dreft. The heavy synthetically simulated earthy floral smell imparted by laundry musks dominates this product and makes it smell unique and (to my nose) excellent. If you hate the smell, you will not like this. To me, this smells much more interesting than Tide or All, but it is a strong polarizing smell.Even if you love the smell, there are other issues. The ingredients here are not at all natural, and are really about as mild as Tide Free and Clear, or other similar hypoallergenic mainstream commercial detergents. However, the price is bout 20-30% more than Tide, which to me is egregious. Dreft Stage 2 removes stains well, but no better than Tide, and Dreft is just as synthetic and mild as Tide F&C, so a buyer in essence is paying a surcharge for some nebulous claims and a strong vibrant smell. If Dreft were a few cents more than Tide, no biggie, but a few dollars more, which is the case, creates great reluctance on the part of this reviewer to say that the price is justified.Finally, Dreft seems to need more product used per load than other detergents, seemingly about 20% more liquid per load. Again, no problem with the cleaning results, but the added product utilization rate combined  with the higher base cost makes Dreft unnecessarily pricey. If you got some benefit from the added cost - efficiency, natural ingredients, better cleaning - I could see the logic here, but all you get is... the smell of laundry musks in heavy volume.Laundry musks are very cheap, so adding a lot of them to a detergent should not add a price premium in and of itself. Not sure why Dreft costs so much, but even if you are a big floral musk fan, you will probably want to get something for less that is just as effective, or pay more and get something that offers more unique and costly ingredients, like Seventh Generation.

**WARNING, SPOILERS BELOW!!**Anihilation is a fun creepy read with lots of strong imagery, a sense of brooding mystery, and a very strong lead character. Lots of intriguing possibilities are raised, and I was interested to see them solved. I should have realized this was not likely...Authority is also pretty neat, but an utter change of pace, a tale of spies and bureacratic infighting, that only gradually comes to reflect the themes of dark nature striking back raised in Anihilation. Control is a flawed though interestihg character, the relationships between him and Grace and between him and Ghost Bird are subtly portrayed and psychologically astute. The growing sense of menace and disorder against dysfunctional corporate / governmental setting reminded me of some work by Thomas Ligotti, and the sequence leading up to the border expansion and its aftermath is gripping. I liked the utter change of direction and tone from Book I, and appreciated the fact that VanderMeer seemed to be working towards unifying characters and theme by the end of Authority. I found this to be the most interesting book of the trilogy, and even though some tones rang false (the high level bureaucrat dueling seemed portrayed a bit abstractly and vaguely) and other tones seemed cliched (Control's field operation mishap flashback: "she trusted me, I made a mistake, and she DIED!!! Boo hoo hoo..." Yes. we've heard that one before!) but overall this and Anihilation made a really strong start to the series.And then Acceptance. Where not much is explained, where some characters we expected / hoped to see again are never seen, where others meet mysterious, indeed inexplicable fates, and where Area X turns out to be not so much malignant as it is simply incomprehensible. After the whole Blair Witch / Cthulhu type buildup in the earlier books, I wanted Area X to turn out to be a world destroying Fury of nature, but instead it turns out to be a puzzle box, mainly indifferent to humanity altogether. It was nice to meet the lighthouse keeper and the Director again, and there is some nice writing here, but the unrealized potential of Acceptance troubles me more than the limited appeal of what is here. The ending is really jumbled (why does Ghost Bird get shot by Grace? Why doesn't it matter?) and the hugely diminished role of Control in the plot and his ultimate fate are big disappointments to a character that seemed central to the story.Ultimately, I think VanderMeer aimed for post-modern style over good storytelling. He is a phenomenal critic and editor, and I've loved some of his short fiction, but ultimately in longer form work, I feel an author should aim for resolution and fulfillment of the reader's expectations rather than simple elegant style and some clever set pieces. If you read Mark Danielewsky's "House of Leaves" and loved it, you might like this, but if you expect a satisfying end to a 600 page book, you may want to skip this.

I was impressed with the quality of this bed in most ways. The Pearce is a memory foam mattress that avoids most of the mishaps traditionally linked to memory foam. It does not smell awful, and really had a very faint "new material" smell when unboxed that quickly faded and was not olfactorily noticeable once sheets were placed on the mattress.The bed also does not feel like one is sinking into mush. The top most part of the mattress feels like a very conventional mattress, and you do not feel like you are lying on foam. The mattress is firmest in the middle, and slightly less firm on the edges, but no more so than with any coil design.More impressively, the mattress does not heat up when you are lying on it, a pitfall of memory foam designs for many years. Whether it is the pillow top or some more granular design of the foam cells, the Pearce does not accumulate or retain heat in a way noticeably different from a conventional design.I was quite impressed with all the above, as I have followed memory foam mattress tech for a few years, and often considered buying one, but was always hesitant because of the smell, texture, and heat issues mentioned above. Be reassured from a skeptic, the Pearce will soon allay all these concerns and at a highly competitive price.Issues? Well, one major one and three minor. When unboxed, the Pearce had numerous loose small threads sticking out of the top of it. None of these appeared to be snags or unraveling threads, so we trimmed them gingerly with scissors and all was well. Inspection of the areas after a months use shows no further loose threads in the stitching, so we assume this was a minor build quality issue.Other minor quibbles: the bed can only be used from the top side, so if you like to rotate and flip your mattresses periodically, you can only perform the first function on these. Also, the box used to deliver the Pearce is huge, and the delivery service used by Amazon was unhelpful and just kinda dumped the box in our lobby. It was a bit of a challenge to get the huge heavy box in the elevator, upstairs, and unpacked, but not impossible. A nicer delivery experience where the dudes take the old mattress out and set the new one up would have been welcome, but I guess the lack of such amenities accounts for the lower price. Finally, no documentation on materials, use, or maintenance, but this absence is also not a deal breaker for such a competitively priced mattress of good quality.On a very subjective note, this is a firm mattress, much firmer than our old queen sized Simmons that was being replaced. I like firm, my wife does not, but she adjusted quickly, and most experts agree firm is better for most backs. Whatever the truth of this, we like this firmness level, but if you like a mushy sleeping surface that resembles a big feather pillow, this is not for you.End of the day: like firm, worried about memory foam issues, want a good price? Get this mattress, check the stitching, be prepared for a bit of moderate exercise in setup, and all will be well.

Curtain is a fairly elegant pattern and color that is a bit sheer. This is good in a way as you can vary the opacity of the shower covering based on what sort of liner you put in; a clear liner will let a lot of light in, a darker liner will give a more shadowed interior.This curtain more or less conforms to what you might find at a major big box store for the price point in terms of construction. That is, there are pretty sturdy well delineated holes to put the hooks, but no metal reinforcing rings. Over time, my experience is that non-reinforced holes tend to tear over time, and are prone to catastrophic failure, i.e. if some klutzy family member yanks on em by accident.Another long term issue is repeated washing. Though these are said to be machine washable, the "holey" pattern does not make me feel confident that these will survive multiple washings. Usually only solid materials prove sturdy enough for many washes, and lacier materials start to pill and develop loose threads. I've washed these once, and they came through OK, no snags, look fine, but the difference between top quality materials and average is whether they'll survive 6-12 washes.All in all, you get what you pay for with shower curtains, and these do not feel too cheap, at least if we accept the frilly lacy design as an aesthetic choice and not merely a cheap way to save on material.  These are at least as good as comparably priced items at Talmart or Warget, but don't expect to pass them on to the grandkids and only buy if you don't want or expect a solid piece of material as a curtain.

The core test of a power pack is whether it reliably charges and delivers its stated power rating. I am pleased to report that the 6000 mAh Sneaker Bank (SB) does this well. 6000 mAh will recharge most cell phones more than 200% and will give an Ipad a big chunk of its power back. The SB charges quickly and fully and reloads up to devices at once, fairly rapidly and with a minimum of fuss.Why only three stars? Though documentation is not exactly a strong point for most battery packs, SB sets a new low basement. The included charging cable includes micro and mini USB connections on the same plug, a clever not unwelcome feature, but one explained only on the flimsy cardboard packaging that I threw away within minutes of receiving this. This feature also is not mentioned on the product's corporate web page, but was only discovered in my case when I read other reviews on Amazon. Come on dudes, you can't put $0.75 worth of cheap manual in the box to point this out?Similarly, I have no idea if power status can be checked without plugging in the SB to a (non-included) wall charger. Most devices like this have a button on them that you can press to illuminate status lights that will tell you how much power is left in the bank. This is kind of useful, and so I looked on SB expecting to find such a button. Could not find it. Maybe it's buried away in that uselessly decorative sneaker tread pattern somewhere, but as there is no manual available, I cannot verify the presence or absence of this feature.What else is not included at this price point? Well, no manual, no wall charger, no Lightning cable for Apple devices. Apparently no power status button. No carrying pouch.Maybe it's me, but this price point seems like it ought to include more product amenities and add-ons than are found in the SB. If all you want is a reliable 6000 mAh power bank, here you go, but many competitors offer as much or more at comparable or lower prices.

It used to be the case that commercial soaps were inevitably loaded with drying detergents and no moisturizers, so one could either use stuff like Dial or Irish Spring and dry your skin out, or you could seek out obscure artisanal soaps that were gentler and costlier. Well, the world has changed.SMSC's Iceland smelled nice enough, a blend of "fresh" vetiver and citrus, but it is not very complex or interesting, and really Irish Spring is more engaging and strong as a scent. If you're a guy and like a strong smelling soap, Iceland barely passes muster. More problematic, Iceland irritated my face and other sensitive parts of the body when lather was left in place for more than a minute or so, making it a race to wash the lather off before Bad Things started to happen.This saponified aversion therapy is about as bad as the effect achieved by Ye Olde Irish Spring Classic, which costs about 10% of what SMS costs, so I wonder why an expensive organic soap could not be less sensitizing.More annoyingly still, Iceland lasted about 2 weeks only, and was thin enough to bust in half on day 12, leaving me to use mini-soap bars for a few more days. I use the bar itself to soap up in the shower and do not use a loofah, so I suspect those who are getting a month of use out of these bars are not using them to lather up directly.What do you like in your soap? Want to save money? Iceland costs a lot and lasts for about 2 weeks of use, as it is not triple milled. Do you just want something cheap that smells nice and won't dry your skin out? Dove Men Plus care has one excellent option:Dove Men+Care Body and Face Bar, Aqua Impact 4 oz, 8 Bar Moisturizing cream built in, no detergent, smells great. And it's $11 for 8 bars, $1.38 per bar, not $7. The Dove product lasts about as long as Iceland soap does per bar, that is 7-10 uses. Iceland may last a bit longer, maybe another 2-4 days, but that hardly offsets the price difference. Irish Spring also now offers a moisturizing bar soap that has the same moisturizer onboard features: Irish Spring Signature Hydrating Bar Soap, 6oz, 3 Count also for $1 per bar, and these are big bars that last 3 weeks plus.Both Irish Spring and Dove Men Plus are not organic soaps by any stretch, so if you think the soapy lather from these commercial products will slowly kill you, you might want organic soap. Surely you can't get good cheap organic soap can you? Well actually, River Soap has great organic soap that has more scent options than SMSC and is triple milled, and so lasts longer in use. And River Soap costs only $4 and change per bar, less than SMS and lasts for about a week longer. You can find River Soap here on Amazon, River Soap Company - Bar Soap Exotic Patchouli - 4.5 oz. but unfortunately the company charges more for shipping than it does for the soap, so you may want to find River Soap locally if you can. Many Whole Foods offer this brand at their $4.40 list price.My own personal favorite men's organic soap is Mistral men's line, which list at $10.50 in stores for a 9 oz bar. This costs more than SMS, but lasts for roughly twice as long or more (4-5 weeks) because of triple milling and the bar size. So given those terms, Mistral Men's is still cheaper than SMSC. Mistral is tougher to find in stores than River Soap, so you may want to order from Amazon, even at price premium, if you want to try the brand. Great powerful scents too!  Mistral Men's Soap, Sandalwood Bamboo, 250 GramsAll in all, I think SMSC soaps are at best an average choice. If money is an issue, there are cheaper options that are just as moisturizing and that last longer and smell stronger. If you want organic soap, there are also cheaper options and more expensive options that match or exceed SMSC due to longer service lives. $7 soap should give one $7 worth of performance, and I don't see that here.

The 92R is well made, and my particular model had symmetric blade exposure on both sides. Well and good. However, the 92R is recommended by some websites as a good starter or general purpose razor, and I can assure you it is not. A lot of blade is showing here, far more than on a Merkur 34C or Jagger DE89, which are good starter razors, and indeed good for most shavers. The 92 R by comparison is far too aggressive for regular beards shaved daily. If you use this even with a mild blade (like a Derby) you will scrape too much skin off your face even with good technique as the blade gap and weight combine to make this a very harsh shaver. Using this razor with a Derby produced razor burn roughly 2 out of 3 times even in my relatively experienced hands (18 months of wet shaving, own 11 razors). Using a sharper blade like say a Persona Blue or Feather is truly a nightmare and I would not suggest doing so unless you have a really voluminous and / or tough beard.As the saying goes, your experience may vary. If you have a tough beard and tough face, this may be a great daily shaver. If you shave like 2 or 3 times per week, this may be ideal for you. But for me, and for other guys who shave daily and have faces sensitive to razor burn, this is a bad idea. I am giving this 2 stars because Parker does not advertise this properly as an aggressive razor for experienced users but instead claims it is Everyman's Razor. Quality is not the problem here, but rather the core design elements.Daily shavers, get a Merkur 34C or Jagger 89, or maybe a Merkur Progress if you want to be fancy. The 34C and DE87 cost a bit more (and the Progress a lot more!) but the more pleasant shaves for most users are worth the money I believe.

My primary vacuum is a Miele Polaris, and suffice to say, comparing that to the Samsung VU3000 is not especially fair, given the Polaris is a bagged canister model costing about twice as much as the upright design Samsung. I will consider the VU3000 on its own merits, and I feel that even with such terms, the Samsung still comes up short.The main problem is one intrinsic to the bagless design. I've owned a few of these, and the appeal of not having to buy and stock replacement bags is rapidly offset by the nasty chore of having to empty the canisters. This produces lots of dust (essentially entirely offsetting whatever filtration system is in place, unless one person vacuums and another empties the canister) and is especially irritating for the Samsung as the canister is far too small.Completely vacuuming a smallish two bedroom apartment that has mainly hardwood floor surfaces created 3 canister loads of dirt, meaning I would frequently have to stop vacuuming to empty. I feel the canister here is excessively small, and I can only imagine how many times one would have to empty the canister if one was cleaning a full size carpeted suburban house.Adding insult to injury, the canister also allows stuff like hair and long fibers to get into the top part of the canister, where the air intake port is, and you have to stop immediately at that point and either empty the canister or shove the hair / fibers back into the lower storage area. If you don't like poking and prodding around inside a filthy vacuum,(and who would enjoy doing that really?, this is not much fun, and it happens a lot especially if one has pets. (We have a single cat.) Indeed, even emptying the canister rarely went smoothly, as the canister has all too many nooks and crannies that dirt and hair gets caught in, meaning in order to clean it fully, you, once again, need to reach inside and pull stuff out into the trash manually. Wait, what's wrong with a bag based system again?By comparison, my Miele needs its high efficiency bag changed once a month or so, meaning you get about 4-6 full house vacuums out of 1 bag, versus 3 canister empties per cleaning with the Samsung. I guess if you think the recycled materials used in the 10 Polaris dust bags or so I use per year are really hurting the planet that much, the added inconvenience and inefficiency of rummaging through the full or jammed canister every few minutes of vacuuming with the Samsung will not trouble you.Besides the annoyingly small and immensely needy canister, the other main issue with the Samsung is its lack of a proximity effect when vacuuming. With a decent vacuum, you can come _near_ the dirt on the floor and the suction zooms it into the head. With the Samsung, there is an annoying need to be _exactly_ on top of the dirt to get it to be sucked up. I would often have to reposition and sometimes even lift the vacuum head directly on top of dirt to get the Samsung to do its job. I think the motor is powerful enough, but I think the plastic head is just not designed efficiently or well, so undue precision is needed to achieve the same effect that most other vacuums get done with simple proximity.Other than these two fairly important issues, the Samsung is well designed. It is very maneuverable and light weight, and can rapidly change positions during use. (Necessary, due to the poor proximity effect mentioned.) The detachable canister and hose means you can convert the Samsung into a very portable semi-canister type device. The attachments all work well, and the unit is attractive in color and styling. Build quality is very good, and the unit feels sturdy and tough. The agitator head works very well on rugs and carpet, and the turbo agitator attachment works even better.Other minor annoyances: no cord winder, meaning you have to manage the cord yourself. The unit is very loud and has no quiet mode. And the turbo carpet agitator has no onboard storage rack or clip, meaning you have to keep track of it yourself. They already have storage clips for the other attachments, so it seems weird and dumb not to put a clip on the frame for the turbo head attachment as well.In conclusion, the difference between 3 and 4 stars here comes to marketing and price point. If Samsung called this a light duty vacuum, or sold it for about a third less than they do, I would give this four stars. Unless you use this to clean a very small and intrinsically clean area, the deficiencies in the small finicky canister and lack of a "sweet spot" in head suction make this device a chore to use for most ordinary cleaning tasks. If Samsung gave one a bigger more robust dirt canister, or just used a bag instead, and if they redesigned the head a bit so one could vacuum up dirt from a couple inches away, this would be a much better design, maybe worthy of five stars. But at this level of price and somewhat mediocre performance, I cannot justify more than a three star rating.Maybe if we didn't have a nicer vacuum to compare this to, or maybe if we didn't have a pet and so many female household members (all that hair!) I would have liked this better. But I do have both a nicer vacuum and lots of longish hair producing household members, so I must rate the Samsung in light of the actual usage environment.

Unfortunately I've had mine for 6 months, and have used it many times and it still stinks. When I realized the odor was not going away through regular use, I used shampoo, body wash, overnight lather holding, etc and the smell would go away for a bit and then creep back in. I have another Omega boar (the 10049) and a Semogue 830 and both of those were just fine, but the Omega Pro is resolute in its stinkiness. Maybe I just got a smelly dud of a 10048, but I am not happy.I suggest trying the 10049 as it is roughly the same price as the 10048 and is slightly smaller and so easier to maneuver. The 10048 is massive because Italian barbers use it to later _other people's_ faces, not their own, and the 10048 (assuming a non stinky one) would be perfect for that. But for using on your own face, the length and bulk of the 10048 are more of a hindrance than a help. If you face lather, a brush this big is definitely a PITA, and something like the Semogue 830 would be better for that purposes. Even if you bowl lather, the 10049 or Semogue 1800 or 2000 would be more than long enough for that purpose.The 10048 has its strengths. It softens up nicely over use as the hairs split, and is really just fine out of the box unless your face is a delicate balloon that will pop easily. The 10048 holds a lot of lather. And its knot is firm, so the brush is not as floppy as some of the big Semogues, so you get some precision for the firm knot, but lose some for the immense bulk of the Pro.If you absolutely cannot spend more than $10 on a shave brush, this is a better deal than the cheapo badgers, but just hope you get a non-perpetual smelly one. Or... get the 10049 for less money.Red handled Omega Professional Boar Hair Shaving Brush Given the pricing of the 10049, I really don't know why the 10048 is so popular. Unless you are an actual barber shaving customers at arm's length, there is no need to choose the 10048.

1) This is an aftershave splash. For most users, the fragrance will last well less than an hour. If you have very oily skin and / or you douse yourself, you may get two hours. If you want to smell like something 4 or 8 hours after you use a product, get an EDT, not aftershave. Similarly, this does not project well, maybe a couple inches from your skin. Even if you douse yourself, you will not do much to increase the range. Again, if you want the folks at the club to smell you from 5 feet away, get an EDT.2) These scents, as honestly described by the maker on the website, are meant to emulate well known male fragrances. The models (and related Fibe scents) are: YSL Rive Gauche PH (American Blend),Terre D'Hermes (Orange Noir), Guerlain Vetiver (Clean Vetiver), Tom Ford Grey Vetiver (Clean Vetiver), and Creed's Aventus (Platinum). Snake Bite is unscented menthol, and Italian Citrus is no longer mentioned on the website, so no idea what that's supposed to be.3) So, related to the points above, if you already own one or more of the model fragrances, don't buy the related Fine aftershave. Even if you love the scent of Terre D'Hermes, Fine's variant does nothing to improve on the original, and lasts for like 45 minutes or so. If you own TDH, put something else on your face after you shave, and then squirt the TDH on after that. No need to duplicate the $50 EDT with a separate $15 aftershave!4) So to put # 3 another way, the main market for Fine splashes are guys who say "heck no, I would never spend $X amount on smelling like sumptin". For every dude, the X variable will be different. For those whose $X is $45, you can get anything in the line and get the smell of the higher price (briefly) for far less money. For me, my $X is higher, so I own TDH, Guerlain Vetiver, and Rive Gauche, but I would not pay Tom Ford $90 or Olivier Creed $250 for their products, so I own Fresh Vetiver and Platinum. This way, I can smell like smoky pineapple (briefly) for a fraction of the cost of the original.The chosen models are carefully selected to be tasteful unique classics (no Acqua Di Gio or Burberry here), and the scent design work here is pretty good. Fine duplicates the fragrance notes pretty well, but the scent pyramid is pretty highly condensed, as it would need to be for something with a 5% fragrance concentration.If you don't want to spend even $15 to smell like sumptin, well, there's always Pinaud and Old Spice, which are decent enough, but which lack menthol and smell comparatively ordinary.5) These products are not ideal for dry / sensitive skin. Alcohol and menthol do nothing to make skin better. They may not make it worse if you are tough skinned or use a moisturizer after the splash, but these definitely will not "soothe" or "moisturize" your skin. Even the menthol cooling effect is really just skin irritation that many find pleasant. If you want healthier and / or moister skin, you need to use a balm or supplement your splash with a moisturizer. Pro Raso White and Nivea Sensitive and Cooling balms are quite good, and they are all cheaper than Fine, but they do not smell like anything famous.6) How to apply: use a teaspoonful. Or cup the palm of a hand, fill the little hollow space in the middle with liquid. Rub your hands together for 3 seconds, and then turn your palms up for 4 seconds to air the alcohol. Then apply. If it stings a lot, you have given yourself a bad shave. The sting should be mild and brief followed by a cooling and tightening sensation. You should not be howling like Macaulay Culkin upon application.So given all the above, I like Fine. I know not everyone wants to spend money on male fragrances, and I like the fact that a guy can smell like Rive Gauche or Aventus for less than $20. Fine makes good stuff, and while ideally I'd like to see them stick some botanicals and / or moisturizing additives in here, I know that's unlikely to happen at this price point. (For those interested in the latter concept, try Barrister and Mann, artisan product not sold on Amazon (yet!) as he does complex splashes with useful additives, though admittedly at a higher price point than Fine.Fine accomplishes their mission, and they do it honestly and effectively. I'd like to see them try something more original, but what they have available now is just... Fine!

AMENDED: Orijen charges $30 for 5 pounds of kibble; Wellness is trying to charge that same price for 2 pounds. Orijen looks like an even better bargain, but I will leave the star rating as is.My dad always used to say that when offered something that was unusual to his taste: sushi, curried chicken, turkey burgers... Our cat is like my Dad, except she doesn't offer the faint praise first, she just declines to eat. Hard for me to evaluate the food positively if kitty won't eat it. I nibbled a bite myself, and it was OK, not exactly enough to make me want to pour out a bowl for myself, but not loathsome either. Our cat eats EVO & Orijen dry foods, a few flavors of each, and she also likes somewhat less healthy "junk food" like Purina Pro Plan "True Nature". She is not especially picky about grain versus meat, or protein versus carbs, but she does not like this stuff.Kind of sad; the food is soft and seems moisturized, and the nutritional info makes the food look decent, though not great. Here is the content info from the mfgrs site:Deboned Chicken, Deboned Turkey, Peas, Gelatin, Natural Flavor, Tomato Pomace, Vegetable Glycerin, Pea Fiber, Salt, Dried Cultured Skim Milk, Sunflower Lecithin, Ground Flaxseed, Chicory Root Extract, Zinc Propoinate, Potassium Citrate, Choline Chloride, Calcium Chloride, Mixed Tocopherols added to preserve freshness, Cranberries, Cranberry Extract Powder, Cranberry Fiber, Vitamin E Supplement, Zinc Proteinate, Zinc Sulfate, Taurine, Ferrous Sulfate, Iron Proteinate, L-Carnitine, Calcium Carbonate, Niacin, Glucosamine Hydrochloride, Chondroitin Sulfate, Copper Sulfate, Copper Proteinate, Manganese Proteinate, Manganese Sulfate, Vitamin A Supplement, Sodium Selenite, Thiamine Mononitrate, d-Calcium Pantothenate, Pyridoxine Hydrochloride, Riboflavin, Vitamin D3 Supplement, Biotin, Calcium Iodate, Dried Kelp, Yucca Schidigera Extract, Vitamin B12 Supplement, Folic Acid, Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C), Rosemary Extract, Green Tea Extract, Spearmint Extract.Of the top 10 ingredients (which are the largest percentages of substances in the food) only 2 of 10 are meat, and there's also stuff like peas, gelatin, and tomato, which cats don't have much use for. If you compare this to Orijen Cat & Kitten food, you will see that Wellness is skimping a bit on ingredients. Orijen: Orijen: Boneless chicken, chicken meal, chicken liver, whole herring, boneless turkey, turkey meal, turkey liver, whole eggs, boneless walleye, whole salmon. No glycerin or pea fiber in that list!Here is the guaranteed analysis for Wellness Core Air Dried, also from their site:GUARANTEED ANALYSISCrude Protein (Min)32.00%Crude Fat (Min)22.00%Crude Fiber (Max)4.00%Moisture (Max)20.00%Calcium (Min)1.80%Phosphorus (Min)1.40%Magnesium (Min)0.060%Magnesium (Max)0.100%Vitamin E (Min)200 IU/kgTaurine* (Min) 0.10%L-Carnitine* (Min)100mg/kgOmega-6 Fatty Acids* (Min)5.00%Omega-3 Fatty Acids* (Min)0.50%Glucosamine* (Min)300 mg/kgNot too bad, about 16% carbs, assuming 8% ash, roughly comparable to Orijen.So how does the kibble crumble? Even if we discount my cat voting with her feet, this stuff is the same price as Orijen and uses much cheaper ingredients. The low carb content is good, and the food _looks_ and _smells_ attractive enough to me, but I ain't the one who has to eat it. If kitty liked it, I would have given it 4 stars, and if kitty liked it and there was less gelatin and peas in it, a fifth star would have been there for the taking. But as formulated and priced, and with kitty not thinking much of it, three stars seems generous. Most buyers would be better off with Orijen at this price point.

Regular Aveeno Daily Moisturizer is my go to moisturizer for most uses. I use it after shaving, use it on dry skin in the winter, and on occasional mild eczema spots on myself and my daughter. The oatmeal does a great job of soothing redness and irritation, and the relatively simple and comedogenic ingredient list makes Aveeno one of the few moisturizers I can use on my overly sensitive face without sting or irritation.The one problem with Aveeno Daily is that it tends to be relatively thick and greasy. Not as greasy as CeraVe or Aquaphor, but a little bit so. Fortunately, this minor deficiency is addressed in the Sheer Hydration variant being reviewed here. Sheer Hydration (hereafter SH) goes on much drier than Daily Moisturizer standard, and is easier to work into the skin quickly. Rather than spending 5 minutes of working 4 squirts of Aveeno standard into my face, SH can be applied in less than 2 minutes. It seems to offer the same soothing and moisturizing benefit of the standard formula, but leaves a smoother "crisper" skin feel and can be applied more quickly.Sounds like a win, right? Pretty much it is; the scent is slightly different from standard, but both are pretty much "unscented" for most noses. The only issue is that SH costs more than daily standard and although SH is claimed to offer more benefits, in my short term comparison of both, I don't see a big difference other than the quicker application and smoother post-use feel. These are not insubstantial benefits, especially for those who want to use Aveeno on their face but don't like its (admittedly minor) greasiness. I would think people with oily skin would prefer SH.Both SH and daily standard have a hard time remediating really dry skin or moderate to severe eczema, and folks suffering from those ailments probably want to invest in something more powerful. (I like CeraVe and Gold Bond Replenishing CoQ10 for those issues.) But assuming you need a pretty mild moisturizer / cheap post shave balm, this is a great product.

As compared to Cool Water, (the role model for most male fresh aquatics) I found Eternity Aqua (hereafter EA) to be more interesting and less artificially pungent. EA begins with a great cucumber lotus accord that smells pretty unique, but sadly these notes are gone in less than 15 minutes. One is left with the all too common aquatic drydown of calone and cedar, with hints of lavender. Still, the calone (artificial melon) notes are underplayed here versus Cool Water or Nautica Voyage, and so this fragrance was less unpleasant for the intermediate term. (Both Voyage and Cool Water make me want to wash them off after about an hour or so, but EA was less annoying by far.)Biggest problem with EA is longevity and projection. The longevity issue is a common one with male aquatics, and EA is very representative of that deficiency. The whole show is over in less than four hours, and the fragrance is close to being a skin scent in less than two hours. This is basically a cologne lifespan at an EDT price, but this longevity issue is pretty much par the course for this school of fragrances. If you want a long lasting aquatic, try Bulgari's "Aqua", but that is a darker more complex scent that is not as "fresh" as EA or its comparable short lifespan brethren.The projection is also quite weak, which makes this good for the workplace, bad for clubs and other social settings where one might want to be smelled. Both Cool Water and Voyage project better, so if you want to reach out and touch someone's scent receptors from more than an arm's length away, EA is not the best choice.This to me is between three and four stars. The sweeter opening and somewhat less artificial drydown are pluses compared to other fresh aquatics, and I like the cucumber and lotus notes, but they are all too brief. The fragrance as a whole could last longer, and the quickly departing top notes only add to the disappointment. If you like aquatics and want something a bit less strident, this is a good choice. I'm rounding up to four stars because I'm a sucker for cucumber smells.Of course, I would also suggest not wearing aquatics at all. These are mainly weak, dull, and simple scents. I suggest trying something with more oomph and interest, like Dior Homme, Aramis 900, or Polo, but then of course you won't smell like every other male aged 16-30 out there. Whether that is a good or bad thing, I will leave up to you to decide!

I had seen this compared to GRR Martin and Bacigalupi science fantasy stuff, so I entered this with unrealistic expectations, which were soon cruelly dashed. More mysteriously, I read some of Liu's short fiction and liked it, and this novel reads almost as if it was written by a different author, one with a worse ear for dialogue and a less keen sense for plotting.Grace of Kings reads rather like an attempt at crossbreeding Homer with Chinese legends, and to my ears at least, it generally fails. To me it seems almost as though Liu had some pre-conceived notions as to the mono-dimensional nature of his characters, and makes efforts to conform their portrayals throughout so that they seem either larger than life, or similar to cardboard cutouts, depending on how kind-hearted the interpreter is. After Ice and Fire, epic fantasy has been transformed into something more realistic (for better or worse) and having the hero always be brave or wily or kind, and / or the villains always be wicked and vicious wears on one quickly.There seem to be few real living breathing characters in here; even the minor characters seem like automatons and plot points. Example: kind hearted crown prince gets forged note from dying Emperor's evil adviser telling the Prince to kill himself by order of the Emperor. "Oh, Ok", says crown prince and kills himself within 2 minutes of getting the note. I don't care what culture you are portraying or what legend you are referencing, that's just bad writing and plotting!I am reminded of the stuff I used to read in high school when I was a kid, like Terry Brooks and the Belgariad series by David Eddings, etc. If that sort of unidimensional black vs white stuff still holds interest for you, you might enjoy this. There's lots of action, the quasi-Asian setting is interesting, and the detailed world building is nice, especially in terms of the pantheon of gods and their various interests, influences, and schemes. There is no real science fantasy element here despite the airships mentioned, so this is more in the realm of (workmanlike) high fantasy.I found Grace of Kings disappointing, but admit this is mainly because I like my fantasy darker, grittier, and more complex. Liu is aiming to simulate both Chinese historical epic and a gentler, kinder (and dumber) sort of fantasy novel, of the sort that was more popular 20-30 years ago. This is like a G or PG rated epic, as compared to the R rated Ice and Fire epic that modern tastes are more accustomed to. If you like PG movies with clear simple heroes and villains, this may be your cup of cha.

Compared this to a Vornado 733 air circulator that sells for more than twice the price, and the ILG8F12 (hereafter F12) is semi-competitive. The 733 is very ugly and loud, but produces a good amount of air. However the plastic blade guard fell off during the first year of ownership and now rests over the blades without any locks holding it it place, so it falls off whenever the fan is moved. The Vornado impressed in technical performance but not in build quality, and it is dreadfully ugly. The worse thing is the noise though as the 733 drowns out a TV on normal volume at its high or medium setting.The F12 in comparison looks a lot nicer, and the all steel cage design is charmingly retro. The fan speed is comparable to the 733, but the absence of any air channeling framework means the F12 cannot match the Vornado in terms of absolute volume of air moved. However, the F12 is decent, certainly better than the cheapest small Vornado, and it is also much quieter even at high speed. Build quality is kind of "meh" on the F12 though, as the rubber feet meant to mount on the frame's bottom for added stability and reduced vibration didn't fit, and the fan sometimes moves its angle of elevation in the stand if you tap it or even walk near it.So ultimately, the F12 design is attractive, build quality mediocre, performance respectable (about what you would expect for this price range) and the quiet motor is a big selling point. For the same price as a Vornado 733, you could get 2.3 of these F12 fans, which would move more air, would create less noise, would look less ugly, and could be separated into different areas as needed. Not a bad deal!

Saw this in TJ Maxx for twenty clams and thought "hmm, this was compared to the discontinued "Gucci Pour Homme" that everyone on Basenotes raves about, and it has synthetic oud in it, the scent element du jour of a few years ago which is now quite rare in mens colognes. I have nothing with oud in it and would love to see what Gucci PH smelled like. What a bargain!". Yep, bad thinking there, self.When a company known for its fragrances notes that product XYZ is not selling well, they just kill it, because they figure if they turn it into utter s***e by reformulating it down to the less than a dollar ingredient cost per bottle, they will embarrass the company name. When a company not really known for its fragrances notes declining sales, they reach a different conclusion... Hence, the current version of Dirty English. Juicy Couture could care less what you think about their parfums as long as you buy their tight pants, so they don't mind ripping off money from fools. The reformulation of this already cheap product has been farmed out to cynical mercenaries who seem to have produced a product that is mostly carrier oil and alcohol, with some immensely uninspired fragrance elements stuck in to appease the undemanding.Not sure what appeal this had when it was fresh, new to the market, and selling well. Maybe back then it smelled exactly like Gucci PH, maybe back then you could smell the oud, the leather, the booze, the vetiver, the breath of angels, whatever. Now, you smell mostly alcohol, cheap cedar, and cheaper musk. These are not pleasant smells in the least. The current version of Dirty English is a vile brew, redeemed only by the fact that it fades quickly and does not project. Axe smells nicer and costs less.Even the bottle is cheaper now, no cute little chain and charm, just fake plastic chain twining around the cap and no charm at all. This is a badge of shame for the proud owner of this overpriced junk to gaze upon and despair over. This is not worth the $20 I paid for it at TJ Maxx, and is certainly not worth more than that. You would get a better bargain for your money by buying bottles of Old Spice and Brut, which have about the same sillage and longevity, but at least smell like they cost $2 or $3 per bottle to make instead of $0.79.I will try to reign in my bright ideas the next time I walk through TJ Maxx and will focus instead on the bath and body section which has products that at least do not smell like industrial accidents in distilleries.

Ungaro III was designed by two heavy hitting perfume designers in the mid-point of their career. Besides this, the internet fragrance community is full of reviews about the "unique vodka note" and "dark Gothic rose" to be smelled here, etc. etc.Well, not sure how U3 used to smell, but it is a waste of money these days, except possibly for cheapskate fans of Dolce & Gabbana Pour Homme, who will find a fairly inexpensive echo of the more expensive fragrance here. Unfortunately D&G PH does nothing for me, so U3 is not even of use to me even as a clone.  I'm not sure how or when this was reformulated from whatever more interesting original has been cited on the internet, but what's left will be of little interest to anyone.U3 opens with a blast of cheap pungent alcohol; not "vodka" but rather cheap rubbing alcohol. This lasts for a few unpleasant minutes and then settles into the heart notes of lavender, sage, and geranium. The lavender and sage are emphasized, which is where the DGPH resemblance comes in. The dry down is also similar in that both have sandalwood and cedar notes featured prominently, but unfortunately for both U3 & DGPH, it's the rather cheap synthetic cedar tone which permeates.Rose, vetiver, musk, and lily of the valley exist only in the scent pyramid text of U3, not anywhere olfactorially  in the fragrance. Lavender and sage transitioning into cedar and sandalwood is done all too frequently in men's perfume, and none of the exotic tones raved about on Basenotes etc. is to be found here. Moreover, the fragrance loses its projection quickly and becomes a skin scent in well less than 4 hours.DGPH though about twice the price of U3 has a little bit more to offer. It projects like a lighthouse for 6-8 hours (which can be a good or bad thing) and offers a richer drydown (some tobacco and tonka bean in there) and better top notes (citrus notes rather than isopropyl). The heart notes are most similar, and as stated, I don't like either, but if you like DGPH and don't want to pay full price for it, U3 may be a cheaper alternative.For the rest of the market, move along, there's nothing to see here. If you want to get something decent for this same price range, Grey Flannel, Havana, Aramis 900 etc all give you far more complex and pleasant smells for the same price or less. No gothic rose, no vodka, just rubbing alcohol, sage, and cedar. Ungaro should pull the plug on this dull disappointment, but apparently a few fish are still biting, in search of complexity and subtlety that no longer exist in this iteration of the product.

I like Neil Gaiman, but his "American Gods" was vastly disappointing to me. Intriguing premise, good writing, dark tone --- but very erratic, devolving into travelogue, nostalgia, low comedy -- the concept of earth bound gods warring and interacting with each other and the world of mortals was poorly developed and not fully utilized, and the small intimate tone and slow turgid pace convinced me that American Gods could and should have been better.Well "Library at Mount Char" (hereafter "LAMC") is what American Gods should have been, Equally intriguing, lots of twists and turns in the plot, consistent tone, and a roller coaster of a plot with tons of action and a vast scope. You will not be bored reading this, and you will feel that the premise was so good and execution so well done that a extra couple of hundred pages in the volume would have been welcome. (Imagine that! A fantasy novel that is too short.. a rare thing!)The idea of scholar apprentices of a dark arbitrary god figure is a pretty neat one. The mystery at the core of the plot is a good one, and the characters are mostly well done. We don't get to know or care about all of the apprentices, but the ones central to the plot are well portrayed and we care about / hate them as intended. The humans we meet are also well done, and the interactions between "gods" and men are logically done and unpredictable.There are also plot points that are thoroughly unpredictable and yet also stunningly well done set pieces. Unlike "American Gods", where the comings and goings of the immortals are barely witnessed by humans, the mortal world is intimately and viscerally connected with the doings of the inhabitants of Mount Char, and the cataclysmic events inherent in a war / death of the gods scenario are not avoided in the intricate plot. If you like broad scopes and lots of stuff getting messed up in your fantasy, this one will serve the bill. It makes the average Godzilla movie seem like random street crime in comparison!More importantly, this book, unlike all too many modern fantasy novels, is self contained and is not merely volume one of an infinite series of 1,000 page tomes. (Martin and Jordan, I'm looking at y'all...). The plot fits in one volume, though as stated, it could have nee twice as long and still would not seem stale, and yet the world created and plot revealed are so interesting that further volumes would not be overly derivative and would be most welcome to me, another rare thing in modern fantasy, where the snail's pace and hordes of picayune details make wading through each new dootstop as much a chore as a pleasure even to fans.Best of all (SPOILER AHEAD!!!!) I like how the love story of Carolyn and Steve does not end happily. Hawkins must have been quite tempted to pave the road to happiness for our star crossed (literally, heh!) lovers, but admirably, he realizes that sub-plot would not work and so he doesn't force it to. This alone shows more maturity and skill than most new writers, genre or otherwise! What does happen instead to Steve and Carolyn in their different quests and arcs is ever more interesting and satisfying than the usual "amor vincit omnia" efforts that most fantasy writers succumb to.Hawkins has talent to burn, and does not make a single misstep here. What deficiencies that exist are almost certainly the result of limits set by the publisher / editor. There are too many apprentices floating around, few of whom matter, The abilities of the apprentices could have used more development and logical explanation, as sometimes the powers we see are kind of deus ex machina plot devices, but considering the subject matter, this is not inappropriate! Still, it seems as if there are too many "godlings" wandering about and the "rules" that they operate under are a bit sketchy.Also, the scope of events portrayed does exceed the stage a bit. (The "Henry V Syndrome" as noted by Shakespeare...) Hawkins does have a pretty capable muse of fire, but still multiple nuclear strikes, reality plagues, rising eldritch forces, solar eclipses... all seem a bit too crammed in less than 400 pages when GRR Martin can take 50 pages to tell you what Tyrion had to eat at the feast... I presume the page limit was set by the publisher, as new authors rarely get 750 page allowances for stand alones. If your bloated 750 pager is volume one of a trilogy, hey that's (usually) ok, new guiy, but a standalone first time novel would not he allocated such a high page count.If anything, it's amazing that LAMC works as well as it does considering its page count, and again, I commend Hawkins for not taking the Lazy Fantasy Author approach and say "well, I'll wrap things up in the next two volumes. Or maybe three volumes. Or maybe 7 volumes. Or maybe...":Anyway, 5 stars easily. If you are sensitive to violence or abuse of various types in books or if you like your fantasy gentle and light, stay away, and if you want a completely logical fantasy world, you may also have complaints, but all other fantasy fans will enjoy this, especially those who wished "American Gods" had a bit more of a superhero movie feel to it!

Apparently Z14 used to be a very complex and interesting masculine scent. It did not do well in the market, and oak moss, one of its key foundation ingredients, was basically banned by the fragrance regulatory authority, so these two facts have led to a very cheap reformulation that is not especially complex or interesting. What we have here is the slightest 10 minute duration hint of citrus followed by an almost entirely cinnamon scent that lasts for another 4 hours or so. The fragrance does not project well, and lasts less than most other masculine fragrances. If you want a cheap way to smell like cinnamon, here is a great option.All the rave reviews here are probably based on vintage stock of this fragrance before the oak moss was removed and the formula was changed to Eau de Cinnamon. I'm not sure why anyone would want this these days, at least in the modern formulation. If you want a cheap good male fragrance, Grey Flannel by G. Beene or Tuscany by Aramis are only slightly more than this and both smell like something other than a Christmas spice. Z14 is not unpleasant, and is certainly the best cheap fragrance you can find at the average Target. (Though even there Stetson and Old Spice are highly competitive...) Just be forewarned that if you get the modern reformulation, you are getting exactly what you pay for: a simple, linear, short-lived fragrance.

Nivea Sensitive Shaving balm (non-cooling) has always been an example of good bang for the buck in shaving balms. At around $5 a bottle online, the Nivea standard Sensitive balm works about as well at calming the skin as much more expensive balms (e.g. ProRaso, three times the price and Jack Black, 4 times the price). It also works much better than costly all organic formulas, such as Pacific Shaving Company's Caffeinated after shave (close to 80% more) and Body Shop's Razor Relief (close to 3 times the price.) Nivea standard Sensitive formula had only two drawbacks: it used witch hazel, an astringent, that some don't care for because it stings a little bit for a short while, and it also was not much of a moisturizer. Note that if you have dry skin, no post shave balm can really replace use of a second moisturizer, but even so, the standard Nivea Sensitive worked very poorly in terms of keeping your face moist after use for the intermediate term.The new Sensitive Cooling formula costs a little more, but fixes the small issues that existed in the original. Specifically, no witch hazel, and it also moisturizes significantly better, but note if you are a dry skinned dude, you will need to apply moisturizer after the balm unless you want your complexion to to look like Clint Eastwood's in an hour or two after shaving. Sensitive Cooling also has a neat trick, mainly it creates a cooling sensation on the face which lasts for a half hour or so after application. More interestingly, it creates this cooling without menthol. Menthol cools, but also hurts the skin at the same time, so if you have really delicate skin, the menthol may irritate even as it cools. The Nivea Sensitive Cooling at least tn theory gives you all the cool and none of the irritation. (I don't know what ingredient in the Cooling balm does the cooling work, so I am not 100% sure that whatever is cooling is not also an irritant to some degree, but on my face at least all is well!)Highly recommended as a cheap effective and pleasant way to calm and cool your sensitive skinned face after a shave. I am one of those masochistic double edged blade guys who make three passes over their face every morning to get a clean shave, so if this works for me, it will be more than enough for all you single pass fusion dudes. Use this with some tallow based shaving soap (Tabac is great here on Amazon, or try Barrister and Mann for a non-Amazon artisanal product) and then put on some Aveeno for a moisturizer, and you will have a smooth, comfortable, and cheap shave!

I don't have rosacea, just occasional post shave irritation and redness. Sad to say, this product is utterly useless for alleviating that problem. It is a watery, unscented fluid that left my face as red after application as it was before use. There are much cheaper alternatives for men who need to fix shaving related redness - try Nivea Sensitive Post Shave Cooling balm, which is about half the price of this, or Proraso Sensitive Skin Aftershave balm, the white stripe bottle, which is about 30% cheaper than the PC option.I do like Paula's choice shave cream, but that product is both cheaper and more effective at its purpose. This product may work fine for rosacea or other non-shaving irritation, but as a post shave soother, it was an expensive flop for me.

Ellena is an immensely talented creative artist, and his work in perfume is fascinating, but this book is dreadful and useless. Ellena does little to explain the technical side of perfumery, and his discussion of both his own and other perfumes is cursory and banal. This is a brief, dull, vague read, and is not even worth a library rental. Perfumes and their culture are explored with great depth on the internet by some really talented bloggers - check out Now Smell This, Bois de Jasmin, and Perfume Shrine to name just several sites. These blogs give you several dozen times more info on materials, manufacture, history and typology than this book does, contain incisive detailed analyses of fragrances, and are also better written. They are also completely free and have many nice pictures to look at... No contest!If you must have a book on perfume, the two books on the subject by Chandler Burr are notable, as is the Perfume Encyclopedia by Turin and Sanchez. Again, a lot more info, and better writing. I think this book was cynically marketed by Ellena and his publisher on the theory that readers would assume an interesting parfumeur would create the assumption that his book would also be interesting. Not the case here, I'm afraid.

The Futur on its lowest setting exposes more blade than the Progess does on its highest setting. For classic Gillette adjustable owners, setting 9 of 9 on the Fatboy or Slim is roughly the same as setting 2 of 6 on the Futur. Plus the Futur is immensely heavy, about 25% heavier than a Progess or a Fatboy. This adds up to a mighty aggressive shaver!In my particular case, I can only use the least sharp blades in the Futur (aka Derby & Merkur) at the lowest possible setting (1 of 6). If I use some sharper blade (Personna Blue, Gillette 7 O'Clock Yellows, or even an Astra SP) or dare to crank the dial up to 2 of 6, aaargggh! Lobster face, razor burn for hours, even without any blood. So I can use 1 or 2 types of blades in this, and on only 1 of 6 settings. (There are half point settings as well, but even 1.5 is gap too far for me...) To me, this is not really an adjustable, as I always have to use the same setting and only certain types of blades, unless I want to rip my face off.Lest you think me unmanly or inexpert, I will say I have used razors that are heavy (Maggard MR8) and some that are known for having aggressive heads (Parker 92R, Weber PH) and I can get smooth skin and a non-lobster face using those razors with all sorts of blades. It's only the Futur that causes me red-faced grief. Of course, in the wet shaving world, we have our flint-bearded Vikings, who have metallic stubble and shave once every several days. If you are one of these types, this may be your razor and maybe you can enjoy different blades and settings.I like the adjustable concept as it gives users a lot of customization options and the ability to mix exposure up during different shave passes. Most users who want this feature set and do not want a deply abraded face would be better off with the Merkur Progress, or a vintage Gillette adjustable if you can get one at a reasonable price (think Super or Slim, not Fatboy!) but for most, the Progress will be the most affordable solution and that model is well made and offers a usable range of adjustment at a cheaper price than the Futur.I feel bad rating the Futur poorly. It is well made, and I have none of the usual complaints. The head does indeed fit into the nooks and crannies of my face well enough, and I find blade replacement to be both simple and safe. I just can't see paying this much for a razor that (in my case) ends up being non-adjustable!Progress = Merkur's adjustable for normal human male faces.Futur = Merkur's adjustable for bristle faced Ubermensch.
