I have another comparably sized battery pack made by Amazon Basic, which I liked, but the Amazon unit was 10% less powerful and also costs close to 10% more. The Luggage Box (hereafter LB) is a little bit less luxurious than the Amazon product, which comes in a soft velvet bag with drawstrings, but the LB includes a nice small LED flashlight integrated into the unit that can run off the internal charge to give you illumination in emergencies. I like this feature more than some silly bag, so thumbs up to Luggage Box for a unique and useful extra feature!I ran the LB down several times with various devices, and it seems to reliably charge and distribute the power amount that is claimed. You can also charge two devices at once from the power pack, as there are two USB outlets. The unit is tough and sturdy, and did not get hot or smell bad during power charging / discharging.My only complaints? LB does not include any Apple compatible cabling or any sort of wall charger, so you have to provide those devices yourself. LB also only gives you a single USB cable to use, despite the two USB outputs. Amazon Basic's unit has these exact same shortcomings, though at a higher price and with less of a power reserve, so I did not take off any stars for these deficiencies as they seem to be the industry standard set or rather non-standards!The only remaining issue is that of style. The Amazon unit looks rather like a cell phone, while the LB unit does indeed look like a suitcase, and is bulkier and somewhat heavier. The ribbed texture is interesting to look at and makes LB grippier if you do need to use it as a flashlight. I like the looks of the Amazon unit more, but this is pretty subjective. I would suggest getting the LB in black though, as the white color is a tad too industrial looking to be charming.**FREE SAMPLE PROVIDED BY MANUFACTURER FOR EVALUATION**

Tide Colorguard does an impressive job of getting stains out even with a very small volume of product dispensed. It is also a very effective pre-wash, and I've gotten better results with rubbing Tide into a stained garment than I have had by using OxyClean and other specifically designated stain removers. Tide HE also works well with cold water washing (even though the product's instructions do not specifically state this) so environmentally conscious launderers can feel good about the ability to use less power and also get clean clothing.I've tried many different detergents over my life, and I've always been reluctant to use Tide because it costs so much more than other brands. Through many misadventures, I've come to see the virtue of using Tide even though it does cost more. Having to rewash inadequately cleaned loads or write off stained clothing with stains that have set permanently more than offsets the lower costs of using other brands or generics. I spend the extra money on Tide and feel there's a real benefit from doing so. (The ability to use the basic detergent as a spot treatment / stain remover is more value added.)I can't speak as to how well ColorGuard preserves colors in washed clothing (which is one of the major selling points of this formula) as this is my first bottle of this particular Tide mix. I normally use a different variant of Tide for reasons to be discussed below.Why not four stars? The color of the liquid is a weird pinkish orange that looks nasty if spilled, but that is not a real detriment. Issue number one for me is the rather sharp and cloying scent. I prefer my detergents unscented, but I know many folks think "that smell = clean". Even if you are in this positivist camp, the odor of Colorguard is a bit too bright and artificial for most. One gets accustomed to it, but I would still prefer no scent at all or a more mild one.Biggest issue with Colorguard is the measuring cup / cap. The dark cap has a virtually invisible set of measuring lines in it, so even with the highly visible Colorguard liquid being poured into it, I can rarely tell if I am at the appropriate level of mix for my load of wash. The lines are not clearly marked at all, and the black interior cap compounds this issue. With HE formula, it's easy to get too much detergent in the load, leading to sudsy and greasy residues, so clear measuring lines are essential. I haven't had any mishaps so far with my basic eyeballing of volume, (err on the side of caution and you should be OK, especially if you've used HE type formulas before) but it is a silly oversight for Tide not to give one a clearly marked and useful measuring cup for premium brand detergent. If you're using your own measuring cup, this won't be an issue, but I found it annoying.So all in all, premium cleaning power, and high efficiency are the main selling points. If you are concerned about your colors fading and don't mind a slightly overpowering scent, you should be well pleased with Tide Colorguard HE. (Though you may want to use your own measuring cup!)

My experience with battery powered grooming devices is that they never have enough "oomph" to get the job done, at least not for male users like myself. I've used a variety of those little weed wacker gadgets to trim nose hair that never do the trick, or at least not as well as scissors. Electric shavers need to be run forever over my thick stubble to work, and a Fusion manual does a better job in half the time. So when I ordered this electric pedicure device to use on my callused feet, I did not expect much and thought a pumice stone would easily best the Amope gadget.To my surprise, the Amope proved really effective at getting rid of thick calluses, quickly and painlessly. The tougher areas of my feet needed a bit of extra going over, but certainly not more than 10 or 20 seconds for even the ridgiest of areas. This is more than the 3 or 4 seconds the Amope manual suggests you spend on each area, but I did not feel any pain or friction even with 10 or 15 seconds of application. I wouldn't grind away for a minute, but I think 3 or 4 seconds is probably a tad conservative. Be sure to use the PP on dry feet though; wet skin might change the effectiveness for the worse and could also lead to possible injury from over-sloughing.The smoothing effect seems to last for a while, so I could not give an estimate as to battery life. The Pedi Perfect is quiet, and has a pretty simple learning curve. I was impressed at how easy the PP was to clean, and cleaning was really quick also.The PP is a lot more effective and easy to use than a pumice stone or a PediEgg. What took 15 minutes to do to a mostly smooth surface with a pumice stone could be done to a smoother level in a third of the time with the Amope gadget. This is a clear case of better living through electricity!Downside? The PP produces a cloud of skin dust as you use it, so be sure to be in a well ventilated area and be aware you will need to clean some callus dust up after the fact. Not sure how they could have fixed this, so I am not taking any point off for it. Plus of course you have to use a lot of batteries over the life of the product to keep it running. Alternate A/C power mode and / or an internal rechargeable battery would have made this a better product.The Pedi Perfect lost a star for me due to price, as I think the current price point is a tad too dear for what you get. Though the PP works well, I think it is overpriced given its relatively low tech level and ongoing need for batteries as the only method for power. But if you don't mind the price, this works great even for those with nasty calluses.

I've used this keyboard for a few weeks now.  Before this I've been using a non-keyboard case with my iPad Air, a Devicewear Slim iPad Air Case.  I also have and use on occasion a Logitech Tablet Keyboard for iPad when I want a BT keyboard to pair with my iPads.Here are some of my thoughts on this Belkin Thin Type keyboard case.DESIGN/BUILDI do not love all aspects of the design of this case.Yes, I agree the aluminum build of this keyboard gives this keyboard a nice substantial feel to it (personally preferable to the feel of a plastic case) yet without making it feel heavy (the case is lighter than the iPad Air).  Plus.Also the design and styling seem to nicely complement that of the iPad Air when being used in "keyboard" mode.  We have the Gray version of the case and a Space Gray iPad Air and while the aluminum of our iPad seems slightly darker than the aluminum of the keyboard case, they do go nicely, if not perfectly, together and look like they were made to go together.  Another plus.However, (note the qualifier in the previous paragraph), I am not a fan of the look of the keyboard case when it is being used in "case" mode as a cover for the iPad.  Specifically, I do not like the look of the bottom of the keyboard, which serves as the outside of the cover when the item is being used as an iPad case.The back of the iPad itself is of course minimalist with the Apple logo in the middle and a black strip at the top, which, while not ideal, I don't find too distracting.  However, the outside face of the Thin Type Keyboard case has a big black plastic strip (about 1.5" wide on a case that is only 6.5" wide) running along the long side of the cover right along the entire length of the hinge.  Further, there is also a raised aluminum ridge that runs right next to that from top to bottom of the case.  (Note, this ridge on cover is the under side of the slot that holds the iPad when the case is being used in "keyboard" mode.  So there is a reason for this ridge.  The keyboard is so thin it does not have the necessary depth for the slot without this.)I understand that the black plastic strip probably helps add to the stability of the unit when the iPad is inserted in keyboard mode and that it probably also helps to provide a comfortable elevated angle to the keyboard so that it does not completely lie flat on the table when in keyboard mode.  However, honestly, I find it a bit ugly.  For some reason I find it a bit aesthetically offensive, as if all the design effort went into the keyboard side but then they forgot they had to do something with the other side too.  It seems as if the look of the product when being used as a case was a bit of an after thought.Yes, the black and aluminum colors match those of the iPad, but the same design aesthetic is not there.  I don't know how they would have solved the issues of being able to support the iPad in keyboard mode or maintaining a comfortable keyboard elevation without these elements, but I think the cover side would have looked more consistent with the Apple aesthetic if it were more elegant.  Perhaps they could have made the unit a wedge shape.  Yes, it would have been heavier and not as thin, but it may have looked nicer overall.  The way it is, whenever I look at the front cover of this Belkin case, I think I'm looking at, well, . . . the bottom of a keyboard.Not to put too fine a point on it, but it is interesting to note that there is not a single full on picture of the "case" side of the item on the product page either on Amazon's or even on Belkin's own site.  You don't even get a glimpse of it on the video on the Amazon product page.  Neither is the case side shown on Belkin's own site in their inspirational product teaser video, which gives you lots of artsy views of the sleekness of the keyboard side, even a close up of the Belkin label and microphone button, but nary a glimpse of the other side.  I guess when Belkin ends by saying that "Typing has never looked this good," they chose not to mention that carrying the iPad around in their keyboard case will not look very good at all!I also don't like the look of the magnetic hinge.However, some people may not really care what the product looks like on the outside.  Believe it or not, I'm actually more of a function guy myself, so let's move on to some functional observations.KEYBOARDSizeIt's very nice that Belkin fit the keyboard within the footprint of the iPad Air.  And it works as a full keyboard.  It is, of course, smaller than a standard sized keyboard and, no, I don't feel like I'm typing on a laptop keyboard.  But, being realistic and keeping in mind the size constraints necessary to make the cover fit the footprint of the iPad Air, the size feels alright.So as long as you have reasonable sized expectations (and fingers) you should be OK.  If you have big, meaty paws, this may not be for you.  I do have to bring my fingers closer together on the Thin Type compared to when using a standard Apple Bluetooth keyboard so that they are almost, but not quite, touching each other when in typing home position.  When I transfer my hands from home position on the Apple BT keyboard to the Thin Type keeping the same position and not adjusting my finger spacing, my pinkies end up on the Caps Lock and Enter keys on the Thin Type keyboard.For reference, the edge to edge width of the outermost keys is 8.74" on the Belkin Thin type and almost 10.75" on a standard Apple Bluetooth keyboard (and almost 11" on a Logitech Tablet Keyboard for iPad).The action on the keyboard is fine.LayoutHowever, as some others have mentioned, to get somewhat reasonable sizing of and spacing between the keys, they have taken some liberties with the layout of the keyboard.  The alt/option and command buttons are now only found on the left side of the space bar, not on both sides as they normally are.  I'm not sure if the control button still exists on the keyboard anymore (unless the key to the right of the space bar with the globe icon is the control button).Eliminating duplicate function type keys is reasonable (and I hope the control button wasn't eliminated and is that button with the globe icon), but what I was less forgiving of was the relocation of one of the standard character keys.As others have pointed out, the semi-colon/colon (;/:) button has been moved.  It has been moved from its rightful place between the (L) and (`/") buttons two whole rows down to the right of the space bar.  In fact, it now shares the key with the icon of the globe, which was mentioned earlier.Any hunt-and-peckers or non-PC folk (non-punctuationally-correct) out there may not see what all the fuss is about, but for those touch typists who are accustomed to keys being where they thought they would be, trust me, this can be a bit of an annoyance.The (\/|) key has also been eliminated and relegated to "Fn" status on the ([/{) and (]/}) keys, respectively.  But no one really cares about that key.Special Keys: The Good, The Bad, and The ?Other than the changes to the layout of the more standard character keys, there are also an array of 15 special keys at the top where various function keys are normally found.Some of these are standard, things like volume/mute buttons (buttons 12-14) and play/pause/fwd/rev buttons (buttons 9-11).Others are nice additions (The Good) customized for a tablet, even specifically an iPad, keyboard.  They add nice functionality tailored for use with the iPad.For example:*The 1st button (looks like a square), functions as the home button on an iPad.  When you push it when you are in an app, it takes you back to the home screen.  It's nice to not have to reach up to push real home button on the iPad.*The next button (looks like a lock) locks your iPad instantly when you push it, the equivalent of closing a smart cover.  I guess that's nice if you want to quickly lock your iPad without having to reassemble the Belkin case and you don't want to wait around for it to go to the lock screen on its own.  The other nice thing is that you can wake a sleeping iPad by pressing almost any key on the keyboard (except from some reason the Fn key) AND you can enter your pass code on the lock screen using the keyboard.  It seems to go straight to the "Enter Passcode" screen without requiring the initial swipe.*The 3rd button (looks like a film strip) is the equivalent of double pressing the home button and gives you a strip view of recently used apps so you can quickly switch between them.*The 5th button (looks like a dashed line rectangle with a cross hair in one corner) essentially takes a picture for you.  If you are in the camera app, it will snap a pic from whichever camera is active.  If you are not in camera mode, it will take a screenshot of whatever is on your screen.  (Cool tip: you can even use it while you are playing a video (from YouTube, the web, a streaming app like Vudu, or your iTunes video library) and it will take a screen shot of your video!)  All pics are saved in your camera roll.*The last (15th) button is a Pair button that makes pairing your iPad and keyboard a snap.Then, there are some other buttons whose utility is a bit more questionable (The Bad):-The 4th button (looks like the keyboard icon that pulls up the touch keyboard on your iPad screen) . . . pulls up the touch keypad on your iPad screen.  Huh?  Why you would want to pull up the touch keypad on your iPad, using a dedicated button no less, from your external keyboard, which you presumably got to not have to use said touch keypad, I don't know.  Maybe you really want to use the currency symbols for the British pound, the euro, or the Japanese yen, the only characters that I can see that are available on the touch keypad (2 layers deep) but not on the Belkin keyboard.And, finally, there are some keys which I still don't know what they do (The ?).  (Buttons 6-8 that look like old TV sets with a star, X, and + symbols in them, I'm looking at you!)  I'm also not sure how the button with the microphone icon down in the lower right works.  Yes, I'm assuming it operates a microphone, but I'm not sure how to use it.  (See the "INSTRUCTIONS" section below).ON/OFF SWITCHBelkin likes to point out that the Thin Type Keyboard Case has an automatic on/off switch.  The keyboard is automatically activated from its off mode when you insert the iPad into its slot in the keyboard.  No switch to fumble with, no forgetting to shut keyboard off and so accidentally drain all your battery life unnecessarily, what's not to like?The switch itself is a little rubber enclosed pressure trigger that sits in the middle of the iPad slot.  When you place your iPad in the slot, the weight of the iPad depresses the trigger and activates the keyboard.  When you remove the iPad, the trigger is released and the keyboard automatically shuts off.  This seems very convenient, and it is.However, I would personally prefer the ability to force the keyboard to stay on, even if there is no iPad inserted into the slot.  The reason is that I could see myself using this keyboard without the iPad inserted in the slot (see below).  However, there is no easy way to do this.  You can force the keyboard to stay on by depressing the on/off button with something else.  Anything that can hold down the button will do.  For example, you could use your finger, but that doesn't work well for typing.  Standard sized pens and pencils won't do it.  As I said, there is no easy way to do this.I would have preferred if they added one small switch that had OFF/AUTO/ON settings.  That way, if you wanted to use it in the automatic on/off mode the way they designed it, you could.  But if you wanted to force it on (see below under VIEWING ANGLE) or off (in case you wanted to make sure it didn't accidentally get turned on somehow), you could also select those options as well.PAIRINGThe process of pairing the keyboard to the iPad is very easy in the initial pairing (just follow the included instructions).Subsequent connections after the initial pairing are automatic.  You don't have to do anything except put the iPad into the slot.Now, I don't know what would happen if you paired the keyboard to multiple iPads and they were both nearby.  And I did have one bit of trouble when I tried to turn off the Bluetooth on the iPad (so that I could pair different keyboard and iPad combos), and when I turned the BT back on, it didn't re-establish the connection automatically.  However, when I just made the iPad forget the device and redid the initial pairing it worked fine again.VIEWING ANGLENote the singular.There is only 1 fixed viewing angle, it is not adjustable.  I measure about a 55 degree angle from the table surface to the back of the iPad.  I'm not sure where Belkin gets their 35 degree angle measurement - maybe that's the angle from your head to the iPad screen.  The inability to adjust the viewing angle limits the range of contexts in which you can comfortably use this keyboard combo.The viewing angle is comfortable when using this iPad keyboard combo while sitting in a chair at a table, at least for me.  That's where this does well.However, if you are using this in other contexts, it may not fare so well.  This unit really needs to be used on a hard flat surface.  I do not find this as comfortable to use, for example, when trying to balance the combo on my lap.  If you are sitting back on a sofa and can position the keyboard further up your lap where it is wider, it feels more stable and works OK.  But if you are sitting somewhere where you have to sit up straighter (like on a subway seat or a hard chair) and have to position the keyboard further out, closer to your knees, it feels much less stable and can feel like it may topple over.Since you do not have the ability to adjust the viewing angle this greatly limits the positions from which you can comfortably view the screen.  Again, the viewing angle is great when you are sitting in a chair with the combo on the table in front of you, but if you are sitting straight up and balancing it on your lap near your knees, or if you are reclining far back, almost lying down on a sofa or bed, the viewing angles are not optimal.One thing that might have helped alleviate this viewing angle limitation is if the unit had that OFF/AUTO/ON switch I mentioned earlier.  With this option, you could force the keyboard to stay on and use it with the iPad when the two are separated.  This way you could position the iPad separately from the keyboard in a more suitable position.STABILITYThen there is the stability issue.The iPad is held in the keyboard only by its own weight in the angled slot.  There is no mechanism, mechanical or magnetic, to hold the iPad securely in the keyboard slot.  Again, when you use the iPad and keyboard on a hard, flat, stable surface (like a table) the iPad feels secure in the slot and the keyboard works great.  But similar to the situation with regard to viewing angles, the design of this keyboard unit limits its ability to be used as easily in other contexts.If you try to hold the combo in your lap or if you are trying to pass the unit around to friends to share what is on the screen there is nothing to prevent the iPad from being accidentally knocked out or from falling out if the unit were tilted.  I would have preferred if there were some kind of mechanism to hold the iPad in the slot a little more securely.  Perhaps a magnetic strip inside the slot similar to the one they have in the hinge might have added a bit of security.PROTECTIONI don't think this cover really offers much protective function at all.  There is no protection at all of the back or sides of the iPad.  I suppose the keyboard can protect the screen somewhat but this unit was primarily designed with the keyboard functionality in mind and not as a protective cover.Some keyboard covers are designed more as a case with an integrated keyboard and offer both the keyboard functionality and also some greater level of protection.  This one is not.  However, there is usually a trade off between the size and protective ability of cases and this one is no exception.  If you are looking for this style of case that does not cover the back at all, you probably are willing to sacrifice some level of protection for a smaller and lighter form factor.  It's really a matter of preference on which type of case you prefer, but know that this one is really not primarily designed to protect your iPad.COVERI already mentioned something about the look of this as an iPad cover and that it isn't really designed to protect the iPad, but there is another aspect of the use of this product as an iPad cover that I would like to point out.The cover is held onto the iPad by a magnetic hinge.  That's nice and all, but to use the keyboard you have to detach the magnetic hinge in order to put the iPad into the slot.  And then you have to remove the iPad from the slot and reattach it to the hinge when you are ready to go.I find this whole process cumbersome.  For keyboard cases, I prefer those that can simply be flipped open or closed and remain attached to the iPad at all times. It's true that those designs are often bulkier because they usually incorporate some kind of protective case along with the keyboard, but I think I would rather sacrifice a smaller form factor and the aluminum look for a (what I consider) more convenient access and also the ability to fold back the cover against the back of the iPad.The design of this unit with a rigid unibody aluminum case and a magnetic hinge does not allow you to fold the cover back all the way against the back of the iPad.  You can open the case, but you have to hold it in "open book" form, which usually requires 2 hands and is inconvenient and cumbersome in most cases.  For example, even the simple task of browsing the web with the cover on and open becomes more tricky.BATTERY LIFEI know this is an important issue, but I have not really tested this.  I charged the unit fully once when I got it a few weeks ago and have not had to recharge it since.  I have only put it through moderate use, but even so, battery life looks like it is OK from what I can tell.INSTRUCTIONSThere are some instructions included on how to pair the keyboard over BT with your iPad.  Those are fine and spell out the process very clearly.But after that, you're on your own.  Granted, it's a keyboard, you just type.  I supposed there isn't really too much to explain.  However, as mentioned above, a little bit of information as to what some of the keys did would have been helpful.  I figured out what a bunch of those short cut function keys did, but the use of some of the others still eludes me.I even looked up the support pages for this product on the Belkin site and couldn't find any more info there either!COMPATIBILITY WITH OTHER iPAD COVERSFrom what I can tell, this is not designed to work with other iPad Covers.I was using a Devicewear Slim iPad Air Case when I got this Belkin Thin Type.  The Devicewear case has a fairly thin plastic backing and when I tried to insert my iPad Air, with the back of the case still on (and the front part folded away), it was not able to fit inside the slot.  I haven't tried any other cases, but it seems that the slot in the keyboard will not be able to accommodate the iPad Air with any kind of a case still on.So, that means you either have to keep switching between the case and the keyboard (a pain) if you want to use the keyboard and still have some protection when you are carrying the iPad around, or just not use a protective case at all.I do like to have some protection for my devices, especially the backs (which is why I never really used Apple's smart covers, even though I thought they were cool when they first came out with their magnetic hinges and all).  So I would have preferred if you could have inserted an iPad with some thin case on into the slot of the keyboard without have to remove the iPad from the case.COMPATIBILITY WITH OTHER iPADSI also have an older iPad 3 (I think that's the model).  Obviously this keyboard case won't fit as a cover, but I was curious to see if it would work with other iPad models in keyboard mode.  In theory it should probably work with any BT enabled iPad.  However, it didn't really in practice because the bigger iPad 3 couldn't properly seat itself fully inside the slot to maintain the keyboard in the activated state.Well, it sort of worked, in landscape mode, but not well.  Not enough to be used reliably.  It's possible it might work as a BT keyboard with a smaller iPad that could fit in the slot, like maybe the iPad mini(?).  Again, an OFF/AUTO/ON button which allows you to force the keyboard on would have made this keyboard potentially usable with other models (for example, I use this primarily with my iPad Air but might occasionally want to use it with my iPad 3 also).SUMMARY RECOMMENDATIONOverall, this could be a decent BT keyboard for your iPad Air depending on how you want to use your iPad with this keyboard cover.If you don't really mind the look of this as a cover, don't have large hands and fingers, and plan to use this mostly sitting in a chair at a table to type and want a better experience than using the touch pad keyboard on the screen, then this would certain provide that.  Perhaps you want to just keep this at your desk and only use it like a keyboard dock for your iPad while sitting at your desk.  That would work.However, if you want a more versatile keyboard cover combo that can do everything well (protect your iPad, have a functional keyboard, be usable in many different contexts, and look good while doing it), or at least be a jack-of-all trades type of unit, then this may not be for you. The Belkin Thin Type seems to be designed with one strength, sitting down at a table and typing, and it seems like it might do that well.  However, the trade off is that it seems to be really limited in many other contexts and uses.

For many years, we used generic dishwashing fluid, and were amazed at how quickly supplies diminished. (We had the same issue with store brand paper towels.) By spending a bit more and using brands like Dawn & Palmolive, we found we used less fluid over time, which lowered use more than offset the purchase price difference.Dawn Ultra has brought this tendency to a new and higher level, as the Ultra concentrated formula means you can get a lot of cleaning done with very little liquid. The biggest challenge with using Ultra is to not put too much on the dishes as we have had a sink filled with suds on many occasions.Ultra cuts through grease very effectively, and letting a grease encrusted pan soak for 15 minutes in Dawn and warm water will give you a really easy clean up at the end of the wait. My one cautionary note is to avoid soaking non-stick coated pans in Ultra for a lengthy period, as the concentrated cleanser agent may cut down on the life of the coating, but this is not really a Dawn problem.Finally, as compared to Palmolive, I find Dawn's scent to be cleaner and more neutral, not quite as cloying or artificial. This to me is the biggest difference between the brands, as I feel cleansing power is roughly comparable, and both are pretty easy on hands. If you like strong artificial scent, Palmolive may be your preference, but I like the more subtle Dawn Ultra.I gave Ultra 4 stars on the logic that it is a premium price product that performs at a premium level. If it were bargain priced and did a great job, five stars would be my rating, but as it is, I feel Dawn is an excellent dishwashing agent, and is worth its price vis a vis competitors. Highly recommended!

The HP50 is the finest sounding portable headphone I have heard, and comes close to being a portable Sennheiser HD600, which is high praise indeed. The HP 50 give amazing levels of clarity, resolution, and dynamic impact, and is also reasonably neutral, with maybe a slight boost in the mid-bass area. You are definitely getting highly accurate sound reproduction here at the core level, though the "RoomFeel" technology modifies things a bit, especially in terms of transient response (esp. drums). The Room Feel acoustical theory apparently mutes transient response a bit to avoid listener fatigue. This works for me - when I listen to metal for lengthy sessions, the HP50 works a lot better than say the Yamaha Pro 500 or ATH M50, but the accuracy of the response is somewhat compromised, which may alienate purists.However, there is an issue with poorly recorded / mastered albums with significant drum presence; these will sound very lifeless on the HP50s - e.g. Pantera, Down both sounded very mediocre on the HP50s, even though both groups sounded just fine on other headphones. Classical and jazz bring out the best in the HP50s and the transient response feels more natural and full there, which is probably due to the mastering quality. I don't want to get rock and metal fans worried for the most part - well mastered stuff like Muse and Tool sound excellent, but it's the sludgier / lo-fi side of rock that sounds a bit washed out on the HP50s. (This was an issue with the HD600s also, so I think the comparison is very accurate!)Besides the Room Feel response modification issue that may affect some recordings, the HP50s have two other issues. First, the headband design assumes the listener has a square head, and there is a inward sloping section right in the middle part of the headband that causes me significant pain right in the middle of the band. I have no idea why they designed the phones that way, maybe to maintain constant tension on the earcups to maintain a good seal, but whatever the design intent was, these are among the least comfortable designs I own, being outdone only by the Yamaha Pro 500s in long term discomfort capability. The pressure on the ears is fine, but that wedge in the middle of your scalp starts to hurt after about an hour. You can move the band around a bit on your head, and / or take a 5 minute rest and you can then keep on listening for another 45-60 minutes. I have indeed listened to the HP50s for hours without needing to go to the ER or take Tylenol, but I needed a lot of micro-adjustments and a few rest periods of several minutes in order to get through the marathon. The HP50s sound good and unique enough to endure a bit of pain, and depending on your head shape and size (I wear a size L hat) you may be just fine.Second issue, and the biggest liability, is build quality / warranty. In my first month of ownership, the Ipod 3 button cable shorted and needed to be replaced. (No trauma involved, just a few days of crackling, and then no sound from it at all.) The company took about a month to get the replacement cable to me, and it involved a lot of emails and use of the rather non-intuitive customer service interface on the NAD site. I had to hunt around to find a way to contact NAD on their site, then had to establish a user ID and account to contact them, and then had to submit a question through the website to get service. Then the company required me to provide proof of purchase from an authorized dealer before they would send me the $5 cable for free, and then they forgot to send it out for a few weeks, and claimed I had failed to provide my address, though I did that in the initial contact. I re-provided my address and eventually got the cable.Though this is not anywhere near as bad as say AKG customer service (think 3 or 4 months of waiting...) it also does not compare well with B&W, at the same price point. My P5s had the same issue shortly after purchase, and B&W sent me a replacement cable overnight after a single 2 minute phone call to a number on their website and with no proof of purchase needed. If you're selling a $300 pair of headphones, you ought to maybe be a tad friendlier to your customers IMO.Then things got worse. After 5 months of ownership, the wiring between the two drivers failed, and now I only get sound from one side or the other of the phones. (You can plug the cable into either side; whichever side I have the cable plugged into works and the other side is silent.) I contacted NAD and was told the company does not do its own warranty service but instead I must return the phones to the original point of purchase, and the authorized dealer will replace them. (Note this replacement will only be done by an authorized dealer; if you buy from an unauthorized dealer, even at list price, I would think you might have a problem...)The dealer was great and provided quick and efficient service, but I had to pay to ship the HP50s to them, which will cost maybe $20 or so, and will of course involve me standing in line at the UPS store or Post Office. Again, though this is not the worst problem ever in life, it is irritating to have to pay for warranty service for a $300 pair of headphones. Also, the point of failure here is one that I have never seen happen on anything other than a $25 pair of Philips cheapies I had owned 10 years ago. If this was some exotic technology that failed, like a new type of planar driver or some such, I might be more accepting of the issue, but wiring from one driver to another? Come on guys, get the simple stuff right for three hundred bills!It seems frankly, that NAD is a tiny company that does not have its act together in terms of manufacturing high quality headphones or supporting them. Not sure how they are in terms of their other electronic devices, but Sennheiser produces higher quality headphones and supports them better. If only the HP50 did not sound as good as it does, I would just write NAD off. But the impressive sound quality of the HP50s, along with their unique and enjoyable Room Feel signature gives me the patience to reluctantly jump through a few more hoops here than I would for lesser sounding headphones. But you may not be as patient as me, especially if you think a luxury headphone price point should also give you world class build quality and customer service.So takeaway points:1) Buy from an authorized dealer; be 100% certain the dealer is authorized, check the NAD website.2) Be prepared for some discomfort during use, especially if you have a big head.3) Expect the worse in terms of build quality, and be prepared for a somewhat onerous customer service experience if problems do develop.As I said, I think the HP50s are worth all this trouble, but if they break again, that's all for me, and I will update the review if and when that happens.

Not sure how they are in terms of their other electronic devices, but Sennheiser produces higher quality headphones and supports them better. If only the HP50 did not sound as good as it does, I would just write NAD off. But the impressive sound quality of the HP50s, along with their unique and enjoyable Room Feel signature gives me the patience to reluctantly jump through a few more hoops here than I would for lesser sounding headphones. But you may not be as patient as me, especially if you think a luxury headphone price point should also give you world class build quality and customer service.So takeaway points:1) Buy from an authorized dealer; be 100% certain the dealer is authorized, check the NAD website.2) Be prepared for some discomfort during use, especially if you have a big head.3) Expect the worse in terms of build quality, and be prepared for a somewhat onerous customer service experience if problems do develop.As I said, I think the HP50s are worth all this trouble, but if they break again, that's all for me, and I will update the review if and when that happens.

The HP50 is the finest sounding portable headphone I have heard, and comes close to being a portable Sennheiser HD600, which is high praise indeed. The HP 50 give amazing levels of clarity, resolution, and dynamic impact, and is also reasonably neutral, with maybe a slight boost in the mid-bass area. You are definitely getting highly accurate sound reproduction here at the core level, though the "RoomFeel" technology modifies things a bit, especially in terms of transient response (esp. drums). The Room Feel acoustical theory apparently mutes transient response a bit to avoid listener fatigue. This works for me - when I listen to metal for lengthy sessions, the HP50 works a lot better than say the Yamaha Pro 500 or ATH M50, but the accuracy of the response is somewhat compromised, which may alienate purists.However, there is an issue with poorly recorded / mastered albums with significant drum presence; these will sound very lifeless on the HP50s - e.g. Pantera, Down both sounded very mediocre on the HP50s, even though both groups sounded just fine on other headphones. Classical and jazz bring out the best in the HP50s and the transient response feels more natural and full there, which is probably due to the mastering quality. I don't want to get rock and metal fans worried for the most part - well mastered stuff like Muse and Tool sound excellent, but it's the sludgier / lo-fi side of rock that sounds a bit washed out on the HP50s. (This was an issue with the HD600s also, so I think the comparison is very accurate!)Besides the Room Feel response modification issue that may affect some recordings, the HP50s have two other issues. First, the headband design assumes the listener has a square head, and there is a inward sloping section right in the middle part of the headband that causes me significant pain right in the middle of the band. I have no idea why they designed the phones that way, maybe to maintain constant tension on the earcups to maintain a good seal, but whatever the design intent was, these are among the least comfortable designs I own, being outdone only by the Yamaha Pro 500s in long term discomfort capability. The pressure on the ears is fine, but that wedge in the middle of your scalp starts to hurt after about an hour. You can move the band around a bit on your head, and / or take a 5 minute rest and you can then keep on listening for another 45-60 minutes. I have indeed listened to the HP50s for hours without needing to go to the ER or take Tylenol, but I needed a lot of micro-adjustments and a few rest periods of several minutes in order to get through the marathon. The HP50s sound good and unique enough to endure a bit of pain, and depending on your head shape and size (I wear a size L hat) you may be just fine.Second issue, and the biggest liability, is build quality / warranty. In my first month of ownership, the Ipod 3 button cable shorted and needed to be replaced. (No trauma involved, just a few days of crackling, and then no sound from it at all.) The company took about a month to get the replacement cable to me, and it involved a lot of emails and use of the rather non-intuitive customer service interface on the NAD site. I had to hunt around to find a way to contact NAD on their site, then had to establish a user ID and account to contact them, and then had to submit a question through the website to get service. Then the company required me to provide proof of purchase from an authorized dealer before they would send me the $5 cable for free, and then they forgot to send it out for a few weeks, and claimed I had failed to provide my address, though I did that in the initial contact. I re-provided my address and eventually got the cable.Though this is not anywhere near as bad as say AKG customer service (think 3 or 4 months of waiting...) it also does not compare well with B&W, at the same price point. My P5s had the same issue shortly after purchase, and B&W sent me a replacement cable overnight after a single 2 minute phone call to a number on their website and with no proof of purchase needed. If you're selling a $300 pair of headphones, you ought to maybe be a tad friendlier to your customers IMO.Then things got worse. After 5 months of ownership, the wiring between the two drivers failed, and now I only get sound from one side or the other of the phones. (You can plug the cable into either side; whichever side I have the cable plugged into works and the other side is silent.) I contacted NAD and was told the company does not do its own warranty service but instead I must return the phones to the original point of purchase, and the authorized dealer will replace them. (Note this replacement will only be done by an authorized dealer; if you buy from an unauthorized dealer, even at list price, I would think you might have a problem...)The dealer was great and provided quick and efficient service, but I had to pay to ship the HP50s to them, which will cost maybe $20 or so, and will of course involve me standing in line at the UPS store or Post Office. Again, though this is not the worst problem ever in life, it is irritating to have to pay for warranty service for a $300 pair of headphones. Also, the point of failure here is one that I have never seen happen on anything other than a $25 pair of Philips cheapies I had owned 10 years ago. If this was some exotic technology that failed, like a new type of planar driver or some such, I might be more accepting of the issue, but wiring from one driver to another? Come on guys, get the simple stuff right for three hundred bills!It seems frankly, that NAD is a tiny company that does not have its act together in terms of manufacturing high quality headphones or supporting them. Not sure how they are in terms of their other electronic devices, but Sennheiser produces higher quality headphones and supports them better. If only the HP50 did not sound as good as it does, I would just write NAD off. But the impressive sound quality of the HP50s, along with their unique and enjoyable Room Feel signature gives me the patience to reluctantly jump through a few more hoops here than I would for lesser sounding headphones. But you may not be as patient as me, especially if you think a luxury headphone price point should also give you world class build quality and customer service.So takeaway points:1) Buy from an authorized dealer; be 100% certain the dealer is authorized, check the NAD website.2) Be prepared for some discomfort during use, especially if you have a big head.3) Expect the worse in terms of build quality, and be prepared for a somewhat onerous customer service experience if problems do develop.As I said, I think the HP50s are worth all this trouble, but if they break again, that's all for me, and I will update the review if and when that happens.

I am unimpressed with the whole concept of the "moderate protection" cell phone case. If you really want to protect your phone, put it in something bulky, ugly, and costly (e.g. Otterbox Defender). Yes, the sleek gadget now no longer looks sleek or thin or attractive, but that's the price you pay for sturdiness. I put my S4 in a "moderate protection" case from Otterbox (not the Defender) and the screen got cracked in a relatively low impact trauma moment, which cost me $150 to fix. Even the best of the moderate protection cases (IMO the Thule Atmos) will only protect against a really limited range of damage, and all the companies only warranty the case, not the phone inside of it. I suggest two options: leave your phone out of a case altogether and enjoy it's sleekness and aesthetic splendor, or put it in the ugly clunky Defender or comparable standard and actually get some useful protection out of it.If you're still convinced you want a moderate protection case, I would not recommend the Case Logic Extreme 2 model for the Galaxy S4. The EXTREME (apparently the mfgr chooses to spell it this way)has a two piece design, thin rubber inner coat that fits into a harder plastic outer frame with your phone under both layers. Despite the two sections of alleged protection, this case has considerably more flex to it than the single piece Thule Atmos does, due to the cheaper thinner plastic used by Case Logic, and the corners of the EXTREME do not have those theoretically useful crush zones that Thule and Otterbox put in their light protection cases. Indeed, the EXTREME has nothing special on the corners at all, as the hard outer frame ends about halfway through the angle of each corner, leaving only the soft thin rubber inner coating to protect the half of the corner angles on the top and bottom of the device. In other words, the hard outer frame does not completely wrap around your phone, but only protects the central portion. This is much worse protection than is standard even for the world of moderate protection!Case Logic indeed tells you nothing about the case, so no details as to why it is good, what design features it uses to protect from hazards, or even how to install it. (Put the two case pieces together first and then fit the phone in, no need to thank me Case Logic...) You get the impression from the packaging and the website that the company's attitude is "here's a cheap cell phone case, what more info do you need, go use it".Besides the flexibility of the frame and the bare bones feature set, there are other issues. The rocker button for volume and the on/off button are encased in thin rubber, not a hard plastic overlay as is seen on more expensive cases. The buttons work just fine, but the thin rubber will not keep them from snapping off if exposed to local trauma in the same way that a plastic overlay would.Also, the headphone port gains special demerits. The problem with most of these cases for most phones is that they give you a small round hole to fit your hp plug in, which will not accommodate exposed metal of less than 1mm length. This means many bulky / stubby hp designs including many popular and common models like the ATH M50, Senn HD25, or Shure 215 will not fit most headphone ports on most cases.  The EXTREME seems to offer a larger shaped port so I was hoping I could use my M50s with it, but the extra cutout space is only in the rubber inner shell so after a few seconds of reluctant compression, the rubber inner lining expands again and unseats the headphone plug that you barely managed to fit in the port in the first place, meaning you lose sound.This decompression pop only happens with plugs of less than 1mm exposed metal, hp plugs with longer lengths of exposed metal are fine. However, the Badge of Dishonor goes to the EXTREME for appearing to be able to accommodate all sorts of plugs and then not being able to actually do so due to poor design that could have been fixed with an extra 8 seconds of design thought / testing and another 2 cents of manufacturing cost.Besides the flex, the vanilla design, and the deceptive headphone compatibility issue, my final complaint is that of aesthetics. The bright candy colored red of my model of the case looks cheap and ugly, especially in comparison the darker more subdued red of my S4 case. I thought a red case and red phone would go well together, but the low rent color scheme of the EXTREME just made my phone look cheaper instead.So bottom line:1) "Moderate Protection" for cell phones is a generally flawed concept;2) Getting a cheap example of a flawed concept only exacerbates the faults in the concept;3) The Case Logic EXTREME appears to have no useful design elements, or at least none that the manufacturer cares to share with us. Plus the case feels cheap, looks cheap, and makes the phones it contains look worse than if they were not in it.I would suggest spending more on a moderate protection case if you feel you want that design at all. The Thule Atmos is more than twice the price of the EXTREME, but feels sturdier, protects buttons and switches better, and looks nicer. Get that model if you want to walk along the risky path of moderate protection for your cell device.

My mom and grandma were wizards with plastic wrap. They would take a plate heaped with bulky irregularly shaped leftovers, get exactly the right amount of wrap on it, wrap the food tightly and completely so that there were no loose ends, and would then tuck the plate in the fridge where it would last for many days pristine and inviolate.My wife and I? No such skills. When we use plastic wrap, we end up having to grab extra pieces to make sure the plate is covered, and then we have to wrap multiple segments together in different areas of the plate. Then nothing is ever tight enough, meaning the ends of the wrap start coming loose in the fridge, meaning either food spilling hazard or the need for a rewrap, consuming even more plastic wrap.To dolts such as us, Press N Seal Wrap is like a gift from the food gods. The ends tuck away neatly and stay sealed around the container even when upsets happen. The PNS stretches out to exactly the right contour and elasticity. And the containers stay wrapped for a really long time. In short, I feel like I am 125% more competent at wrapping food when I use PNS.However, this competence comes at a price. PNS is roughly 4 times as much per inch as regular Glad plastic wrap, and about 6 to 8 times as much as generic plastic wrap. If you are a really competent user of regular plastic wrap, like my Mom and Grandma were, you may just want to save money and get the regular stuff. The rolls will last longer and cost much less.Also, PNS does not handle re-wraps well: e.g. you want to unwrap the food, get something out and then re-wrap the container. In general, I have found PNS loses its stickiness after the initial wrap, and you need to use more PNS to wrap the container again. If you do this a lot, the cost of use of PNS rises. We don't do this much, as most of our leftovers are single use portions.Like most plastic wrap, PNS does not microwave very well, arguably even worse that regular wrap as the PNS is tighter and leaves less room for steam to escape. If you microwave with plastic wrap a lot (which is really not that good of an idea anyway) you may want to use regular plastic wrap. (Or better yet, a paper towel!)Most users will delight in the ease of use of PNS, and I personally view it as a kitchen essential. If you are a master user of the regular style plastic wrap, you can save your money, but I view purchase of PNS as money well spent for our home, as it minimizes food spills in the fridge, ensures freshness, and minimizes frustration.If this were only say twice as much as conventional wrap, and / or if it could be reused more effectively, I'd give this product five stars, but at current price level, PNS is a solid 4 stars, 5 stars if cost is no issue to you.

One link broke from another, spontaneously with no force exerted. Had the necklace for exactly 34 days, which is 4 days over the lame warranty extended by seller. Works out to be a chain rental at $0.56 per day. Lesson learned: if you must buy cheap jewelry, get it with a decent warranty. And avoid this product and seller!

I'll just start this review with my bias: I didn't particularly enjoy Jeff Shinabarger' book Yes or No.  It has more to do with my expectations rather than the book itself, but my expectations were shaped by the title and promotional material.  First of all, look at the full title: Yes or No: How Your Everyday Decisions Will Forever Shape Your Life.  This isn't a book about everyday decisions.  The book description says it will help you "develop your personal philosophy of choice" and show a "practical process for making good choices."None of the above, in my view, really fits the content of Yes or No.  Shinabarger writes a lot about his own life, and the development of his organization, Cardboard People.  I am interested in this organization, which helps "social entrepreneurs" get started.  They are the real target of this book: people who are starting an organization and need help with their vision and focus.  If this is you, great.  You are probably the type-A, motivated individual that Shinabarger is writing for.For the rest of us, the non-entrepreneurial, low-profile types who would like some guidance in seeking God and making wise and productive decisions as we look for jobs, serve in our churches and communities, and lead our families, Yes or No misses the mark.  It simply didn't deliver as advertised.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

I love this CD.  I have loved Keith Green's music for a long time, but have lamented that he died before I ever knew who he was.  This collection of songs from several live performances captures his humor, joy, and, most of all, his passionate heart for worship like I had not seen and heard before.  Keith Green fans, this one is a must for your collection.

At the height of the Cold War, a serial killer is on the loose in Soviet Russia.  An unlikely hero, Leo Demidov, has to use stealth and misdirection to solve the heinous crimes.  The problem is, investigating crime in the Soviet regime means admitting that there is crime.  In the workers' paradise, crime, of course, should not exist.  Child 44, Tom Rob Smith's first novel, traces Leo's pursuit of truth in spite of state dogma, while describing a political and social system that we can be thankful no longer exists (at least in that form).Leo, a war hero and patriot, serves in the secret police, whose primary objective is to uphold the State.  Suspects are guilty until proven innocent, but they are never proven innocent because only the guilty are arrested.  To release someone who had been arrested would be to admit that the State made a mistake, and the State never makes mistakes.Leo convinces the family of a murdered child to accept the murder as a mere accident, but when he learns of murders that resemble that child's murder, he doggedly pursues the truth about the killer.  Of course he must do so covertly and at the risk of his life because of the treasonous thought that there is a murderer on the lose and that the State had not "solved" the crimes correctly.On one level, Leo's chase is good crime drama.  Putting the pieces together, while constantly looking over his shoulder, he never imagines where the path is taking him.  (The reader, however, has a pretty good idea before Leo does. . . .)  Leo's crisis of integrity and determination to do what he knows is right makes the story interesting, as does the setting of Soviet Russia and the bureaucratic, oppressive, hypocritical, deadly, unjust, and downright evil mess that it was.If parts of the story, especially the climactic reveal, seem a bit stilted or contrived, that's OK.  It's crime fiction, not academic history.  Child 44 is a fun read.  I look forward to Tom Rob Smith's next book.

This year I have been reading the Bible in chronological order.  I admit, it's been a while since I have read through the Old Testament.  As I read the history of the Patriarchs, and especially the history of the kingdoms of Judah and Israel, I get so frustrated with the stories.  There are times when the people of the Bible make ISIS look reasonable and the God of the Old Testament seems far distant from the character of Jesus.  I have to come to grips with the fact that I would rather cut some of those passages right out of the Bible instead of dealing with them as a part of my heritage of faith.Brian Cosby, a pastor in the Presbyterian Church in America denomination, addresses this very struggle in his new book, Uncensored: Daring to Embrace the Entire Bible.  He writes that "many self-professing Christians cherry pick the Scriptures for a feel-good faith."  We like the scriptures that make a good bumper sticker or t-shirt slogan, but spend a little time reading the Bible and you'll find plenty that you don't want to see on your next youth retreat t-shirt.Cosby leaves no doubt that he holds a high view of scripture.  He affirms that "God's Word is inspired, inerrant, and authoritative."  When there's something troubling in the Bible, "it beckons my trust in a God who is using His Word to take me to His intended destination."  Cosby shares R.C. Sproul's view: "When there's something in the Word of God that I don't like, the problem is not with the Word of God, it's with me."After affirming the reliability and authority of scripture, Cosby addresses some specific areas in which Christians tend to be selective in their reading and use of scripture.  He discusses creation, God's justice, God's role in restraining evil while not being the source of evil, his intolerance for sin, and the reality of hell.  Cosby also delves into some expressions of cherry-picking faith: churches that emphasize entertainment as worship, and parents who outsource the development and teaching of their children to third parties.Uncensored has helped me to reflect on ways in which I tend to gloss over or ignore passages that I don't like as I read.  It's a great reminder that "all scripture is God-breathed and is useful . . ."  His advice is perfect: "When we come to a Scripture passage that is offensive, we should pray and ask, 'God, why have You inspired this text?  What are You trying to teach Your church?  How does this humble me and glorify Christ?'"Cosby addresses some of the "hard passages" that may come to your mind as you read, although not to an extent that will satisfy everyone.  He gives some good examples, but the strength of Uncensored lies in the encouragement to embrace all of the Bible with the attitude that God included even the embarrassing, unsettling, and downright offensive portions of scripture for a good reason.  That reason may not be evident to me, but, like Sproul said, my presumption must be that the problem lies with me, not with God.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

As the father of a high school junior, I have a front-row seat for the pursuit of the college dream.  Like many kids near the top of their high school class, my son is a shoo-in for acceptance to the vast majority of colleges in the U.S.  But when it comes to competitive scholarships and acceptance to that small percentage of elite schools, the odds are not in his favor.  Truth be told, the odds are against anyone getting into some of the elite colleges, with acceptance rates in the single digits.Into that fray enters Aayush Upadhyay, a recent Yale grad who has crunched some numbers and has valuable insights for high school students whose sights are set on the Ivy League. In Behind the Ivy Curtain: A Data-Driven Guide to College Admissions, Upadhyay breaks down admissions data culled from collegeconfidential.com to give applicants some insight into what matters for those seeking to join the ranks of the Ivy League.None of Upadhyay's conclusions will shock the reader.  The higher the rank, the higher the test scores, the better the chances for admission.  He sheds some light on some of the more subjective elements, like extracurriculars (multiple years in one activity tends to beat short tenures in multiple activities), but, again, nothing too surprising.Upadhyay's analysis and conclusions are worth reading for applicants to Ivy League schools.  I was left with the feeling that unless GPA, class rank, and test scores aren't top-notch, the rest of the application will never matter.  Behind the Ivy Curtain feeds into the growing perception of ambitious high school students that admission to an Ivy League school is the only route to success in academics and life.  I hope my son and others like him will realize that while Ivy League schools may provide a great academic experience, there are plenty of other schools around the country where excellent academics, excellent professional development and networking, excellent character building, and excellent life experiences can be found.Thanks to the author for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Way back in the early 80s, after he and his wife split up, Sting, lead singer of The Police, wrote a song called "King of Pain."  His poetic expression of grief, pain, and loneliness became one of his band's biggest hits.When his son was struggling with a serious illness, illustrator Sven Volker heard "King of Pain" and thought it captured the struggles he and his son were experiencing.  Thus was born his book There's a Little Black Spot on the Sun Today, which brings to life Sting's lyrics with minimalistic pictures, using simple arrangements of geometric shapes, perhaps inspired by the cover of the single.There's Little Black Spot is simple and cute, while at the same time emphasizing the poetic power of Sting's lyrics.  It's worth a look for a general audience, and could be a helpful tool for children dealing with grief or pain.  How is your pain like a black spot on the sun?  How is your grief like a hat caught in a treetop?  More than just a cool song and neat graphics, there's an opportunity for reflection and healing in the lyrics and pictures.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Are you experiencing discord, disagreement, unhappiness, or discontent in your marriage?  Whether it's just a little, every now and then, or a permanent state, the reason your marriage is less than it could be is likely because you are believing a lie about yourself, your spouse, or marriage itself.  In Lies Couples Believe: How Living the Truth Transforms Your Marriage, Dr. Chris Thurman breaks down ten common lies that can diminish or even destroy a marriage.Drawing on decades of counseling married couples, Dr. Thurman identifies ten lies that he has seen impact marriages.  No marriage is exempt.  He writes, "every one of us who are married believes all ten of the lies covered in this book.  We believe some of these lies more strongly than others, but we believe all of them to some degree."  I will leave it to you to conclude whether he is correct.  I will say that if you have never believed any of them at any time, you are a better spouse than I!Here are the lies:1. The purpose of marriage is to be happy.2. My spouse can completely meet all my needs.3. My spouse is a bigger mess of a human being than I am.4. I am entitled to my spouse's love.5. Our marital problems are all my spouse's fault.6. My spouse should accept me just the way I am.7. My spouse should be just like me.8. I see my spouse for who my spouse really is.9. My spouse has to earn my forgiveness.10. We can reconcile without repenting.Do you see yourself in some of those?  All of those?  Maybe depending on the day or month, you have bought into some of these lies.  Dr. Thurman's emphasis throughout Lies Couples Believe is fixing your own attitudes.  As tempting as it might be to blame marital unhappiness on your partner, you can see by the lies he lists that step one is acknowledging the lie and changing one's own beliefs and actions.Each chapter (lie) concludes with practical steps to reflect, to apply biblical truth, and to take action.  Like I suspect many readers will do, I initially scanned the list of lies and thought I was exempt.  Surely this book isn't for me. . . . But I have to admit (as will, I suspect, will most readers), most of these hit home.  Newlyweds or old couples, blissfully happy or on the ropes, just about any couple can benefit from reading Lies Couples Believe.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Fran Krause sees peril all around him, real, potential, or purely fantastical.  Based on some of his own fears, as well as some solicited from readers of his blog, he has created a collection of comics encouraging just a little bit more fear.  Deep Dark Fears will ring true with many readers.  Reactions will range from, "I am scared of the same thing!" to "That's ridiculous!" to "I never thought of that--but now I will!"I don't worry so much about ghosts or a parallel world in the mirror or my loved ones being reincarnated as pets, who then see me going to the bathroom.  But I can see how some might!  More compelling are the fears that pretty much all of us can relate to, like being caught publicly doing something on social media, like "Facebook stalking" your old girlfriend.  And who can't relate to being afraid of becoming "an old person who makes kids afraid of getting old"?Krause's humor is on the dark side, funny and thoughtful.  His drawings are the sort that makes you feel like anyone could draw them.  I mean that in the best sense--the art conveys a sense of shared experience.  Deep Dark Fears reminds me of my friend who always seemed to imagine the worst that could happen.  Maybe you've never been afraid of being cut in half by the elevator.  But pick up Deep Dark Fears and you're sure to find some familiar fears--and maybe some new ones, too.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Like many churches, my church has a men's ministry.  Starting with Promise Keepers and influenced by John Eldredge's books, men's ministries seem to have flourished, emphasizing shooting guns, eating wild game, growing beards, and thumping chests.  OK, I'm being a bit facetious; I know much good has come from these ministries.  But, as Nate Pyle writes in Man Enough: How Jesus Redefines Manhood, it may be that men's ministries are missing the mark when they characterize manliness by hunting and fishing, sports, cars, and cooking on the grill.These men movements have been built in reaction to what is viewed as a feminization of the church.  Pyle argues that the emphasis on the "wild man" has "encouraged some men while emasculating and alienating others."  Not all men are into hunting and sports.  In fact, the image many men's ministries promote is more an American ideal than a biblical ideal, the self-made man, the independent hero, the star athlete.Taking Jesus as our model, we see he was not a warrior, a fighter, or a football player.  He was humble, a servant.  We want to emulate him by exhibiting the fruit of the spirit: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, gentleness, self-control, traits that are typically viewed as more feminine.  Further, Paul writes that there is no longer male and female in Christ; both men and women are called to become more like Christ.Pyle in no way diminishes gender differences.  Clearly men and women are different and have different roles.  His task is to remind us that "Jesus showed us that to be fully human is to embrace the masculine and feminine qualities that exist within all of us."  He concludes, "the world doesn't need a manlier man; the world needs a more human man."Pyle writes with compassion while challenging the reader to be more like Christ and not aim to be more like a modern, American image of a "real man." There's nothing wrong with such an image, but it's not the primary ideal to which Christians should aim.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

iRules: What Every Tech-Healthy Family Needs to Know about Selfies, Sexting, Gaming, and Growing Up isn't really a book about technology; it's a book about parenting.  Jannell Burley Hofmann wants parents to recognize that, yes, there's lots of new technology out there, but that parents have a responsibility to keep up with their children, no matter the media.Hofmann encourages parents not only to be aware of what social media and other communications their children have online, but to follow their Facebook, Instragram, Twitter, or other feeds, so they can see what their children and peers are posting.  Further, she asserts that parents' demanding to have access to password-protected sites is acceptable.  Just as we might allow our children to have a lock on their bedroom door, to allow for privacy when needed or wanted, we would insist that we have a key (and that they not lock themselves in with friends of the opposite sex!).A good parent will have a good idea of who their child is hanging out with, what kinds of activities they participate in, and what their hobbies and interests are.  Electronic communications should not change that.  Even as social media, video gaming, and electronic-based relationships become more complex, parents have a responsibility to provide guidance and oversight.  Hofmann's suggestions are reasonable, knowledgable, and welcome.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Every Chuck Palahniuk book I read makes me sadder and sadder about his writing career.  The brilliance and social commentary that made him famous have either run out or gone bad.  Beautiful You may be one of the worst.A billionaire invents a line of, ahem, tools of self-gratification for females.  "A billion husbands are about to be replaced. . . ."  His products take over the world, introducing an experience more addicting than any drug.  Women disappear from public life.  Of course he's being absurd, taking the story to ridiculous extremes.  But he doesn't make a worthwhile point.Speaking of worthwhile, I don't anticipate that any future Palahniuk books will be worth my while.  If any future titles return to the level of Fight Club, feel free to correct me if I'm wrong.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Sometimes you just need a little diversion to break up the work day.  The folks at Hide & Seek have just the thing for you.  Tiny Games for Work is full of ideas for tiny games that you can play at work, many of them while actually working!I like the fact that many of their game suggestions can be played without completely detracting from productivity.  I also like that fact that the games are positive, i.e. not destructive or bullying.  For example, one game challenges employees to attempt to pour on compliments to customers, with extra points for every use of the word "very."  (That's a very, very, very lovely dress you have on!)Many of the games can be played anywhere, not just in the workplace.  If you need ideas for car games or party games, you'll find some fun ones here.  Challenge yourself to use the "random article" feature on Wikipedia, then incorporate the results into your e-mails all day.  Or, challenge yourself to see how many times you can get your chair to spin.  Or, challenge your co-workers to see who can build the tallest tower of Post-It notes.When traffic is slow in your place of business, or the afternoon hours are getting too lazy, brighten up the office with a little distraction.  Challenge the mind with some mental gymnastics. Participate in some team building.  Just be sure not to attract the boss's ire.  Have fun!Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

For more than twenty years, through ten novels, fans of Jan Karon have followed the lives of Father Tim and his friends and family.  In her eleventh Mitford novel, Come Rain or Come Shine, Karon brings the whole gang together to celebrate Dooley and Lace's wedding.I don't know whether Karon intends to close the book on Mitford--she has threatened to before--but Come Rain or Come Shine reads like the end of a series.  Characters from earlier books come together from around the country.  Relationships are healed and restored.  Nostalgic stories are told.  It reminded me of a TV series finale.On the other hand, Dooley and Lace are celebrating all kinds of new beginnings.  Not only are they getting married, Dooley has graduated from veterinary school and opened his clinic.  They have brought a bull to Meadowgate to assist in adding to the herd.  They get a new puppy.  Last but not least, they adopt a little boy, who joins the family on the eve of the wedding.  So even though she seems wrapping up the Mitford series, maybe she's kicking off a new Meadowgate series.Readers who have read some or all of the Mitford books will love Come Rain or Come Shine.  The reunions are sweet and the characters are their usual colorful self.  Those who are not familiar with all the characters may feel a bit lost.  Karon jumps between characters' perspectives frequently.  It was easy for me to get confused about who Karon was talking about.  (This is partly a result of my little bitty brain, but mostly because of the Kindle version, which did not give a visual cue when shifting to a new storyline.  The print versions of Karon's books have a design at each break.)Come Rain or Come Shine has all the elements that Karon's fans love.  She writes with good humor, encouraging wisdom, and genuine faith.  The wedding plans, the wedding, and the potluck reception and dance afterwards offer lots of opportunities for grins and laugh out loud moments.  The reunions and intimate chats offer lots of opportunities for tears and "awww" moments.  Time, and Jan Karon's will, will tell whether we hear more stories from Mitford or Meadowgate.  In the meantime, Karon's fans will love catching up with their old Mitford friends in Come Rain of Come Shine.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Every now and then I'll read a novel that worms its way into my consciousness, quietly asserting itself immediately into my long-term memory, bypassing the spots taken up by more forgettable fiction.  A Free State is one of those memorable novels.  Tom Piazza masterfully captures life in the mid-nineteenth century, bringing to life a southern plantation, the filthy streets of Philadelphia, and a personal, unforgettable portrait of slavery.As the son of a plantation owner and a slave woman, Henry Sims was never a typical field slave.  He learned to read, and played the banjo and sang for the master and his guests.  As he grew up and the life and abuse of the plantation became untenable, he made his escape.  He found his way to the minstrel shows of Philadelphia, at first passing himself as Spanish, but on stage wearing blackface over his lighter, mixed-race skin.In spite of his incognito appearance, his banjo playing renown catches up with him when a slave hunter tracks him down.  In the hunt, the real ugliness and evil of slavery manifests, especially as personified in Tull, the slave hunter.  The stories of Tull's exploits, surely based on actual practices, will turn the stomach of any reader.I thoroughly enjoyed A Free State.  Piazza doesn't make the slave owner out to be pure evil.  (Well, he's pretty evil.)  More notably, he doesn't present Henry as some pure, noble character.  He is very human, and not necessarily a great moral figure, but he is one with whom the reader can have compassion.  Perhaps the most moral figure is the abolitionist senator, but he was also a product of his times, even if more enlightened than most.Piazza captured the views of slavery and slaves from several perspectives.  Even those helping him out wanted him to fit a certain mold: "To the abolitionists, Henry was a representative of a subjugated people, nothing less, and nothing more."  His friend in the minstrel show reflected on the idyllic plantation scene they used as a backdrop on stage: "I knew that Negroes we depicted so fancifully were, in real life, subject to harsh treatment and compulsory labor."  Getting know Henry, he realizes that "I had let myself be deceived, though I should have known better.  And now, from behind that beautiful, pernicious illusion, reality had come snarling."  As mentioned, Tull's attitude of Henry as property or contraband contrasts with the senator's beginning to see Henry as, if not an equal, at least as a peer and companion.Through all of this, Piazza never seems to impose 21st century moral standards on 19th century characters.  I thought Piazza artfully captured the tone of the times.  In fact, I found myself wondering if A Free State was actually written in the 19th century.  Black slavery in the United States seems like ancient history, but the attitudes and history are still relevant today.  This is a novel I highly recommend.Thanks to Edelweiss and the publisher for the complimentary electronic review copy!

Tis the season for football, so how about an inspirational football movie?  In a few weeks Woodlawn will be released, bringing to the big screen the story of an Alabama high school football team in the 1970s.  In case the place and date don't click with you, this is at the time of school desegregation in one of the most racially divided parts of the country.  Woodlawn follows the desegregation of Woodlawn High School and the response of the football team.The Woodlawn football coach, Tandy Gerelds, didn't set out to be a trailblazer or revolutionary.
