He ends his account in 1960.I found myself in the role of the "Greek chorus," that is, knowing how the drama would turn out. For example, in reading about Robert Schuman, and how he was instrumental in creating the European Coal and Steel Community that would ultimately lead to the Euros I have held in my hand. The war in Algeria was not concluded upon publication, and now I have a much better personal awareness of its denouement. Likewise, the length of time to the denouement not only of Portugal's colonies, but communism itself.As a final note, I found a list of 60 or so great books that was given to me by that college professor in my junior year. I've managed to read about half of them so far... and if I really hurry, who knows if I can break three-quarters?  As for Hughes truly brilliant history, 6-stars.(Note: of the various versions listed at Amazon, mine is the one published in 1961, with 502 pages of text.)

... revealed.Ali Kazuyoshi Nomachi is an outstanding Japanese photographer who converted to Islam. Seyyed Hossein Nasr is Iranian-born, and a Professor of Islamic Studies at George Washington University when this book was first published in 1997. They had "access," which should probably be written in capital letters. You have to have ACCESS to take aerial photographs in Saudi Arabia, and they are most impressive. The "access" came from the Saudi Royal family, in the personages of the governors of Mecca and Medina. The other essential piece of this collaborative effort is the publisher, "Aperture," perhaps THE publisher of photographic books, with my copies of their books on W. Eugene Smith, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Paul Strand, et al., readily coming to mind. The result of this collaboration is a very high quality, and in many ways unique book, that can be appreciated by Muslims and non-Muslims alike.Dr. Nasr commences with a historical explanation of the relevance of the region, starting with Adam and Eve, through Abraham, and then the origins of Islam, with the Prophet Mohammed. I have an overall familiarity with the story, and found the summary useful. The heart of the book, of course, is the photographs. Nomachi has a keen eye, and brings out the sheer diversity of those who consider themselves Muslims, and live over that vast swath of earth from Mauritania to Indonesia. For example, there are some colorfully dressed African women, probably from Nigeria, and other more uniformly dressed women from Indonesia. In another picture, Nomachi brings out the fact that the Muslim men and women from South Africa pray in a single straight line, which is not the norm. Although somewhat understated, some of the problems of the pilgrimage are indicated, including heat stroke and public health problems related to contagious diseases. And the ritual of stoning the pillars (Jumarat) that represent the devil is historically dangerous, due to crowding and stampeding. The only issue I found confusing is when Nomachi was actually there:  during the "Haj," or during Ramadan, which is roughly two and a half months earlier, or both?The photographer grants "equal time" to Medina, the second holiest city. I have seen numerous quality pictures related to Mecca and the Haj; far less so for Medina. The aerial photograph of the Prophet's Mosque at sunset, with the mountains of the Hijaz is most impressive. All religions have their charlatans and "believers" who are only going through the motions. Nomachi had a knack for capturing those individuals whose belief seems most genuine. For many, this would be the highlight of their life. The last 10% of the book is composed of pictures from other areas of Saudi Arabia. I found the sunset pictures around the oasis of al-Ula stunning.I lived in Saudi Arabia for 20 years, and traveled extensively throughout the country. As a non-Muslim I was not permitted to go to these cities. That issue is the source for a couple one-star reviews of this book. One even charged that the cities are "racist," which is irrefutably belied by these pictures. The exclusion is based on one's professed faith. If anyone really felt a visit was essential, they could always become Muslim, as the photographer did. Though I would have liked to have seen these cities in person, I ultimately decided that the exclusion is OK, since most religions have rules regulating those outside the in-group, including the Indian pueblos of New Mexico.As a final point, this was a wonderful "impulse" purchase. Amazon, in their "wisdom," offered me the book based on my other purchases, for four bucks, and some change. As I post this, it is no longer available at that price. The luck of the draw... or, hum is Amazon moving towards omniscient status? Anyhow, I am quite pleased with my 5-star purchase.

Lies, deceit, treachery, poison, knives in the night, justified paranoia, guilt, revenge... it is all there, and more, in this classic story of how the lust for power can literally drive people crazy. It can also kill them. I first read this play of William Shakespeare as a high school reading assignment, the way the vast majority of people do.  Lo these many years later, Ive undertaken a project of re-reading a lot of those H.S. reading assignments, including the plays of Shakespeare, in part to determine how much I missed the first time around, which, in two short words is normally: a lot.The play is set in Scotland. The king is Duncan. His not faithful lord, called thane in Scotland at the time, is Macbeth. And he has a wife who has become a symbol of all wives who relentlessly push their husbands to be successful, and who is normally addressed with the misnomer of Lady. (Thats no lady, thats my wife...but I digress). As Cliff Notes will tell you, Duncan is murdered in his sleep, with those proverbial long knives. Macbeth skillfully diverts the blame to his body guards, who are conveniently also killed (a death man tells no tales) while also casting suspicion on Duncans sons, who have fled for their lives to further shores. How many times, throughout all the cultures and civilizations of the world, has this scenario basically unfolded?Throughout many of his plays Shakespeare utilizes elements from the ancient Greek plays, such as prophecy and a chorus that predicts future events, often esoterically. In this play, Shakespeare uses three witches around a cauldron, stirring, and if there is one line that most people remember from the play, it is the first line of their chorus:  Double, double, toil and trouble.A fellow Amazon reviewer noted a quip that Shakespeares plays are simply quotes strung together, a humorous way of noting that many portions of the play have entered the popular, albeit intellectual portion, of our culture. For example, after the first Iraq War (yeah, I know, it is hard to say which one was the first one now), the cover to the The Economist featured the line: When the hurlyburlys done.  My first high school reading failed me, and I had no idea this was a reference to a line in Macbeths opening scene, with the second line being: When the battles lost and won. And is that battle lost or won?  Proving the enduring relevance of Shakespeare in so many settings, later in the same scene he writes: Her husbands to Aleppo gone, master o the Tiger. I havent seen The Economist use that line to refer to its British citizens going to fight for ISIS.Another quote that I remembered, and life experience has proven to be so true: Sleep that knits up the raveld sleeve of care. Hum. Another quote that life experience proves true: Lechery, sir, it provokes and unprovokes: it provokes the desire, but it takes away the performance. Therefore much drink may be said to be an equivocator with lechery: it makes him, and it mars him... makes him stand to and not stand to...  Finally, so that I literally dont quote the entire play, another classic scene that personally resonated, due to my travels, was Lady Macbeths efforts to wash the blood off her hands, and she proclaims: All the perfume of Arabia will not sweeten this little hand.Another excellent, still so relevant play of Shakespeare, that needs to read more than twice. 5-stars, plus.

Alexandre Yersin.He was born a Swiss national in 1863. His father died when he was young. His mother raised him, and the letters that he conscientiously wrote her throughout her life provided a valuable source for reconstructing his fascinating life. He was fluent in German and French. His initial medical training was Germany, in the town of Marburg. But it was ultimately France that would attract him, decisively, and he joined the "band of Pasteur." These were a group of gifted "disciples" who studied under Louis Pasteur, who established the field of microbiology, and developed immunizations against various diseases, notably rabies.It was "La Belle Epoque." Much scientific progress was being made on many fronts, with notable improvements on the human condition.  Yersin made his "mark" early, contributing to the understanding of diphtheria. Scientifically, he is most remembered as "Yersinia pestis." During an outbreak of the plague - "the Black Death" of the Middle Ages - in Hong Kong, he was the first to identify the bacterium that causes the plague, which led to the immunizations against it.He was a polymath, and had the wanderlust. His "hero" was Livingstone, a fellow physician best known for his explorations in Africa. Before it was even known officially as "Indochine," Yersin hired on as a ship's physician, and went to what we still call the Far East. For a couple of years, he was a regular on the "Saigon-Manila" run. He would eventually stake out his claim to a bit of earth (which he kept constantly expanding!) in Nha Trang, in modern day Vietnam. Like numerous others, the mountains of the Annamite Cordillera "called to him."  The achievement that I envy the most is that one day he left his home of the "wooden shack" in Nha Trang, and walked all the way across the Cordillera to the Mekong, and beyond, to Phnom Penh, in present-day Cambodia. In the process, he passed an area he realized would make an excellent "hill-station," where Da Lat would ultimately be founded, through his vision (and political contacts).Patrick Deville tells the story of Yersin so well. He won the "Prix Femina" in 2012 for his efforts. He smoothly moves back and forth across time, with a key event being when he left France for the last time, in May, 1940. Deville also had to master a great deal of scientific detail (but does not convey enough to make the reader's eyes glaze over). He repeats some common themes (like how Yersin hated the "filth" of the political world, and usually stood aloof), with the appropriate frequency. Deville weaves into his story the ironies a long life can provide. Consider: It was Hitler and Goering's love of art that spared the Bourget airfield from bombing (since this is where Hitler would land for his "lighting tour" of Paris, in June, 1940). And Yersin would be on the last French plane that left that airfield in May, 1940... making the long journey back to his beloved "empire within an empire," Nha Trang, and his extended agricultural estate, to die, at the age of 80, while it was under Japanese occupation, in 1943.I've read my share of books on Vietnam, and some have certainly been a "trodden path." Few books have provided so much sheer NEW information to me. In addition to the above, Deville relates Yersin's relationship with a host of individuals, like Paul Doumer, who, for Americans, was most famous for lending his name to a bridge in Hanoi we were trying to bomb during "our" war there. Doumer was "the orphan of Aurillac" who helped found Da Lat, and would eventually be gunned down by an assassin in France, in the 1930's. Yersin also knew Louis Ferdinand Celine, another physician who was in the "band of Pasteur."  Yersin would become rich, and was known as the king of rubber and quinine, for the production from the trees of his "little empire," that he thrust into the hills above Nha Trang.Deville's excellent book resonated on so many points. For four months the aforementioned Annamite Cordillera called to me, and said "come," walk through me, as Tim O'Brien captured in Going After Cacciato [Paperback] [1999] (Author) Tim O'Brien. Around 200 km from Nha Trang I was once a small cog in the process that Yersin initiated, and over the course of a year gave 200-300 immunizations for the plague and cholera, still remembering the dosages (.2cc and .5cc). And during a war there is that grave fear of communications lost - that helicopter that went down, et al.; in Yersin's day it was the loss of ships to German submarines, and he kept a log of them, with the first being "La Ville de la Ciotat." And there was Yersin, at the very end, studying Latin and Greek.Deville's book proves to be an excellent recommendation that should be shared with friends who still seek to know what is around the next curve in the road, at any age. 5-stars, plus.

There isn't anyone to replace you."It has been almost a decade since Hurricane Katrina destroyed large portions of New Orleans while killing almost 2,000 people there and along other portions of the Gulf Coast. The emergency response of the concerned governmental agencies and leadership was famously inadequate. A large portion of the population of New Orleans was displaced, many permanently, to other cities. Kaycee Eckhardt is a native of New Orleans, was teaching in Japan when the hurricane struck, and decided to be part of the effort to restore the much needed educational services to the students (optimistically called "scholars") of her hometown. On her first day of work, her supervisor admonished her with the subject quote, since her two immediate predecessors had quit after very brief stints on the job. And the reader will find out why.I'm not an education "professional." Most of the blurbs at Amazon are from people in the field. My interest in the book (and my way there, more of which later) are more abstract. Education, like agricultural and health care policy, is an important aspect of our society. Eckhardt provides a vivid report from the proverbial "trenches" of "trying to make a difference" and this book needs to be read by far more "generalists."Consider her first year, trying to help revive one of the closed public schools. Students are far below grade level, and generally quite rebellious. Some die, at times by a bullet. Eckhardt's bike is trashed, her purse stolen twice, and she receives very real death threats, all of which she relates in an amazingly low-key matter-of-fact manner. A fellow teacher, in her "stiletto heels" is having an affair with the captain of the football team. The "faculty room" is described as: "There are three sofas, 50 odd-cardboard boxes filled with brand new textbooks too expensive to distribute for use, a filthy microwave, two wheezing refrigerators and, when many of the teachers were present together, conversations so poisonous that carbon monoxide would be preferable...the spectres of administration, rules, obstacles, and children were hung like verbal piatas, and bashed, bashed, bashed...I brought cold lunches and ate them, lukewarm, from my desk drawer, preferring a possible bacteria attack to facing this frigid venom." In the midst of all this there are the heart-breaking tales of what students face, for example, Robyn, who, at the age of 12, when Katrina hit, pushed her diabetic grandmother for help, and watched her die. At 16, she is pregnant, and decides to have the baby in her grandmother's honor, or, as she says: "Miss, Eckhardt, you're cool and all, but we gonna see this differently.""Sci Academy" is a charter school (and I am so much of a generalist, I am still "agnostic" as to if charter schools are the "answer.") The author signed on at the beginning, and would ultimately spend four years there, both in leadership roles and as a teacher. And she describes education policy, team building, discipline, the success of raising reading levels three grades in one year. There remain the numerous heart-breaks, like a student who was so perceptive in analyzing stories, yet would place a gun in his mouth at 16.Eckhardt gave it her all for four years, working the 70-80 hours a week, being deeply emotionally involved with her mission and her students. The adrenalin can only last so long, and she did indeed have to "fold" to preserve the other aspects of her life. And I kept thinking what an awful shame that the work cannot be more evenly distributed, since there are so very many (like the telemarketer who just called me) who have no meaningful work at all. The mission of the school is for each "scholar" to be able to go to college. The school achieved some media prominence, and even obtained a million dollar award from Oprah Winfrey. But the author is wise enough to recognize, in a society in which graduates of Ivy League schools can still wind up being "au pairs" that college can also be a trap, particularly in New Orleans which is a city geared to the hospitality industry that values minimum wage workers "...a city dependent on hospitality janitors, dishwashers, short-order cooks."In conclusion, two tales of sweet serendipity. Eckhardt describes herself as being a bit rebellious in school, and was failing French in college, when the student counselor, during the allocated 15 minutes a quarter of talk, sarcastically suggested she study Japanese instead, which is how she got to Japan. Meanwhile, I swim my laps at the local pool. When leaving one day, I noticed that one of the new lifeguards was reading The Catcher in the Rye, one of the coming-of-age books of my youth. Surely, "kids nowadays" didn't still read it. But in the case of Kaycee's sister, Simone, mentioned in the book as "the Lobo," at least "one kid" still did... and she is the one who told me about the "sandcastles" that were / are being constructed after Katrina. And I am ever so grateful for the recommendation. 6-stars for this essential read.

The Gaiam Storm fitness mat, made in China, measures 24W x 68L x 15mm, weighs 2lb 10oz / 1210g, and comes with a carrying strap.  The fitness mat has non-slip ridges for traction and plenty of firm support for comfort.  The bottom of the mat is smooth, but works well on solid surfaces.Due to the thickness, I cant roll up this fitness mat and transport it in my yoga bag, or strap it to the side of my yoga backpack.  The rolled up diameter is about 8 inches.  Fortunately the lightweight mat comes with a carrying strap and isnt a big deal to transport.The thickness provides comfortable use.  I could do yoga poses while barefoot and not worry about slipping from either the mat on the floor or my feet on the mat.  The mat is firm enough to for ab exercises while remaining comfortable and eliminating hard spots.If a typical yoga mat doesnt seem padded enough, the Gaiam Storm fitness mat may just be the alternative youre looking for.  This lightweight mat is comfortable, effective, and worth your consideration.PROS:Comes with carry strapFirm supportComfortableLightweightAmple sizeLifetime guaranteeCONS:Bulky for transport

The highlighted feature of the Ferplast mini tape retractable dog lead, made in Ukraine, is the ability to change the cover to fit your taste.  Otherwise this retractable lead is designed similarly to all the others on the market.  The top button locks the lead or releases it.  Locking the lead can be done momentarily by pressing the soft touch button, or by locking it into place.Changing the covers is simple enough, just pop one off and place the new one on.  The lead comes with a basic white cover, and can be replaced with something like wood slat, NY City skyline, paint splats, or more.  Each replacement cover runs from about $13 to $16.The retractable dog lead is simple and comfortable to use.  The lead expands and retracts smoothly, and the lock is effective.  The position of the lock button feels natural as well.  This retractable dog lead will work well for your 55 lb or less dog.The Ferplast mini tape retractable dog lead is effective as a dog lead and is comfortable to use.  The ability to change covers seems silly and unnecessary to me, but maybe its appealing to others.  From my perspective it just increases the price of a tool which is currently priced on the higher end.  Id rather purchase the lead with the cover I like and move on.  If changing covers appeals to you, this retractable dog lead will surely be good purchase.PROS:Comfortable gripSmooth lead retractionSimple to useReplaceable coverCONS:Not currently a good value

Due to remodeling a house, I have a DeWalt DC720KA Heavy-Duty Cordless 18-Volt Compact Drill/Driver and the [[ASIN:B0052TZB76 Bosch DDH181-01 18V Brute Tough Drill Driver.  Both are excellent cordless drills which continue to get use to this day.The Metabo 18V LT Quick Drill/Driver 2.0Ah, made in China, comes with an air cooled battery charger, 2 18v 2.0 Ah lithium-ion batteries, a users guide, and a durable plastic carrying case.  The drill driver, weighing 2 lb 13 oz, features 20 torque settings, quick drill chuck change system, 531 maximum torque, and a durable ergonomic body.Compared to the DeWalt DC720KA and Bosch DDH181, the Metabo BS18 Quick is lighter weight, and more compact.  All three drills have basically the same basic features, although max torque is lower on the Metabo.  For simple DIY jobs around the house, all three drills will get the job done.Charging the batteries on all three drills is the same process.  However the Metabo charger has an internal cooling fan which runs while charging and can be heard.  The other chargers are silent.  The Bosch battery charger recharges a battery in 30 minutes while the Metabo takes 45 minutes to reach a full charge. The Metabo batteries include a charge level status button, which are not found on the other drills batteries.As an active DYIer, the Metabo BS18 Quick is more than powerful enough to get my to-do list done.  The significantly lighter weight feels better and is less fatiguing.  If you're looking for a durable Drill Driver to complete projects around the house, the Metabo BS18 Quick is a great option to consider.PROS:Weight balanced ergonomic design531 lb torqueDurable housingLong lasting batteries with a 45 minute charge3 year warrantyCONS:Noisy charger

The iLuv Collision wireless Bluetooth portable speaker, made in China, comes with the speaker, a carabineer, and a USB to micro-USB cable.  The 1800mAh rechargeable battery lasts up to 8 hours of play time.  The speaker is water resistant, shock and dust proof, and ready for use in the great outdoors.Ive tried water resistant Bluetooth speakers in the past, and they have all have had a muffled sound to them.  The iLuv Collision wireless Bluetooth portable speaker doesnt sound like the others.  The sound is pleasing to the ear, doesnt falter at full volume, and gets quite loud for its small size.The rechargeable battery lasts for about 8 hours.  There doesnt seem to be an advanced warning when the battery is drained; I heard a tone, then the speaker shut off.  I turned the speaker on when this first happened, and the process repeated.  Then I plugged the speaker in and the battery indicator shown red and normal play was resumed.  Advanced warning is common on my other wireless speakers, and would be beneficial in the iLuv Collision too.The black rubber buttons on the top of the speaker have black raised symbols to indicate what the buttons do.  They are simple to use and are visible in well lighted areas.  In dim environments, the buttons are extremely difficult to read.  A low contrast alternate color on the raised symbols would be beneficial while maintaining the speakers minimalist appearance.This speaker was provided to me at a significant discount in exchange for an honest review, however I would gladly purchase the Collusion at regular price for use around the pool or while camping.  If youre looking for a water resistant speaker for use outdoors or in questionable environments, the iLuv Collusion wireless Bluetooth speaker is a great sounding option.PROS:Hands-free callingWater resistantShock proof8 hour battery life90 day limited warranty, 1 year partsCONS:No early battery low indicatorButtons difficult to read in low light environments

Incredibly Decadent Desserts: Over 100 Divine Treats with 300 Calories or Less By Deb Wise contains over 100 recipes with 300 calories or less per serving.  The book is broken down into seven chapters, plus nutritional information, metric equivalents, and the index.  The book begins with the informational Introduction and The Basics chapters before recipes are provided in the The Cake Walk, Upper Crust, Small Bites, Old School, Frozen And Chilled, and Labors Of Love chapters. Each recipe includes a tantalizing color photo, and on many a sidebar with technique tips, ingredient details, or helpful instructions.  Between recipes, there may be an expanded tip such as My Top 5 Tips For Making Merengue or My Top 5 Tips For Creating The Best Texture.While I like desserts, I dont get to enjoy them very often.  I am currently training to compete in a mens physique competition.  Lighter dessert recipes for the occasional cheat or when bulking is a benefit.  I would prefer some high protein options.  Additionally, I try to stick to natural ingredients.  Cool Whip is a common ingredient, I dont eat this fake food and find the thought of eating it revolting.  However Deb makes a solid case for her use in The Basics chapter.  Whipped cream is high calorie and Cool Whip is a low calorie replacement that make low calorie alternatives possible.There are several recipes I want to try and adapt for my current diet.  I am allowed to have a dessert each night as my final meal.  Ive eaten lots of Greek yogurt and berries over the last 18 months.  Ive been told I can have high protein pudding, so Im going to try adapting the rice pudding and panna cotta recipes and see if they work using my protein powder as an ingredient if my coach approves of the recipe.If youre looking to reduce caloric intake and dont want to give up on desserts entirely, Deb Wises Incredibly Decadent Desserts will help bridge your dietary goals with your desires.  The recipes contained in this cookbook are enticing and mouthwatering, and sure to be a hit.PROS:Tantalizing color photosEasy to follow instructionsTips and techniques found throughoutCONS:No recipes based on high protein diets

The Kody double dish, made in China, is made of two nesting melamine bowls.  The top oval shaped bowl measures 4.75 x 6 inches, 1.25 inches deep, and hold about 10 ounces of water.  The bottom bowl holds about 16 ounces and is about 1.5 inches deep with sides raised another 1.25 inches.  The bowls can be used separately, or nested.When nested, the top bowl can hold cherries, nuts, or something of the sort where there is waste from eating.  The uneaten items go in the top bowl, while the pits, stems, or shells are discarded in the bottom.The Kody double bowl set is kinda a novelty.  Its really too small for a party, and would work for two to three people while watching TV.  The bowls are not meant for use in the microwave either, although the type of foods this set is meant for dont usually get microwaved.  For the bowls purpose, it works well.If you enjoy snacking on cherries or pistachios, The Kody double bowl will keep the waste contained.  I was given this set to test and review, however I would have no reservation against purchasing a set for myself or as a gift.  Give this double bowl set a try.PROS:Good looking nested bowlsKeep shells, pits, and stems containedBowls can be used separatelyAttractive modern appearanceCONS:Not microwave safe

The Stacy Adams Men's cognac Stratford slip-on loafer is a reddish brown color with a buckle strap on top.  The shoe is made in China with leather uppers and manmade materials.  The soles do not have any grip, except for the back half of the heel, and the interior bottom has memory foam cushioning.When I opened the box, I noticed the loafers had a strong chemical scent.  I dismissed the odor for being new shoes, and immediately tried them on.  I have a long somewhat narrow foot, so finding a good fitting pair of dress shoes can difficult.  These loafers fit my foot length wise, but feel too big since they are a little wider than I need.  The buckled strap doesnt adjust to tighten the fit either, the only option is to loosen the strap by one hole.  The sizing issue is workable though, I just wear thicker cotton dress socks to help fill the space.  However, I would prefer a better fitting narrow version.I decided to wear the loafers to work the next day.  They were comfortable, I had no problems remaining upright, and I even received a few compliments.  I kept thinking I smelt gas while sitting in my cube, as did a few of my coworkers in surrounding cubes.  They were commenting on the odor, and postulated the buildings heaters were probably started up for the first time.  Later when I got into my car to drive home, I drove a few blocks before the scent of gas hit me.  Thats when I realized the scent was coming from the loafers.  The scent has dissipated over several days, but the loafers still have an odor.If youre looking for a good looking pair of shoes, the Stacy Adams Men's cognac Stratford slip-on loafer may be a good option to consider.  However the scent is overwhelming and may be a deal breaker.  The scent does dissipate in time, and may be worth the hassle of defuming before wearing.  If it werent for the odor, I would gladly consider purchasing these loafers for myself.PROS:Looks sharpCONS:Obnoxious scentNo grip on soles

The Cakes Athirst Hilarity unauthorized Cards Against Humanity expansion packs, printed in China on premium casino-quality linen cards.  Each of the four expansion packs contains 80 white cards and 30 black cards.  Each card has Cakes Athirst Hilarity printed on one side, and a question or answer plus a yellow volume indicator on the other.The deck packaging indicates not to purchase the expansion pack without first obtaining the original Cards Against Humanity game.  The only necessary part of the original game is understanding game play.  Being an expansion pack, there isnt any instructions.  Otherwise the original game isnt really necessary.  Id still suggest having the original game, as there simply isnt enough cards in an expansion pack for a fun game.The Cakes Athirst Hilarity cards are printed on better quality stock than the original deck.  The original cards are basic paper cards, while Cakes Athirst Hilarity cards are linen which should last longer.  The fonts on both cards are similar, although the Cakes Athirst Hilarity cards use a smaller font size.  Plus both sets use a crass sense of humor, although the Cakes Athirst Hilarity cards seem edgier, more current, and just as disturbingly fun.Cards Against Humanity expansion packs are a necessity to keeping the game fresh.  The Cakes Athirst Hilarity cards achieve the same purpose and fit well with the original game.  I received this expansion pack as part of a four volume set in exchange for an honest review, although I would have no problem purchasing them.  The Cakes Athirst Hilarity expansion packs, along with the quality of the cards, are a worthy purchase and quite possibly a better value.PROS:High quality linen cardsCrass, edgier, and more currentFun, but oh so wrongCONS:None I could find

The E-PRANCE Heavy Duty Stainless-Steel Manual Lemon/Lime Juicer weighs 14.4 ounces or 405 grams and has a 2 3/4 inch diameter bowl.  Stainless steel makes the juicer heavier than aluminum versions, however will not corrode and is dishwasher safe.To use, I roll lemons on the counter under my palm to loosen the juices, then cut them in half.  Once cut the lemon is placed with the cut end facing into the bowl.  Pressing the lemon required using both hands until the hollow handles got close enough for one handed squeezing.  The process may sound difficult, however it was quite simple to accomplish.  Once squeezed, I opened the squeezer, removed the lemon half, and repeated the process for the other half.I previously reviewed a similar silicon handled lemon juicer.  This other juicer has a larger bowl, the pieces dont wiggle from side to side.  The E-Prance lemon juicer doesnt have silicon handle covers, a smaller bowl, and the pieces have more side to side movement.  These differences dont affect performance, both lemon juicers are effective.I received this juicer in exchange for an honest review.  If I were in the market for a hand juicer, I would purchase the silicon handled lemon juicer since the current prices are similar.  However if there were a pricing incentive, I would have no problem purchasing E-Prances lemon juicer.  If youre looking for a quality stainless steel lemon/lime squeezer, look for the best value.  If it turns out to be the E-Prance lemon juicer, you will be making a good purchase.PROS:Simple to operateMade from 316 stainless steelEasy to cleanCONS:Some side to side movement

The WINOMO wall mounted broom/mop rack with four positions and five hooks, made in China, hangs on the wall using the two provided anchored screws.  Once hung, cleaning tools such as mops and brooms can be stored using the quick grip position or a hook.There are basic mounting instructions on the box; however they dont indicate what size drill bit to use for the pilot hole.  I apparently went too big, as the anchor fell behind the wall as I was attempting to the rack into place.  I went to the local home improvement store and bought a $1.69 bag of flanged pop-toggle anchors with screws to use instead.  This style of anchor worked with the supplied flathead screws, is far more forgiving without adding significant expense, and should be supplied.Once the wall mounted broom/mop rack was installed, I began organizing hanging our floor cleaning tools.  Each item went into place easily; however it felt somewhat like completing a puzzle.  The positions and hooks can slide a bit, but cannot be reconfigured.  I have a Gladiator wall system in the garage which can be configured as needed, although the WINOMO wall mounted broom/mop rack is more economically priced.Even though I received the WINOMO wall mounted broom/mop rack in exchange for an honest review, I would gladly purchase one.  Installing was simple, and the rack effectively organizes my floor cleaning tools.  If you are wanting to do the same, the WINOMO wall mounted broom/mop rack is a good economical choice.PROS:Simple to installEconomical priceOrganizes floor cleaning toolsGets mops and brooms off the floorCONS:Could include better instructions/anchorsCannot be configured

Ive been taking the premium tribulus terrestris dietary supplement, made in the USA by Peak Performance Nutrition, on and off for a couple months.  This product, provided in exchange for an honest review, is designed to promote testosterone production, plus boost libido and stamina.While I recommend consistency with nutritional products, my inconsistent use has helped me to see the difference between taking this supplement and not.  I take one 1000mg capsule a day with 10 oz. water while eating breakfast.  I dont notice any immediate effect from taking the capsule.It would be easy to question whether this product does anything at all.  I cant really tell if my testosterone production has increased, and as an active person Im not even sure I get a stamina or libido boost.  However, when I take the premium tribulus terrestris supplement, I consistently wake with a raging firm stiffy.  Its not that I dont get wood, but as a snooze bar sleeper, the effect has often dissipated before I am fully awake and aware.Ive heard tribulus has a positive effect on some people, while others it may do nothing.  Ive seen no adverse side effects from taking the premium tribulus terrestris supplement.  It seems to benefit me, while I cant offer quantifiable evidence.  If you want/need a testosterone boost, give the premium tribulus terrestris supplement a try.PROS:Promote testosterone productionBoosts libido and staminaCONS:Difficult to prove effects

The Aroma AWK-165DI glass and stainless digital kettle with tea infuser, made in China, comes with the glass kettle, stainless steel tea infuser, corded base, and instruction manual.  The kettle heats up to 7 cups or 1.7 liters room temperature water in 6 minutes 40 seconds.  While heating, a blue LED light shines around the bottom edge of the glass into the water.  The base includes a 30 inch cord which can be wrapped up underneath to eliminate excess.  An easily removable water filter rests at the inside of the drip free spout.The stainless steel tea infuser is a 5 inch tall thin walled fine meshed container.  Once the water is of the correct temperature, press the lid button to open, slip the filled tea infuser into place, and let steep for the recommended amount of time.  With water at the maximum level, only a couple inches of the tea infuser is submerged; plan on making a kettle of tea and not one or two cups.The warming feature brings cold water up to the desired temperature ranging from 105 and increasing in 10 degree intervals up to 195.  We occasionally purchase loose tea from Teavana, where recommended temperatures and times are provided.  Rooibos, mate, and herbal teas require 5-6 minutes at 208, a temperature without a setting.  The best one can do is boil and add the tea once the temp drops enough.  The kettle isnt insulated, so the temp may drop over the required steeping time.  The remaining teas are either at 175 or 195 degrees, which works with the kettles temperature settings.I have used water kettles for years, as they are a convenient way to have boiled water for tea, oatmeal, or anything else.  This is the first kettle Ive used with temperature controls.  When it comes to enjoying a cup of good tea, getting the temperature right is a big deal.  The Aroma AWK-165DI glass and stainless digital kettle is missing a key warming temperature, however adds far more control than Ive had in the past.  This kettle has already replaced my older one.  If youre looking for a reasonably priced digital kettle, the Aroma AWK-165DI glass and stainless digital kettle is a good option to consider.PROS:Digital temperature controlsKeep warm functionNo exposed heating elements5 year limited warrantyCONS:No warming setting for 208 degrees

The Gladiator GAGP32G2WY garage wall gear kit, made in China, comes with a 32 GearTrack channel, tool hook, utility hook, scoop hook, small item bin, two J hooks, two end caps, and six color matched screws.Installation requires a drill, tape measure, stud finder, and a level.  I considered installing this wall starter pack in the garage and in pantry to organize floor cleaning tools.  Once identifying the spot for this organizer, I cleared the area of clutter, identified and marked the studs, installed a screw at the top left, leveled the GearTrack, continued installing two screws into each stud, attached the accessory pieces, and organized my stuff.  Even though I needed to find a new place for a few items, it all went together quickly and resulted in an organized section of the garage.The GearTrack and all the pieces appear to be well constructed, sturdy, and is effective at garage organization.  The hooks held all my stuff with ease and the entire system showed no signs of being overwhelmed.  Additionally, getting my stuff of the floor helps me maintain a cleaner garage floor.  Im glad to have this wall starter pack installed and am now considering other pieces.If youre not sure the Gladiator system is for you, start with this inexpensive and effective set.  The Gladiator GAGP32G2WY garage wall gear kit is a great way to get started on an organized garage.PROS:Quick and easy to installAttachments can be repositioned as neededOrganizes your stuff10 year warranty on GearTrackLifetime warranty on hooksCONS:Can make garage organization an addiction

The Pathfinder Wrath of the Righteous adventure card game base set can be played by 1-4 players over 13.  Character card sets may be added for 5-6 player games.  Everything needed is provided in the base set, plus the first adventure deck is included.  Although, accessories such as the adventure mat, character mats, card sleeves, and the pro dual deck box can be purchased.The base set includes dice, cards, organizer, instructions, and tokens, plus the first of six adventure decks.  The cards and tokens are of good quality and the organizer effectively organized and assists game play.  The organizer even includes a storage location for developed characters to keep everything ready for the next game night.  All in all, the base set is well thought out.The box indicates a game can be played in about 90 minutes.  Perhaps a group of individuals familiar with the game can do so, but that wasnt our experience.  Four of us, one familiar with Pathfinder games, sat at the table and started preparing the board.  This involved answering questions, shuffling decks, arranging cards on the table, choosing characters, etc.  90 minutes later, we were ready to start playing.After choosing who went first, we began game play.  Our board included six locations which we closed one by one.  Ive played D&D, this game has a similar approach, players develop their characters, assist others in their team, and progress on a journey.  Although a good dungeon master can weave an interesting story into game play.  With this card game, play seemed more mechanical and less story bound.  I can see where the game would be more fun once one knew the intricacies of game play though. After playing for a couple hours, I felt like this game was just dragging on.  Our first game lasted for 3.5 hours.The character cards are basically a single use item.  There are boxes to check when attributes improve.  Once checked, these cards are no longer useful for the next player.  Using a sleeve makes sense so the character cards can be used multiple times.I can see the appeal to the Pathfinder Wrath of the Righteous adventure card game.  Our experience is based on inexperienced players.  Im certain experienced players can get through adventures with more efficiency and better understanding.  Everything is provided to get the first game started, and five additional adventure deck can be purchased to expand the campaign.Experienced Pathfinder adventure card game players will likely enjoy the Wrath of the Righteous base set.  New players will experience a steep learning curve unless they can find experienced players to interact with.  Otherwise expect to spend time learning game play and referring to the instructions often.  No matter which group you belong to, this game is worth considering an investment of time and money.PROS:Organized game playExpandableQuality and well thought out base setCONS:Mechanical game playSingle use character cards

Geared Beard beard oil, made with all natural ingredients, tames and softens your bear.  The bottle includes a dropper for drawing and measuring the oil in preparation for application.  I simply place the beard oil in my fingers, then spread it into my freshly showered and dried beard. As a result, my beard appears properly groomed and is less itchy for the day.Generally I dont like products with scents.  Geared Beard beard oil doesnt add fragrance although some of the ingredients have noticeable scents.  The aroma of the oil is strong, and the eucalyptus is obvious when smelling from the bottle.  Other ingredients add to the scent, such as peppermint, lemon, and cardamom as well.  However I dont notice the scent after spreading the beard oil onto my beard.Ive used beard oil for years, primarily to make growing a beard more comfortable.  Geared Beard beard oil not only makes growing a beard comfortable, but also helps keep it tamed.  If youre looking for a good beard oil/balm, Geared Beard beard oil is worth considering.PROS:Keeps beard healthy, manageable, and comfortableAll natural ingredients100% money-back guaranteeCONS:Fragrant ingredients

The Black & Decker D3030 Allure iron, made in China, has a stainless steel soleplate, adjustable temperature and steam, plus auto shut off.  Advanced technology provides 30% more steam than competing models, plus the Allure has an auto-clean system and three way auto shut off.I have an older Black & Decker PROfinish 700 iron, it looks dated compared to the Allure.  However, functionally they are close to the same.  They both have adjustable steam, steam and spray buttons, and stainless steel soleplate.  The Allure D3030 with its modern appearance has an improved water intake, two additional steam settings, and two fewer temperature settings.The Allure D3030 is well balanced and glides across the fabric being ironed.  The only thing I dont like is the temperature dial being positioned below the handle.  The light grey numbers on a darker grey dial is difficult for me to see and having the handle hinder the view doesnt help.Our iron is not a commonly used appliance in our house, so the old iron would probably serve its purpose for years to come.  However, the Allure D3030 iron is a suitable upgrade.  If youre looking for a good quality iron, the Black & Decker Allure D3030 iron is worth considering.PROS:Dynamic steam technologyAuto-clean systemAuto shut-off2 year limited warrantyCONS:Temperature dial is difficult to see

The PowerStroke 1100-watt PS901200D gas-powered portable generator, made in China, requires no assembly. The well packed container includes the portable generator, engine lubricant, spark plug tool, and the operators manual.Starting for the first time includes adding oil and fuel, turning the fuel valve on, placing the choke in the start position, pull the starter, then after 15-30 seconds placing the choke in the run position. Stopping the generator is much simpler and only requires pressing the stop switch.While the generator can be used for recreational or worksite purposes, we have occasional power outages. Between the low runtime and wattage, Im not sure how advantageous using the generator would be for use on the comforts of home. It seems like this lighter weight portable generator is more ideal for recreational use. Although, I can swap out powered items as needed to prevent overloading instead of having everything connected at once.If I were to purchase a portable power generator, I would consider one of the higher powered units. However, the PowerStroke 1100-watt PS901200D gas-powered portable generator is easy to maintain and use. If youre looking for a portable generator, the PowerStroke is a good option, just consider how much power you need.PROS:Up to an 8 hour runtimeLow oil shut down2 year limited warrantyCONS:Short run-time

The Parasheet beach / picnic blanket by Gecko Active is a large lightweight blanket meant to shade or spread out on the ground.  Each corner of the 7 by 6.5 foot blanket has a sand pocket and a tie-off loop.  The loops can be used to hang the blanket as a sun shade or to stake down to the ground.The 362 g / 12.75 ounce blanket, which includes a belt clip and locking drawstring closure, folds into a 6 x 9 inch bag made from the same material.  The compact bag is great for storage and packing into a day pack or picnic basket.  The blankets compact and light weight features is the result of using the thin parasheet material.  Dont expect any level of padding, although padding wouldnt necessarily be needed on the grass or a sandy beach.While I received this Parasheet beach / picnic blanket by Gecko Active in exchange for an honest review, I would be willing to purchase one for my own personal use.  Whether planning a day at the beach, park, or camping, this blanket can provide shade or a place to rest.PROS:Compact and light weightUse as blanket or sunshade100% satisfaction guarantee1 year warrantyCONS:Thin material provides no padding

The Vtin Dew Bluetooth 4.0 wireless stereo headphones with microphone is compatible with iOS and Android operating systems.  The package contains the Vtin Dew Bluetooth 4.0 wireless stereo headphones, a 32 inch USB charging cable, 6 ear cups, and 6 ear hooks, with the medium cups and hooks pre-installed.  Charging takes about 2 hours and provides about 185 hours stand by or 4-5 hours use.The sport earbuds required charging and pairing before use.  The audio is clear and pleasing to the ears, whether listening to music or talking on the phone.  It's been reported back to me that those I am conversing with can hear me clearly as well.The only issue I've had is with the ear hooks.  I have a rook piercing in my left ear which caused interference.  I swapped the medium ear hooks for the smaller ones.  The smaller ear hooks feel a little small, however they keep the headphones in my ears without discomfort.The design works well for working in the yard, going to the gym, or heading out for a run.  These headphones were provided to me in exchange for an honest review.  They have become my go to headphones and I would purchase them if I needed a new pair.  If you're looking for a good pair of sport stereo earbuds, the economical SVtin Dew Bluetooth 4.0 wireless stereo headphones are worthy of your consideration.PROS:Pleasing sound qualityLightweight and comfortable1 year warrantyCONS:Ear hooks may be problematic

The Foxnovo FP10 10400mAh lithium polymer dual-port power bank charger, made in China, comes with the power bank, storage pouch, a multi-connector USB cord, and documentation.  The multi-connector USB cord can be used to charge the power bank, or to charge apple and android devices.  The port end of the 8.6 ounce or 245 gram power bank includes a 5V/2.1A USB output port, 5V/1.0A USB output port, micro USB input port, a power button, and 4 LED charge level indicators.The weight of the power bank is expected for the amount of power it provides.  Occasionally I use power banks on hiking trips.  While only weighing 8.6 ounces on its own, it feels heavy for use on a hike with a pack full of gear.  I would probably opt for one of my less powerful lighter options for such a trip.When the extra power is the priority, this is my go to power bank.  Not only can I charge my device multiple times, I can charge a couple devices simultaneously.  Even though I was provided the Foxnovo FP10 10400mAh lithium polymer dual-port power bank charger in exchange for an honest review, I would gladly purchase one if I needed another.If you're looking for a dual port power bank with plenty of charging capacity, the Foxnovo FP10 10400mAh lithium polymer dual-port power bank charger is definitely worthy of your consideration.PROS:Dual charging portsAnticorrosive aluminum alloy shell500+ lifetime charge cyclesMulti-connector USB cord includedLifetime warrantyCONS:May be heavy for certain uses

*NOBODY* currently makes 256GB micro-SD cards. Even if they did, they would be SDXC cards, not SDHC. The SDHC card standard is valid up to a max capacity of 32GB. And even if it were SDXC, the price would be well over $100.  FOr under $25 you are guaranteed a fake.You risk losing some or all of your valuable data If you buy this card. Read on...Beware of fake capacity SD memory cards. This and many other cheap, apparently-high-capacity SD memory cards are often low capacity 8GB or 16GB cards that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. These cards are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.Such cards will show their false capacity both in your phone and in Windows properties, and they will even work normally under low usage.  However, once their true (low) capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your photos, videos, music, contact list, and other data will be irretrievably lost.Be especially wary of cards with a stated capacity of 64GB or above marked as "SDHC" (not "SDXC"). The SD card association controls and licenses the SD card standards and they define "SDHC" up to a maximum capacity of 32GB. For larger capacity cards, only the "SDXC" standard is valid.*Nobody* currently manufactures 256GB micro-SD cards.  The technology is simply not there yet to pack that much memory onto a single chip. As of Q4 2015, the top capacity for micro SD is generally 128GB. (The one exception is a very expensive 200GB micro SD card recently introduced by SanDisk.) Good cards are out there, but anything 64GB and up will conform to the SDXC standard and will be clearly marked as such. Expect to pay roughly $25 and up for 64GB (as of Q4 2015) and at least twice that for 128GB cards. The 256GB cards (full size only) run over $100.If you do buy a low-priced card, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the card with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient.You can also test by filling the card up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

Seems too good to be true? It is! There are precisely two 512GB USB flash drives on the market - the Corsair Flash Voyager GS and the Kingston HyperX Predator. For about $300 and up, you can buy a genuine 512GB drive. For less than $25 you get a fake-capacity drive that will seem to work at first, but will eventually destroy some or all of your valuable data..They come in a wide variety of styles - brand-name look-alikes, plastic sticks, metal swivels, silver bullets, gold bars, iron man (like this one), and a whole range of generic and novelty drives. They advertise huge memory capacities at wildly low prices. What else do they have in common? If you look inside, they have the same internals *AND* they all have fake capacity.You risk losing some or all of your valuable data if you buy this drive.Beware fake capacity flash drives. This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are really low capacity 4GB or 8GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by a few clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.These drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties, but will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data once their true capacity is exceeded. They will seem to work at first and files will look okay in their folders, but you will eventually find some or all of your data unusable when played, viewed, or otherwise read back. Your valuable data will be irretrievably lost.Only a few manufacturers such as Kingston and Corsair make legitimate 512GB drives and those cost several hundred dollars (as of Q4 2015). The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars.The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting generic and novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips. They also do not have the ability to make a 512GB drive using a single chip design as is contained in this drive. The technology is not there yet.Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below.  For example, if the 64GB drive is only $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is only $10 more than the 64GB.  Real memory is not that cheap.If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

If you think it seems to good to be true, you are most certainly correct beyond any shadow of a doubt.Nobody makes a 512GB micro SD card - *NOBODY*.... And even if they did, it would be an "SDXC" card, not "SDHC". The SDHC card standard is only valid up to a max capacity of 32GB.... And even if it were SDXC, the market price would likely be between $300 and $500, not $25.Instead, what you have here is a hacked, fake-capacity card that will appear to work at first, but will eventually destroy some or all of your valuable data.  Read on...Beware of fake capacity SD memory cards. This and many other cheap, apparently-high-capacity SD memory cards are often low capacity 8GB or 16GB cards that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. These cards are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.Such cards will show their false capacity both in your phone and in Windows properties, and they will even work normally under low usage.  However, once their true (low) capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your photos, videos, music, contact list, and other data will be irretrievably lost.Be especially wary of cards with a stated capacity of 64GB or above marked as "SDHC" (not "SDXC"). The SD card association controls and licenses the SD card standards and they define "SDHC" up to a maximum capacity of 32GB. For larger capacity cards, only the "SDXC" standard is valid.*Nobody* currently manufactures 256GB or 512GB micro-SD cards.  The technology is simply not there yet to pack that much memory onto a single chip. As of Q4 2015, the top capacity for micro SD is generally 128GB. (The one exception is a very expensive 200GB micro SD card recently introduced by SanDisk.) Good cards are out there, but anything 64GB and up will conform to the SDXC standard and will be clearly marked as such. Expect to pay roughly $25 and up for 64GB (as of Q4 2015) and at least twice that for 128GB cards. The 256GB cards (full size only) run over $100. Expect to pay roughly $25 and up for 64GB (as of Q4 2015) and at least twice that for 128GB cards.If you do buy a low-priced card, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the card with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient.You can also test by filling the card up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

This product keeps popping up under new listings. If you take a look at reviews for other listings of this product, you will see a pattern of drives that seem to work at first, but eventually lead to significant data loss.Plastic sticks, metal swivels, silver bullets, gold bars, iron man, and a whole range of generic and novelty styles drives advertising huge memory capacities at wildly low prices. What do they have in common? If you look inside, they have the same internals and (at these prices) they all have fake capacity.You risk losing some or all of your valuable data if you buy this drive.Beware of fake capacity flash drives. This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are often low capacity 8GB or 16GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.These drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties will work normally under low usage.  However, once their true capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your documents, photos, videos and music will be irretrievably lost.Good 128GB drives are out there, mostly brand name drives plus a few generics, but their cost is about $35 and up (as of Q4 2015). The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars. The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips.Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below.  For example, if the 64GB drive is less than $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is less than $10 more than the 64GB.  Real memory is not that cheap.If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

Seems too good to be true? It is! There are precisely two genuine 512GB USB flash drives currently on the market - The Corsair Flash Voyager GS and the Kingston HyperX Predator.This drive is neither.They come in a wide variety of styles - brand-name look-alikes, plastic sticks, metal swivels, silver bullets, gold bars, iron man, and a whole range of generic and novelty drives. If you look inside, they have the same internals *AND* they all have fake capacity.Beware fake capacity flash drives. The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars.The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting generic and novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips. They also do not have the ability to make a 512GB drive using a single chip design as is contained in this drive. The technology is not there yet.Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

For about $80 you may get 256GB of real memory. For about $25 you will most certainly get a hacked, fake-capacity drive that will seem to work initially, but will eventually delete or corrupt your valuable data.They come in many styles: plastic sticks, metal swivels, silver bullets (like this one), gold bars, iron man, and a whole range of generic and novelty styles drives advertising huge memory capacities at wildly low prices. What do they have in common? If you look inside, they have the same internals and (at these prices) they all have fake capacity.Read on...Beware of fake capacity flash drives. This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are really low capacity 4GB or 8GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.These drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties will work normally under low usage.  However, once their true capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your documents, photos, videos and music will be irretrievably lost.Good 256GB drives are out there, mostly brand name drives plus a few USB 3.0 generics, but their cost is about $80 and up (as of Q4 2015). The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars. The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips.Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below.  For example, if the 64GB drive is less than $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is less than $10 more than the 64GB. This and many other cheap, apparently-high-capacity SD memory cards are often low capacity 8GB or 16GB cards that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. These cards are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.Such cards will show their false capacity both in your phone and in Windows properties, and they will even work normally under low usage.  However, once their true (low) capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your photos, videos, music, contact list, and other data will be irretrievably lost.Good 128GB SD cards are out there, but they will conform to the SDXC standard and will be clearly marked as such. Expect to pay roughly $25 and up for 64GB (as of Q4 2015) and at least twice that for 128GB cards.If you do buy a low-priced card, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the card with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient.You can also test by filling the card up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information

Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.  Your photos, videos, music, contact list, and other data will be irretrievably lost.Be especially wary of cards with a stated capacity of 64GB or above marked as "SDHC" (not "SDXC"). The SD card association controls and licenses the SD card standards and they define "SDHC" up to a maximum capacity of 32GB. For larger capacity cards, only the "SDXC" standard is valid.Good 128GB SD cards are out there, but they will conform to the SDXC standard and will be clearly marked as such. Expect to pay roughly $25 and up for 64GB (as of Q4 2015) and at least twice that for 128GB cards.If you do buy a low-priced card, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the card with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient.You can also test by filling the card up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

New listing, save drive, same seller, same story.Plastic sticks, metal swivels, silver bullets, gold bars, iron man, brand look-alikes, and a whole range of generic and novelty styles drives advertising huge memory capacities at wildly low prices. What do they have in common? If you look inside, they have the same internal circuit card *and* they all have fake capacity.You risk losing some or all of your valuable data if you buy this drive. Read on...Beware fake capacity flash drives - especially unusually low-priced generic (and brand-name look-alike) drives 64GB and up.This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are really low capacity 4GB or 8GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by a few clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.These drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties, but will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data once their true capacity is exceeded. They will seem to work at first and files will look okay in their folders, but you will eventually find some or all of your data corrupt when played, viewed, or otherwise read back.  Your valuable data will be irretrievably lost.As of Q4 2015, the *only* manufacturer of 1TB USB flash drives is Kingston with their DTHXP30 HyperX Predator drive.  To achieve that capacity, Kingston mounts 8 memory chips, a controller chip and other necessary components on three interconnected circuit cards packed into a necessarily bulky package. Search for "DTHXP30 review" to see photos of the internals.  Those drives cost several hundred dollars, and most of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars.The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting generic and novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips. They also do not have the ability to make a 1TB drive using a single chip design as is contained in this drive. The technology is not there yet.Good generic flash drives *are* out there, but the true capacity generic drives top out at 128GB for USB 2.0 drives (costing about $35), and the less common 256GB USB 3.0 generics (costing about $80). The market is also flooded with fake capacity drives offered at prices well below the true capacity drives.Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below.  For example, if the 64GB drive is only $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is only $10 more than the 64GB.  Real memory is not that cheap.If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.
