You can do things to make it hotter (press out a very distilled batch then add boiling water), but it still won't be super-hot, or as high quality. Then again, real coffee connoisseurs wouldn't have thought much of the super-hot coffee I drank when I was a kid.2) If I'm having some friends over and want to make them all coffee, it's not going to happen with an AeroPress. It's really a one cup at a time device.

A lot of people these days are singing the praises of DHA... EPA is equally important, and is a natural antidepressant. (DHA, on the other hand, can sometimes have a depressive effect.)The capsules are sturdy and well designed to keep the oil inside fresh.One tip when buying any kind of fish oil: though the container doesn't say so, I'd recommend refrigerating this product, and all fish oil, after purchasing it. It'll keep the oil fresh longer. (You should also of course keep the container tightly sealed.

I use blenders mainly for making butter coffee, also known as bulletproof coffee (blending hot coffee, MCT oil, butter, cream and a little vanilla extract).  I bought this blender to replace an old Black and Decker model that had given me a few good years of use before giving up the ghost.When using my old blender, I would fill the glass food container nearly full, push in the top to secure it, and push a button to start the coffee blending.  I figured this one would work the same way.Well... not quite.I noticed when I took this one out of the box that they had made two design changes:1) in my old blender there was a replaceable rubber gasket in the blade assembly, which could be removed for cleaning. In the new design, the gasket is built into the blade assembly and can't be removed or cleaned. This is fine, it actually seems like an improvement, because the old style gasket could get moldy easily, or could get lost after disassembling for cleaning.2) I also noticed that the black plastic top (which covers the glass food container) seemed much flimsier when I pulled it out of the box.... not like the top of my previous blender, which seemed more solid and durable.So, I tried it today. Here's what I experienced.1) I put in the ingredients as usual: hot coffee, coconut oil, MCT oil, butter and cream and vanilla extract.2) I put on the lid.3) I pushed a button to start it blending at low speed.4) The top of the container went flying off, spraying oily coffee all over the kitchen.  The hot coffee, steam, and force of blending was too much for the friction holding on the container top.The solution is obvious, now that I know about the problem: Hold the top on with one hand while pushing "go" with the other. (Or leave the hole in the top open, covered by some napkins, so the steam can escape.)  The main point though is that the new top is not as secure as the old one, because I didn't have to take either of these measures with my old Black and Decker blender.. the stayed in place come hell or high water.  The top of this one is noticeably cheaper and flimsier, so does not stay in place as well.Still, the other design change (getting rid of the gasket) is a good one. So I'm happy all in all, so far.  I've used it for about a week, and have not had any problems yet.  Knock wood.

I like this product (DHEA for Men) but I like DHEA Plus better. (They're made by the same company, Life Flo.)The first few times I used Life Flo DHEA for Men, it squirted out of the container in a watery, runny way... kinda drippy. After a few uses, it started looking more like a foam, and was easier to apply.  I'm not sure what the problem was. If I buy it again I'll give it a good shake before using it.The "DHEA for Men" product contains saw palmetto; I'm not sure that this is a necessary addition.  Some men might want it because it supposedly provides some benefits to the prostate. But I can take it or leave it.  I tend to like pure products DHEA products better.

Most vitamin C nowadays is made in China. Considering China's frankly horrific quality control and history of product contamination, many people are understandably cautious about buying products from that country.Quali-C is produced in Scotland, by one of the longest-established manufacturers of synthetic vitamin C.  It's a good alternative for people trying to avoid Chinese products.  It's the L-ascorbate form, which most researchers recommend taking instead of the D- form used in cheaper supplements.I'd like to close by addressing a couple of questions that people often post in response to supplement reviews:1) Quali-C is synthetic. Isn't it better to take natural vitamin C?  Answer: Generally, yes.  To get natural vitamin C, just eat an orange or some berries. But if you're taking a large amount on the advice of your doctor or naturopath, you will by definition be taking a synthetic product. (Genuine "natural" vitamin C can cost FIFTY TIMES MORE than synthetic!)2) Isn't it better to take ascorbate, than ascorbic acid?  Answer: Yes, but unfortunately, most manufacturers use the two terms interchangeably on their labels.  (Those selling "ascorbate" will often label it "ascorbic acid" as if there were no difference.)  So you can't necessarily tell what you're getting from whether the word "acid" appears on the label.  The important thing is to ask whether you are buying the L-form, or the D-form.  Synthetic L-ascorbate acts just like natural L-ascorbate in the body. The "D" form is the one you want to avoid, whether the label calls it "ascorbic acid" or not.In sum: Quali-C's vitamin C supplements are the L form of vitamin C. They are free of contaminants. Quali-C is a highly respected company.  If you need to take more vitamin C than could be found easily in food, I recommend this product.

What I like: the fixture is nicely designed and works (so far).However, the lights have problems.One of the bulbs burned out two minutes after I turned it on. The ones next to it did not burn out and are still working.Each fixture is supposed to come with a fuse.  But there was only one fuse for all three fixtures.  I recognized it as a fuse but some people might not; it was not labeled in any way.

Part of the problems with "Assassin" is that the premise (a killer robot hunting down humans) has been done much better, many times, in the years since the movie was made. It's pre-CGI, and low budget, so you can't blame it really for having poor special FX.  But even as a period piece, bearing in mind what was and wasn't possible when it was made, it's a major flop.The production values are poor. The resolution is very low.  The print is so dark in places that it's often hard to tell what's going on.  It was made for television and it shows: the scenes seem designed to be viewed on a small television screen, with a preponderance of closeups and medium shots.  The audio sounds like it was made for television too, from the days when TV sets had poor sound systems and tinny speakers. Assassin was made in the 80s but has the feeling of early 70s television, like an overly long episode of some show like Six Million Dollar Man.If the story was interesting it might still be worth watching, but it's dull and lackluster, a thriller with little or no suspense.  Scenes come and go without advancing the plot.  The robot wanders around killing people we have not had a chance to get to know or care about. Or trying to kill them.  The ones it does kill are such bland bozos that it's not sad to see them die.  In one scene it picks up a woman and spends the night with her.  She giggles and implies they had sex all night.  But the scene, the sex and the woman have nothing to do with the story and none of them are ever referred to again.  They appear to be filler to make the movie last the required number of minutes.The narrative is predictable and gives us no real reason to care about any of the characters.  Even the fact that it's a robot turns out to be irrelevant. It's a robot that shoots people. But so what? Is it worse to be shot by a robot than a person?Here I should stick in a ******** SPOILER WARNING******** for anyone who keeps watching all the way to the end:SPOILER 1: The robot dies at the end. (Surprise.) However, the hero doesn't kill it.  In fact he doesn't end up doing much at all. I couldn't really figure out, by the end of the movie, why he had even been in the film.Spoiler 2:  After killing a bunch of boring guys and trying to kill some other guys, the robot  gets stuck in a room but can't leave because the door gets stuck, so it's locked in.  That's all. It gets locked in a room.  This apparently is too much for its high tech sophisticated humanoid killing machine brain. It does not do anything a human might do in that situation, such as finding something in the room to break down the door (or break it down itself... it was shown punching through a few walls and breaking through a locked door earlier.)  Instead, it gets wigged out and starts spinning around in circles making an irritating high pitched sound, then blows up. (It may have just felt like exiting the movie, and blowing up was the easiest way to do so.)If you can watch Assassin for free as part of Amazon Prime, just to blow some time when there's nothing else to do, Assassin should work for that; otherwise I'd skip this one.

I bought a box of these out of curiosity because they were on sale.  I like a number of Mercola's products, including the Cocoa Cassava bars (which are fantastic, though high in carbs), so I thought I'd try something new.  I was looking for a snack I could take with me on the road, that's healthy ready and in an instant; these do fit the bill.Having tried a couple of bars, I would say: They're pretty good. I gave them 4 stars, but my actual rating would be 3.5, if that were an option. They're better than okay, but not spectacular.WHAT I LIKE:1) They're not too sweet. I don 't like the overly sweet taste of a lot of protein bars (and breakfast cereals and other odious snacks).  The sweetness here is like that of a mild wafer such as a scone.2) They have a good balance of protein and carbohydrates (14 grams of protein, and 21 grams of carbs, minus 5 grams of fiber). Oh, and they have 9 grams of fat.  The macronutrient breakdown is similar to that of a glass of milk. If you like the 4:3:3 balance of carbs, protein and fats recommended by regimens like the Zone Diet, these are close to ideal.3) The ingredients are mostly organic, another plus.WHAT I DISLIKE:1) The taste.  The peanut butter flavor is mild and in the background; the main taste, as far as I can tell, is tapioca.2) The texture. They're dry, not moist, and actually kind of hard to get down. The problem may be that since they're not appetizing, they don't stimulate much saliva.  So I'd recommend having some water or another beverage on hand ready to help wash them down.SUMMING UPIn sum, I'm not crazy about them, and likely won't buy them again, but I do like some things about them.  Oh, BTW, be aware that the price varies a lot, even on Amazon. So I recommend shopping around before buying.

Like a lot of kids in the sixties, I grew up reading MAD magazine. My parents bought Newsweek, Time, and the Saturday Evening Post; I bought MAD.  I liked how it poked fun at and deflated everything from movies to Madison Avenue.  I recognized even as a kid that MAD (the magazine) was a tad formulaic and predictable, but it was still worth buying and reading.I learned later that MAD (the magazine) was the descendant of MAD (the comic book), a wilder and more freewheeling publication which had broken ground in the 50s, and had played a part in changing both comics and the world beyond comics. The first few MAD comics had a frenetic energy and a dark and sometimes violent undercurrent that were only hinted at in the magazine it would develop into over the years.  MAD the comic was not "safe" like the later magazine; it was crazier, more subversive and more revolutionary.  The early stories seemed fearless, and even a little scary.  They were funny and incisive and anything but polite.  I read them years after their original publication as reprints, admiring and enjoying the crazy energy of the satirical comics and articles, and appreciating the hints of social commentary under their acerbic veneer.I didn't realize till years later that the stories I was enjoying in reprinted form, drawn by some of the most brilliant comic book artists of the period, were expressions of the creativity of a single man, Harvey Kurtzman.  Kurtzman's work in MAD transformed comics in the early 1950s; and in this well-written and well-researched book, Bill Schelly makes a case that Kurtzman's influence went far beyond comics, to have an influence on popular culture in the United States.  If you like Lenny Bruce (and his progeny), or Woody Allen, or Saturday Night Live, or almost any contemporary comedian, you can thank Kurtzman -- because, according to Schelly, he created, or popularized, the style of humor most modern comedians rely on.  It's a provocative thesis that's explored and reinforced nicely in this book.Harvey Kurtzman: The Man Who Created MAD and Revolutionized Humor in America is a detailed and fascinating account of Kurtzman's life, struggles, and creative ventures.  It's an incisive portrait of the the man and his work which includes, but goes far beyond, his involvement in the early MAD comic book, and is rightfully receiving attention from reviewers far removed from comics. It's a genuine work of scholarship that works on several different levels, and explores both Kurtzman the person, and the connections between Kurtzman's creative impulses and the transformations that were occurring in both popular and personal culture in the United States in the decades following World War Two.Bill Schelly's book is both a good read in its own right, and an important work of scholarship detailing the life, battles, and working methods of a man whose work had a profound influence on popular culture in ways that may not be immediately obvious. I recommend it for anyone interested in history, comics, popular culture, or the creative process.

I find it astonishing that Madison Avenue has convinced people that products like this smell "fresh" or "nice."  They have a terrible chemical stink.  I opened one of these bags in my car and had to open the windows while driving to try to air the smell out.  Products containing synthetic perfumes are bad for the people who use them and terrible for the environment and human health.  They will stink up your house if you use them. In my case, just a few-minute exposure was enough to trigger a migraine. The scent clings to clothing, hair and furniture.  There are web pages devoted to brainstorming solutions to get the horrible smell out of items that come in contact with them. (Do a web search for "Fabric softener Begone" or "Removing horrible Febreze smell" or "Febreze Carcinogenic".)  Consumers should demand that stinky, toxic "perfumey" products be taken out of consumer goods.

First I should say, I like PS. I find it relaxing, and it helps my short term memory.  There's evidence that it may protect the brain and keep it working well as we age. When I'm stressed, it's a blessing to have around.  I've tried several brands (NOW, Jarrow and Country Life), and like most of them.I also like Jarrow's products as a general rule. Their soy-free PS in gel caps is my favorite kind.So when I saw that Jarrow PS was available as "Yum Yums" (gummies), I thought, what the heck, it sounded fun...  I was running low anyway... why not buy some in this form, and see if I liked 'em.  I know they're aimed at kids and parents - at least the design on the bottle seems to be.  But they could be a fun way for adults to get their daily PS, too.WHAT I LIKE:1) They're effective.2) They're fast acting (I can feel the effect a few minutes after chewing them (or letting 'em melt in my mouth)... faster than I do when swallowing them then waiting for the gel caps to digest).TWO CAVEATS:1) My first caveat is that they're too sweet for my taste, like biting into a liquid sugar cube.  I know this is how most gummy supplements are, but  I'd be happier if they were about 1/10th the sweetness.  It also bothers me that the sweetness comes from sugar, not all that good for the teeth.If Jarrow's reading this, I have a request: come up with a PS gummy made with stevia or xylitol.  (Lots of people avoid products with this much sugar because they're high in sucrose and high in carbs.)2) Since some people are buying these for their kids, I would recommend caution. I can picture a little tyke eating a bottle full of these because they taste like candy.  If you buy them for young children, don't leave them out where the kids can get into them.  One or two a day might be beneficial, but I doubt that a whole bottle would.

The X-Men have had a number of incarnations.  The first was in the 1960s, when Lee and Kirby came up with the premise (a school for fledgling superheroes who had been born with unusual powers), and created the original characters. The series ran for a few years then fizzled out, and was replaced with reprints for about 1/3 of its print run.Several years later, Len Wein, Chris Claremont and Dave Cockrum collaborated in reviving the book, which was retitled Uncanny X-Men.  They threw out several of the original characters, brought in some new ones, and took the narrative in exciting new directions.A couple of years later, Cockrum was replaced by John Byrne, who helped shape the book visually and was instrumental in co-plotting the series through some of its most seminal issues, including the original Dark Phoenix storyline.Byrne is a skilled writer and artist, as he demonstrated in his work on several major comic books over the years, so I had high hopes for X-Men The Hidden Years, which he had almost total control over.  So I have to confess that I was a little disappointed, not by the art or storytelling, but by the writing, which is not Byrne's best.Byrne's artwork is wonderful, clear, beautiful and vibrant, on par with his best work on Superman/Man of Steel.  Tom Palmer's inking, assisted on some pages by Joe Sinnott, is also wonderful.  But the stories in this book feel like a kind of pablum compared Byrne's work on titles like Fantastic Four and Superman, which he also wrote and drew.Those stories were compelling and had depth; the characters felt real and three dimensional. The ones in this book are fast-moving and have some clever elements, but by and large are not in the same league.The main problem is that things drag.  There's a lot of action but very little character development -- a problem that plagued the original X-Men series, because the characters and their relationships were inherently dull.  Uncanny X-Men had the tension between Cyclops and Wolverine, and the troubled love story between Scott Summers and Jean Grey/Phoenix to make it compelling; this book, like the first X-Men series that fizzled, has a lot of nice characters being nice to each other issue after issue.  That's all well and good but it means any drama has to be external, and not affect the characters on a core level.Of course Byrne was constrained, restricted by the (already published) stories on either side of the continuity gap this series tried to fill.  But he could have revealed more about the characters' lives, pasts and personalities.  It's hard for a reader to stay interested when there's not even a remote possibility of character development or change.Another problem is that the dialogue is a little stodgy.  The characters tend to stand around talking about and explaining things we've already seen.  We see Iceman leave the team for a while, and we see why.  We then see other characters talking for a page or two about the fact that he's left, and speculating about his reasons for leaving, which were made clear at the time.  We see the Angel fly a dying character up into the sky; the character thinks he's taking her to heaven.  All well and good, but then the other characters have a little conversation remarking on the fact that he's just flying her into the sky, not really taking her to heaven. Which we just saw. It's not that the scene is bad, but the dialogue is redundant, tells us things we already know, and should have been trimmed.  Byrne could have used a more active editor to deal with moments like these, because they do drag the book down after a while.The result is what I'd call "X-Men Lite"... stories with a lot of action and color, but a dearth of emotional substance.  If the series had continued I expect Byrne would have realized this, but it ended after the 22 issues reprinted in this volume and in Volume 2.On the plus side, both books do work as an homage of sorts to the previous writers and artists. The layouts remind me of some of the most innovative page and panel compositions of Neal Adams. Tom Palmer's inking is still extraordinary after all these years. Even Joe Sinnott drops by to lend a hand.If you don't mind the repetition and lack of character development, these stories can be fun to read, and nice to look at.  John's come a long way as an artist; his work on a visual level in this series is extraordinary. I hope he'll return to comics soon with a series where he can show his strengths as a writer again.  He is a wonderful one, on the right series, when he's free to surprise readers and make changes.

WHAT I LIKE:Phosphatidylserine (PS) is a supplement that more and more people are becoming aware of.Tests have shown that it helps with memory and cognition, making it particularly useful to those of us in our middle years or older.It's important to note, however, that the tests showing its effectiveness were done years ago using bovine PS derived from cows' brains, which are naturally high in DHA. Patients with memory problems showed dramatic improvement when taking it.Unfortunately the kind used in the early tests is no longer available in the U.S. due to fears of  mad cow disease.  The kind found in supplements is derived from plant sources, a similar but not identical product.  Most supplemental PS has two problems: 1) It's made from soy, which is high in phyto-estrogens, and 2) It's missing DHA, because it's made from plant sources rather than bovine brains.This product (Conjugated Phosphatidylserine with DHA) solves both problems:1) It's made from sunflower seeds, not soy.2) It's been bound to DHA from fish oil, making it much closer to the type that occurs naturally in the human brain.  In theory this should make it more easily absorbed, and more like bovine PS in its effects.I've been taking it for about a year and a half, and have found that it helps my mood and memory, and is also effective against inflammation.  Of all the DHA products I've tried, I like this product and one made by Jarrow the best. (I usually take them together, actually.)CAVEATS:I sometimes find myself feeling a little sleepy after taking PS, particularly with large doses. If you do take large doses (more than 200 mg/day) I recommend spreading them out over the day (or taking it in the evening, when you're getting ready for bed.)ADDENDUMS: The manufacturer (Swanson) sometimes offers this product at a substantial discount (such as two for the price of one) on their website. I'd love to see the two for one price available on Amazon. You can take Swanson conjugated PS by itself, or for even more benefit, throw in a couple of fish oil capsules, another excellent source of DHA.  Salmon oil or krill oil are both excellent additional sources of DHA. Side note: PS is also available from food sources, including egg yolks, lecithin, some types of mackerel, and navy beans. If you're on a budget,you might try first adding more egg yolks to your diet.  But if you can afford it, supplementation is also a good way to do.

WHAT I LIKE:It's organic... no chemicals, no sprays, no toxic junk.It's comfortable. The material is soft.It's affordable: ten bucks for an organic cotton shirt. (The price varies by size; that was the price of the one I purchased.)I normally buy "L" (not XL) shirts. I ordered this on in XL because "large" was not listed as an option.  It fits fine... a little loose, but again that's because I normally buy a size smaller.All in all my impression so far is that it's an excellent product.  I'll be looking for other products from this company.WHAT I DISLIKE:If I run into any problems with this shirt down the road, I'll update this review. But at this time they're nothing to dislike.

I avoided watching this for a few months because I didn't expect to like it.  I expected a campy and pointless remake.  I was surprised at how good it was.The 1980s version was fun, but made little attempt to be believable.  The action in it had a cartoonish quality, which was appropriate at the time.The 2014 version is grounded in this century's political and social realities, as well as a few decades of advances in robotics. I wouldn't say it's a realistic view of the future, but in some respects it may not be far off. The lead character's reaction when he finds out his human body has been replaced by something inhuman is one of the more disturbing moments in the story -- he wants "out" but there's nowhere for him to go.The writing, acting and directing are all excellent. The characters' emotions are real, and the character development as the movie moves along is thoughtful and low-key. There's  a undercurrent of political satire and social commentary which many viewers will appreciate.So why so many negative reviews? I think it may be because a lot of people tuned into the movie hoping for a mindless action/adventure, a live action cartoon with cardboard characters like the original.  If you're looking for that, this version will seem a little slow in places. But if you're looking for a thought-provoking story, I expect you'll like it.

What I like about this product:1) The softgels are small and easy to swallow.2) The company has a good reputation for quality control.3) I find that when I take astaxanthin, my eyesight improves and I can spend more time in the sun without burning. (Astaxanthin alone doesn't improve my eyesight, but taking it along with lutein, another natural antioxidant, does.)4) The bottle came with a coupon for a second (smaller) bottle of astaxanthin.  I know this is a promotion, but it's a generous one, and I do appreciate it.What I don't like:1) In addition to astaxanthin, the softgels contain two ingredients that I normally try to avoid: carrageenan (an emulsifier which a lot of people have become wary of recently) and sorbitol (an artificial sweetener).  I'm not sure why the sorbitol, in particular, is needed, since we're not chewing the capsules, just quickly swallowing them.  I would encourage the company to phase both additives out in the future.2) The plastic bottle.  This isn't so much a complaint about this company, but about all of the supplement manufacturers who've gone in this direction. I remember the days when all supplements were routinely packaged in glass, which is becoming rarer and rarer. Plastic, even hard plastic, is semi-porous to air, so supplements packaged in it won't stay fresh as long as those in glass bottles.  And plastic can leach into food products including supplements over time.  So if anyone from the company is reading this - I and many people I know would gladly pay a little more for glass.

I've been taking B12 shots for the past few weeks, and found them to be beneficial.  I started looking for an alternative because:1) Shots are expensive.  (The ones I've been getting from my naturopath are $15 each. That adds up!)2) B12 may be "natural," but needles aren't.  Something bothers me about the idea of trying to fortify my health by jabbing a sharp metal tube under my skin and giving myself an injection.3) They can hurt, if you inject them in an area that has a lot of nerve endings.3) With needles, there's a possibility of infection or complications.4) Many injectable formulas contain cyanocobalamin, not necessarily the best kind of B12 to take.SO WHAT ARE THE ALTERNATIVES?If you don't want to take B12 shots, you might consider:(1) B12 capsules and tablets (typical "vitamin pills" designed to be swallowed and digested)(2) B12 tablets (sublingual; designed to dissolve under your tongue)(3) B12 liquids and sprays (sublingual)(4) B12 patches (transdermal; the vitamin is absorbed through your skin)(5) B12 creams (also transdermal) (such as this one)The problem with item 1 (typical B vitamin pills) is that if you're not absorbing B12 from food, you're unlikely to absorb it from a tablets and capsules which, like food, end up in your digestive tract.Items 2,3,4 and 5 are all intended to bypass the intestinal tract (like injections)  so in theory could result in better absorption.My experience with item 2, sublingual tablets, has been uneven.  When I feel anything, it's a quick burst of energy that fades quickly.  The ones I like best are the B12/folic acid/B6 tabs from Trader Joe's.  But again, they're made from cyanocobalamin. And their effect doesn't seem to last.I've also tried item 3, sublingual liquids and sprays, but have not felt the same benefit I get from shots.B12 patches (item 4) are a popular alternative to injections. Some people like them a lot.  But they can sometimes come off as they rub against clothing, or when taking baths or showers.  And they're pretty pricey -- over $2 per patch, on the average. This is less than the cost of an injection, but still adds up. The cheaper ones have a reputation for not staying on, and for staining clothing and skin.This leaves item 5, B12 cream. Creams, like patches, deliver their product transdermally, through the skin. They're not patches, so you don't have to worry about them staying on.HOW THIS PRODUCT WORKSThe cream goes on pretty much like any hand lotion. The insert recommends rubbing it into the wrists, so I've been doing that that way. I roll up my sleeves, apply the cream to one wrist and rub with the other. There are visible blood vessels in the wrists, visible just under the surface, so I assume it's going rapidly into the bloodstream, when applied this way.The cream is a light pink in color (all B12 products have some "red" in them), and has a very faint fragrance, almost undetectable.  Initially it's very visible on  your skin, but if you rub it in again a few minutes after applying it, it won't be visible anymore. It feels a bit like applying a thin film of soap to the skin.One nice thing about this product, Vita Sciences Maxasorb B12 cream is that it contains methylcobalamin, which many people prefer to cyanocobalamin.MY EXPERIENCEMy first impression (on day 1) was of a jolt of energy.  It felt as effective, and even faster acting, than the shots I had been giving myself.  The second time I used it (day 2), I noticed a milder energy boost.  It may be that my body was lower in B12 the first time, so the cream had a more noticeable effect. Still, I did feel something.  All in all, my impression is that it works well, works quickly, and is an effective product.  For those looking for an alternative to injections, it's worth trying.CAVEATSThe first time I pressed the dispenser, a tiny chunk came out. Apparently this is what was stuck in the dispenser.  The second time, I got a large ribbon of cream. The third time, a big blob. The next couple of times, more ribbons of cream. It may be because the container is new; hopefully it'll settle into giving the same amount in each dose as the days go by.  If I run into any other problems, I'll update this.

I bought these out of curiosity. (They were cheap, and I was looking to increase my B vitamin intake.  So I figured, what the heck.)LIKES:* They're sublingual. They're designed to dissolve under the tongue, which bypasses the digestive tract.  In theory, more of the vitamins could end up in your bloodstream.* They're affordable (though of course, the cost of shipping also needs to be considered).  Many supplements nowadays are prohibitively expensive. These are a great price.* They include a good dosage of most of the key B vitamins people people are looking to supplement.DISLIKES:* They're low in vitamin B12 (they contain only 6 micrograms per tablet). And the B12 they did include is in the cyanocobalimin form, which, according to some sources, is not well absorbed.  These would NOT be a good choice for people (such as vegetarians) wanting to increase their intake of B12 (unless you also take the B12 product, as mentioned above)* The taste isn't very pleasant.  (I'm not saying all sublinguals need to be sweet, but these are pretty harsh.)NOTE:* The company that makes these also makes a "no-shot" vitamin B12 supplement, which is also sublingual, and has 1000 micrograms of B12.  So if your goal is to increase your B12, you might buy it along with this product.In sum, I'd say these are a good idea, and I appreciate the low price, but they would be improved by working on the taste and adding more B12 to the formula.

WHY I TAKE ASTAXANTHINI've been taking astaxanthin on and off for the past few years.The first thing I noticed was an improvement in my eyesight.  When I'd look up at trees (without my glasses on), I could see the individual leaves clearly and distinctly.  Usually they'd be a blur.  The same is true about reading fine type in a book or on a computer screen. When I don't take astaxanthin, my eyes can get bleary after working at my computer all day, making it hard to read sometimes. If I take astaxanthin when my eyes get bleary, the words and images on the screen or in the book are clear and easy to read again.  The effect is particularly striking when I take it along with other eye nutrients like lutein and zeaxanthinThe second thing I noticed was that I wasn't getting sunburned. I have a history of burning easily. When I take astaxanthin, I can work shirtless in the hot sun for a couple of hours without getting anything than a mild reddening. Without the astaxanthin, I'd be burned to a crisp. This wasn't an immediate effect, I'd been taking astaxanthin for about a month before I noticed it.HOW TO TELL IF THE ASTAXANTHIN YOU ARE TAKING IS REAL OR FAKE.Fake supplements are a big business. Some companies make counterfeit products and sell them online.  Astaxanthin is easy to fake -- some companies just put red food coloring in the capsules!  Here's how to tell is your astaxanthin is real or fake. This information is rewritten from an article on the Algae World News website:1) TEST IT IN SOME OILAstananthin is lipid soluble (i.e., it dissolves easily in fats and oils). Cut a capsule open and drip some of the liquid inside into a cup with some cooking oil in it. Stir it gently. If the oil in the cup turns red, as the product diffuses out into the oil, it's likely real. If it doesn't, it may be fake.2) TEST IT IN SOME WATEROil and water don't mix. So if you're trying to find out if it's really oil in the capsule, cut a capsule open and drip it into a glass of water. Real astaxanthin will spread out on the surface of the water like an oil slick on the ocean... i.e., it will NOT mix into the water. If it diffuses easily into the water it's probably fake.3) TEST IT ON SOME WHITE PAPER. Does the color change?Drip some on a piece of paper and put the paper in bright sunshine. If it's real astaxanthin its color will fade  in about 24 hours, and may get slightly greenish (from cholorphyll). If it's fake (red food coloring in a capsule or gel cap) it won't fade and won't turn green.

The cover of this volume is beautiful; it's a classic Wally Wood drawing, nicely colored and beautifully printed.  It's what made me decide to buy the book (just as Wood's covers used to induce me to buy the Thunder Agents comics when I was a kid).  I'd love to have an oversized, full color poster of the cover image without the lettering.... I'd buy it :)The interior artwork is nice, though I had mixed feelings about the story choices.  Wood worked with lots of pencilers, some of whom (like Dan Adkins) were a little static.  I would say that's true about most of the layouts in this edition; the characters' poses are static, without a lot of life. (Pencillers like Ditko had more dynamic compositions, but were not included in this book.)  I loved Wood's artwork when I was a kid, and was somewhat in awe of it, so it was a nostalgic rush to see it again in this volume.  But it also confirmed my feeling that Wood did his finest artwork in the 1950s, about ten years before the "Thunder Agents" days. I'd love to see more volumes of his artwork from that period.I expected this book to be shrink-wrapped. It wasn't.  I'd have been happier as it was, as shrink-wrapping can protect items from scuffing and other damage during shipping. It actually arrived dented, because it had been shipped in a padded envelope with no further protection. I called Amazon, thinking I might return it, and they offered me the choice of returning it, exchanging it, or a partial refund, which I accepted.The printing in this edition is nice, a step above the printing in DC's Thunder Agents archives. The pages are about 10 percent larger than the pages of the original comics they came from.  The paper's durable and slick. Wally would have been pleased, I think, to see his artistry showcased in this manner.

I like this product, and like Starwest's approach.  It's an innovative idea to sell pure powdered enzymes in bulk, in sealed airtight bags, instead of putting a tiny amount into a capsule or tablet then selling it for a greatly inflated price.I bought two products from this company: Bromelain powder and Papain powder. Both ae high quality. They arrived packaged in airtight foil packages. I opened the packages and transferred the powder into glass jars, which I keep in a cupboard away from excess heat, and away from light.  (I'm not sure if light damages enzymes like it does other supplements, but better safe than sorry.)I'm happy with the product, and recommend both (powdered bromelain and papain) for people looking for a better way to buy and take enzymes.

I take powdered papain along with powdered bromelain -- a teaspoon of each in a glass of water  in the morning, a half hour before meals -- because both enzymes have been shown to be effective against intestinal parasites.I bought both from this company (Starwest botanicals). They arrived nicely packaged in airtight foil packages.  I opened the packages and transferred the powder into glass jars, which I keep in a cupboard away from excess heat.  As far as I can tell, both are pure, high quality products.  They don't have any taste at all.I like the powders (such as this one) because they're pure, and are much more affordable, for the amount you're getting, than most papain supplements. Most "chewable papain" supplements are mostly sugar, with a little bit of papain, so it's hard to imagine them being very effective either in helping digestion or clearing out parasites.  This (powdered) papain product does not have added sugar; as far as I'm aware, it's genuine, pure papain.  I recommend it.

Dietary collagen and gelatin products are said to be good for:- firming the skin, and reducing wrinkles, when taken internally (evidence of this is mostly anecdotal, but many people swear by it)- strengthening hair, toenails and fingernails- healing UV skin damage (this claim has been verified in studies in which mice were fed gelatin, rich in collagen, then exposed to UV light).- killing candida and restoring gut health, when taken internally.  (Recent studies have verified that gelatin is 100 percent effective in preventing candida from adhering to the intestinal lining, thus preventing candidadiasis -- and that collagen, a gelatin product, is 68 percent effective at preventing adherence.)  (Amazon reviews do not allow links to external websites, but to read about the studies, Google the phrase, "Gelatin fragments block adherence of Candida albicans to extracellular matrix proteins."Some people don't like using collagen because some brands smell like gelatin (which, to some people, smells like wet leather). (This makes sense, because both gelatin and collagen are made from cow hides.)  The smell doesn't bother me but to some folks it's a major issue.  So I'm happy to report that this product, Vital Proteins Pasture-Raised Collagen, has no odor at all.  I received it today, opened the container and inhaled deeply.... nothing.  (By comparison, Neo Cell's "Super Collagen" has a strong gelatin smell.)

I like this product. I've been taking it for a couple of weeks, and will likely buy it again.I like the wide range of health-promoting ingredients, though it would be nice if they'd indicate how much they're including of each one.  The way the label lists them, it's impossible to get a sense of relative quantities, because they're broken down by category instead of ingredient.  Still, I like what's in it and what's not. Unlike some "greens" powders, it's not stuffed with cheap filler ingredients like ground flax seeds.I love that the product is packaged in glass, rather than plastic.  Kudos to the company for that decision.Some people have commented negatively about the taste.  I actually kind of like it.  I should clarify though that I don't like sweet foods.... I find sour and bitter flavors more palatable than overly sweet ones. My favorite foods are plain, unflavored yogurt and kefir, and "bitter" vegetables like like broccoli and curly parsley, eaten raw without flavorings. This product has kind of a harsh taste that some people (like me) like, but others have a hard time getting down.If you have a hard time with sharp or bitter tastes, I'd recommend starting with a small amount of this product till you get used to it.  I would NOT recommend mixing it into sweet smoothies, at least not in large amounts, because it overpowers the taste of the blander ingredients.  You might try putting some into a little cup of water, gulping it down, then chasing it with more water. Or  try mixing it with a little tomato juice or mixed-vegetable juice (instead of sweet juice).  I personally like it plain, mixed into some water, but again, I kind of go for the bitter taste.While I like this product and will buy it again in the future, I was bothered by some of the text on the label. The point of the text about organic seems to be to make people doubt that the "organic" label is valid.  Instead they've come up with the word TruGanic. Their website states that "...all TruGanic sourced ingredients are either certified organic, wildcrafted, or naturally grown, without pesticides/herbicides."I appreciate the intent behind this, but it's odd and seems a little disingenuous that they don't indicate which ingredients are which.  It's simple enough to put a little asterisk or something beside the name of each ingredient, to let consumers know whether it's certified organic (which has a very specific legal meaning), or "pesticide free," (which, again, is a very specific claim), or just "naturally grown" (which is vague, and has no legal meaning).  I wouldn't buy a product labeled "naturally grown" in a supermarket (because the term has no meaning), so I'm surprised to find it used here. Still, this is a minor issue. I'm happy with the product and do like using it.I found the label difficult to read. For others having a hard time reading it, here's a list of the ingredients from their website:Land Vegetables: Nettle leaf, horsetail (shavegrass), burdock root, ginger root, beet root juice, alfalfa leaf juice, dandelion leaf juice, broccoli juice, kale juice, spinach juice, parsley juice, yucca juice, nopal cactusSea Vegetables: Icelandic kelp, Nova Scotia dulseCereal Grasses: Whole leaf barley grass, whole leaf wheat grass, kamut grass juice, barley grass juice, oat grass juiceFruits: Acerola berry juice, amla berry, carob podAlgaes: Spirulina, broken cell wall chlorellaEnzymes: Protease, papain, bromelain, amylase, cellulase, lipase, alpha galactosidaseProbiotics & Microflora: Beneficial organisms. Includes exclusive NSO (Natural Soil Organisms) and implantable species. A. agilis, L. acidophilus, R. arrhizus, DDS-1 acidophilus, bifidus, L. bulgaricus, A. brasilienese, B. brenis, P. chrysosporium, A. citreus, L. casei, P. calcis, S. cellulasae, P. denitrificans, S. daecium, S. dradiae, P. dlourescens, A. globiformis, S. griseoflavus, P. gelatic, B. lipolyticum, A. luteus, A. lipoferum, A. lwolfii, B. laterosporous, P. marinoglutinosa, B. macerans, P. nigraclens, P. putida, L. plantarum, B. pumilus, B. polymyxa, B. stationis, L. salivarius, B. subtilus, B. Succinogenes, A. simplex, B. subtilus, S. thermopolis , A. terreus, M. verrucaria, T. viride. K. zopfit.

Most cotton swabs nowadays "bend" when you apply pressure.  This makes them useless for craft projects (such as blending pencil leads in graphite or colored pencils).  These are firm and won't bend, so work well for crafts.

IMPORTANT NOTE: BUY THE KIND IN THE WHITE BOTTLE, NOT THE BLACK ONE.Amazon recently intermixed the reviews for two different PS (phosphatidylserine) products. Both are made by Jarrow, and Amazon sells both of them.  I can see why Amazon was confused, because the labels are virtually identical.  However, the products are NOT equally effective.  Combining the reviews has confused a lot of people, and has also resulted in some people ordering the wrong product. (I did it myself recently, and had to call Amazon to cancel the mistaken order.) The labels look the same, and the reviews are intermixed, but the product inside is very different.The only way to tell them apart is from the color of the bottle.The Jarrow PS100 in the BLACK BOTTLE is  NOT the one I am recommending. It's from genetically modified soybeans.  The capsules are large and hard to swallow. They contain a brown powder which is not very effective. I have to take three or four of them to get the same effect as the other product, described below.The Jarrow PS100 in the WHITE BOTTLE is made from sunflowers, not soybeans.  It is  NOT genetically modified. The gel caps are small and easy to swallow.  The product is easy to absorb, and very potent.  This is the product I am recommending below.WHY I TAKE PS* I started taking PS a few months ago, when I was dealing with high stress and had high cortisol levels, making it difficult for me to relax and unwind.* Taking it made an almost immediate difference.* Months later, I still find that when I'm stressed, I still find that PS relaxes me.  I feel like it calms my mind without sedating me.* When I take it, I feel better; I sleep better, and my short term memory seems better.* When I miss a day or two, I start noticing the same old short term memory problems:  I'll go into the kitchen, then forget what I went in there for.  When I take it, this seems much more rare.  It's not that the PS caused the problems; I was experiencing them before the PS; it's that the PS seems to make my memory sharper and clearer, on days when I take it.* When I take PS at night, I tend to wake up the next morning feeling more refreshed than usual.* It's one of the few supplements I consider essential.WHAT I LIKE ABOUT THIS FORMULA:* This formula (in the blue/gold container) is made from sunflowers, not soy (so, no GM residues.)* It comes in soft gels, not capsules.  They are smaller and easier to swallow than capsules.* I feel the effects sooner when I take the soft gels, than when I take Jarrow's other PS formula (or other companies' products) in gelatin capsules.* Because it's so more effective, I need less of it to get a beneficial effect. So the gelcaps are more economical also, in the long run.CAVEATS AND CAUTIONS* On Jarrow's website and elsewhere on the web, it says that this product (in the gel caps) should be kept REFRIGERATED after opening, to prevent it from spoiling.  I wish this was made clearer in the Amazon ads. People who buy a bottle and stick it in a warm cupboard for a couple of months are probably taking a lower potency product as a result.* PS (of whatever type or brand) is most effective when taken with a source of DHA.  PS was originally found in cows' brains, where it's naturally conjugated with DHA, and the lab studies that showed how much it helped with memory, were done with that type.  But then due to fears about mad cow disease, it stopped being sold in that form.  Unfortunately, most PS supplements, including this one, do NOT add in the DHA.  My recommendation is to take a gelcap of PS with a capsule of fish oil or krill oil, both of which are high in DHA.  Or you could take it along with a product like Conjugated Phosphatidylserine with DHA (my second favorite PS product). I like taking the Jarrow and Swanson products together for maximum benefit.Though normal amounts shouldn't have this effect, taking a large amount of PS may make you sleepy. For a while I got into taking several PS capsules a day... we're talking 7 or 8 caps of PS ... and found myself feeling "dozy" during the daytime hours and needing to lie down a lot.  This improved when I cut back on the dose.  My current approach (which is working better) is to take a gelcap in the morning with a little fish or krill oil, then take a couple of gelcaps at night (when it may possibly help you get a good night's sleep).IN SUM:Great product, highly recommended. Just make sure that if you're buying Jarrow's PS, that you get the kind in gel caps, not the powdered stuff.

I have to say, I love these.  Sardines are a near-perfect food, naturally high in CoQ10 and animal-based omega 3 fatty acids. But not all "sardines" are created equal.  Some are large, and higher on the food chain. The ones in this product are small and very low on the food chain, which makes them very low in pthalates and other pollutants that accumulate as we move up the chain.  Besides which, they're delicious. I love them sauteed with a little white rice and some vegetables.One reviewer wrote that the ones he bought were dry; this has not been my experience. If it was true when he bought this product (back in 2008), I don't think it is anymore.

I've bought tower ceramic heaters before from other companies; I thought this one would be similar (just pull it out of the box, plug it in, turn it on, and enjoy the heat). It wasn't. The box should say "assembly required."For starters, the base is not attached and the awkwardly designed pieces, which do not snap together cleanly, need to be held together with one hand while screws are inserted then screwed in with the other.  This sounds easier than it turned out to be in practice.I suppose if I had assembled a few of these previously, it would have gone faster.  But it took a good 40 minutes to find all of the pieces, figure out how they snapped together (they don't fit neatly or easily), find a Phillips screwdriver with a small enough head, line up the plastic parts with holes that needed to be felt rather than seen, and screw the cheap, brittle, easily damaged screws into cheap, brittle, easily damaged plastic.The screws warped and tore when I tried to turn them with the screwdriver. I wasn't turning the driver with great force; they are just very poor screws, like ones you might find "100 for a dollar" in a dollar store.  The plastic on the product's base also tore where the screws went in crooked.When I finally got the base on and the screws in, I stood it up and turned it on. It emitted a strong unpleasant small, and made a rattling noise as it worked.  Usually that happens because the fan is seated poorly or has come loose during delivery, a problem that can't be fixed the the consumer.In sum, this product is:- poorly designed- unusable out of the box (assembly is required, which is not the case with most heaters);- difficult to assemble- and the one I bought had a bad smell and a loud distracting fan sound.It's hard to see why anyone would want to buy it.I have to wonder, did Duraflame test these at all with consumers before selling them?  If so, it's hard to believe they wouldn't have tried to fix the problems, or start over from scratch.
I would say these are just okay.... not my favorite type of Epic bar... the turkey and bison bars taste better and have a better texture.

This product is well-designed, easy to use, and works well to control moisture.  It also helps control odors related to humidity and moisture.  As moisture is absorbed from the air, it drips down and fills the bottom of the container.  When it's full, it's time to throw it away.I have one in my living room, one in my office, one in the bathroom, and one in my van (braced so it can't tip over when the vehicle is in motion).Not surprisingly, the one in the bathroom fills up with water fastest.  But even in the other rooms, and the van, a great deal of moisture is sucked out of the air.The only thing I didn't like about the product I bought was the old orange/blue label, which was, well, ugly (bordering on fugly).  From the picture on Amazon it appears that they have replaced the old label with one that you won't mind having in your house.

SERRAPEPTASE - 120,000 SPU CAPSULESDAY 1: 10/12/14I have chronic sinus congestion, and noticed this morning, to my surprise, that my breathing cleared up about 20 minutes after taking this product.I was surprised by this effect, because I've taken serrapeptase before without noticing anything similar.  When I took it in the past, I usually took one or two 40,000 SPU capsules (for a total dosage of 80,000 SPU). Today I took two 120,000 SPU capsules (for a total dosage of 240,000 SPU.) The larger dose is what appears to have made a difference.I should mention that I was not taking serrapeptase alone.  I took it in water along with some other enzymes, on an empty stomach.  (I don't take proteolytic enzymes with food, I take them an hour or so before eating.)  I take the other enzymes regularly, but have not noticed them helping my breathing.  It was the addition of serrapeptase that appears to have made a difference.After noticing the clearer breathing, out of curiosity, I typed in "serrapeptase mucus" in my browser, and found some web pages and videos saying that others have experienced this effect.  One Youtube video by John Gray talks specifically about the effects of serrapeptase on mucus and congestion.  Just google the name of the video if you'd like to watch it: "Serrapeptase reduces inflammation and mucus in the body"As Mr. Gray points out, "When you have mucus in your gut, fungus can grow in your gut."  So clearing out mucus could have beneficial effects for people trying to clear up fungal infections.I'll keep taking it and report back in a few days, but my initial response is, I like this product.ADDENDUMS:1) I took more serrapeptase later in the day, and did not notice  the mucus-thinning effect, maybe because I'd eaten some food not long before.2) I noticed this at the end of the day that my vision suddenly seemed dramatically clearer.  When I look at the edges of letters I'm typing on a computer screen, they appear crisp and clear, not blurred as they sometimes do.  This totally surprised me.  I like reading in bed but sometimes have a hard time doing so because my eyes aren't up to it.  At the end of Day 1, I found, to my total surprise, that I was able to read fine print with less light. I'm typing this on my computer.... I would usually blow up the lettering to a large side to read more easily, but I can read it fine using a very small font.  The serrapeptase is the only thing I'm doing differently.So -- two effects so far, both of them unexpected and remarkable.(Later note: DAY 2: my vision is still crisp and clear, and I'm reading a very tiny font with no problems on my computer screen.)(Later note: DAY 3: my vision seems back to normal today. (I can read small print but it's not as crisp/clear as it looked on Days 1 and 2)I should emphasize that (1) I am taking serrapeptase with some other enzymes (NOW Super Enzymes); and the clearer breathing and eyesight did NOT happen when I took serrapeptase at a lower dose.  Some people, like Ray Sahelian, recommend taking a very small dose; but when I took a small dose, it didn't have any noticeable effect.SIDE EFFECTS:On Day 1, I noticed some itching on my arms about two hours after taking it in the morning.  It lasted ten or fifteen minutes, then faded away.  When I took serrapeptase later in the day, it didn't have this effect.I also noticed some belching in the evening on Day 1 ... a by-product of the digestive process I guess. I think it was because I hadn't drunk enough water during the day.  With the enzyme doing so much inside of me, I'm going to need to remember to increase my water consumption.DAY 9: 10/21/14I've been taking serrapeptase for the last nine days. I usually take a couple of capsules of SP along with olive leaf extract and another enzyme supplement with water in the morning, then once or twice during the day.  I still feel that it's beneficial, and, I think, it's gradually clearing up a chronic sinus condition.  My breathing is clearer. I was exposed to a cold a few days ago, but didn't catch it.  I believe the supplements I'm taking are helping.DAY 32: 11/3/14Still taking serrapeptase, and I still feel like it's helping me.  I'm not I can explain or justify why I feel that way  I usually take 6 or 7 capsules a day on an empty stomach, (2 or 3 in the morning before breakfast; 2 or 3 at night; and sometimes a couple during the day.)As an experiment, I tried dissolving the content of a capsule in my mouth once.  I do NOT recommend doing so.  After about ten minutes, I had a burning sensation in the back of my throat.  I'm not sure why... serrapeptase is only supposed to dissolve dead tissue... but it felt like it "burned" my throat, which felt a little raw for a couple of days.

WHAT I LIKE:* It's more natural than most vitamin C supplements. Most are synthetic; this one is derived from food.* Because it's more natural and is made from acerola berries, the vitamin C is presumably in a more absorbable form.* I like the idea of taking supplements in powder form, not tablets or capsules, and like that you can just mix this in juice or water.* The glass bottle. It's a high quality dark brown glass which protects the product inside from light, which can damage supplements.* The taste is okay. Not terrific, but not terrible either.WHAT I DISLIKE:THE LABEL:Products should be labeled clearly in a way that is easy to read and understand. This one is not.  Most of the print on the label is small and white against a multicolored background, making it a challenge to find the simplest information. I needed a magnifying glass and lamp to understand it, and even then there were parts I couldn't read.THE PRICE:What matters when buying powdered vitamin C isn't the price per bottle, but the price per gram.According to the label there are 302 mg of vitamin C in each serving, and 31 servings per container. The serving size is 1.5 teaspoons. This means there are only 9.3 grams of vitamin C in the entire bottle.  The very cheapest I've found this product on Amazon is $17.17.  $17.17 divided by 9.3 means you are paying $1.85 per gram.Let's compare it to another product available on Amazon: Nutribiotic Ascorbate Bio-C Powder  (which is pure vitamin C, no acerolo berries).  A 16 ounce bottle costs of Bio-C powder costs about $22.00.  Each teaspoon contains 3000 mg (3 grams) of vitamin C. There are 181 teaspoons in the container, which equals 543 grams. The cost of Bio-C powder is $0.04 per gram.Would you rather pay $1.85 per gram, or $0.04 per gram? Healthforce may be a wonderful product, but you are paying almost FIFTY TIMES MORE for it than Bio-C.I can understand natural products costing more than synthetic, but the price difference here is astronomical.THE INGREDIENTS:This product contains maltodextrin, a sweet-tasting white powder often used in processed foods as a thickener or a filler. (Maltodextrin is a partially hydrolyzed starch used as a bulking agent in artificial sweeteners.) Opinions vary about whether or not it's healthy for the human body.NOT FOR MEGADOSESIf you're goal is to take a large dose of vitamin C at an affordable price it's not going to happen with this product.  Some people, for example, like to do a periodic vitamin C "flush" in which they clean out their intenstinal tract periodically by taking large doses of vitamin C. I do this myself at least once a month. I usually end up taking 20 grams of vitamin C when I do a flush. This costs about 80 cents when I use Bio-C, and I only have to take a few teaspoons full.  It would cost almost $40, and I would have to take TWO FULL BOTTLES of Healthforce Truly Natural Vitamin C to take that much vitamin C using this product.CONCLUSIONSFor people who just want to add a little vitamin C to their diet, the amount they'd get from a glass of orange juice,  this product should be fine.  But for people who want to take large doses of Vitamin C, it's not a good choice.  So whether it's the right choice for you would come down to why you're taking it and how much vitamin C you want to take.

When Dead Like Me came out, I liked it so much that I set aside time to watch it every week.The first episode was great.  The concept was promising. The casting seemed perfect. It's still hard to imagine anyone else playing the lead character, the slacker reaper, George.As the weeks passed, problems became apparent.  There were interesting elements in every episode, but other elements that  dragged the show down.  It's odd that the writers couldn't see the problems, because viewers could, and bailed on the show in large numbers as a result.What worked about the series were the relationships among the "undeads," particularly George and Rube. The actor playing Rube brought an intensity that was the perfect counterbalance to George's apathy.  The revelations in the final episodes about his character and his family, particularly his daughter, were nicely crafted and beautifully acted.What ruined Dead Like Me were the seemingly endless interludes dwelling on George's family.  In a typical episode, we might see George's mother argue with her sister about what to wear or what to have for dinner; watch George's mother be caustic and nasty to her father; watch George's father look morose and wander off; watch George's mother sell her house; watch George's sister steal toilet seats and deny that she was stealing them; watch George's sister make lunch; watch George's sister try on makeup for the first time; watch George's sister stop using makeup; watch George's mother have an affair; watch George's father have an affair; watch George's mother and sister move into a new house; watch the family's dog get sick; watch the family's dog get hit by a car; etc., etc., etc. Most of this had little if anything to do with the episode's main story arc. It became a tedious kind of filler, truly difficult after a while to keep watching.It's one thing for the characters to be trapped in an endless kind of purgatory; it's another thing to ask the audience to endure it, week after week, when it's clear that it's pointless and going nowhere.  Audiences bailed, and I'd say this was the reason.  So Dead Like Me died young, like its protagonist. So it goes.

WHAT I LIKE:* Some reviewers wrote that this product wasn't sweet enough for them.  I have to say I was surprised, because in my experience, if anything, it's overly sweet.  I used a whole teaspoon in a smoothie, and it was waaaaay too sweet for my taste.  Even a half teaspoon is sweeter than I like. I'd recommend starting with 1/4 teaspoon of this product, as the bottle suggests.  You can always add more if that's not sweet enough for your taste.* It does not affect blood sugar.  Again, some people have disputed this, but my experience has been that it's safe in this regard.  This is important to me because I'm hypoglycemic. Sugary foods (high in sucrose or fructose) can literally kick me into insulin shock. I've never had that happen with stevia.WHAT I DISLIKE:* There's something about the flavor of stevia that puts me off. It's nice when I want to add a little sweetness but I'll never be a big fan.* Stevia is often promoted as a health food, but I'm not sure this is accurate.  (Even soy was once thought to be a health food, but most people have now realized it's not.)  It does have effects that go beyond adding a little sweetness.  In some countries stevia is used as a form of birth control. This isn't an issue for me - no plans to father a child - but if a food affects your reproductive system that dramatically, it's worth asking if it might also be having other effects you're not aware of.  In any case, you should use it with caution if you're trying to get pregnant.

It's odd to find someone selling AppleWorks 6 in 2014. It hasn't been updated since 2004, and is not designed for today's Macs. It's a shame, because it was reasonably good software in its day.If you bought your Mac in the last year or two, don't bother buying this software. But if you have an older Mac you *may* be able to use it.Case in point: I have a Mac Pro which can't run Appleworks.  It's an older Mac Pro, circa 2009, using the Snow Leopard operating system. I was able to install Appleworks on it but it crashes frequently and creates conflicts with my other software. So I've found it by and large unusable on that machine.  This was a little irksome because I have thousands of files written and formatted in Appleworks, and had no way to open them after it stopped working on my Mac.Interestingly though, I was able to install it and use it without problems on my Macbook Pro laptop, which I bought in 2010.  The MacBook Pro is also running Snow Leopard. I'm still using it successfully on that machine.If you do decide to take a chance on it, before you will be able to install it, you would first need to install Rosetta (which used to come as part of the older Mac OS.  (You can find Rosetta online if you poke around long enough.)  But again, don't bother trying unless you're using an older Mac.  Best to look for current software instead.
To be honest, I wasn't expecting much. I was surprised to find a nicely paced, intelligent and engaging movie.

So having watched the first season:The first episode of Extant was excellent... good writing, editing and (for the most part) acting.  The child actor who plays Ethan was particularly well cast.The second episode was pretty good.After that, it went downhill rapidly.The concepts are good, and the production values are excellent. But the writing is awful, and becomes worse as the season moves along.  Characters speak their subtext, then speak it three or four more times in each scene to make sure the audience "gets" it.  Very little happens in each episode to move the story forward.  Since so little is happening, the story is padded with unnecessary characters to use up the time.I can imagine how frustrated Halle must be feeling, having committed to this series, which could have been so promising, then seeing it degenerate so quickly into pablum.

An excellent product.It has a good balance of l-ascorbate and electrolytes, from a trusted company.  It dissolves nicely and tastes okay - i.e., it's not overly sour like some ascorbate powders.Some buffered "C" powders taste like chalk, because the calcium in them is literally made from chalk. This one has high quality minerals, which dissolve better and are better absorbed.In sum, I would say Perque Potent C Guard is a good choice for those who can afford it.  But shop around first because even on Amazon, some vendors are more affordable.For those on tight budgets, I would skip this one and look for other buffered C powders.  Just make sure they contain l-ascorbate.

I've tried three brands of coconut water in the past few days.  Of the ones I've tried lately, this is the best tasting, and a good value at its current price.WHAT I LIKE ABOUT IT:* It tastes good.* It's affordable.  The price for a twelve pack is very reasonable, especially if you have Amazon prime and don't pay extra for shipping.WHAT I DISLIKE:* It's a little too sweet for me.  While I like the taste, I don't need the extra fructose.  (Like many people, I'm trying to avoid fructose, so would not want to drink too much of this.)* The label says it's "pure coconut water" but the small print says it has "less than 1 percent added fruit sugars."  I don't know the ins and outs of the labeling laws, but how can something be "pure coconut water," then have added sugar?I would give it five stars if they would take out the added fructose.WOULD I RECOMMEND IT?* Yes, but with a caveat. If you're trying to watch your carbs, be aware that one carton of this provides 15 grams of carbs.  So you might need to split it in half and drink half each day, if you're following a paleo diet and trying to limit yourself to 20 grams of carbs a day.

This is the second time in recent weeks that I've bought a coconut water product expecting to like it, but found myself barely able to finish it. This one claims to be raw, 100 percent organic, with no added flavors .... it should be a good product... but the bottle I just drank tasted unpleasant and rancid, and has a strong plastic aftertaste.I have read other reviews online from people who like this product, and have good things to say about the brand. So it may be that I just got a bad batch.

I bought a case of these on sale, hoping and expecting to like them. They're coconut water, and are USDA organic... what could go wrong?Well... sorry to say...1. These are not pure coconut water.2. They are reconstituted. The question is, what kind of water is used to dilute  the concentrate?  Is it ordinary using tap water, which tends to be full of fluoride, chlorine, and dozens of other contaminants. If it's filtered or distilled, I expect they'd say so, since that would be a selling point.  I don't drink tap water at home; why would I want it in my coconut water?3. The small print says the flavor is "enhanced" with "natural flavors" which the Coco Libre website says are from "fruit and vegetable sources." Which fruits? Which vegetables? Why not identify them?  What if they're ones people are allergic to, or trying to avoid? Are the fruits and veggies used to make the "natural flavors" organic, or GMO?4. For that matter, real coconut water tastes wonderful right out of the coconut; why "enhance" it with a bunch of undisclosed flavorings? Perhaps because it tastes a little ucky when it's reconstituted?5. I like the very light sweetness of real coconut water. There are 14 grams of carbs and 13 grams of sugars in this product. I have to watch my blood sugar, and was only able to finish about a third of a carton before feeling "sugared out."

The directions said to take 1-1/4 droppers full to get 50 mg of zinc.  But what's a dropper? Each time I tried filling the dropper that came with the bottle, it filled to a different level. Sometimes it filled almost to the top, other times it only filled 1/4 of the way.I finally ended up taking a nearly-full dropper, which I poured into a spoon and swallowed. I have a cast iron stomach and rarely get sick from foods, but in less than three minutes I was in the bathroom leaning over the toilet, sure I was going to vomit.  I almost did, then the feeling passed. I still feel queasy (twenty minutes later, as I'm writing this), but I don't think I'm going to throw up.After this experience, I got out a magnifying glass and read the (very) small print on the label. The very-small-print instructions said that because it's so concentrated, you should:1) NOT take it on an empty stomach (I had done so)2) Take it diluted (I hadn't done diluted it at all)3) Break  up the dose into several smaller doses during the day (I had taken it all at once, but again, with the dropper filling to different levels on every try, what's a full dose?)4) The directions also said to shake well, which I hadn't done.So in the company's defense, they did advise the above safeguards when taking it. But the print on the bottle is very tiny, light print on a very dark blue label. I really did need a magnifying glass to read it.So I can't say my first experience was good.  But I'll give it a few days then try again, following the directions this time. If it works out better when I follow the company's directions, I'll revise my review and upgrade the rating.

What I like about DE (Diatomaceous earth):1) It kills bugs.  (It works best on large ones.)  It does this not by poisoning them, but by dehydrating them.  They walk on it, and it works its way up into their carapace (the outer body wall of an insect) and punctures it. This makes them dehydrate and die.)This has led some people, who misunderstand what's happening, to claim that is "dehydrating," as if taking it would dehydrate a person or animal. This is not the case. The dehydration in insects occur because the diamond-sharp shards of the DE cut their exoskeletons.  (The reason it harms insects, rather than people or pets, is because to an insect, a shard of DE is large enough relative to their body size to do damage.)2) It kills worms and parasites inside pets and farm animals. Farmers have used it for decades to safely deworm horses and other livestock, and flush parasites from their systems.3) Many pet owners have used it successfully to deworm and de-parasite their dogs and cats.  It does this without causing any harm to the animal. In fact it benefits the animal by scrubbing debris out of its colon.4) It kills worms, eggs and parasites inside people (pork eaters, take note... you probably have worms.  If so, try taking DE for a couple of months.  Just make sure it's food grade.)5) Some people have claimed that that taking DE killed their candida infections or other fungal infections.  I'm not sure if this is accurate, but considering its colon cleansing properties, it makes sense that it could help against such infections.What I dislike about DE:1) I inhaled some a couple of times and it made me cough. I believe those who say it's not harmful when inhaled, but it is a dry powder, irritating when inhaled.  If you're pouring some into a container, try not to make a dust cloud when you do so or breathe it in.  And don't get the dust in your eyes.2) While it kills large bugs effectively, it does not work as well, in my experience, for tiny little bugs like kitchen ants.  To kill and repel tiny insects, I would suggest white (cleaning) vinegar as a better alternative.

Like any fish product, this one has some pluses and minuses.PLUSES:* This product has a light, pleasant flavor.  I just ate a tin of them with some sauerkraut... delicious!* One tin has 19 grams of protein, and zero carbs.* Chub mackerel has 1000 mg of DHA per 100 grams, which is tremendously beneficial to the brain.  (Our brains are largely made of DHA, and we need some in our diet throughout our lives)* Chub mackerel has 900 mg of EPA per 100 grams (another natural component of fish oil), which helps bolster mood and thinking.* To me this is the best point: According to Wikipedia, a 100 gram serving of chub mackerel has over 400 mg of PS (phosphatidylserine), which is also wonderful for the brain (and works best when taken or eaten along with DHA.  DHA and PS are naturally complexed in this product. (PS needs DHA, according to some studies, to do its positive work in the brain.)MINUSES:* It comes in those little tins sardines come in, which I believe are still made of aluminum.  If I could have a wish magically granted, it would be to have products like this available in glass. (With that said, since it's packed in oil, rather than an acid base like tomato sauce, I doubt that much aluminum is transferred to the fish.)* It's expensive. (But then again, consider what it would cost to supplement with EPA, DHA, CoQ10, and PS.)* There is also the  question of mercury.  I've read some reports that mackerel is "low in mercury," but what does this really mean? According to wikipedia, chub mackerel has .088 ppm of mercury (not particularly low.)However, I suspect the fish in these tins may have less, because they are smaller (lower on the food chain) than some chub mackerel.  They are close in size to sardines, which have only  0.013 ppm of mercury. (The size of the fish matters because large fish accumulate more toxins; small fish are generally much safer to eat.)  Pregnant women should check with their doctors before eating fish; the rest of us can probably eat this sort of fish safely.IN SUMTo me the benefits of eating Chub Mackerel to me, far outweigh the risks.  And this brand has a mild and pleasant flavor.  I highly recommend it.

DISAPPOINTING.I tried this product hoping it would open up my breathing, which was stuffed up due to pollen and allergic rhinitis.  I bought this particular formula because I was hoping to avoid the artificial coloring in the regular product.  I took two 24 milligram gel caps with water.I'm not sure why, but it didn't help.  I had taken it once before, a few years ago, and it had helped clear my breathing.  I'm not sure if the formula has changed, or I got a bad batch, or if something else was going on. If anything, the benadryl seemed to make some some head/neck inflammation I had been experiencing, worse.SO I TRIED...After trying this product with no result, I ordered a different product I'd used previously to clear my sinuses, Jarrow sustained-release NAC (N Acetyl Cysteine).  It worked better for me than the Benadryl.P.S. Several reviewers have said they find this product (Benadryl gel caps) hard to open. I'm not sure why they're having problems, unless they're forgetting to remove the backing. Here's an easy way to open them:1) Pull out a perforated sheet with 12 capsules on it2) Tear off one of the 12 squares (holding one capsule)3) Bend back the indicated corner (marked with a black arrow), and tear off the paper backing.4) Then just slit the foil with a fingernail or thumbnail, and pop out the capsule.

This equipment is just too fragile. After assembling it, I tested it by having my 50 lb daughter step on it and it immediately lost a leg in a sudden crack. Also, the balls are of poor quality.  So even before gameplay, it was out of the running.

This is not quite a high fidelity system. It's a bit too boomy. But for when you need a portable boom-box, it does quite nicely. It paired easily with my iPhone and iPads, but I can't get it to pair with my Windows 10 Asus tablet, or Samsung Note tablet. In which case, there is a mini-jack style auxiliary cable which works quite well, although plugging it in automatically disables any Bluetooth connection.Controls are simple. There is a "handle" built in in the center of the back panel which makes grabbing it and going easy.Sound is pretty loud but not deafening. Sound quality is pretty good. I plugged it into my MacBook Pro, and let it play while I worked and it didn't run out of battery power, so it's at least 8 hours per charge. The power cord is shorter than I would like. The design is stylish and attractive.If you need portable music for things like picnics or backyard activities, and have an iOS device, I think this will workout nicely.

To a user, a tablet is mostly screen, and this convertible has quite a nice screen. An IPS display with excellent viewing angles and nice color reproduction. It's reminiscent of the similar panel in the original iPad and the iPad 2, not a Retina class display, but nice.Unfortunately, that's about it when it comes to competitive features.The box is sluggish. To the point my son asked me about why Netflix navigation was so slow.
