So, I bought a copy of Geekbench 3 and ran comparisons for raw 64-bit performance against my mid-2014 Retina Macbook Pro, my aging iPhone 5 S, and the iPad Mini 4 at my desk.Asus Transformer: Single Core 957, Multi-core 2892Retina Macbook Pro: Single Core 3942, Multi-core 15326 (this is the 4 core i7 variant)iPhone 5 S: Single Core 1346, Multi-core 2297iPad Mini 4: Single  Core 1712, Multi-core 2944So for single core operations, a 2+ year old phone is beating this PC! And for Multi-core it's getting about the same marks as a device that weighs about 1/3rd as much and has half the cores. That is just not right, and it shows as it tries to keep up with the demands of a desktop operating system.Single core performance makes web browsing in particular unpleasant. Many times a page will start to load, I'll tap on a visible link, and then the page will finish reformatting itself and process my tap as if it were on a different link and load a page I didn't want to visit. On a faster computer, like my phone, the page would have reached a final layout faster than I could tap. This is annoying and makes visiting heavy Javascript sites like Yahoo sports a chore.The keyboard joins nicely with the tablet, but the keyboard itself is mediocre. I've reviewed several iPad Bluetooth docks with more satisfying typing experiences. For someone coming from using Apple trackpads, the integrated trackpad is abysmal. I can't believe they thought this trackpad was up to snuff. Luckily, the tablet digitizer is well done, so you can bypass the trackpad for navigation.When you unpack your convertible, be prepared to wait. The battery comes fully discharged and it takes a half hour to get enough charge to boot. The charger uses a mini-USB plug, but the charger itself is 9V instead of the standard USB 5V. USB-C would have been a more modern choice. Battery life is quite good; it had better be given the weight of the device and the low performing Atom processors used. Available storage at the beginning is only about 36GB once Window's needs are taken into account. Bloatware is fairly minimal for a PC. The stickers on the palm rest are easily scraped off.I purchased a 128GB micro-SD chip to supplement the integrated disk store, and that was easily added via the built-in SD card reader.The Windows 10 experience is hobbled by the Atom processor, but Cortana works well and is my favorite feature of the computer. I installed Chrome and Netflix, and that's much of what I use a tablet for. There doesn't appear to be an included camera app, but I found one on the Windows Store. Both cameras are awful with horrid color reproduction and a lot of graininess.I don't know why anyone would buy this machine.[Update: since the comments seem to think it is unfair that I'm comparing this convertible to a phone, I ran the Kraken 1.1 Javascript benchmark on both this box and my aging 2011 MacBook Pro which is an i5 dual core. Safari on the 2011 MBP completed the benchmark in 1.5s, my phone does it in 4.2s, and Edge on the Asus in 8.9s. The older box is nearly 6x faster at running JavaScript which would show up in dealing with the ad encrusted sites of the Internet. This computer is really slow by modern standards.Update 2: A commenter indicated my measured Kraken times were unlike his, so I remeasured. This time I got a half as terrible 4.7s so this box is only 1/3rd as fast as a 4+ year old i5 laptop. I guess there must have been a hungry background process running to interfere with the benchmark run.]

These days, I will settle for a product that isn't overly clever, but just executes the basics. This is a thermometer so it's most basic task is to quickly record a person's body temperature. Does it do so? Yes, in about 5 seconds if you get it properly placed under the tongue. Is it accurate? I don't know, if it is, my son runs a bit hot, and I run a bit cool.It has an app, does it execute on making a competent iOS app? Yes. I make my living as an iOS dev, and I'd say I'd be reasonably proud to have written this app. It's a bit more cluttered than I'd have gone with, but presumably they hit the style they were going for. Also, it does have a bad case of featuritis, and could have been a much simpler app.  It paired quickly with the thermometer and I was storing temperature measurements for my family members within seconds. I don't know what the privacy implications, or why the app wants my actual birthday, you'd think month/year would be medically close enough.As for issues. It was hard getting my son to get an acceptable reading under his tongue, but we eventually got one. That could just be lack of focus on his part. The protective cover almost got lost in the packaging, be sure to retrieve it.  I don't know if the added technology makes this more useful than a cheaper, non-smart thermometer, maybe if you are tracking the course of an illness.For what it is, a nice product.

I'd rather not have the corner of my kitchen be a mess of chargers and wires. With this 4 port charger, it is at least only a mess of wires.Using a USB Ampmeter, I am able to see how much current it delivers to plugged in devices. And it varies a lot, wherein a fully drained tablet, which in my case is either an iPad Air 2 or a Samsung Galaxy Note 12.2, can pull in 2A or more from their own chargers, I've never seen this charger deliver more than 1.6A and often seen it practically idling at .8A. It seems as there is some difference between the individual ports they can deliver or how much Amperage the charger negotiates with any given device. So, I don't think this delivers as well as a dedicated charger, but I use it anyway for overnight charging when it doesn't matter much.Overall design is good with a long power cord which I hide behind my kitchen side cabinet.I've used this with an iPhone 5 S, my tablets, a cheap Kindle, a battery pack, my Apple Watch, and an old Apple Watch. Again, I don't think I get as fast a charging as with a dedicated charger, but they do work.

The world is filled with different designs of water bottles. Everyone, it seems, has run down to their local patent attorney with some new mechanism for making a more complicated water bottle. So, it's nice to see someone execute a fairly simple design that satisfies my basic needs for a water bottle.Does it seal in the water when closed? Yes and no. When you first close it, there are a few drops of water caught on the outside of the seal, and those can be shaked out, but everything else is snug in the bottle.Can I grip it easily? Yes, it has a gradual, and elegant curvature which allows even my smallish adult hands to comfortably grasp its middle. This allows for more insulating void at the top and bottom.Is it easy to clean?  Yes, very and unlike a straw design, I'm reasonably sure it's clean.Other, less critical features also come up. It's insulated so there is no sweating of condensed water all over my stuff. The shell is a delightful anodized aluminum like on an iPhone which brings color and the promise of toughness and durability. The sealing lever has a satisfying mechanism that is easy without being loose.Capacity could be a bit larger.To sum up. A quality item.

As a router, this is a nice, simplified system for getting online. The previous router in that corner of the house was an Airport Express which does not support ac style WiFi. Of course, the only device in the house that currently supports ac is my iPad Air 2, but as time goes on and old iPhones and computers are switched out for new ones, this will change. Nor can I determine whether the Air 2 is even taking advantage of ac networking. Unlike the Airport Express, with its Airport Utility, I don't have control over what network standard is used. That level of configuration has been simplified out.I went about taking some quick measurements of speed. In the same room, both this router and the Airport Express were giving me 30 Mbits/sec downloads and 15 Mbits/sec uploads with either my iPad Air 2 or my iPhone 5 S to the Internet. When I went 60 feet away to the opposite end of the house, through a brick wall, there was a more substantial difference I'm going to attribute to the larger, more antenna filled space of the OnHub, I was able to still get 27 Mbits/sec with the on hub with my Air 2 and the OnHub. My iPhone 5 S had much more variability, getting 5Mbits/sec on one run and 15Mbits/sec on another. When I switched to the Airport Express, my throughput dropped substantially to 21 Mbits/sec on the Air 2. Again there was more variability with the 5 S, but it had about half the average throughput when using Apple's router.That was for connecting with the outside Internet. I also tried transfers within my home network using my trusty 2011 MacBook Pro, that was able to transfer a 257MB folder in 32 seconds when connected to the Airport Express and 16 seconds when connected to this OnHub. Both in the same room as the router. Quite an improvement.This is not to say that you couldn't get the same performance in a lower cost hub, but beyond the raw numbers, this hub has value. Because of its Objet d'art aspirations, I can put this hub in plain view on a shelf or side table where it will work better and not have it ruin the esthetics of my home. It comes with narrow dark grey Ethernet cables, and a thin dark grey charging cable so as to be inconspicuous as practical when disguised as a statue. I wish the cables were longer so allow for discrete installation on higher shelves. As it is, I ended up putting it right in the middle of my house, proudly displayed on the side cabinet in my kitchen where only the most curious guest will figure out it's something more than an abstracted cylinder.The associated iPhone app is cleanly done and non-techy. There are a few high end features buried in it like port forwarding and dynamic DNS, but in general, it keeps things at a level appropriate for the non-expert. It's also interesting to be able to remotely see what devices are connected, so when I was off in Chicago on a trip, I could open the app and see which tablets were connected back home. I can use the app to set the brightness of the colored LED glow. In a bedroom, I'd set this to zero, whereas in my kitchen, I set it quite bright to act as a night light.So, in general, this is a simple premium router. Whether you'd want to pay the premium is up to you.

First off, I don't care for this product. Too fishy. However, my daughter loves seaweed crisps, and while her initial reaction was "too spicy" and to reach for the milk, this passed within seconds and she now says she likes it. Similarly, my wife has no problems with it.My son doesn't even want to be in the same room with it though and some will dislike the smell.I'm concerned that the first ingredient listed is starch, with actual seaweed towards the bottom. So, this is probably not a health food.Anyway, if you like fishy smelling seaweed, this may be for you.

These are serviceable cups but are not of the highest quality. The plastic is on the thin side. The printing is rough. The cups I received have the Tennessee Vols T logo and a rendering of their mascot Smokey. Neither of these are crisply printed, and Smokey could have done with another color ink.The cups hold water, and I doubt you are going to be holding a magnifying glass up to it. So maybe these will work out.

As a simple home owner, I'm just a reasonably adept amateur electrician. Yes, I did take instrumentation electronics in graduate school, but that was not big on alternating current. Anyway, I'm not really qualified to review this product from the point of view of someone who would actually want to buy it. I'm not a professional electrician, and as far as I can tell, this device would be useful only for a professional. As for me, I cannot get it to work.First, it didn't work with my little cheap multi-meter as it had integrated leads, so there was no socket to attach this device. Then when I purchased the cheapest multimeter I could find with compatible sockets, the readout always indicates there is 5A of current regardless of if I'm running current through it or not. Yes, the device is on. Yes, I'm only putting it around one wire of a circuit. Maybe I broke it somehow. Maybe I got a lemon. Whatever is going on, it isn't going to be useful to me.It seems nicely made out of sturdy plastic and the loop is flexible and narrow enough to get through narrow openings. If I could have made it work, I'd have given it a good review. But I couldn't.

The nicest feature of this power strip is the ample cord. I recently reviewed one with a 3 foot cord, and I'm glad to try out a 6 footer.Other than that, it's an OK if extremely cheap looking and feeling power strip with the sockets closer together than I'd like.It's nice to know my ground prong is properly connected and I guess I might use the socket dust covers someday.You could do worse.

I've been using this over the weekend to plug in my various tools as I rebuild my bathroom. It seems a decent enough midrange product. Not junk but not premium. They've managed to make its metal shell look like cheap plastic, but scrape it off and there is some metal inside.There are sliding plastic covers for the prong holes. They are to keep dust out, but in a non - dusty environment, they are just a hinderance.My greatest concern is the shortness of the cable. I tried it in a couple situations where it was too short: lying on the floor while plugged into my bathroom outlet, and lying on my work desk while plugged into a floor level outlet. Another couple feet would have made a big difference.Anyway, if you need an inexpensive non - junky power strip, this will do.

I've received several of these lately, and while my kids might prefer the squeeling pig, there is something to be said for the excellent choice of materials to evoke the dinosaurs scaly hide. Also, the action is great. You can choose to control the tiny arms, or get your whole hand around the jaws to really bite. The teeth, while firm enough to be scratchy, don't hurt when biting.I'm just impressed by the design and craftsmanship of this piece. Great job.We decided this Dino would have a snooty British accent and be named Mr. Bitingsworth.

I've had the pleasure of reviewing several of these well made hand puppets recently, and this is the worst of a very good lot. While well-made and clever it isn't as fun as its brethren and also, my wife tells me it's been shedding.The gimmick of this one is that you can rotate its head owl-like all the way around with a knob hidden in its hand pocket. Cute, but for whatever reason, not something I could riff off.Also there is wingtip Velcro, so I guess you can store it like it's sleeping. Cute.If you like owls, and don't mind a bit of shedding, this may work for you.

After my 8 year old daughter assembled this kit we had a conversation in which she asked me to give this a rating of 1 star. I told her I  reserve 1 star reviews for products that burst into flame or otherwise are safety hazards.  She still thought I should give it 1 star.Her complaint and it is pretty obvious to anyone handling the completed creation. It just will not stay together and falls apart on the slightest perturbation. Plus the lights are pretty lame.But it isn't a safety hazard so 2 stars.

I sat down and played this with my 8 and 10 year old children. This is the first card game I've actually enjoyed competing with them in playing. My 10 year old in particular quickly figured out all the angles of the constantly changing rules, much to the aggravation of the 8 year old who didn't want to give up her princess Keeper cards.I know there are many themed variations of the Fluxx game, but Adventure Time is the reason I grabbed this pack. My son has been watching Adventure Time for years and in general I associate it with genial, smart, wholesomeness. Which fits in well with how you play this game.The game comes in a box about 2x the size of a standard pack of playing cards.

I'd been meaning to get a bench vise for the longest time. I remember my dad having one when I was a kid, and it doesn't seem like a proper workshop without one.This is very much a no frills model. Well, there are two fills, you can rotate it, and the area covering the main screw is armored up as a small anvil.  Both are useful features. I can rotate the vise out of my way by loosening two clasps, good. And I can hammer on, and therefore shape, thin, small pieces of metal. I demonstrated this to my daughter by taking a deadbolt strike and making it L shaped, and then flattened it out again.Installation took 3 longish 5/16" boltsprovided by me. 8mm ones would have worked too. As my bench has a fairly thin top, I reinforced it from underneath the table top with a large piece of wood (half a stair tread, but any wide, thick scrap would have done). There is no fourth bolt hole on the vise as that would have gone through the corner of the table. Once tightened down the vise isn't going anywhere without the whole table.  I took care to place the vise close enough to the edge that it's sliding handle wouldn't hit the tabletop, while still being far enough in that the washers around the bolts wouldn't hit the inside of the table's trim. So, in my case, the vise had to be 2" from two edges of the table top. Remember, it rotates. At this position, there is about " to spare when fully closed. The base jaws are quite severe. The instructions comes with a list of magnetic jaw caps that you can purchase to change the texture of the clamping surface. So, someone doing gunsmithing, for example, might want to purchase a plastic or rubber coated jaw cap so as to not mar components. Amazon sells 4" jaw caps, which sell for a large fraction of the price of the vise.  After buying mounting wood, bolts, washers, nuts and a jaw cap, you can easily double the price of the vise itself.I like this vise. It might not have a high gloss finish, but the screw turns easily and the grip is solid. I guess I now have a proper workshop.

My children have been delighting themselves terrorizing their Mom with this toy. For some reason it's close enough to real to freak her out when it is thrust at her while oinking. Great fun except for my wife.This thing is well crafted, and looks great. I'm particularly taken with the eyelids and the cute hooves.My daughter has named it Chris P. Bacon.

I'm afraid this medium shirt is a bit short of medium, especially in the sleeves. The joints tend to bind up and my wrists are bare.  I'm also not a fan of the fabric as it is both lightweight and scratchy. To my mind, it doesn't seem all that masculine a look.However, unlike the other Wrangler shirt I took delivery of this week, all the buttons are properly sewn on.

My wife is not a fan of pod delivered laundry detergent. I like the convenience well enough, but wouldn't pay much of a premium for it. It is nice tossing one of these into the washer and being done with it, and not getting detergent on my fingers. It's interesting that they advocate throwing 2 into an oversized load; there are no half measures here. \Plus you always know the moment you run out of detergent.As for the actual detergent. It seems to work as well as any other brand. I had hopes it would magically remove an old stain from a white stripe on one of my shirts, but it did not.Smell of washed clothing is good. Some cheaper detergents sort of nauseate me, but this is fine.So, I can recommend this to those who like a little convenience in their lives and don't expect miracles.

I quite like the shape of this shirt. It's masculine and fits well without a lot of flapping around. I'm a medium and this medium shirt fits me well.Being 100% cotton it is on the wrinkly side after a wash, and since I iron about once a decade, it stays a bit wrinkly. There is a bit of reinforcement around the shoulders so it should last.One of the middle buttons isn't stitched well. One wash and the thread is already coming loose. So the craftsmanship isn't perfect. I'll have to sew it back on soon unfortunately.

These headphones are really quite nice. While I still prefer the wired Quiet Comfort model, these have much to recommend them.First, they are optionally cord free. So they don't get entangled with my chair and rip my computer off my desk. Or alternatively, they are corded, but the cord pulls out of its socket before breaking my neck. And the batteries are long lasting. I can go an entire workday and go from 100 to 90% with my usage pattern. As an added bonus, the batteries are rechargeable, a big advantage over the Quiet Comfort which eats AAAs.I'm quite happy that I can simultaneously pair with both my iPhone and my MacBook Pro. I was also able to pair with a Samsung Galaxy Note tablet, although that took a couple tries. Much more convenient than pairing, unpairing and pairing again.Sound isolation is good, as my wife can attest to when I can't hear her speaking, but is, of course worse with noise than the active noise canceling of the Quiet Comfort. Sound quality is good enough; I can't hear the unavoidable recompression errors with what I've been using it for, and there is always that cord.The media controls are small and take getting used to reaching. They should consider putting really big buttons on the side. They work with my Apple devices although the inconvenience make me more likely to just use the device directly.As for comfort, it is only just OK due to weight issues. I was able to mow my lawn using these, and sweating like the ocean the whole time because these are pretty good earmuffs. Still better than wire headphones which would have tangled up whenever I bent down.I'm happy with these as work/desk headphones.

This small bottle is complicated in its design. Leaning towards too complicated. It is straw based, and like all straw based systems bring with it the worry of cleaning a straw. At least most of the straw is detachable.The mouthpiece is comfortable, and because of the straw design, no head tilting is necessary. When clasped, no water escapes, however sometimes it takes a few tries to get the top all clamped down.I was able to fill the bottle full of a half ice mixture and still get the straw through the icebergs and close it up, but 100% ice is not going to allow passage of the straw. Again, standard problem for a straw design.This review was for the smaller bottle, which is really small, probably too small for most purposes not involving a toddler.

This is a nice piece of daily wear jewelry. Religious without being in your face. My wife, who only joined Christianity a couple years ago likes it a good deal. She would like to particularly praise the clasp which is big and easily fastened.So, if you aren't looking for bling, but do want to quietly proclaim your faith, this is a good choice.

I constructed a new longer dryer vent path out to the front of the house, so I needed a new inline fan for that extra oomph. As I didn't want lint clogging the fan, or cluttering up my front yard, I purchased this lint trap. I had seen it used on the TV show Holmes Inspection (available on Netflix) and thought it a great idea. My previous system of venting into an external water trap in my 3 season porch had resulted in an horrible accumulation of lint all over the place, not to mention the fire hazard of flexible ductwork filled with lint.So, I'm happy to report that this does a very good job of stopping lint from progressing through my ductwork. I have not seen so much as a thread get all the way through to my front yard.To get it offset from the wall, and give room for the fan which I placed immediately above it, I mounted this on doubled blocks of 2x6 that I rounded off a bit and painted white before attaching with deck screws to my wall. Then I put screws right through the corners of this trap. It isn't going anywhere. I had a bit of trouble getting a decent seal to the 4 inch flexible ducting from my dryer, and it does whistle a tiny bit, but it looks OK and is functional.My one real issue (and I don't know if this is solvable) is that to clean the trap, I have to jerk the cover out of the box, and this action invariably brings a spray of dryer debris (little bits of hardened paper, etc.) which I have to wipe off my washer--which is immediately below this trap. As others have pointed out, the cover does not fit quite square in the box, but this might just be to allow the cover to come out at all. It doesn't appear to leak hot moist air into the room, which would be an actual problem.I'm quite happy with this product and would recommend it to anyone willing to listen to my epic story of installing a 30 foot dryer vent.

My wife loves this huge pan, but it has its caveats.First, it's big. This is about as big of a pan as you can fit on a homeowner size stovetop. So this will be great when making shepherd's pie.Second, it's easy to clean. Wipe it off or throw it in the dish washer.Third, it's good looking.Now, on the downside, and for what you'd expect in an inexpensive pan, it has a small hotspot. So, if I heat it up over my gas stove, the center will be at 320F (as measured by my infrared thermometer), while the edges will be at 250F. Contrast with a more expensive all clad pan that has a big hunk of metal under the bottom which might vary by 10 or less in the same situation. You aren't going to be able to make giant pancakes in this thing, not unless you like pancakes with raw edges and burnt centers.  Presumably you can cook around this, but this is not a premium pan. Cooker beware. [Update: I actually cooked a pancake and it wasn't that bad, so feel free to use it as such. The non-stick surface has already gotten a tiny chip after 3 weeks, so I'm now worried about durability.]

My children have been using this a lot the last couple weeks, and for what they use it for: watching Netflix and YouTube it has been great. They love the huge screen, which can be propped up anywhere convenient. It's fit in nicely with our iPads, which are also mainly portable TVs to the children.I'm more of a Web browser, so I miss Safari and other iOS apps. I should mention that I make my living writing iPhone and iPad apps, so I might be expected to be unimpressed by this upstart. But, Samsung has made a compelling product in a very Samsungy way. They mainly just threw whatever features they could conjure into a box with really nice specs and hoped enough of it worked out to make people like it.So it's a big wide screen tablet, which makes it mainly a video watching machine. But, you can use split screen multitasking which makes better use of the space. So I can have Chrome and YouTube on the screen at once. It adds something useful. It's rough and feels hacky, and isn't quite as nice as the same feature in IOS 9, but it makes this huge wide screen practical. I've found myself browsing the web in the awkward portrait mode, but it shows a lot of content and works better than landscape.The stylus isn't quite as useful as I would have hoped, but my 8 year old daughter took to drawing with it, and when in use, it is smooth, responsive and quite capable of creating pixel art. I am not a fan of styli, so I haven't done much with it. But, it is much nicer than any stylus you can buy for the current iPad, yes even better then the 53 Pencil. The tablet was designed from the ground up to use one, and it shows.The camera is OK. I am not one to mock people who take photos with tablets. It takes pictures, front and back. There are numerous options. You have the world's largest viewfinder.Bluetooth devices work pretty well. I took a few tries to pair my Bose headphones with it, but once paired the audio quality was fine.  Same with WiFi. I've had no troubles connecting with the various brands of WiFi hubs in the house; it even connected easily to my iPhone's hotspot.Construction is semi-decent. The "leather" back is comfortable and warm. The chrome ring is cheap and old fashioned. The seams are a bit wide. I'm glad there is a mini-SD slot, because 32 GB is not a lot these days. The stylus is a bit cheap feeling. The worst part of the tablet is the home button which an unreliable and creaky.Other than the split screen feature, I would probably have preferred stock Android, and I really miss the keyboard from my iPad. Also, TouchID and good battery life. This one comes with that ridiculous big USB 3 plug, and the next version with the USB C connector will be much improved. As it is, charging takes too long even though Samsung "cheats" by making the charger a bit over (5.3V) the standard  voltage. You will probably want to only charge this with its original charger.In general, an interesting and useful device.

I purchased this because my new door (from Lowe's) had a cutout that was exactly this size. It nestled in nicely and the screws are flush inside their beveled openings (assuming you install it correctly with the beveled side out). The deadbolt fits in the main opening without catching. And it looks nice, if you like shiny chrome finishes. So there's no reason this wouldn't work for you if you have a cutout of exactly the correct dimensions.

My eight year old daughter quickly assembled two of the projects, the airplane and the pontoon boat. The airplane was fragile, and somewhat hard to hold together, and couldn't fly from a rolling takeoff, but was fun nevertheless. The boat was more robust, and was able to drag itself from one end of the bathtub to the other under its own power.  She'd like you know she would give it 5 stars. I was most gratified that she improvised and put together a couple of ad hoc creations, like a little cart and a spinner; free form play is the ideal for kits like this.I think the wings on the plane could have better fasteners, and there could be better descriptions of the control surfaces. Plus, the wings fell off too easily.A fine little kit which my daughter had fun creating with.

Bose did an excellent job with these headphones. They are comfortable, convenient, keep out noise, don't leak sound and sound good.Comfort. I'd say these are as comfortable as in-ear headphones are going to get without a specialized fitting. In the past, I've noticed that other in-ear headphones tend to rub against the ear opening making a noise and irritating the skin, but these seem OK. I can wear these for hours without much issue. (I still prefer over the ear headphones, but for compactness these are good.)Convenience: These work perfectly well with my Apple devices. Apple devices include my Mac Mini which can make use of both the media controls and the microphone via its headphone port. The cord is a good length without being extra long. The controls are easily accessible hanging around collarbone height. For some reason the controls are on the right cord, whereas in my Bose QuietComfort headphones they are on the left. You would be hard pressed to put the wrong bud in your left or right ear as the buds are very asymmetric.Keeping Out the World: My wife had to yell at me this morning to get me to breakfast. She was quite impressed.Keeping the Sound In: Bose is very good at keeping the sound directed at your ear drums and not leaking out to know what you are listening to. Very Private.Sounding Good: The sound is nice and flat. Not as good as my active QuietComfort headphones, but clear and without noticeable distortion.  The microphone does a good job of picking up your voice and doesn't pick up much noise.Some nits: The clip looks quite cheap and brittle. The insulation on the wires is sort of stiff and rubbery in a not-quite premium way.

My 8 year old daughter has given me some notes about this doll. It isn't perfect, the earrings fall off, the hair clip is hard to attach. The dress is really cute, and she loves the butterflies on its clothing.As for myself, it seems like a decent doll, although this character has an awful case of jaundice. There are several parts that are easily lost including the earrings and the tambourine. Manufacturing quality is good. The box is ridiculously hard to get into and to detach the doll from its cardboard shipping position.

One of my favorite possessions is a DeWalt 20V Max (18V) hammer drill. It's a premium, rugged, powerful tool that can do what I need. It's one problem is it's heavy. Really heavy, and after a day of drilling holes to install a fence, my arms could barely lift it. So, there is a place for a lightweight drill, and this one certainly is. If all I need from it is to loosen screws and drill narrow holes then it can do that, easily enough.With the lack of weight, comes the lack of power. Whereas I can use a paddle bit to drill " holes into a log with my DeWalt, and go until the battery overheats (maybe six inches deep), this drill won't go " into the log. Same deal with a 2" hole saw into composite planking; this drill won't drive it more than " before stopping, while my DeWalt zips right through.This is not a premium tool. The case is not formfitting. The bits are sticky out of the box. The LED light goes immediately off with the trigger instead of waiting a few seconds. The battery takes care to slot into place, so you can't just casually snap it into place with the palm of your hand. The flashing pattern to indicate pre-charging is the same as the pattern for charged.  The chuck cover is cheap plastic.I'm also not a fan of tool manufactures labeling 10.8V tools as 12V, but even DeWalt did that with its 20V Max series, so I'll let it pass.The grip is nice enough, soft and a bit tactile. You can remove the belt clip, or switch it over to the other side for lefties. The included bits are a decent steel.If you need a drill for lightweight around the house use and can't afford the really good stuff, then this would be OK if you know what you are getting into. I think I'll get a lot of use out of it myself.

I don't think this product is for everyone. I, for one, don't have a problem putting a nail into my walls should I need to hang a piece of art. But renters might prefer this, and it works easier and with more stability than the traditional steel wire on the back, or the dreaded loop or ring in the back. The integrated level makes it easy to align, and once the frame is pushed into the velcro it isn't tilting, or leaning. This is the metaphorical better mousetrap.I was sent a series of monochrome photographs for my artworks, which would probably be appropriate for a caf or other place where impersonal, inoffensive decoration is needed. I would have rather tried a chalkboard or whiteboard facing, so I could have gotten my ever crafty daughter to make a statement. That would be great.  There was one extension piece, so one of the pictures could be mounted further from the wall, to break it up a bit and give some 3D effect; it works reasonably well, but does expose the frame which would otherwise be hidden.Installation was as quick and errorless as they claim. Just make sure the wall is clean.

Reviewing cereal is hard. Most of you reading this are probably already Special K enjoyers, and just want to know if anything is wrong with the packaging or whether the addition of dried strawberries or yogurt detracts from the original. I'll try.The portions are too large. I'm an average sized male; (5'11", 182 lbs) and I have a hard time eating all the cereal in a cup in one sitting; and of course, you pretty much have to eat it all in one sitting for it to have the convenience you bought it for. And once the milk is poured on, the clock starts ticking; my daughter filled a cup up with milk, then forgot it on the counter; this stuff turns to mush fast, you can't just put it back in the fridge.Of the three varieties, I guess the Red Berry version with dried strawberries is the best; I like strawberries. I don't think the yogurt version is any improvement, chunks of dried yogurt that settle to the bottom of the cup with a flavor that isn't so much tangy yogurt as it is emptiness.The packaging does deliver everything fresh, crisp and well preserved. So if you are a Special K lover and just need a convenient way to keep a single serving this will work out for you. Although I'd imagine it would be cheaper and more resource friendly in the long run to get a securely sealable bowl and fill it daily from a bulk box.

This is an adequately executed apron. If you need an apron, and want a little whimsy, this would be fine. It just isn't amazingly whimsical, you could 'design' this in about 5 minutes given the original drawing. Also, I'm not a fan of the hand feel for the actual design, and I'm worried about how many washes the artwork will remain on.My 8 year old daughter is a huge Frozen fan and will sing 'Let it Snow' with little nudging, but this is an adult size, so she isn't quite the target market. She likes wearing this like a faux dress, it goes down to her ankles.

Ever since our children were babies, we've used a heavy rubber mattress cover on one of our beds and while it definitely kept fluids from penetrating, during summer it was horrible as it just did not breath at all. We put a mattress pad on top of it which alleviated that somewhat, but I was not happy with it. That is why I'm so very happy to take delivery of this much lighter weight cover. It's much more clothlike yet it does a good job of keeping fluid from penetrating. I poured water on it, put a piece of paper underneath, and let it sit for 20 minutes, nothing came through, not a drop.As for comfort, while I wouldn't want to sleep on it directly, it isn't quite cotton-like in its texture, it isn't bad at all. Put a sheet or a sheet and a mattress pad over it and you are good to go. My daughter has been sleeping with just a sheet between her and this pad for a couple weeks with zero complaints.I recommend this cover.

I was sent two Brinks Push Pull locks; the other one had a privacy lock on it, and a nickel finish. I liked the other one better, but this is a nice latch, if you are lucky enough to have a door it fits. I tried this lock first on the door leading out to my garage, but unfortunately, neither the 60 or 70mm bolt modules this lock ships with fit; I needed around a 65mm one. So there went that idea. I subsequently tried installing it on a closet door, and that went much better; the 70 mm bolt fit perfectly, and I had the old latch off and this new one installed in under 10 minutes. The mechanism was pre-set for my standard interior door, but adjusting it for a thicker size can be done in a few minutes of mainly reading the instructions.Once installed, I have a fairly smooth mechanism that can be opened by either pulling, pushing or twisting. I will be mainly pulling because the door opens towards me. I'm concerned that the finish will scratch; that's why I prefer the better aging nickel surfaces, but it hasn't scratched yet.  It is certainly an improvement over the old fashioned door knob it's replacing and will make it easier to get into the linen closet with my arms filled with sheets and towels.

This door lock is for those who just need to get into the bathroom NOW! Come barreling up to the door and pop it by pushing into the handle and it opens up all in one smooth motion. Really clever. So probably best for doors that open in, but still functional if pulling the door opens it, just not as fun. Unless, of course, the lock is actually locked in which case a Three Stooges bit ensues.Finish and decorative detail work are OK, if not fantastic, and construction is all metal. I'm curious about the mirror finish on the bolt, it seems as if that can't last. The handles are a bit loose, and I think the set screw on the inside handle is likely to require periodic retightening. The lock takes a little work to engage as you have to reach around the inside handle, but unlocking is easy: just twist the handle. Emergency unlocking, which is sometimes a daily occurrence around here with the kids is accomplished by a bit of included stiff wire.Installation was done in a few minutes, and most of it was done by my 9 year old, so even novice handymen should have little trouble.

I was recently offered a variety pack of Tacwise staples to review; along with it came a cousin of this Z3-140 model. I liked the staples, but loved the stapler and I jumped at the chance of getting another. Even though my house now has 5 hand staplers and my wife will look at me like I'm insane should she find out I took delivery of another one. Regardless, this is an excellent stapler. It fires firmly and evenly, it's comfortable in the hand, and the detachable guide makes stapling along a line easy.I would say this is a feature-rich model. You know that they threw in the kitchen sink when they put in a little window to put your initials inside. But the gimmicks do not make a stapler gimmicky if it does its primary task easily and without error.  The only thing I can say against it is that the staples they throw in are quite short, and you will likely want to buy a more varied pack.

This is a decent read. The main character is mostly pleasant if self-rightious, and it seems like she could quickly dispense with her main problemthat folks won't believe she can talk with magical creatureswhich should be easily and irrefutably provable. Regardless, I took a liking to the idealistic girl.The most unsatisfying part of the book is the antagonist, who takes the role of the voice of reason. The town is being invaded by a magical pest, which threatens the lives and property of the inhabitants, and the antagonist is forcefully advocating for the town to vote for erradication of said creatures. This is not Cruella de Ville, the antagonist is just using the democratic process to do what is sensible: eliminate harmful creatures. Imagine reading a book where the protagonist was fighting to protect malarial mosquitos. If my kids read this book, I will be sure to point out the softheadedness of Pip's point of view.One of the philosophical quandries about this book is that Pip finds that almost all magical creatures can speak. Thus, they are intelligent and I would think more deserving of protection than everyday mindless things. So imagine mosquitos that can talk, would they be just as swat-table? For that matter, would creatures capable of intelligent conversation be appropriate as subservient pets?I had thought there would be more clippings from the imaginary 'Guide to Magical Creatures' and this would have been an opportunity to add something special and diffentiating for the book, but the clippings are short and far between. And could have more imagination.I'd say this is a decent book for young people, not a great one, that many will enjoy.

This is not a horrible monitor. At its native resolution1080pit is quite crisp. However, it is what is, an inexpensive LCD monitor, and for a lot of people it will be sufficient and maybe even a bargain. But make no mistake; it is not as good as pricier models.For example, I have it sharing my Mac desktop with a Thunderbolt Display, which has a quite good LG panel. For the life of me, I cannot get the HP panel to calibrate where the standard Mac gamma of 2.2 looks good. I'm not talking some purist's calibration, just set it so that colors look the same, and I can watch TV shows without it looking either washed out or way too dark. Contrast with the great panel on the ViewSonic monitor hanging over my printer. Also there is a lot of changes in brightness as you change your position so that from my normal seated position, the top of the HP looks like the solid background color is a completely different shade of blue.I can see where someone could need a monitor on the cheap, or have a little-used workstation which just needs a monitor. For this, it would be fine. And maybe, the user hasn't been ruined by using a good monitor, thus my advice to keep it away from a good one. As for me, I'll just keep it here and use it to display auxiliary windows when I program, and it should be OK for that, at least I won't have to stare at it.For whatever reason, it shipped with a VGA cable instead of a more useful HDMI or DVI cable. And of course, it doesn't have a Display Port, or any audio out. Onscreen controls were a bit confusing but you get the hang of them. The face of the display is a bit under 6 inches from the back most part of the stand, so it will jam against the wall pretty tight. The status light is a pleasant white dot and there isn't anything in the way of HP branding on power up, so it isn't deliberately annoying in any way.It seems to take longer than most monitors to negotiate a resolution with my Mac, so awaking from sleep takes several seconds longer and involves my desktop going black twice. And if I restart my Mac Mini, it will flash many times and I'll end up cycling the monitors power in order to get it back in sync. My advice here would be to avoid using this with a Mac.If your budget is larger, I've found Samsung's SD590 series to be more praiseworthy at about the same size.Just know what you are buying and not to expect more and you should be fine.

I think this a nice case, and it would make a good gift; as it comes with an extra nice box and comes with fancy accessories such as a transparent bubble scraper with an owl logo. I am not convince, however, that it is a great case. I think there was some compromise in fit when it was crafted to also fit the iPhone 5c, so it's a bit loose on my 5S, and it doesn't give much of protection on the speaker grill. But these compromises can be turned into strengths as in: too loose = easy to remove, scant speaker protection = can use any lightening connector including Apple's bulky 30 pin to lightening adaptor plus the sound is less muffled.I didn't have great luck with the screen protector, getting a couple of trapped bits of dust, but it does have the advantage of coming with both top and bottom protective sheets, so you can scratch up the sacrificial top sheet to your heart's content with the bubble scraper and when you are satisfied peel it off leaving the unblemished protector. I'm not so sure about not having a front facing camera opening on the protector, but it has good clarity, and neglecting the dust bubbles looks great.Hand feel is good, and it's neither overly cold or slippery. [Update: I've been using this case for few weeks, and the texture is its best feature, and gives a lot of comfort.] [Update again: unfortunately after several months, the leather is starting to peel away from the frame, making for an unsightly mess.]So, not the most protective case in the world, but stylish enough and sort of fancy.

This is a nicely done product ifand this is a big ifyou like the odor. Unfortunately, I am not a fan. But, it has other nice qualities, such as being neither too runny or too thick, and quickly disappearing into the skin. This might be the most cleanly disappearing sunscreen I've ever seen; put a dollop on your skin, rub for a few seconds and the white disappears, first replaced with shiny and disappears completely in a minute. You can tell it's still there because you taste awful and smell like sunscreen.Water resistance is OK, but it goes away with hot water in a few seconds under the tap.The squeeze bottle has a bit of texture on one side, I guess to make it less slippery.I'm not going to pretend to know how efficient it is at actually blocking UV, I assume it lives up the SPF 30, which in my experience is adequate for most exposures.[Update, the nozzle jammed up pretty solidly requiring me to take the top off to get to the lotion. Poor design somewhere.]

This appears to be a quite decent watch albeit a bit large for a lady's watch. My wife prefers a smaller dial for one, but some like a more easily read face. My one problem with the watch is that the texture of the underlying mother-of-pearl face of the watch fools my eyes into thinking there's some sort of imperfection in the crystal overlay.Out of the box, the band was way too big for my wife's slender wrists, something fixed for $15 at a jeweller's kiosk at the mall. This still left the watch a bit loose, but rather too loose than too tight.As for being a watch, it seems to keep adequate time, not losing a second over the course of a week.This is plated gold, you can see the underlying steel if you look at the normally hidden parts of the links and looks fine. It comes with a big pillow for display, although it doesn't fit very well after you've changed the size of the band. The instructions are in several languages but don't include any instructions for removing links.In general, a serviceable if not particularly exceptional watch.

This is a exceedingly large mouse pad made out of wetsuit material. I'm not quite sure about why you'd want either quality. I had to shift several accessories on my desk to make room for the pad, and then I didn't actually make use of the area. I could have changed my mouse's acceleration but then I'd be moving my hand farther to get around the screen.It's made of wetsuit like material, which allows it to be compactly rolled up without crimping for shipping, and is a nicely even surface to roll over. On the other hand, it gives padding and more damping than a harder surface would making for more effort in moving. Which may be what you want, a mouse on a frictionless surface would never come to a complete stop. The question is one of balance between too much damping and too little, and I'd say this pad gives just a bit too much, but it's close.As for other qualities, the backside grabs my desk well so it doesn't move. It's thin enough that the lip doesn't bother or impede me.  The artwork is not my kind of thing, too much affectation. It is well put together, I don't see this peeling apart as other pads have for me.In general, a reasonable choice if you prefer an unreasonably large mouse pad.

So what does the package mean when it says that Irish Spring Signature is for men?Apparently, men like oversized bars of boxy soap. Well, I appreciate the extra soap, it lasts longer, and the 90 edges round out after a couple of sessions making it less like I'm cleaning myself like real men do, with a brick.Men must like pleasant smelling soap where one wet bar in the shower can fill an entire basement with fragrance. Don't worry you'll get used to it, but you might want to keep it in a soap box.And men must like moisturized skin. My skin does seem less wintery dry since I started using it.In general, this is a nicely done soap. It cleans, washes off cleanly, smells good, and doesn't irritate the skin.

I am impressed by the craftsmanship of this convenient Capo. It's quite obviously machined well, and is easily adjustable although it fit right on my family's acoustic Fender Squier right out of the packaging. I wasn't able to test the tuning bracket, as the tuners we own have a different mounting system, but the bracket slides on and off easily and stays in place.  My neighbour, the real musician, seemed impressed by it too.  I also like the material covering the arm which holds down the strings, not too spongy, not too hard.

I will admit to not being an avid dice game player, but I just don't see the enjoyment from this game. I played it with my children over the weekend and at no time did I experience the maniacal joy shared by the Martians as they went about destroying people, places and things. It just seemed to be a lot of rolling of little dice, trying to avoid rolling too many nukes, and mechanically accumulating cards. Maybe if I were playing someone I could talk smack with when I sniped one of their cards then some joy could be manufactured, but it wasn't to be.The packaging and materials are fine. The cards are grotesquely cute. The instructions long but not excessive.If you don't love dice games you won't have any chance of loving this one.

I unintentionally ended up using an unusual technique for testing this mat's durability. My daughter loves playing hot lava so she grabbed one end and hopped all over the basement curling, pounding and twisting it. Absolutely no visible damage from even this unusual abuse. It also doesn't show any marks from my rolling my office chair over it all day.As for the mat's comfort, one's feet sink gently into the foam rubber. It seems like they calibrated this compression so while it will uniformly distribute the force of gravity along the surface of the average shoe, you don't quite feel like you are sinking into quicksand. It succeeds at making standing noticeably less fatiguing.The mat has a faux diamond plate pattern across its surface with the apparent intention of minimizing slipping. I don't think one would slip very easily on the surface anyway, what with your feet pressed  a centimeter below the surface, but it probably helps a bit.I think Stanley has a winner here, but it's quite possible that some people will find the mat too squishy. You may want to order a single piece to try it out before committing to an entire set.

This is my first selfie stick style monopod. One thing that's now apparent is that these things are not just for taking selfies. Anytime you need a longer arm or to make a quick, stable shot, this thing becomes useful. It's useful from all the way collapsed to fully extended (about 2.5 feet of arm) and will hold any position in between with friction. I'd be a bit worried that this slide out mechanism will wear out and lose its grip, but at least for now it's fine. I have an iPhone 5S in a case and it popped right into the bracket, but if I take my phone out of its case, I have to put in an included rubbery piece to hold it tight into the stick's bracket.The most satisfying part of the monopod is the shutter release button integrated into the grip. I paired it with my phone via the Bluetooth settings panel in a few seconds, and it was immediately able to trigger my phone's camera shutter. I find I can take much more stable photos than I would if were tapping the screen or pressing the volume down button.Conversely, the least satisfying part of the monopod is the shutter release button as it is covered by a rubber sleeve and that sleeve can easily rotate or pull out of position making the bump that is supposed to be over the button in the wrong place, and leaving me pressing nothing. It's easily realigned but it is annoying for a device that is almost just right.Anyway, I like this fun monopod.(The company provided me with a free copy of this monopod in exchange for me taking the time to write this review.)

I used to think that people that referred to their pets as their "Furbaby" were a little bit crazy...until I got my dog. Now I get it. They are a part of your family! We got our first family dog Odie around the holiday season last year so it seemed appropriate to get him a companion for the holidays this year!We like having small dogs because of the limited space for them in our backyard. We got another Chihuahua named Belle. Belle of course needed all the doggie gear including a dog collar. We were really happy with Odie's dog bed from Blueberry Pet so it instantly became a name I trusted when it came to pet products.They have a really cute Christmas collection for the holidays.I liked the snowflake one best even though I loved all the patterns in the red, green and gold color scheme. What I immediately noticed when I got it was it's huge! I got the small size since I have five pound Chihuahua's and even on the smallest setting it's big on her. It doesn't come in extra small so if you have a small dog it probably wouldn't fit. I would guess smaller than ten pounds it would be too big.The second thing I noticed was the incredible quality. I have only gotten the cheap collars from Walmart before so I didn't even know they came this nice! It's much thicker and more solid then any I've seen before. The buckle part is really solid and probably won't ever break.I thought the bow was absolutely adorable! This would be so cute to put on a puppy that's a gift for Christmas! Imagine seeing that under the tree Christmas morning!DSCN2519I'm disappointed in the fit and that these collars are designed for bigger dogs but they really are adorable and well made. This Christmas dog collar would make a great gift for a Fur baby!

This is great for keeping baby out of trouble, or in my current situation, keeping puppy out! ! There are things and places you don't want them accessing, touching, playing with or coming into contact with at all! But babies and puppies alike are determined and skilled at getting into places they aren't allowed. So what's a mom to do? Meet my new best friend: the 3 in 1 Play Yard from Dreambaby!I really should have invested in one of these seven years ago when I had my first baby. It's one of those items that are pricey and you put on your baby registry and hope you get it but then don't buy for yourself if you don't. In hindsight and after using it for just a week, it would have been so worth the investment! Even having for just my third child, and second puppy; I think it's worth it!I was a little worried about the setup but luckily it comes 90% put together! I had visions of attaching all of these separate pieces but the panels fold in opposite direction to each other so that they can completely collapse for easy storage and transportation. You simply unfold and then stand it up where you want it.As I mentioned we just got a new puppy and wanted her blocked off in the kitchen until she's completely potty trained. This covered the area I needed perfectly!The best feature is the gate! It's a swing close gate so even if the little ones forget to close it; it closes on it's own! You do have the option to push all the way to prop and leave open. I do this when the dog has already gone to the bathroom and can be free for a bit. I close it when she can't.It's an easy squeeze lever to move quickly through the gate but hard enough so that my toddler can't open it on his own.Since this is a temporary situation, we didn't secure to the walls. However, if I had gotten this sooner OR have another baby in the future, I will put it in front of the fireplace and entertainment center area. We already lost one TV to a baby throwing something at it!Included are directions and hardware to secure to the wall. The best part of this is there's a pattern included that you can tape to the wall and install the hardware first instead of trying to guesstimate where exactly the screws go. This will save some extra holes in the wall!The other option for this is to make it a playpen; again perfect for babies and puppies! I think we'll be taking this camping with us. Since Jax is still a toddler he tends to wander off. This is a great option to let him play outside with his siblings without me having to worry if I have to run in the trailer for something.This whole set is top quality and I was really impressed that it could be free standing without having to secure it down.Whether you have a toddler, a newborn or a puppy; this 3 in 1 Play-Yard is a great option to section off areas you don't want them accessing or just to give them their own safe play area. It's one of those things on my "should have gotten this years ago" list!

I searched high and low for the perfect wallet phone case for my iPhone. What I realized is that there aren't a whole lot of options for good quality leather cases! Sure there are thousands when you search but as I narrowed it down there weren't a whole lot.I wanted the drivers license window which was really hard to find and one of the reasons I chose this one. I also liked that there were three additional slots for credit cards and then a slot behind them for money.My phone fits very snug inside. I have a bad habit of dropping it all the time and cracking the screen so it was really important for me to have something secure. I've already drop tested it (not on purpose of course) and it has survived! The soft leather protects it and it doesn't come out. In fact, I have a hard time taking it out when I want to put it in my running armband. But that's probably a good thing.I love the coffee color. It looks nice for fall and matches most everything I have.It gets kind of fat with three credit cards and money it but it seems to have expanded nicely and it's not hard at all to close it. The magnet is obviously good quality and it snaps and stays shut. I'm still able to put the whole thing in my back pocket without any trouble.

My kids now have nicer sheets then me! Seriously - I didn't expect much from sheets with characters on them. Whenever I buy my kids these kinds of sheets they are scratchy and not the best quality. But they're kids and they don't know the difference so they don't complain.When I got this set I was quite shocked at how soft and silky they are! I got them for my youngest son and as soon as my older saw them, he asked for a set! Now they know the difference between cheap sheets and quality sheets so it's quality only from now on!The design is pretty awesome. I love the clean, classic batman symbol on the bottom sheet and the top sheet has all the different years and models of the Batmobile. The pillowcase has two different designs on each side.Now I'm going to have to see if they come in California King size because my husband wants them! They are on the pricey side if you compare to others. I bought them for the design but now I see the higher price is for higher quality. With these sheets you get what you pay for!

I bought the bunk bed that goes with this dresser at a yard sale and wanted to find the matching accessories. I was happy to find them on Amazon without having to pay more at Ashley.The dresser is smaller then I expected but better quality than I thought it would be. It's solid with a nice finish and beautiful look.Here is the best part: it came fully assembled! I have never bought furniture online that was delivered in one piece! It was packaged perfectly to protect it and all I had to do was screw in the knobs on the drawers! That's it!I was so happy with the quality and with the customer service of this company that I just ordered the matching Wooden Loft Bookcase and Lower Storage. Can't wait until it comes in!

My kids have gone through so many pairs of goggles I could scream! With two kiddos on the local swim team, goggles are an important part of their every day life so they HAVE to be good.After going through several pairs their swim coach recommended these to me. They fit my kids great and after using for a couple of months; they are still in perfect condition!

Life is full of possibilities and opportunities to help others. Unfortunately, not everyone fully appreciates or takes advantage of this fact. What I have found when trying to bless others through volunteering is that I'm usually the one that's blessed! At this point in my life with my children at the forefront of all my activities, I like to volunteer in areas that involved them. Helping in the classroom or at the nursery at church are some of my favorite things to do because they involved my favorite little people.It is never lost on me how much of a difference you can make and how much other people appreciate it. When you hear their thanks, it's all worth it! After losing my dad this summer and seeing him spend the last year of his life in a nursing home, I have a whole new appreciation for anyone that volunteers with the elderly. Since I've seen how few people do it; it's been on my heart to find a way to volunteer once my last child is in school and I have more time.Reading Volunteering & Giving Back brought me to tears, as all the Chicken Soup books do, and inspired me to want to do more. It's such a huge opportunity to bless someone and in turn to be blessed.There are ten different topics with stories in each including my favorites Who's Helping Whom, The Spirit of Christmas and Filling a Need. I have a bad habit of jumping around in these books. I always open to the index to see what the topics are and start with the ones that interest me the most. I always end up reading the whole thing in the end so I don't know why I don't read it cover to cover. I just can't seem to do it that way. I get too excited about the topics and want to read them first!One that that helped me in all my flipping about that I believe is fairly new is that the page numbers are sideways on the bottom along with the section title. It's perfect for those of us that like to flip around and want to easily find things!I loved The Spirit of Christmas probably the most and it's a great reminder with the holiday season approaching that there are many opportunities to volunteer this time of year and so many that are less fortunate than us.I really enjoyed Where do Those Toys go that was about the Toys for Tots program. This is one I always do with my kids and have them pick out a toy for a child their age to donate. But I always wondered too; where DO the toys go? This one was informative as well as touching and a great reminder that there are people on the other end of giving who are receiving a much greater gift than the toy itself.People tend to get depressed around the holidays and are lonely and sad if they don't have happiness in their life. Volunteering & Giving Back made me want to reach out more to those in need and volunteer wherever I can. There is no greater gift to give!I received a copy of this book in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Thanksgiving is just around the corner and what better time to remind our kids to be thankful! I know it's something that doesn't come naturally to most children so they have to be taught. I have one child that always remembers to say thank you and frequently says "thank you for making me dinner" or "thank you for taking me shopping." This thanks is music to my ears as it was the way I was raised. I have another child, however, who it doesn't come naturally to and has to be constantly reminded. I think it's a good thing to instill in them at a very young age.Thank you, Lord, for Everything is a great book to help do that! It's a board book so it's designed for the younger crowd. I read it with my 21 month old today and he absolutely loved it. It instantly became one of those books that you have to read to them over and over again. What better message to drill in his head, over and over!I like books that rhyme for the little ones. It makes it more sing-songy which Jax tends to listen and pay attention to more. Since he's just a toddler, long books and uninteresting words don't go far with him. The repetition also helps as each page ended up with the same statement "thank you Lord for everything!" He's just putting together words and phrases now but I'm hoping this is one of the first sentences he remembers and says.The thing I like about this message is that it's a great reminder to be grateful for even the little things. Sometimes we forget to be thankful for food and shelter and things that we take for granted when there are those that do without. The little things to us are the big things to other and I think it's a great message to give our children as we approach the holiday season.The pictures are adorable and I think that's part of what kept Jax in tune. The first time through I pointed out some things I thought he'd like and remember since he's also learning to talk. I pointed out a ball, rabbit, bees and flowers. The next time through he pointed at them and said their names. Early reading is also a great tool for learning to talk and it's such a joy to share this with him.Thank you, Lord, for Everything became an instant favorite with my toddler and is a great book to read for the holidays and a message to reinforce all year!I received a copy of this book in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Odie is our first family pet so he might be a little bit spoiled! I admit I went overboard when we got him last year buying him everything I thought he would need. Of course, like my kids, I got it wrong the first time! I didn't know what to buy so often when left with a decision I just went with the cheapest option being the practical person that I am! When it comes to a dog bed, however, cheaper is not better; especially when you get what you pay for!I got his bed from a local store for around $10. It was cute but I noticed that the cushion went down pretty fast, especially after a few washes. When I ordered this bed from Blueberry Pet, I ordered the smallest size since Odie is just a five pound Chihuahua. I was literally shocked by it's size when it came! And it's not just the size I was impressed with; it was the quality.I couldn't get over how fat and fluffy it was! Odie wasted no time checking it out, and never did my one year old! He thought it was comfy enough for nap time! I guess I've been doing it all wrong with his sleep training too!Seriously though, the quality, amazing! My absolute favorite thing is the dog bone pillow. I mean how cute is that? It even has a little squeaker inside so it can double as a chew toy if they are so inclined!One side drops down so they can easily step inside without having to jump. I loved the colors and how it is two toned. The beige part happens to match my carpet perfectly, and my dog! It looks stylish but will also hide any hairs. It comes in other pretty colors and fun pattern options.The microsuede material is super soft and I've noticed when he gets up, it feels super warm where his body was. Chihuahua's are notorious for their shaking because they're always cold. Odie is short haired with no body fat so he needs all the help he can get staying warm! There is a zipper where you can remove the padding to get the outside cleaned and it's machine washable. It's a little hard to get it out and back in but luckily it's not something I'll need to do often.I figured I would keep his old bed in one room and this one in another since he tends to follow me and stay in whichever room I'm in. I noticed those days are over though because now he stays with the warmer, comfier bed every time!The Blueberry Pet bed is honestly a little bit pricey and more then I would want to pay. However, after seeing the extreme difference in quality I've realized that dog beds are one of those things where you get what you pay for!

Hello sleep my old friend! I've been waiting for you! Ever since I had my first baby seven years ago, sleep has been a thing of the past! Just when I get one sleeping through the night, the next one enters a new stage or phase where sleep is once again a thing of the past.Jax is just twenty one months old so ideally he would still be in a crib. Unfortunately, he learned how to conquer the walls of his crib at seventeen months old! Next was the toddler bed that he would never stay in. Needless to say, I was desperate! Desperate for a sleep solution!Last weekend we got the boys bunk beds to save space in their shared room. I hoped that putting Jax in a "big boy bed" with his favorite character sheets might do the trick! The only problem was how to stop him from falling out of bed since he's still so young. I have seen a few different options but decided to go with a traditional bed rail.Reed had his for years and it seemed to be the best solution for a twin sized bed with a toddler. Unfortunately we got rid of it when we were "done having kids!" The Dreambaby Harrogate Bed Rail appealed to me because of it's ease of use and the fact that it's extra long and tall. With it's drop down sides it looked like the easiest way to be able to still change sheets and bedding without having to remove the whole thing.It's all one piece so there's no assembly. I just followed the easy directions. One thing that Reed's old rail didn't have that I really liked about this one was the straps that extended to the other side of the bed for added stability and security.I first put the two long rails under the mattress and then pulled the straps out to the other side and adjusted for a good fit. I liked that I could easily drop down the side by pulling up the two adjustments at the same time. It easily dropped down so that I could make the bed.It was easy to work the sheets and bedding around the rail without it getting in the way much.Once the bed was completely made I just pulled up and it clicked into place. This is my favorite feature! You hear the click and you know it's locked. With some other kinds you have to slide things around and line up until the red lock turned to green. I always struggled with our old one and this one is easy peasy!While I'd love to be able to say that he sleep through the night, he didn't. What I can say is that he didn't fall out of bed so the bed rail worked! I'm really happy with it's ease of use, quality and effectiveness! Now to work on the sleeping through the night part!

It has been way too long since I read a good book and The Girl Without a Name reinvigorated my love of reading! I read it cover to cover in a day; thank you for the day off Labor Day!This one had my hooked from page one; clearly since I never put it down! I always know the first couple pages and usually even by the first page if I will like or hate a book. This one got the love nod immediately.I have always been interested in Psychiatry so the main character Dr. Zoe Goldman immediately had my attention. The fact that she worked in a psych ward set the tone for me. It seems like such an interesting place to work and the colorful cast of patients confirmed that assumption! There is one patient that stands out and that is our girl without a name and so dubbed Jane Doe.Jane Doe seems to have come from nowhere and in her catatonic state, she isn't going to be helping to solve her mystery anytime soon. Zoe doubles as an investigator of sorts as she picks up on and follows clues that might lead to her identification. The story has many twists and turns as she unravels the clues, only to lead to more mysteries.I have to admit, I didn't see the end coming and I LOVE that about this book! I only wish I wasn't so greedy and hadn't gone through The Girl Without a Name so quickly because now I'm left wanting more!

While I received this product for free, the opinions and thoughts included in this review are my own.I have tried many different car and booster seats over the years between my three kids and I have finally found "the one!" I'm happy to say this is the last car seat/booster I will ever need since it's a 3-in-1! I never even knew there was such a thing before now and I am in love!In all honesty, I was initially attracted because of the colors! I know it's superficial but hey, if you have to look at something every day, you want to like it right?When it arrived I was thrilled at the quality. It is so solid and sturdy and really pays attention to detail. For me it's really the little things that shows a company cares about their product. For example, there are directions right on the seat in case you lose the separate ones it comes with (and don't we all?) I also love the little cushion that goes behind the seat belt. I have pinched every one of my children's sweet little thighs buckling them in a car seat. Those days are gone! Finally someone realized that something that is supposed to protect your child shouldn't injure them in use! There are also little cushions that go on the two arm straps for added comfort.Other details I love include the cup holder that's deep enough to support a sippie cup and the two pockets under it on each side where he can store things like a snack, pacifier or small toys like action figures! It's such a huge help for him to have all these things right at his fingertips!My son is well passed the infant stage but I still want him in a five point harness for safety as long as possible. This seat is good from 20 - 100 pounds and he's on the low end of that scale at around thirty pounds so the timing is perfect.The best thing about this seat is when he outgrows the five point harness, I don't have to buy the next seat. This transforms to a belted booster with a back and then a backless booster in a few easy steps! No more trading in and upgrading. This can be his last seat! The harnessed booster is good up to 65 pounds and I'll keep it that way until he hits the limit before converting. There is a one hand adjustment on the headrest to change as he grows taller.With three different reclining positions you can find the one that's just right for your child at the age and height they are and then change as they grow. This also easily reclines with one hand adjustment.I always like to play with my new "toys" when I get them so I did the conversions just to see how easy they are even though he's not ready for them yet. You can convert between the stages in a matter of minutes. I'll admit I had to look at the directions the first time but now that I know how it'll be easy when it comes time.I have always been sad to say goodbye to baby stages but now that I'm on my third, it's exciting to watch them grow, not sad! Even though Jax is my last baby and this will be the last seat he'll ever need, I'm thrilled with the seat itself and watching him grow through these stages.The Graco Nautilus three in one will supply all his needs until he outgrows it. This is by far my favorite seat so it's appropriate that it's also the last!

We have all seen photos and videos of babies pick up their food and throw it across the room. Before becoming a parent, these were hilarious to me. Now, not so much. With three kids, I have had more than my fair share of messes to clean up, especially when it comes to food.Sometimes it really is the little things in life that can make things so much easier like this suction bowl and spoon. Why has no one thought of this sooner? We all know kids like to throw their food, so let's make it as hard for them as possible!I like that this bowl set has everything that you need to. The bowl itself is nice and large so you can put a whole meal in it. The suction ring at the bottom sticks to their tray or table, preventing the dreaded lifting and throwing the bowl. It also comes with a lid if you are on the go and want to bring their food with you and a spoon that snaps quite handily right onto the top. My only complaint is that the spoon it's self is a little bit narrow. It might be good for younger babies but it's a bit small for my 20 month old.Jax is no different than any other toddler/baby in that he likes to throw his food and whatever container they are inside of. It's such an age of exploration and discovery. While I encourage this in most areas, playing with their food and throwing it is not one of them! This suction bowl set nicely puts an end to all of that!It is dishwasher and microwave safe, as all things nowadays should but aren't. You do have to remove the suction ring before putting in the dishwasher which is kind of annoying but I prefer to just hand wash it quickly since it is now my favorite go to bowl anyway and I don't have time to wait for the dishwasher! But the option is there if you prefer the dishwasher.Jax is not happy about the inability to play with his suction bowl but I am and in this instance, that's all that matters!

Who remembers the magic of a simple sticker book? I remember when I was a kid that stickers were the most magical little things and I loved to collect them all! From puffy stickers to scratch-n-sniff, they were one of life's simple little pleasures.These are the kinds of things that are so fun to do with my own children because it makes me feel like a kid again! The Beginners Bible now offers up Sticker & Activity books! The latest are All About Jesus and Wild About Creation.
