They are both themed sticker and activity books that will keep your kids busy and happy for hours!With puzzles and activity pages in addition to the stickers, there are lots of fun Bible themed things to do! My six year old daughter dove right in and didn't come up for air until she had gone through most of the book. Some of her favorites were connect the dots and drawing her own picture where she added the included stickers.Since we are familiar with The Beginners Bible and all it's characters, this is a fun tie in to what we have been learning from them.The Beginners Bible All About Jesus Sticker and Activity Book is a fun and affordable thing for kids to do from Zonderkidz to emphasize what they have learned!

Yesterday I wrote about The Berenstain Bears Storybook Bible for Little Ones and today I have another fun title from The Berenstain Bears: Harvest Festival.Fall is my favorite season and I can already see the light beginning to change bringing the promise of the season! What better way to get in the mood that to settle in for story time with our favorite bears!The book begins with one of those things that always makes me think of fall and my childhood in New Hampshire: raking leaves and then jumping in the pile! I love that the harvest festival the bears attend involves many of my favorite things about fall including pumpkin pie, apple picking, visiting the pumpkin patch and a good old fashioned hayride.This book is chalk full of all the wonders of the season and while reading to my children, they recalled some of our own experiences with these same activities. Most people when asked will say that Christmas is their favorite holiday season but not in my house! We're about to enter my favorite!The end of the book has activities and questions from Brother and Sister Bear. I like to ask my kids these questions to make sure they were listening and to hear the way that they interpret things. In first and second grade they both have nightly required reading so this was a perfect book to read as well as to check their understanding of what it was about.The Berenstain Bears: Harvest Festival will get you in the mood for fall. It can't come soon enough for me but the book is already here!

This is such a fun set for little girls to enjoy! Actually, my little boys have been enjoying it too - shhhh - they don't want people to know they like something "girly." But seriously it is so nice to see things that involve building that aren't just blocks or things for boys! It's about time! The Learning Resources Sweet Shop Building Set is perfect for my six year old little girl. She loves to build and she loves sweets!The set has 82 pieces which is a good amount but not too much. It comes with fun stickers as well so that they can design their set.As I have discovered with all Learning Resources products we have tried, this set is really well made. I wasn't sure how well the gears would actually work but they turn amazingly well! Even though this set is designed for PreK+, it has withstood my rough and tumble toddler who loves to watch those gears spin! He bangs on them and they hold on pretty well!I love all the vibrant colors and watching the wheels turn in my daughters mine as she designed and put them together. She has asked to do this together several times. Once we opened the box I realized a bunch of pieces were missing and I discovered them in her play kitchen! She loves the little cupcakes and ice creams and so they double between this building set and playtime in her kitchen. I love things that have more then one use.Little girls love to build and play as much as boys do so it's really encouraging to find sets like the Sweet Shop Building Set that they can enjoy!This game was provided to me for review purposes. All thoughts and opinions are my own.

I have adored The Berenstain Bears since I was a little girl so it always makes their books extra special for me to share with my kids. The Berenstain Bears Storybook Bible for Little Ones is created for 2 - 4 year olds so I read it with my almost two year old son Jax.This is a board book which is always good for the little hands that tend to tear delicate pages. Jax likes to hold the book in his cute, chubby little hands and turn the pages himself.This isn't typical of the Berenstain Bears books because while it shows the bears as the characters in the illustrations, they are appearing as characters in the Bible, not as themselves. This is basically a Bible storybook but everyone in it is a Bear!This isn't the entire Bible but some of the main stories that kids usually learn first as little ones such as the story of creation, the birth of Jesus and his Resurrection.I like that the illustrations are just like the regular Berenstain Bear books so people who love them and are fans will appreciate the illustrations. However, they are not those typical of Bible storybooks. As I mentioned, they are all bears as the characters and they are kind of light and muted in color whereas most storybooks are brighter.As a fan of the bears, I loved sharing The Berenstain Bears Storybook Bible for Little Ones with Jax and that he is now a fan of the bears and has started pulling them off the shelf to read!

Whether you like your beverage hot or cold; the Ozeri Serafino double wall insulated beverage and coffee glasses hold it all!Lately I've been really into iced coffee but I'm always worried about glasses breaking when dealing with hot and cold beverages. For iced coffee I filled these with ice, then put it under my coffee maker where hot coffee went directly onto the ice. There was no cracking or breaking and I feel like something that starts out cold and ends up hot is the ultimate test!These glasses are beautiful to look at with their double layer and have a very unique appealing look to them. My kids are obsessed with these glasses and want to use them for their juice but they are a mommy only item!They are definitely delicate though and should be treated with care. I had one break in the dishwasher just from going through a normal cycle so I decided these should be hand wash only. While they are technically dishwasher safe, they should be separate from anything else if you are going to run them through.I love that these Serafino glasses hold both hot and cold beverages and are so nice to look at.

My kids love to do their own experiments, even if it means they don't have any official equipment or direction! It's fun to play with these things and educational insights helps do it safely with the Stir-it-Up Chemistry Lab.This set comes up most things you need to complete the experiments but not everything. Other things needed are usually household items you will have on hand like baking soda and white vinegar. I do wish it included every single thing so that when the box was opened it was good to go. We had trouble locating a few random things like a balloon (only around for birthdays) and candle (I go flameless). However, the kids had fun playing with the little vials and pretending they were doing things while we were on the hunting for the needed items.The guidebook tells you step by step exactly what to do and what you will need for each experiment. It also includes a pair of safety goggles so that their eyes are protected. Safety first! I happened to have a spare pair on hand so that both kids could do this together.Daddy helped out with the experiment while I gathered everything we needed so it was fun that the whole family could do it together.Since we didn't have everything on hand the first time we just did the experiments we did have things for like extinguishing the candle flame by creating our own gas. The kids thought this was the coolest thing ever and wanted to do it over and over again.Since they are also huge Star Wars fans they were obsessed with the idea of making their own lava in a bottle!The kids loved doing these experiments and ask every day if they can be scientists! While I do wish that the kit came with at least some of the required elements, I do see the appeal of being able to do multiple experiments using household items.The kit comes with all the scientific items required including the beaker, test tubes and rack to keep them in, graduated cylinder and lab glasses and more! See Product Description below for a complete list of what's included.

I have mixed feelings about this lunch box. I bought it for my Batman obsessed son who is seven years old.When it came I thought it was adorable. It has the classic Batman Logo on front and the inclusion of the cape on the back is adorable. I like the zipper pocket on the bottom where I can put an ice pack or additional food.However, that's there the positives end. I ran into a major problem when I went to pack it. It is way too small! I can't fit a normal sized water bottle or thermos in it without laying it diagonal and taking up too much space. I can fit something like a lunchable but only the really small sized ones.On the outside this is adorable but it is sadly not very practical.

Unlike another silicone muffin pan I have that is so floppy I can't really use it except for very stiff doughs, this one has stiffer sides and holds up well for making mini egg-based quiche muffins that I freeze and use for portion-controlled breakfasts. I like the straight sides a lot, which make it very easy to remove the contents. The pan is still flexible, but not too much. It cleans up well in the dishwasher, and any spots that the dishwasher might leave are easily removed by rubbing a very small amount of coconut oil onto the pans surface. I can't use it with the turntable in my microwave because of its shape, because it is too long to rotate freely, but that is true of any pan like this. I'd like to see this company make a round muffin pan that stands up as well as this one does. I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

I got these to go with my Presto percolator, and they are perfect for it. The filters cover up the little holes in the bottom of the basket so no grounds get through. However, there is a slightly bad off taste to the coffee when I use these, and all I can figure is that it's because they are bleached. I pulled the stainless steel screen off my little-used 32-oz. French press and that fits great, gets the same job done, and no more bad taste. If you tend to be sensitive to slight differences in flavors, you might want to try that instead. Amazon sells two-pack replacement screens for the French presses, and I think the 4" is what you need.

I'm an original Pebble watch user (the white one in my photos), and I've also tried several fitness-type bands (Fitbit, Misfit, etc.). I have an Amazon Fire Phone that I use to port music to my hearing aids via Bluetooth; I don't have a cellular service on it because I'm slow to the whole smart phone thing and can't justify the cost, but one day I'll get one. I did go through the motions of pairing this U8 smart watch to my phonepiece of cakeand installing the BT Notification appwhich requires sideloading because it's not available in the Amazon app store for the Fire Phone. I couldn't test the specific phone-related features (e.g., answering and making calls), but the phone book import feature seemed to work well. The Bluetooth, when enabled, interferes with the reception of my hearing aids from my Fire Phone (naturally), so I disabled it, disconnected the U8 from my phone after testing, and uninstalled BT Notification. That's not why I wanted to get this phone smart watch.What this watch is GREAT for as a standalone is all kinds of health tracking activities. All of the features I've posted in my photos work without connecting to an external device except for the pedometer; the U8 doesn't have its own accelerometer like the Pebble watch does. I track my steps and mileage using the Endomondo app on my phone strapped to my arm, so I don't need that feature, but if step-counting without having to use something else is important to you, this won't do it. The altimeter works by measuring altitude from the point at which you click the reset button, which can be useful if you climb a lot of hills. The stopwatch counts up in seconds/milliseconds increments; I wish there were a countdown timer/alarm feature as well, because I would use that more, but it's good to have the stopwatch.But reminders! Oh MY! There are so many different ways to configure this watch, and they all work together: Vibrate every hour on the hour; five different alarms you can configure independently to work once, every day, or on days of your choice; a "Rest" feature with four separately configurable times and day(s) and a funky Beethoven's Fifth alert (da-da-da-dah...); the same thing in a "Drink" feature but with eight instead of four and a glub-glub alert to remind yourself to drink more water. You can use these as intended or for other forms of tracking, like for taking supplements and meds. And, unlike my Pebble, I can actually read the screen to set these things up.The settings are all done the same on the different reminders and the time setting could not be easier or more intuitive. (Good thing, too, because the printed instructions that come with this watch are impossible to read and understand.) You can actually put together some pretty sophisticated Tabata or Pomodoro-type sequences using a combination of all these timers. You have a choice of five different ringtone types, three of which are really dorky but two that are kind of uplifting (1 and 4), plus the ability to choose ring-only, vibrate-only, or ring and vibrate modes. I have my morning wakeup alarm set to both vibrate and ring, my "go walking" alarm set to just ring, and my "go to sleep" set to vibrate only as a gentle reminder that I'm supposed to be going to sleep without waking me up if I'm already nodding. I haven't yet played with the sleep monitoring feature because I always forget to start it.It would be extraordinary if there were a way to add in a short notification for each of these reminders ("walk," "lunch," "morning meds," etc.), but for the price of this watch, what it does just cannot be beat. You'd have to be able to load apps onto it, like you can with the Pebble watch, for this added functionality, and that would add cost to the watch. I keep a calendar in Taco on my "New Tab" window with what I have to do, so when my U8 vibrates or rings, I can always glance up and see what I'm supposed to be doing if I forget.The biggest "con" is that I cannot choose to keep the screen on for longer than 3 minutes max. I would like to be able to keep the time visible while I'm out walking for an hour so I can just glance at it without having to press a button. (I thought that by turning off Power Saving, it would leave the screen on, but this is not what happens. I have no idea what that setting does, actually.) Another "con" is that, while you CAN select 12-hour or 24-hour clock settings, you cannot select imperial instead of metric measurements for things like height, weight, and pace (pedometer). You are stuck with centigrade for the temperature setting in the barometer. I would very strongly recommend to the manufacturer that they give American users a way of selecting the measurements they are used to. (Yes, I know, we should get with the rest of the world, but many of us have spent our entire lives using the "wrong" system and we're too old and set in our ways now to be able to cope with the alternative!)Anyway, I'm pretty pleased with this watch, which I was given in exchange for my unbiased review. It's just an incredibly useful little tool, even without being connected to a smart phone.

I read somewhere that this makes really good coffee in a percolator, so I thought I'd try it. The price is definitely right, but I don't really care for the taste. The size of the grind is great, though. I will wind up mixing this coffee with another kind to improve the taste.

I bought this exact same percolator about ten years ago and made the mistake of following somebody's advice to wash it by putting dishwasher detergent in it and running it through a perk cycle. This served to pit the metal piece on the bottom that the percolator spindle seats down into, and metal started flaking off into the coffee. I stopped using it because I was afraid of being poisoned and was thinking I'd try to find the parts to replace that piece at some point.I finally broke down and just bought another pot. It's the exact same pot I had before, and it works exactly the same way. I read somewhere that percolators burn your coffee, so this time I took pains to measure the temperature of the water both immediately after perking and after it has sat there for a while. As soon as I was able to remove the lid after perking, meaning the water had cooled somewhat, my reading was 188 degrees F, and then it hovered around 186 thereafter. This seems about right to me, because I figure the water is probably perking through the grounds at a little higher temp but not by much. The coffee sites recommend to brew from 195 to 205 degrees F, so that's pretty darned close for something you don't have to do anything to.I did invest in a package of those disk-shaped coffee filters, and I have no trouble whatsoever with coffee grounds in my coffee. The first few pots of coffee I made in it (after washing the pot out first as instructed, of course) didn't taste very goodthen it dawned on me that maybe it was the bleached filters. I put the screen from my little-used 32-oz. French press into the basket instead (fits perfectly!), and the taste problem disappeared so that must have been it.We make 8 cups (which is actually 40 oz. of water, not 64 oz.), and that's just right for the two of us to have two full mugs of coffee in the morning. Using the "1 coffee scoop for 2 cups" method, with "one for the pot" on top of that, the coffee strength is just right for us. (I use a 1/8-cup scoop, which is 1 oz. or 2 level tablespoons.) After we finish our coffee, I immediately dump the grounds and rinse out the pot, then leave it unassembled to dry out during the day. At night, I prepare the next morning's pot, which is on a timer so it'll be ready when we wake up. But it doesn't take long to perk a pot; figure about one minute per cup.

This is a very special tea, an experience that I really was not expecting. I don't know a lot about teas, only that up until recently I haven't really wanted to drink much tea. I have to cut back on coffee because of my osteoporosis, so I've been exploring lower-caffeine alternatives like green and herbal teas. The stuff you buy off the shelf at the grocery store is pretty ghastly, though, in my opinion.Elitea offered me this tea and a bag of their daily green tea (reviewed separately) in exchange for my honest review. Unlike the green tea, which is bagged loose, this tea is packaged as 20 "sachets," pre-measured amounts of the little pearls of tea suitable for a serving (which can be refreshed several times). You can see from my photos how much one sachet is, both dried and brewed for a minute or two.I was unprepared for how marvelously scented this tea is. What starts out as interesting little balls unfolds into very fine end tips of tea with the most heady jasmine scent you can imagine. This is not a tea for gulping down while you're doing something else. No, it is to be lingered over, to disappear into, to take a flight from the everyday into a peaceful, blissful space. Think a long, slow soak in a fragrant bath...a mindful walk in fresh air after a cleansing rain...a meditation on all that is beautiful in this world. That's what drinking this tea is like.If you are entertaining and want to give your guests a special experience, you can't go wrong with this tea. Put it in a glass tea infuser, watch it unfold, and escape your cares for a while.

I am not a tea conossieur, but I've got osteoporosis and have been told by my doctor to cut back on the amount of coffee I drink and caffeine I consume. I was buying your typical bagged green and herbal teas from the grocery store and was not thrilled about the taste. I found myself not drinking any at all and craving more coffee.I know green tea is touted as being very good for you, health-wise, so when I was offered a bag of this green tea in exchange for my honest review, I thought I'd try it and see if it was any better. Boy howdy, is it. The grocery store bagged green tea has a bitter flavor no matter how long or short of a time I steep it and the color is more brownish-green. This loose green tea brews to a beautiful light golden-green color with a delicate, non-bitter, somewhat grassy taste. I brew it in one of my nice little tea infuser cups, and I can fill the infuser three times on one 3- to 5-gram serving of the tea. That's more than 24 ounces of water plus the tea, both of which are good for my health. It's an enjoyable habit to get into every afternoon.The bag is large and the tea will last a long time even if imbibed every day. I really like watching how the flat lengths of dried tea reconstitute in water to show the tea leaves and stems. It's a decidedly more pleasurable experience than the old yucky teabag one. Less trash, too. I may even try eating the spent leaves in salads or throwing them into smoothies because the leaves will still have nutrients even when spent.

Exactly what I needed to be able to use an outlet on a kitchen wall that's low to the floor and behind shelving. I've got two Origami square shelves along that wall that we use to keep our large-quantity Costco products on, on the lower shelves, and rarely used pots, pans, etc., up high on the top shelf. Because the kitchen is small with not very much counter space, and only two outlets there, I wanted something that would allow me to plug in things like my rice cooker, crock pot, and water kettle on the remaining working-height shelves so they aren't cluttering up my counters.The problem in the past has been that those big surge-suppressor type strips are just too big and bulky and we can't really mount them on the wall up where we can reach them because this is an apartment that prohibits that. But this extension cord hangs tidily from the top shelf by a hook and gives me three grounded plugs for my appliances. The only thing that could make this better is if it had a rocker switch to turn off the power, but it's easy to unplug things when they are not in use and replug them in when I need them, so I am quite happy.

I have not worn makeup in years, but when I got new tortoise shell glasses, I realized I needed a little something to brighten my skin because the contrast of the dark frames against my sixtysomething skin is pretty intense.This kit is large with a number of colors that can be mixed or used individually for various effects. The effects are subtle, which is a good thing for me because I detest the look of most heavy makeup. The kit does not come with its own brushes, so you need to have makeup brushes to use it. I like that I can twirl a brush into the different "pots" and brighten up my skin when I'm going out. The powders are not drying, and they feel smooth on my skin. Again, subtle. I don't know how these would combine with the usual liquid foundation many women use because I don't use it, but I would think  the different colors could be used for some nice subtle contouring. I was given this product in exchange for my honest review.

I love this beautiful stainless steel spice bowl. Some might want to use this for sugar, but we don't really use sugar in our house. What I plan to use this for is salt beside the stove. The little spoon holds exactly half a teaspoon, which is the perfect size for adding salt to foods. I particularly like the weight of the lid; it's a good heavy stainless steel that's a pleasure to use. It's stable and elegant. I may also get one to keep coconut or olive oil in for oiling pans without using too much oil. I was given this pot in exchange for my honest reveiw.

I've been seeing these Pure Komachi-type knives in the stores and online and have wondered about how good they are. I have a set of Victorinox kitchen knives (chef, paring, and slicing) that I like, but the slicer and chef's knife are both a bit big for me (I'm under 5' tall and have short arms), so I wind up using the paring knife (also a pretty big parer) for most cutting-board tasks. When I was offered this set of Kai Pure Komachi HD knives in exchange for my honest review, I thought I'd give them a try.What can I say? I love them. I've never owned a Santoku knife before, and I really like the balance and feel of this one. It's lightweight but very sharp, and it glides through whatever I'm chopping with ease. I didn't realize I'm more of a top-down chopper (which is what the Santoku is designed for) than a rocker-chopper (chef knife's forte), but I am. So the Santoku is much more comfortable and less stressful to use for me.The purple multi-purpose knife is the one I will probably use the least. I don't do a lot of boning or scaling, but that is what this knife is mainly for. It has serrations on half the blade, closest to the handle, allowing for a steady, strong grip, plus a very sharp point for getting into joints and slicing tendons.I think I may like the paring knife the best of the three. The shape is wider and a little shorter than my Victorinox parer, so it gives me a lot of control. It can also be used to chop with a rocking motion for things that I tend to chop often (celery, herbs, carrots, onion halves), and it matches my silicone cutting board. I just leave it out, in its silicone sheath, so it's always at hand for food prep. My magnetic knife strip is full of other knives, so the other two Pure Komachi knives will be kept in a drawer, but they do stick to the strip. I'm more likely to reach for the Santoku now than my chef's knife, and my other parer will likely be used by my partner instead of me.I used to think the colored coatings on Komachi knives were kind of gimmicky, but they serve two purposes: (1) they cause food to glide off the blades instead of sticking, further reducing fatigue and increasing efficiency, and (2) they are color-coded so you can keep them for separate meat- and vegetable-cutting tasks. The silicone sleeves are great for protecting both the knives and your fingers. I highly recommend these knives.

A few drops of this muscle relief essential oil blend is marvelous in a bath after a workout. I also find it very helpful to knock back the itching and pain of a tibial tuberosity ("bump" on my kneecap) that plagues me on occasion. I blend a few drops into some coconut carrier oil I have, and it goes a long, long, long way. The smell of the blend is similar to Bengay but not as offensive; it's a brisk, uplifting, minty scent that would also work well in a diffuser if you like the smell. It'll make you clear-headed! I received this product free in exchange for my honest review.

I was really excited for the opportunity to be given a sample of this multi-functional automatic breadmaker in exchange for my honest review. It has 19 different programs for all kinds of things, not just different varieties of breads (including quick, sweet, and traditional loaves of all kinds) but also jams, rice wine, yogurt, and "stir-fry" (which I gather from the instructions really is for roasting things like peanuts, not stir-frying as most people think of the term). The yogurt setting, especially, is what I was most interested in, although I was interested to see if you can roast canned garbanzo beans to make a healthy, crunchy snack.This is a very sophisticated breadmaker, but you need to have the space for it. I was disappointed that, in my typically small apartment kitchen, there is just no place to put it to be able to use it. First, it doesn't really fit underneath the cabinets because you can't open up the lid enough to get the baking pan into it. Even when I move everything out of the way and pull it out all the way to the edge of the countertop, turning it sideways so I can get into it better, the lid still hits against the bottom of the cabinet and I have difficulty getting the bread pan in and out. Too, the little rubber feet tend to come off when sliding the appliance out, which is a pain. I tried moving the whole thing to a large Origami shelf I have in a corner of my kitchen, but even with a substantial amount of room between the shelves, the lid won't fully open, the shelf really isn't level enough, and I have to crawl underneath the shelf practically to unplug the unit after each use, which is just too much.Because I'm under five feet tall and this breadmaker sits up so high on the countertop, I can only look at the digital readout from a side angle, and you really need to be able to look down on it to see the readout well. I have had this trouble with other digital displays. Unlike other breadmakers I have owned in the past there is a lot of extra space around the bread pan when it is inserted, which is a good thing for allowing for air circulation, even baking, and good color; it does make for a bigger appliance, however.The instructions caution you not to add ingredients to the pan while it is inserted in the machine to prevent dropping ingredients onto the heating coils, but it's very hard to put the pan into the machine properly with ingredients already in it, especially if you are trying to keep the yeast dry. If you are careful, I see no reason why you couldn't just add the ingredients to the pan when it is inserted into the machine.Two things bother me, but they are more cosmetic than anything else: The hinged lid has a good bit of float to it, so when you close the lid it oftens closes off-kilter and has to be repositioned. If I weren't trying to work with it in such a crammed spacewhich is the fault of my space, not the breadmakerthis probably would not be an issue. I do find the "Quality Life of Petty Bourgeois" emblazoned on the side to be weird. Maybe it's just because I'm American; maybe in the rest of the world that slogan would not seem so dated and odd.This breadmaker really is better suited for a large kitchen with plenty of open countertop space and no cabinets overhead. It needs to be placed in a dedicated spot where it doesn't have to be moved and where you can get to the plug to unplug it easily. The cord is amply long, which is really good, so if you've got the space and if you're tall enough that you can stand facing directly down over the digital readout and not have to look at it at an angle, this might work well for you. For those who are trying out using a breadmaker as a cooking utensil (and I know that's a trend these days), this may be just what you're looking for.

I was not quite prepared for how DIVINE this moisturizing oil smells. Do you work someplace where your hair takes on smells that aren't that wonderful (e.g., cigarette smoke, food) and want to spiff up before a date? Just a few drops of this stuff run through your hair, and you will be instantly refreshed. It's got lavender and sweet almond oil scents, but it doesn't smell like lavender (which I tend not to be fond of), not really. I don't know how to describe it. It's just awesome! It also feels great on the skin. I have very dry skin on my arms, and I rubbed just a few drops into my palms, then rubbed them over my forearms. Without any greasiness, my skin feels softer and smoother, and of course I smell fantastic. One drop on a tissue in my underwear drawer...instant freshness. The scent is absolutely intoxicating. And because it's lavender, I'm sure it will be good to help with sleep. I'm so glad I was offered this product free in exchange for my honest review. Love it....

I received the Blue A style of this pillow case in exchange for my honest review. I had an old ratty square pillow I got at the thrift store that was the perfect size for this case, and it immediately transformed the corner chair that it was placed on. The zipper is truly hidden, so it looks like the pillow is sewn. You just have to fold the pillow to insert it, then work it in straight before zipping up the case. If you want to give your space a nice punch of color inexpensively, hit the thrift store for the pillow(s) and then add these cases. Or you could use them to stow away some bulky piece of clothing like a big sweater or a throw during the summer until you need them later.

These silicone spoon rests are really big, big enough to protect your countertop no matter how large of a kitchen utensil you try to rest on one of them. The well holds about 3/4 cup of liquid, that's how big they are. I was actually thinking I might be able to use these for poaching eggs in a skillet, but they are really too floppy for that purpose. I would like them better if they were a little less floppy, but they work fine for their stated purpose. If you catch, say, spaghetti sauce or pancake batter in them, you can just pick the whole thing up and pinch the edges together and pour whatever has dripped out back into your pan or onto your food. For the price, you can't beat them. I received these spoon rests in exchange for my honest review.

This is a very nicely designed and packaged fingertip pulse oximeter. The included lanyard works either with the oximeter itself or with the included carrying case. The carrying case has both a belt loop and a plastic keychain-type ring. The oximeter works with two AAA batteries, which are included, and gives a quick and easy-to-read reading. The reading doesn't freeze, so you can see real-time fluctuations, which will be handy for anyone using one of these while exercising.When I first received this and tried to use it, I thought it was defective because I could not get a display. The battery case has the springs that I associate with the negative ends of the battery aligned together on one end, and at first I put the batteries both in with the negative poles on the springs. No love. But then I looked in the case and saw that the +/- were inverted, as on many battery cases, so I reversed one of the batteries (thinking it wouldn't work because of the spring being in the wrong place) and it then worked just fine. So be aware of this. Don't let the spring positions fool you, in other words.I will use this oximeter to take readings when I am biking on my indoor cycle. It is not designed for medical use. I received this oximeter in exchange for my honest review.

I was given this product in exchange for my honest review. I want to point out, first, that the company has been fantastic to work with. The first unit I received was defective and had to be replaced, which they did quickly. They gave me a shipping label and RA# to return the defective product so they can return it to the manufacturer, which turned out to be a bit of a hassle because I had to take it up to the UPS store, but the new one arrived quickly and worked fine out of the box. I had to uninstall all the software and reinstall it. The person I worked with made himself available 24/7 to help me get things set up. The company gets five stars.I have an Amazon Fire Phone, and the Amcrest View Lite app WAS available for it. (This is not true of a lot of apps; often I have to sideload apps to the Fire Phone, and sometimes they just won't work.) However, scanning the QR code did not work so I had to try manually entering the serial number. This did not work either, so I moved on to my MacBook Pro, thinking it was a Fire Phone issue. I don't have a disk drive on my Mac, so I downloaded the configuration software and installed it that way. Again, I had to manually enter the serial number, which is tiny and hard to read, but I managed to get the camera installed. It was recognized immediately. Not only that, the Fire Phone app then recognized the camera. Go figure!I stood in front of the camera with my Fire Phone and discovered there is a slight lag in recognition of movements. This is not a big deal. When I turn on the sound, there is feedback, but that might be because the phone was so close to the camera. (I don't have a cellular service, so I can't check the phone/camera interface from a distance, so I'll have to wait until I do get service before I can tell how well it's going to work for distance monitoring.) I was pretty impressed with how the camera can pan the whole room, and it's a stable, tidy camera and the images are high resolution and sharp. The app can toggle between a single full view and a view from four different cameras (if you have that many).Before I can really put this camera through its paces, I'm going to have to spend more time with the user manual. Fortunately, you can download the full manual from the amcrest website. I don't particularly like the fact that I have to use Safari or Internet Explorer instead of Chrome; this is a deficiency, in my view. (I mean, who uses Internet Explorer? And I don't use Safari because I have a Chromebook as my second machine and I want the experience to be seamless between the two of them.)But the camera is well made and versatile. You have choices of how you want to store your images and video recordings, if it's important to you to be able to save them. For me, my intended use will be as a pet monitor and a way of reassuring my nutso dog if we go out without him. I see no reason, now that everything is installed and operative, why the distance viewing feature won't work well. I just have to get a cellular account so I can take full advantage of it. Miracles of modern technology!

When I was offered a pack of these washable pet training pads in exchange for my honest review, I jumped on it because I was almost out of my disposable ones. Bingo, a 10-lb. chiweenie, goes outside twice a day (DP and I take turns), but sometimes he'll get up in the middle of the night to go and that's when he needs and knows to use the pee pad.I like these pads because they can be washed and reused. That's that much more plastic that doesn't wind up in our landfills and oceans. I do all of my laundry with a Breathing Mobile Washer, hanging it to dry on a drying rack, and these pads lend themselves well to my routine. I can wash one quickly and hang it up, and by the time I need to wash the other one, it's dry and ready to use. I don't know how well the waterproof (pee-proof) backing will hold up over time, but so far so good.

The best part of this set, which I was given in exchange for my honest review, is the spatula. It is the perfect size for turning eggs in an 8" skillet: not too big, not too small. The soup ladle only holds about a third of a cup, which is a good size for portion control, and the slotted spoon and noodle ladle are good for a number of uses. I really like that these are silicone molded over plastic, which lends strength to the utensils that you don't get with silicone alone. The only thing I don't like about these is that I wish the plastic over which the silicone is molded were more of a bright white. They look at little yellowish, and I would prefer that they not be so. But other than the color, this is a very sturdy, useful set. The hanging holes, especially, are great: large enough to easily hang on hooks or pegs.

If you are used to strong chemical fragrances, you might think there's nothing special about this Luseta Coconut Milk Shampoo and Conditioner for dry and normal hair because you aren't immediately knocked out by perfume. That's a GOOD thing! Especially for people who are chemically sensitive, but those who appreciate less chemically concocted products will benefit too. I love the gentle scent of coconut, and I really love the fact that there are no parabens in this formulation because I am allergic to them.I have short, curly, salt-and-pepper grey hair that has a tendency to do the "rooster" number on me. This shampoo tames the spikies and frizzies while leaving my hair soft and shiny and my hard-earned grey shimmering in the light. I don't use conditioner a lot, because it tends to weigh my hair down, but for purposes of this review I tried it. The conditioner is also lightweight and gives silky results. I use hair conditioner as a shaving lotion for shaving my legs in the tub, and this conditioner works beautifully for that purpose, leaving my skin feeling silky-smooth but not greasy.Together, this shampoo/conditioner set gives a true spa feeling. The pumps work well to dispense the product, which is important to me because I have arthritis and detest pumps that are a hassle to use. Overall, a very nice product that I enjoy. I was given the set in exchange for my honest review.

These reuseable chalkboard labels are great for labeling smooth surfaces. I save those huge plastic Snyder Pretzel Snaps jars and use them to store dog food, cereals, snack bars, etc., and having these labels work great with them. If you use 2-liter soda bottles to store things, that would also be a good use for them.I like how white and bright the included chalkboard pen is, and the labels are easily wiped clean for relabeling as needed. There is plenty of room to put things like calories per portion info, too, which is important to me.I also use a lot of mason jars, and these labels do stick well to the jars. However, because the jars have raised markings (the name, the measurements, and decorative touches), the labels don't lie flat and so do not look as good as they do on a flat surface. They do stay stuck on, however, so if a flawlessly smooth look is not that important to you, these labels will work well for your mason jars as well. They pull off and restick easily and look like they'll hold up over time. I was given these labels in exchange for my honest review.

This Senyoo aromatherapy diffuser differs from some other diffusers I have tried in that it holds a little more water and also mists more faintly. The latter is good in the sense of the unit operating for a longer period of time, but it doesn't put out as much humidity into the air as diffusers with more noticeable misting. It all depends on what you want. If you don't want a lot of humidity, this would be a great choice because you can fill it, set it, and leave it for half a day or more without having to refill it. If you are wanting more humidity in the air and a more noticeable scent, another type would be better.The unit sits solidly and the lid is easy to remove, unlike some others I've tried.  The colors are more pastel and subtle. I was given this diffuser in exchange for my honest review.

I have been researching both manual and electric ceramic burr grinders for some months now. The electric ones that get good ratings are frightfully expensive, and even the highest-rated manual grinders are costly. I had to return a cheaper electric grinder because it failed within a few weeks of buying it, and I've been coarse-grinding my whole beans in Costco's grinder for my French press until I could decide what else I can do. When I was offered this iNeibo stainless steel manual coffee grinder in exchange for my unbiased review, I leapt at the chance to try it.My only experience with a manual grinder is an old brass Turkish coffee grinder i picked up on eBay years ago when one of the chef shows recommended it for grinding pepper. It was impossible to grind coffee with because the handle was only about 3" long and it took literally forever to grind coffee. (Back then I was trying to grind for espressono way!) The handle on this iNeibo grinder is much longer, so grinding is not such a chore. I turned the adjustment screw (easy because it's got a plastic thumb-screw on it) counter-clockwise to adjust the grind coarser and just ground a few beans until I got the grind like I wanted it; for finer grind, you turn the screw clockwise. I was then able to fill the grinder with beans and get a grind that was as consistent as the Costco grinder gives menot perfect, but adequatebut it was fresher and the coffee tasted better.I'll be honest: although grinding goes more quickly than I expected with this grinder, it's still a relatively slow process. Anyone who wakes up first thing in the morning staggering around until they get their caffeine infusion is not likely to have the patience to manually grind their coffee. But for the purist who makes coffee ritualistically and appreciates freshly ground beans enough to put the work into itand who, like me, can't afford hundreds of dollars for a top-quality electric ceramic burr grinderthis grinder will be appreciated. It is well made, the handle fits solidly onto the turn bolt at the top but removes easily for storage, and the whole thing stays reliably together while grinding no matter what angle you hold it. It is also comfortable to hold. It's a little tricky at first to figure out how to get the coffee receptacle off because it fits so snugly, but once you've done it a time or two, it's a snap. I recommend this grinder to anyone wishing to experience a really good cup of coffee.

I was hoping this bluetooth player would work with my bluetooth hearing aids, but I was probably expecting too much. I couldn't get them to connect. I can only guess that it has something to do with the way this outputs the sound. So it doesn't work the way I wanted it to work for me, but for what's it's designed for, it works just fine. I love that you can pop your SD card from another player into this one and take off in your car. It's tidy on your dashboard and seems to be working as advertised. I don't have a cellphone to test it with, though. I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

After having worn so many plastic and pleather watch straps that irritate my skin, what a pleasure it is to wear a watch with a real leather band. This is billed as a man's watch, but after wearing an original Pebble watch for a while, I find it's no bigger than that and the larger size would not bother me. But I won't be wearing it because it's going to be the perfect gift for a certain guy in my life. The watch comes beautifully prepared for giving in a nice gift box with puffy pillow inside and even a gift bag.It's a beautiful, minimalist style watch, definitely suitable for business attire. If you're used to digital watches, especially atomic ones, you may find setting it and keeping the day/date windows lined up with the calendar a little fiddly, but start with the instructions and you'll be fine. (Don't do what I did and try to set the watch without reading them first. I did this, and wound up having to turn the crown repeatedly to get back to the proper date because that setting only advances in one direction.)For the day-of-the-week setting, there are selections in (I think) French that might be seasons, but I have no idea what they mean. There was nothing in the instructions about this. The days of the week are in English. The face is clean and modern but with a traditional feel, and the whole thing exudes elegance. The Swiss movement seems very precise, snapping through the seconds like your grandfather's watch used to do. A very clean, very elegant, stylish watch at a price that cannot be beat. I was given this watch in exchange for my honest review.

I design book covers for a small independent press (futurecycle dot org) on a frayed-shoestring budget. I'm completely self-taught, so I'm always on the lookout for two things: inexpensive (i.e., free) art and incentives to be more creative and learn new things. Let me say right up front that I know precious little about how to take good photos, although I can appreciate good ones when I see them. For this reason, I have been timid about shooting my own photos. But I have a Fire Phone with a 13MP camera with high-def capabilities, so when I was offered this 3-in-1 lens kit at a discount in exchange for my honest review, I thought I'd try it and see if it might seduce me into doing more shots for use as backgrounds on my covers.The attached photos are my very first experiments with this lens kit. I was sloppy with it, but I was able to get a feel for what these lenses can do. Although the fisheye lens has potential for some thingsnow that I see how it bends the image, I want to try doing some deliberately distorted shots for further croppingI was mainly interested in the macro lens for taking shots, then applying effects and enhancements in Perfect Photo Studio. I've included a few examples using ON1 and Photomorphis presets.As you can see, you have to be careful to clip the lens on so as to clear the edge of the lens or shadows in the original shot may be magnified in post-processing. I took these photos without benefit of a stabilizing tripod, so some of the blur is not the lens' fault. I look forward to playing with this kit to see what kinds of effects I can achieve.

It's hard to get terribly excited about a hydration bladder, but this one seems well-made and durable. It is of the non-pressurized type, which many find preferable because they are less complicated to use than the pressurized ones. Other bladders on the market have wider openings that you can get your hand into for cleaning, but this bladder's opening is large enough and it's not as expensive as those other bladders. (The main thing when using a hydration bladder is not to leave it with old water in it shut up; when finished with it for an outing, rinse it out well with some water and a little baking soda and hang it up open to dry. Be sure to flush the tubing, too.) The attached hose cap will help you keep from losing this important piece, and the quick disconnect feature makes it easy to remove and store the hose when not in use. I was given this product in exchange for my honest review.

What I like about this is that the hooks come down far enough that I, a 4'11" person, can reach them to hang up my coat, vest, gloves, and dog leash. It fits over the exterior door of my apartment without interfering with opening and closing the door, and it looks unobtrusive. It seems to be well enough built to last, so I'm pleased with it.

I'm a sixtysomething woman who is supposed to be exercising more, and while I'm planning to take a yoga class at the community center near me, so far I'm basically just trying to get in the habit of doing floor exercises at home. This mat works well on my cheap apartment-style carpeting (which tends to burn my skin during workouts), stays flat and put, and rolls up easily to tuck behind a chair or under a table when I'm done. It's solid but not heavy. I like the two ways the straps can be positioned for carrying, too, so when I do get my act together to head out the door, I'll be set.I was given this mat in the Purity style, along with the matching towel that fits it perfectly, in exchange for my honest review. I've looked at various yoga mats and haven't known which would be the best to get, but I very much like the fact that this is made of natural tree rubber, which is a renewable resource. You're supposed to be able to flip this mat over to work on the black side for "hot" yoga (whatever that is), but I prefer to use the towel-surface side for body contact. You don't have to use a towel with it, but if I'm doing something to make me really sweat, I do. Also, I have a mild latex allergy, and I'm assuming "natural rubber" means latex. So far, I have not had any problems with a reaction but, again, I have not worked out with the black side facing up.Anyway, what can I say? It's pretty. Anything that helps me have a positive feeling about exercising helps me develop the habit to do it.

This is a pretty bright light with a nice hanging loop and, if you need it, an included hook with adhesive for hanging it up. It plugs into the USB port of a computer or power bank, and this is where it gets its power. It has an on/off switch on the cord, but it doesn't hold any kind of charge. If you want to use it at a height, like in a tent, you'd need a longer cable; that, or take a power bank that also can be hung up near it. Of course, there are power supplies that can power USB devices as well.We'll keep this in the supplies we have on hand in case the power goes out, along with our dynamo USB charger, so we can always have light just by cranking the dynamo. I was given free or discounted product in exchange for my honest review.

These white mulberries are really tasty! Too tasty, actually...so be sure to portion control them. I'm always trying to find healthy, nutrient-dense foods to incorporate into my healthy clean-eating diet to give myself some variety and a bit of naughtiness without going completely ape and off-diet so I gain back the 83 lbs. I've so painstakingly lost. I don't have much of a problem with sugar, and these mulberries are naturally sweet but not too sweet, so I like that about them. They have a subtle, complex flavor that's satisfying just rolled around on the tongue. I will most likely use these as tide-me-over nibbles and also as a sweetness booster for green smoothies. The only thing I don't love about them is that some of the berries still have stems on them that I have to removebut, come to think of it, that actually serves to slow me down. Which is a good thing! I was given free or discounted product in exchange for my honest review.

Well, whodda thunk it? With all of our technological gizmos and battery-hungry everythings, this simple solution is really the best. Put your items of clothing inside one of these bags, zip it up at the top about 95% closed, then roll up the bag. This presses the air out through the tiny remaining opening, which you then seal down when all the air has been pressed out. You can leave the bag rolled up, or you can flatten it back out. It looks like you've taken a vacuum cleaner to it.I'm not giving these five stars for the simple reason that the little tab thing at the top seems to be useless and acts more to confuse you than anything. I thought at first it was like one of those zipper-like tabs on ziplock bags that help you make sure the bag is being sealed. However, by gliding this tab back and forth, it did nothing. To actually seal the bag (which has two rows of strong but easily sealed-down surfaces), you have to press down with your thumbs, just like you'd do with a standard ziplock freezer bag. This is not big deal. I thought maybe the clip was supposed to be used to keep rolled-up bags rolled up, but if that were what that plastic tab is for, there should be two of them per bag.But, anyway, I like these. I got them in exchange for my honest review; otherwise, I doubt I would have tried them. But now that I have, I'm glad I've got them. I don't travel, but I do have to pack up things for the winter. I can't stand the smell of mothballs, so packing sweaters in these will not only save space; it will help keep the moths away. In the summer, I'd think one of these bags could be use to keep wet bathing suits from dripping all over your car or even to keep the smell of yucky dirty cloth diapers at bay (although you'd need to dedicate any bags used this way to just that use). If you are in a situation where you need to remove most of the air for a good long while, like when you're trying to kill insect eggs, these bags should do the trick. Just don't let your kids play with them!

I have a very small head and faceso small that I've been known to look for sunglasses in the kids' departmentbut the way the ear pieces subtly wrap around my head keeps these snug on my face. Unlike some of the other styles shown on this same page, the lenses in mine are not mirror-finish, and I like it that they are not. The frames are a matte black with understated pinnings on the outer edges of the lenses, which I also like. Call me unfashionable, but the trend toward lots of color and stripes and other loud ornamentation that we're seeing now in both prescription glasses and sunglasses just looks stupid to me. (Give me that geeky, post-apocalyptic "Matrix" look any old day!)It remains to be seen how well these will hold up over timethere are also a lot of really cheap frames out there nowbut the warranty and 100% satisfaction guarantee that come with these glasses should ease anyone's mind about these sunglasses. They are reasonably priced, very lightweight and comfortable to wear, and they'll get the job done. I was given this pair in exchange for my honest review.

Here's my experience with the 8-pack of vinyl weekly wall planner stickons, which I received in exchange for my honest review. This is an excellent value for the price, and I would have bought something like this six months ago when I was looking for something for my home office to help me visualize the big picture of tasks I was tracking in Taco. (Instead, I shelled out $$$ for a big laminated thing I've got pinned to my wall with push pins.)I live in an apartment with a prohibition against tacking up stuff on the walls, and it's your typical bland ivory cheap paint. Very hesitantly I peeled back a portion of the backside of one of the times and stuck it up on the wall to see (1) how hard it would be to get on straight, (2) how well it would adhere, andmost importantlyhow hard it would be to remove and if removal would cause damage.(1) Not hard if you don't peel off the entire backing at once. Those who have installed screen protectors on their phones already know what to do: peel back the edge and get it going straight and positioned like you want it, then slowly pull of the rest, pressing to apply and remove any bubbles that might form. I had no trouble in my test with bubbles.(2) It adheres quite well. I did not test it over many hours to see if it would loosen or the edges curlI will update you if that should occurbut in the initial test, it sticks very well.(3) Yes, it can be removed without damage. But only if you are careful to pull it off slowly. I expect if you tripped one of these off quickly, it might take the paint off with it, especially cheap paint.Because I don't need these for my original purpose, I'm thinking of doing something decorative over the head of my bed with these. My color scheme in my home office/bedroom is taupe, cream, grey, brown, and black, so the black chalkboard material will balance my 40" TV screen on the other side of the room. The set comes with one stick of that really porous chalk like they use in schools, but I have some much-harder fine-point chalk sticks that came with this nice little chalkboard canister set, and it works great for doing fine detail work.Oh, and a tip: When measuring your space to position these, do not bother trying to work in Imperial inches. These are exactly 20 x 30 mm, so use the metric side of the tape measure.

I got the chance to review this really nice VicTSing Android TV Box in exchange for my honest review. Let me say at the outset that I didn't give this an "I love it" five stars only because it does not have Bluetooth. It's not advertised to have Bluetooth, but without it I can't use my hearing aids with this box, and that's what I really need: this box with Bluetooth! But simply saying "I like it" should not detract from your impression of this product.This box has more capabilities and features than I am likely ever to understand/use because I'm not terribly technologically savvy and don't really know how to take advantage of them all. But I can give you my experience with the product as somebody who normally has a lot of trouble installing sophisticated electronics like this one. The instructions are better written than some, but they are fairly sparse. (I'd like to see them put a manual online that goes into more detail about how to use the product once it's initially installed.) Even so, and even with me not being a techie, I was able to pretty much plug it in and run with it. If you want to access more than what's operative at the plug-in stage, you have to go through the settings and get everything set up properly for your system and wireless network (although the ethernet port is an awesome inclusion!).Trying to go through setup with the remote is not a pleasant experience. I could not for the life of me figure out how to dismiss the popup virtual keyboard so it wasn't covering up important completion buttons (Next, Continue). I had a very frustrating half an hour until it dawned on me that I could just plug any old USB mouse into the box and work far more quickly and reliablyplus mouse-clicking outside of the keyboard dismissed it. Magically!!! (...) Once I plugged in that mouse, everything went smoothly with the setup, and it was far easier to explore the apps and see what everything does.After the initial entry of your network connection info and such, you can unplug the mouse as long as you don't have to do a lot of typing on the remote to do what you want. Which is a royal PITA. The remote has a button that can be put into mouse mode, but without good instructions on how it works, I don't know how it works. I did plug in the dongle for my wireless Logitech keyboard after I got everything set up, and it works flawlessly. So, too, does the SanDisk flash drive for saving apps, and the system recognizes the extra space automatically.So at the home screen, you've got 10 apps that you can change (Kodi, Netflix, Spotify, YouTube, Facebook, Skype, WhatsApp, Aptoide, and Chrome and a blank box that is for adding new apps, I think), plus five icons at the bottom: Apps, Browser, Media, File Manager, and Settings. In the settings, among other things, there is a System Update button that, when I click on it, shows a screen with Version Detect, and it shows that my version 1.0.0. is the most current version. I don't know what will happen when they have an update available. The App Manage and Developer buttons offer a lot of control. I was able to install my Smart Connect (hearing aid) app, but because there is no way to pair my Bluetooth control device, it doesn't work for me.Anyway, I'm taking my time discovering all this box can do because I have to wait until my roommate is out of the house so I can turn the TV up loud enough to hear it without my hearing aids. But if you have an Android tablet, you already know how to use this. And, yes, it's like turning your crummy not-smart TV into an Android-based computer with a big screen. It will definitely make ditching cable TV easier to do, if that's your aim, but I've got my cable box on one HDMI port and the Android TV box on another, and they live together just fine.Little things mean a lot: I was able to plug the power supply into the last slot of my surge suppressor and still all the other slots open; this would not be the case if it were plugged into a middle slot. But I need every one of those slots, so I was glad this VicTsing box could live with the rest of the stuff on that wall.

This EverGreen grinder is a little thing of beauty. It's extremely well machined, has two super-fine mesh screens that will screen out the powder (which can be used for other purposes if it's your uber-expensive spice), and perfectly calibrated magnetic closures: not too heavy, not too light. It's definitely better for grinding dry materials, but you can also do fresh ones. I won't do things like fresh basil leaves with this because they are delicate and tend to get stuck in the teeth of the grinder; but tougher fresh herbs like rosemary grind great. And there's just something very nice about seeing the company name, "Evergreen," on the cover. It doesn't give the impression of being a branding; rather, it serves as a reminder to live clean and green. I keep this on my countertop beside my Nutri Ninja as a little psychological kudo for doing my green smoothies every morning.

The concept behind this spray is one I would never have thought about, but for some people who either have dreadfully stinky poop that embarrasses the heck out of them or for people having to live or work with people who think their poop literally doesn't stink, I think this might be something they would have use for. People who travel a lot on planes, especially, whether passenger or crew, could do each other a favor by carrying a bottle of this with them into the john. (Although I don't know if it would get through screening. Maybe the airlines could provide bottles to keep in the john.)To be honest, I wasn't wild about the smell, and that's why I didn't like this Mask spray very much. I associate "clean smells" in the toilet with Pine-sol, not a rose fragrance. I would more likely give a product like this as a gag gift than to actually use it, but of course nobody has to use my toilet but me so I don't have to worry about offending other people. For some, this might be great.

I got this in exchange for my unbiased review thinking it would be authentic 108-bead prayer beads that could be worn on the wrist when not being used as prayer beads. If the bead count had actually been 108 beads, I would have rated it higher. But for what it isreally meant to be a decorative casual jewelry item and not the real thingit's an attractive item. It can be worn as a one-strand necklace or wound around the wrist as shown in the product photo. The stretchy thread on which the beads are strung seems to be pretty strong and so far is not unraveling on the outside like some of the cheaper products do. The color scheme of the beads is definitely vintage sixities (Hippie-era). It should go with a lot of different-colored outfits.

You wouldn't think a stainless steel chain would be nicer than a silver one, but I actually like this one more than the silver chains I have. It's smoothly machined, lies nice and flat like it's supposed to, looks good with tailored outfits, and can be worn dressed up or down. It's unisex, too, and would make a nice gift or his-and-hers set. One end of the chain I received in exchange for my unbiased review had the lobster claw clasp and the other ended in just one of the chain links. I like this better than having another different (and tinier) end piece. To me, it looks better and feels sturdier.

Okay, look, don't even bother buying the one with the handle. Go get the other one that comes without the handle, then go to your local Lowe's and buy a Quickie Cobweb Remover. (They look like this one but I was able to take my Ball washer piece with me to test the fit. They had them in standing displays all over the store for $10.38. )When I first got this washer, I could tell it was going to revolutionize my life, but I was infuriated that the handle (wooden with metal casing for the screw end) would not stay tightly screwed on and kept falling off. Also, the handle that comes with it is really too short to be able to do the washing without bending over. I mean, it really did suck. I started to glue it on with Gorilla glue so at least I could get some use out of it, but I'm so glad I didn't. Had I bought the cheaper version without the handle, then used the Quickie handle with it (saving the cobweb duster end for the handful of times a year I might use it), I'd have what I have now: a dependable, highly workable, color-coordinated handle and washer end that I can hang up when not in use. I can even telescope the handle if I want to, but I don't need to. The lowest setting makes for a good full-length handle that's easy to hold and wash with. Seriously, they should package that exact same handle with the Ball washer head.I'm washing all kinds of things with this washer. I didn't think it was going to work trying to wash a full-sized microfiber comforter in the bathtub with it, thinking I'd need to put it in a ten-gallon bucket for the Ball washer to do the job, but it's fine. The million-dollar question is whether it's going to fit in my SUPERB Nina Soft Spin Dryer, but it looks like it might. I couldn't be happier now.Oh, that million-dollar question was very easy to answer: NO. Don't even try!

I went crazy when this Nina Soft Spin Dryer arrived. DP and I do our own laundry. He goes to the laundromat and I wash my stuff mostly by hand. He hates going to the laundromat and lets his dirty laundry pile up into huge mounds. I've been doing the hand-washing almost two years without benefit of anything but my hands and a few tub trugs and a strainer basket, but ringing out the clothes is really rough on me and I can't do the best job. DP wanted to get a small portable washing machine (which we aren't supposed to have in our apartment because of problems with leaking), but the more I read reviews of what's out there, the more I knew I did not want to spend that much money on what seem to be, today, largely inferior products. So I got this Nina dryer and one of those breathing washer things. (The latter item is a disappointment because the handle keeps falling out; it'll work great if I glue the handle into it.)But this dryer! I am so knocked-out thrilled with it that I wanted to wash all the dirty laundry in the house, not only mine but DP's. He had 2 sets of full-sized sheets (one mismatched with a queen-sized flannel top sheet), two shams, and a pillowcase that I said I would wash for him because I was having so much fun with this Nina dryer. After the aggravation with the loose breathing washer handle, I just slopped those sopping-wet sheets into the dryer. I didn't even try to balance them much. I did them in three loads and just threw the sheets in. The one flannel sheet I did by itself, and that was the only one that gave me some balancing problems that I had to rectify. The other two loads (a set of sheets in one, one bottom sheet and the shams and pillowcase in the other) settled into smooth spinning quickly after closing the lid. I just held the sides until the spinning got going good.Everything went from sopping wet to spun out really close to dry in a minute or two. I didn't time it; I just watched for the water coming out to reduce to a bit of dribbling, then opened the lid to stop the dryer. I threw the load I'd just spun onto the bottom shelf of my dryer rackno dripping!started up another one, and then hung the first one. It was so EASY! Jiminy, if I had realized how wonderful this was going to be, I would have bought one of these Nina soft spin dryers two years ago! And the clothes came out smelling so fresh and clean (thanks in part to the breathing washer thing, ECOS HD instead of Tide, and a touch of vinegar in the rinse water), it was like clothes hung on the line in the breeze and sunshine when I was a child. I used to run through the sheets, and doing this laundry was a pleasant remembrance of the past.I washed two pairs of my Costco Gloria Vanderbilt denim capris and spun both pairs at the same time. I spun them until the dripping stopped, then hung them to dry. Five hours later they were almost completely dry and wearable, with only a tiny bit of moisture at the thick waist band, and it was pretty humid. I also washed a particularly nasty thick reversible white cotton rug and spun it dry in the dryer. It got a lot cleaner than it ever has in a washing machine; the threads didn't unravel more like they would have it a washer; and it was fully dry about a day later. The six bamboo T-shirts were a breeze to wash and dry; I could have put one on right out of the Nina. I'm just knocked out...

You can put this pitcher in the freezer and the microwave! You just have to be careful to sit it on a towel and give it a minute for the temperature to equalize so you don't risk breaking it. When I first got it, I filled it up with room-temperature filtered water from my Berkey and put it in the freezer. A few hours later it was nice and cold for dinner.I love that it's a good, heavy, lead-free glass and that it's square. Round pitchers take up more real estate than necessary, but the square shape of this allows for sitting alongside boxes of drinks in the fridge or on a shelf with dry ingredients stored in it. I absolutely love the very wide mouth. The lid will seal tight with a turn of the handle, but I found it too aggravating to unscrew it to pour so I just leave it loosened but nested down into the mouth. This keeps it sealed well enough against odors without making it hard to get into. To pour, I don't fool with trying to get the pour slots lined up; I just pull the whole lid off, then plop it back on when I'm finished.One thing I really like is that this holds two full 32-ounce blender cups from my Nutri Ninja. I freeze 4-oz. smoothie balls (in ice ball makers) in quantity to have on hand as the frozen part of morning smoothies so I don't have to calculate out the portion for My Fitness Pal. I love watermelon smoothie balls, so I'll go get a big watermelon and blend it up with the NN, but that makes for a lot of watermelon juice. This pitcher can hold two big blender cups full, which I can then stick in the fridge until I'm ready to do the ice ball maker thing. This pitcher holds enough for 16 smoothie balls, exactly how many of the ice ball makers I've got, so I can line them all up and pour from this pitcher. (The reference to this holding two pints in the description is not accurate. It's twice that size.) Little things mean a lot!I was given this product in exchange for my unbiased review. I'll buy another one or two, I like it so much.

Okay, I was looking at all the uber-expensive burr grinders, researching reviews all over the internet, and finally came to a review that recommended this one in the lower-priced category. When I saw that there was a $20-off coupon for it, I knee-jerk jumped on it before reading all the reviews here. Then, while waiting for it to get here and planning to return it, I read the reviews and realized that the biggest complaint about this grinderother than the fact that it does not work as well as a high-end grinder, which I don't expect that at this price pointis the design of the bottom holder and the fact that it makes a mess trying to get ground beans into your coffee pot.When it arrived, I had been struggling trying to grind decent coffee for our French press in my Nutri Ninja. DP kept complaining about the ick in the bottom of his cup. So I thought, what the hay, I got this thing for under $40 so I'm going to try it and if it's as wretched as everyone says, I'll donate it to the thrift store. And I had the perfect solution to the mess problem.I have a stainless steel canning funnel that I use for everything, but it's always in my way because there's just no good place to put it. It turned out to be the perfect size to dump a measured amount of freshly ground coffee directly into my French press; the offending Krups coffee container fits entirely inside the funnel so nothing can spill anywhere except into and through the funnel into either my French press or a mason jar or, if I'm cleaning the grinder with a handful of steel-cut oats as I plan to do, right into my Ninja blender cup for my morning smoothie! Not only that, I now have a place to keep the funnel because it can sit on top of the coffee grinder until I'm ready to use it for whatever I'm going to use it for. I'll just have to be sure to dry it after rinsing it out if I use it for anything other than coffee.In the photos I'm posting, you'll see my first run-through making coffee with Krups-ground coffee. I set it on the coarsest setting (how easy was that?) and filled the hopper about half full of beans. I set it on two cups and, thinking that would be 16 ounces, poured my French press about half full of water. Gad, that was some strong coffee! I poured it into two mugs, and you can see how much I got. So the next morning, I left it on two cups, kicked the coarse grind back one notch (I mean, how easy was that?), dumped the ground coffee into my French press, then filled it to the top. That made a coffee that was not too strong, only a tad weak, and quite smooth. And DP did not complain about ick in the bottom of his cup.So, I'll tell you, if this grinder holds up for a few years, I will be quite happy with it. Already it's much better than I thought it would be, given my canning funnel idea. And look how nice my little coffee-making setup looks!UPDATE: Oh, dear. I wish I had something better to report, but I had to send this back. I'd had it maybe two weeks when it started sounding rough. I was going to grind up the last of the beans in the hopper, then try to see if a bean was stuck or something, when it started giving off that bad burning machine odor. That was it. I wanted to like it, and I didn't like the hassle of having to send it back, but send it back I did! Fortunately, Amazon being Amazon, I had no trouble at all doing this for a full refund.

I've always been curious about whiskey stones, so I was glad to get the chance to review these. I was offered the productglasses and stonesat a discount in exchange for my unbiased review, so I thought I'd try them.First, let me say that I am suspicious that there is no mention of what kind of glass these are made of. Many of the double-walled glass products on the market are borosilicate, and there are standards for its manufacture. I have some very nice tea infuser glasses made of borosilicate glass, and they just look to be of a higher quality glass than are these whiskey glasses (which are not as clear). I know that borosilicate tends to be less thick than other types of glass (there is a good discussion of it on Wikipedia that explains why) and that borosilicate CAN shatter in certain circumstances, but I don't worry about that so much with these other glasses as I do with these TeiKis glasses. The whiskey glasses just feel very thin and fragile to me, and after reading some of the reviews about them shattering, I do have to wonder if they are not made of a form of glass so adulterated that it doesn't pass muster.I probably would have given this set a middle-of-the-road rating of three had there been any instructions included with the set, but there weren't. I didn't know I was supposed to wash the stones before first use, nor how long they were to be frozen to be effective, so I just threw them in the freezer for a few hours, then took them out to test them in some cold tonic water because I didn't have any whiskey on hand. Well, drinking it made me sick. Soapstone is not supposed to react with liquids and is supposed to be safe, but god only knows what kind of residue from the manufacturing process I imbibed along with the tonic water.Finallyand this is not the fault of TeiKis because these whiskey stones seem to be sold in sets of ninewhy package an even number of glasses with an odd number of stones? One person gets five of them and the other gets four? Why not eight? Why not ten?

Okay, first, let me say that I do not think I asked for this particular product from TeiKis when they approached me about honestly reviewing some of their products in exchange for discounted or free product. I asked for the whiskey stones and glasses, which I will review separately, and the ice ball makers, which I did not receive. That said, once the box arrived with the whiskey stone set and this Boston cocktail shaker set, I realized I was going to have to go out researching how this shaker actually works so I could at least make a decent stab at reviewing it. (Sheesh, at first I was thinking "They didn't sent me a lid with it!" LOL!)Anyway, a foray into youtube looking for Boston cocktail shaker how-tos was really fascinating. Some of the guys really got into their shaker technique, and I can see that learning to use a set like this is an art.
