There were plenty of explanations about why one's shaker might leak and how to fix it; different ways to shake to be the most comfortable for you and to develop your own style; some fun bar humor; etc. And I couldn't help thinking of Sean Connery's famous James Bond line: "...shaken and not stirred...."I think this would be a fabulous gift for someone approaching drinking age to get them thinking in terms of ritual, finesse, and careful consumptionimpressing all their friends with quality, not quantityso they don't fall into the whole binge-drinking thing that hurts so many young people. But this shaker set doesn't have to be used for alcohol-based drinks; there are plenty of healthy cocktail recipes that don't call for alcohol. For the price of this set, I think it's pretty impressive, and it's what I'd be considering if I were planning to purchase a gift for someone I knew was planning to take a bartending course to see if it's something they really want to do. Heck, now that I have it, maybe I'll think about learning more about making cocktails myself.My set did come with a wooden muddler, and the weight and feel of the whole set does seem to be of good quality to me. I don't have anything else to compare this to, and I don't drink cocktails as a rule, so I can only say that I will use it only occasionally for its actual purpose: mixing drinks. That bar spoon is great and is going to be used to stir the coffee in my French press because it fits, and matches, my 32-ounce double-walled one perfectly. I'll be using the glass with measurements to help me measure out smoothie ingredients or for portion control, and the stainless measuring jiggers will be used similarly. I think this set is an excellent value.

I haven't used a lot of essential oils, so I'm not an expert on them, but I've been offered several different brands and bottles of the oils lately in exchange for an unbiased review. I also (conveniently) was offered a nice little aromatherapy diffuser from another company to test them with.I work in a home office (an older apartment, actually) and the air quality is not too great. I get sleepy easily while I'm working. I like the essential oils to help with breathing problems, of course, and it's nice to use a lavender blend to help me sleep. But what I really needed was something that would help accomplish improving my breathing but also help me stay alert when I'm working.When this Living Pure Essential Oils Frankincense arrived (again, in exchange for my honest review) and I took a whiff of it from the bottle, I thought "So that's what frankincense smells like. What's the big deal?" I would not have chosen it from a lineup of other oils if I were shopping for this in a health store or boutique. But I put a few drops into my little misting diffuser to test it, and I was floored at how much I liked it. It smells very different when atomized than it does full-strength in the bottle. It opens up my sinuses and the passageways of my lungs; importantly, it is uplifting and makes me feel mentally less fatigued than I usually do. It's a winner!

In my twenties and thirties, I wore tortoise shell glasses that looked very similar to these, and I not only loved them, they really were part of my personality and made me feel like "me." Then the wire frames came out and the skinny frames came out and I've hated my glasses ever since. Well, I'm in my sixties now. I have some rounded wire-framed prescription glasses (that aren't "me") that have started to be not good for anything I do closer up, like reading on my Kindle Paperwhite or watching videos on my phone. I still have to have the other glasses for distance and working on a desktop-distance computer, but I absolutely love these Marrywindix glasses for everything else. It may sound silly, I know, but I actually look forward to the end of the day when I'm settled into bed with my Fire phone feeling like "me" again.I like the styling of these so much that I wrote the company to ask if I could have prescription lenses put in them. (I haven't heard back, so I'm going to ask here on Amazon.) They fit my smallU.S. man's hat size smallhead perfectly with no slipping but also are not tight on my temples so they are very comfortable. They are NOT spring-loaded, but I don't need them to be. The only complaint I had about them is that they were kind of "smeary," but I cleaned them with an alcohol wipe and then they were fine. But, oh, the relief of wearing these when reading on my Fire phone. I hadn't realized how strained and tired my eyes were getting until I put these on. Love 'em! (I was given free or discounted product in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.)

I really like these headbands. I've never had to buy sweatbands before, so I don't know how they compare with other more expensive ones, but these are thick and stretchy and fit my small head snugly. I am able to hold my glasses on with them while still keeping my hearing aids open to the air and the sweat out of them. I take turns washing them out by hand in the sink and hanging them to dry. By the time one is dirty, the other is dry.

Wow. This is one heavy-duty, gorgeous citrus squeezer. It is large enough to squeeze juice oranges (not the big navels, but why would you want to), yet it operates smoothly and without strain. It is built like a tank. It feels good in the hand, and it's a breeze to clean it. Dishwasher safe, of course, if you want, but I probably will just rinse it after each use. It's a lovely piece, supremely functional but almost a work of art. I was given this superjuicer at a discount in exchange for my honest review. I am very pleased to have it in my kitchen, where it will definitely earn its keep.

I was actually wondering what kind of urban guerilla gardening tool I could carry with me on my morning walks to trim back the bushes that have grown over the sidewalks to keep them from whapping me in the facewhen I was offered this neat pocket chainsaw in exchange for my honest review. It comes in a perfect little tactical-type carrying case that can be carried on a belt. The bushes in question happen to be at houses that I know are rented by college students, so I'm sure they could care less if I do what the landlord is supposed to do but apparently isn't. It takes a different approach than using pruning sheers would, but I'm not likely to carry heavy pruning sheers with me. This saw has really strong biting teeth; all you need is the elbow grease and you're good to go. This chainsaw will, of course, be great for camping and wilderness hiking and useful for many activities. Shoot, god forbid you should ever get pinned under a rock or tree, but if you do, you won't have to make like a rabbit so you can escape to live another day. Just whip out this little saw and take your limb off! (The truly survival-minded among us will know I'm only partially kidding.)

I drink a lot of smoothies and have a lot of different dried "boosters" (chia seeds, cacao nibs, and the like) that I like to be able to have on a little shelf above my sink where I don't forget to use them. I've been using mason jars with those white screw-on plastic lids, but it takes two hands to get into them and then close them back up, and I wanted something I could access with just one hand. I also needed a way to label them better, because I don't much care for the Avery label look or the hassle of getting the old labels off!These are very nice jars for my purposes. First, they are smooth white ceramic, so they protect the ingredients inside from light. They each hold a cup and a half of dried product, and they can be filled pretty much all the way to the top. The silicone seals are smooth and flexible and effective for closing the jars with one hand, and the chalkboard part is fantastic for labeling those bits and pieces of things that you know you're not going to buy again but don't want to go to waste. Each jar comes with a really neat little chalk stick. It's a harder chalk than what's used on blackboards, and it allows for writing with a fine point. You can put a lot of information on the chalkboard. Just be careful not to rub what you write with wet hands or you'll wipe it off....Speaking of chalk, when I first took these out of the box, I thought they were defective because it appeared that some of the chalkboard part had not been painted on very well. But this was not the case! It's just that there was some white chalky substance on the jars that must have been left over from manufacturing. A quick swipe with a sponge, and it was gone, ready to write on.I started to knock off a star because you can't really solidly stack these. Yes, they do stack but they will roll a bit and not stand totally straight. But this is a small thing. Most people are not going to want to stack them. I mean, the idea is to be able to reach with one hand for one without having to move the other jars around. One interesting thing is that the recession on the top of the lid (also made of ceramic) holds approximately 1/8 cup, or two tablespoons, which is exactly how much I typically use of the ingredients I'm storing in these. I could actually use the lid to measure my ingredient and then just dump it right into my smoothie blending cup. I really do love them. And they look great in my kitchen. Thanks, Vikalis, for sending me a set in exchange for my unbiased review!

I have a little chiweenie who runs to the living room window while I am in the far back of the house workingpropped up in a recliner and under a lap desk with 15" MacBook Probarking his you-know-what off at any activity outside. He knows he's supposed to "soft bark," but he also knows that it's going to take me a while to get out of my chair and get into the living room to yell at him, so he takes advantage of that time to really feel his oats. I've tried bark control products, but they just don't make them small enough for Bingo, so I've wondered if a camera like this with two-way voice would work. Well, let me tell you, I don't know how long it's going to last, but I had one freaked out little dog when I said through the camera "Do you want a timeout?" Talk about getting quiet in a hurry! Too funny...We never go anywhere without the dog because we're afraid he'll bark the whole time we're gone and the neighbors will complain. Now I'm thinking we'll have to try going out to dinner and see what Bingo does while we're gone. It will be funny to see how he reacts when we talk to him. Waiting for payday to try that...but I'm having a lot of fun with the camera.The camera itself is well made and stable. I didn't understand the directions at first for how to get it installed because it had the different ways to handle installation using different devices in a series of what looked like numbered steps. I think a lot of Chinese-made products get panned not because they are not made well but because the English-language instructions tend to be poorespecially for someone who is not particularly tech-savvy like myself. But after I dove in and just did it (with help from reading some of the other reviews here and also through contacting the vendor), I didn't have any trouble. The app is pretty straightforward and easy to use.I was given discounted product in exchange for my honest review. I never would have taken the leap to get something like this had I not, but I'm glad now that I have it. What can I say? It's fun having this around. If you have pets (or children), get one!

I'm a real sucker for beautifully designed products that not only make my life easier but also make me feel like a million bucks when using them. So when I was offered a discounted review sample of one of these double-walled tea cup/infusers from The Immortalitea Companyeven the company name is beautifulI couldn't resist. As soon as I pulled it out of the gift-quality box and found the coupon for a free sample of loose tea, I went to their web site and ordered the tea and another cup so DP and I will both have one. While waiting for the tea to arrive, I tried my infuser/cup with a regular tea bag (and it worked as expected) and also tried some ground coffee in it. The tea was great; the coffee, because the grind was too fine, not so much. A French press grind would probably work fine with it, but this cup is really meant for tea. (If using coffee, I'd recommend pouring the water in first, then sitting the infuser with coffee grounds down into it slowly.)After I cleaned the little (very fine) drainage slots with a soft-bristled toothbrush to remove the trapped fine coffee grounds, making a cup of tea with one of my Alvita ginger-peppermint stringless bags worked just great. I love how the base of the infuser sits inside the inverted lid so you don't have drips all over the place. You can also add dried blueberries or other fruits if you like that kind of thing.But the real pleasure of the experience came when I received my sample of Thai Jasmine Oolong loose tea. The pea-sized buds of dried tea literally bloomed in the water, fascinating to watch, and had such a fine aroma that I just wanted to sit still and linger a while with it. The combination of good tea and a beautifully designed infuser was such a pleasure that I might actually start drinking more tea and less coffee.I haven't tried this yet, but it seems like this cup would also serve for preparing Greek yogurt from regular homemade yogurt. Whey might be too dense to drain through the very fine notches in the infuser glass, but if it works, the infuser would hold an individual serving of the yogurt that could then be mixed with fruit. It would also be a nice receptacle for those kefir grains you wind up having to stick in the fridge for a while because you can't keep up with them. I rest mine in a little filtered water, and this cup would be a mess-free way to hold them cold and drain them as needed.

I needed a case for my Amazon Fire phone that allows for strapping to either my upper arm, forearm, and leg for various activities where I'm tracking movements. This band gets the job done and is a good strong velcro that makes for a really nice, secure fit. I like this band much better than some of those T-style bands because it's a lot cooler. The case proper doesn't offer a lot of protection when the band is removed and I wish they'd make a hybrid-type case that has a hardshell backing that could snap onto the case when it's not being used with the band. But for my purposes, it's working out great.

I received two different styles (and, apparently, different builds) of this product in exchange for my unbiased review. This is the second one I received, and it was much better than the first one.The other version, iKoo Powered by 4 Batteries Brushed Stainless Steel body - Top button Automatic Salt, Pepper, or Spice Mill with Led light(one pack), had a black plastic thumbscrew type mechanism on the bottom that could be easily unscrewed (and lost), used to adjust the grind. This one has a different mechanism involving a stainless steel screw that seems more secure and well built. Importantly, this one came with instructions showing how to put everything together. If you happen to get this and it doesn't come with instructions, be sure to pay close attention to where the inner plastic sleeve in the top goes so you can put it back on correctly!With a slight loosening of the grinder screw on the bottom, my pink Himalayan salt ground up perfectly, which is really nice to have at the table. The grinder does not make much noise when grinding, which is a good thing. I don't think this is a $75 product, however. Maybe a pair, one for salt and one for pepper, at that pricea little smaller, with smaller or fewer batteries.The product could be improved by including some kind of funnel to help pour the spice into the cannister. It is not completely open; there is a cross bar over it, and my regular funnels don't fit. I had to make a paper funnel to fill the grinder without spilling salt all over the place. If the price for one of these grinders stays in the $75 range, I would expect less plastic inside and also perhaps a funnel and a little stand to sit it in that could double as a measuring receptacle so the whole thing could sit beside the stove for cooking.I'd like to see someone design a grinder like this that allows for grinding just enough fresh coffee beans for a mug or two of french-pressed coffee. You couldn't do that with this grinder because there's really not enough space for anything larger than a peppercorn to enter the grinding chamber. I tried cacao nibs and chia seeds in the first grinder I received, and neither of them ground well at all. I think that was because the first one was not as well designed as this one. But now I'm kind of afraid to try them with this one for fear it will ruin it for my salt.

I received two different styles (and, apparently, different builds) of this product in exchange for my unbiased review. This is the first one I received, and it came with no instructions for use. Because I did not know the top part was supposed to be pulled up and off the see-through part in order to fill it, I only tried to do that once and it was so tightly fitted onto the cannister that I thought that must not be the way to do it. I wound up going in through the bottom of the grinder, removing the screw-on part that is used to adjust the grinder and having to take the ceramic burr grinder piece out to put salt in it. This was too aggravating for words, and then I couldn't get it to grind well. I did like the flat-top styling of this grinder better than the rounded one that came a few days later. Fortunately, the tops are completely interchangeable.The other version, iKoo Battery Powered Brushed Stainless Steel body - Top button Automatic Salt, Pepper, or Spice Mill with Led light(one pack), was made better than the first one I received. Where before there had been a black plastic thumbscrew type mechanism that could be easily unscrewed, this new one had a different mechanism involving a stainless steel screw that seems more secure and well built. The instructions showed exactly how to insert batteries and fill the spice canister, so I knew the top was supposed to pull off and wasn't so intimidated in trying it. With a slight loosening of the grinder screw on the bottom, my pink Himalayan salt ground up perfectly, which is really nice to have at the table. The grinder does not make much noise when grinding, which is a good thing. I was able to pull the flat-top head from the other grinder off and put it onto the newer one, and now I have a grinder I really like.The product could be improved by including some kind of funnel to help pour the spice into the cannister. It is not completely open; there is a cross bar over it, and my regular funnels don't fit. I had to make a paper funnel to fill the grinder without spilling salt all over the place. I don't know what the ultimate price of these grinders will wind up beingI know a lot of vendors price things unreasonably high to keep people from buying them until they get a few last-minute kinds worked outbut if the price stays in the $75 range, I would expect less plastic inside and also perhaps a funnel and a little stand to sit it in that could double as a measuring receptacle so the whole thing could sit beside the stove for cooking.Finally, the four AA batteries make this grinder pretty heavy for what it does. While the shape of it is good, the weight is not. Is that much juice really needed to grind salt and peppercorns? If one were trying to grind coffee beans in something like this (don't even think it; the burrs are too small), I could see it.

I love this microfiber towel with zipper pocket. I love the little carrying case it comes with, too, because it can hold not only the towel but also a comb or small hairbrush and maybe some toothpast and toothbrush. I wouldn't try to carry a phone in the zippered case for fear someone might sit on it and smash it, but it would be good for keys, a little cash, and an ID.Don't make the mistake of not washing it first, however. The instructions say to wash it first. I started to just try using it without washing, but it had the sticky feel that new microfiber often does and I didn't want that feeling against my skin. I washed it by hand because we don't have a washing machine, and a ton of dye came out into the water. (I got the grey one.) After that, I rung it out and hung it up to dry, and even when pretty sopping wet it dried within 24 hours.It's a great size towel, and I love it. I walk five miles every morning and come in sweaty. This is the towel I reach for. I was given this product in exchange for my honest review.

This is a good little stash to have on you when traveling, and it does what it says it does. It is lightweight, sturdy where it really counts (the belt loop especially), and it's got lots of pockets to stick things into. The opening to the back mesh side is small enough that I think it probably is not intended for use for anything except maybe stashing some tissues in it, but you probably want to travel light with this anyway so it's not obvious when worn under clothing. A cell phone would fit in the side zippered pocket, but it's really intended for carrying travel papers on your body without calling attention to itself.

I agreed to honestly review these sport headphones in exchange for discounted product. I have very small ears with tiny ear canals, so I knew at the outset that these might not work for MEI have yet to find anything but $$$$ Bluetooth RIC (receiver-in-canal) hearing aids that willbut I thought I'd test them and pass them along to my sister if they didn't.Well, as expected, they don't work with my crazy little ears, but I can say that of the many earbud-style headphones I've tried, the build of these is well above average. I like the strong, flat connecting cable and also the included USB charging cable, which is similarly made, brightly colored, and short so you don't have all this long mess of cabling to deal with at your hub. The USB port cover is better than most and stays firmly closed. The two control buttons give good tactile feedback, although I wish the instructions were clearer on their functions. (The instruction sheet is set in about 4-point type and the photos showing the buttons are tiny. The information included with the photos has been reduced to such a small size that there is no way anyone can read it.) It would be good if they would prominently show a link to online instructions so people can actually find out how to use the product correctly. After much trial and error because of the lack of clear instructions, I was able to get the headphones to pair with my Fire Phone as "MoMo." I don't have cellphone service on my phone, so I was not able to test answering calls.I had a terrible time trying to change the bud coverings to the smallest of the three different pairs included with the headphones, but I finally soaked the pair in hot water to soften them, dried them off quickly, and through sheer brute force was able to get them to go on. If there was a better way, it would be nice to have a how-to included. But they were still too big for my ears. I was able to test the sound quality to a degree by holding the earbuds in my hears, and the quality seemed pretty good to me, but I can't say how they will sound to someone with normal-sized ears who can get a good in-ear fit.If you were wondering what those little loop things are at the top of the earbuds, they are auricles that you seat inside your ear, under the outer folds of your ears, to help hold the headphones in; this is a very nice feature for active types. So is the sweatproof nature of the headphones. (My hearing aids are decidedly NOT sweatproof.) And the packaging itself deserves real raves. When you first receive the headphones, it looks like they are in a clamshell-type package, but it's actually a hard clear case held together by a cardboard sleeve containing the product name and advertising. Remove the cardboard, and you have a two-piece case with an inside clear tray to hold all the pieces. If you wanted to toss it all into a gym bag, just wrap a rubber band around it to keep it together. Less plastic in our landfills and oceans!

Jeff Lynne is a brilliant pop musician. There are more undeniable earworms scattered through his work with The Idle Race, The Move, ELO and solo than you'd find in the careers of any ten more mortal musicians. I've been a huge fan of his work for about 40 years now. And this, his first full album of new original material in nearly a decade and a half, is cause for celebration if only for the fact that it has been way too long that Jeff's been alone in the universe.But, sadly, after well more than a baker's dozen full plays to fully let the album sink in and work its charms, I've found that there's not as much here to love as I'd wish, or that I'd reasonably expect. By my count, there are three very good songs here (When I Was a Boy, Dirty to the Bone and All My Life), and a fourth that sounds like a demo for a really good song (Alone in the Universe). And the rest? Well, every ELO album had a few "skippers"--tracks that weren't exactly horrible, but which I move past when I have the chance. But in the good old days (and even on his first solo album) they didn't constitute 6/10 (60%) of the album...And in the good old days, the skippers weren't so obvious rewrites of other Jeff Lynne work (more on that later).On top of the somewhat low hit-to-miss ratio here, the entire album has an uninvolving boxed in sound, and features drab canned drum tracks. Apparently, Jeff recorded the entire thing on his own, and while it's kind of impressive that a guy can record an entire album on his own in his home studio, maybe it's not as, er, good as it is impressive. I wish Jeff had used a band and an orchestrator to move from these songs--which ultimately mostly sound like highly produced demos--to a more vibrant finished product.The song-by-song rundown.When I was a Boy: The best song here by far. Nice arrangement. This is a latter-day Jeff Lynne classic, no question.  If only the rest of the album were up to this standard.Love and Rain: Typical mid-tempo song that doesn't pay off in the chorus. I do like the that key change around 2:20 where you get the choral "Love and Rain" chorus for about 20 seconds--that sounds like good ELO. But then it's back to the drab mid-tempo main verse/chorus.Dirty to the Bone: Clever start, good song. Catchy, and I'm happy to hear it each time it comes on. But like most of the album, it sounds like a demo.When the Night Comes: Starts like a direct rewrite of Balance of Power's second string track "Is it Alright" at a slower pace, with crummier production, and doesn't improve from there.The Sun Will Shine On You: I think there might be a very good song hiding here with the right arrangement choices. But as it is, it's merely adequate.Ain't it a Drag: This one's a funny one. Taken by itself, outside the context of the album it's kind of fun, and sounds like an outtake from the Full Moon Fever sessions. But it's missing what Jeff once described as "the magic chord change" or something else to keep it from ultimately feeling like a promising idea that isn't fleshed out properly. And within the context of the album, it just slides by.All My Life: Utter pop classicism. Two minutes and 50 seconds of sweet pop bliss. But where are the strings that this song deserves?I'm Leaving You: The best part is the nice guitar figure at the start, clearly inspired by the one Jeff used on Stormy Weather (from Armchair Theater). Then it leads into what sounds like a (very) lousy first attempt at the song that eventually became California Blue, and appeared on Roy Orbison's "Mystery Girl".One Step at a Time: The epitome of a Lynne by-the-numbers mid-tempo rocker, OK verses, lame choruses, filler on any albumAlone in the Universe: It doesn't take a genius to hear the orchestral embellishments that this song would have demanded on a classic era ELO album. With those, it would take its place with such sweeping closers as One Summer Dream. As it is, it's a decent song not given its due.

Asus has become something of a household name over the past couple of decade via their entries in the laptop, tablet and other electronic peripheral markets. What not everyone knows is that they have also made a substantial effort in the past few years to become a player in the cell phone market. And, as you might guess, since not everyone knows that, they haven't been exactly super burning up the sales charts in the US in that area.But that doesn't mean they aren't worth your consideration, if you are one of those people willing to look beyond Apple and Samsung.Earlier this year, Asus introduced a new line of phones the Asus ZenFone 2. These were nice, carrier unlocked, relatively inexpensive phones that offered pretty good functionalty. They didn't have the best cameras on the market, or the best performance. But the phone reception on the phones is very good, and as long as you aren't pushing them too hard, they're attractive lower cost options.One of the features that differentiated those earlier generation ZenFone 2 models is that they featured (relatively expensive) Intel processors, giving them a bit of a performance boost, but making those phones a bit like lone wolves in an ecosystem where Qualcomm Snapdragon processors rule, which, among other things, adds to the support costs for phone manufacturers who want to ensure every new Android update lands on their phone line.So it's probably not a surprise that for their new iteration of the ZenFone, the Asus ZenFone 2 Laser, Asus has moved over to the Qualcomm platform. Beyond the change in processor, the main new feature of this iteration of ZenFones is that Asus has added laser assisted focusing technology to the (13 megapixel) rear-facing camera. On top of that, the specs of this particular phone are pretty solid: An upper-midline Qualcomm Snapdragon 615 processor (MSM8930) with associated Adreno 405 GPU. A full HD resolution (1080x1920) 5.5" screen. A larger-sized 3000mAh battery. A generous 3Gb of RAM and 32Gb of storage.  Two sim card slots (you can have two phone numbers with this single phone--although few people use that feature). A second, 5 megapixel, front facing camera. And a micro-sd slot to add storage.The phone comes carrier unlocked and is supported on all GSM networks (so in North America that would mean AT&T, T-Mobile and Rogers (in Canada), plus the third party carriers who use those networks).In the box you get the phone, a USB cable, and a charge. You do NOT get a pair of headphones (honestly, given the quality of the included headphones with most phones, not a loss). Any Android compatible headphones will work with this.Enough about specs and features. How good is this phone?First off, the operating system. The phone comes with Android 5 (Lollipop). That's the good news. On the not as good side of things, to that Asus has added a bunch of (IMHO) unnecessary software on top, which they call the ZenUI. I mean, the added launcher and other software isn't terrible. But I don't think it adds much to the vanilla Android 5 experience and does add more software to slightly slow down your phone and possibly cause issues down the road. That said, one feature of the ZenUI I do like is that it automatically separates your apps into folders based on their category of function. (Photo apps, games, etc.). I do this by hand on my other phones with more vanilla Android interfaces, so having it done automatically (assuming you're OK with the categorization) is not a bad thing. As for responsiveness, I found the phone pretty fast. With about 15 apps opened, including Google Maps, three different browsers, a third party messaging app (Pinger), and a few other things, I was still able to open and play a low-stress game (Angry Birds) without any issue. Everything worked as it should and I could switch between apps and browsers without issue. Responsiveness of the browers remained good and fluid.I wouldn't say the phone was MORE responsive than other mid/high end recent phones. But it was quite satisfactory.In terms of ergonomics of the external buttons, the phone is...odd. The power button is on the top of the phone, not on the side where it's located on just about every other smartphone on the planet. I found that the position of the power button was very inconvenient for one handed operation. This might have been a deal breaker except for the fact that you can also do the equivalent of a power button push by double tapping the screen. While it took a little while to get used to that, once I did, I found that a wholly acceptable alternative to the physical power button. (You still need to use the physical power button to get to the Power Off menu, but I don't typically need to do that with one hand). The volume buttons are also oddly located: On the back of the phone, near the camera, not on the side. Almost immediately, I found this position for the volume buttons to actually be preferable to where you typically find that. They feel very comfortable there. I was worried whether the buttons would be more prone to pushing when the phone was in my pocket, but I didn't find that to be a problem.The screen is bright and clear, as you'd expect for a full HD screen. It didn't seem that the images were quite as vibrant as on some of the top end phones I've used, but certainly it's good enough.Battery life was very good, as would be expected for phone with a larger battery like this one. For an average user, you should have no problem getting through a full day without recharging. In my preliminary testing, I had 35% of the battery left after a full day of power use. A non-typical test of playing video continuously (720p video) until a fully charged battery died gave about 11 hours of play time (with screen at about 70% brightness). The combination of the fairly hefty battery along with the conservative processor and screen shows its power here.On top of the pretty great battery life, the battery is easily replaceable on this phone (snap off the back, change battery). In a world where more and more phones have gone to non-removable batteries, that's certainly a nice feature!The phone, in terms of capability as, you know, a phone, worked quite well. It seemed to be able to pull in a stronger signal in the same place as an iPhone 6--although comparisons based on "reception bar" readout are always suspect. Callers told me I sounded very clear, both in standard and speaker phone mode. The built in speaker is clear, precise, and reasonably loud.Finally, there's the camera. (You were wondering if I'd forgotten?) That's supposed to be the special allure of this phone, because the "laser assisted focusing" is supposed to allow the camera to focus more quickly and accurately, especially in low light. This is a relatively rare feature on camera phones, available only on a few other phones like the LG G3 (The laser assisted focusing sends out a beam that makes it possible for the phone to quickly and accurately focus even in low light. Most phone cameras auto focus by maximizing contrast/phase in the image, and this tends to start to fail in low light). And I did, indeed, find that the camera focused quickly and reliably on objects that were near to the camera. I have no reservations in asserting that in terms of auto-focusing, the camera in this phone works more reliably than any other mid-line phone camera I've ever used, and arguably better than the top end cameras in phones like the iPhone 6 and the Galaxy S6. That's the good news. The bad news? Well, outside of the focusing, the image quality from this camera is pretty average. Photos tended to be somewhat soft. Also, the laser focusing only works well for objects that are close to the phone. If you try to take a photo of something far from the phone, the laser assist has little effect (and in fact the camera automatically reverts to standard contrast based focusing). Finally, while the camera did reliably focus even in low light, the quality of low light images wasn't particularly impressive--images tended to be grainy. This isn't a surprise, but the quality of the (admitedly focused) images wasn't as good as you could get with the very best camera phones.Then again, let's remember this is a relatively inexpensive no-contract unlocked phone.On the whole, I found this phone to offer quite a bit to like for the price. No, it's not a competitor for the top end of the current generation if things like having the very best camera or playing the most demanding games are important. But it has an acceptable camera, a decent processor, a decent screen, good battery life, a replaceable battery (!), two sim slots and micro-sd expansion. A phone like this would have been amazing a few years ago, and it's still a good phone now.It's worth considering that in terms of processor, GPU, screen size, and battery, this phone is very similar to the new highly hyped Moto X Play. It adds laser focusing but has an arguably slightly inferior camera, the Asus has 1Gb more RAM than the Moto X Play (3Gb versus 2Gb), and the Asus has a somewhat smaller battery (but both phones have large enough batteries for full day use). Depending on what you think is important and your budget (and current pricing when you're looking) comparing these two phones would be a great place to start.

Amazing top end quality leather duffle. If you're looking for a really fine leather duffle, this is the one.It can be confusing to try to pick leather luggage through mail order. First off, everything carries a high list price, but most of those are just nonsense. Some brands typically sell (after common discount) at 60-70% off list, at least, and sometimes more.Also, just because something is made of leather doesn't mean it's made WELL of leather.This particular duffle is, in fact, very high quality. The zippers are good. The seams are well sewn. The lining is high quality. They didn't cheap out here anywhere. Oh, and the bottom is a thick piece of leather, not pressboard with a thin leather veneer. The latter construction is very common among even mid priced leather duffle bags. Here, high quality stitching  in a appropriately thick leather are used instead.Derek Alexander is not that well known in the US, but it's a pretty well known brand of leather goods (especially handbags) in Canada. This is not a budget line. And the real sell through price of this item is only about 20-30% off full list, even on sale.This isn't cheap. So if you need something cheap, look elsewhere. But if you're looking for something really nice, something that's going to last and that you'll feel good about owning and using, you've come to the right place.

Well, it's interesting, innit? A router with a built in LCD screen that allows you to do basic setup without connecting it to your computer.In addition, it supposedly has amazingly high power antennae.Very cool, very exciting.I wish it were so in practice. While this isn't a horrible router, it has its problems and I didn't find the LCD screen input all that hot, nor the power all that great.More on that...Setup:Took the router out of the box, attached the antenna, connected it to my modem and powered it up. It took about 3 minutes from power on to actually presenting an interactive screen. No big deal...There's an included stylus (plastic pointer device; you can also use your finger). There's a Wireless Setup walk through that only offers you the ability to name your networks and give them passwords. I found entering this data through the screen using the on-screen keyboard, to be painful. Yes, you don't have to connect it to a computer. For some, that's a relief. I don't find it hard to connect a router (attach Ethernet cable and browse to the correct IP address...not rocket science). But OK, it's kind of cool. And the resolution of the LCD is sufficient to not imagine you've been sent back in time. But data entry is really laggy and cumbersome. Once you've set up the basic info, there are a variety of other buttons that will take you to various interfaces. There's nothing very deep here--mostly you can get simple readouts of your network status and that kind of thing, set up a DMZ and a few things like that if you need to (most won't). You can also check for updated firmware (mine said none was available). Ultimately, I started to feel after a few minutes that this was as much gimmick as good...But alright...How about performance?Well, I almost didn't think I was going to be able to test it. I set my password, went to my wireless PC (Microsoft Surface Pro), selected the new wireless network, entered the password and...nothing...no connection. Tried again. Nope. Went back to the router to make sure I'd entered the correct password there. Yup. Reentered the password and rebooted. Went back to the Surface Pro. Still no joy. I wasted probably half an hour trying to get the router to talk to the laptop on either the 5ghz or 2.4ghz channel and couldn't succeed on either channel. So then I went back and tried to connect via the WPS service. THAT worked. Finally. But it still doesn't explain the problem negotiating a real password. Anyway, having connected (via 5ghz) I was able to test the speed of the router.On the speed front, the router was fine. I got download and upload speeds equivalent to the built in antenna of the model/router (Verizon FIOS Quantum Gateway). The speed was about 10% faster than  a Wireless N (not AC) router in the same place, the Asus RT-N66U.In terms of coverage...OK, but not amazing. I measured the wireless signal one floor down from the location of the router. The signal for the 5ghz signal was at least 10% LOWER than that eminating from the Verizon FIOS Quantum Gateway router. It was also about 10% LOWER than the 5Ghz signal for the Asus router. On the 2.4Ghz channel, the signal of the Amped router was once again at least 10% lower than that of the Fios Gateway router. More significantly, it was at least 40% LOWER than the 2.4Ghz signal I was getting from the Asus RT-N66U in the same place.Based on these measurements, I can't say I'm extremely impressed with the power of this router. The router is advertised as having an amazing set of high powered antennae, but in my test, the signal from this router wasn't quite as good as two other (high quality) routers just one floor away on the 5Ghz band, and was APPRECIABLY worse than the Asus router on the 2.4Ghz band.The throughput was as expected/hoped, and that was nice to see. But the problems I had in connecting the router using anything other than the WPS mode makes me wonder how convenient this router will be in the long term.The LCD screen input is interesting, kind of cool even, but for me the painfulness of entering information chicklet by chicklet with the onscreen keyboard, and the laggy response to the keyboard input, outweighed the convenience of the screen.On the whole, this is an interesting router, and it seemed to work well enough once set up, but whether one would buy it would depend a lot on the the relative prices of similar spec high end routers....

Another USB 3.0 hub. You have a zillion purchase options for something like this. But before you pass on this and move to something cheaper, it's worth noting two things:1) All USB 3.0 hubs are not the same: The cheap ones don't reliably perform at USB 3.0 speeds. (And that's a huge thing, because real world USB 3.0 speeds are at least 4-5 times those of USB 2.0 on most platforms).2) Not all USB 3.0 hubs are powered. That isn't a deal breaker for every installation. But if you plan to run multiple devices that have any power hunger (e.g. a hard drive, even some flash drives, a tablet or a phone, etc.) then having a powered hub is definitely worth having--maybe even essential. If all you will use this for is a mouse and a keyboard, then power is not typically required. (But then, why are you buying a USB 3.0 hub?)(Note that while this hub has a power option, and includes the required power supply, you can run it as an unpowered hub for devices that don't require much power).Anyway, enough of the preamble. What about this hub?First, the contents: You get the hub (quite small), a USB 3.0 cable, and a power adapter ("wall wart"). The power adapter is one of those annoying ones that takes up at least two spaces on your power strip, but is otherwise uninteresting.I tested this hub on a PC (Microsoft Surface Pro) that has built in, on board USB 3.0. To test the ability of the hub to perform at USB 3.0 speeds, I connected a USB 3.0 hard drive in three ways and measured the read/write performance of the drive. The three connections tested:A) Hard drive connected directly to the USB connection of the PCB) Hard drive connected to this TRENDnet USB 3.0 hub, hub connected to the PC. No power to the hub.C) Hard drive connected to this TRENDnet USB 3.0 hub, hub connected to the PC. Power applied to the hub.The speed tests were carried out using the industry standard program CrystalMark. The results can be summarized thusly: It made no difference at all to read or write speeds if the hard drive was connected directly to the PC or through this hub, and it didn't make any difference whether the hub was being powered or not. That's perfect. It means the hub is doing a fully compliant pass through of the data at full USB 3.0 speeds. A+In summary: I was happy with this hub. It actually performs at USB 3.0 speeds, has a small form factor, and includes the option of external power. The only reason I give it four stars rather than five is that the power supply is inelegant, taking up two spaces on a standard power strip or possibly both positions of your wall outlet, depending on how that's situated.

First things first: This phone is not as good as your iPhone6, your Samsung S5, your Droid Turbo, or any other $600-700 phone you can mention.It just isn't. And if you somehow thought that someone could give you a phone that's 100% as good as those top of the line phones for 1/4 the price...well, you can't. There may be fat built into smartphone pricing, but there isn't that much.So let's get real here. This is a $140 phone. No contract, not subsidized. $140 shipped to your home. To bring you a phone at that price point, you would expect some corners to be cut. And some have been cut here.But, terrifically, not so many that this isn't a very intriguing, pretty compelling phone at its price point.So what do you get?Highlights are:** A 5.5" screen (about the same as those expensive flagships),** A 4000mAh battery (better than much of the competition), This phone EASILY lasts a full day without charging, even if you do a lot of screen-on surfing, etc. Note that the battery is not easily user-accessible/replaceable, but with that much juice, you won't have to worry about carrying extra batteries!** Nearly plain vanilla Android 5 (Lollipop). You'll see some reviewers complaining that plain vanilla Android is missing some of their favorite bloatware, or their favorite launcher, or some other doo-dad. For me, vanilla Android is a major feature. It just works better. It's Android the way Google has designed it, without added third party software that mostly tends to get in the way or break things in the long run. Blu had made a few very nominal changes to generic Android, such as the shapes of some icons, but they are pretty irrelevant.** Dual (two) SIM slots--in theory you can use this phone simultaneously with two carriers** A micro SD slot that be used with cards up to 64gb** Expected connectivity: Bluetooth, Wireless, GSM, etc.** Weight is light GIVEN THE LARGE BATTERY SIZE. Weight is 169g, which is basically identical to something like the recent Droid Turbo (another phone with a huge battery).** The phone comes with a protective case and a screen protector. (This is pretty amazing. The expensive phones I've purchased have never included these...For $140 Blu includes them...Something is wrong with this picture, but kudos to Blu!)Midlights are:** Processor is: Quad core, 1300 MHz, ARM Cortex-A7. ( Mediatek MT6582 SoC with Mali-400 graphics). This is a midline processor. Absolutely fine for simple stuff like surfing the web, email, etc. It will breeze through all that. If you are a hardcore gamer, however, you may find this processor a bit laggy with demanding games.** Screen resolution is 720x1280. This is lower than the expensive flagship phones which for this size screen often have double the resolution in each dimension (1440x2560). There's nothing wrong with this resolution, but it won't be as sharp as the higher resolution screens. On the upside, lower resolution screens take less power and increase battery life.** Generally, the screen is adequate, but not as vibrant as a high end phone** While the phone has clean lines and generally feels nice enough, it's made of plastic and will likely have a higher damage rate if you happen to drop it.Lowlights are:** Only 1Gb of RAM, which can nip you if you have multiple big apps running at the same time** Only 8Gb of built in memory. However, the available MicroSD slot means you can add lots of additional memory at low cost** THIS IS THE BIG ONE: The cameras are fairly lousy. The rear 8MP camera takes pictures that tend to be grainy and/or washed out in anything but bright light. Even in bright light, I found that the camera was often relatively slow to focus. If the camera is critical to you, this may not be the phone for you. The front facing camera offers 5MP resolution (higher than average for inexpensive phones) AND a front facing flash (unusual), but it, too, is pretty mediocre.** Phone is only for GSM carriers (AT&T, T-Mobile, Rogers, etc.). This phone will NOT work on Verizon (no LTE) or Sprint.** No wireless charging. No fast (turbo) charging.What's in the box: The phone, a special protective case, a screen protector, a USB wall charger, a USB charging cable, a sim card ejector tool, a low end pair of headphones with in-line microphone, and a couple of quick start guides.In terms of basic functionality I found this phone to be perfectly fine. Calls sounded decent both to me and to the person on the other end of the call. Reception seemed to be the same as flagship phones in the same area. The built in speaker is tinny, but it's reasonably loud.On the whole, there's a lot to like about this phone, such as a large battery, a large screen, great battery life, vanilla Lollipop Android, and a SD memory expansion card. Oh, and the amazingly cheap price. The biggest Achilles heel here is the camera. If you are photobug and have the cash, you may not want this phone. But if you can live with a sub-par camera, you aren't really going to find the remaining feature set anywhere else at this price....Those who simply must have a somewhat better camera might want to give consideration to the Motorola Moto G (3rd generation) - Global GSM - Unlocked - 8 GB Black phone, which retails for only a little more than this phone, and has a somewhat better (and higher resolution) camera. But that it's important to note that the camera in the Moto G is better, but not great. And with that phone you give up considerable screen size (5" versus 5.5") and you also give up about half the battery capacity/life. Those are major compromises, and you'll have to make up your own mind what's most important.

I have owned dozens of flash drives over the years, starting with my first drive, which was 64mb and cost nearly a hundred bucks (to give you an idea of how long ago that was), to some very recent and good drives from SanDisk, Corsair and others.I have also owned PNY flash drives in the past, which were OK.I have had flash drives start to go flaky, but typically only after years of service. Even the cheapo bottom end flash drives that I regularly use at work for temporary file transfers are reliable, if slow.But THIS PNY drive is an utter piece of junk. It worked a sum total of ONE time before it went flaky. I was barely able to get it to be recognized on a PC the second time (I had to try three PCs; it was only recognized on one). By the third time I tried to use it: Dead. It's recognized as a PNY flash device, but with no identifiable memory attached.I should have trusted the other very negative reviews I read.Trust me: I have a ton of experience with flash drives. This one is utter junk. DO NOT BUY IT.I know it's super cheap for the storage and performance it promises. But don't do it. Move. Away. From. The. Computer. Terminal. Now.SanDisk has a 128Gb USB drive for about $5 more on sale. Go with that.

I'm a little perplexed. Reading over some of the  other reviews for these headphones, I see many claims that the noise canceling  doesn't work.I can assure you: It does. I have well over a dozen different pairs of noise canceling headphones, including a couple of pairs of Bose, Dishwasher, Sennheiser, AKG, Sony,and others. The noise canceling ability of these headphones is better than average.I think it's important to clarify what noise canceling can do. Basically, noise canceling listens to the ambient noise and creates a sound wave that cancels the part of the ambient noise that is predictable and continual. So, for example, the rumble of a jet engine on a plane or the hum of a refrigerator can be canceled. Talking can't be canceled, because it's not predictable. Total noise reduction combines the active noise reduction with additional noise suppression that comes from the design of the headphone.These Panasonic noise canceling headphones definitely work pretty well. You can easily experience this: Put on the headphones without turning them on. Go stand next to your refrigerator, then press the on button. You will suddenly hear the refrigerator rumble disappear. That's the active noise canceling.I've used these headphones on a plane, on a subway, and while mowing the yard. While they will not totally turn your world to silence in those environments, they definitely reduce the ambient noise level enough to make it possible to listen to music at a comfortable volume. I find that the noise canceling on these is better than the Sony and AKG in-ear headphones I have, They are about comparable in that respect to the much more expensive Sennheiser headphones. And they don't block noise as well as something like the Bose over-the-hear noise canceling headphones. But again, they're more portable.In terms of ergonomics: The earbuds themselves are surprisingly comfortable to wear. I find a lot of earbuds either don't form a good fit or else aren't comfortable. With these, the fit was great right out of the box. There's a battery compartment that uses a AAA battery and add weights in the middle of the cable. I don't much like that, but it pretty much goes with the territory with these in-ear noise canceling headphones. You don't have the luxury of placing the battery compartment in earphones themselves, as you do with over-the-ear models. The battery compartment does have a clip on it that can be used to clip the compartment to your shirt to reduce the apparent weight.The headphones only work when a battery is inserted. No battery: No sound. These use a standard AAA battery, which is easily replaceable. I like that better than a proprietary rechargeable battery, which is the design some manufacturers use. Just carry an extra AAA and worst case you replace the battery as needed.In terms of sound: The bass is solid, although it won't please bass-heads. The high end is fine. Not too shrill, easy to listen to over extended periods, but clear. The mid-range is the weak link here. It's a bit muddy. On the whole, the sound is pleasant, but because of the mid-range falls short of great. That said, most noise-canceling headphones don't offer optimal sound, with some sacrifice made for the sake of noise canceling. These headphones are better than average in terms of sound for this segment.On the whole, I like these. Despite midrange that's a bit smeary, on the whole these are pleasant to listen to and are comfortable for extended periods of time. Though I prefer my Sennheiser in ears for overall experience, those are about 3x as expensive. Given the performance at at the price point, these are a very good, and easily recommended, set of noise canceling in-ear headphones.

This is a very nice, upper end Ricardo Beverly Hills bag. This is basically marketed as competition to the expensive traveler lines like Tumi, although the normal sell through price is considerably cheaper.Construction is good. It comes with a removable garment bag, which is a nice touch. A semi hidden garment tag  that comes out of the side and is held by a piece of flexible elastic (for your ID) is also a nice touch. There's a zipper so you can expand the width of the bag, although it only extends across three dimensions, so the expansion comes primarily at the top of the bag, and not at all at the bottom of the bag. The handle works fine. The bag is (for its size) acceptably roomy.And it's reasonably light (especially if you remove the optional garment bag).What I don't like about this bag: Although it's sold as a "22 inch" bag (hence acceptable for most US domestic flights as an onboard, although not acceptable for most international flights as an onboard [since they often limit to 21"]), it's actually closer to a 23" bag, measured the bottom of the wheels to the top. An airline that wants to be a stickler will, in fact, measure from the very lowest protrusion to the very top protusion. And in that case, this is a 23" bag. (The body of the bag is itself 22"). As a result,  you risk this bag getting picked for checking--whether you like that or not.Buy and use at  your own risk as a carry-on.

If you were a Veruca Salt fan in 1997, dropped  into a coma in 1998 and woke up this year, and someone handed you this album, you'd say "well done, it's just what I expected from their third album...sorry I missed it when it was new about a decade and a half ago".Yeah, it sounds very much like the third album that never happened. I consider that both interesting, impressive, and a bit disappointing. See, while I think both of the mach I albums with both Nina Gordon and Louise Post were pretty decent, I also thought they were a little hamstrung by the post grunge aesthete of the time. It always felt there was a better version of this group under the production.And I felt vindicated in that belief when Nina Gordon left and proceeded to record a couple of very good to great rockin' pop albums in the '00s. I was less inspired by the Veruca Salt releases post Gordon. Which is to say I own them, and they have a good layer of dust on them from sitting in place since about the time I spent money on them. Foolish me.Anyway, I was more than a little disappointed that after her second solo record, Nina Gordon seemed to go into retirement. Her website went dormant and there wasn't a shred of evidence that she'd ever record anything new. Nearly a decade later and...well, suddenly we were hearing how Gordon and Post had buried the hatchets (rumors at the time suggested there were a bunch of them) and a new Veruca Salt album was in the works. "I'll believe it when I see it,' I thought. And then I wondered if it would reflect the greater pop sensibilities of Gordon's solo material.Well, as it turns out, no, not much. As noted, this really does sound very much like what a third Veruca Salt album in the late '90s or early '00s would probably have sounded like. To me, that's something of a disappointment, for reasons already noted. I would have preferred something that sounded like what the band would probably have evolved to over the intervening 15 years--something kinder, gentler, and less still in the shadow of what Nirvana had wrought. But I think what we get here is a savvy move. I guess that if Nina wanted to release another shiny pop record, she would have just released another shiny pop record.As for the songs, it feels like the other two proper Veruca Salt albums, i.e. some great and catchy, some that sound like they'd be great in concert but aren't super catchy, and a bit of filler.Honestly, I can't imagine anyone who is still a big fan of the first two records not coming away from this one pretty happy. If, like me, you were hoping for another Nina record, I guess you'll have to continue waiting. But at least this album will get repeated plays...

Years ago, I purchased what was then a pretty state of the art home use thermocouple temperature measurement device. It was reasonably accurate, but slow, and hard to use. It also used a weird, ultimately unreplaceable battery, so it wound up in a junk heap years ago. Since then, I've used infrared thermometers at work, but I've never had another one at home.The ones I've used at work have mostly been industrial in design, which means built to withstand the rigors of mishandling. The Amprobe IR-710 isn't like that. It's plastic. But that said, it feels very well put together. The trigger doesn't have side wobble play, and the whole thing seems pretty good for a home use device. The LCD readout is kind of dim, even illuminated, and I've seen better, but it's fine...In terms of accuracy...I took it to work and got the HVAC guy who was working down the hall to do a shootout with his (nearly $1000 high end Fluke) device versus mine. The result? Both guns gave readings withing 0.5 degrees in about half a dozen different spots when we accounted for the better distance-to-spot ratio of his gun (in other words, I had to be closer). The HVAC guy, who uses his gun continually every day, snickered when I asked to compare, but he was very impressed with the accuracy when the shootout was done. Other than build quality and a much better LCD screen on his gun, it should be noted that his distance-to-spot ratio is about 6 times better and he can measure temperatures below 0 degrees, whereas this gun cannot. So there are tradeoffs.But if what you need is a light utility device for home use, you don't need pinpoint accuracy from a long distance, and you won't be measuring temperatures below zero (and most don't), this is a great little item to have...

This is a review of the VINYL version. We all know the relative merits of this compilation.As for the vinylNot bad, vinyl is quiet, but obviously the reissue vinyl is pressed from a compilation reel submaster, and not from the original mixdowns. This is particularly clear for Cups and Cakes, where they have (once again) used the inferior stereo compilation album remix version rather than the original mono single version, or even the stereo mix from the original album release.

You can be forgiven for getting confused by all the new HDMI "dongle" appliances that seem to be coming onto the market. You have android platforms on a dongle. You have the Google Chromecast device. And you have several vendors offering "Miracast" devices. What's a poor boy to do?Well, here's the quick shake out:1) Most of the full android platform devices are for geeks only. A lot of them are underpowered, are difficult to interact with, etc. To be honest, I'd stay away from those, unless you know exactly what you're doing. And if you do, then you're not reading my review, anyway.2) The Google Chromecast has probably received the most attention. It's nice, and allows you to stream a few content providers (Netflix, etc.) to your TV "out of the box". Recently, Google has loosened the reigns on the device and toolkit, and now more apps are getting supported. You can also stream whatever is in your Google Chrome browser from some platforms. The upside is that the device is cheap ($35 list). The downside is, I've found, that it doesn't always play nice with platforms like phones, and the built in wifi (how it communicates with your world) is mediocre. It also offered extremely limited functionality until recently, although, as noted, that's changing.3) The Miracast video adaptor, such as the one being sold here under the Belkin name. This is basically a wireless TV adapter. If your device is capable of wireless broadcasting of video, then it transmits its signal to the Miracast, which then pushes that to your TV screen. IMHO, and in my experience, this is more useful than the more limited Chromecast dongle. However, it's also about twice as expensive.In my hands, I find that the Belkin Miracast works very well. I was able to set up a connection between my phone my Miracast/TV in about 1 minute without reading any manual. From that point forward, ANYTHING that was on my phone screen appeared on the TV, exactly as it appeared on the phone. I used it with video streaming (Netflix, Youtube) and found that the connection held quite well, and the picture quality was excellent. The one downside was that there were occasional pixelation glitches on the screen (but not on the phone). But these were a very minor nuisance (and a considerably smaller issue than when using the Google Chromecast, for comparison). After streaming for an hour and a half from Netflix, the adaptor didn't get too hot, and was still working fine.On the basis of functionality, i.e. doing what it's supposed to do, it's great.Breaking things down on a pro/con basis:Pros:1) Super easy to set up if you have a Miracast broadcast (wireless monitor) enabled device2) Easy installation3) Held the signal well4) Good picture quality5) Dongle worked fine out of the box. No need for a firmware update. None of the nightmares (bad firmware) that people have reported with first generation Miracast devices from other manufacturers.Cons:1) Requires USB power input in additional to HDMI connection. If your TV has a HDMI port on the back, this just means connecting that port to the USB input on the dongle, using the supplied cable. If you don't have a USB connector on the back of your TV, then you'll need to buy a USB power adaptor. This adds clutter. But again, the same is true of the Google Chromecast.2) Only works with Miracast enabled devices. I have two cell phones at home. One, a top of the line Razr MAXX phone from a couple of years ago, does not support Miracast. My newer phone (Moto X) does. For the most part, only recent phones actually support Miracast. So check before buying if that's your use case. As for PCs, any PC that supports wireless and that came with Windows 8 or 8.1 supports Miracast--provided you've updated the OS to Windows 8.1. Older PCs that have been upgraded to Windows 8.1 may or may not support Miracast (check before you buy).3) Miracast is essentially a second screen technology. That means that your source device will show the same picture as the Miracast device and you may not have a way of turning off the source device screen. On my phone, for example, I couldn't find a way to do that.4) In the end, Miracast should be considered basically IDENTICAL in functionality to running a HDMI cable from your source device to the TV. There's no functional difference whatsoever. So if you have a source device and the idea of running a HDMI cable from your source device to the TV is not offensive/problematic, just do that--you'll save money and won't have to deal with the occasional data glitches inherent in wireless streaming.So, in the end, would I recommend this? Sure, IF you need it, and if your source device(s) support it. Look again at #4 above: For many people, this is a lot cooler than a HDMI cable, but it doesn't get you anything the HDMI cable won't, if you can run HDMI cable from your source, and if that won't offend the aesthetic (wife) or accessibility gods.  Although, of course, the idea of sitting with a Windows 8.1 table in your lap 15 feet from the TV and controlling what's on the TV is a little more enticing than having a 20' HDMI cable tethering your tablet to the TV--even if you CAN get the OK to do that.And it needs to emphasized that a really useful use case for the Miracast is with your phone while traveling, since most phones don't offer HDMI out.I took my Miracast on my latest business trip and found it a fun way to circumvent the $10/movie charges from the hotel. My new phone doesn't have HDMI out, so running a HDMI cable wouldn't be an option, anyway. The movies weren't great, but the smile I got from knowing that Hyatt wasn't getting a cut made it a lot better. (Don't forget the USB charge adapter, though).On the whole, I was really impressed with how easily this device was to set up and was happy with the performance. I found it quite useful for situations where running a HDMI cable was impossible (phone source). If you have a similar need, this may well be the tech toy for you!

I was looking for a fully adjustable stand to replace the one-position stand for my Microsoft Surface. This seemed to fill the bill and I ordered it.The pros:1) Fully adjustable. Very easy to put your tablet in almost any position from full 90 degree (standing up) to around 0 degrees (almost lying down).2) Sturdy enough (touching the screen, the tablet stays in place).3) The "sticky" rubber guides keep your tablet in place.4) Easy to set up.5) Will work with any standard tablet from 7" to 12" either portrait or landscape. It will actually work with larger tablets, but as things get too big, it's not going to be very stable.Now the con:1) It's almost entirely plastic, and it doesn't feel well enough constructed to last for the long run if you're using it as a travel device (where you'll continually be folding/unfolding it and possibly subjecting it to travel stresses). Should be fine if you just want to set it up somewhere and leave it.I was disappointed with the plastic design. It looks like metal in the pictures here. It's not. I guess at the price I shouldn't have expected anything more. I am a little worried how well it will hold up in the long term. But the ergonomics are great, and it's kind of amazing that there are so few comparably good general use stands at this price. Basically, Amazon has this particular market to themselves.On the whole, as long as you keep your expectations in check, this is a great little stand.

Thought I'd save a mint versus the Microsoft official Type keyboard and get this instead. Saw some good reviews, took a flyer.Big mistake. On the plus side, you do get the leather case and the bluetooth keyboard for less than half the retail price of the Microsoft Type keyboard. And the case does fit the Microsoft Surface snugly. But......but the keyboard itself is hideous. First off, it's a very small keyboard--think the really bad miniaturized keyboards that some of the worst netbooks came with. And remember how some of the key layouts on those were bad. Yeah, this has that problem, too. I could overlook the chicklet feel of the keyboard, if the keys were bigger. But they're not. And that means it's a total chore to type on this thing.But that's not all. The responsiveness of the keyboard is also rather pathetic. Thinking you'll get good use out of the mouse pad? Think again. Lag city. Sorry, but if I'm in keyboard mode, I need a mouse pad. I don't want to switch between touching the screen and typing on the keyboard that frequently.On the plus side: It was easy to set up the keyboard and the bluetooth coupled fine.On the whole, this is another one of those "get what you pay for" deals. I might be able to deal with the cheap chicklet feel if the keys were bigger. But they're not. I might be able to deal with the small keys if the touchpad worked properly. But it doesn't--it lags.Oh, and did I mention that one of the straps that keeps the Surface in the leather binder overlaps the power button and sometimes pushes it for you, "just for fun."Sorry to say...save your money.

At the price point of this printer, you have a decent number of choices in terms of monochrome laser printers. In fact, you can monochrome laser printers with more functionality for as little as half the price. If you're looking for the cheapest solution for printing, you might want to look at one of those.This particular printer is more aimed at workgroup use. That means better construction, higher reliability, cheaper consumables (toner), and a few well implemented features you won't find on the cheap printers, particularly duplexing (printing both sides of a page), which is almost never available on the cheapest printers (and almost always subject to mechanical failure when it is).Setup is as easy as any laser printer: install the toner and imaging cartridges: It takes about 10 minutes, including unboxing and reading the instructions. Connectivity is solely wired, so either you connect to your network via an Ethernet cable, or to a specific computer using a USB cable. Both Windows and MacOS are supported. The underlying processor is dual core and 800Mhz and there is 256mb of installed memory. Both specs are way more than sufficient for the purpose and better than most cheaper printers. Build quality is good (weight is 31 pounds).Print quality is very good, and offers up to 1200x1200 dpi resolution. The print quality is acceptable for both personal and business use. The printer is rated at up to 40 pages per minute, although my experience with real life monochrome documents (.pdf) was about 1/3 to 1/2 that once the document was loaded on the printer and it began printing. That's still way more than acceptable for a workgroup printer.Printer options can be set using a small  readout and buttons on the front panel, but I found this to be cumbersome. The network interface that is available once you install the printer is far easier to use and is recommended. (If you really insist on using the on-printer display/interface for setup, I recommend moving up to the MS510dn; but that printer costs a lot more and doesn't deliver better performance).In printing several hundred pages on this machine, I did not experience any problems, either with the network interface, or with paper jamming. I was able to send heavier card stock through the bypass tray without issue, and it printed properly as well.The main cons to this printer are A) the included paper tray is big enough to hold about half a ream of paper (250 sheets) and there is only one paper tray. In many business settings it's useful to have larger capacity and/or the ability to use at least two different paper supplies and B) there is no built in wireless connectivity (although you can solve that using a wireless access point, if you wish).On the whole, this printer doesn't offer a lot of bells and whistles (no copier, no scanner, no fax, no wireless, no color), but if you need a very solidly built workhorse basic laser printer at a good price, with the added bonus of built in duplexing, this is an excellent choice.

First off: The expiration date on these is two months in the future as I write this review. That's how I received them from Amazon.Second: They are stale, with a distinct off flavor from the old oils in the nutsThird: Beyond that, these are not very good toffee almonds. The toffee flavor is very mild, and not at all what I typically find with toffee almonds. Mostly almond flavor with a bare hint of toffee.I gave some of these as presents, and no one was impressed. I gave some to myself and I'm not impressed.Don't make the same mistake I did: Avoid these.

The Dell XPS-18:Is is a ginormous tablet or is it a really small All-In-One?It's both.And as such, when I got it, I wasn't sure if it was really a case of neither fish nor fowl--a product without a niche. Certainly, before I got my hands on it, I hadn't been dreaming of the day I could have a five pound 18" tablet in my lap while watching TV. And I hadn't been hoping to replace the 24" touch screen All In One I have in the kitchen with one that's way small at 18".In fact, this unit seemed so far from what I'd been dreaming of, I figured it just had to be better than I expected.And it is, in fact.Until you've played with an 18" tablet, you don't know what you're missing. Or gaining (about 2+ pounds). Interactive material (videos, web pages, etc.) is a lot more fun at the larger size.And if you want to attract attention, just pull one of these out at your coffee house or other favorite hangout. It works. I tried it. In fact, it was like the first time I had a laptop that could play videos--ahead of the curve--and I pulled that out in an airport lounge. By the time I was 10 minutes into my movie, I had a crowd. Same with this thing. At least right this minute.As for the portability factor. Well, it's 5 pounds. And battery life is kind of anemic by today's standards, at about (in my tests) a little under 4 hours. (Note: This uses the last generation Intel "Ivy Bridge" processor. The new Haswell line is now out, and when the next generation of this device comes out, I'd expect battery life to be bumped by at least 50-60%). A wireless keyboard and mouse come with the unit, but they're not integrated (like a laptop), so if you want to have a full solution to take on the road, you not only have the large-ish, heavy-ish tablet, you also have to take the separate mouse and keyboard. I file that under "not fun for road warriors". To be quite honest, for travel, I'd rather get a good 17" laptop.Anyway, back to this device. If it's not perfectly suited to travel, then what's the point? Well, the point is supposed to be that you can easily move this from room-to-room at home, used as either an All-in-One OR a tablet. That's kind of cool--provided your home is big enough to justify it. You need to work that you for yourself.On the whole, I found this to be (to my surprise) more fun and useful than I expected. No, once the "hey look at me" novelty wears off, I can't see taking this with me out of the house. But I did find the very large tablet mode continually alluring and I'm using it in lieu of my other tablets (smaller, lighter) more than I originally expected. In terms of performance, I found the I3 processor more than sufficient for anything I'd want to do (light gaming, heavy Web surfing, watching streaming video like Netflix or Youtube). It has no issues whatsoever running Microsoft Office, either, which is something my other tablets (other than a Surface RT) can't even begin to do. Ditto with Photoshop Elements, etc. CPU hogs like video encoding were predictably slower than when performed on my much more powerful desktop. But they didn't bring the system to its knees, either.The ergonomics are fine: Rubberized feel around the edges is a nice touch, and there's a built in kick stand that allows only one stand-up position, but is fine for All-In-One use. (Demerits to Dell, however, for not including the nicer charger/stand and instead charging $100 for it as an option). Connectivity options are mediocre: A couple of USB 3.0 slots and wireless internet, along with a media card reader (thankfully...) But no HDMI, no video out of ANY kind (which means this device is a dog if you need something to take around with you for professional presentations...unfortunately).Summarizing:Pros:Intel I3-3227u processor is sufficiently fast to do most anything you'd want to do on this tablet (there's an optional I7 processor; most people won't be able to tell the difference except for very cpu intense processes, such as video editing)4Gb memory is sufficient (an optional upgrade bumps this to 8Gb; few will notice the difference)Nice high resolution graphics: 1920x1080Fast to bootBluetooth 4.0Media card reader ("8 in 1")Pretty good sound quality for a tabletEh:Built in front-facing webcam is adequate, not great (720p = 1280x720)Included wireless mouse and keyboard are pretty genericUses basic Intel integrated graphics.
