Fine for most purposes. Will not thrill hardcore gamersGlossy screen suffers standard reflection issues when viewed head-onCons:Uses last generation "Ivy Bridge" processor. New "Haswell" processors get much better battery life with same performance and will assuredly be in next version of this productMediocre battery life (~4 hours)No GPSNo video out (no HDMI, no video display port, nothing)No wired eithernet port (you will have to buy a USB-to-ethernet adapter if you need wired ethernet. It has wireless, of course).Base model uses a old style 5400rpm spinning hard drive, rather than a faster, more reliable SSD (SSD available in more expensive models)

This is a hefty drive, both in terms of storage (128Gb) and in terms of physical construction (brushed aluminum). In an age where many of the recent drives are enclosed in plastic, a hefty metal housing is something of a novelty. That said, the design of the casing is strictly old school: Large, with a removable cap. Personally, I prefer designs that keep the cap attached to the housing--I have lost too many removable caps in my time...But, ultimately, for any modern large capacity flash drive, the big question is: How fast is it? Because if you have 128gb to fill, and you can't fill them fast, you may well take hours to take advantage of that capacity (or even days, if your drive stinks).I ran CrystalDiskMark 3.02 x64 (the standard drive performance test program) and attained the following results, averaged over 3 runs and a 1000Mb test size. Results are:Sequential Read (block size = 1024KB): 281.2 MB/sSequential Write (block size = 1024KB): 173.4 MB/sSequential Read (block size = 512KB): 213.0 MB/sSequential Write (block size = 512KB): 1.516 MB/sSequential Read (block size = 4KB): 5.629 MB/sSequential Write (block size = 4KB): 1.287 MB/sSequential Read (block size = 4KB, QD32): 7.367 MB/sSequential Write (block size = 4KB, QD32): 0.790 MB/sThe read and write speeds for the moderate sized (1028KB) files are very very good, and are in line with the speeds promised by Corsair on the packaging and on their website.For most users who will use this drive to store and/or read standard data (e.g. music or video files, documents, etc.) this is the speed test of greatest importance. If you're in that group, you can't go wrong with this drive.The read speed for the 512KB files is also very good.The write speed for the 512KB files, on the other hand, is very slow. This is not unusual for flash memory USB drives, but it indicates that this drive is not optimized for writing very small files.The 4K speeds are mostly of importance to those who either plan on running an operating system from this drive or else will be running certain types of programs from the drive. In these cases, a lot of small files (or fragments) will get written to the drive. The write speeds of this drive are relatively anemic and this drive is not well suited for this purpose.If you don't plan to run an OS or programs directly from this drive, then the 4K (and 512K) speeds aren't that important, and you should, as noted before, simply focus on the 1028KB speeds.Ultimately, this is a super fast drive if you're looking for raw storage--for a place to store your files for reading and writing. It's highly recommended for that purpose. Those looking for advanced functionality (OS on a stick, etc) should look elsewhere.

As has been noted and discussed at length, the first release of this release was defective, with the incorrect labels on many of the vinyl records (the music on the records was fine, but the labels were wrong).Subsequently, the manufacturer pressed up replacement records with the correct labels. In sets released since the fix, the replacement records are shoved into the box (in individual "inner" sleeves) next to the box set itself. I didn't find this particularly worrisome or problematic, and because they packaged the set this way, you wind up with a spare set of most of the records that you can give to a friend (at least, a friend who can deal with the labels being wrong).The pressings are fine and the sound quality is fine.The sets are advertised as "autographed" and, indeed, a special 12x12" cardstock insert appears in the middle of the gatefold for Transatlanticism that features the original signatures of the group.So far, so good.Here's where it goes awry: The box that holds the individual albums is manufactured in such a way that every album has a cut/dent at the edge of the album. Every set I've seen or read about has this problem. For the price being charged for this set, that's unforgivable. This should be close to perfect, and it assuredly won't be.On the whole, at well over $200 for the set of 7 albums (8 vinyl records), this is extremely pricey. Hardcore fans will want it regardless of the price. But anyone forking over that much cash for this set will assuredly expect something a little closer to perfection in the packaging.

I would have given this 3-4 stars if I'd written the review right after I got it. However, it has failed a key test: durability. Despite being babied (never over-inflated, never inflated until we were in the air and the pressure had equilibrated, being stored carefully), after about 10 trips it developed a leak. Now it will not stay inflated and has become useless.$24 down the drain and lesson learned. On to a better made item.You're been informed...

First off, this is an extension camera for an SDI system. To use this camera, you need a SDI format DVR or other SDI compatible receiver. If you don't, you can't use this camera. Such a system can run you several hundred dollars and up.Second, this camera is wired. You need to run a cable from the camera to your receiver. If you need a wireless system, move along.OK, if you haven't been put off, the question you have is: How good is this camera? To test it, I tried it in two environments: 1) pointed to a fairly well lit street and 2) pointed into a nearly pitch black back yard. For the first test (well lit) I would say that the picture this camera is capable of is excellent--more than sufficient for any purpose. The auto focus is very good and when put into motion detection mode, it seemed to be quite adept at doing its job. But all cameras these days are fairly good with good light. It is in the second test (very low light) that I found that this camera really shines. Although the picture was unexpectedly grainy (it was amplifying the very little light it could pull in), the images were still more than acceptable (for a surveillance camera; don't expect to show these at your next anniversary).On the whole, if price is no object, I'd strongly recommend this camera. On the other hand, if you want to be cost efficient, then I'd suggest you could do with a cheaper camera in locations with good light. However, for very low light situations, you will probably find this camera is the best solution--despite the added cost.

5 CDs that cover just about every artist of major note of the pop/rock era. Surprisingly well cross-licensed with very few notable artist omissions. If you want a good survey of the Australian contribution to popular music, this is it.

I'll tell you what this is: It's a flaming pile.Once upon a time, there was a pretty cool LA punk band named Fear, back when punk was still kind of scary. Fear were always too smart for the room, and beneath the dangerous facade, there was a knowing wink. But it was all good. (Trivia note: I worked with guitarist Philo Cramer for a couple of Summers at a job where he put his physics degree to good use).Anyway, Fear put out several albums over the years, but it's only the first one that most really care about. It was (and is) a classic of the era: Fear: The Record. (The Record) (It came out in 1982, on Slash Records, they good ears folks of LA who also brought us early X, Germs, Los Lobos and Blasters, among others.)Three decades have gone by since Fear: The Record came out. The band split up and the members have cast to the wind, mostly, as good ex punks are wont to do. The original release has become a very quiet catalog release that sells whatever an artifact release like this might sell, which is probably not a lot. Certainly not a lot enough to keep any of the original members swimming in dough.So Lee Ving, original lead singer has been recruited to form a new version of "Fear" and re-record the original album. Because that's just what the world is waiting for. Or not. Perhaps, and by perhaps I mean assuredly, there was a modest check in it for him proffered by some huckster with a plan: Call the new album "The Fear Album" instead of "Fear: The Album" and lure a bunch of suckers. Oh, and make the cover kind of similar, too, just in case.So that's what you have here: A paycheck masquerading as some kind of relevant release. I don't need to tell you that this doesn't sound like Fear, and that even if it did, it would sound like Fear after Fear got fat and happy and more concerned with making the mortgage than with instigating the gobsters in the front row and hanging with fast living hipsters.This is atrocious, unnecessary and unworthy.  It's everything that punks spit on back in the day.I say spit on this.

This is one of a new breed of convertible laptops created to take advantage of the Windows 8 paradigm, which allows use as both as tablet and a laptop. While this category is expected to grow, right now, there are essentially only a modest number of entrants, and only two that could be reasonably be called innovative: The Dell XPS 12 (this one), and the Lenovo Yoga 13. The Dell and Lenovo sport similar power specs (cpu, memory, hard drive, battery life), but the Dell has a much higher resolution, better, screen. In my opinion, the Dell takes that competition handily.This is actually the second generation of the XPS 12, which replaces the earlier model which was released last year (Dell XPS 12 12.5-Inch Convertible 2-in-1 Touchscreen Ultrabook). The new version is almost identical to the older version in all physical terms, with the primary difference being that it's slightly lighter (about 3 ounces lighter). Under the hood, there is one very significant difference: This new model uses Intel's latest "Haswell" line of processes. These processors are APPRECIABLY more energy efficient than the previous generation processors ("Ivy Bridge") that were used in the previous iteration of the XPS12. This means that run time on a full battery charge has increased from around 5 hours to around 8 hours. (!!!!) That single change--to run time on a full charge--addresses what many considered to be one of the major downsides of the previous generation XPS 12. (Note: The two processor lines, Haswell and Ivy Bridge, are pretty close to indistinguishable in terms of performance, with the Haswell just ever-so-slightly better [PassMark scores of 3380 and 3278 for the Haswell and Ivy Bridge, respectively, with higher being better]).Now, focusing on the XPS 12 as a total package: This is a terrific piece of hardware, with a lot of pros, and only a few significant cons.Summarizing,Pros:Beautiful super high resolution 1920x1080 12.5" screenVery high build qualityTerrific innovative screen that rotates in the frame to go from laptop/keyboard to tablet configurationVery responsive with even the base configuration of an Intel I5 processor and 4Gb memoryIncredibly fast boot time (10-15 seconds)Very good keyboardResponsive touchscreen which operates in both laptop and tablet modesFast SSD drive in all configurationsDecent webcam (1.3mp)Light, portable charging cable.Bluetooth, Wireless N (5 + 2.4Ghz)Backlit keys on keyboardBattery life is 8+ hours (New for this version!)Eh:Weight is 3.2 pounds, which isn't heavy, but isn't super light for a 12.5" laptop. A bit heavy feeling in tablet modeSpeakers are predictably mediocre for a small laptopBase configuration has only a 128Gb mSata SSD hard drive. However, the hard drive IS user replaceable.Cons:No HDMI or VGA port. Only a graphics mini displayport, which means you will need to carry a mini displayport -> HDMI or VGA adapter if you want to use this for business or with a TV/external monitor.Memory is soldiered to motherboard and is not upgradeable. Fortunately, even the base configuration 4Gb of memory is more than sufficient.Only two USB ports (both USB 3.0, however)Battery is not easily user swapped/replacableNo built in media card reader. If you want to the SD card from your camera, you'll need to carry an external reader.No GPSNo wired Ethernet port. If you want wired Ethernet, you'll need to buy a USB-to-Ethernet adapter. (You have wireless Ethernet, of course).Of the cons, the worst, in my opinion, is the fact that the battery is not easily swapped/replaced. While the 8+ hour run time is very respectable, one can expect battery life to diminish over time, and I am not looking forward to dealing with that eventuality. Also, I like to carry a spare battery to swap out for long trips. That's not possible here.Having struggled with various underpowered Android based tablets, including the Asus TF301/keyboard dock, I can say that using the XPS 12 in tablet mode is like a huge weight has been lifted. The XPS 12 screams when surfing the web, which is something I can't say about any Android (or Mac) tablet I've used--and I've used a lot of them.People have complained about the lack of apps in the Windows 8 app store--and it's true that the Windows 8 app store is pretty anemic compared to Andoid or Mac. But some of the most important apps are there (Skype, Netflix, etc.) and it's still growing. There are enough to make using the tablet mode acceptable now...and the responsiveness provided by the Intel I5 processor makes it a pleasure to use.There are a few configuration options available for the XPS 12, all related to the processor (a few speeds of I5 and I7), memory (4Gb or 8Gb) and hard drive size (128Gb or 256Gb or 512Gb). My recommendation: Any of the available processor speeds will be more than acceptable and the difference between the I5 and I7 processors for almost any user will be negligible. Similarly, most users will not need the 8Gb of memory. Windows 8 runs perfectly fine on 4Gb of memory. Unless you plan on running memory hog processes (advanced video editing, certain scientific apps, etc.) you won't need the extra memory. If you do need the extra memory, however, you need to order the laptop with 8Gb installed from the factory, as the memory is not user-upgradeable (it's soldiered to the motherboard...grrr...) A larger hard drive than the 128Gb SSD that comes installed on the base model is definitely a nice feature. But the hard drive IS user replaceable, and the incremental cost of getting the 256Gb mSata SSD from Dell is more than it would be to buy that 256Gb mSata SSD on the aftermarket and clone your 128Gb drive onto it. (You will also wind up with a spare 128Gb drive that way). Unless you are scared of the idea of hard drive cloning/migration, I'd recommend that path. Please note that this laptop uses the mSata configuration hard drive, rather than a full sized SSD to save space. mSata drives tend to be a bit more expensive than standard SSD drives.Overall, this is a terrific laptop, and buying the least expensive configuration version is, for most, the recommended route. In addition, the newer generation processor used for this updated version of the XPS 12 had addressed one of the major limitations of the earlier version, bumping the battery life to over eight hours.

You may be thinking: With a list price of $24.74 and a shipping weight of 3 pounds, the description of this product must be wrong, i.e. although it claims to be a single 2.64 ounce container of oatmeal, it really must be a 12 pack thereof. And thinking that, you might buy this, like I did.But then, like I was, you'd be wrong. Nope, this is a single 2.64 container of oatmeal. For $8.And no, there's no gold inside. Just oatmeal. Really really really expensive oatmeal.The listing is messed up, because the list price and shipping weight correspond to the 12 pack. But you will get one, single, solitary 2.64 container if you order.So save your money and move along.

It's getting mighty crowded in here. "Here" being the portable and semi-portable bluetooth enabled speaker segment of the market. Thanks to the success of the Jambox, a truly portable (although heavy) small battery-powered bluetooth speaker, every Tom, Dick and Huckster has come out with a competitor. Some of these are really great given their limitations, such as the JBL Charge Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker (Grey) (and much better than the Jambox), many others are, er, not as good. To be polite.Rather than just add more noise to the segment, venerable speaker maker Boston Acoustics has taken a different approach. They've ditched the attempt to make a truly portable (read: battery powered and easily slid into your backpack) speaker, and instead made something with a little bigger footprint and a lot bigger sound. In the process, they also tossed the built in battery: This speaker is powered from your AC outlet, although Boston Acoustics cleverly neglects to show that cord in most of the photos. So if you want to move it from room-to-room in your house: no problem. If you want to move it from your house to the beach or the outdoor patio at your local Starbucks--this is not gonna cut it.But, truly, how often do you actually carry your several pound portable speaker with you? I have a couple of them--and they're nice for what they are--but I generally find a nice place for them to sit at home or at the office, and then they sit there for eternity. I guess maybe I'm beyond the age of "dude, instant party!" and perhaps that's the focus of this product.Anyway, back to the BA MC100. This is an elegant AC powered speaker (well two speakers in the case, actually) bluetooth enabled speaker. Like all the other bluetooth enabled speakers, you can connect it to your bluetooth enabled phone/tablet/laptop and like the other bluetooth enabled speakers, you can use it to fill your room (a moderate sized room, anyway) with sound. This one gets louder than most (perhaps all) of those smaller portables, however, and does it without straining and distorting as you raise the volume. I think the JBL Charge is swell (and pretty much the segment leader in portable bluetooth speakers), but this unit pretty handily crushes it. But it's not really portable in a backpack way (unless you have a big hunkin' backpack). It's portable in a "could you please take that speaker up to your room so we don't have to listen to YOUR music anymore?" way.Beyond the basic bluetooth enabled functionality, this isn't huge on features. You can connect it via the newish "NFC" protocol, if your phone/tablet/laptop supports it. (This protocol means you just touch the two devices and they connect. The rest of us actually have to press about 2-4 keys, once, which is not really a hardship). And if you don't have bluetooth, you can connect the speaker to your device via a minijack input. And the speaker supports the very new AptX bluetooth protocol for, arguably, better sound transmission (if you phone/tablet/pc supports it). But most probably won't notice.That's it. You can't charge any devices with this speaker (unlike some of the portables) and there's no built-in microphone (so you can't use it as a hands-free speaker with your phone--not that any of the portables with this feature work very well, anyway). So if you need and want those features (or true portability) move along.But if sound quality--especially at higher volumes--is your main concern, and you are willing to accept that this is only portable within the confines of your home (or within the confines of your work cubicle), then I strongly recommend you audition this speaker (which, I should point out, retails for the same price as most of those decent portables). For me, at the price and with bluetooth connectivity, this is the one.

Bacco Bucci has, for some time, stood for reasonable quality, with a line of made-in-Italy shoes that combine good materials and design with a fit that is comfortable for American feet (uncommon for Italian shoes).These shoes, however, are another story. The caste is still comfortable. However, the leather feels thin and cheap, the soul is cheap plastic, and (perhaps not surprisingly) this one is made in China.It carries the Bacco Bucci name, but it's hardly worthy of their typical lines.The look is OK, and if you can get them cheaply, give them a try. Just don't expect too much quality.

When someone demonstrates a real market for a new electronics product, you can be sure that the rest of the industry will soon follow with a variety of me-too and me-better competitors. So it is with the now seemingly endless array of bluetooth speakers that are appearing on the market, in the wake of the first hit in this segment, the Jambox (Jawbone JAMBOX Wireless Bluetooth Speaker - Black Diamond - Retail Packaging).Basically, all of these speakers are portable, allow Bluetooth connections, and promise "good" and loud sound. Not all fulfill their promises, of course.Tylt's TUNZ Bluetooth speaker system is very clearly aimed directly at one-upping the Jambox. It even looks like a Jambox, although it's about 1.5" more narrow and 1.5" thicker in the other dimensions. The question is, is it better, or even as good?First things first: While Jambox defined the segment, there are now a few high end competitors who are considered by many (including myself) better. First among these, perhaps, is JBL's Charge (JBL Charge Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker (Grey)), which sounds better than the Jambox. And I can say without any hesitation that the Tylt TUNZ speaker does not compete on sound with the JBL. The JBL runs away with the sound quality competition. So if that's your one and only criterion, then stop reading and go get one.But for many, this is a lifestyle product, and in that case, the ergonomics and other features may hold some sway. So let's get to the pro/con analysis.Pros:1) Comes with three different changeable colored rubber gaskets (black, blue, orange) that fit around the speaker, so you can coordinate with your room, your backpack, or your mood.2) Unlike the Jambox, TUNZ allows you to connect a USB device to the back and use the internal battery to charge your device (at the rate of 1A). Note that the internal battery is 2800 mAh in size, and you can only charge an attached device until the internal battery is half empty. That means that you only have 1400 mAh, maximum, to devote to device charging. What all this means is that a fully charged TUNZ device could probably provide a decent charge to your smartphone once, and will not be able to provide more than a modest charge to your tablet or other more hungry device. Also note that TUNZ won't even start to charge a device if the battery is less than 75% charged, so if you use it for a while, it's not likely going to be able to even start providing a charge until you recharge the speaker itself.3) A list price that's 25% lower than the list price of the comparable Jambox (although actual selling price is about the same).4) Allows for NFC connection. This means that if your phone is "NFC" enabled, all you need to do is tap your phone against the body of the TUNZ speaker, and the Bluetooth connection will be automatically set up. Kind of neat, although a lot of phones are not NFC enabled, and the real amount of effort this reduces (if you have to force the Bluetooth connection with the button on the speaker) is modest. More cool that essential, in other words.5) Has an integrated microphone that allows phone calls to be handled through the speaker6) Sound at low-to-mid levels is good, with decent (for this size device) perceived bass.7) Can get sufficiently loud to fill a modest sized room8) With a fully charged battery, the manufacturer claims 20 hours of life at "half volume". To test, I charged mine and played at a moderate volume continuously until the unit gave out. I got a little over 17 hours. Which isn't bad. Note that at loud volumes, the rated playtime is only 8 hours.9) Bluetooth implementation is version 3, which is somewhat faster to create a connection than the older implementation in most Bluetooth devices. The TUNZ speaker connected very quickly in my tests.Cons:1) At loud volumes, the speaker tends to distort. To my ears, the Jambox does better at loud volumes than the TUNZ. And the JBL Charge does much better. To be fair, however, the TUNZ speaker does seem to get a little louder than that of the Jambox.2) The unit is very slow to charge. A full charge through the USB cable takes 6-7 hours.3) I found the unit pretty useless for making/receiving calls. The problem is that integrated microphone isn't very sensitive. When I tried to call people using this speaker, they would complain that I was too distant unless I was speaking loudly very near the speaker itself. This defeats the purpose of using this as a hands free speaker for calls. Although it's nice to have this feature (and the better sounding JBL Charge doesn't have it), the implementation is inferior enough that I would say that it's irrelevant. (Again, in fairness, the implementation for the Jambox, which include a microphone, is also problematic).On the whole, I found TUNZ speaker to be reasonable in quality, with some nice additional features. Sound quality at low and mid volumes is competitive with the Jambox. This speaker seems to get somewhat louder than the Jambox at higher volumes, but also seems to distort more than the Jambox at high volumes. Sound quality across the spectrum is inferior to the JBL Charge. The ergonomics (shape, weight) are comparable to the Jambox, and TUNZ has some cute colorful rubber gaskets to personalize the look, which the Jambox does not. TUNZ has a built in microphone, but I found the performance of the microphone disappointing and nearly useless--which is an issue with the Jambox as well. In terms of add-on functional niceties, TUNZ has two that stand out, relative to the Jambox: 1) Ability to charge a smartphone or other low power device (although only with the TUNZ battery is nearly full); 2) NFC connection, which allows equipped phones to start a connection by merely tapping the TUNZ speaker.Given the slightly lower price, and the various differentiating niceties, I would suggest that TUNZ is worth auditioning for those who would otherwise purchase the Jambox.That said, if you are satisfied with the ergonomics and can live without the (flawed) microphone, my recommendation would still be the JBL Charge (JBL Charge Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker (Grey)), which offers better sound quality, as well as (like the TUNZ speaker) the ability to charge your smartphone--and the internal battery in the JBL Charge is 6000mAh in size, more than double that in the TUNZ speaker.

Got two pairs of these. On both pairs, one of the buttons on the headphones was defective (did not work). A different button on each pair. On one pair, I was able to listen (though not adjust the volume), and the sound quality was mediocre at best: Thin and inaccurate.They weren't very comfortable to wear, either.The only positive things I can say is that the Bluetooth connection was easy to set up. And they look reasonably nice.But I would strongly recommend looking elsewhere.

This is a straight reissue of David Gates' four solo albums for Elektra: First, Never Let Her Go, Goodbye Girl and Falling in Love Again.Gates, the songwriter, singer and arranger of all of Bread's most famous songs, started out very strongly with his debut solo album, First. Great songs, great arrangements, excellent singing. The songs on his followup, Never Let Her Go, are somewhat weaker, but this is still a generally strong entry. The third album, Goodbye Girl, features his only actual hit as a solo artist (the title track), and mixes it with a combination of decent new material and some songs recycled from earlier releases. At this point, Gates seemed to be running out of steam somewhat, which was probably due in part to using some of his material for the Bread reunion album (Lost Without Your Love) around the same period. The recycled songs that originally appeared on Goodbye Girl are not presented again in this collection. Finally, Gates closed out his Elektra tenure with Falling in Love Again. This album is appreciably weaker than any that appeared before. Gates sounds tired and uninspired here, and in interviews years later has admitted that he had lost the muse when it came time to record this record. To my ears, there's only one really good song on this album, Where Does the Loving Go.After the Elektra period, Gates would record one more solo album, for Arista, and then go into a more than decade long retirement. (The Arista album is better than Falling in Love Again, but it's not great).I'm giving this collection four stars on the basis of how I'd rate the individual albums:First: 4.5*Never Let Her Go: 3.5*Goodbye Girl: 3*Falling in Love Again: 2*and rounding up the result to reflect the discount one-stop-shopping available here. In truth, this collection is about a 3.5* set, if Amazon allowed partial rankings.

First off: All the negative reviews that appear here aren't related to the music that's here. They are related to the fact that this was misleadingly marketed as the soundtrack to the reformed ELP's shows at the High Voltage festival. It's not. It's just a compilation of old studio material.OK, now you know.What do you get?You get1) Side one of Tarkus in its entirety. (This is the 20+ minute fan favorite progressive suite that fills the entirety of side one of the original album).2) You get the entirety of the live Pictures at an Exhibition album.3) You get about 1/2 of their debut album, including the best tracks, and including the 12+ minute extended opus from that album, Take a Pebble.4) You get one of the two group showpieces from the Works Vol 1 album, Fanfare for the Common Man5) You get the minor late-era hit Touch and GoThat's it. And taken just in terms of music, that's a pretty good list. Strangely, you get absolutely nothing from their biggest album, Brain Salad Surgery. But side one of Tarkus and all of Pictures, plus the three tracks from the debut album constitute something of a generous best-of of the first three albums. Combine this with a cheap copy of Brain Salad Surgery and you'll have a pretty good cheap starter collection--although you'll have nothing from the worthy Trilogy.

Another day, another set of headphones added to the arsenal. I have everything from very high end Shure and Sennheiser headphones to a handful of mid priced headphones from brands like Sony, Sennheiser, Bose, Monster, Beats and AKG, to a drawer full of the cheap stuff. While the super high end phones are great, they are also super expensive (too expensive for me to comfortably take them on a trip, for example). Also they're usually klunky looking for wearing outside the home. The middle ground headphones are sometimes really good, but also mostly have their limitations. And the cheap stuff is all over the map.Anyway, back to these phones. They're definitely priced and marketed as middle ground headphones, intended for use outside the house. They're kind of trendy looking--as much so as over the ears headphones can be--and they're priced to compete with stuff like Monster.The question is: How do they sound.Answer: Pretty good. VERY deep bass, clear, non fatiguing highs. Clear midrange. These are NOT the headphones for you if you want a neutral listening experience. However, if you are looking for a "fun" headphone that will do well with bass rich music (rock, rap, etc.) you'll likely enjoy these. To compare these with what I suspect is one of AKGs competitive targets: These wipe the floor with the popular Beats by Dr Dre line--better defined bass and without the hideous flabby midrange and mediocre high end.In terms of long term listening (several hours): I found these headphones pretty comfortable when I put them on--a little tight on the ears, but nothing bad. But I did start to get mechanical fatigue from the headband and earpads after a couple of hours. These are assuredly not as comfortable as something like a comfort leader like the Bose Quiet Comfort headphones for extended listening (but they are better in a low noise environment).Noise isolation seemed pretty good. I tried them out in a bus environment and was able to fully enjoy my music. There doesn't seem to be much leakage of sound to annoy the person next to you, either. This might make them OK for a plane flight--but I'd hesitate due to questions of whether they'd be comfortable for that long a duration.These come with an in-line remote and microphone, which are designed for use with an iPhone/iPad. I don't use that ecosystem, so I didn't try out these features.The package comes with the headphones, a minijack to full jack adapter, a simple pouch and a cord extender.On the whole, I like these headphones. Whether these should be one of your top considerations should depend very much on whether you tend to prefer a neutral listening experience, or whether a headphone that can (and does) emphasize the bass appeals to you. These are assuredly of the latter type. I find that fine and fun, and often my preference for non-critical listening in public, in the gym, etc. But if you want that neutral experience (usually my preference at home, and assuredly what most classical/jazz/etc listeners will want) then I'd suggest looking at a different model.I can state with 100% assurety that if you are considering something like the Beats line, these headphones are both cheaper and hands down MUCH better.

The Belkin @TV Premium mobile TV platform is one of a growing number of devices that allow you to broadcast your home video to your mobile devices or to computers (mobile or on your home network). It follows the segment leading Slingbox, as well as a number of other brands, including Monsoon (of which this is a rebranded variant), Sony, and others.The question is, then, what does this device bring to the table that the well-established (and fairly slick) Slingbox platform does not? I can answer that very quickly:1) It's somewhat cheaper than the comparable Slingbox hardware (at retail, about $50 cheaper)2) It offers built in wireless, whereas the comparable Slingbox does not. (You must move up to a much more expensive model Slingbox to get wireless built in).3) The app to view Belkin @TV broadcast on your tablet is free (Slingbox charges $15 for it). HOWEVER, you still need to pay to get the app for your phone (same as Slingbox, although at the time of writing, the Belkin app is a couple of dollars cheaper). It's worth noting that you can buy the Slingbox phone app and use that on both your phone and your tablet, so if you plan to buy the phone app, this is really a push for the two platforms.4) Using the mobile software, you can record video on your mobile device (tablet/phone). Note that this is real time recording (your @TV broadcasts the video and you capture it into a file on your mobile device as it is received). So this isn't going to be of much help if you're about to get on a plane and forget that you wanted something to watch while you're not connected to the internet.5) This device allows multiple users on a local network to watch the video from a @TV Premium source. This means if you are AT HOME and you have multiple users that want to watch the same video at the same time on different platforms AT HOME, you can do so. Slingbox doesn't support this, and I can see where this might be useful. HOWEVER, if you are outside your local network (on your phone or tablet or PC away from home), only one user can watch the @TV unit at once (and that one total user includes home users)--same as Slingbox.Here's where this device is inferior to the Slingbox:1) To watch on any PC device, you need to install substantial software. Unlike the Slingbox, there is no browser embedded application. Right now, the only platforms that are supported are Android, iOS (Apple iPhone/table), Windows, and MacOS. Glaringly absent from that list are platforms like the Chromebook--since there's no browser embedded app. Also, you will need to download and install a > 200 mb file to run the player on a Mac or PC. Some will find this annoying.Here's an annoyance this device shares with the comparable Slingbox model:No HDMI connectivity. You have to use analog/composite connectors. Cable clutter is so 2005, don't you think?As for setup and performance: I found the Belkin @TV Premium pretty straightforward. Connect the proper cables, set up the IR blaster (to control your device), download the software for your PC (or Mac or Android or iOS), set up an account, go through the setup and tell the device what it's connected to and what video source it will be controlling, and watch. One caveat: You HAVE to connect the Belkin unit via wired ethernet for initial setup, even if you will subsequently use wireless. Once you set things up, you can remove the cable. But be aware you'll have to do this.Video quality seemed good once I had it all set up. On my home network, video was clear with no stutters, and seemed comparable to Slingbox. When I went to a local coffee shop to test the remote broadcasting capability, I got a pretty good signal, with a few stutters. It appears a few seconds of buffering on intermediate servers is implemented on this device, just as with Slingbox, so even if your signal gets dodgy for a few seconds, you can watch a fairly constant video flow.I had a Slingbox attached to the same video source, so I was able to A/B the video quality with the same signal at the remote location, for this device versus a Slingbox. My qualitative analysis is that most of the time the two signals were pretty much the same, although when the internet signal got slow, it appeared to me that the Slingbox did a little better job of maintaining a watchable (though degraded) picture.On the whole, this seems like a decent alternative to Slingbox, and at a lower price. Normally, I'd be a little worried that this device represents only a narrow piece of the corporate Belkin pie, and so support could be dropped at any time if it's not a raging success. However, Belkin is just front ending a device and software being supported by a company whose primary focus is this type of device (Monsoon), so I'm not too worried about that.The one important drawback to this @TV device is that it does not support a browser embedded app. This means you have a large program you will need to download and install on your PC or Mac. More significantly, it means that for now you can't use this device with platforms like Chromebook (where there is a Slingbox app). Depending on the hardware you use, this could be significant.

Musically, this is a straight reissue of the Crosby Stills and Nash box set that was originally issued in 1991 and which went out of print two years ago, in August of 2011. The difference between that issue and this one is that the current reissue comes in a small CD brick and does not include the nice LP sized booklet that came with the original issue. The mastering has not been changed, so if only the music matters to you, this set is as good as the previous one.Breaking things down into bullet points:Good:Half the cost of the original issue. The original box was sold at discount at between 60 and 64 dollars. This current box sells at discount for roughly half that.Space saver. This box takes the space of roughly 3 regular sized CDs in jewel cases. The original box took the space of a small stack of vinyl LPs.Push:Same songs, same mastering. Nothing changes.Bad:This set doesn't include the LP sized deluxe booklet that accompanied the music.If you're a collector or a big fan who like tactile materials, you will want the older issue. If all you care about is the music, then this reissue will suit you just fine.

The story of Flash Harry is pretty well known: Harry Nilsson, he of anglelic 3+ octive voice and commensurate songwriting abiltities is signed to RCA, where he releases a string of criticially adored albums and one commercial blockbuster, then blows his voice out in a lost weekend recording session with John Lennon, loses his songwriting muse in a blur of alcohol and other sidelines, and ultimately loses his RCA contract, never to release another album in the US in his lifetime.He did, however, release one more album. That being this, Flash Harry. Issued in limited quantities to a non-plussed select few countries in 1980. Quantities pressed and sold were minimal and it has become something of a holy grail rarity over the years for Nilsson fans--although more because it has seldom been heard than because it's great.And make no mistake: This is NOT a great Nilsson album. It's not even a good album. It's mostly a mish-mosh of covers and moldy stuff that had been written years before, delivered in a voice that isn't even as good as the somewhat recovered voice Nilsson revealed on his last RCA album (Knnillssonn). Nilsson doesn't sound engaged here and, to be bluntly honest, it's entirely clear why Mercury (his record label for this release) chose to not even bothering to release it in his home country. Rather, the surprise is that it got a release in ANY country.That's sad, but it's the hard truth.At any rate, in the wake of "The Year (or so) of Nilsson" (a box set covering his tenure at RCA; a well-received documentary; a biography) we get this piece of the puzzle that serves as an endcap on the RCA box. Those who fall in love again with Nilsson on the basis of the box and those who never gave up the faith will undoubtedly be happy to finally be able to get a copy of this album at a reasonable price. And completists--being completists--will rest more easily for that fact. But the rest of us--the fans-but-not-fanboys and the casual observers--should move along, as there's really not a lot to hear here...

Neither the listing nor the boatload of reviews seems to give any real pertinent information about this charger. So I will.First off, the specs: This is a 1A, 5V USB charger. The 5V part is standard. The 1A (1000 mA) value is the key one. You want a charger that can provide AT LEAST the amperage requirements of the device you're attaching to it. This value does NOT have to match the rating of the device you're attaching, but if your device is designed to use more than 1000 mA then this charger won't keep it charged while in use (it WILL slowly charge it when not in use). What this means, in practical terms, is that this charger is suitable for just about every smartphone made (all of which use about 1000 mA or less), but will NOT keep something like a power hungry tablet charged while in use.Second, this charger, while it carries the Kodak brand name, is just a standard charger from China, and also appears in other contexts without the Kodak name. This charger is not "designed by Kodak" or "proprietary to Kodak". That said, it appears to be of reasonable quality.Ultimately, if you need a USB charger with the above specs, then this is a reasonable possibility. Would I recommend it? If the price is good. I WOULD recommend this over any of the no name chargers you see being sold by the online cell phone accessory companies for $1-2. Those are typically underpowered AND poorly regulated (meaning they can burn out your device if the charger doesn't burn out first).One last note: These things are also manufactured in huge quantity as counterfeits. If you decide to buy this, I strongly encourage you to buy only directly from Amazon. You have been warned...

This album is atrocious:1) It's a bootleg. The material covered by this album is owned by the Gene Clark estate and this is an unauthorized release.2) The sound quality on the first disc, which is copy of the legitimate/licensed Gene Clark Live Silverado '75-Live & Unreleased is unbelievably bad. Sound is ridiculously bad. Song order is wrong. They even speeded up the recordings when mastering. This is a grand master class in the creation of bootleg rubbish.3) The sound quality on the second disc is mediocre at best, and this material has NOTHING to do with the material on the first disc. It wasn't recorded at the same time (it was recorded years later). It sounds like an average bootleg, and really brings little to the table that isn't already available on legitimate issues.Stay as far away from this piece of junk as you can.

I love hot and spicy, and I love hot sauce. I'm the guy in the crowd who orders his food too hot for anyone else to share...not to be antisocial, but because I like hot.I have a love/hate relationship with this Huy Fong Sriacha sauce.On the plus side: 1) Decent heat; 2) Not vinegary; 3) Pleasant flavor, not just hot; 4) Super cheapOn the down side: 1) Not super heat; 2) Second ingredient is sugar.#2 on the down side is why I have the love/hate relationship. I wish this had less sugar in it. It's not super sweet--don't get me wrong. But it's sweeter than I would generally like, and for that reason, while it works great in some dishes, in others it adds some sweetness that's unwelcome.The high sugar content is why I consider this to be, basically, Asian ketchup. Ketchup is tomatoes, sugar and vinegar. This is hot peppers, sugar, and vinegar (with a bit of garlic). You wouldn't put ketchup on everything, even if you love ketchup on some things, and it's the same with this stuff. And I think the places they don't belong are pretty similar: Foods where the added sweet is not a plus.Anyway, I keep a bottle of this around for all the foods it DOES work well with. But I also keep my Mexican and American hot sauces around for the numerous foods where this is NOT the right choice.

If you're looking at this Eagles box set, presumably you already know most of what you need to know about the band, and about their albums. They started as a country-influenced band, had a few hit singles and modestly successful albums. Over the course of their first four albums, they moved increasingly towards the pop/rock middle. With their fifth album, they took on rock guitarist Joe Walsh, lost the last vestiges of country (and some of their original members) and had their biggest, most shining, moment with Hotel California, which rightfully defined a musical time and place. Hubris, infighting, drugs, and many other withering influences wrecked havoc with the now huge band in the wake of Hotel California, and the long delayed swan-song studio album of their original run, The Long Run, was disappointingly inferior given expectations and the time it took to come to fruition.Later came the Hell Freezes Over reunion, the endless tours, and one more (decent) studio album (so far). But that part of the story isn't covered by this box.So what do you get here? You get all the original studio albums of their 1970s Asylum tenure. You don't get the live album from that era (rather dull anyway), and you don't get the one-off Christmas single (Please Come Home for Christmas), or a stray b-side. But other than that, this is their entire released studio output of that era. There are no bonus tracks on any of these albums. The albums also have not been remastered for this release, but instead are identical to the previous remasters from more than a decade ago. They sound fine, though...The mini sleeves are adequate, as is the enclosing box. There are no liner notes.Ultimately, this is a good deal for someone who wants all the music, with decent sound quality, for a low price.

The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up: the Japanese art of decluttering and organizing by Marie Kondo has become my new bible.  I never even heard of this book until I saw it on a recent best-seller list.  I read the reviews and was intrigued.  Many readers claimed that it changed their life.  Although I havent yet begun decluttering, I have taken to heart many of Kondos lessons about accumulating too much stuff and I am forming an action plan.My husband and I have been married almost 32 years, and we have lived in our present (very large) house for 30 years.  We have been talking about downsizing and moving, but the thought of divesting ourselves of all our possessions is a daunting task.  Like many, we have clothes that havent been worn in 20 years, greeting cards going back decades, bills and cancelled checks from our entire married life, pictures, books, knickknacks, mementoes and the list goes on.  Kondo provides many lessons about how to get control of your life by getting control of your stuff.  First, you need to discard and then you can organize what remains.  She also recommends sorting by category, and not by location.  So if youre going tackle your clothes, do all your clothes in every closet and bureau in every room.  Then you can move on to the next category.  I love greeting cards and save them for sentimental reasons.  But Kondo claims that each card has fulfilled its purpose the moment the receiver finishes reading it.  Kondo also advises saving things because you love them and because they bring you joy.  This is especially important when assessing sentimental items.  No matter how wonderful things used to be, we cannot live in the past.  The joy and excitement we feel here and now are more important.Kondo includes so many little tips throughout her book.  Dont save extra buttons.  We never use them.  If you have owned a book for some time and havent read it, you wont.  Dont scatter storage places.  Clutter is caused by a failure to return things to where they belong. Therefore, storage should reduce the effort needed to put things away, not the effort needed to get them out.  Dont stack items when you store them.  The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up is filled with such gems.  Will I follow all of them?  Probably not.  Im a bibliophile and the thought of parting with books is just more than I can tolerate right now.  But I am looking forward to using Kondos techniques to get the rest of our house in order.  People who have done so claim it is life transforming.  I certainly hope so.

Sarah Vowell has a way of bringing history to life with knowledge and humor, and I was thrilled to obtain her latest effort, Lafayette in the Somewhat United States, through Amazon Vine.  Not too long ago, I wondered why there are so many cities and towns named Fayetteville throughout the United States.  When reading the history of Fayetteville, NC, I realized that all these places are named after Revolutionary War hero, the Marquis de Lafayette.  Unfortunately, the contributions by this French citizen to our own country have been largely forgotten.  So leave it to Vowell to bring Lafayette back to life in this interesting and entertaining book.Lafayette was born Marie-Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier de Lafayette.  Mostly, he is known as the Marquis de Lafayette or just Lafayette.  The thing that drew me to Lafayette as a subjectthat he was the rare object of agreement in the ironically named United Stateskept me coming back to why that made him unique.  His father died when he was only two in the Seven Years War and he was born hating the British.  When he was 19, he sailed to the United States without the knowledge of his family to offer his services to the Continental Army.  His reasons were varied including a lust for glory, the appeal of escaping his nagging in-laws, boredom with the court shenanigans of Versailles, and a head full of Enlightenment chitchat about liberty and equality.  It didnt hurt that he was independently wealthy and agreed to serve without pay.  At first he was given the rank of major general, but without any duties. But it didnt take long for George Washington and Lafayette to form a father-son bond and General Washington soon started trusting the young Frenchman with more leadership rolls.  Vowell takes  us through the Revolutionary War and highlights Lafayettes contributions in the war effort.  She also covers his grand tour of American in 1824-1825, where tens of thousands of Americans came out to see him as he toured all the states then in the US, as well as visiting those friends from Revolutionary War times who were still alive including John Adams, John Quincy Adams, and Thomas Jefferson.  At the time, Lafayette was the last surviving general from the Revolutionary War.But what makes Lafayette in the Somewhat United States so good is Vowells humor, her impertinence and her ability to compare past to present.  She travels to Brandywine, PA to see the sight of the Battle of Brandywine.  She times her visit so that she is there for a Battle of Brandywine reenactment and A Son of Liberty puppet show about Lafayette.  I neednt have worried about how the event planners could possibly turn a bummer like Brandywine into a celebration.  If Americans can transform Memorial Day, technically a remembrance of all our war dead ever, into the official kickoff of summer, we can handle adapting one demoralizing battle into a wholesome, chipper get-together.  In 1934, FDR gave a speech before congress honoring Lafayette on the 100th anniversary of his death.  FDRs speech acknowledged that every now and then, a bunch of backbiting blowhards like the United States Congress can temporarily come together with their president to mourn the death of one of the few people, places, or things they and their fidgety constituents have ever agreed on.Vowell says it best when she writes that Lafayette represented neither North nor South, East or West, left or right, Yankees or Red Sox.  Lafayette has always belonged to all of us.  In her book, Lafayette in the Somewhat United States, she puts him back on our national stage and gives him the prominence he deserves.

Louise Pennys The Long Way Home is the 10th novel in her Inspector Armand Gamache-series.  However, Gamache is now retired from his job of Chief Inspector of Homicide for the Surete du Quebec and is living in the small village of Three Pines with his wife, Reine-Marie.  The Long Way Home was a bit of a disappointment and it is not what I have come to expect from Penny.  I think her Gamache-series works better as a police procedural.  Without that discipline and focus, this novel tends to wander.  Also, please dont try to read any of these novels out of order.In novel number seven, A Trick of the Light, Clara and Peter Morrow, two recurring characters who live in Three Pines, have separated.  The deal is that after living apart without any contact for one year, Peter will return to their home on the exact anniversary day of his departure and they will decide how to proceed with their marriage.  Both artists, the breach was caused by Claras sudden artistic success after years of struggling, along with Peters jealousy.  But that anniversary comes and goes and Peter is missing.  Clara asks Gamache for help, and the former chief inspector enlists the aid of his former assistant and now son-in-law, Jean-Guy Beauvoir.  Along with retired psychologist and Three Pines bookseller, Myrna Anders, the four take off to track Peters journey.  Credit card records show he traveled to Europe and back, but the trail goes cold once he arrived back home in Canada.  And so Gamache and crew figure out that he must be painting with a former professor in a very remote area of Canada.  It appears that this once very conservative artist is trying to expand his horizons, although all think that Peter is in danger.There was just too much that didnt quite work in The Long Way Home.  The plot was totally implausible.  Do we really think that someone would try to murder another by exposing them to asbestos?  The constant art talk got tedious and it was tiring each time the crew tried to analyze and interpret Peters five new paintings.  Their constant travel was also monotonous (plane, boat, car).  The areas in which they ended up including Charlevois and Baie-Saint-Paul sound stunning, but without photos, the written descriptions were lacking.  And the ending was a total disappointment.  Still, Pennys writing is poignant except that instead of writing about crime, most of her observations were about art and the damaged souls of the characters.  Although Peters new paintings are very disturbing and not pleasing to the eye, they were markers, signposts. Pointing out where hed been and where he was going.  The route he was traveling, artistically, emotionally, creatively.After going through all of Pennys previous novels in quick order, I now am down to her latest book, The Nature of the Beast.  I do hope that Penny finds a better way to utilize Gamaches talents in book number eleven.

Deep South by Paul Theroux is the second Vine book Ive ordered recently because the promo said it would appeal to readers who enjoy both Tony Horwitz and Bill Bryson. Those are two of my favorites, so I just had to order Deep South: Four Seasons on Back Roads.  Deep South is a wonderfully written travelogue that is fascinating, depressing, informative and yet hopeful.  Deep South has photographs by Steve McCurry, but unfortunately, the uncorrected proof didnt have any except for the haunting cover shot.Paul Theroux is a very prolific writer but most of his books are written from foreign locales.  During the United States presidential campaign of 2012, he travels through the South and realizes how little of the United States he has actually seen.  So he returns to the South during all four seasons.  After his first trip, I knew that the South had me, sometimes in a comforting embrace, occasionally in its frenzied and unrelenting grip.  He tries to stay away from major cities and instead, visits the Lowcountry, the Black Belt, the Delta, and the backwoods  What Theroux experiences during his four seasons is a mixed bag.  On the negative side, he saw extreme poverty, hunger, bank and food deserts, struggling farmers, closed industries, few jobs, a lack of health care, discrimination and the long shadow of the Ku Klux Klan.  Much of what Theroux saw reminded him of the Third World countries in which he traveled, only they received hundreds of millions of dollars from the United States to aid projects to improve or promote education, create energy resources, offer medical care, even help the tourism industry ($700 million to Tanzania and $350 million to Zambia, for example).  Most of these areas in the US receive little or no federal dollars.  On the positive side, Theroux witnessed beautiful country, friendly and earnest people, hard-working farmers, a number of characters and many true heroes (Cynthia Burton, Bernie Mazyck, and Pam Dorrto name just a few).  He also discovered that The Deep South today is not in its books, its in its people and the people are hospitable, they are talkers, and if they take to you, theyll tell you their stories.I also enjoyed Deep South as this book is also about Southern writers and Southern books.  Theroux quotes liberally from writers who have made similar journeys.  He also critiques a number of Southern writers including William Faulkner, James Agee, Harper Lee, and Charles Portis.  If I have one negative about Deep South, its that I think the author spent a little too much time blasting Bill Clinton.  He continually criticized the Clinton Foundation for helping countries overseas without spending anything in the United States.  That is a valid point, but he doesnt have to mention it over and over again.  He also condemned Clinton as being a bird-dogger of chicks, a Southern hackster, emotionally immature and hungry for the worlds affection.  Again, this book was about the Deep South and not Bill Clinton.Throughout Deep South, I was enthralled by Therouxs writing and observations and even though Ive read a Vine uncorrected proof, I plan to purchase the published book so that Ill have the photographs to enjoy, as well.  I also plan to start reading some of Therouxs others works, as Deep South was my first exposure to him as a writer.

After finishing Louise Pennys The Beautiful Mystery, I had to immediately begin How the Light Gets In to see how this continuing plot-line played out.  How the Light Gets In is book number 10 in Pennys Inspector Armand Gamache series, and is extremely dark, complex, and intricately woven together.  Yet, it ends on a note of hopefulness.As in most Gamache novels, the chief of homicide for the Surete du Quebec has two storylines.  The first is the murder or murders that Gamache and his team must solve.  The second is a plot that carries over between novels and mostly goes back to the Arnot case and also, the evil Superintendent of the Surete Sylvain Francoeur.  The Christmas season is approaching and retired psychologist, Myrna Landers, is hosting a former patient and now friend, Constance Pineault.  Pineault has never really revealed all the secrets of her childhood to Anders, but she appears on the verge of doing so when she is found murdered in her home.  Very few except Landers know that Constance is the last of the Oulette quintuplets (think Dionne quintuplets born in 1934).  They were removed from their parents, lived in a house built by the government, and put on display to become a major tourist attraction.  Although the victim doesnt live in Gamaches territory, their homicide chief is happy to dump the case in Gamaches lap because of the approaching holidays.  Meanwhile, Superintendent Francoeur is doing everything in his power to destroy the much beloved and successful homicide chief.  Almost every agent except for Isabelle Lacoste has been removed from his team, and instead, hes been given the dregs of the Surete.  Gamache seems not to be bothered by this and plays along with Francoeur.  But what really disturbing to Gamache is the falling out that he had with his second in command, Jean-Guy Beauvoir.I found How the Light Gets In to be a haunting book.  Armand Gamache had always held unfashionable beliefs.  He believed that light would banish the shadows.  That kindness was more powerful than cruelty, and that goodness existed, even in the most desperate places.  He believed that evil had its limits.  But looking at the young men and women staring at him now, whod seen something terrible about to happen and had done nothing, Chief Inspector Gamache wondered if he could have been wrong all this time.  Maybe the darkness sometimes won.  Maybe evil had no limits.  But there is also a lot of good in this bookespecially the residents and recurring characters from Three Pines.  I sometimes grow tired of having so many Penny books take place in Three Pines, but How the Light Gets In isnt one of them.Although How the Light Gets In is dark and disturbing, it ends on a hopeful note.  Also, based on the ending, it is possible that Louise Penny might take Gamache in a new direction in future novels.  I cant wait to see when I begin The Long Way Home.

Upon starting Sweet Forgiveness by Lori Nelson Spielman, I thought this was going to be a very enjoyable novel.  True, it was a little sappy and very predictable, but it was fun.  And then I reached the end and thought that the author really dropped the ball.Hannah Farr has her own morning television show in New Orleans.  To outward appearances, it might seem that Farr has it all together.  But her ratings are slumping, she has creative differences with her boss, and a new, beautiful and young co-worker is trying to muscle in on her territory.  She is also in a relationship with the mayor of New Orleans, which is going nowhere.  And she hasnt seen or spoken to her mom since her graduation from high school.  A former classmate, Fiona Knowles, has scored a big social trend with forgiveness stones.  You send two small stones or pebbles to a person you have wronged.  If they forgive you, theyre supposed to return one of the stones to you.  Fiona Knowles bullied Farr in grade school, and so Farr is one of the first to receive stones from Knowles (the Original 35).  But Farr isnt sure shes ready to forgive and the stones have been sitting in her desk for two years.  Its not until shes forced to deal with this as a television topic that all of Farrs secrets are exposed.Where Spielman lost me is in her subplot over the inappropriate touching of Farr when she was 13 years old by her step-father.  I think that the author botches who was the victim here.  When Farr finally has a chance to learn the truth, she backs away.  A fishing tackle box might hold the clues to what happened years ago.  Instead, I slam the lid shut.  No one needs to know the truth.  Not RJ.  Not my mother.  Not my old fans or former employers.  Not even me.  I will learn to live with ambiguity.  Really???  This book teaches the wrong lessons about sexual abuse.  I just wish that Spielman had dealt with this issue more appropriately.

Having been on a Louise Penny Inspector Gamache-kick lately, I decided to read her novella, The Hangman.  The Hangman was written for Good Reads as an easy-reader for beginning adult readers or English as a second language readers.  While The Hangman was very good, it was much too short and a bit of a tease.Outside Three Pines, Chief Inspector Armand Gamache and his assistant, Jean-Guy Beauvoir, are called to the scene of what appears to be a suicide.  A man was found hanging from a tree near the local Inn and Spa.  From the very beginning, red flags are raised over the lies and inconsistencies that the two inspectors discover.  Soon, those at the Inn and Spa are assembled (ala Agatha Christie) so that Gamache can reveal the killer(s).  Gamache tells the assembled group Like most murders, this one was about secrets and lies.  But hidden below all those lies was an emotion.  Sorrow.  A sorrow so great it turned into a monster.  And that monster finally consumed the man.  But what was the secret that led to murder?  Leave it to Gamache and Beauvoir to solve what appears to be an impossible crime.It is very commendable that Louise Penny would lend her talents to such an effort and even though The Hangman was short, I enjoyed the story.

I guess I would have to say that 2015 for me is the year of Louise Penny.  I just cant get enough of her Inspector Gamache mystery series.  I keep telling myself that Im going to slow down, but I just cant help myself.  The Beautiful Mystery is number nine in her series and is a beautifully written story with an intricate plot.  I was also happy that in The Beautiful Mystery, Penny gets away from her usual locale of Three Pines.Inspector Armand Gamache is head of homicide for the Surete du Quebec.  He and his second in command, Jean-Guy Beauvoir, are called to Saint-Gilbert-Entres-les-Loupes (Saint Gilbert among the wolves).  This monastery of Gilbertine monks was hidden to the outside world until a recording of their Gregorian Chants was produced and sent out into the world.  But the 24 monks live in almost total silence except for their singing in a compound that is closed to outsiders.  That is, until their choir director is found murdered.  Now it is the job of Gamache and Beauvoir to investigate the killing and discover which of the remaining 23 monks is the killer.  There is much of beauty in the monastery and the two agents are drawn into a world of simplicity, worship, hard work, good but simple food, and beautiful music.  But the two also start to see something very ugly, and that is a breach between the prior and the murdered choir director that has divided the monks.  And somehow, that breach has led to the murder.  The monastery doctor tells Gamache that often times there are little deaths before a murder.  People die in bits and pieces.  A series of petites morts. Little deaths.  They lose their sight, their hearing, their independence.  Those are the physical ones.  But therere others.  Less obvious, but more fatal.  They lose heart. They lose hope. They lose faith.  They lose interest. And finally, they lose themselves.  And if there isnt enough evil in the monastery with a murder, the malicious, corrupt and manipulative Superintendent Sylvain Francoceur of the Surete shows up at the monastery with a hidden agenda.  This book will end of a very dark note.I thoroughly enjoyed The Beautiful Mystery and after finishing this novel, I immediately had to begin the next, How the Light Gets In. As a church musician, I am fascinated with the history of church music, and Louise Penny gives the reader a pretty good tutorial on Gregorian Chant.  While this might seem a bit much for a novice, I was thrilled to read a novel where music played such an important part.  I plan on giving copies to my choir friends this Christmas.

Leave it to Liane Moriarty to start a novel with a major birthday brawl in a local restaurant that will keep people talking for years.  The novel is Three Wishes and its Moriartys first effort and as with all her later books, it combines humor and sadness in a creative way.Cat, Lyn and Gemma Kettle are triplets celebrating their 34th birthday when their night of fun turns into a nightmare.  The triplets are beautiful and attract attention where ever they go.  But they also each have their own demons.  Each sister is totally different and they are dealing with a host of issues including a cheating spouse, infertility, a miscarriage, panic attacks, abuse, failure to commit and the death of a fianc. They also suffer scars from their divorced parents, who seem to be showing an interest in each other once again.  For as much as the sisters love each other, they also have major altercations.  It was like every fight theyd ever had over the past thirty years was all part of the one endless argument.  At any moment, without notice, it could be started again, hurtling them straight into the middle of irrational, out-of-control, name-calling fury.  They never said sorry.  They just threw down their still-loaded weapons, ready for next time.  The story alternates between the triplets, so we get a personal glimpse of each sister.  And this is where Moriarty really shines.  Her writing combines so many different emotions and her observations can be so very moving.  Gemma lost her fiance in an accident years ago.  It felt as if Gemma had moved up to a higher, more complex level of human emotions that Lyn couldnt even hope to understand.  She didnt know the rules.  She didnt know the right thing to say to make it better.  It was like Gemma possessed a secret, terrible knowledge that Lyn could only clumsily guess at.  I am sure that many readers will identify with this on some level.The only negative about Three Wishes is that after finishing this book, Ive read all the adult novels that Moriarty has written.  I certainly hope shell be publishing another one very soon.

Love May Fail by Matthew Quick is one of those novels that appealed to me on so many different levels.  It appealed to me as a retired educator.  It was fun to read in that it took place close to my home and I knew all the landmarks.  I enjoyed that the story was clever and moving and very engaging.  And I have enjoyed every novel that Ive read by Matthew Quick.  I believe that Love May Fail is one of the best novels that Ive read this summer.Love May Fail is told through four characters.  The two main characters are Portia Kane and Nate Vernon.  The novel opens when Kanes marriage is imploding.  Her husband is a handsome but sleazy millionaire who produces pornographic movies.  She flees Florida to return to her childhood home in Westmont, NJ.  Once home, Kane learns that her very favorite teacher, Nate Vernon (think Robin Williams in Dead Poets Society) has had a very unfortunate bit of bad luck and is no longer teaching.  She hasnt even seen or talked to Vernon since she graduated high school, over 20 years ago.  But not even knowing where he is now living, she decides that it is her job to save him.  The other two characters are Vernons mother-turned nun, Sister Maeve Smith and Chuck Bass, the older brother of one of Kanes classmates.  But what happens when a person doesnt want to be saved?  And maybe in trying to save someone else, you also have a chance to safe yourself.  Quick examines these themes in great detail in Love May Fail.Serendipity plays a big part in many of Quicks novels, and Love May Fail is no exception.  Maybe its God, or coincidence, or fate, or luck, but more than a few times, these four characters are brought together by serendipity.  As always, Quicks writing is insightful, eloquent and extremely moving.  Portias mother has mental issues. You can get lost in Moms madness.  Its like a maze of tall bushes, all thorns and no roses.  And she insists I navigate while blindfolded.  Later on, Vernon tries to convince Kane that she never really knew him.  You do not know me.  Trust me on this.  Students never really know their teachers.  Its all a bit of a show, and you are familiar with the show I used to put on twenty-some years ago, for a paycheck, health insurance, and a meager pension.  I no longer play that roleThrew out the required mask many years ago.I have had the pleasure to hear Matthew Quick at the Free Library of Philadelphia on the release of his last two novels, and Quick is as talented a speaker and a storyteller as he is a writer.  I would have loved to have Quick as an English teacher back in high school and I suspect that there is a lot of Quick in both Nate Vernon and Chuck Bass.

After watching several television movies based on Robert B. Parker's Jesse Stone series, I decided to read some of Parker's novels.  When I picked up Killing the Blues, I didn't realize that this novel was actually written after Parker's death by Michael Brandman.  Brandman assisted in co-writing and producing some of the movies, and was hand-picked to continue the series by Parker's estate.  Although I thought that Brandman's dialogue sounded very similar, I felt that his Jesse Stone was more violent and operated more outside the law.The summer season is about to begin in the resort town of Paradise, Massachusetts and a crime wave begins.  Someone is stealing Honda Civics, although a heist gone bad ends in murder.  At the local school, 14 year old Lisa Barry takes the principal hostage with a gun because of a bunch of nasty girls who won't stop bullying her.  And just when things can't get any worse, Rollo Nurse, a psychopath who Stone put away while working in California is now out of jail and coming east to seek revenge.  Stone's love life always is a sub-plot and in Killing the Blues, his love interest is Alexis Richard.  Richard was hired as a public relations specialist and event planner for Paradise.  But things are made a little more complicated because her uncle is selectman Carter Hansen (not a fan of Jesse Stone).  As the story developed, I thought that no police chief could do what Stone did and get away with his actions.  Then again, I guess that's why they call this genre fiction.This fast-paced book was a quick, entertaining and suspenseful read.  Some die-hard fans might be disappointed in Brandman's efforts, but I think that maybe Jesse Stone still has a future, after all.

Split Image is the third Jesse Stone book that I've read in a row, and this book by Robert B. Parker is pretty lame.  I understand that this is the last Jesse Stone book that Robert Parker wrote before he died, and maybe he just wasn't playing with his A-game anymore.  But for whatever reason, Split Image was a big disappointment.Jesse Stone is the chief of police in the fictional town of Paradise, Massachusetts.  As in most Stone books, there are numerous plots and subplots.  The major plot focuses on the murders of two men. One of them was a local gangster who lived right next door to another career criminal.  They were both married to beautiful, identical twins.  This part of the novel was totally bizarre and unbelievable.  It was also hard to keep all the characters straight.  A subplot involved a local religious cult, Bond of the Renewal, that may or may not be keeping people against their will.  And then there is also the issue of Stone's love life.  At least his obnoxious ex-wife, Jenn, seems to be totally out of the picture.  But now he's going back and forth with Sunny Randall.I guess with an author as prolific as Robert Parker, you're bound to write a clunker every now and then.  This one certainly was in my estimation.  If it wasn't for some sharp repartee from time to time, I would have given it 1 star.

Growing up in the Philadelphia area, I visited the Mutter Museum a number of times.  But as much as I knew about the museum, I actually knew very little about Dr. Thomas Dent Mutter, whose collection of medical curiosities was the core of the museum.  Wanting to learn more about Mutter, I selected Dr. Mutter's Marvels: A True Tale of Intrigue and Innovation at the Dawn of Modern Medicine written by Cristin O'Keefe Aptowicz.  While very interesting and informative, the book is more about Mutter and less about his museum, which is perfectly fine since this former rock-star of 19th century medicine is now largely forgotten.Thomas Mutter was born in Virginia and orphaned at an early age.  Deciding he wanted to study medicine, he traveled to Philadelphia and earned a degree from the University of Pennsylvania.  After graduation, he spent a year in Paris, learning the latest surgical techniques of the time, including plastic surgery.  He then returned to Philadelphia where he built up a private practice, before being hired on as professor of surgery at the new Jefferson Medical College.  It was at Jefferson that he truly made a name for himself.  He not only performed surgeries that were never heard of at the time, but treated his patients with compassion.  One procedure, the Mutter Flap, is still done today.  He was the first physician to use ether as an anesthetic in Philadelphia at a time when many doctors were thoroughly against the practice.  He believed that surgeons should keep clean, both their persons and their instruments, before germ theory was even understood.  He lobbied for the opening of a hospital at Jefferson to care for their surgical patients.  After surgery, patients were simply sent home.  It took some years before Jefferson finally did open a hospital.  And he was a riveting lecturer who was beloved by his students. Instead of straight lectures, he engaged them and challenged them to come up with the answers.  Throughout his life, he was a dapper guy who dressed in suits of bright colored silk and entertained lavishlysomething not always appreciated in Quaker Philadelphia.  Unfortunately, Mutter spent much of his life in ill-health and his fellow colleagues were not able to save his life.  He retired early and died in 1859 at age 48.Perhaps Mutter's largest legacy is the museum that today bears his name.  Mutter's reputation as riveting lecturer also partly owed to his habit of bringing specimens to class, those he kept safely store at the school's anatomical museum a well as those from his personal collection.  And to his students, the volume of diagrams, models, and specimens collected from around the world seemed nearly limitless.  There didn't seem to be an injury, disease, malady, or treatment for which Mutter couldn't seem to produce a relevant sample, and he would weave these specimens into his lectures masterfully...  It is these specimens that made up the nucleus of the Mutter Museum.  Knowing that his health was failing, he wanted to donate them to Jefferson Medical College.  The gift would come with a  $30,000 bequest and several strings attached.
