Finally, the College of Physicians (not an actual college) accepted Mutter's collection and met his requirements.It was especially interesting to read about the evolution of medical practices during this period, and it was gratifying to learn of the important role that Philadelphia played in the education of medical students.  After reading Dr. Mutter's Marvels, I think I'm due to revisit his museum which can be found at 19 South 22nd Street in Philadelphia.

I saw Driving the King by Ravi Howard on several lists of the best books of 2015, so I ordered it when I saw it offered through Amazon Vine.  I generally shy away from historical fiction, and although this novel is beautifully written, I kept getting stuck on the fact that a lot of what was written here wasn't true.Nathaniel Weary and Nathaniel Cole (Nat King Cole) both were born in Montgomery, Alabama.  They were in the same class in school until the Cole family moved to Chicago when Cole was still small.  Without giving the plot away, after a grave injustice was done to Weary, Cole hires his childhood friend to move to Los Angelos and become his driver.  After serving as a soldier in World War II, this may seem a bit of a come-down, but Weary is hoping that in LA, he won't find the kind of racial hatred that exists in his home town.  During this time period, the Montgomery Bus Boycott is getting under way and members of his family are directly involved.  Dr. Martin Luther King is a pastor in a Montgomery church, and he, his family, and his church are threatened.  It truly is an ugly period in our history.  Yet, Weary discovers that this type of racism is not limited to the south, and that there are many who would love to see the talents of Nat King Cole silenced.  It is Weary's observations about this time that are Howard's strength. It was just tiresome thinking about folks having to fight for the least little thing.  I loved my people for fighting, but hated the reason why, and that left me with that crosscut notion of pride and anger pulling in different directions, two kinds of muscle fighting for the same piece of bone.But while I enjoyed this story, I found out early on that Nathaniel Weary was a totally fictional character, and thus, I felt that Driving the King rang false.  Also, a major subplot in Driving the King was about Nat King Cole's return to Montgomery for another concert, years after his first concert in his hometown was disrupted by violence and he was injured.  Unfortunately, I read that after the incident at the first Montgomery concert, Cole never gave another concert in the souththus another untruth.  But perhaps blame my own prejudice of historic fiction for my taking exception to these embellishments.

I have discovered that two of the finest books written about Franklin Delano Roosevelt were written by Geoffrey C. Ward.  The first, Before the Trumpet, covers FDR's life from his birth to his marriage to Eleanor Roosevelt in 1905.  The second book, A First Class Temperament: The Emergence of Franklin Roosevelt, 1905-1928 is just as meticulously researched and wonderfully written as Before the Trumpet.  A First Class Temperament ends when when FDR is first elected governor of New York, and it is fascinating to read so much about the time before FDR became president.If Before the Trumpet details those influences that made FDR the man he became, A First Class Temperament covers those factors in his life that made him one of our most influential leaders.  The key events in A First Class Temperament include his early forays into politics, his desire to follow in the footsteps of his distant cousin Teddy Roosevelt, and his battles with Tammany Hall.  Quite a bit of time is dedicated to his stint as Assistant Secretary of the Navy in the Woodrow Wilson administration.  During this time, Eleanor Roosevelt discovered the infidelity of her husband with her social secretary, Lucy Mercer.  This event caused a change in the dynamics of their marriage and allowed Eleanor more freedom to take on the causes that were important to her.  During the years covered, FDR will meet many individuals who will play an important part in his administration including Louis Howe, Frances Perkins and Marguerite LeHand.  And then there is his contracting polio and his unsuccessful fight of many years to fully recover.  This not only made Roosevelt a different man, but again, it helped push Eleanor to become more independent and more politically active.One aspect of Roosevelt's life that I found particularly interesting was his time spent as Assistant Secretary of the Navy.  I always thought that Roosevelt looked down his patrician nose at Naval Secretary, Josephus Daniels. FDR thought that the North Carolina newspaper editor was a bit of a country bumpkin.  Yet Ward shows us that although Daniels had no naval experiences, he was shrewd when it came to the DC political game and he had much to teach his young charge.  Years of political experience had taught the older man the ways and means with which to deal effectively with Congress; he spent much of his time as Secretary on the Hill, doing the sort of amiable, indispensable lobbying on the Navy's behalf that the impatient, impulsive younger man would then have found impossible.  Daniels gave us young assistant many lessons in dealing with Congress, admirals, and big business.  It was also compelling to read about his struggle against polio.  This often debilitating disease turned him from a spoiled, self-absorbed youth cut short by an illness whose searing impact somehow transformed its victim into a thoughtful and compassionate leader.  This change gave him the empathy to deal with those less fortunate and was a important lesson leading up to the Great Depression.I was privileged to see Geoffrey C. Ward not too long ago for an author talk with Ken Burns, promoting their mini-series, The Roosevelts: An Intimate History.  Ward spoke of the steady stream of questions that people ask him about when he is going to finish his biographical work on FDR.  His answer was that the mini-series and companion book are the ending.  For our sake, I hope not!  I don't think that anybody has done FDR better than Geoffrey C. Ward.

I am always game for a new book about the Roosevelts.  When I told my husband that I had ordered Hissing Cousins: The Untold Story about Eleanor Roosevelt and Alice Roosevelt Longworth by Marc Peyser and Timothy Dwyer through Amazon Vine, he rolled his eyes and said I wasn't going to read anything new.  I am happy to report that the authors proved him wrong.  Yet, I wouldn't call it the untold story.  It is no secret that these first cousins were at odds for much of their adult life.  Over the years, the press played Alice and Eleanor off each other like rivals in a blue-blooded version of Oz: the good witch [Eleanor] and the bad witch [Alice].Alice and Eleanor were born in the same year to fathers who were brothers.  Alice's mother died two days after giving birth to Alice, and father Theodore Roosevelt handed off baby Alice to one of his sisters to raise while he headed out West.  He would not reclaim Alice until he remarried, almost 3 years later.  Eleanor's father Elliott was a lovable but out-of-control alcoholic.  Her mother was beautiful but remote.  When both of Eleanor's parents died before she turned 10, she was sent to her stern maternal-grandmother to be raised.  The two girls were different in many ways.  Alice was beautiful, bold, and reckless.  When Theodore becamse president, she became Princess Alicethe first media celebrity of the 20th Century.  Eleanor was not very attractive, uneasy in society, and afraid to break the rules.  She had a great interest in helping those less fortunate.  Both girls were largely educated at home, until Eleanor was sent away to an English boarding school where she would gain confidence and poise.  Alice and Eleanor were both from the Oyster Bay-branch of the Roosevelt family.  When Eleanor married Franklin Roosevelt (from the Hyde Park-branch), she became the bridge between the two.  But it was also the catalyst that started the bitter rivalry between the two branches, each one believing that they had a claim to continue Theodore Roosevelt's legacy.Throughout their years, Eleanor and Alice did many of the same things, although Alice tended to work from behind the scenes.  Eleanor tried not to let politics get in the way of their relationship, but it was often difficult when Alice treated both Franklin and Eleanor with such venim.  Several times she was even banned from the White House because of her behavior.  But despite their differences, these women were more alike that even they would admit.  They both lost parents and siblings at a young age. They both married powerful men who were mamas' boys and unfaithful to them.  They were much better grandmothers than they were mothers.  They also share part of at least one important legacy: they short-circuited the twentieth century's rules of gender and power.  Their roles as power players are all the more impressive given that they didn't even have the right to vote until they were thirty-six.I thoroughly enjoyed Hissing Cousins, and savored some of the new anecdotes and stories that were included.  It starts off strong with the funeral of Eleanor Roosevelt, much of which was new information to me.  But lots of the middle sections are common knowledge.  Otherwise, I would have given it five stars instead of four.

I have long been fascinated by the Abraham Lincoln assassination and John Wilkes Booth.  I selected Fortunes Fool: The Life of John Wilkes Booth by Terry Alford through Amazon Vine.  While Alford calls this book the first biography on Booth in quite some time, I believe that other books that Ive read provide a more comprehensive background on the actor-turned-assassin.Fortunes Fool can be divided into two halves.  The details of the life of John Wilkes Booth are fairly well known, and the first half provides information on his childhood and into his acting career.  Booth was born the son of famous Shakespearian actor Junius Brutus Booth.  The family moved between Baltimore and rural Maryland.  Booth fell naturally into the family business of acting, following in the steps of his father and his two older brothers, Junius, Jr. and Edwin.  Much of this first half deals with his acting career, and I felt this section contained too much minutia.  Alford is to be commended on the extent of his research, but as a reader, I got tired of reading about all his acting gigs, the theaters, the towns, the plays, the costumes, his fellow actors, and the reviews.  Also, in the first half, Alford portrays Booth as St. John.  He was a gentleman, kind-hearted, beautiful, loyal, a good son and brother, charismatic, generous, and a genius on the stage.  He could do no wrong.  Even when someone wrote that Booth was a bully in school, Alford dismisses the charges as unbelievable.The second half of Fortunes Fool deals with Booths conversion to the dark-side during the Civil War which led to his assassinating Lincoln.  While his family remained loyal to the Union, Booth had strong feelings for the Confederacy.  Eventually, he stopped acting and started developing a plot to kidnap President Lincoln and force a prisoner exchange.  During this period, even his closest friends felt that Booth exhibited symptoms of madness.  Although the story definitely picks up, there isnt much new in terms of information.  I did find the information in the Epilogue interesting about what happened to his body after his death.Alford seems an apologist for John Wilkes Booth and loves to quote from Booths friends who still held the actor in high esteem even decades after the assassination.  Fellow actress Kathryn Evans couldnt forgive the assassination, but still claimed I cannot refrain from telling those who never saw him that he was the finest gentleman I ever met.  Also, Alford claims that perhaps its time that we forgive and embrace John Wilkes Booth.  Maybe history will forgive Booth, but I dont think we can be expected to ever embrace the man.While I enjoyed Fortunes Fool, I think that two better books on the subject of John Wilkes Booth are American Brutus: John Wilkes Booth and the Lincoln Conspiracies by Michael W. Kauffman and My Thoughts Be Bloody: The Bitter Rivalry that Led to the Assassination of Abraham Lincoln by Nora Titone.

Ive become a fan of John Sanford and his Lucas Davenport series, and even Sanford admits that Winter Prey, his 5th in the series, is one of his favorites.  Winter Prey is not just a riveting thriller, but it also introduces the reader to Dr. Weather Karkinnen, who will become a regular in Sanfords novels and Davenports life.Lucas Davenport is a former Minneapolis cop.  Needing a break, he decides to leave the city and spend some time in his isolated Wisconsin cabin.  While in the area, a totally evil person, the Iceman, brutally murders the LaCourt family and then burns down their home.  The relentlessly cold winter has paralyzed the region and makes investigating the case so much harder.  Being entirely out of their league, the county sheriff deputizes Davenport and asks for his assistance.  The murders are tied to a child sex-ring, and as Davenport gets closer to the truth, more and more people disappear and/or murdered.  Not only must Davenport faceoff against the Iceman, but the entire law-enforcement community must battle the weather.  This makes things even trickier as the Iceman can zip around unnoticed on his snow mobile.  Davenport also realizes that the Iceman is targeting the local medical examiner, Dr. Weather Karkinnen--a woman who is starting to melt the former-cops heart.Winter Prey follows the same formula as the other Prey books that Ive read. The point of view alternates between Davenport and the Iceman.  In some books, you know the villain right away.  In Winter Prey, the identity of the Iceman was not revealed until the end, and came as a complete surprise.Im happy to have finally started reading John Sanford.  I wouldnt want to read all of his books in a row, but they are well-written and suspenseful and a nice treat from time to time.

I truly enjoyed the first two Liane Moriarty novels that I read, What Alice Forgot and The Husbands Secret.  I dont think that The Last Anniversary, one of her earlier books, quite measures up to her later efforts.  While I liked the ending, I thought that the journey was often tedious and the entire plot was a stretch.Like the previous two novels that Ive read, The Last Anniversary rotates viewpoints between several characters.  And the anniversary in the title is not a wedding anniversary, but the anniversary of an unsolved mystery that took place on Scribbly Gum Island.  On July 15, 1932, teenaged sisters Connie and Rose Doughty stopped by their neighbors cottage for tea.  Instead, they discovered the kettle about to boil, a freshly baked marble cake waiting to be iced, and a tiny baby waking for her feed.  Somehow, the sisters raised the baby, named Enigma, and it is now present day.  Enigma has her own extended family with children and grandchildren, and they all have made a big business and earned lots of money over the Munro mystery.  When Connie passes away, her death sets the family (along with a friend, Sophie Honeywell) on a collision course with the truth.The entire Munro mystery is unbelievable and early on, its obvious that its not really a mystery at all.  Also, some of the characters were not that likeable.  Im sorry, but the subplot with Grace was pretty horrible, and Veronika was insufferable.  But Moriarty does have some gems of wisdom in The Last Anniversary. Connie tells a reporter that marriage is housework.  Its never finished.  Youve just got to grit your teeth and keep working away at it, day after day.  Connie also observes that marriages go through patchesgood ones, bad ones, so-so ones.  For example, there was that really enjoyable time in the early Eighties when they discovered apricot massage oil from Avon.  Goodness me.  That had certainly spiced things up in the bedroom (and once in the bathroom and quite a few times in the living room!).I think that Liane Moriarty is a talented writer, and in reading The Last Anniversary, I can see how much shes developed as a writer over the years.  I will certainly not give up reading her novels.  Next on my list is her best-seller, Big Little Lies.

When I first started reading David Baldacci, I would purchase a hard back as soon as one was published.  And I started reading him from his very first book, Absolute Power.  After awhile, I would wait until them came out in paperback.  Im at the point now that I get new Baldacci books from my county library-- theyre just not worth the money.  His latest novel, The Escape, is the third in his John Puller-series.  The good news is that at least John Puller is developing a personality and is less a Jack Reacher clone.  The bad news is that there are just too many issues with The Escape to make it one of Baldaccis better novels.John Puller is an investigator with the US Army Criminal Investigative Division.  His brilliant older brother, Robert Puller, was a major in the USAF and a fast-rising star in the intelligence community.  That was until he was convicted of treason.  Serving a life-term in a military jail at Fort Leavenworth, he escapes when a storm wreaks havoc on the facility.  John Puller is brought in by three very important people who have a mission for him: find his brother.  Early on, Puller runs across some very bad men who want nothing better than to shut down the investigation by killing him.  He realizes that he not only needs to find Robert, but he also needs to discover whether or not the treason charge was a frame.  He is also assigned as a partner, Veronica Knoxa captain with the United States Armys Intelligence and Security Command.  Throughout the book, Puller doesnt know if he can trust Knox, or not.  He also doesnt know what her motives are.  Their investigation will leave many dead bodies in their wake, as well as evidence that top officials in the government are working for the enemy.  But identifying them is no easy task and finding proof is even more difficult.But as I said previously, there are just too many issues for me in The Escape. The plot is fleshed out and the book comes in at almost 500 pages.  But the plot itself is pretty far-fetched.  You have to suspend all logic in order to believe most of the story. From the opening pages, I knew how this novel was going to end.  Also, the many intelligence groups, military and otherwise, are totally confusing.  There are almost as many acronym-groups (NSA, NSC, DOD, STRATCOM, SES, DTRA, ISR, etc.) as FDR had Alphabet Agencies.  Puller has become less like Jack Reacher in that he now shows emotions, cries, has a cat, and drinks tea instead of coffee.  And I didnt like Veronica Knox at the beginning, or the end of this book.  To me, it felt like Baldacci was just writing his quota of words without really crafting this novel.  Sad in that he used to be one of my favorites.I will continue to read David Baldacci, but I have stopped spending any money on his novels.  Maybe he will figure this out, but most likely, not.

I have read quite a few novels by Anne Rivers Siddons and I always find them well-written and very enjoyableuntil I read her latest book, The Girls of August.  I am not one who generally low-balls my ratings, but the only reason that I gave this book two stars is because I like the locale.  Otherwise, it was horrible and I cant imagine why her editor let something so shabby be published.Madison, Rachel, Barbara, and Melinda met while their husbands were in medical school.  Ever since, theyve always spent a girls-only week at the beach in August.  Their only requirements are that the house be isolated and that they always stay somewhere new.  When Melinda dies in a car crash, they take some years off.  But when Melindas husband marries Baby, a 22-year old bimbo, they decide to try and resurrect their yearly vacation.  It just so happens that Baby has a beach house on Tiger Island, a very secluded spot where they will need a boat to reach the island, and then be stranded there for two weeks.  Each woman comes to the island with baggage and after time together and enough alcohol, the secrets seep out. But overall, this book is pretty horrible.  The characters are totally obnoxious with Baby being the worst.  The ending of the book was so weak and very rushed, and The Girls of August was much shorter than any other Anne Rivers Siddons book Ive ever read.  Also, there seemed to be a problem with the final two chapters.  A part of chapter 7 seemed like it should have been in chapter 8, or maybe these two chapters should have been flip-flopped.  Perhaps it was a problem with the Kindle edition. I am very surprised that Anne Rivers Siddons published something so shoddy.  The only good thing for me was that I borrowed it from the library.  I would have been seriously upset if I had paid good money for The Girls of August.

I have always wanted to travel to Venice, and reading The Golden Egg by Donna Leon is a bonusnot only does her Commissario Brunetti-series take place in Venice, but this is a mystery series that shows how different law enforcement is in the City of Lights.  I truly enjoyed The Golden Egg, but as this is book number 22 in the series, I think it would have been better to start with book number one.Commissario Guido Brunetti lives in Venice with his wife and two children.  His wife mentions that the handicapped boy who worked for their dry cleaners died, and she asks her husband for more information.  Davide Cavanella was actually near 40 years old and the cause of death was suicide by drug overdose.  But it seems strange that when Brunetti starts asking around, he finds no records associated with Cavanella including no birth certificate, baptismal certificate, and school or medical records.  Its like he never existed.  When he interviews this mother, he gets evasive stories and downright lies.  This makes Brunetti even more curious, which is difficult because a crime hasnt been committedor has it?Donna Leons books take us to a world where native Venetians arent accepting of outsiders, including fellow Italians.  Some still speak Venetian, rather than Italian.  Its an environment where police get around by boats instead of cars.  And I enjoyed reading about Venetian culturethe history, the food, the buildings, the customs, etc.  The Golden Egg starts out slow and deliberate and even by the end, were not sure if a crime has been committed.  But we do know that something horrible happened to Davide Cavanella.  In addition to recommending that a new reader start this series at the beginning, I also suggest that Leon provide a glossary for Venetian and/or Italian words that liberally sprinkle her novels.  She does place them in italics, and while I could figure out some, others I couldnt.Im so glad a friend introduced me to Donna Leon and Commissario Brunelli, and I look forward to picking up this series at the beginning.

Needing a new series on audiobook for long car trips, my husband and I settled on Craig Johnsons Longmire series.  Being big fans of the television series based on these books, it seemed like a good choice.  We decided to start with book one, The Cold Dish, which is narrated by George Guidall.  While The Cold Dish was suspenseful and entertaining, there are some differences between the books and the television shows and it is really unfair to compare the two.Walter Longmire is the sheriff of fictional Absaroka County in Wyoming.  Bordering on Indian territory, Longmire sometimes finds himself caught between two worlds.  His best friend, Henry Standing Bear, is his bridge between two cultures.  Several years prior, four white teenage boys sexually assaulted a special needs Indian girl.  The four got off with outrageously light sentences.  When one of the boys is found dead of a gunshot wound, there is speculation that it could have been a hunting accident. But soon, Walt knows for sure that the boys are being targeted by someone seeking revenge for their prior sins.  The murder weapon is a Sharps riflea historic gun and not too common in these parts.  It also takes special talent to fire a Sharps great distances, which narrows Longmires list of suspects. How The Cold Dish plays out it exciting and suspenseful.  It definitely had us on the edge of our seats and we didnt see the ending coming, at all.On the whole, I found that The Cold Dish had many more comical moments than the television series.  The book provides interesting background on Walter and Henry including their high school and college years and their time in Vietnam, where Walter served as a Marine and Henry was Special Forces.  But if youre looking for the characters to be an exact match between books and television shows, you might be disappointed.  The book characters dont always look like their television counterparts (Walter and Henry are both much bigger guys, Vic is a dark-haired, olive-skinned Italian, Ferg is much older, etc.).  Sometimes their personalities are different.  Turk (Branch in the show) has a lot less redeeming qualities in the book.  But overall, my husband and I are hooked on Longmirethe book and the show.  And I guess its a good thing that we discovered the books because it doesnt look like the show will be back for season 4.  We are already looking forward to listening to books two and three on our next car trip.

The Husbands Secret by Liane Moriarty was highly recommended by a number of friends, and I can see why.  This haunting and beautifully written story would be the perfect book club selection as it provides quite a few different angles for discussion.Moriarty weaves together the stories of three Australian women.  Rachel, a widow, is still mourning the murder of her only daughter, Janie, when she was 17 years old.  The crime is still unsolved, although Rachel believes she knows the identity of the killer.  Coming up on the 28th anniversary of Janies death, the pain has not dulled and we contemplate what Rachel might do, if anything, to avenge her daughters death.  Tess is happily married with a six year old son.  But when she discovers her husbands betrayal, she takes her son and moves to her mothers to lick her wounds and regroup.  Cecilia has the perfect husband, the perfect daughters, the perfect house, and a perfect life.  But then she learns her husbands terrible secret and her life will never be the same.  The lives of Rachel, Tess and Cecilia will all intersect at some point.The Husbands secret is about marriage and families.  Its about hurts and forgiveness.  Its about the dangers of secrets.  Its about what we will do to protect our families.  And sometimes those things we do to protect them can actually cause unforeseen damage.  Moriarty is an accomplished writer and sometimes she made me chuckle, sometimes she made me sad, but always she made me think.  This is a novel that will haunt you long after youve finished.  Comparing one couple: Hed wronged her.  Shed wronged him right back.  Had they both been suffering a form of temporary insanity?  It was a defense for murder, after all; why not for married couples?  Marriage was a form of insanity; love hovering permanently on the edge of aggravation.  How true  I also liked the Epilogue, although would have liked to learn more of what happens to Cecilia and her family.After thoroughly enjoying The Husbands Secret, I have What Alice Forgot, also by Moriarty, on deck.  In fact, I predict that Liane Moriarty might just become one of my new favorite fiction authors.

When Lions Roar: The Churchills and the Kennedys by Thomas Maier is not just about Winston Churchill and Joesph P. Kennedy, Sr., but also includes their extended families as well.  I always enjoy reading about Churchill, and so selected this book from Amazon Vine.  Reading more like a novel, this book far exceeded my expectations.The story of Joseph Kennedy's years as American Ambassador to Great Britain is pretty well known.  Because of his generous support of Franklin Delano Roosevelt and the Democratic Party in the election of 1932, the ambassadorship was the second big job with which Joe was awarded.  A strong isolationist who wished to offer little or no support to Britain, Kennedy proved to be an embarrassment to the Roosevelt White House and he was eventually removed.  Churchill and Kennedy had a fascinating and complicated relationship that exposes the politically astuteness of Churchill.  But When Lions Roar is not just a story about these two powerful men.  It is also a story about their children and how difficult it is for the sons of strong men to make their own way.  For the first half of this book, this also includes FDR and his bunch of dysfunctional children.  This is a story of intrigue and affairs and spies.  Winston condoned an affair between his young daughter-in-law, Pamela, with American Averell Harriman.  His son Randolph never quite forgave his father and suspected the real reason Winston accepted Pamela's cheating on Randolph was because she was passing along Harriman's secrets.  Sometimes they shared the same women.  Claire Booth Luce had affairs with Randolph, Joe Sr., and Bernard Baruch (another major player in this book).  They definitely shared many of the same people in their orbits.I enjoyed When Lions Roar because of the many little-known facts that came to light.  Maybe others know them already.  I didn't realize the delicate relationship between the White House and the Vatican during World War II.  Although Rose Kennedy isn't necessarily the power behind the throne, she was definitely on board with her husband's plans for a political dynasty for his family and was one of the few who could criticize Joe for his boorish behavior.  We learn that Joe, Jr. signed up for that extra month of service in England (which ultimately lead to the mission that caused his death) because he was seeing a married woman.  We also learn that maybe Jack was the best of the sons to be president, and not Joe Jr.  Although When Lions Roar was a bit long, I didn't want it to end.  But I do have two complaints:  first, Maier has a tendency to jump around between time periods.  You might reach 1941, and then you're back to 1940.  Also, I don't always appreciate some of his observations.  Maier says that Randolph was Still ruggedly handsome in a boozy way.  I'm not really sure what he means by that.Otherwise, When Lions Roar was an engaging read and I thoroughly enjoyed reading about the Churchill and Kennedy families.

New Orleans is one of my favorite cities, so selecting Empire of Sin: A Story of Sex, Jazz, Murder and the Battle for Modern New Orleans by Gary Krist through Amazon Vine was a natural for me.  The entire history of New Orleans is rich and varied, and Krist gives us a quick lesson on the history of the Crescent City.  But the focus of Empire of Sin is what Krist calls the 30 year civil war that New Orleans waged with itself over the Storyville District.  This is a story that is equally fascinating and depressing.New Orleans has often been called the Sodom of the South.  Up until the late 1800s, gambling, prostitution, street violence, and bawdy entertainment had been a prominent feature of the city's life for its entire history.  But as brothels and gaming houses started moving into residential areas, a move began to make the city more respectable.  Alderman Sidney Story came up with the idea to move all vice to an area that became known as Storyville.  And for 30 years, between 1897 and 1917, business was booming.  But soon, even this small pocket of vice became unacceptable to social reformers, clergymen, and even the US Military.Empire of Sin is a story of culture, sex, music, organized crime, and Jim Crow.  It pits politicians against businessmen, and businessmen against law enforcement.  It features violence, murders, riots, vigilante justice, and lynchings.  It counters Americans against immigrants (mostly Italians), and the Black Hand against the Italian Mafia.  It features social reformers and the US Military trying to regulate morality.  It is the battle by white leaders to suppress the new black music, Jazz.  And it is a war to fully segregate a city that for centuries had a large population of black and white creoles who intermingled and intermarried.  These actions not only contributed to the Great Migration of blacks to the north, but the city razed almost the entire Storyville District (including beautiful Victorian mansions along Basin Street) to create a public housing project.  What happened to Storyville was ultimately depressing, and even today, it is ugly to read this history.Empire of Sin is the second book that I have ready by Gary Krist, the first being City of Scoundrels.  My one complaint with Empire of Sin is that Krist does jump around quite a bit, which I think detracts from the flow of the story.  Also, I'm not sure that the Axman is really part of this story, and the case is still unsolved.  But I did enjoy so much of the history that he presentsespecially the history of Jazz. I'm hoping to travel to New Orleans sometime next year and hope to see some of the places that Krist writes about that are still standing.

As one of 6 million active geocachers, I was surprised to see a new mystery on the Amazon Vine list that used a geocaching-theme.  Ursula Archer has written other books, but Five: A Novel is her first adult mystery and very good first effort.  I especially liked that it took place in Austria, where geocaching protocol is slightly different than in the United States.Beatrice Kaspary and Florin Wenninger are called to the scene when a farmer discovers a dead woman in his cow pasture.  Kaspary and Wenninger are homicide detectives who work for the Salzburg State Office of Criminal Investigation.  With hands tied behind her back, the one strange find on the body is that numbers were tattooed to the soles of her feet.  It takes a little figuring before the detectives realize that the numbers are GPS coordinates.  One of their colleagues is a geocacher, and he gets assigned to help with the case because of his hobby.  Soon, they're involved in a geocaching chase, but instead of looking for treasures, they're finding body parts and dead bodies.  The entire time, the killer is toying with them and taunting them for being incompetent.  But Kaspary and Wenninger also figure out that in playing the killer's game, they are also lending him assistance.  This psychological thriller had me guessing until the end.Archer is a good writer and I enjoyed her descriptions of things.  At one point, Kaspary had never described to the belief that dead people looked like they were sleeping.  They looked like a foreign species.  Shockingly different, even if they had died peacefully. But I did get more than tired of the drama with her ex-husband and also, the description of every cup of coffee she ever made or drank.  I don't think that these things added to the story.  But overall, Five is a fine read and you don't have to be a geocacher to enjoy this book.  In fact, it might be a good introduction to geocaching, although geocachers tend to be kind, gentle peopleunlike in the book.

Another long car trip...another Jack Reacher thriller.  Our departure just happened to occur right after Lee Child published his new novel, Personal.  This is book 19 in his Jack Reacher series and is read by Dick Hill.  My husband and I enjoyed Personal, although it is not without some issues.Former Army MP and current nomad Jack Reacher is traveling by bus near a military base.  He picks up a discarded copy of Stars and Stripes and finds a personal advertisement directing him to call a one-star general with whom he's had previous dealings.  In a flash, he's being flown to Fort Bragg and it turns out that the Army (and the CIA and the State Department) need his services.  A sniper took a shot at the French president, but it's not just any sniper.  This shooter is one of the elite who can hit a target at  mile away and he appears to have military training.  Reacher once put such a sniper in jail, John Kott.  Those trying to prevent a catastrophe at the coming G-8 Conference set for London are betting that Reacher can once again track down Kott.  Of course, the chase will mean that Reacher will be acting on his own.  Plus, he's given a rookie CIA agent, Casey Nice, to baby sit him.  But not only is Reacher after the sniper, but he also has to battle a local gang and the Serbian Mafia.  And there is always the possibility that Reacher is the real target.Entertainingyes.  Hokeyabsolutely.  But Personal suffers from a variety of maladies.  First, the descriptions go way overboard in this novel, and the beginning of this book was especially slow in getting started.  Although it was nice that Reacher avoids any sexual activity in Personal, Casey Nice was more like a daughter.  I was thoroughly tired of the neurotic, untested agent very quickly.  Also, the possibility that the Army (or the CIA or the State Department) recruiting anyone on the outside for an operation is pretty laughable.  We all know that these groups don't play well with others.Still, a Lee Child with some issues is better than a lot of other authors at their best, and Child will continue to be our go-to author when taking long car trips.

I was in high school when Eleanor and Franklin by Joseph P. Lash was published, and it started me on a life-long fascination with the Roosevelt family.  I have quite an extensive collection of Roosevelt books, and I never tire of reading anything new.  I found out last year that Ken Burns and Geoffrey Ward were going to debut a 14 hour mini-series on Theodore, Franklin and Eleanor in September 2014 and I have been counting the days ever since.  Well, that time is finally here!  Their companion book, The Roosevelts: An Intimate History, was published today to supplement the series, and I am thoroughly enchanted.  Although this coffee table-style book has over 700 photos, it also contains a strong and well-written narrative about the lives of these three remarkable people.The Roosevelts were a noteworthy and prolific family, descended from Claes Martertenszen van Roosevelt who settled in New York in 1644.  Two branches of the family were the Oyster Bay Roosevelts (Teddys family) and the Hyde Park Roosevelts (FDRs family).  Eleanor was the bridge between to two branches, being the niece of Teddy and the wife of FDR.  Although the branches were different in many ways, including political affiliation, they both had a love of the land, a sense of duty to others, family tragedies, and great ambition.  The Roosevelts: An Intimate History covers the large lives of Theodore, Franklin and Eleanor.  Teddy and FDR were natural leaders, and FDR set his career path to emulate that of his older cousin.  Eleanor was a more reluctant leader, taking on a bigger role only after FDR came down with polio.  In reading this book, I was haunted by so much of the Roosevelt history.  Teddys first wife and mother die on the same day, two days after the birth of his daughter.  Eleanors parents and her younger brother die young.  Both branches were plagued by alcoholism.  Franklin, a mamas boy, was unwilling to cut the apron strings and was unfaithful to the emotionally fragile Eleanor.  Teddys youngest son, Quentin, was killed in World War I. The Oyster Bay and the Hyde Park branches had a falling out when FDR went into politics as a Democrat, and they continued to feud long after Teddy was dead.  And although Eleanor and FDR might have been a power-couple in many ways and loved each other more than they would admit, they found the most happiness in other people.The photographs in The Roosevelts are worth the price of the book.  Many of them have never been published before and I thoroughly enjoyed them all.  It is especially haunting to see modern-day pictures of intimate objects owned and worn by the Roosevelts. There is Eleanors engagement ring and her engagement pendant with teeth-marks from her babies.  There is a photo of the lucky campaign hat worn by FDR during all four of his presidential campaigns.  It was raffled off after the third election, but returned to FDR in time for the fourth.  Theres a glass case with a bullet hole that most likely saved Teddys life. And there is a beautiful Cartier watch given to FDRs mother when his father found out she was pregnant with FDR. There are campaign buttons and posters, wedding and baby pictures, maps, magazine and newspaper articles, postcards, political cartoons, formal portraits and candids, pictures of Roosevelts at work and at play, houses and the White House, family pets, etc.  This book is also filled with fun stories and ironic anecdotes.  Someone asked Teddy why he couldnt do anything to control his wayward daughter, Alice.  I can be President of the United States, her exasperated father once told a friend, or I can attend to Alice. I cannot possibly do both! Another story has FDR visiting Grover Cleveland in the White House when he was five.  As they were leaving, the weary president shook Franklins hand and said, My little man, I am making a strange wish for you.  It is that you may never be president of the United States.After the publication of The Roosevelts: An Intimate History, I cant wait to watch the series.  Im sure that I will go to this book again and again throughout the coming weeks, and beyond.

If any book should be made into a blockbuster movie, it's Tinseltown: Murder, Morphine, and Madness at the Dawn of Hollywood by William J. Mann.  Tinseltown has it all--murders, rising and falling stars, movie moguls, Prohibition, extortionists, civic reformers, etc.  Just add hooch and illegal drugs and stir. It makes for an explosive combination.The centerpiece of Tinseltown is the murder of famed director, William Desmond Taylor--still unsolved to this day.  His killing brought out his many secrets including the fact that his name wasn't even William Desmond Taylor.  Two female stars were directly linked to Taylor and they were suspects for a time.  During this same period, Fatty Arbuckle is on trial for the brutal rape and death of Virginia Rappe at a wild party.  Some of Hollywood's biggest stars are addicted to illegal drugs and alcohol (also illegal).  Adolph Zukor and his colleagues run their companies with iron fists.  During the days of silent films, big stars belonged to studios, who not only produced the films but then showed them in their theaters (something the FTC will eventually target).  During this same period, a group of "church ladies," flush from their success in finally pushing through Prohibition now feel it their duty to regulate morality through Hollywood movies.  Zukor knows that for the film industry, "the greatest threats it faced were in those civic reformers and church ladies who saw the handiwork of Satan in silvery shadowplays that flickered across the nation's screens.  Movies glorified sex and sin, these bluenoses charged, and the movie players, with all their affairs and divorces, were agents of the devil."  The effects of their efforts will be felt for over 35 years.One of the most fascinating men in Tinseltown is Adolph Zukor, president of Famous Players-Lasky and Paramount Studios.  This movie mogul had a vision of the future.  "Zukor envisioned longer, more complex narratives for films.  He took the movies out of their makeshift storefront theaters and enshrined them in grand palaces of entertainment." He also saw movies moving beyond silent, and beyond black and white.  "What if someday they could be synchronized with music scores?  What if they could be shot in color?  What if movies could talk?"  He also imagined a time when movies could be seen at home "on devices not yet invented."  Zukor lived until 1976, when he died at the age of 103--ultimately seeing his dreams become reality.I know very little about the early days of Hollywood, and Mann gives us a fascinating look at this particular window in time.  Most of these stars who were very big names are now mostly forgotten.  I found Mann's tabloid-style writing well suited to this story.  And although some have complained that it is too long, I disagree.  It's not just a story about Taylor's murder--it's so much more.  Think Devil in the White City or Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil.  There are a lot of patches in this quilt.I only have two complaints about Tinseltown.  First, there are no photos in the Vine edition, although there are plenty to be found online.  I assume the published book will include many.  The second and more serious charge is that Mann does not solve the murder of William Desmond Taylor.  Although he speculates on who may have committed the crime, he has no hard evidence or concrete proof.  Otherwise, I found Tinseltown to be thoroughly enjoyable and learned a lot about the early days of the film industry.

Each bottle of PacificCoast NutriLab's nutrients is a different color- CoEnzymeQ10  a bright orange.On the side of each container is the URL for an ebook about that specific nutrient (TheCoQ10effect.com). These ebooks are beautifully illustrated in brilliant color and are very informative. In fact it could be said that each ebook is the horse's mouth for that particular nutrient.No hanky-panky. No anecdotal observations. Scientifically backed research.Although I have just received my COQ10 from PCNL, I have been taking this amazing nutrient for years. And I am a case in point:  85 years old. All my marbles. I design Tshirts on the Internet. I am never sick. Although I walk with a cane I walk fast. It would not be proper to say that my longevity is due to COQ10 because I cannot prove it.  But if I had to give up all supplements other than multiple vitamins, except one, COQ10 would be my choice.The capsules are egg-shaped, small and smooth and go down with a gulp.Based on the ebooks which are excellent and classy, I am willing to put my trust in PCNL products and stick with them in the future. I received CoQ10 and Arginine free in return for an honest, unbiased review for each. I award both 5 stars and am delighted to do so.

Based on a couple other reviews, I was leery about what I would really get with this lens kit.  As it turns out, all the pieces were there and the quality of construction exceeded my expectations.  It comes with a Samsung Galaxy S6 phone back case which the lens screws into. Also included is a sturdy little tabletop tripod that attaches to the lens by means of an aluminum ring that slides onto the lens.  Assembly is quick and easy.  Usage is just as easy.  You merely turn the focusing ring and snap away!  The lens provides 12 X magnification. Also included are a soft storage pouch, a lens cleaning cloth, clearly written instruction sheet and lens caps. Even the box is high quality.  Nowhere could I find that said it was made in China, so I don't really know.  Regardless, it is well made and packaged.  I highly recommend this lens kit if you are in the market for a camera phone telephoto lens. -- Roger Meyer

Grilling season is here!  Because I live in the southwest, grilling season never really goes away, but it's "official" after Memorial Day.  We like grilled chicken breasts and salmon marinated and basted with Teriyaki sauce.  This large bottle should last quite some time, even with our grilling habits.  The flavor is a little "weaker" than some others we are used to, but still tastes very good.  Once opened, it must be refrigerated and, therefore, takes up quite a bit of refrigerator space.  That is no fault of the Teriyaki sauce, however, just a side comment.  As much as this will get used, it won't be a problem for long! While an acceptable Teriyaki sauce, I will be less likely to seek out and purchase it just because of the bottle size and the fact that its flavor really isn't superior to others we've used.- - Roger Meyer

When I first got the mugs I tried two things- putting hot coffee in one, ice water in the other. The coffee stayed hot right to the last drop, but I timed the ice water one to see how long it took for the ice to melt.Even in warm New Mexico the ice persisted for an hour and a halfI have a habit of carrying my coffee mug around the house sort of like a security blanket. Trouble is I would often leave it somewhere and then I couldn't find it, the ceramic mug blending in. NO problem with these beautiful copper mugs! I can spot one practically a mile off as it catches the light like a little beacon.The mugs are very light, the handles are smooth, and they're comfortable to hold. I've never had a copper mug before, or any copper kitchen thingy for that matter. I am both pleased and impressed and I like things that are different. These mugs are different in nice ways.A recipe for a Moscow Mule, a concoction of ginger beer and lime juice poured over ice is printed on the colorful box the mugs come in.I received the mugs free of charge in return for an unbiased review, which I am happy to provide.I received the mugs free in exchange for an unbiased review, which I am very happy to provide.

As part of a Vine program review of several selfie sticks, this stick was reviewed after reviewing the URPower Monopod QuickSnap Pro 3-in-1 selfie stick.  The only significant difference in the two units was the phone mounting fixture.  In this unit, two different phone mounting fixtures are provided.  They are different sizes and therefore will accommodate a wider range of phones.  My review of that unit follows and applies to this unit as well. The camera mounting fixture is padded with foam to protect your phone while mounted in the fixture.  When I first installed my phone (Samsung Galaxy S4), I was concerned because it seemed that it was not centered along the axis of the stick and would tend to "roll" to the heave side.  After playing with the unit for a while, I happened to notice there were screws on the bottom of the camera holder.  I loosened them which allowed me to slide the camera back and forth and could center it.  I didn't see that feature indicated anywhere in the instruction, on the box, or on the Amazon web page (In fairness, there was a photo showing the base extended, but no reference to that ability, and it was not on the main photo page.). The stick itself seems substantial and extends to around 38," and the extensions do not rotate, thereby keeping the phone in the orientation desired.  The device comes with Bluetooth shutter activation.  It paired to my phone flawlessly and activated the shutter the first time I tried it.  Shutter activation is accomplished with a button on the handle that is easily pressed while holding the stick.  Included in the package is a short USB cable to be used to recharge the batteries in the handle. The only other criticism I have is the instructions included.  I realize this unit is made in China, but I've seen much better translations in other products.  It was hard to read because of the tiny print and VERY difficult to understand. Granted, while this product is somewhat intuitive in its operation, some people who are not technically inclined could use some better instructions for Bluetooth operation and charging the batteries. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and ease of setup.  I would recommend this to anyone looking for a selfie stick.  The price is reasonable too.-Roger Meyer

The URPower Monopod QuickSnap Pro 3-in-1 selfie stick is very easy to set up an use.  The camera mounting fixture is padded with foam to protect your phone while mounted in the fixture.  When I first installed my phone (Samsung Galaxy S4), I was concerned because it seemed that it was not centered along the axis of the stick and would tend to "roll" to the heave side. The first thing I noticed about this selfie stick after opening the box was that it came with a key fob type Bluetooth shutter activation device.  I was intrigued and surprised as to how easy it was to pair with my phone and use it to activate the shutter.  I'll be using this even without the selfie stick as I frequently get blurry photos when pressing the phone screen shutter button because I move the phone slightly. The phone mounts to the holding fixture quite easily and can be moved, as necessary, to avoid any side buttons on the phone. Stick extension is about 33" and seems sturdy.  A complaint I have, however, is that the mounting of the camera holder to the pivoting fixture on the stick was difficult.  It seems that the threads did not mesh properly, and I could only screw it on by a few threads which left the camera holder very loose.  I eventually used some tools and forced it tight, all the while hoping it would not break.  It didn't.  Another complaint is that there were not an instruction sheet in the box, only very brief instructions on the box, but no reference to Bluetooth operation.  There was actually more information on the Amazon web page than included with the selfie stick. Apparently, the manufacturer assumes that the Bluetooth setup is intuitive, and is to a certain extent, but no explanation was given as to operation of the fob, e.g., the power switch, meaning of the blue light, and operating abilities/constraints. I would have given this device only three stars because of the camera holder attachment difficulty and lack of detailed instructions for the Bluetooth device, but the convenience of the Bluetooth device being separate and allowing me to use it without the selfie stick bumped it up to four stars.Roger Meyer --

The Ohuhu Heavy Duty Drying Rack is perfect for  our needs, which is to have a sturdy spot to dry our towels and swimwear after swimming.  This is a fairly large stand, and like the title states, heavy duty.  It's not like one of those cheap foldable hanging racks that knock over at the slightest breeze.  This drying rack is quite substantial and is absolutely perfect for our needs.  It's heavy, but not too heavy that I can't easily cart it around, and it has plenty of places to hang towels and swimwear.  Very happy with this drying rack!-Victoria Franks

I admit I was always prejudiced against Patsy Ramsey who I felt was railroading JonBenet into competing in child beauty pageant contests for the sake of her own vicarious gratification and ego. I find repelling such contests which are both tacky and tasteless. Unspeakable is coaching little girls to assume suggestive poses. And little girls' values may be warped into thinking beauty is everything. JonBenet was wetting the bed virtually every night which would certainly indicate she was stressed. I came away from reading Foreign Factions still disliking Patsy but being a bit more sympathetic towards  a woman to whom appearances, both physically and socially, were everything. I was surprised to learn she had graduated from college magna cum laude, a Barbie doll with brains, perhaps, and she was determined to morph her daughter into a junior version.Faction is a documentary containing a huge amount of information. Author James Kolar, a  former police officer, plays his hunches, his instincts and he sees red flags everywhere.  He opens the book with a pastiche- four intruders with a grudge against John Ramsey, sneak into his house on Christmas night, their prey JonBenet, and one of them the Monster does unspeakable things to the little girl. This scenario is not out of line with many theories and speculations concerning the death of this child who has achieved a ghastly sort of fame.Kolar pokes his bloodhound's nose into every crevice concerning this remarkable case and you, the reader, feel comfortable with him. He follows his hunches. He sees red flags everywhere. He takes you by the hand and  propels you into the drama and you will come away with enough information for you to easily navigate the interior of the Ramsey house if you were suddenly to land there. He  shows that the Ramseys-  eys. That John's money, and influence  bought him a reprieve from the District Attorney Mary Lacy who astoundingly put into writing in a letter to John that she believed the Ramseys totally innocent of the death of JonBenet. The Ramseys and their lawyers barricaded themselves from the Boulder police department which they scorned. When you consider that defense attorneys charge $500 AN HOUR and that John Ramsey kept a stable of them for years after his daughter's death, you realize what sort of financial ballpark he inhabits. Money talks and money is a deodorant.Author Kolar easily penetrates the coverup smokescreen John Ramsey created with an experienced policeman's cold hard facts. He is like Jack Webb who played Sergeant Friday on TV many years ago and always opined just the facts, Ma'am. He never actually accuses anyone as the murderer of JonBenet but he gives you enough evidence- psychological, and factual- for you to point your finger at the  perpetrator yourself. I think the person is obvious, but some other readers disagree with my choice.It is highly recommended that you read the incredibly varied and intelligent comments made by readers of  the Foreign Faction reviews here on Amazon.You will learn a  lot about polygraphs and how they operate and the fine nuances of a stun gun and what one does to human flesh as well as many interesting procedures accompanying a murder investigation. Faction is a page turner, a lesson in police procedures, a lesson into the complexity of human nature. But not a lesson in justice because poor little JonBenet did not receive justice.

I received Mastermind and PAS free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review, which I am delighted to provide for these very effective products. It should be noted that the two Zahler compounds- Mastermind and PAS- were taken together. Both can be taken separately, and they are effective separately, but together they seem to be synergistic or they may simply pack a double punch. Certainly they cover the bases for physical and mental health.The beautifully packaged Mastermind is pure serendipity. You can't help judging a book by its cover as you open the box. You virtually never see a superior product packaged in an ugly or boring container. You realize at once that Zahler is proud of this offering and  they tweak you a bit by including  a handsome embroidered Zahler baseball cap.There are a great many types of depression other than grief, a normal emotion which time will alleviate. I am a very old lady, 85, with all my marbles, but have been afflicted all my adult life  with a miasma of depression that settles down and covers me like a cowl. My problem is not manic-depression as there is no up swing. The miasma can hit any time and any place with no warning and no reason. Because it doesn't appear to be triggered by any life event the cause is elusive, but my instinct is it's metabolic. I looked for help and found Zahler, a caring company with superior compounds for both mental and physical health.If you look at the ingredients in Mastermind you will notice they include very large amounts of Vitamin B6 and B12. Four caplets a day are recommended. When I researched this I found there is good reason. Studies have shown low body levels of B12 may be associated with Alzheimer's and actual shrinkage of the brain and people over 50, some 20% of them, may have a borderline deficiency because they can't absorb enough of the vitamin (mostly found in meats). Vegetarians are at risk (but I am not one). I don't have Alzheimer's either, but I'm WAY over 50.  Not enough B12 can result in mood swings, depression and lethargy. The Harvard Medical School calls a B12 deficiency sneaky and harmful.B12 gives you physical, emotional and mental energy.PAS is not intended as a vitamin supplement, although it contains A, C and E. It is actually a polynutrient which plugs in where your multivitamin supplement leaves off by providing the strengths of highly selected botanicals.  Two of these herbs are Valerian and Rhodiola. Valerian root  has been used for centuries to combat insomnia and stress. The Greeks knew Rhodiola as an antidepressant, the Vikings took it for strength and stamina, the Chinese called it the golden root. and took it, probably, for everything.So how did an old lady of 85 respond to Mastermind and PAS? You may think any supplement for someone that old would be like putting a sugar coating around a pill. OK, I walk with a cane, but fast. My mind has never been sharper and I am in my element designing tee shirts. BUT, as I mentioned earlier I am susceptible to crippling depression and I am arthritic enough to make getting up from a chair a production. I spend hours at my computer with the consequence that I can hardly get up.I did not expect this: about six hours  after taking my first two Mastermind capsules and two PAS capsules  I was able to pull myself out of the chair with comparative ease and I seem to be infused with new energy. Whether this amazing result is the consequence of taking both products or one or the other it is impossible to tell.  This would be easy enough to prove by taking just one to see what happens but I am loath to do this. Because if it  ain't broke don't fix it. That same night my arthritic shoulders which had made turning over in bed painful, were not hurting.Today (day 2 with Mastermind and PAS) I had enough energy to vacuum the carpets, a chore I had put off much too long. If you've never seen an elderly lady whizzing around with a vacuum cleaner, come on over!Now for the depression. I am on a level keel at the present. I am not running down the hall singing the Hallelujah chorus (although I should be if my arthritis is actually zapped);  however, I am not down. In the middle. This mood is perfectly acceptable and may approach a normal state of mind. I don't expect to ever achieve a state of Nirvana, but maybe I will down the road, once or twice.Mastermind and PAS in tandem do nice things for me. Yes, they are expensive but not nearly as pricey as psychiatrists and physicians. Everything is relative. Highly recommended.

I received Mastermind and PAS free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review, which I am delighted to provide for these very effective products. It should be noted that the two Zahler compounds- Mastermind and PAS- were taken together. Both can be taken separately, and they are effective separately, but together they seem to be synergistic or they may simply pack a double punch. Certainly they cover the bases for physical and mental health.The beautifully packaged Mastermind is pure serendipity. You can't help judging a book by its cover as you open the box. You virtually never see a superior product packaged in an ugly or boring container. You realize at once that Zahler is proud of this offering and  they tweak you a bit by including  a handsome embroidered Zahler baseball cap.There are a great many types of depression other than grief, a normal emotion which time will alleviate. I am a very old lady, 85, with all my marbles, but have been afflicted all my adult life  with a miasma of depression that settles down and covers me like a cowl. My problem is not manic-depression as there is no up swing. The miasma can hit any time and any place with no warning and no reason. Because it doesn't appear to be triggered by any life event the cause is elusive, but my instinct is it's metabolic. I looked for help and found Zahler, a caring company with superior compounds for both mental and physical health.If you look at the ingredients in Mastermind you will notice they include very large amounts of Vitamin B6 and B12. Four caplets a day are recommended. When I researched this I found there is good reason. Studies have shown low body levels of B12 may be associated with Alzheimer's and actual shrinkage of the brain and people over 50, some 20% of them, may have a borderline deficiency because they can't absorb enough of the vitamin (mostly found in meats). Vegetarians are at risk (but I am not one). I don't have Alzheimer's either, but I'm WAY over 50.  Not enough B12 can result in mood swings, depression and lethargy. The Harvard Medical School calls a B12 deficiency sneaky and harmful.B12 gives you physical, emotional and mental energy.PAS is not intended as a vitamin supplement, although it contains A, C and E. It is actually a polynutrient which plugs in where your multivitamin supplement leaves off by providing the strengths of highly selected botanicals.  Two of these herbs are Valerian and Rhodiola. Valerian root  has been used for centuries to combat insomnia and stress. The Greeks knew Rhodiola as an antidepressant, the Vikings took it for strength and stamina, the Chinese called it the golden root. and took it, probably, for everything.So how did an old lady of 85 respond to Mastermind and PAS? You may think any supplement for someone that old would be like putting a sugar coating around a pill. OK, I walk with a cane, but fast. My mind has never been sharper and I am in my element designing tee shirts. BUT, as I mentioned earlier I am susceptible to crippling depression and I am arthritic enough to make getting up from a chair a production. I spend hours at my computer with the consequence that I can hardly get up.I did not expect this: about six hours  after taking my first two Mastermind capsules and two PAS capsules  I was able to pull myself out of the chair with comparative ease and I seem to be infused with new energy. Whether this amazing result is the consequence of taking both products or one or the other it is impossible to tell.  This would be easy enough to prove by taking just one to see what happens but I am loath to do this. Because if it  ain't broke don't fix it. That same night my arthritic shoulders which had made turning over in bed painful, were not hurting.Today (day 2 with Mastermind and PAS) I had enough energy to vacuum the carpets, a chore I had put off much too long. If you've never seen an elderly lady whizzing around with a vacuum cleaner, come on over!Now for the depression. I am on a level keel at the present. I am not running down the hall singing the Hallelujah chorus (although I should be if my arthritis is actually zapped);  however, I am not down. In the middle. This mood is perfectly acceptable and may approach a normal state of mind. I don't expect to ever achieve a state of Nirvana, but maybe I will down the road, once or twice.Mastermind and PAS in tandem do nice things for me. Yes, they are expensive but not nearly as pricey as psychiatrists and physicians. Everything is relative. Highly recommended.

I showed the new Dimore Boys Boxer Brief underwear (although the label states E.T.X. underwear they are the same as pictured) to my 4 year old and he immediately took off his shorts and underwear and put a pair of these on!  The manufacturer thankfully sizes them based on age so you dont have to decide whether or not a 4T or 5T is the right choice.  This set is labelled for 4-5 year olds and fits perfectly.They are made of 95% cotton and 5% polyester and feel very soft.  According to my son, they feel very comfortable and cozy.  There is a pouch sewn into the front for added comfort and support which is a nice, quality touch.  The set we received contains 5 pairs in a variety of stylish colors.  All of the seams and stitching are perfect.  They look like high end adult underwear.The one drawback to these is the manufacturers label which is sewn into the outer left thigh area.  The description for these underwear states,  and he loves that there are no scratchy tags.  This is misleading because I inferred that there are no tags; perhaps they meant the tags they have sewn into the product are not scratchy?  Maybe the E.T.X. version have tags and the Dimore do not?  This may cause some irritation down the road but well have to wait and see.  If so, Ill just remove them.Overall, these underwear are luxurious and well-constructed for a young boy.  My son certainly feels very comfortable in them and refuses to take them off for their first laundering which is a good sign!--Gina Meyer

What is great about the Soundpeats A1 Bluetooth 4.1 Headphones is that they are very comfortable. Im one of those who hates headphones as a rule, just because they are uncomfortable and inconvenient, but these are great - soft and cushion-y.These are Bluetooth headphones meaning that they are WIRELESS!! No more getting all tangled when trying to listen. I didnt have high expectations for the sound quality given the price of these but I am pleasantly surprised, and they charge fully in about an hour. Also, the are easy enough to pair up  I just turned the Bluetooth on on my iPhone and despite it having several other devices synced to it, it still found the headphones in just a few seconds.  They do have a cord so I can use them while plugged in if my Bluetooth goes down or I dont have a full charge  its great to have these options.--Victoria Franks

The Tailgaterz Cool-N-Carry Cooler is so perfect for taking all the snacks you need for your next tailgating party but more importantly (for a mom of two littles!) for transporting groceries and shopping items without everything spilling over in the trunk, while keeping cold items cold for the trip home!  This cooler features a foldable cooler that keeps beverages and snacks organized, four mesh pockets that provide added storage space, a cooler compartment that is supposed to stay cool for 12 hours (I haven't tested that yet!), a favorite feature of a folding design to make storage easier, and finally, an adjustable shoulder strap that makes it easier to transport into the house!  I love this well-built addition to my trunk!--Victoria Franks

Sherpa fleece is not from a lamb (thank goodness) but a man made polyester fabric than is even softer than lamb's wool and feels like lamb's wool to the touch. The Sherpa nubby side is on the bottom, the printed side on top is as soft as velvet. This blanket-throw is just plain luxurious.The name Sherpa comes from the ethnic people of Nepal,  but any mountain guide in the Himalayas is referred to as a Sherpa even if he is not technically of the ethnic group. There are 2,5000 genuine Sherpas in New York City, amazingly. A skyscaper in place of Everest?All our family are rabid Anglophiles and everybody wanted the Union Jack. The colors are simply brilliant. The throw is very light, and although very warm it is not burdensome. Our cats found the throw right away where it was draped over the couch arm. We (humans and kitties) are 100% enthusiastic. Hail Britannia!

While this is a decent clipper set for the home, it is definitely not a professional clipping/grooming set and the price is a bit high for what you get.  These pet hair clippers are a pretty basic set and they have 4 attachments. The unit seems pretty solidly constructed (made in China) and includes an A/C cable. I do have to say that they are very loud!  It has a blade adjustment lever and comes with a little cleaning brush and all of it comes in a black plastic carrying case.  I have 2 small dogs (well one is medium sized) and I had to go over the dogs a couple of times to get their hair off. I didn't expect professional quality, so with that in mind it's decent enough for how I groom my dogs at home.--Victoria Franks

Some years ago I went to the Hollywood Bowl to see Zubin Mehta conduct the LA Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra. I couldn't take my eyes off Mehta who is a rather small man off stage  but he becomes a Titan on the podium. I felt that he was drawing forth from each member of the orchestra beautiful music by osmosis. That symbiosis between a conductor and his musicians, between a corporate executive and his company is what this interesting and provocative book is all about. Author Itay Talgam is both an orchestra conductor and a conductor of people, a guru for executives and corporations. The goal is the most beautiful music possible or the greatest achievements possible, and the hearts of all the players whether on Wall Street or Carnegie must be in the enterprise.A conductor is a virile, iconic symbol of leadership but a great maestro is not an autocrat. Whether a man is on a podium or in a director's chair, author Talgam  explores and defines  the nuances necessary to bring out the best performance in musicians or the fellow members of a corporation. An orchestra is not a place for prima donnas but every person whether a first violin or the guy that tinkles the triangle has to be imbued with enthusiasm, even eagerness and ambition to do his best not for glory to himself but glory to the whole.An executive has to allow for creative freedom in his group. He is the boss but he must supply his underlings with enthusiasm by letting them come forth with their own ideas. Passion is a big factor here. A violinist must play the proper notes but how he wrenches the tones issuing from his instrument is his to discover and make his own. But he is contributing to the whole, the glorious sound of a great orchestra.In between a conductor's baton and the members of an orchestra there is a gap. There is a gap, really, between all people. The maestro or the corporation CEO fills this gap by listening. The members of each may have great ideas, suggestions and sheer talent and the maestro or boss must have his ear to the ground. This is definitely a two way street. Neither the executive nor the conductor is in isolation on a pinnacle. Harmony can only prevail when everybody is allowed to do his thing. Not playing any old note, of course, but coaxing his instrument, being a dynamic member of a corporation group.Author Talgam explores the style of six world-class conductors. The approach in each case is how each maestro controls and yet inspires his players. It is helpful to run these famous musicians through Google to witness their performance on the podium. You can check out Arturo Toscanini temper tantrums (all bark and no bite), The six conductors are Riccardo Muti (autocratic but he pulls forth glorious music from his orchestra); the emotional and passionate Arturo Toscanini; the sedate Richard Strauss; the aristocratic Herbert von Karajan; the incredibly agile Carlos Kleiber; the charismatic, handsome Leonard Bernstein.The title  The ignorant Maestro bothers me just a bit- it's that word ignorant. Certainly any executive, conductor or entrepreneur will find many gaps between himself and his players, areas in which  he has to fill in and even embrace because hidden in those gaps may be superb talent, a wealth of ideas, cutting edge originality.  But ignorant implies to me a lack of education not a lack of understanding, a lack of information of his group. But I won't belabor the point. The book is highly original, and Talman appears as a very knowledgeable and likable guy with plenty of talent to spare.The bottom line here is that when the players on a stage- any players, any stage- give up on self expression, when the joy of discovery and creativity have been buried by routine a vital element has disappeared. And somehow when I see a conductor raise his baton to signal the start of a piece, I am irresistibly reminded of Charlton Heston as Moses raising his staff and parting the Red Sea. Perhaps Moses and the conductor and the CEO are all part of the same thing.

I received a free sample in return for writing an unbiased review.You can't judge a book by its cover (but everybody does including me). The attractive packaging of any item is to me paramount to my decision to buy the item. These BodyVega Omega-3 fish oil capsules come in a nice-looking bottle in blue and chartreuse colors and the ingredients are very clearly stated on the back. The bottle itself is very smooth, fitting your hand nicely. Good packaging gives the product CLASS.  (I know you are laughing at me but that's OK).Now, about the performance in a serving which is two soft gels containing 800 mg of EPA and 600 mg of DHA. Other reviewers have written excellent reviews comparing the ingredients of Omega 3 capsules to other fish oil brands and relating their own experiences using the gels. It can be said that Body Vega fish oil capsules are power-packed. In my experience there is no after taste whatever and no lemon flavor, not even when gulped down with hot coffee at breakfast.There is an enormous amount of research concerning the efficacy of fish oil. I have taken it for years but this is my first bottle of Body Vega. I didn't start seeing miracles with Body Vega- the miracles have really already occurred. Peering at the monitor all day while designing tee shirts and other items wreaks havoc with my eyes without a fish oil supplement. I am 85 years old and with all older people arthritis is a big problem. In my case the shoulders are the worst hit, making turning in bed a nightmare. Fish oil is a huge help, in fact it is so helpful to me that I am awed.BodyVega Fish Oil appears to be a superior supplement based on what other people have said and although my experience with this brand is short I will stick with BodyVega. This brand is number one, the biggest fish oil supplement on Amazon. It appears to be a power-house and its efficacy is backed up by other reviewers and the manufacturer as well.  Maybe because we all evolved from creatures in the sea  our bodies are very amenable to fish oil. The solution is very simple: two capsules a day and you're off and running or maybe I should say swimming. And your brain may benefit, too. Take it from a very old lady:  if fish oil can help a person like me, think what it can do for you!

Wolf Hall is a highly intelligent, superbly nuanced adaptation of Hilary Mantel's stunning book. The film is not a study in extremes such as black and white, good and evil, but a subtle study in shades of grey. It embraces the underbelly of the Tudor Court where the mechanics of  governing the country grind.The atmosphere of England in sixteenth century of Wolf Hall is wonderfully embracing,  The ambiance will take you right in. The dark, gloomy nights lit only by candlelight almost make you want to watch your back, in the gloom an enemy could be lurking right there, behind the drape. In the daytime no sunshine enters the small windows and outside the sun does not sparkle, the shadows are misty. Wolf Hall is never exuberant. The camera often follows a person from the rear-in a dark cape he may like a crow. It is interesting that the back of an individual speaks as much as the front- the position of the hands, the tilt of the neck,  a rapid or slow gait, even the mood...I have never seen a camera perform this trick so often. In one scene it follows Cromwell and a crony, both dressed in black riding on dark brown horses. Sort of a sea in darkness on a bleak day. I know there is a metaphor here and I ponder it.Mark Rylance as Thomas Cromwell brings a great deal of nuance into the role, his dark eyes always watchful. He is not inscrutable, the thin mouth often hovering in the ghost of a smile as he goes about performing his tasks as principal minister to Henry VIII. He is immensely likable and if the real Thomas Cromwell was not likable it matters not.  Who are we to say? The plot revolves around him and you see him tete a tete with many famous sixteenth century characters. I read that there are 102 characters in the series- they fit seamlessly into the story because a master hand, is directing them.Claire Foy is perfect as Anne Boleyn, capturing her brittleness, her bravado.
