She is obliged to walk a tight rope controlled by Henry and she is fully aware that if she doesn't produce a son her life as Queen is over. Her distress is palpable but she takes great pains to conceal it, often acting haughty.Thomas Wolsey like Thomas Cromwell hasn't been treated kindly by history and usually appears greedy and self-serving and yet he earned his accumulation of wealth including a palace,  as rewards for his services to Henry. Jonathan Pryce as the Cardinal, like the film portrayal of Thomas Cromwell, is a well rounded personality, sensitive and loyal to the King. But he cannot convince the Pope to declare the marriage between Henry and Katherine of Aragon  annulled.  And so Henry VIII pulls the plug and the Cardinal is stripped of earthly glory. You see him at the end of his life shuffling slowly along, his red robe no longer a symbol of power. You feel for him.Damian Lewis makes a fine King Henry with his (genuine) red beard, his aristocratic mien, his arrogance, his mercurial temper, his power. He often has a diabolic grin on his face that is close to snarling. When Henry is on stage, metaphorically speaking, nobody else is. He is the magnet that draws all attention. However, in one amusing scene Henry falls asleep at the dinner table. There is an immediate hush as none of the diners dares to wake him for fear of a reprisal. Finally a girl taps his arm and Henry comes to, remarking he has just been resting his eyes, and all is well, but the relief around the table is palpable. When Henry is present the air seems electric, wired, almost turbulent.Although a small role, that of Mary Boleyn, Anne's sister, gives  the story piquancy and charm. And as Mary actress Charity Wakefield with her snub nose and mischievous smile often banters with Cromwell. She has been dumped by Henry VIII who saw a better catch in Anne Boleyn, but Mary is relieved to be off the royal hook, she laughs at Anne and she likes Cromwell. Plenty of chemistry between the two even if it comes to naught.One very important aspect of Wolf Hall is the character and portrayal of Thomas More, who was made a saint by the Catholic Church in 1940. Hilary Mantel is an outspoken anti-Catholic and More (played ably by Anton Lesser) becomes in the film adaptation of the book a cruel, hypocritical prig who actually enjoys attending burnings at the stake of Protestant heretics. While historically More has been regarded as somewhat of a hero in his courageous stand against Henry's divorce and Cromwell has the reputation of a villain, both men were creatures of their time and behaved as such and neither could be called scrupulous. Whatever the reader's feelings are on this subject, it is best to let sleeping dogs lie and enjoy this splendid series for what it is: a very fine drama

This laptop review will be more of a high level review from the point of an "average" user, not a technophile. I was very impressed immediately upon opening the box.  This laptop appears to be very sturdy.  The case feels like it can take the abuse of being carried around in daily use in less than the ideal home or office environment.  I was leery of the design of the swivel screen, but upon inspection and using it for a while, I am very happy with it.  It is well built and offers a wide range of uses.  Since this laptop is really a laptop/tablet combination, the swivel screen can be placed in whatever position the user wants - traditional laptop configuration, as an easel, or fully flat in the table mode. I am also impressed with battery life.  My past experience with laptops has been that, if they lasted 4 - 5 hours, I was lucky.  This laptop has exceeded 8 hours in my usage so far, and the battery monitor indicated over 10 hours available when fully charged. Since this unit comes with Windows 8.1, which most new computers are loaded with, I won't address the software aspects.  I'm also not a fan of Windows 8.1. I wasn't sure I would use the touchscreen much in the laptop mode, but I find myself using it more and more, especially when I have the screen in an easel configuration.  The touchscreen is easy to use, not overly sensitive, and very convenient. I find that I use it especially when I'm using a web browser.  It's much easier to use when scrolling the screen than using the touch-pad.  The keyboard is the standard layout, of course, and is comfortable to use.  The keys, once one is pressed, have a back-light that lights up the perimeter of them with a soft blue light.  The touch-pad is also pretty much standard fare and works quite well. One of the technical features I really like is that this unit uses solid state devices (SSD) instead of a hard disk.  This results in amazingly fast boot-up times as well as fast operation for any function that requires typical disk drive operations.  There are three USB ports, two USB 3.0 and one USB 2.0. There is also an HDMI port, and SD card reader, and a combination mic/headphone jack. Overall, I am very satisfied with this laptop/touch-pad computer and highly recommend it to others.  It is versatile, fun to use, has long battery life, and is sturdy.Ports include two USB 3.0 ports, one USB 2.0 port and an HDMI port. You'll also find an SD card reader and a combination headphone/mic jack.  - See more at: http://www.laptopmag.com/reviews/laptops/acer-aspire-r-13#sthash.2QNuF29F.dpufRoger Meyer

I was very surprised at the negative reviews for this fine production. Some reviewers complained that the series was like a stage play. It is, but that fact in no way mars the quality. I have to say up front that I am deaf and require the closed cc's  but it is easy to follow the plot. using the captions I can't  judge the quality of the voice  acting. However the ccs are perfectly synchronized with the speech which is not always the case.The casting  and costuming of the various characters is spot on. Aside from the major players it is easy to recognize Cromwell, Cranmer, Woolsey and even the Duke of Norfolk. The production accurately brings to the viewer Henry's six wives in all their agonies and ecstasies. A great deal of research was required and Henry VIII's court as it appears in this series is a reflection of the real thing. You are there. Highly recommended.

I received the Nerf Rebelle Super Soaker Tri Threat squirt crossbow today and my 4 year old son couldnt wait for me to free it from its packaging.Although it is obviously marketed toward a female target market he didnt seem to notice; it has a blue stock and the other colors are neutral orange, white, and dark purple.  Besides, its a CROSSBOW, what boy wouldnt love to have a crossbow that shoots water?  If you are purchasing this for a girl, she will certainly enjoy it.The suggested minimum age is 6; however, my 4 year old had no problem operating this weapon of mass hydration.  Instead of a traditional trigger, this reimagined squirt gun employs a pump-style mechanism at the front to deploy its liquid bolts.  I appreciate the pump design because as a boy I routinely wore the skin off of my trigger finger on my primitive squirt guns.  My son was able to shoot this device effectively whereas with some other squirt guns his fingers arent strong enough to pull the triggers.This squirt crossbow has a novel feature of 3 simultaneous streams of water.  I was skeptical about the distance it would shoot due to the limited range of motion of the pump mechanism but it gets the job done and shoots quite a distance.  The center stream is definitely more powerful than the two side streams but the overall result is the same:  you will thoroughly soak your enemy.Overall, it is well-built, feels comfortable to hold, survives inevitable drops, shoots far, and is priced reasonably.  The only drawback is if you are on the receiving end, you will be soaked with one blast.-  Matt Meyer

"The Tudors" is gorgeous, exciting, a feast for the senses. However I have a major problem: I cannot  visualize Henry VIII without his trade mark red hair, a sort of Tudor beacon that he passed on to his daughter Elizabeth.The series wrenches history a bit- for instance Henry's sister Margaret did not marry the King of Portugal, but the King of Scotland and she became the grandmother of Mary Queen of Scots. Cardinal Wolsey did not commit suicide although he may have wanted to. There are other historical wrenches but if you are not an historical purist, these irregularities won't dampen your enthusiasm and enjoyment for the series.Jonathan Rhys Meyers is handsome, viril, and dynamic but to me he is not Henry VIII but an actor playing the part very competently but through a glass darkly. Catherine of Aragon does not  sartorially do much better. Catherine, the real Catherine, was not swarthy with dark hair, she was fair with light brown hair. In fact she was much nearer the  physical ideal for a woman in the sixteenth century than the raven haired Anne Boleyn.I loved this series, especially the jousting and the wonderful panoramas of the lushly green English countryside. But I am giving the series four stars, not five because Henry VIII, although character-wise was authentic has to be auburn-haired. The emperor's new clothes simply do not fit the real Henry VIII.

The shower caddy is perfect for all of my girly shower supplies because of all of the mesh which allows everything to dry out.  I've decided that it will be used to organize all of my lotions, scrubs, mani/pedi supplies and body butters.  It's small enough to haul around but still has enough pockets and storage for all of my beauty supply needs.  It's a great little caddy!--Victoria Franks

The Mengo S-Power solar backup battery is a very clever, rugged device.  It can charge up to two cell phones at once via dual USB connectors.  The manufacturer says that only one tablet should be charged at a time though.  The indicator lights provide a four point level of charge indication for the internal battery.  To recharge the device, you have a couple options.  It will charge when placed in sunlight, but it is a slow process. Just place it in the sun and a green LED will illuminate indicating that it is in solar charge mode.  The manufacturer says that only about 1/8 of full charge is input per day, however, so it is a slow process.  It would be a good way to keep it "topped off," however.  The best way to recharge it is to connect a power source (phone charger, computer, etc) via the micro-USB connector port.  A short USB to micro-USB cable is provided with the unit.  Also provided is a carabiner for attaching the unit to belt loops, backpacks, etc.  The unit is advertised as being resistant to some water such as rainfall, splashing, etc, but not submersion in water. While I haven't had this device for a very long time, I can see it as being a handy battery charger for those times when you forget to recharge your phone, have been away from a charging source longer than you had planned, or in emergency situations.  It is reasonably priced, conveniently sized, rugged, and attractive in appearance.--Roger Meyer

I wanted these to see if my child would notice a difference, but she seemed to not notice any cool alert at all. I also thought they seemed to hold a little bit less than the regular pull ups. Maybe they will work for some children, but for mine there was no difference, so I decided to stick with the regular pull ups. I have seen some reviews of  them being too cold & some of them not being cold enough, so I guess the designers must have made changes, but in my experience the cold  simply hasn't  been enough.--Victoria Franks

The biggest disappointment I have with this entertaining  group of essays is the fact that the rich eccentrics are not named*. But Kirshenbaum is loyal and he protects them. Even evidence like a painting hanging in a mansion is not attributed to the artist. There are hints but I couldn't guess who any of the disguised people are maybe because my situation as a church mouse is practically on a different planet. The book is not an expose nor is it titillating. The super-rich are not funny, they are quirky. The playing field of  Old Money versus  nouveau riche has leveled as Old Money felt themselves getting stale, getting submerged in fuddy-duddyism, perhaps and therefore welcomed the Nouveaus into their hallowed halls. Not many years ago the Nouveaus were considered vulgar parvenus. Not any more according to the author.One interesting discussion involves the very posh and their sense of entitlement. Aside from royalty only the super rich feel entitled. You can be a famous artist or music composer or writer and not feel the world is your oyster. It is the very wealthy who believe the world revolves around them. Their teenage kids have been brought up believing in their superior status, that their money opens all the doors.  Family chauffeurs  are often delegated to being nannies for these rich kids, getting them home if they have passed out in a night club or have committed some another social gaffe. The drivers, many of whom are ex-cops, know how to beat the system in getting their young masters out of trouble. Money talks.The author seems to have a permanent pass into the lives of the moneyed class and his descriptions of the elegant  dinners he has with the money crowd will get you drooling as you read, even if you (like me) haven't  a clue as to what some entrees are: malazania parmigiana; hijicki salad washed down with Sancerre; gigande beans. Your tastebuds are telling you something even if you don't know quite what and you will end up starving when you finish the book.The best dressed persons among the privileged are men, not women, and they are Italian. With these guys a suit is a way of life. They are part Casanova, part hockey stars. Nobody can lounge around the way a slinky well-dressed Italian can. For women looking chic is a huge on-going battle. Getting an appointment with her eyebrow lady is like getting an audience with the pope. Their hair must be salon blown EVERY day except maybe Sunday. When you are super-rich you must look the part, even subsisting on lettuce or kale to keep elegantly thin.Is there a downside to being a member of the 1% club? One father complained that he was an invisible ATM since the minute he walked in the door his wife and daughters would all start clamoring for something expensive. Whether the filthy rich are happy is a point to ponder although I imagine it is better to be unhappy rich than unhappy poor. Some of the disguised characters in the book appear reasonably exuberant, but not all. Some appear just plain disgruntled.And so author Kirshenbaum cheerfully wends his way between the watering holes of his well-heeled friends and acquaintances. He himself emerges from the pages of Isn't that rich?as very likable. He is the perfect fly on the wall, but a discrete fly.* I am reminded of Truman Capote who had been a pet of the very rich and very famous, circulating freely among them. Extremely unwisely he decided to put into print juicy gossip about them. He had betrayed their trust and they all dropped him like a hot potato. I don't think he ever recovered.

I haven't had a chance to try this blade yet, but based on inspection and reading of the claims, it appears to be incredibly "universal" in that is supposedly fits a wide variety of oscillating tools. Based on some other reviewers, however, it seems that a few, at least, had some minor difficulties in fitting and/or securing the blade.  I would like to think that when the manufacturer claims the blade will fit on a particular brand of tool, that they have actually tried it and found it to be a successful fit. The difficulties could arise, perhaps, from minor changes made over the years and/or different models offered by the same manufacturer. I noticed that this blade has a unique "set" to the teeth that will help with use on wood that should prevent burning by removing sawdust that one reviewer complained about with other blades, but not this one.This blade is an economical alternative to some pricier blades and "should" fit most tools, it the claims are true. The manufacturer also offers several styles of blades for different applications.--Roger Meyer

This card is an economical way to go for your smart phone, tablet, camera, or any device utilizing a micro SD card.  While another reviewer claimed its transfer speed is slower than competitors, I can't verify that claim.  I don't know how to measure that speed, but I suppose "there's an app for that," or something.  I'm not too concerned with that feature because it seems plenty fast to me when transferring photos on my phone to my desktop computer. I think we are sometimes spoiled by our gadgets and always want the latest, fastest, lightest, etc., when many times "good enough" is good enough - and definitely more economical.  Maybe I'm just slowing down in my old age.In summary, this card is economical and serves the purpose for which it is intended.  Time will tell, however, whether the quality is there that ensures this device a long life.--Roger Meyer

This sleek black scanner is a cinch to set up and many of the commands can be done from your computer screen. A CD is included which installs the drives and command modules. I like particularly that creating a PDF is one of the options.  If you just want to scan without a printer or fax attached it's the way to go. The scanned copies are sharp and true to color and you can direct the machine to store them where you like, in my case in My Documents.

I received the Adonit Mini Precision Disc Jot stylus and was immediately impressed by its overall design.  It looks sleek, stylish, and functional.  I proceeded to use it with my Samsung Galaxy S5 in my favorite drawing game, Draw Something, and was finally able to draw the finer details my fingers have been unable to.The device is constructed of lightweight aluminum and the writing point is centered in a clear disk which helps to properly position the point in the same plane as the writing/drawing surface.  The disk also fully rotates to accommodate any writing position.  The diameter of the shaft is sized properly and fits comfortably in my fingers.  I appreciate that it isn't large like other styli; it unobtrusively fits in my pocket.  The device also comes with a screw-on protective lid which screws onto the opposite end to prevent losing it--nice touch. It works as advertised and I am pleased with the results it gave me.  I look forward to using it anytime a fine touch is required.  Overall, very satisfied with this product.--Matt Meyer

Death ex machina is derived from the Latin deus ex machina. Death or god from the machine has evolved as a plot device meaning an obtuse problem is abruptly resolved by the intervention of a new event, character, ability or object. (Wiki). In the novel it is a double entendre as a death literally occurs aboard a crane like machine used to lift the actor high above the stage.Gary Corby takes you back to 485 BCE during the Golden Age of Pericles where you will feel quite comfortable. Conversations are in the modern vernacular and it's easy to imagine the characters speaking in the Greek vernacular. There are many descriptions of various ancient Greek activities and methods that are not only interesting but most certainly authentic, such the tortuous manner in which a surgeon sets a broken bone and the molten beeswax an artist uses to prepare a wall for a fresco-like painting.  A device which plays a central role in the plot is a unique hoisting machine which  grabs an actor playing a god and suspends him high above the stage as though on Mount Olympus.There are many touches of humor and you can imagine Sophocles or Socrates slapping his leg and guffawing. Sophocles and Socrates are among the famous characters which are seamlessly woven into the novel and of course Aeschylus the playwright is included as this is a novel centered around the theater.A  huge festival, the Great Dionysia, is about to convene with thousands of people from all the Greek provinces on their way, expecting a series of stage plays honoring Dionysus, the god of wine. But a taint hovers over the city-a murder on stage under the watchful eye of the god. Dionysos will not be mollified until the killer is apprehended. The actors and stage hands of the theater think that a ghost is loose when strange things begin to happen like accidents which escalate into a murder. Husband and wife detectives Nico and Diotima are employed by Pericles to investigate and find the assassin but quick as the crime must be solved before the festival begins.  The people are literally at the gates of Athens, a great mass of revelers moving exorbitantly towards the city.The novel is funny, with plenty of suspense and it's interesting, too. You will learn a lot about ancient Greece. In fact the parts I liked the best in the book were purely descriptive, such as word pictures of  a sleek ship manned by three tiers of rowers on each side . The Salaminia was the fastest boat in all the world.Death ex Machina is a good read, original and fast-moving. Although it is part of a series it is not necessary to have read the previous volumes. The book can easily stand on its own.

After reading the former review "If you don't mind the assembly" I turned chicken and ran for the nearest man  to help a helpless old lady (85). The nightstand weighs 38 pounds and after struggling to get it in the door I decided this nightstand and I were not going to tango. My handyman- inclined friend made me feel somewhat mollified by remarking the stand wasn't all that simple to assemble. However all is well and it is now sitting next to my bed where it will hold books under the drawer and in the drawer odds and ends for late night reading, pencils for making notes for reviews, granola bars, a notebook or two and even a hair dryer and curlers.The nightstand is handsome, grey in color,  quite distinctive, the cloth pattern on the drawer a nice touch. Bravo to the other reviewer for heroically putting her stand together herself. No heroics here but all's well that ends well, and we both have our nightstands performing nicely as a handsome piece of furniture and perhaps a catchall.. Cheers!

My initial intent for this SSD was to use it as a secondary drive, which I did.  Very satisfied with its performance.  Much faster, as expected, than my old HDD.  I have an older Dell Dimension E521 (amazing what we consider old when it comes to electronic products and computers!) and will eventually clone my primary drive to achieve faster boot times and to increase storage space.  Based on what others have said in the reviews, I would expect a MAJOR reduction of boot time.  As my older system has lots of programs that start on boot up, I am looking forward to the decreased boot time.  This drive is easy to install and (obviously) quiet since there are no moving parts.  Predicted life span and not hearing those typical warning sounds of impending HDD failure is something to look forward to also. In summary, this SSD is an amazing product that for not much money, you can increase performance, reduce boot time, add lots of storage space economically, and have a reasonable expectation of not having a sudden drive failure as with a HDD.  Great product for the money.--Roger Meyer

We did not know who Jerry Baird was, so we Googled him and found this former college professor has spent some thirty years  perfecting his gourmet spices by cooking for hungry Texas cowboys from a chuck wagon. And what is a chuck wagon?. a wagon carrying cooking facilities and food for serving people who work outdoors such as lumberjacks, and cowboys.  The cowboys in Texas have been Jerry Laird's guinea pigs as he concocted various herb and spice combinations  to liven up Tex-Mex food  which morphs into Tex Mex gourmet foods with Jerry's unique blends of  herbs and spices. You can put it on anything that ain't movin'. There are at present nine different seasoning combinations. We have the Jalapeno Sizzling Salt which can literally be sprinkled on anything that would be improved by a little Jalapeno pizzazz. Bear in mind this is a salt substitute- don't add table salt on top of it!  If you love those little green (and hot) peppers you'll love this seasoning without  being overwhelmed. It's particularly cool on bland vegetables such as cauliflower and Brussels sprouts and on top of a salad. Campfire cookery is just as much an authentic cuisine as Julia Child's French Chef. And it's made in America!

I used this bottle for the first time today by taking it to work.  I particularly like the diameter.  It's not too big and is very comfortable to hold.  The sealing mechanism is well designed and easy to use.  The cap pops open with a simple push of the button.  The opening button can be prevented from accidental opening by simple flipping up the locking bar. It is comfortable to drink from and water flows easily because of the air hole.  Both the air hole and the drinking spout seal easily by merely snapping the lid closed.  The carry strap is a handy addition which allows you to carry it with one finger, if you so choose.  Overall, it is attractive, easy and convenient to use, seals well, and comfortable to hold.  The only negative I would give it is the price point.  It seems a little high, but it is a quality bottle.  Highly recommended.-- Roger Meyer

These are very light weight, bunchable towels that easily fit in your gym bag or even your purse. The larger one covers my mat perfectly. The  towel microfiber is  soft and the member of our family appreciates it the most is our baby, Ellie, thirteen months old, who toddles over to it where it is sitting on the kitchen linoleum floor. She loves to do what I do so she uses some inventive baby style yoga positions after plunking herself down on the towel. She coos and strokes it.  Not to be out-maneuvered by a mere toddler our cat once joined her and soon was rolling around on his back. The bigger towel works very fine as a towel-towel for a quick dry after the shower. Well, our Athletec Sports Towel got a very nice reception by our family.  So if it's not on the floor it's hanging over the towel rack in the bathroom.We like the color, too- a deep blue with chartreuse lettering and trim.--Jean Browning

It is hard to judge the style of a novel that is translated, in this case from Italian but the prose is clear and purposeful; however, there are many cliches. The novel itself represents a great deal of research of pre- renaissance Italy and its powerful warmongering states but it is too long, with too many characters and the reader-at least this reader-got somewhat bogged down. Some of the characters talk like college professors and at length about the architecture of the cathedral among other things. There is too much unnecessary dialog and data in this novel which slows the plot.Italy itself in the fifteenth century was not a unified country but consisted of states vying for power and the most powerful state was Milan. The supreme ruler of Italy was the Catholic Church which held sway over all the states, however in Milan the church was infiltrated by Celts who had first come to Italy many years before. These Druids performed their rituals in deep secrecy, hidden away in  a subterranean cave near the cathedral which was in the process of being constructed. I checked with Google, having never heard of Druids practicing  alchemy and the magic arts anywhere in Milan, let alone Italy. Author Piazza is right: the Druids were a large presence. In the novel they built a temple "The Temple of Light" near the foundation of the cathedral, and their goddess was Belisama who  in the novel evolved and morphed into the Virgin Mary. The brotherhood are intriguers and deadly serious about ancient prophecies which must be fulfilled.The protagonist of the story is Niccolo, son of the deceased Duke of Milan, who demands on his deathbed that the Archdeacon Onorio bring up Niccolo in secret as his son as the Duke had many enemies and many might be tempted to kill the boy. Unknown to the Duke, Onorio is a Druid priest. As he grows up, Niccolo feels his calling as a sculptor and little by little practicing the craft on hunks of marble he morphs into an artist. Interwoven with his story are threads about the beautiful dark haired Lorenzo who is a paid killer and his sister Maria who had become an aristocrat's mistress but is discarded when convenient. The aristocracy is powerful and at times ruthless and at times cruel.  That might makes right was alive and well in fifteenth century Milan.And there is the chestnut-haired  Angelica with whom Niccolo falls in love, but he is noble and  she is a commoner. Angelica, Lorenzo and Maria are threaded through the novel and in Niccolo's life. There is a great deal of detail about the Druids, their philosophy, they are guardians of the Philosopher's Stone. They seek a temple with direct access to the Virgin Mary, a pillar of light. But there is too much on this plate. I felt I had to plow through endless detail to finally reach the end. The novel is erudite but needs lightening up. I feel rather guilty giving this novel three stars because it is obviously a huge undertaking, but author Piazza, who has great potential, needs an editor who can separate the grain from the chaff

Benjamin Percy.is a descriptive writer, rather a rarity these days with the popularity of he-man prose with no adjectives, the text an unadorned skeleton. The prose in this highly original thriller is beautiful. and sets you down into the plot where you feel belonged and part of the action.  Lewis Meriwether (formerly Meriwether Lewis of the Northwest Passage) Wilhelmina Clark (morphed into a girl from William Clark) along with a ragged survivors of a holocaust, a nuclear war that has flattened North America, eke out an existence in the Sanctuary. The Sanctuary is the  ruins of Saint Louis, the famous arch in shreds, the vestige of the city supporting a few survivors who have reverted to riding horses, killing the little game they can find with bows and arrows. The small population lives on the decaying ruins of Saint Louis and is coerced into obeying its leaders. Escape is ruthlessly suppressed. But rain rarely falls and the area is drying up.Creating a new wrinkle in the famous Lewis and Clark expedition which was sent by Thomas Jefferson to head West into unknown territory in 1804 is ingenious. In The Dead Lands after radiation  from  a nuclear holocaust and a flu epidemic have devastated North America the narrative compares the formidable dangers of slogging into the wilderness in 1804  with the present  formidable dangers of slogging into the nuclear radiation-ravaged Dead Lands. From out of nowhere a girl on horseback arrives at The Sanctuary. This young woman who will guide the small party West is Gawea, a modern edition of the famous Shoshone guide and interpreter Sacagawea* who married one of Lewis and Clark's expedition members. Gawea has come from Oregon, riding alone by horseback. She tells Lewis he is being summoned West by Aran Burr. A version of the arch-traitor? You the reader will not understand this until you reach the end of the book.Six people sneak out of the Sanctuary-Lewis Meriwether, Wilhelmina Mina Clark, a woman doctor, two young men, and Gawea. They must travel over a vast dead civilization, the mid-west remnants of America, with  horrid reminders and echoes such as a decrepit ferris wheel, children's skeletons in a bus, a  mummified body on a brass bed. They are attacked by man-sized white bats, horrible mutations and enormous white bears. Danger lurks under every leaf. The poor horses suffer from one catastrophe after another, they whicker and scream and drum their feet and die.In the meantime, back at the Sanctuary the remaining citizens of the city rail against the authoritarian rule of the mayor. Simon, a brash young man who is a thief (but lovable) and his girlfriend Ella are subjected to constant indignities and coercion  of a dictatorship where floggings and executions seem to be an everyday affair and where freedom does not exist. They learn of the adventures of the group that has gone West via a mechanical owl programmed by Lewis with a cavity inside for hiding letters. Ella and Simon face a great dilemma: should they also venture forth into the dangers or remain in relative safety in what is really a prison.Surely one of the hallmarks for a great science fiction or fantasy novel is its plausability.. Benjamin Percy's bone-chilling story in no way seems contrived as he seamlessly records the adventures of a latter day Lewis and Clark. One of the characters, John Colter, was a real member of the explorer team and is considered one of the first mountain men, an expert tracker at home in the wilderness. In the book he is a strange man who dressed in black and rode a black horse. A knight come riding in a way, but just as vulnerable physically and emotionally as the rest of the explorers.When the little ragged band reaches the Pacific they have suffered just about any indignity, hardship or physical pain possible. Some of their woes are self-inflicted, others the slings and arrows of enemies lurking everywhere. The voice of Aran Burr has beckoned the little troupe to the Pacific like a Siren. Aran Burr is a symbol- you will have your own interpretation based on the fact that Aaron Burr was thearch-traitor of the early, struggling America. The novel is really an allegory. It takes you to the frontier of the human soul. The greatest human emotion is love, which will conquer evil. Will the adventurers finally see in a glass face to face? The ending of the novel is stunning, delicious and exactly right.*In 2000 the US Mint issued a gold-plated dollar with a rendition of a Shoshone girl engraved upon it. The coin was a tribute to Sacagawea but most people hadn't a clue as to who Sacagawea was and the rendition appeared rather uninspired to boot. The coin like the one of Susan B. Anthony bombed.

The Avery 8820 printable business card stock comes as a 120 sheet package suitable for inkjet printers.  These business cards are not the usual 2" x 3-1/2" card stock, however.  This particular version is a folded two-side printable card stock.  This means you can print on up to four sides, thereby conveying much more information.  They could even be used as place cards for meetings, dinners, etc. As with most all Avery products, templates and software for printing on these cards is available on line at the Avery web site.Once printed, the cards separate cleanly by folding along the scored lines.  The cards can then be folded in half for presentation or placement on a table.Having used Avery products before, these folded two-sided printable business cards are up to par with their other products.  These cards are probably not extremely popular, but do fill a particular need quite well.---  Roger Meyer

These lights are very different from the "2 for 5 dollars" solar lights that are perennially on special at the local hardware store. They're heavy duty, made from thick aluminum. They're quite large, about 6 inches in diameter and standing about 15-16 inches above the ground once the stakes are pushed in. They're quite bright, with a warm white (not bluish) light. Two lights are sufficient to light up my 24' sidewalk. The manufacturer did a nice job of matching the paint color with the solar panel on top; as a result, the solar panel doesn't stand out at all, unlike many lights I've seen. The on/off switch is a nice touch. In the "on" position, the lights will come on automatically at night, and turn off (and charge) by day. In the "off" position, the lights won't come on automatically at night.Overall, these lights are as sturdy and put out as much light as the hardwired NightHawk landscaping lights they replaced. The solar Gama Sonic lights are much easier to move around since they have no wires, and I won't have the same problem of mice, squirrels, etc. chewing through the wires.So, they're much sturdier and higher quality than the plastic lights at the hardware store, which have to be replaced every season. And they're as bright as but more flexible than hardwired lights. Based on these comparisons, it might sound like a clear five star product. However, when the lights arrived, I noticed a rattling sound in one of them. When I took apart the fixture, I found a loose screw. I found it's matching hole and tried to put it back in place, but the threads were stripped, which why the screw hand come loose. There were three screws holding this part of the fixture together, so losing one screw shouldn't affect performance, but having a loose screw rattling around in a product that's positioned as a higher end product isn't right. Also, the threading on the poles wasn't well matched. High quality design and heavy duty materials should be matched by high quality manufacturing and quality control. Overall, I would purchase these lights at their current price without hesitation, and feel that I'd received good value for my dollar, but a bit better manufacturing quality control would make for an overall better customer experience out of the box.Bottom line: I almost took off a star for the loose screw, but these lights are so superior in so many ways (heavy metal construction, great light output, warm white light color, on/off switch, large solar panel, pole height, etc.), that I still give them five stars. In terms of appearance and performance, they really are the equivalent of my old wired NightHawk landscape lights, which is not the case with 95% of the solar landscape lights I've encountered.UPDATE Oct 2015, after the lights have been in place through one spring/summer/fall season: I still like these lights a lot. They look good, they're much taller than many other path lights, they're heavy and durable, and they put out many hours of light each night. But the manufacturing quality issues have become an increasing issue. Today I noticed that one of the two lights had started to fill up with water. The water was about to the top of the reflector cone in the bottom of the glass fixture. We've only had a few days of rain in the past few weeks, and not particularly heavy rain. I can't see how the water is getting in (must be a leaky seal around the solar panel), and I can't see any way to drain the water without tipping the unit upside down, which would submerge the electronics, which are in the top of the fixture. I have a feeling the water will continue to accumulate until it reaches the top and kills the light. So, I still really like the design and performance of these lights, but it appears that you can't expect more than a season. I hope they fix the Quality Control issues. For now, I've knocked off a star. If the water issue doesn't get worse and kill the light, I'll leave it at that; if it gets worse, I'll knock off another star or two.

There are a number of places around the house where I need just a little light for a brief time, like when going into the garage to empty the trash, or coming in through the walk-out basement door on the way upstairs. In those cases it often feels wasteful to flip on a light switch that lights up the whole room (garage/basement), especially given that both are lit with fluorescent shop lights, which use a lot of power on start-up and don't like being turned on and off frequently. Also, my hands are often full or filthy. These sensor lights solved the problem. I just plugged one into each wall outlet near the garage and basement doors. They can be pointed right at the door, which in my experience has made the motion sensor wicked sensitive. The light turns on instantly when I open or approach the door, then turns off again about half a minute after I leave the space. The LEDs put out a lot of light for 5w, and the standby motion sensing mode uses minimal power (a fraction of a watt). This is a really slick solution for spaces where you want spot lighting that turns on and off automatically.I previously had bought a couple of very similar looking Mudder brand sensor lights. The Mudder lights are a more intense cool white light (6000K), like a cool white fluorescent, whereas these Bessky lights are a warmer white (2700K), more like an incandescent bulb. Given how I'm using them, I actually prefer the cooler white lights, but these Bessky lights were a quarter the price of the Mudder lights, so I'm more than happy with the warmer white. They did take a few weeks to arrive, having been shipped regular post from China, but for 75% savings over the Prime-eligible lights I ordered earlier I was willing to wait a few weeks.

Adding one of these packets to a liter of water really is like squeezing in a couple of lemon wedges. After years of drinking lemon seltzer water, I'd gotten used to artificial lemon flavor. It was a delight to remember how much better and fresher real lemon tastes, without the hassle and expense of keeping and cutting up actual lemons. We use one packet per SodaStream bottle. True Lemon is significantly cheaper than the lemon/line/orange essences sold by SodaStream, it tastes better, and it's easier to get consistent flavor. We also add True Lemon to regular uncarbonated water. We use two packets per half-gallon jug of water. It provides a beverage that's tastier than plain water but without all the sugar and calories of juices or sodas. This company also sells Lime and Orange packets. We've tried all three flavors and really like them. The lemon and lime flavors are great when mixed, one packet of each in a half gallon of water. This is one of those products that's so good, so simple, and so inexpensive that we actually tell friends about it.

This is an outstanding lighting product. It comes in and out of availability on Amazon, so you may have to check back regularly, or go direct to the site of one of the Marketplace vendors, like Energy Saving Lighting (I've bought from them both direct and via Amazon).This Philips LED light basically allows you to install what looks like a recessed light with diffuser into a location that's wired for a light fixture. It wires direction into the junction box that the light fixture used to be wired into. LEDs are mounted across the disc, and because LEDs are very thin, the whole fixture only sticks out about half an inch from the ceiling. Once installed, it looks like it's a recessed light with a diffuser, even though it's really just a half-inch-thick LED light disc, rather than a recessed light that sticks up into the ceiling.The light is is very even. I can't tell there are individual LEDs mounted on the disc even when I look directly at it. The light is quite bright -- to my eye, it seems to create about the same brightness as a 75-100w light in a recessed can. The light is more directional than a flush-mount fixture, since there's little light cast to the side. The down-light effect works great in the hallway locations where I've installed them.Installation was a breeze. I installed two in our hallway (including removing the old, heavy flush-mount fixtures) in about 20 minutes. To install, you fit a mounting plate onto your junction box, connect three wires (black, white, ground), then push the fixture up onto the mounting plate. The wires and LED driver tuck up into the junction box. The fixture is held onto the mounting plate by a couple of spring steel clips. The fixture is extremely light, so installing is considerably easier than with old-fashioned fixtures.The fixture draws only about 12w and runs significantly cooler than a traditional fixture with a couple of 60w bulbs, so it doesn't need all the layers of insulation that old flush-mount fixtures have. And since it's almost completely flush with the ceiling, it makes our hallway ceilings look higher. Best of all, because it uses so little electricity, I don't have to feel guilty about leaving the hallway lights on, which is nice for both safety and comfort.I initially bought two of these for a downstairs hallway, but have subsequently ordered five more for other locations. I've long wanted to replace the flush mount ceiling light fixtures around our house, but installing recessed lights was too much of a hassle. This light does the same thing without the hassle, and it has the added benefit of using about 80% less electricity. I normally don't get too excited about lighting products, but the engineers at Philips really did come up with a great innovation when they dreamed up this LED fixture.

This hat is a good design (reminds me of the "Flap Happy" hats our young kids used to wear to the beach). You won't get a sunburnt face, ears, or neck. It has good ventilation panels, and the material seems both lightweight and likely to be durable. And the price is great -- less than that of a cheap baseball cap.On the downside, the hat runs quite small, and one size definitely does not fit all. I wear a men's large hat (not an XL), and this hat was painfully tight. My wife wears a much smaller hat size, and this hat was a good to snug fit on her. [Update: I just checked the tag inside the hat and it says S/M, not one-size-fits-most, so the product label is right but the product description on Amazon is not. In fact, it runs on the small side of medium, as the product tag of S/M would indicate.]In terms of quality, the material is good, but there were a couple of missed/broken stitches around the brim of the hat. Those threads will work loose before there time and shorten the life of the hat. Also, the cord and clip that keep the hat from being lost if it blows off were not included. They're clearly shown in the product photo, but they weren't on the hat or in the box. Another customer noted the missing retainer strap, so it doesn't seem like this was a one-time accidental omission.Bottom line: Good design. Quality is not great but is OK, in line with price. Product is not as advertised (missing strap), which may or may not matter to you. But most important of all, the hat runs small, only up to about a men's M. "One size fits most" is always risky, and one-size hats rarely fit XL, but this hat runs particularly small for a one-size hat and is very, very tight if you normally wear even a L.

While watching this movie, I felt the same sense I used to have when watching the original Twilight Zone episodes back in the day. A very good short story (one with unanticipated twists and turns), turned into a simple screen play (one that could be filmed on a handful of simple sets, with not a hint of computer generated imagery), cast with well-known actors playing character roles. Add to that the emotional drama of tortured souls who want the world to be better, and the extra twists and turns allowed by a feature length film, and you have a genuinely captivating movie.Don't get me wrong -- I've enjoyed Transformers, Avengers, etc. But after a decade of computer generated battle scenes, I'd forgotten how much I enjoyed old-fashioned science fiction story telling and stage-style acting. It was a genuine treat.The movie is slower paced than action adventure flicks, especially up front, and there's not a radical new time travel twist here. What you will find is a good story, that follows an arc you probably didn't expect. And you'll feel the angst of the characters, and understand and believe how their loves and turmoils drive the actions that propel the story to its surprising end.I wish the industry were producing more movies like this.

I've had pretty good luck with this Scotts grass seed. Each seed is covered with a coating that provides a bit of starter fertilizer, prevents fungus, and holds a bit of moisture to the seed. It's not a miracle product, meaning you still have to water the new seed regularly, meaning every day. But it is a slightly more forgiving product, meaning that the seeds are more likely to survive if you're half a day late watering, or if you get an unexpectedly warm/sunny day during the sprouting period. The downside of this coating technology is that you only get about half as much actual seed per pound, since half the weight is in the coating. But having used a wide variety of both uncoated and coated seeds over the past 15 years, I'm convinced that my success rate is at least 2x better with these Scotts coated seeds, so I still think they're more efficient in terms of end product. Given my work schedule and the unpredictability of our weather, it's hard for me to keep seeds constantly damp for two weeks, so these coated seeds raise my odds of actually turning seeds into grass, which makes them worth the premium. If you're able to water your newly seeded areas a couple of times a day, regular uncoated seeds may be a better deal for you.In terms of specific mixes, I've had good luck with Scott's Northeast Mix. It filled in thin areas nicely when I used it for overseeding. This is my first season with the Sunny Mix

This is a Tale of Two Products ...First, there is the tale of physical installation, which was a royal pain. The space between the mounting plate and the unit is negligible, so all of the wiring (and I do mean ALL of the wiring) had to be stuffed back into the hole in my wall, the one the doorbell wire was poking through. That was easier said than done, since the hole was just wide enough for the doorbell wire and wouldn't accommodate the crimp-on connectors that came with the SkyBell or the extra wires from the SkyBell. I had to widen the hole, cut off the SkyBell connectors, work up an alternative connection solution, etc., etc. All told, physical installation took a couple hours, most of which involved figuring out workaround solutions, whereas just installing a simple doorbell button is usually a five minute project.Once the physical installation was complete, though, the tale of the second city emerged, and this city is a place of wonder. The SkyBell synced with my home network and my iPhone on the first try. Setup was absolutely seamless and took roughly a minute (maybe two at most). The universal app also loaded onto my iPad and worked perfectly first time. The installation instructions had all kinds of warnings about setting separate SSIDs on dual band routers, making sure my iPhone was on the 2.4 band, etc., but I just went ahead and started the sync without making any of those adjustments and it worked flawlessly on the first try. Maybe I got lucky, or maybe SkyBell has worked out some of the kinks reported by earlier users.In use, the SkyBell has exceeded my expectations, which is highly unusual for early generation home automation products. When someone rings the doorbell, the SkyBell rings the physical chime on the wall, and with only about a half-second delay it rings a doorbell sound on my iPhone. Establishing the video connection is fast and simple, and the two-way voice connection works great. The camera is very wide angle, and I can see all the way to bottom of my very long driveway, about 100-120 feet away. When the FedEx guy came this morning, the motion sensor "rang" the doorbell on my iPhone to let me know someone was there (which allowed me to get the package before it got soaked in the rain). And starting up a video feed on demand (without someone pressing the button or triggering the motion sensor ... basically using the SkyBell like a web cam) works great. In a nutshell, every feature of the SkyBell is working as advertised and better than I expected.I haven't used the SkyBell remotely yet (e.g., answering my home doorbell while at work, over an internet connection rather than being on the house wifi), so I can't evaluate that functionality. I'll post an update if I run into any issues.After I had read the installation instructions but before I started the installation, I had some questions about the wiring, since I wasn't sure whether my indoor doorbell chime would be compatible with the SkyBell. I submitted a question to SkyBell customer service via their website and received an answer very quickly (within an hour or so, as I recall). We exchanged a few more emails in rapid succession, and they answered my questions. Two thumbs up for quick and clear customer support.Bottom line:  I wish SkyBell had some old-fashioned home hardware folks on the team, since someone with experience in that market could improve the physical hardware design pretty easily (e.g., by designing in space to stuff the extra wire, as with any electrical fixture). But those are minor annoyances. The important parts of the product -- the camera, the app, two-way audio, the motion sensor functionality, the integration with the physical indoor chime -- work perfectly for me. Skybell has brought another dumb part of my house (the doorbell), into the wired age. Now I know who's at the door before I open it, I can hear the doorbell anywhere in the house (or yard), I can answer the door (at least virtually) when I'm traveling, I know when someone (e.g., FedEx, oil delivery, neighbor) stops by even if I'm not there, I can take a snapshot of whoever is at the door.I absolutely love this product. Sometimes I wait for later versions of a product. But the SkyBell v2.0 offers so much value right now that I'm really glad I bought it today. I may swap it out in a few years, just like I upgrade my phone every few years, but I'll absolutely get my money's worth during that time. This product is insanely cool and genuinely valuable.[And now a few suggestions for the SkyBell engineers, in case you read the Amazon reviews of your product:1) To avoid "ringing" the app every time someone walks past the doorbell, you've built a timer into the software, so the SkyBell only sends a notification if someone is in front of the SkyBell for 10 seconds. I wish the delay were a user-adjustable parameter. We live in a very quiet area, so it's rare for people to wander by, so the 10-second delay isn't really needed. And our UPS driver drops and goes so fast that the SkyBell doesn't register him, since he's in and out in under 10 seconds. I'd like to be able to adjust the delay to suit my needs.2) Since installing the SkyBell, there seems to be a consistent faint hum from my wall-mounted doorbell chime. It seems that the SkyBell must keep the circuit always closed, with the resulting hum. It's very faint, and no big deal; I just thought this feedback from the field my be useful to your engineers as you refine the product.3) Please add space inside the case, between the SkyBell and the mounting plate, for a bit of excess wire. See above. It would make installation easier for more homeowners.4) You know that ridiculously tiny set screw that needs to be screwed in to secure the unit as the last step of installation? Well, it's ridiculously tiny. It would be fine if this were a consumer electronics product. But that screw has to be installed outside, in the sun and wind, over a driveway or porch or grass. It's hard to get into place (it wasn't pre-installed, as the instructions said, but rather loose in the parts bag), easy to drop, and impossible to find if you do drop it. Need a better solution on v3.0.]

Like most of the other reviewers, I received a free Workshop WS0610VA for review. Until I received this new unit, I was still using the hold ShopVac I bought with my first house, close to thirty years ago. The old ShopVac was still running, so I never thought seriously about replacing it. Having now seen how much wet/dry shop vacuums have improved over the past three decades, I regret not having replaced the old warhorse sooner.Positives of the WORKSHOP WS0610VA:+ Good size for home shop use. About half the size of my old ShopVac, which is optimal for home use.+ Good ergonomics. Wide base relative to height, so it doesn't tip easily. Casters glide well. Top mounted handle is very convenient. Ability to store tools on the unit (they slide into fittings on top of the caster feet) is great -- I wouldn't store the tools there while the vacuum is in use, but it's very convenient to be able to store everything together when I put the vacuum away.+ Cord length is good for home use. My old vac had a super long hose, which I actually found unwieldy. 10' is right for my workshop.+ It's still loud, but a bit quieter than my old shop vac (which sounded like an old 727 at takeoff).+ The pleated filter plus filter bag do a very good job of filtration. When collecting fine particulates (like plaster dust) I like being able to just pull out the bag, rather than dumping the bin into the trash and creating a secondary dust cloud. On an open job site, it would be different. But for home use, the bag is a real plus.+ The hose is large diameter, like my old vac.+ The attachment clips are more secure than my old vac (which used friction-only connections, which came loose at all the wrong times).Shortfalls:- You need to buy a separate filter if you plan to suck up more than a minimal amount of water. The wet filter should be included if this is marketed as a wet/dry vac ... and even if it isn't, since everyone expects a shop vac to work for dry or wet.- The unit comes with the bare minimum of tools -- just the extension wand and one floor nozzle. At a minimum, it should come with a brush attachment.Bottom line: I'm very pleased with the WORKSHOP WS0610VA as a home shop vac. It's a good design and the right size for a small home shop like mine, with excellent filtration options for both sawdust and finer particles like plaster dust. It does not come with what should be standard equipment, like a wet filter and a brush attachment.

I hate sunscreen. It seems that there's the choice between greasy and sticky, and I hate the feel of both. Also, the smell of many sunscreen lotions is like a coconut supernova. I wear a wide-brimmed hat and a long-sleeved fishing shirt outdoors so that I don't have to wear sunscreen. Having said that, there are times when it's not practical to stay covered up, and in those situations I'm grateful to Neutrogena for creating this product. It's a sport formulation, so it provides lasting protection, but it's a nice creamy lotion that doesn't feel greasy or sticky. It works into the skin like a simple moisturizing lotion. I'm not sure how they did it, but it works and feels great. Also, the fragrance is very mild and doesn't scream "I'm covered in sunscreen here!" Last, but certainly not least, it hasn't caused any skin reactions. Hands down, this is the best feeling, least smelly, easiest on my skin sunscreen I've found in the past thirty years. Great product.

This is a good light-duty backpack.  It has enough room for a good four-inch stack of homework or business work, a single padded laptop slot that handles my 13" Lenovo with room to spare, and three separate areas for chargers, gadgets, etc.  Like all Targus packs, the space is well thought through for handling the stuff you're likely to carry for school or business.  The material is heavy duty, the stitching is even, the zippers are good quality, and overall construction is what I'd expect from Targus.On the downside, the straps are thinner and not as well padded as on my preferred backpacks.  And the back, while padded, doesn't have a mesh cover of the type that's become fairly standard on more expensive packs.  The combination of these two factors means that I wouldn't use this backpack every day for carrying heavier loads or for longer durations.  Also, the pack has just one device slot, for a laptop -- a second padded area for a tablet would have been nice.  The storm flap around the zipper is a nice touch if you'll be walking in the rain, but it also makes it more cumbersome to zip the pack open and shut in everyday use.  One upside of the lighter construction is that the pack is quite lightweight.The bottom line is that this case offers good value and quality for it's price.  In fact, a bit more quality than I expected at this price.  But I wouldn't use it to carry heavy loads for long periods on a daily basis.  It's destined to become my "side trip" pack -- something to use when I want a light pack to carry some but not all of the stuff in my regular pack (e.g., for weekend trips).

I have a Timex Expedition watch that needs a new battery.  The shop in the mall wanted $15 to replace the battery.  I bought this watch opener so that I could replace the battery myself from now on.  Unfortunately, the blade is too thick and will not get under the edge of the back plate on the watch.  I tried multiple times over the course of a week, and all I succeeded in doing was scratching the back of the watch.  This knife may work for some watches, but not for my Timex Expedition.

I've always thought that exercise tights were way too expensive, so I thought I'd give this pair a try.  They ended up being uncomfortably small with a waist that rode too low.  I found the waistband to be uncomfortable.  After wearing these a couple of times, I bought a pair of ASICS Men's PR Tights, which I found to be much more comfortable.  The ASICS were also more expensive, although not outrageous.  If you just need a pair of cheap tights for occasional use, and have very short legs and a low rise, these might do it for you.  It was worth trying these tights, to see whether the super-cheap alternative would work, but I've retired them.  Two stars for quality and comfort, but three stars for value due to their very low price.

I put this bag through its paces during a week of cycling in Maine then another week along the seashore in southern New England.  The bag exceeded expectations.  It's not fancy, and didn't win me any points for being the coolest bit of biking gear.  But it's very well designed and offers great functionality and value at a low price compared to what was available in the local bike store.  Specifically:+ The size is perfect for day trips when the weather is changeable.  I stuffed in a rain jacket, rain pants, an extra jersey, and an extra pair of shorts in the main compartment.  The side compartments held stuff I bought along the way, and the velcro-sealed pouch on the end held my good-sized first aid kit.+ The shape really works.  The rounded ends are very smart.  One tucks under the seat (I'm short, and I don't have as much seat post showing as in their product picture), and the sloped back end provides just a bit extra clearance when swinging my leg over the back of the bike.+ It installed easily, with two big velcro straps on the bottom.+ The bag washed off nicely with a hose after it got caked in mud during one particularly fun ride.Well designed, and a super value at a modest price compared to many bike bags.  Very happy with how the bag performed during weeks of hard riding in rough conditions this summer.

Given how often we lose power, and how long it stays out, we have lot's of solar powered lights.  For durability, functionality, speed of charging, and hours of light, my favorites are the lantern and task light from d.light.  However, the d.light products are rigid, so although they're great for home use, they're not so good for travel.  That's where this Hallomall solar light really shines.  The Hallomall light is basically a cylindrical beach ball with a solar panel, battery, and LEDs embedded in the disk at one end.  When filled with air it's about the size of two rolls of duct tape stacked one atop the other.  When deflated, though, it's only about half an inch thick.  At just 3.4 ounces, it's also feather light compared to most alternatives.The light is surprisingly bright.  On the dim setting, it easily lit a 20x30 foot space enough that we could move around and work.  On the bright setting, it pumped out enough light that several of us could read at the same time.  In other words, its coverage area and intensity are quite impressive.  I can't attest to how many hours of light it puts out, since I haven't run it all the way down before recharging.The vinyl seems to be pretty thick, so I'm optimistic that this product will hold up well.  Time will tell.  There are vinyl grab straps fused to both faces, presumably so that you can hang it on the outside of your backpack and charge while hiking.  I'm not sure I'd trust the vinyl straps in rough conditions.This product seems to be a knock-off of the Luci solar light.  I like to reward innovators, but in this case I bought the knock off since it seemed to offer better features/functionality in several areas:1) The vinyl is stamped with a prismatic pattern that does a very good job of diffracting and smoothing the light from the LEDs without decreasing brightness.  Reminds me of the lenses in old New England lighthouses.2) The rated lumens are higher (80 vs 65 at the time I bought).3) The Hallomall base product includes high, low, and flashing settings.  With Luci, you have to buy a different (more expensive) model to get flashing.A number of reviewers have commented on the inflation nozzle.  It's the same as on kids toys or air mattresses.  It has a flap to prevent air from blowing back out when you're not blowing in, so you have to pinch the nozzle when blowing in (to open the flap).  I didn't have to puncture anything the first time.  Even easier, if you just pinch the nozzle and gently pull the two ends apart (like an accordion), the lantern will self inflate 90% of the way, which keeps the moisture from your breath out of the cylinder.My primary use for this product isn't backpacking or camping, it's traveling to countries where there are frequent power outages.  During a business trip to India, we lost power four or five times a day.  The conference room we were meeting in had no windows, so it went pitch black during the outages.  In settings like that, having this little three-ounce wonder in the briefcase is really handy.Bottom Line: This product is worth every penny of the fifteen bucks I spent on it.  I plan to buy a few more to give to family and colleagues.  Seriously, every house should have one for emergencies, and every international traveler should stuff one in the travel pack.

(Note: This review is a transcription of an interview with my eight-year old niece, who is the primary user of the seat.  She's also the one who set the rating, at four stars.)  (Second Note: I received this seat for free through Amazon's Vine program so that I could review it.  I liked it enough that I just ordered and paid for a second seat to give to a relative.)"I like this seat because you can move it around.  It isn't heavy like my other booster seat so I don't have to lug it around.  It feels like I'm not in a booster seat because it isn't on my back like some seats that come up over your back and near your head.  It's like I don't even have a booster seat.""I really liked how it worked because it wasn't hard to use.  You don't have to do a lot of things.  With my other booster seat you have to do more stuff.  With this one you just have to put it down basically."  [Editor's Note: You also have to fasten the side clips around the seat belt for proper installation, but it's a very simple task given the seat design.]"It's comfortable."And now, in my own words:  This is a good seat for aunts, uncles, and others who intermittently transport younger relatives who aren't quite big enough to ride safely with just the regular car belts.  It's much lighter weight than most full booster seats, so it's easy to move around; it's very low profile, so it's easy to store; and it's simple and easy to install, so you can pop it in place quickly when needed.  Importantly, this is a minimalist seat, for older youngsters who are just under the height limit and need a "positioning" seat for safety but don't need a full "booster" seat.  For youngsters in this range (and for the aunts and uncles who occasionally drive them), this is a convenient solution.  If you have a younger/smaller child, want more "lift", and plan to leave the seat permanently installed, you may prefer a more traditional booster seat, but for our needs this is a very good solution.

This is a good niche product for specialized situations when you need a ruggedized (water and impact resistant) auxiliary battery.  The case is rugged rubber.  It adds a good deal of shock absorption in case of drops.  It also adds a bit of thickness relative to other 6000 mAh batteries, but surprisingly not a lot of weight.  The input and output ports are sealed with rubber flaps.  I don't know that they would protect the battery if it were totally immersed in water, but they're more than sufficient to seal the ports if you get caught in a downpour.The battery charges quickly with a standard iPad (2.1 amp) charger.  I had less luck charging the battery with backpacking style solar panels.  The battery comes with about a 50% charge.  I tried hooking it up to a Nomad 7 solar panel (two panels) and an Instapark Mercury 10 panel (3 panel).  Both panels connected fine and caused the battery to show that it was charging (the next LED, for 75% charge, started blinking).  But neither panel was able to bump the battery charge indicator up to the next level.  On the days of my tests, it was sunny but with big puffy clouds, so the sunshine came and went.  I wonder whether this battery is like an iPad, which requires a more constant input from its charging source, without cloud interruptions.When it comes to dumping power back into phones and tablets, the NOCO battery performs well.  It charged my iPhone 5s from 45% to 95% in an hour and five minutes.  It took another half hour to punch it up from 95% to 100%, but that's fairly standard and mimics charge time with a wall charger.  Charging my iPhone 5s from 45% to 95% didn't appreciably drain the XGB6 -- it was still showing 100% charged after filling the iPhone, which supports the product claim of being able to charge a smartphone several times.The 6000mAh capacity of the battery is not quite sufficient to deliver a full charge to my iPad Air, but it does fill it up enough to get a good day's work done.The built-in LED "glow light" is a nice touch.  It won't throw a beam down a dark trail, but it is more than sufficient to find things in a tent or in a car.The battery instructions are a bit quirky (I don't understand why they designed the battery so that it has to be "turned on" with a power switch before charging a device).  It's worth trying the battery when you first get it, rather than trying to figure it out in the dark woods or in an emergency.The battery is pretty expensive for a 6000 mAh external battery.  If you don't need the ruggedized, water resistant case, you can get smaller, cheaper batteries with higher capacities.  This battery is really designed for specialized applications where the battery will receive rough treatment or be subjected to wet weather.  Unless your phone/tablet are also in ruggedized, water resistant cases, having a rugged battery may not make much sense.Bottom Line:  Good solid battery for specialized situations where you need a rugged battery.  Didn't play well with my backpacking solar panels, but otherwise performed admirably.  Expensive if you don't need the ruggedness.  Four stars.

I'm a big fan of OXO products, and for years their 4" paring knife has been one of my most heavily used kitchen knives, so I was eager to try this 6" utility knife (disclosure: I received the knife at no cost for evaluation).  The 6" utility knife has the signature OXO design, meaning there's a heavy emphasis on ergonomics.  The handle is very comfortably contoured, and it's covered in a rubber-like sheath that provides an extremely secure grip.  The metal between the handle and blade is shaped to protect your hand from the blade.  The design emphasizes safety and comfort -- little risk of this knife slipping, even when wet.The knife is heavier than I expected for a utility knife, weighing in at a bit over 4 ounces.  The blade is thicker and stiffer than I expected from a utility knife -- in use, it almost feels more like a narrow-bladed chef's knife than a typical thin blade utility knife.  For me, this is a positive, but if you're used to an Asian style flexible blade, this knife will seem heavy and stiff.  Like I said, it almost has more of the feel of a French knife.The blade is no-stain, but takes an edge.  Like my other OXO knife, I expect this knife to be in the sweet spot -- a little harder to put an edge on, since it's harder steel, but also requiring sharpening less often, since it's harder steel.  A very good balance for my use.The reason for four instead of five stars is the packaging.  The plastic packaging is the opposite of frustration free.  It was one of the harder plastic clamshell cases I've dealt with in quite a while, and I really feared I was going to slice my fingers trying to get it open.  It may seem harsh to subtract a star for packaging, but the whole point of OXO is comfort and safety, and I wouldn't give the product in this package to my elderly parents.Bottom line:  Excellent, sturdy, durable knife designed for comfort and safety ... but in a package that's the antithesis of the wonderful knife.  OXO needs to apply their outstanding principles of product design to their package design.

Used these this weekend to help my eldest child move into a new apartment.  We had to lash mattresses to the top of my RAV4.  The straps are long enough to wrap around two twin mattresses and the roof rack easily.  The spring-loaded latch made it very easy to cinch the straps very tight, and equally easy to unfasten when we arrived.  Much, much faster than trying to tie the mattress down with rope.  Nothing shifted during our ride.  Every car should have a pair of these straps in the trunk.  Beats having a knot slip and watching the mattress fly loose on the highway.The straps that came with my Thule kayak carriers have fancy rubber covers over the metal buckles.  These straps don't (and they're also much cheaper), so when positioning make sure to keep the metal buckle up away from the car's finish.

I've tried a number of sensor systems for monitoring my household environment (temperature, humidity, and water leaks) when I'm gone for extended periods.  I haven't found any perfect system, but the Wally system is definitely the best I've found.  After several months of use, I've found ways to work around the system's shortcomings and it's become my default system for home environment monitoring.[Important Update: In my initial review, which was posted after a month or two of use, I noted that I was having trouble making reliable connections.  I think I found out why.  I had some repair work done in the basement shortly after setting up the Wally system.  Apparently the electrician unplugged the Wally hub from the "dumb" extension strip and plugged it into a power strip that has a surge suppressor.  I just noticed this yesterday.  Since the hub was taken off the surge suppressor and plugged into a regular extension cord, the performance has been close to flawless.  The sensors still have to be "near" house wiring, but "near" can be several paces away from any obvious outlets.  This is a huge improvement, and I'm raising my rating from to five stars.  The Wally manual says to avoid plugging the hub into a power strip with surge suppression, and they mean it.  Now, back to the original review ...]Strengths:+ Exceptional battery life.  Most other sensors either have to be plugged in or chew through batteries.  My Quirky+GE Spotter sensor, for example, chews through batteries, and the Spotter is designed to turn off half the sensor functions unless it's plugged into an A/C adapter.+ Design.  The sensors are very small (about the size of a credit card and about as thick as my iPhone) and have a nice, unobtrusive shape.  They can be tucked away almost anywhere.+ Setup.  Adding a sensor via the web interface or iPhone app is trivially simple, as long as the sensor can get can communicate with the hub.+ Accuracy.  The readings match well with my regular thermometer and hygrometer.+ Interface.  The sensors feed data to both an app and also to a web site that can be accessed with any browser.  The web page and app both have a very clean, intuitive, easy-to-use interface.  Also, very importantly, Wally is clearly investing continuously in the web dashboard and app.  They have pushed several updates to the app, and the latest web site design is outstanding.+ Connectedness.  Alerts are easy to customize and can be sent to smartphone or email.  Most leak sensors just sound a buzzer on the device if they they detect water, which doesn't do any good if you're not home.  Others work only with a dedicated app or send text messages to only one phone.  Wally wins for flexibility; it pushes alerts and email notices, and you can pull status information from any browser on any device.+ Intelligence.  The website/app don't just display current readings, they also store a year's worth of history, so you can track conditions over time in problem locations (e.g., to see what times of year a basement space is prone to high humidity).+ The conditions that trigger an alert (e.g., high and low boundaries for humidity) can be customized for each sensor, and the system pushes three types of alerts (email, alert notifications via the smartphone app, and alert badges on the monitoring dashboard) when conditions go outside the bounds you set.  Very customizable to avoid false alarms, and the redundant alerts raise the odds you'll know about a real problem quickly.+ You can add sensors and they all report through the common dashboard and app.Weaknesses:- Wally's "special sauce" is that it sends signals through house wires, rather than having to maintain a high-powered wifi connection (which is how the sensors get such great battery life).  My guess is that whether you are satisfied or not with this system will depend on whether you need to put a sensor in a specific location that doesn't have any house wires nearby.  [As mentioned in the update, my "problem locations" are all now communicating with the hub just fine, once I plugged the Wally hub directly into a dumb extension cord rather than into a power strip with a surge suppressor.]- Part of Wally's value proposition is that it doesn't just measure and display your temperature, humidity, etc., it also analyzes the data.  For example, they say they'll send me a message if conditions in my home suggest I might have a problem with mold, and will even suggest contractors who might help.  That could be helpful, but I'm guessing this is also part of their model for making money.  I wish they would give me control over my data and what stays strictly private.[UPDATE Summer 2014:  We were away for a week, visiting the parents.  While we were away, I started receiving alerts from the Wally sensors, saying that the temperature and humidity were above their ranges.  I thought the system was glitching, since this was my first summer after installing the sensors.  When we got home, we found that a mouse had gotten into the air conditioner, chewed on the wires, and shorted out the system.  We got home late Friday afternoon and weren't able to get repair service until Monday, and it was a very hot and humid weekend.  If I'd believed the Wally sensors, I could have called the repair guy from my folks' house and had the system up and running again before we got home.  I should have trusted the sensor system.][UPDATE Spring 2015:  The Wally sensor system just paid for itself!  We had just left for a weekend getaway when I received an alert on my phone, saying that a Wally sensor in the basement near the water tank had detected a water leak.  I had never received a false leak alert, so I turned the car around and headed back home to check.  Sure enough, there was a fresh and growing puddle on the basement floor.
